description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Ahl, nelle sorti umane, Handel; Music at the Court of Henry VIII and Elizabeth I.

title: Arizona Businessman Dominates Start of Bolles Trial
description: PHOENIX, Sept. 2More than 14 months after a bomb killed Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic, wealthy land developer and a downonhisluck plumber went on trial today for his murder.

title: William J. Norton, 79, ExChairman Of Douglass Philosophy Department
description: William J. Norton, farmer chairman of the philosophy department at Douglass College, died at his Metuchen, N.J., home on Thursday. He was 79 years old.

title: The Standings
description: Saturday, September 3, 1977

title: 3 Monkeys Taken (Tranquilized) From Apartment to A.S.P.C.A. Shelter
description: Three screeching monkeys scrambling around in garbagestrewn cages were shot with tranquilizer darts and taken into protective custody yesterday by authorities who broke into an unoccupied East Side apartment after neighbors complained of foul odors.

title: Victory String of Rutgers Is Dashed by Penn State
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.,Sept. 2The 18game football winning streak of Rutgers came to an end tonight, and the Scarlet Knights were humiliated in the process, as Penn State whipped the ambitious New Jersey team, 457, at Giants Stadium.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error in The Times yesterday, ovedrafts by Mrs. Bert Lance of $110,000 at the Calhoun First National Bank were attributed to Mr. Lance.

title: Action by Higher Court Is Urged in Berkowitz Case
description: The chief administrative judge of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn said yesterday that he would welcome intervention by a higher court to settle a dispute among three of the city's district attorneys before it led to multiple competency hearings for David R. Berkowitz, the man accused of being the .44caliber killer.

title: Oh, Aaron Are Still Tied
description: TOKYO, Sept. 2 (AP)Sadaharu Oh failed to hit a home run tonight as the Yomiuri Giants lost to the Yakult Swallows, 31. A crowd, of 50,000 turned out hoping to see Oh, who had tied Hank Aarons United States major league record of 755 homers Wednesday night, circle the bases for the 756th time. The Giants first baseman collected one hit, a double, in four plate appearances. Oh also grounded to the pitcher and walked twice.

title: World Coffee Output Estimated To Be 69.9 Million Bags for 77
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI)The Agriculture Department today estimated 1977 world coffee production at 69.9 million bags, slightly below an earlier forecast but still well above the small 1976 crop, which sent prices skyrocketing to records earlier this year.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5

title: Families of MIA's Move To Challenge Law Used To Declare Them Dead
description: The families of 21 servicemen listed as missing in action in Southeast Asia asked a Federal court yesterday to declare that a law used by Government officials to declare missing as dead is unconstitutional.

title: Priest and Penitent: Legal Challenges May Alter Ancient Tradition of Confidentiality
description: The traditional right of religious leaders to withhold confidential information from courts of law is facing new tests that could extend the concept. Some religious figures are calling for a revised definition of the priestandpenitent safeguard to cover a variety of situations in which the clergyman, in the conduct of his mumstry becoanes privy to the inner workings of activist groups. Others are seeking to promote an interpretation of the guarantees of freedom of religion of the First Amendment to protect members of religious groups from testifying against one another if the welfare of the group is involved.

title: GEORGE GINGELL
description: COLUMBUS, Ga.,Sept. 2 (AP)George Gingell, general manager of station WRBLTV and radio, died in St. Francis Hospital yesterday. He was admitted to the hospital on Tuesday after suffering a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: Some Looting at U.S. Fire in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2Ambassador Malcolm Toon conceded today that some looting occurred when Soviet firemen quelled a fire that ravaged the normally restricted upper floors of the United States Embassy here a week ago.

title: STOCKS UP A 3D DAY AS DOW GAINS BY 7.45
description: The stock market scored its third consecutive advance yesterday in slow trading despite some adverse economic news. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, finished ahead 7.45 points to 872;31. its high for the day.

title: Background to Bhutto's Arrest
description: The prospect of official sanctions against former Prime Minister Bhutto and his Pakistan People's Party arose as early as midAugust just two weeks after he was released from the protective custody that was imposed by the military on leaders of the country's warring political forces on July 5.

title: Monmouth
description: FIRST$7,500, cl., 2Y0 6r.

title: Malaysia, Spurred by U.S., Letting In Indochinese
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31President Carter's decision last month to admit 15,000 more refugees from Indochina has already produced one important result, American diplomats report: Malaysia, where most of the Vietnamese fleeing in fishing boats run ashore, no longer pushes them back out to sea, as it frequently did.

title: U.S. BANKERS LOBBY CRITICAL OF LANCE
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 2 (AP)  The American Bankers Association said today that Budget Director Bert Lance's history of overdrawn checking accounts cannot be considered normal banking practice and expressed fear that the controversy would damage the image of bankers.

title: I've Got Hugh Under My Skin
description: A guide to the forthcoming New York City primary election, composed after four months of wondering what in the world the Yankees are up to and why those politicians keep interfering with the view:

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Stay of Execution Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI)Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court today stayed the execution of Edward Lincoln King, who was sentenced to die Sep. 13 for the murder of a Dallas policeman. The stay will be good until the high court acts on Mr. King's appeal from decision last May 11 by the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals upholding the conviction.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dismissal notices were put in the mail to a third of Clifton's 140member police force in connection with a dispute over a contract promise and a 5 percent budget restriction. The city manager, William Holster, said the dismissal of 49 officers would take effect Oct. 15 unless the dispute were resolved. State regulations require 45days notice to dismiss Civil Service employees.

title: 5Hitter for Zachry
description: Well, boys, the Mets were eliminated from the pennant race last night on the respectably lateor embarrassingly earlydate of Sept. 2, depending on how you look at it.

title: Rights Campaign in Rumania Wilts After a Vigorous and Bold Start
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 2The Rumanian human  rights movement, which began this year with an optimism and vigor unusual in this country, appears to have been crushed.

title: Primary Roundup
description: The deathpenalty issue, already a major point of contention in the Democratic primary for Mayor, caused yet another skirmish yesterday as the race entered its final week.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY. SEPTEMBER 3, 1977

title: 11 CANDIDATES VYING TO BE DETROIT MAYOR
description: DETROIT. Sept. 1For a city that was said to be steadily going down the tubes this time a year ago, there are certainly a lot of people interested today in running it.

title: In Memoriam
description: ALPERTDavid J, it's been 7 years. Times has not made it easler. W? miss You.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONSuper slurpers, the materials that will absorb several thousands of times their weight in water, can be made from flour. A patent for the process was granted this week to George F. Fanta and William M. Doane of the Agriculture Department's Agricultural Research Service in Peoria. I??.

title: World News Briefs
description: UDINE, Italy, Sept. 2 (Reuters;A scandal over alleged misuse of public funds for the earthquake relief in the Friuli region broadened today with the announcement of the arrests of the former mayor of a village in the area and his son.

title: Victor Knauth Dies; Newsman, Publisher And Station Owner
description: Victor W. Knauth, former correspondent for The United Press, a publisher and radio executive, died yesterday in his home at 165 Drum Hill Road, Wilton Conn., after a long illness. His age was 82.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Muggers Pick on Magician and Are Taught a Trick or Two
description: Tony Echavarria, a street magician who wallows fire and makes coins vanish, turned, up in Criminal Court yesterday and tbld how he turned a silk scarfpoof!into a cane and dazzled three alleged muggers in Times Square until the police arrived.

title: Sander Upset by Bond In Amateur on 21st Hole
description: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., Sept. 2 (AP)Tim Bond, an Aberdeen, Wash., schoolteacher, upset the defending champion, BM Sander of Kenmore, Wash., today in the third round of the 77th United States Amateur golf championship.

title: About Newyork
description: The merchants of Third Avenue in East Harlem are led by Morris Wittenberg, who more often refers to himself as Morris Toyland. They are one and the same after 30 years of retailing in the neighborhoodthe man is the store. Indeed, both were devastated the night of the July 13 blackout when the looters came.

title: The Latest Entertainment Trend: Charter a Yacht for Four Hours
description: The 100foot diesel vessel Cabaret was carrying what could have been a humdrum cargo as she plied the East River one recent evening: shrimp and meat. But the meat was all filet mignon, and the big shrimp were on parsleygarnished hors d'oeuvre trays offered by butlers to a deckful of realestate and banking executives.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: AL FRESCO TEAMS Contrasting concerts may be heard this weekend in Queens and Nassau, by those interested in hearing outdoor music without going to a concert hall. One program in Queens tomorrow is a presentation of early Dutch music by the Nieuw Nederlande Consort, a group of young people who are gaining a reputation for their carefully researched musicales. Today is the first of the fall series of popular music concerts presented in conjunction with activities at the Belmont Park Race Track. Glen Campbell is the attraction today, and Ray Charles and his orchestra Monday.

title: Guard Allegedly Shoots Relief Client in Argument At a Center in Manhattan
description: A security guard at the Dyckman Welfare. Center was accused yesterday of critically wounding a welfare client during an argument at the center.

title: Stock Driver Killed
description: PLUMSTED TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept, 2 (AP)A 38yearold stock car driver, Jack Ely, of Manasquan, N.J., died in an accident during a race at New Egypt Speedway last night. His car ran onto the infield and struck a wall.

title: Council Panel Votes Out Measure To Limit Rent Rises to 7.5% a Year
description: A bill that would roll back laborcost Passalongs to tenants in more than 500,000 rentcontrolled apartments and limit the total rent increase to 7.5 percent a year was voted out yesterday by the city Council's General Welfare Committee. The vote was 6 to 0.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY. SEPTEMBER 3, 1977

title: Economy Brightens In Britain as Vote On Pay Plan Nears
description: LONDON, Sept. 2Two more batches of favorable economic news arrived today, giving the Government additional credibility just before its restrictive pay policy comes to a vole of sharply divided labor leaders next week.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Drop in Weekly Sale
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned yesterday in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Warsaw Airport to Close Briefly
description: WARSAW, Sept. 2 (AP)Warsaw's airport will be closed to all traffic Sept. 2529 so runways can be repaired, the Polish airline LOT announced today. The announcement said the airports at Gdansk, Poznan and Cracow would remain in service.

title: BLACKS BEAR BRUNT OF JOBLESS RATE RISE TO 7.1% FOR AUGUST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The Labor Department reported today that the unemployment rate rose twotenths of a percentage point in August, to 7.1 percent of the work force, and said that the increase reflected almost exclusively higher unemployment among black workers.

title: LI. Boaters Warned On Disaster Band Use
description: The head of the Coast Guard station at Eaton Neck, LI said yesterday that boaters were making improper use of the radio distress frequencies and that their actions could endanger many lives during the Labor Day weekend, which is expected to attract thousands of boating enthusiasts to open waters.

title: Forecast Brightens to Normal for Holiday
description: New Yorkers, who have survived a summer of record high temperatures, which followed a winter of equally discomforting cold, began taking to the beaches, parks and resorts yesterday for a Labor Day weekend that the National Weather Service said would be plain old normal.

title: Connor Sailing Victor
description: KIEL, West Germany, Sept. 2 (AP)Dennis Connor of San Diego, Calif., won his fifth straight event in Star Class sailing today in the final run of the sixday Kiel regatta. He became the world champion yesterday after his fourth victory in five days.

title: George Adams, Tenor Saxophonist, Improvises With Brilliance
description: Studio Rivbea, the Bond Street jazz loft which abruptly canceled its traditional summer festival early in July because of competition from newer lofts and other factors, was back in business this week. The belated summer festival concludes tonight and tomorrow night with performances by Sam Rivers, the Studio's founder and a formidable tenor saxophonist.

title: Ashe Is Back at Forest Hills With a Wife but Without a Racquet
description: It's no surprise to hear the name Ashe in connection with the United States Open, but this year there are two Ashes at Forest Hillsand neither of them is swinging a tennis racquet.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesFreddle Gonzalez, 115 pounds, knocked out Santo Nunez, 114, Mitchocan, Mexico, 7 rounds; Gonzalo Montellano, 135, Bakersfield, Callf., knocked out Ti?er Noji, 137, Hiroshima, Japan, 5.

title: Baltimore Official Decries Stadium Leases of Teams
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 (AP)Baltimore's Memorial Stadium registered operating losses of $730,894 last year, which was $86,371 more than the previous year's losses, according to a city auditor's report.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8

title: Idaho Takeover Law Ruled Illegal
description: In a decision expected to have farreac?ing consequences for corporate takeovers, a Federal judge ruled in Dallas yesterday that the Idaho takeover lawused as a delay tacticviolated both Federal law and the United States Constitution.

title: WIDER LANDING RIGHTS FOR CONCORDE HINTED_
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The Carter Administration is weighing the possibility of giving the Concorde supersonic airliner landing rights at 10 cities in addition to New York and Washington despite the controversy surrounding the noise of the craft, Government sources said today.

title: United Merchants, in Bankruptcy, Offers Its Creditors 44c on Dollar
description: In its first formal offer to creditors, United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., has reportedly proposed a cash payment of 44 cents on each dollar of debt upon release from the Chapter XI bankruptcy status that it entered on July 12.

title: U.S. and Canada Agree on a Plan For Gas Pipeline
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 2Negotiators for Canada and the United States reached an agreement in principle tonight on conditions for the construction of a multibilliondollar pipeline to carry Alaskan natural gas to the lower 48 states through Canadian territory, but the final decision rests with President Carter.

title: Storm Skirts Texas, Strikes Mexico
description: SOTO LA MARINA, Mexico,Sept 2. (AP)The first hurricane of the season struck the northeastern Mexican coast today after having first headed toward Texas areas more than 150 miles to the north.

title: Batsman Up! Yes, It's Cricket Today In AllStar Game in Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 2Was that really Sir Garfield Sobers chasing a cricket ball across the artificial turf of Giants Stadium here in the Meadowlands this morning? And was that indeed Everton Weekes who had cracked out the small, redleather ball with his gleaming bat?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error in The Times yesterday, ovedrafts by Mrs. Bert Lance of $110,000 at the Calhoun First National Bank were attributed to Mr. Lance.

title: Letters;
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians View American Fashions With Translatable Delight
description: A long, drawn out oh or ah means the same thing in Russian as it does in English. And four guests of honor viewing a fashion show at Jerry Silverman the other day used both words often, sometimes punctuating the expressions with delighted hand clapping.

title: Nastase and Smith Defeated in Forest Hills Upsets
description: Ilie Nastase won't have the United States Open to kick around anymore. The temperamental Rumanian, seeded No. 7 in singles, was ousted in the second round of the tennis championships yesterday by Corrado Barazzutti of Italy, 64, 64, and then dropped out of the doubles shortly afterward.

title: Units of Dictaphone And G.E. Go South
description: Two large companiesthe General Electric Company and the Dictaphone Corporationyesterday announced shifts of some manufacturing operations to the South.

title: U.S. and Canada Agree on a Plan For Gas Pipeline
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 2Negotiators for Canada and the United States reached an agreement in principle tonight on conditions for the construction of multibilliondollar pipeline to carry Alaskan natural gas to the lower 48 states through Canadian territory, but the final decision rests with President Carter.

title: Paying to Be Spied On
description: In accord with the recommendation of a National Security Agency panel, the Federal Government is spending $10 million to reroute sensitive calls through underground cables as a way of foiling Soviet eavesdroppers in this country. Other costly methods of safeguarding Federal and private communicationsincluding one approach that would cost from $2 to $3 billionare also being proposed. However, all of these efforts are being directed exclusively at protecting telephone calls by technical devices, not at making the Russians stop.

title: BHUTTO IS ARRESTED, POLICE SOURCES SAY
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Saturday, Sept. 3, (Reuters)Police sources said that former Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto was arrested early today at his home here.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: Front Page 3

title: Israeli Army Units Said to Kidnap 16 In Lebanon Villages
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2 (Reuters)Reports from southern Lebanon today said Israeli troops struck across the border before dawn and kidnapped at least 16 people from two villages for questioning, presumably about Palestinian guerrilla movements in the area.

title: INDIA COCACOLA BOTTLERS SEEK IMPORT PERMISSION
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 2 (UPI)Indian bottlers of CocaCola asked the Government today to allow importation of raw materials needed to bottle the drink and save them from financial disaster.

title: BELL WOULD PROTECT SUED U.S. EMPLOYEES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that the Justice Department would soon propose that the Federal Government be substituted as the sole defendant in civil suits against Federal employees for actions taken in the course of their duties.

title: Sonny Fox Overhauls NBC's Shows for Children
description: People over 15 are likely to remember Sonny Fox as the witty and ebullient emcee of the fourhour Sunday children's show Wonderama during the 1960's, and before that as host of such network shows as Lets Take a Trip and The $64.000 Challenge.

title: Panamanian Dies Of Burns Suffered In Treaty Protest
description: Leopoldo Aragn, a Panamanian who set himself afire Thursday outside the United States Embassy in Stockholm to protest the signing of the Panama Canal treaties, died yesterday at the Karolinska hospital in Stockholm. He was 50 years old.

title: Israel Denies Report
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 2An Israeli military spokesman tonight denied reports from Lebanon that Israeli troops had raided Lebanese villages and taken prisoners for questioning.

title: White House Confirms Inquiry Into Lance Accounts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Federal bank examiners are questioning a procedure that permits Bert Lance the director of the Office of Management and Budget, to cover overdrafts at one Georgia bank through automatic transfers of funds from another bank, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Armco Won't Join Industry In Raisins Steel Prices 6%
description: A major break in steel pricing appears to have developed with a decision by the Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's fifthlargest producer, that it will not go along with tomorrow's scheduled 6 percent price increase for structural products, thus keeping its prices at present levels on a major portion of its structural products.

title: PRICES OF SOYBEANS SHOW A FIRM RISE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP)A period of heavy rains, expected to cause some harvest delays, generated firmly higher soybean prices on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

title: A CABBY IS SHOT TO DEATH IN MORRIS HEIGHTS AREA
description: A 38yearold taxi driver was found shot to death in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx yesterday afternoon. The police said he had been shot twice in the back of the head in an apparent robbery.

title: Super Slurper Patent
description: A patent for a process using flour to make super slurpers, materials that will absorb several thousands of times their weight in water, has been granted to two Agriculture Department researchers. Page 26.

title: Adele Chatfield Taylor, Civic Aide
description: Adele Blow ChatfieldTaylor, the widow of Wayne ChatfieldTaylor, former Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and died Wednesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 82 years old and a resident of Washington. D.C.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1

title: Letters: On the Energy Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal mediator called a night session in Mineola with negotiators late Friday as he stepped up efforts to end a twocounty garbage strike on Long Island. The new meeting followed by only a few hours a preliminary session called by Hezekiah Brown, of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: Seattle Slew's Nice Long Holiday
description: Thanks partly to J. O. Tobin and partly to W. G. Barry, Seattle Slew is now enjoying the long rest he should have had in June and July. J. O. Tobin is the fine colt that beat Slew off at Hollywood Park about three weeks after the Triple Crown winner completed a skein of nine straight victories that included the Champagne Stakes, the Flamingo, Wood Memorial, Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: No Truth Is Found in Rumors Of Colombia Coffee Changes
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 2 (UPI)Coffee and economic experts said today that they know of no plans by Colombia to change its coffee export regulations or adjust export prices.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Lehigh Portland Cement Company announced yesterday that it had been offered $25 a share for its shares by Heidelberg Cement Inc. in a transaction valued at $85 million.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Officials of the BergenPassaic Lung Association said yesterday that they were elated over the response from school officials across the state to a warning on the use of possible cancercausing chemicals in classroom science laboratories.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing

title: LABOR DAY WEEKEND
description: BusinessesVirtually all will be open Monday, and regular schedules will be followed by most on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Braves Keep Trading: Gianelli Goes to Bucks
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 2 (UPI)  The Buffalo Braves, continuing to trade, sent John Gianelli, a reserve center, to the Milwaukee Bucks today for a firstround draft choice in either 1979 or 1980 and an undisclosed amount of cash. Gianelli, 27 years old, came to the Braves last Dec. 9 in the trade that sent Bob McAdoo and Tom McMillen to the New York Knicks.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Sept. 2, 1977

title: Hailstork, Walker and Cordero In a Black Composers Concert
description: Of the three composers on the Celebration of Black Composers program Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall, Adolphus Hailstork and George Walker are Americans, while Roque Cordero was born in Panama but is living and teaching in this country. They had at least one thing in common besides race,

title: Sock It to Bette Davis? Not Even on Laugh In
description: I could work all of the time if I took just whatever came along. Bits here and there, aunts, mothers and those also starring roles. But I dont want to end my career that way. I want my name above the title. I have fought all of my professional life to put it there and that's where I'm going to keep it. When scripts come in, I dont count the pages. But I wont do cameos.

title: Lou Gehrig's Disease
description: It's known generally as Lou Gehrig's disease, because it killed the great Yankee first baseman, and there is no known cure for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a fairly common neurological disorder that gradually cripples its victims. The hands and feet weaken until they cannot function. Speaking becomes difficult and swallowing almost impossible.

title: Lance Inquiry Reported to Find Bank Planes Made Political Trips
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3An investigation by the office of the Comptroller of the Currency has disclosed that aircraft leased or owned by a Georgia bank then headed by Bert Lance may have been used for political purposes, including trips to last year's Democratic National Convention, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: There's a Morel to the Story
description: MAHOPAC

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WASHING machines are usually hooked up to hot and cold water lines in a basement or utility room by means of flexible hoses that screw onto spigots something like those used around the outside of the house.

title: Topics
description: The Art of Miss Hanks

title: Israeli Resettlement Chief Envisions a Security Belt Involving 2 Million Jews
description: TEL AVIV. Sept. 3 (Reuters)Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli general who now is Minister of Agriculture and is in charge of resettlement programs, said today he had a plan to settle about two million Jews in a security belt extending from the occupied Golan Heights of Syria, in the north, to the tip of the occupied Sinai Peninsula of Egypt, in the south.

title: Watchdog Aide Criticizes Lack of Central Control Over City Bank Accounts
description: A special financial watchdog for New York City reported yesterday that city agencies kept money in 2,488 bank accounts with no centralized control and without justifying their need to do so.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Time off. . . . Enjoy the Labor Day weekend.

title: Mets and Espinosa Beat ErrorProne Braves, 91
description: Having been bumped from the pennant race and having been spurned by Dave Kingman, the New York Mets turned to the workaday chore of just finishing the season yesterday, and they handled that with ease by overpowering the Atlanta Braves. 91.

title: JOHN W. GARDNER
description: John W. Gardner, retired assistant vice president for manufacturing of the American Can Company, died Friday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Stratford, Conn.

title: A Physician Looks At Medical Liability
description: IN JUST a few months, the medicalliability crisis, which has been dormant this spring and summer, will resurface in the state. The stopgap solutions offered by Public Law 1952 and the insurance company of the Medical Society of the State of New Jersey were temporary indeed. The malpractice monster that was swept under the rug after the crisis of November 1976 will come up again as a more formidable force in November 1977.

title: Pickup U.S. Team Stuns West Indies Cricket Stars
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 3At 8:15 o'clock tonight, Carlyle Miller of New York was wondrously weighing a question in the locker room of Giants Stadium: Could it be true that his hastilyassembled American team had just defeated a powerful allstar West Indies team in a cricket match?

title: Some Beings Out There Just May Be Listening
description: Most scientists today assume that life is not unique to Earth and that around some of the countless stars in the universe there must be planets where civilizations have evolved, some of which could be more advanced than Earth's. Accordingly, a small but inspired effort has been under way for years to locate these extraterrestrial beings and to let them know someone is here. It is a fascinating exercise born of curiosity and cosmic loneliness.

title: IN BRIEF
description: THE NATION'S unemployment rose to a seasonally adjusted 7.1 percent in August from 6.9 percent in July, the Labor Department reported. An additional 180,000 Americans were out of work in August, bringing the total to 6.93 million. The Department said the increase was concentrated among black workers, whose unemployment rate jumped to 14.5 percent in August from 13.2 percent in July.

title: Calling Dr. Energy
description: IN order to practice energy conservation or find alternative energy options, I, as a homeowner, can find plentiful sources of information. I have booklets from government agencies and from utilities. I can call hotlines, both near and far, and can attend local seminars and workshops.

title: Argentine Accused of Killing Baby
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3 (UPI)The police found the body of David Kraiselburd, 21monthold son of a prominent Argentine newspaper publisher, and arrested his chauffeur in connection with his kidnapping and murder more than a year ago, the newspaper La Prensa reported today.

title: For 5,720, a BlueWater Ship Is the Place to Spend Labor Day
description: Compared with the hundreds of thousands of people who are leaving the city for the Labor Day weekend, 5,720 passengers who will spend Labor Day at sea isn't much. Yet, for the port, which has been struggling in recent years to revive its cruise business, it is a respectable total. The ship travelers at sea tomorrow will be aboard one transAtlantic ship, Cunar??'s Queen Elizabeth 2, and seven cruise ships, the Cunard Princess, the Home Lines Doric and Oceanic, Holland America Cruises Rotterdam and Statendam, the Russian Kazakhstan and Norwegian America's Sagafjord. The Queen sailed on Thursday. The other seven ships left on Friday.

title: Because $8,000 Is Unavailable, A Team Dies
description: The college football season for 150pound teams is about to start, minus one team. Columbia University has eliminated 150pound football, partly because its team has not been competitive. It lost 17 of its last 18 games, 11 by shutouts, and it was outscored in those games, 651 points to 41.

title: The Rights of Cogs
description: Public discussion on the issue of human rights in the third world has generated more heat than light because it has failed to recognize the largescale economic costs of more humane policies. There is no natural affinity among capitalist growth, political freedom and social justice. In the contemporary underdeveloped world, repression and poverty have become integral and essential parts of the dominant growth strategies.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayRice Farms Fall, Middle Island Arena, Rocky Point Road, Middle Island, L.I. Regular, green, amateurowner, special. Junior and children's working hunters; intermediate and junior jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Sensory Garden in Wantagh Enables the Handicapped to Experience the Thrill of Sowing and Harvesting
description: WANTAGH, L.I.Until a few months ago, Gerry Ahern had never held a gardening tool in her hand or pushed a seed deep into fertile earth. Born with a congenital defect called spina bifida, Miss Ahern, a Seaford resident, has been confined to a wheelchair for most of her 30 years, unable to engage in most of the simple pleasures of gardening.

title: Joyous Musical jivation With the PFunkadelics
description: There is a sputtering at the back of the arenaa miniaturized flying saucer, spitting smoke and sparks and lurching along a wire. When it reaches a point above the stage, one's attention is shifted to a huge hat that has been suspended there all along. To portentous music, a far larger version of the saucer descends from the hat, exhaust spewing from its thrusters. Finally to flashing lights emerges Dr. Funkenstein (actually hoisted up to saucer level by an elevator in back of the landing platform)George Clinton himself, in full ermine regalia. It's all really quite wonderful.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: DIABETICS ORGANIZE SIX CLUBS ON L.I.
description: We deal with the problems of diabetes, and try to get the diabetic uptodate information. We discuss the everyday problems of the diabetic. We get them talking about some of their living experiences, and they help each other a great deal.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: OffDuty Officer Kills Youth Who Allegedly Cut Him
description: An offduty policeman shot and killed an 18yearold youth in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn Friday night after the youth reportedly attacked the officer with a knife.

title: September Song: There's Life in the Old Summer Yet
description: LABOR DAY, to a small boy who spent some of his early years as a yearround resident of a beach community, was a glorious time. It meant watching the summer people leave and then wandering for blocks with friends to pick through the curbside mounds of summer debris.

title: Ann Zegob to Wed Oct. 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nesrala Zegob Jr. of San Luis, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Louise Zegob, to David Gardner Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton D. Hoffman of Stamford, Conn. The wedding will take place on Oct. 9.

title: MUSIC
description: IF YOU WERE paying attention last June, you read in this column about the intriguing chamber music programs at Music Moun tain, near Falls Village, in the foothills of the Connecticut Berkshires. Well, the string quartet season is over, but folk fans have a rare and wonderful treat still ahead next Saturday afternoon. In a special postseason benefit concert for Music Mountain, four of the finest folk singers in America today will hold forth with ballads, chanties and love songs.

title: GARDENING
description: LABOR DAY is a splendid time to work in gardens. Those who plan to plant peonies this fall can excavate a few planting holes ahead of time. Gardeners who live in an area of New Jersey where the soil is heavy clay will be able to brag of really laboring on Labor Day.

title: An Original Flea Market
description: SALISBURY

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Bertolt Brecht, a very different kind of writer, had a high and remarkably acute regard for Bernard Shaw. He praised him not primarily for dramatic skill, nor for ideology, but for his cheerfulness. He called him a good man and a terrorist.

title: GARDENING
description: SUBURBIA is in a pachysandra rut. This ubiquitous ground cover has everything going for it price, ease in planting and quick growth. When the pachysandra has had a year or so to settle its roots, it provides a finished and evergreen trim to the property with a tone of elegance.

title: Pirates, Soldiers of Fortune and Spies
description: GIVEN its size, heft and ambitions, this first novel by an experienced Hollywood screenwriter comes on like the Moby Dick of ransom capers. Picture the 65,000ton French Atlantic liner S.S. Marseille, with 3,000 funloving passengers aboard, diverted on its New YorktoLe Havre run by a wellorganized cadre of shipnappers demanding $3 million in gold within 48 hours or they'll send the shin to the bottom.

title: Sigel, Fought, Brannan In U.S. Golf Quarterfinal
description: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., Sept. 3 UPI)Jay Sigel, hometown hero, and John Fought, college student, shot subpar rounds today and joined their Walker Cup teammate, Michael Branban, in the quarterfinals of the United States Amateur golf championship.

title: Yankees Set Back Twins, 74
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn.,Sept. 3Lou Piniella, a baseball player with an unusual negotiating philosophy, contributed two key hitsa single and a tworun homertoday as the Yankees continued coasting toward their second straight division championship.

title: Monmouth
Protectors of Marine Life
description: STAMFORD

title: Federal Judges Rate 7.1 Percent of Lawyers Incompetent in Study of Three State Area
description: Federal judges have rated 7.1 percent of the lawyers appearing before them as incompetent in a 13month experiment completed earlier this year in the Second Judicial DistrictNew York. Connecticut and Vermont.

title: Vivid Reminders of Brooklyn Past
description: BROOKLYN

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Robert S. Elegant
description: That ephemeral phenomenon called wordofmouth is tricky to trace in a big country. If publishers could order acclaim by the page or folio, editorial computers would be commanded to write bestselling books. Of course, some novels read that way. Still, it isn't often that the serious novel can surface without the usdal trumpets of the marketplace.

title: The World
description: Internal politics have always had a way of upsetting hopes for greater economic unity in Europe, So it was again last week when Sweden's conservative Government, trying to pass in some its large trade deficit, devalued its currency, forcing Denmark and Norway, its trade competitors, to devalue as well. Other countries discussed expansionary stepsFrance, worried about high employment with an election months away, said it would pump $1 billion into its economy. But when added together, the moves toward austerity and expansion did not add up to Europewide economic health.

title: Millions in Sales Taxes Lost to Cigarette Smugglers
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 3Interstate bootlegging of cigarettes, increasing for a decade because of growing disparities in state and local tax rates, has reached such proportions that it is regarded by some as second only to narcotics as a profit item for organized crime.

title: The New York Times
description: The New York Times

title: MillerWohl Rings Up No Sale
description: Wall Street loves a mystery, and by late last week it had a good one

title: World Cup Track Summaries
description: MEN'S TRACK EVENTS

title: Big Business in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE late Bennett Cerf, who frequently served as a judge at the Miss America Pageant, once described it as attractive to fault finders as sugar is to ants because it is strongwilled and somewhat arrogant, and involves the earth's most controversial ingredientpretty girls.

title: Meryl Kaynard Is the Bride Of Gerald Osher, a Student
description: The marriage of Meryl Kaynard to Gerald Osher took place last Sunday in Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L. I. The bride Is a daughter of Samuel M. Kaynard, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board and Ann Kaynard, assistant executive director of the Nassau. County chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. They live in Roslyn Estates, L. I.

title: Hartford Loses to Its SuburbsOr Does It?
description: HARTFORD

title: Gallup Survey Indicates That Foes of Canal Pact Hold Edge on Proponents
description: In a survey of public opinion on the Panama Canal treaty, the Gallup Poll has found slightly more Americans opposed to the treaty than in favor of it.

title: The Soaring Career of Fledermaus
description: The music of Johann Strauss Jr. has always been with us in abundance, but rarely more so than in recent months. George Balanchine's hugely popular Vienna Waltzes, based on the Waltz King's melodies, delighted patrons at the City Ballet this summer, while the City Opera is currently offering its bubbly production of his most famous operetta, Die Fledermaus. Performances of Fledermaus are scheduled for tonight and Wednesday, and the company has further enlivened the proceedings with a surpriseBeverly Sills in the role of the chamber maid Adele, an unusual assignment for such a noted prima donna.

title: COMBAT FLIER QUITS NAVY TO TRAIN FOR PRIESTHOOD
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP)Lieut. Jim Bauer of the Navy, a combat veteran who handles nonflying administrative duties with the Blue Angels flight team here, has resigned his commission to join the clergy.

title: Joan P. Dacey Wed To Karl E. Seib Jr.
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church yesterday, Joan Patten Dacey, a partner in the New York law firm of Jacobs, Persinger & Parker, was married to Karl E. Seib Jr., an associate with Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, lawyers in New York.

title: This Week's Meeting Is Canceled, and the Old Pact May Be Extended
description: WASHINGTONThe decision last week by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to cancel discussions in Vienna Wednesday on advancing the deadlocked Strategic Arms Limitation Talks was made after both sides realized that nothing of importance would emerge from the Vienna session. In fact, the cancellation made clear that despite the more pleasant mood music emanating from Washington and Moscow in recent weeks, the two sides are about as far apart on the major issues holding up a new treaty as they were when Mr. Vance and Mr. Gromyko last discussed them in Geneva in May.

title: Nancy Coutts Married To Stephen H. Johnson
description: Nancy Coutts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald M. Coutts of New Canaan, Conn., Bras married there yesterday to Stephen Harris Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K.Johnson of Kitty Hawk, N. C. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony in the Congregational ChurchUnited Church of Christ.

title: The Region
description: Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, still answering charges that they wasted public monies on air travel abroad, now have been accused of wasting funds on air travel around town. And those charges were only part of the agency's new troubles. Their chief spokesman, John Tillman, who has spent the last several months as chief apologist for the expense accounts of his various colleagues, was unable to do so in the new disclosures last week. He had some apologizing to do about his own expense account and was suspended from his $55,000ayear job.

title: Jamie Walker Bergford Is Wed on L.I. To Geoffrey R. Parkins, Ph.D. Student
description: Jamie Walker Bergford, a magna cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College, class of 76, was married yesterday afternoon to Geoffrey Richard Parkins, who expects to receive a Ph D. in physics from Dartmouth this fall.

title: Bolivia Wants U.S. Help in Winning Access to Pacific
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3The last time an American President, Lyndon B. Johnson, met in a hemispheric conclave with the Latin American chiefs of state, Bolivia's President at the time, Gen. Rene Barrientos Ortuno, stayed away to underscore his country's historical grievance, the lack of access to the sea.

title: Gambling and Organized Crime
description: BEFORE last November's election, New Jersey voters were warned that legalized gambling would bring with it the involvement of organized crime.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: The Sky Is Their Limit
description: SOUTHOLD

title: EnergySaving Heating For the Home Greenhouse
description: There was a time the word greenhouse was synonymous with heaven for the dedicated gardener. He or she could grow and prop agate all kinds of plants on a yearround basis . Mention the word today, and a dark cloud hovers. Increasing fuel costs cause worries on how to keep a greenhouse heated without going broke.

title: Mandel Trial: How Long Is Too Long for a Jury?
description: How long can a jury properly takeor be heldto make up its collective mind about the guild or innocence of criminal defendants? That puzzling question was raised by the Federal mail fraud conviction, the week before last, of Maryland Governor Marvin Mandel and five friends. The jury deliberated for 12 days before returning the guilty verdictan extraordinary length of time even by the sometimes gargantuan standards of American trials.

title: Echoes of Triumph, Defeat:
description: In the mid1960's, when I was walking with my notebook and camera next to protest marchers on the steamy streets of Montgomery, I never dreamed that someday I would be describing the birthplace of the Civil Rights Movement as a tourist attraction.

title: For Theater People, The Drama Book Shop Speaks Volumes
description: Looking for a copy of Equus? Brentano's can help you. If it's an acting edition of a play you want, Quinion Books in the Village may be able to find it on its 10 drama shelves. But a more specialized item, such as the Jones Pronouncing Dictionary Geraldine Page recently requested at Barnes and Noble, will elicit a suggestion that you visit the Drama Book Shop.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: RIDGEWOOD

title: Action to Block Signing
description: WASHINGTON,Sept. 3 (AP)The attorneys general of four states today asked the Supreme Court to order President Carter not to sign the proposed Panama Canal treaties until all details are made public.

title: Tito Visits China Resort
description: PEKING, Sept. 3 (Reuters)President Tito of Yugoslavia left Peking for theresort town of Hangchow today, Yugoslav sources said. Marshal Tito had an hourlong talk with Chairman Hua Kuofeng this morning and then attended a lunch given by Mr. Hua. The Yugoslav leader will rest at Hangchow before visiting Shanghai. He is scheduled to leave China on Sept. 8.

title: Where Were You in the War, Mommy?
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, during a school holiday, I took the kids to visit my mother in the East Bronx, where I grew up. As we were leaving, she handed me my publicschool graduation picture (1993) and a small plastic disk engraved with my name, birth date and a sevendigit number followed by the initials NYC.

title: Patty Cake, 5, Finds Fame Fades
description: Patty Cake, the gorilla who has been the superstar of the Central Park Zoo even since her birth there, marked her fifth birthday yesterday with a cageside party at which she oblingingly capered about for 50 guests.

title: Madge Huber Is Bride Of Dr.RolandHenning
description: Madge Bennett Huber, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Roger Huber of Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dr. Roland Henning, professor of biochemistry in the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Ulm, West Germany.

title: Notes: A Showcase For the Fisher Award Winners
description: There is probably nothing quite like the Avery Fisher Artist Program among noncompetitive cultural prizes. Like the Clarence Derwent Awards in the theater, for example, it gives a sum of money to gifted young performers, who also gain the prestige of being singled out from their colleagues for the honor. The Fisher program goes beyond that, finding as many major performance opportunities as possible for the chosen few.

title: MASSACHUSETTS SEES HEATED RACE COMING
description: BOSTON, Sept. 3In politics, timing is everything, the son of the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives explained after saying that he would not specify his career plans.

title: Encounter: The Night of the Stallion
description: We wheeled the Chevy Blazer off Interstate 40 at Canoncito, N.M. A bright, round moon cast eerie shadows on the lonely rest area, with its leafless trees and pitted earth, as we quickly inflated air maftresses; locked the car and crawled into cold bedrolls. But my friends and I were not to sleep that night.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Evan (Big Cat) Williams, the defending champion, was down to his last chance in the National Long Driving Championship. His first three tries had missed the 40yard fairway, and he needed to keep his final ball in play and move it at least 316 yards or he was out.

title: A Monument Is Urged For Martha Mitchell
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., Sept. 3 (UPI)A newspaper has begun a fundraising drive to build a monument to the late Martha Mitchell, the wife of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The method used to compensate stockbrokers has been working against the interests of investors for many years.

title: Miss Joskow Fiancee Of Rafael Yglesias
description: Margaret Joskow, a freelance graphic designer, and Rafael Yglesias, an author, will be married on Oct. 15 at the Glen Head (L. I.) Country Club. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jules Joskow of Kings Point, L. I. Mr. Yglesias is a son of Helen and Jos Yglesias of North Brooklin, Me. They also are authors.

title: Food
description: There are numerous desserts in pastrymaker's art that border on the miraculous  things that puff in the oven out of all proportion to what they were when they went in. Count among these the highrise souffles and the somewhat more complicated thousandlayered millefeuilles, or napoleons.

title: Total Flow of 5 Largest Rivers Slightly Above. Normal in August
description: WASHINGTON,Sept. 3 (UPI)For the first time since last November, the combined flow of the nation's five largest rivers inched into the abovenormal range last month, according to the United States Geological Survey.

title: Down to the Wire in Nassau
description: THE three contests for County Executive nominations are only the tip of the iceberg in the most important primary election in Nassau County history. The County Executive contests, highly visible and bitterly fought in public, have their counterparts behind the scenestests of the leadership of the Republican, Democratic and Conservative Parties in the county.

title: Unmarried Couples Look
description: Unmarried couples, known in the law as cohabitors but otherwise rather awkwardly left without a label, are beginning to take an interest in buying cooperative apartments.

title: Maria Antonio, Bank Aide, Wed to Raymond R. Barlaam
description: St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church in Briarcliff, N. Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Maria E. Antonio and Raymond R. Barlaam. The Rev. Ronald Saucci performed the ceremony.

description: WANTAGH

title: Primary Campaign: Diffusion, Confusion, Illusion
description: In one of the most difficult periods in New York City's history, when the city is still unable to borrow funds in the private market because of its precarious financial position, when 600,000 jobs have been lost and 2,000,000 middle class residents have fled, when whole neighborhoods look like bombed out Berlin at the end of World War II, the first stage of a mayoral campaign is winding down with more attention focused on personalities and a nonmayoral issue, capital punishment, than on solutions to the city's problems.

title: G.B. Hudson Fiance Of Ellen Weathers
description: The engagement of Ellen Cushing Weathers to Glenn Buker Hudson has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eliot. B. Weathers of Scarsdale, N.Y. Mr. Hudson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Hudson of Sunapee, N.H. The wedding is planned for October.

title: Oh Surpasses Aaron With 756th Home Run
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3Sadaharu Oh hit the 756th homer of his Japanese baseball career here tonight, making him the most prolific homerun hitter in professional history.

title: State Watchdog Sought on Pensions
description: TRENTON PENSION payments to retired stateand localgovernment employees in New Jersey have been more or less doubling every five years, and now total about $225 million annually to 55,000 retired workers.

title: F.C.C. Asked to Bar Junk Phone Calls As Potential Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission is being asked to protect the public from a possible avalanche of junk telephone calls made by a device that dials a series of numbers, either preselected or at random, and plays a prerecorded message when each call is answered.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The nation's economic activity is slowing, reports last week showed, but it is far from clear whether the deceleration is the mild slowdown that had been muchpredicted for the second half of this year or the first warning signals of a new recession.

title: Beverly Sills Tries a New Role
description: The first New York City Opera Fledermaus of the season Friday night at the New York State Theater was newsworthy for Beverly Sills's fist Adele. But what made the performance enjoyable was the way Miss Sills subsumed her performance and her assertive personality into a coherent. amusing ensemble effort.

title: Me First
description: THERE seems to be no end in sight to the proliferation of selfhelp books. They differ in the kinds of selflove they appeal to and promote, in the particular catchphrasesor movements or systemsthey retail and in their various styles. But they share certain values:

title: 2,300 Students to Lose Bus Service in a Greenburgh Economy Move
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 3 (UPI)About 2,300 students in the Greenburgh Central 7 School District will not have schoolbus service next Wednesday because of a shortage of funds, according to Superintendent of Schools Robert Frelow.

title: Nixon's Drug Crusade
description: WATERGATE, about which we have heard both too much and too little, not only turned Richard Nixon out of office but also opened up the American political system like an archeologist's trench. One result is that Nixon's Presidency is rapidly coming to hold a unique position in American history, one crucial to our understanding of who we are and how we conduct the public business, and yet elusive and difficult to define. Perhaps the best way to describe it is to say that the Nixon Administration is becoming for serious students of American politics what the Boswell papers are for English scholars, what flatworms and white mice are for medical researchers and what American Samoa was for Margaret Mead.It is, in short, a kind of captive epoch, an allpurpose case in point.

title: Rufus W. Rauch Jr., Professor Of History at Temple University
description: Rufus William Rauch Jr., an associate professor of history at Temple University in Philadelphia, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Paoli (Pa.) Memorial Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Devon, a Philadelphia suburb. He also maintained a summer home in Buck Hills Falls. Pa.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: The easy smile disappears without trace, and the energy he exudes can leave exhaustion in its wake. He thinks usually on paper and with the help of pocket calculators  and frequently criticizes, like a whiplash.

description: Many of the city's most prestigious cooperative apartment buildings have long had a reputation for discriminating against wouldbe purchasers.

description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., Sept. 3Nearly 100,000 exuberant rock fans converged today on a dragrace track near this Monmouth County town for what was billed as New Jersey's biggest outdoor concert ever. Its main attraction was the Grateful Dead, a rock group.

title: Melissa Moore Wed in Suburbs To R. B. Wilson
description: Melissa Woodburn Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dongan Reynolds Moore of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Ballou Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Stuart Wilson of Poi?t Cla?e Quebec.

title: Weehawken: Small Town With Urban Problems
description: WEEHAWKEN is a picturesque community on the Palisades. It has large Victorian and Tudor houses and a spectacular view of the Manhattan skyline. It is a small town, but it has chronic urban headaches.

title: HOW TO MAKE PUFF PASTRIES
description: 1. Put one cup cold water in saucepan and add eight tablespoons butter, salt to taste and onehalf teaspoon sugar. Bring to the boil.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Until now he always kept his basestealing secrets to himself, but Lou Brock of the St. Louis Cardinals has succeeded Ty Cobb as the recordholder for career stolen bases. Lou Brock can tell a few stories now. Not all the stories, of course; not all the secrets. Still slim and supple at age 38, the eventual Hall of Famer should

title: Anniversaries
description: Schwartz

title: Soap or No Soap?
description: The news that a few sponsors have withdrawn from the controversial new television series, Soap, and that a few local stations have refused to screen it has sent TV and advertising agency executives into a snit. They warn of pressure groups . . . trying to drive off the air whatever conflicts with their views, and warn that television may be driven deeper and deeper into the quagmire of mediocrity. Since these are the people who have been doing the driving all these years, their response smacks of dramatic license.

title: Headliners
description: Lyle F. Lane, the head of a 10member interest section that has arrived in Havana to renew formal diplomatic contact with Cuba for the first time in 16 years, reports that the old United States embassy there is a treasure trove of fifties nostalgia. Among the relics: numerous portraits of President Eisenhower, a Coke machine offering the soda at five cents a bottle, and a flag with 49 stars. While Mr. Lane took office in Havana, a Cuban group reopened the old Cuban embassy in Washington. Key issues still to be resolved before the two countries will resume full diplomatic relations include Cuba's military presence in Africa, the status of Americans still held prisoner in Cuban jails and $1.8 billion in claims against the Castro Government by American companies and individuals.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Touring New York's WineMaking Country
description: In a few weeks the grape harvest will begin. The early morning air will turn sharply colder, but the steep stony slopes in the Finger Lakes district will drain any hint of killing frost to stillwarm Keuka Lake far below. In the heart of New York state's wine country, thriving vineyards are clustered around the drowsy village of Hammondsport, at the foot of the lake. Last spring, in a twoday tour of five wineries, I discovered what may be the last of the great free lunches: hot and cold canapes of exotic description and brimming glassfuls of the area's produce served with ungrudging hospitality.

title: Marred Sound Of Bernstein
description: The hourlong program of works by Leonard Bernstein presented in the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden on Friday night was largely a study in frustration for the listener. Except for those seated directly in front of and not too distant from the performers, the members of the audience could catch few of the words and only unbalanced portions of the instrumental accompaniment. It was as tantalizing as the sound of a distant radio from which the music approaches and fades and is not quite recognizable.

title: Primary Roundup
description: Primary election candidates scoured a depopulated city yesterday to seek support from any enrolled voters who might have been left behind in the holiday exodus.

title: Book Review
Hot New Torches for The Home Handyman
description: In recent years more and more manufacturers have introduced professional type moderately priced brazing/welding/and metalcutting torches which are now available in many local retail outlets.

title: Roberta Lee Fagin Bride Of Ernest P. De Simone
description: Holy Family Roman Catholic Chapel in Convent Station, N. J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Roberta Lee Fagin to Ernest Peter De Simone. The Rev. Elso Introini, chaplain of St. Elizabeth's College, officiated.

title: Pearl Necklace, 72, Wins Gazelle With Cauthen Up
description: Steve Cauthen had been scheduled to ride David Reynolds's Small Raja, the overnight favorite, in the $52,950 Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. But Small Raja was a late scratch, because of a muddy track, so Cauthen found himself a ride on Pearl Necklace and guided Reginald Webster's charge to a 2length victory in the mileandaneighth test for 3yearold fillies.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Numismatic and Antiquarian Service Corporation of America (NASCA) had an auction not long ago that produced a few surprises. Their catalogue gave esti mates for the various lots that turned out to be pretty accurate, as predictions go, but there were a few items that soared far above the expected figure.
