title: A Mausoleum for Mao Is Opened in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 9Chita commemorated the first anniversary of the death of Mao Tsetung today with a brief, solemn ceremony opening his white marble mausoleum in Peking's Tien An Men Square.

title: MANUFACTURERS PROFITS INCREASED IN 2D QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP)Manufacturers aftertax profits averaged 5.8 cents per dollar of sales in the second quarter of 1977, compared with 5 cents in the first quarter, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

title: Notes on People
description: Ending his weeklong first series of religious meetings in a Soviet bloc country yesterday, Billy Graham said in Budapest that his visit to Hungary had changed his thinking about Communism, and said that he had found that in that officially atheist nation neonle can freely worship God.

title: Bonn Accepts Swiss as Intermediary With Terrorists
description: BONN, Sept. 9The West German Government informed the kidnappers of a leading industrialist by radio today that it would accept a Swiss lawyer as an intermediary for negotiations to free him.

title: Yale Student Withdraws From Lawsuit
description: NEW HAVENEugenia Leftwich, Yale University undergraduate, has withdrawn from a controversial suit filed against Yale this summer, in which she and four other plaintiffs charged that female students have been sexually harassed by their male professors.

title: Prison Fight Is Halted By Shots, With 11 Hurt
description: SOLEDAD, Calif., Sept. 9 (UPI)  A racial fight among three dozen black and white inmates at Soledad state prison was halted by gunfire, and 11 Inmates were injured, two by shots, the prison has disclosed.

title: Newspaper Strike Deadline Set
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 9 (AP)Local 200 of the International TypographScal Union at The Youngstown Vindicatpr set a strike deadline for 10 P.M: tomorrow while continuing contract talks today. Richard Cantwell, president of the 150member local, told representatives of other unions at the afternoon daily newspaper last night that all issues had been settled except that of. money. The typog???phers have been without a contract since last September.

title: Kenneth P. O'Donnell Dies at 53; Key Adviser to President Kennedy
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9 Kenneth P. O'Donnell, former aide and close adviser to President John F. Kennedy, died at 3:15 A.M. today in the intensive care unit of Boston's Beth Israel Hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: Republicans Propose Plan to Cure Deficits in Social Security System
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The House Republican leadership proposed today comprehensive plan for curing the deficits in the Social Security System by variety of means, including mandatory inclusion in Social Security of the 2.5 million civilian Government employees who now have a separate retirement system.

title: .Nassati G.O.P. Facing a Tough Fight in November
description: MINEOLA, LI., Sept. 9Although the Nassau County Republican organization handily won the threeway primary election yesterday, the party still faces the possibility of another threeway split in November that could lead to the loss of the County Executive seat.

title: U.S.Soviet Trade Declined By 21.7% in First Half of 1977
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (UPI)Trade between the United States and the Soviet Union dropped by 21.7 percent during the ??? of 1977, reflecting cuts in both Soviet agricultural and nonagricultural ourehases.

title: Books of The Times
description: On a hot June night in 1964, group of Mississippi men, all of them members of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, abducted and murdered three civilrights workers, Michael Schwerner, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman. They then sought to bury their crime from the world beneath 20 feet of earth at a dam site.

title: Cause of Legion Disease Sought
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (UPI)Federal health officials said today that an investigation was being conducted to determine whether an outbreak of legionnaires disease in Columbus, Ohio, may be connected with excavation for a new building at a hospital where many of the cases have occurred.

description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 1:55 P.M.)

title: Chilean Hailed on Return From U. S.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9President Augusto Pinochet received a triumphal welcome in the streets of this capital today on his return from a visit to the United States.

title: The Control Room That Didn't Control
description: If, in the critical hour or so before the July 13 blackout, key personnel in Con Edison's control center had taken correct action promptly, they might well have averted complete collapse of the system. Instead, they bumbled. Whatever larger verdicts are ultimately reached in the several continuing investigations of the blackout, it now clear from Con Edison's second blackout report and hearings before a special mayoral commission that the utility left the public in the care of a control room whose personnel and equipment were not prepared to handle the emergency.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)Hospital costs in this country are increasing at rate of $1 million an hour, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told a House health subcommittee today.

title: Greek Cypriots Mourn Makarios, but, They Say, He Lives
description: PAPHOS, Cyprus, Sept. 5On farmhouse walls and the sides of weathered old pastel buildings, on streets near cozy Mediterranean inlets and high is the distant cool mountains, the inscription Zei can be found. Pronounced zee, it is Greek and it The Talk means He lives. of Paphos

title: President to Campaign For Byrne Today
description: President Carter will spend five hours in New Jersey today to help Governor Byrne's campaign for reelection. New Jersey and Virginia are the only states with gubernatorial elections this fall.

title: ALICE CRIMMINS GRACE IS FREED ON PAROLE
description: Alice Crimmins Grace, freed on a controvordal parole, dashed into a waiting car and presumably a new life yesterday after serving five years of a fiveto20year sentence for the strangulation of her 4 yearsold daughter.

title: Abzug Defeat Laid to 3 Candidates And Length of Primary Campaign
description: Everybody felt that Bella Abzug was going to do a lot better, Mayor Beame said at a news conference yesterday. From the opening bell to the final preprimary polls, she had been counted at least second, and thus destined for the mayoral runoff. But Mrs. Abzug garnered less than 17 percent of the vote, half her onetime strength.

title: Disability Pension Rise Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)The Senate passed today a bill calling for a 6.6 percent cost of living increase in the pensions of 2.2 million veterans with serviceconnected disabilities. The bill would increase benefits for a veteran with a 50 percent disability from $203 to $216 a month. The legislation was returned to the House, which had approved an increase of only 6.3 percent. The increase would go into effect Oct. 1.

title: Bridging The G.O.P. And Labor
description: WASHINGTON  Many Republicans are talking about an offyear tuneup for their party, when what it needs is an overhaul.

title: 15 Killed by a Uganda Firing Squad
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 9 (AP)Fifteen men, among them teachers, businessmen and former Government officials, were put to death today by a firing squad on the outskirts of Kampala.

title: Governors Overwhelmingly Back President's Proposals on Welfare
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9The nation's governors voted overwhelmingly today to back President Carter's welfare reform proposals as they wound up a convention that took them outside their fancy hotel into the slums, factories and corporate headauarters of Detroit.

title: Peter Crandall Scott Weds Claudia Barnett
description: Claudia Elizabeth Barnett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Raymond Barnett of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to Peter Crandall Scott, son of Faith Crandall Scott of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Gordon Kendall Scott, professor emeritus at the Stanford University Law School.

title: Jazz: Cool Baker's HalfDozen
description: The Chet Baker Quartet that played at Stryker's, 86th Street at Columbus Avenue, Thursday evening, was a bit unusual. It consisted of six musicians, only three of whom were officially members of Mr. Baker's quartet. Two a drummer from Seattle and a tenor saxophonistwere sitting in and the bassist was a substitute for the bassist Mr. Baker had planned to have.

title: C. T. Maxwell Weds Virginia Dorr Wiese
description: The marriage of Virginia Dorr Wiese to Charles T. Maxwell, senior vice president and director of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., were married yesterday in the chapel of Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Charles L. Copenhaver, senior minister of the Dutch Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y.. performed the ceremony.

title: All 13 on 2Engine Plane Are Killed In Crash Into Mountain in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE, Sept. 9 (AP)All 13 persons aboard a twinengine plane bound from Iliamna to Anchorage died when it crashed into 10,016foot Mount Iliamna about 200 miles southeast of here, according to state troopers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Associated Press caption on photograph that appeared in The Times on July 13and an article that accompanied the pictureincorrectly identified a demonstrator arrested at Kent State University on July 12 as Martin Scheuer, whose daughter was killed at Kent State in 1970. The person pictured was Albert Canfora, whose son was wounded on the same occasion.

title: Petit's Coppelia Is About Life, Love and the Eternal Triangle
description: LONDON  It was Edwin Denby, that most insightful of critics, who once, with only a smidgin of irony, praised the ballet Coppelia for teaching the facts of life to the young. That was more than 30 years ago, but undoubtedly he would approve of the substance, if not the style, of Roland Petit's witty new Coppelia for his Marseille Ballet. The Marseille cornpany is now paying its first visit to Britainappearing surprisingly enough in that popcitadel of vaudeville, the London Palladiumand it opened with his radical new version of Coppelia, which not only teaches the facts of life, but also positively lectures on them.

title: Ninon Tallon Kariweis Dies at 68; An International Theatrical Agent
description: Ninon Talton Karlweis, the theatrical agent who was responsible for introducing Eugene Ionesco's play Rhinoceros, costarring Zero Mostel, Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson, to American audiences in 1961, died yesterday in the American Hospital in Paris. She was 68 years old. She had been hospitalized for the last two weeks.

title: Chile's OpenDoor Economic Policy Admits Flood of Luxury Goods, While Millions Live Hand to Mouth
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9Chile has become a bazaar filled with foreign goods that are snapped up by the welltodo while millions of workers and their families are living hand to mouth.

title: Bomb Explodes at Opera House
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (AP)Abomb exploded early today at the entrance to the San Francisco War Memorial Opera House, but no major damage or injuries were reported. About an hour after the 12:25 A.M. blast, a woman telephoned The Associated Press and said that the New World Liberation Front claimed responsibility for the bomb. She gave directions to a telephone booth containing a Liberation Front communiqu, which demanded that elderly tenants evicted weeks ago from the International Hotel be allowed to return, and that the hotel be brought up to code without a rant inrraacp.

title: FORMER LADY ASHLEY, 73; MARRIED 2 FILM STARS
description: The former Lady Ashley, who was the widow of Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and former wife of Clark Gable, died of cancer June 30 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 73 years old.

title: His Guru Discusses Jimmy Connors
description: After his other victories in the United States Open, only few newsmen waited in the upstairs lounge at the West Side Tennis Club for Jimmy Connors to appear after a massage and a shower. But on Thursday night, nearly 100 notebooks and tape recorders were poised and the TV lights were on when Jimmy Connors arrived. This, he said quietly, is more like it. And at last, this is more like a tennis tournament than a sideshow. After two days of Renee Richards, one day of Ilie Nastase, one day of Michael Fishbach's spaghetti racquet and four days of 14yearold Tracy Austin, the tournament had finally begun. Jimmy Connors had stormed into today's semifinals of the men's singles at peak form and peak fury. He had assaulted Manuel Orantes, his conqueror in the 1975 final, 62, 64, 63, and at Forest Hills, people were finally talking tennis. Pancho Segura especially was talking tennis.

title: Toys That Speak to Children in a Special Way
description: Eightyearold Ann, whose cerebral palsy kept her in a wheelchair, was known to have a severe hearing loss. She never responded to the other children at Wayne Multiple Handicapped Center, in Wayne, N.3., and the therapists wondered if she could hear anything softer than a loud noise.

title: L.I. Man Charged With Molesting A Girl, 10, at Knifepoint in Queens
description: A 34yearold Suffolk County man was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually molesting a 10yearold girl at knifepoint in Glen Oaks, Queens. He was also being quetoned by the police about the rapes of a dozen women in this middleclass community and in neighboring Fresh Meadows over the east year.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The Advisory Council of National Organizations, formed in 1969 as the publicparticipation arm of the Corpora* An for Public Broadcasting, voted late last night to dissolve itself.much. Then we began to find we were not being listened to and that we weren't being given access to all the information we needed. That gave them the ability to say our advice wasn't valid because we didn't know all the facts, Mrs. McMahon said.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9In a break with a policy of long standing, the Carter Administration deoided today to allow four Soviet trade union representatives to visit the United States, despite the opposition of the A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: U.S. Steel to File Dumping Charge
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to file complaint next week with the Treasury Department P hsrging Japanese steelmakers with dumping steel products in this. The steelmaker also said that it was investigating the possibility of filing dumping charges against British, French, Italian and other foreign steelmakers.

title: LongTerm Users of Pill Found to Run Higher Risk Of a Rare Liver Tumor
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (UPI) The longer that women use oral contraceptives the greater their risk of developing a rare but serious nonmalignant liver tumor, Federal health officials said today.

title: NONREFILLABLE: A giant 520,000gallon fuel tank for the U.S. Space Shuttle being rolled out at the Illichoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans yesterday.
description: Associated Press The $2.5 million tank, 153 feet long and almost 30 feet wide, is made of an aluminum alloy, and is designed to be jettisonedthen to disintegrateonce shuttle is in orbit.

title: Letter: On Floating Currencies
description: To the Editor: The Editorial Notebook on Aug. 25, Legthe Currencies Float, states that there is a growing sentiment among business people for a return to government supported, fixed rates. I question this assertion and believe Peter Passel( will find instead that most internationhl business executives wholeheartedly support his conclusions agaihst a return to fixed rates.

title: Spaniards Rally Over Prices
description: MADRID, Sept. 9 (AP)An estimated 125,000 people, some waving placards and republican flags, staged three demonstrations against inflation tonight.

title: Courageous in Practice For Cup Race Today
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 9 (UPI)  The 12Meter yacht Courageous practiced against Independence today in preparation for her upcoming defense of the America's Cup against Australia on Tuesday.

title: Voting in Runoff Open To All on Party's Roll
description: The 910,000 Democrats who voted in Thursday's primary election will not be the only New Yorkers to decide on Sept. 19 who will be their party's untimate nominees for Mayor and City Council President in the runoff voting.

title: BULLET FIRED IN ROBBERY WOUNDS ELDERLY COUPLE
description: A Brooklyn man and his wife both in their 70's, were wounded yesterday by a single bullet fired during a robbery attempt the police reported.

title: ROBERT W. THIBODEAU, 59; TREASURER OF EMHART
description: Robert W. Thibodeau, for 10 years treasurer of the Emhart Corporation of Farmington, Conn., machinery manufacturers, died Thursday night at his home, 57 Crocus Lane, Farmington. He was 59 years old.

title: Hot Line Helps Find Welfare Fraud
description: OLYMPIA. Wash., Sept. 10 (AP)With a tollfree hot line and a promise of anonymity. Washington State has enlisted its citizens in tracking down welfare fraud.

title: Miss Hatfield Bride Of Brian O. Innes
description: Barbara Campbell Hatfield and Brian Ogilvie Inne.s were married yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Terence Finlay performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Reamer Kline.

title: India Agrees to Deal That Allows I.B.M. To Stay in Country
description: NEW DELHI, SEPT. 10The Government has decided in effect to allow the International Business Machines Corporation to split into two companies in India to enable it to comply with the Foreign Exchange Regulations Act that requires the company to dilute its equity.

title: HE WAS THERE
description: A man with a camera and the curious name of Weegee made photo history as he captured the city's night dramas and disasters. Now a major exhibition puts him in the spotlight.wagons, and ice wagons, and cops who looked like cops and robbers who looked like robbers. And, looking not entirely.

title: Pakistan's New Military Leader Talks a Strong Civilian Game
description: ISLAMABAD, PakistanGen. Mohammed Zia ulHaq, the tough professional soldier now in charge of Pakistan, insisting several times a week that he intends to turn the government back over to the civilian politicians next month, after a national election. I definitely plan to go ahead with that election on schedule and to have a civilian government, General Zia said in an interview last week. A military government is not the solution for Pakistan. But military regimes have a way of hanging on, and some Pakistanis remain skeptical about General Zia's determination to end martial law and yield control as well as about his ability to do so without bringing back the political turmoil that has afflicted this impoverished nation for most of 1977.

title: 3 Mew Publications Arise From Protest Of Editors Ouster
description: SSCANABA, Mich.. Sept. 10 A new weekly newspaper, The Escanaba Reporter, published its first issue here this week, the first of three new publications planned in Michigan's Upper Peninsula following public uproar over the dismissals last June of the editors of The Escanaba Daily Press and The Marquette Mining Journal.

title: Mary Theo Toomey Married
description: Mary Theo Tuomey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Douglas Tuomey Jr. of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday toStephen Austin Hayes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Webb C. Hayes 3d of Chevy Chase. Md.

title: WILDEY CLEGG RICKERSON
description: Wildey Clegg Rickerson, former chairman of the Unexcelled Manufacturing Company, makers of explosive devices, died yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital, Middletown, Conn. He was 80 years old and had homes in New York City and Deep River, Conn.

title: C.A.B. VIEW RESISTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS
description: Officials of British Airways said yesterday that they would make vigorous efforts at the White House to overrule decision Friday by the Civil Aeronautics Board that the airline said puts severe limits on competition against Laker Airways nofrills. $236 roundtrip bargain fare between New York and London. President Carter has the final say on the key issues because international travel is involved.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: The house plants have had a good summer outdoors. They are many inches taller. Their leaves are shiny and strong. And they have had plenty of fresh air and rainfall. But now for them, it must all end. In they come. Even though the weather may be tempting to keep them outdoors for a bit longer, be diligent. The reason is very simple. Growing conditions indoors will be very different.

title: Elizabeth Layton Bride Of Benjamin Shepherd
description: Elizabeth Rose Layton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Layton of New Canaan, Conn., was married last evening to Benjamin Allen Shepherd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Robert Shepherd. also of New Canaan. Rabbi Samuel Silver, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Layton home.

title: Flood Control Perils Bog Turtle
description: PLAINFIELD ALTHOUGH few people in Central Jersey have ever seen the rare and unassuming bog turtle, the tiny creature is casting a monstrous shadow over thousands of floodaggrieved residents of the area.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TARANTEL (Bar Blue). Singapore Oct. 10 and Port Kelag 17; sails from Kane St., Brooklyn.

title: Adaline Havemeyer Frelinghuysen Is Bride of William Blair Meyer Jr.
description: The marriage of Adaline Havemeyer Frelinghuysen to William Blair Meyer Jr. took place yesterday afternoon in Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. G. Douglas Krumbhaar performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the bride's uncle. Retired Bishop Anson Phelps Stokes of Massachusetts, and by the Rev Theodore Evans.

title: Rx on Risks for Athletes
description: GREENWICH THEY were tall and they were short, they were broad and they were slim, and they all shared youthful passion for high school football. On this particular day, entire careers were on the linenot along the savaged grass of a noisy stadium but in the paneled solemnity of a doctor's office.

title: A Modest Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Panama Canal is gradually building into an issue of historic importance, and the nought in this corner is that when the decisive debate finally reaches the floor of the Senate in February or March, it should be carried to the American people on national television.

title: The Standings
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Jessica Fredell Amer Is Married to Eli Abbe
description: Jessica Fredell Amer and Eli Abbe, Yale University graduates with the class of 74, were married yesterday afternoon in Leonia, N. J. Mayor Sondra Greenberg of Englewood, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Arner, parents of the bride. Mr. and Mrs. James Abbe Jr. of Jericho, L. I. are the bridegroom's parents.

title: Drought in Northwest Is Broken But California's Is Unaffected
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)The agricultural drought in the Pacific Northwest has been broken but the drought in the northern two thirds of California continues unabated, according to the National Weather Service.

title: Polaris Missile Test Delayed
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 10 (AP) The scheduled test of a British Polaris missile has been delayed by technical problems that stopped the countdown with one second to go. Yesterday's launching was to have been the first in a series of flight tests of the improved submarinebased missile, but it was called off when downrange tracking stations reported mechanical difficulties.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Margaret Ellis teaches and coaches at St. Paul's Episcopal School in Mobile, Ala. This article is reprinted by permission from women Sports Magazine, July 1977. Copyright  1977 by womenSports Publishing Company.

title: Morgan Stanley Hangs Out a Retail Shingle
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, the presitgious investment banking house, announced last week that it was opening a retail office in New York. The idea is to attract wealthy individuals and small institutions as clients.

title: Federally Financed Harlem Housing Project Marks 40 Years
description: This is my estate, 67yearold Nixcola Ramsay said as she sat in the shade in the courtyard of the Harlem River Houses at West 152d Street yesterday afternoon. Daisy Ivory, 89, who sat nearby, smiled and agreed.

title: Irish Beat Pitt Team By 19 to 9
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 Pittsburgh's 13game winning streak and hopes to repeat as college football's national champion ended today as Notre Dame rallied with 13 points in the last quarter for a 199 victory in the opening game for both teams.

title: LOSUIT AGAINST AGNEW DELAYED PENDING RULING
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP)Action on a $2 million suit against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew has been put off, pending a ruling by the Supreme Curt on whether he should be compelled to testify under oath.

title: Impediment
description: APRUSSIAN surgeon of the early 19th century, Johann Friedrich Dieffenbach, used to snip off the end and edges of a stutterer's tongue in an attempt to cure him. Alexander Melville Bell treated the ailment by having the stutterer bite down on the blade of a papercutter while speaking, so that the tongue would be disciplined to Rood habits and broken off from had ones

title: Loretta Otte Is Wed To James. J. Mullin
description: Loretta Otte, daughter of June C. Otte of Port Washington, L.I. and William N. Otte of New York, was married yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation to James J. Mullin, also of Port Washington. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mullin. Canon Robert Lewis performed the ceremony. There was a reception at the Union League Club.

title: Ann S. Forshay Is Bride Of Eugene C. Breaznell
description: In the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church yesterday afternoon, Ann Stewart Forshay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Field Forshay of Garden City, was married to Eugene Carder Breaznell, son of Mrs. Earle Carder of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Eugene Breaznell. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg performed the ceremony.

title: Boulanger20thCentury Music Was Born in Her Classroom
description: A ll the music world knows Mademoiselle, just as they know Aaron and Virgil, the first American students of Nadia Boulanger. This extraordinary Frenchwoman, who celebrates her 90th birthday this Friday, has been Mademoiselle to countless musicians since Aaron Copland and Virgil Thomson discovered her in France in 1921. Paris was the place to be in the 20's. Music was clearly moving away from German domination, and as the word spread about an exceptional teacher in France, aspiring music students came in droves to study with her.

title: Race Excursions
description: M.V. Block Island, capacity 500 spectators; leaves daily during Cup races at 10:30 A.M. from Hammett's Wharf; tickets $30 per race or $100 for fourrace book; main deck includes bar and snack bar; Nelseco Navigation Company, New London, Conn., phone (203) 4427891.

title: Two Mavericks to Battle For Yachting's Great Cup
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10Initial consideration of Alan Bond and Robert E. Turner 3d racing for the America's Cup next week might suggest gyrations within the tomb of Harold Stirling (Mike) Vanderbilt, the genteel threetime defender of yachting's great prize, because Bondy and Terrible Ted are outrageous outbacks. On the other hand the solemnity of the America's Cup experience this summer has subdued them both; bent them to the wheel of convention and calm.

title: TODAY'S MATCHES
description: 11 A.M.Women's Doubles Final: Martkna Navratilova. Betty Stove vs. Renee RichardsBetiyann Stuart.

title: O'Neill Asserts Social Security Will Not Be Allowed to Go Broke
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 10 (AP)Fears that the Social Security system will go broke are unfounded, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House, said today. The, truth of the matter is that the Government of the United States is not oing to allow the Social Security system to go broke, Representative O'Neill, Democrat of Massachusetts, said. He held a news conference with the House Majorlty Leader, Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Pubic Affairs, where they had spoken with students and faculty.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: United Press Intonation BIRTHDAY ATTEMPT TO CROSS ATLANTIC: Double Eagle, a heliumfilled black and silver balloon, lifting off from gravel pit at Marshfield, Mass., Ftiday night. Yesterday, the two balloonists, Ben Abruzzo, 47, and Maxie Anderson, 44, were celebrating Mr. Anderson's birthday with cake as they made fifteenth recorded attempt by balloon at the 3,000mile crossing. Fourteen previous attempts failed, and several ended in death. The balloon gondola is a twinhulled boat with radio and survival gear.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Saturday, Sept. 10, 12th day. Weather cloudy, track muddy for five races, good thereafter.

title: Old Mines Mapped in Safety Drive
description: TRENTON LIKE a mariner's chart showing reefs, shoals and sunken hulks, a map of New Jersey's pastdays when iron forges belched smoke and cannonballs were cast for the Colonial artilleryis being drawn for the safety of the future. It may save camper from tumbling down a mine shaft or deter a builder from putting shopping center on land that is as pitted and vorous as a sponge.

title: Werner Herzog: Film Is Not the Art of Scholars, But of Illiterates
description: Werner Herzog, the 34yearold German director, whom critic Richard Eder recently described as the most unusual and  the greatest of the talented moviemakers who have appeared in West Germany in the past decade, stopped over in New York the other day to complete arrangements for the imminent showing at the New York Film Festival of his feature Heart of Glass, in which the actors played under hypnosis. The film is about a mad glass manufacturer's futile quest for a lost process for making ruby glass. Herzog's deeply personal cinematic depictions of human suffering and strange, even mad, human activity are much in demand at film festivals. And two of his films, Aguirre, the Wrath of God (about the mad, powerobsessed conquistador) and Stroszek (about three German losers adrift in Wisconsin), are playing here to full art houses.

title: Colleges Take Aim on Fairfield Market
description: COTINUINGUATION programs, while not new in the StamfordGreenwich area of Connecticut, are burgeoning forth as never before. With some indications of haste, private universities are offering credit and noncredit courses off campus to take advantage of the influx of employees and their families who have accompanied corporate headquarters into the area. The companies have enthusiastically supported the programs and some businessmanagement and related courses are being held in of the headuuarters.

title: Hsuehming Wang Married
description: Hsuehming Wang, a management ??? with the Bankers Trust Com??? was married yesterday in Cam??? Mass., to James Thomas Healy who is, with the Manufacturers ??? Company. The Rev. Edward M. D Paoli performed the Roman Catholic ???ony in the Appleton Chapel at Harvard University. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Chenrhua Wang of Newton, Mass., and,Mr. and Mrs. Healy of Doylestown, Pa.

title: Rail Escalator Is Stalled by Dispute
description: In addition to the array of potential burdens faced by commuters arriving in Penn Station., there is an escalator between tracks 15 and 16 that has not worked in more than a year because Amtrak and the Long Island Rail Road, whose passengers the escalator is supposed to sere, cannotagree on who will pay how much of the repair costs.

title: Italy's Besieged Managers
description: TURIN, Italy  A thin red ribbon stretched across the partially closed gates of the Fiat headquarters here in late June  a symbolic closing as bluecoated workers picketed nearby, waving handlettered posters proclaiming a strike over the terms of a new labor contract.

title: The Gains They Made in the 60's Have Evaporated
description: On a crisp October afternoon last year, a group activists in New York City's millionstrong Puerto Rican community gathered at a Lexington Avenue hotel at the invitation of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The first nationwide study on Puerto Ricans by a Federal agency had been released by the commission the previous day, and they were there to discuss it. The report's message had been bleak. It did not take long for even this largely middleclass audience to take out its anger and despair on the messengers.

title: The World
description: When the Secretary of State, Cyrus R. Vance, described his recent talks in Peking as useful and helpful, the remark was clearly a diplomatic euphemism for, well, failure. Since then, the Chinese have given their view of the talks, and they agree.

title: CRIME
description: A skillful writer can get away with using the most conventional of materials, and Robert L. Duncan does so in TEMPLE DOGS (Morrow, $8.95). This is a novel of Big Business, and in it can be found our usual assortment of friends. There is the flinty, amoral tycoon, interested only in making a profit even if it means tinkering with national governments. There are the usual executive types, some craven, some bootlicking, some clutching a dagger in nervous hands. There is a ruthless general with a computer. You have met them all. You will meet them again.

title: BYRD BIDS LANCE QUIT AFTER SENATORS HEAR TESTIMONY THURSDAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Senate Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, said today that the resignation of Bert Lance, director of the.01fice of Management and Budget, was inevitable, and suggested that Mr. Lance should resign after his appearance next Thursday before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee.

title: The Man Behind the Courthouse Mall
description: PETER D. LEIBOWITS lives in Harrison, works in Manhattan and builds shopping centers throughout the nation. The huge mall that he is planning for downtown White Plains on the site of the old courthouse and in the area around it is his first project at home.

title: Passionate Scholar
description: AS explorer of a virtually unknown tradition of Judaismthe history and documents of its mystic teaching  Gershom Scholem's achievement has already put a generation of readers in his debt. Although frequently derided, he has intrepidly, single handedly, almost monomanically, pursued the task of saving the literature of Jewish mysticism, interpreting its dicta, retrieving it from the position of contempt in which it had been held by religious rationalists and embarrassed assimilationists and restoring it to an estate of respect, honor and importance. In On Jews & Judaism in Crisis, edited with grace and ingenuity by Werner J. Dannhauser, Scholem emerges as a man of immense passion, elegance of expression, capaciousness of intellect and relevance as well. Now approaching 80, Scholem has taught since 1925 at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, where he is professor emeritus.

title: Is It Dj Vu? No, It's the Return Of the Palazzo
description: Picture Gloria Swanson descending the staircase in Sunset Boulevard. She's making a comeback as Norma Desmond, crazed silentscreen star. For a movie of 1950, the setting is suitably symbolic.

title: Sterility Linked to Pesticide Spurs Fear on Chemical Use
description: For perhaps a year, the question kept coming up among the dozen workers in one section of the Occidental Chemical Company plant at Lathrop. Calif: Why weren't any of them having children?

title: Headliners
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, once chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has been nominated by President Carter as an ambassadoratlarge and chairman of the United States delegation to next month's Conference on European Security and Cooperation in Belgrade. One reason for the choice is that, despite a nineyear absence from public life, Mr. Goldberg's skill in negotiating with the Russians is still respected. The Soviet Union has been accused by the United States of failing to meet some terms of the 1975 Helsinki agreement; and these accusations will figure prominently in the coming EastWest discussions.

title: 25 Jumpers Gain Final of Gold Cup
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10  Six horsesthe Crimson Tide, Do Right, The Cardinal, Grande, Balbuco and Puebloscored clean rounds today in the qualifying competition of the American Gold Cup.

title: Fossil Scientists At Parley Differ Over True Man
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept 10Many of the world's leading authorities on human evolution met here this week to sort but a vast array of fossils of early man and nearman that even they often find confusing. They left today agreeing to disagree on some of the most basic questions of man's evolution.

title: Rep. Shipley Won't Seek Reelection
description: OLNEY, Ill., Sept. 10 (UPI)Representative George. E. Shipley, an Illinois Democrat who has served 10 terms ini Congress, announced today that he would not seek reelection next year. The 50yearold Mr. Shipley said that back problems were preventing him from devoting, full time to the job. Donald H. Watson 45, Mr. Shipley's brotherinlaw and his administrative assistant for the last 19 years, said he would seek the 22d Congressional District post.

title: TV VIEW
description: Sex and violence have long been the two hypersensitive areas of TV programming. Now that the opponents of violence seem to be getting their way (the networks claim there will be less of it this season), sex is going to be served up bounteously. Some observers credit the decline of violence TV programming to the campaigns of various pressure groups. Those of a more cynical bent note that police/detective shows, chief offenders in the violence category, had proliferated to the point of diminishing ratings returns anyway.

title: IN BRIEF
description: THE SENATE VOTED, 62 to 30, to kill an amendment that would have kept major oil companies from acquiring. any more of the nation's coal and Uranium reserves. Defeat of the measurewhich had been attached by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to one of the five bills that make up the Senate version of the Administration's national energy packageIs a strong signal that Congress will probably not come to grips with the broader Issue of complete horizontal divestiture this session.

title: Guilford's Living Legacy
description: GUILFORD THE residents of Guilford have a strong pride in their town, coupled with a conviction that the rest of the world should share their enthusiasm. And the Leete's Island Garden Club Project, called Legacy, being held this Tuesday at the Henry Whitfield house, is not a fundraising enterprise, according to the cochairmen, Mrs. Crawford Thompson and Mrs. William Horton, but simply an event for people's enjoyment.

title: Subcontracted Courses Stir Controversy
description: ALARMED by declining enrollment and skyrocketing expenses, many colleges and universities have turned to private subcontractors for help in developing offcampus programs to attract employed adults and others who have shown little interest in traditional curriculums.

title: Sarah Byrne, Aide With a State Unit, Bride of John Quirk
description: Sarah Myers Byrne, an investigative aide with the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct in Albany, was married yesterday afternoon to John Benjamin Quirk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Quirk of Dalton, Mass.

title: Outbreaks of Crime and Disease Are Shaking Italy's Deep South
description: NAPLES, Sept. 10Italy's deep south is making news again after one of its periods of seeming inertia when the rest of the nation tends to forget about it and its ancient unresolved problems.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The Japanese elevate their finest actors to the rank of National Living Treasure. In England, actors can earn knighthoods. In America, the actor has no such honor to look forward to. I do not mean suggest that we ought to institute a Hall of Fame, or some other form of institutionalized elitism.

title: LEBANESE ARMY IS SET TO STOP WAR IN SOUTH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10  Lebanese regular troops are standing by to move into the border area with Israel under an agreement that could end the fighting there.

title: MARKETS
description: Prices on the stock market plunged last week mid fears of another possible credittightening move by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: One of the most common myths in clublevel tennis is that ground strokes should be hit on a horizontal plane. As a result, many weekend hackers stand on the baseline trying to drive the ball as straight and as hard as they can so that it just skims the net.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Sept. 17Greater Rockaway Auto Sports Society 65mile T.S.D. rally; start at Livingston Mall, junction of Eisenhower Parkway and South Orange Avenue, Livingston, N.J. Registration: 7 P.M.; first car off 7:31. Information: Atwell Haines (201)5841643 or (201)5844758.

title: Miss Correa Bride of James W. Lapsley
description: Catherine Hewitt Correll, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James William Correll of Suffern, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Tuxedo (N.Y.) Club, to James William Lapsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lapsley of Paget, Bermuda. The Rev. Melvin Campbell of the Westside Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: Pro Football Preview: Viewing Options Limited
description: The pro football season begins for real next Sunday and the primary question for its followers in this metropolitan region is how to see it. Few will be happy with the options for the following reasons:

title: An Uneasy Canada Does Not, Somehow, Fault Trudeau
description: MONTREALFor Canadians, this has been a decidely downbeat summer: They are actively and simultaneously considering the breakup of their country and the breakdown of their way of life. When someone is not lecturing on the dangers of the independence movement in Quebec, someone else is sadly noting the decline of the Canadian dollar and the accompanying inability of the economy to cope with unemployment, inflation, low productivity and a costly foreign debt.

title: A Champion Too Perfect to Root For
description: She has the prettiest dresses, the most polished appearance and the best strokes in women's tennis. Sometimes Chris Evert must wonder why she does not have the crowds.

title: Cornell Names CoCaptains
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP)Tony Anzalone of Hamburg, N.Y., and Terr Lee of Medford, Mass., were elected co captains of Cornell University's football team last night.

title: PryBulk SetupFor Containers Gains Giound
description: Ever since the port opened its first specialized container terminal in Elizabeth 15 years ago ship operators, and eqUipment manufacturers, have beenbusy discovering new ways to put, cargoes into boxes. The latest development in this continuing and successful effort is a new. Port system for shipping dry dotes bulk materials, developed, jointly by SeaLand Service Inc., one of the world's laigest container lines and TriWall Containers.

title: POLITICS
description: NOW that the number of candidates for Mayor of New York City has been drastically reduced, the television stations can go back briefly to selling soap before the finals of the city election and the New Jersey gubernatorial race again interrupt football games and movie reruns.

title: Lawyer Asserts Ink on Hughes Will Matches That on Known Documents
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)A lawyer representing supporters of the socalled Mormon will of the late Howard Hughes asserted that ink used to write the disputed document matched ink on papers known to have been written by the billionaire.

title: Judith A. Armstrong Is Bride
description: The marriage of Judith Amelia Armstrong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Foster Armstrong of Stamford, Conn.. to Francis Patrick Cunnion Jr., took place yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Ronald S. James performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Village Justice Cunnion of Tuckahoe, N. Y., and Mrs. Cunnion.

title: Namath Is Booed in Rams 240 Defeat
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10A cascade of boos poured over Joe Namath last night when he reentered the game unexpectedly in the third quarter with the Los Angeles Rams trailing the Oakland Raiders, 210.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: SINCE repairing or replacing windowscreen mesh is a fairly simple job that requires only ordinary hand tools, there is no reason why anyone should tolerate tears or holes for any length of time. Small holes or tears can usually be patched, but if there are many, it pays to install new screening over the existing frame.

title: CHESS
description: Morrnua, Spair. The rule regarding a lead in development is to attack, yet, like all generalities of strategy, there are exceptions, and besides, the rule does not spell out how the at tacking is to be done.

title: Brown Sets New Technology Policy Expected to Favor China's Needs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Defense Secretary Harold Brown, in a key decision that may spur the sale of American material with a military capacity to China, has quietly moved to ease the export of some defenserelated equipment while restricting the transfer of design and manufacturing skills.

title: 77 Hit: Novel on French Left in 78
description: PARIS, Sept. 10  A book purporting to paint a realistically catastrophic scenario of what would happen if the alliance of Socialists and Communists took power in France after legislative elections next March is climbing rapidly on the bestseller lists here.

title: The Nation
description: The Justice Department has made public its indictment of Tongsun Park, and it provides new details of the bribery that was the heart of his alleged efforts to influence Congressmen for the benefit of the South Korean Government. However, it is uplikely that Mr, Park, who is now in South Korea, will stand trial soon. The United States has no extradition treaty with South Korea and the Seoul Government, while denying any connection with Mr. Park's lobbying activities, said it would not force him to return to Washington despite personal request from President Carter and attempts in Congress to cut off aid.

title: The State's Disappearing Heritage
description: CONNECTICUT is disappearing. By small degrees, by hundreds of small decisions by property owners and redevelopmentagency directors, by fires, by probate tangles, the buildings, villages and seascapes that are among Connecticut's greatest assets and drawing cards are being pulled down.

title: Columbia Scores, 107
description: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Sept. 10 Kevin Burns strengthened his bid to become Columbia University's starting quarterback by completing seven of 12 passes for 118 yards and a touchdown in one half of play today to lead the Lions to a 107 scrimmage victory over East Stroudsburg (Pa.) State.

title: THE PLIGHT OF DISCARD D'ESTANG
description: PARIS. The honeymoon was short and the marriage is on the rocks. Things simply have not worked out between France and her young President, the French Kennedy, Valery Giscard d'Estaing. Unless the situation changes rapidly, the French will win the Western European sweepstakes on where the Communists finally win a solid share of power. Portugal took the early lead, only to be passed by Italy, which has now given way to the new frontrunner, France.

title: House Tours.
description: Staten island Institute, Barnett Shepherd A. cottage on the former estate of the architect Ernest Flagg is included in a house tour Oct. 23 on Staten Island. A listing of some of the other upcoming tours in the New York area appears oapage 8.

title: The Canal Terms, Argued From Different Premises
description: STANFORD, Calif.In his frenetic blitz to gain public approval of the two Panama Canal treaties, President Carter has stressed that he wishes to dispel misinformation by laying out the facts. Thus, he and his chief negotiators, Ellsworth Bunker and Sol M. Linowitz, repeatedly have assured the public that the United States would have the permanent right to defend the canal by sending troops into Panama in time of crisis. Additionally, the White House says that United States warships would have the permanent right to transit the canal expeditiously and without conditions, for indefinite period.

title: A Harvest for Bridgeport's Needy
description: EASTON SEVERAL mornings each week corps of volunteers turns up at a twoacre parcel of land here to till the soil to raise vegetables to feed the street people and the innercity poor of the Bridgeport area.

title: The Region
description: Department of silver linings: After sharply declining for years, New York City's population may be stabilizing, with important implications for the financially strapped city. A continued loss of population means a continued loss of revenue, both in terms of fewer residents to tax and of a reduction of Federal aid, calculated largely on a population basis. A stable population would help stabilize revenues.

title: Clarissa Rowe, Stephen Batzell, Teacher, Wed
description: St. Christopher Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Clarissa Rowe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Rowe of Washington and Chatham, to Stephen W. Batzell, son of Mrs. Elmer E. Batzell, also of Washington, and the late Mr. Batzell. The Rev. Steven Russell performed the ceremony.

title: When Day Care Works
description: When Johnnie first started,he'd cry every morning, says Zolla Allen. Now he cries when he goes home.

title: An Internal Struggle Shakes Spain's Governing Body
description: MADRID, Sept. 10  A power struggle within Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's badly organized governing party has unsettled Spain's threemonthold parliamentary democracy, and a bleak economic picture, compounded by runaway inflation and the prospect of an autumn of labor disputes, has clouded matters further.

title: Affirmed, $4.40, Beats Alydar by a Nose
description: Harbor View Farm's Affirmed continued to show who's boss in the dramatic rivalry he's been waging with Calumet's Alydar by capturing the $112,950 Futurity yesterday before 25,479 specators at Belmont Park.

title: The Region
description: In an age of diminishing influence for the oldline political boss, Joseph M. Margiotta has demonstrated that party organization can still count.

title: Teacher Earns Pay Without Work
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel and the Board of Education have been unable to retire a school administrator who has been receiving full pay and other awards amounting to $264,000 even though she has not reported to work in 13 years.

title: Twin Speech: A Language of Their Own
description: SAN DIEGOPlaying with a doll house in the speech therapy center at Children's Hospital here, Virginia and Grace Kennedy, identical twins who will be 7 years old next month, carried on an animated conversation broken by outbursts of childish laughter.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Better management of cityowned properties has resulted in an increase of $250,000 in commercial rents collected by the city in the last three months, Mayor Beame said.

title: Behind the Morris PhaseOut
description: NINETEEN seventySeven will be remembered by the families of the Morris Elementary Schbol in Rockville, Centre as the year in which summer never came.

title: FAREWELL TO FOREST HILLS
description: Q ueens Boulevard, despite the freshsqueezed breakfast orange juice at the TBone Diner on the corner of Continental, has not qualified as the road to romance for a long time. Still, before the United States Tennis Association announced that it was divorcing Forest Hills, marrying Abe Beame and taking its U.S. Open tennis championships to the city's larger Flushing Meadow Park in 1978, Queens Boulevard was the route on (or under) which tens of thousands traveled the same time each year to a very special affair: the first and often the only time many of us were able to see the great virtuososwithrackets perform, to watch a Ken Rosewall or Maria Bueno gliding across the grass, or a Don Budge or a Maureen Connolly bludgeoning tennis balls, or a Lew Hoad or a Gussie Moran doing what few others could do for the Tshirt. On the other 353 days a year, give or take 12 at Wimbledon, the game of tennis could have been off somewhere with Judge Crater officiating in the umpire's chair for all anybody noticed back in the times before the current Tennis Epidemic. But Forest Hills was different. It was always a firstrate event, and fascinating.

title: EDWARD B. LOCKWOOD
description: Edward B. Lockwood, who for more than 30 years was president of the Park Avenue Association and who was the man responsible for placing memorial Christmas trees along the Avenue during the winter holiday season, died yesterday at his home. He was a lifetime resident of Manhattan and was 77 years old.

title: Fashion
description: Yves Saint Laurent is the most influential fashion designer in the world today. Whenever he presents a collection, his ideas, through inspiration or imitation, affect clothes women wear, everywhere. This fall, Saint Laurent is still The King of Fashion. He has designed a couture collection which carries his dreams of fantasy dressing even further than the peasant romance of last year: clothes that echo the rich realms of the Orient, the harem, Victorian and turnofthecentury lavishness. And, as some sharp observers have noted, there is a brandnew direction  loose, sensuous, freeflowing. This collection, with its brilliant multiplicity of ideas, may be more subtle in its impact, but his influence, as always will he felt. Because of this continuing effect on fashion, this Magazine asked the eminent writer Anthony Burgess to take a look at Yves Saint Laurent man and artist, worldfamous vet wellknown by few  and report on him from a personal point of view.

title: The Grandeur That Was Hoad
description: It should be a time for tradition. When the United States Open tennis championships end today at Forest Hills, an era will end, an era that lasted from Bill Tilden and Helen Wills to Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert, an era that spanned more than half a century. All the old names should be stuffed and mounted at Forest Sports Hills today because next year a new of site at Flushing The runes Meadow is planned for the tournament. But there will be no gathering of the old names today, a casualty of the bitterness between the United States Tennis Association and the West Side Tennis Club. But one of the old names is here anyway, one of the best names and one of the best peopleLew Hoad, the Australian with the flat flaxen hair and the flat serve.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Some Words of Praise For State Government

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11 A.M. Channel 2 Newsmakers': Stephen Berger. executive director of the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Dogs Owners With a Wall St. Scent Gather for Show
description: TARRYTOWN IT will be neither the bulls nor the bears, but the dogs, overrunning Tarrytown today as the Westchester Kennel Club, dominated by Wall Street executives, stages its 60th showthis time at Lyndhurst, the national landmark on Route 9, just south of the Tappan Zee Bridge. Of the club's 17 members, 10 have been actively associated with New York's financial district in the brokerage, banking, law and affiliated fields. Peter Knoop, serving his eighth year as club president, a syndicate manager for the stockbrokers, LaidlawCoggeshall, while Judson Streicher, the show chairman and club treasurer, has had a seat on the New York Stock Exchange for more than 25 years.

title: ART

title: Debating Life Experience
description: IF A college gives an accountant crkdit for his work experience, shobld it give a woman credit for bearing and raising children? If canoe trip down the Connecticut River is worth six credits in biology, how many credits in penology should an inmate get for spending a year in prison?

title: Article 3  No Title
description: When did you last see anything new in dance?I don't mean just a work you have never seen before, or a new aancer, or a new choreographer, or even, for that matter, a new company. I mean something newsomething different. Personally, I know when the last time wascontain your impatience, for I shall disclose all in good time but I'm not so sure about the time before that. Alwin Nikolais perhaps. Certainly Nikolais's use of lighting and his conception of theatrical dance as a kind of Wagnerian Gesamtkunstwerk was very new, but his actual choreography was clearly a personal development from the school of Hanya Holm and, through her, Mary Wigman. However strange the blossom, Nikolais's roots were always showing. This is how it is, and how it should be. But Pilobolus Dance Theater is something different. It really is something new. The more I see of the company the more convinced I am, not merely of their novelty, but their actual, unmistakable, almost incredible, newness.

title: Youth and Sports: Beware Of Underage Chauvinists
description: Nobody ever wanted to play baseball more than I did. But the world began to conspire against me as early as my ninth year when I was refused membership in the Knothole Gang, a freepass club sponsored by our Meridian, Miss., pro baseball teamfor boys only.

title: CORRECTION
description: Due to an editing error, it was stated in the article A Capital InvestmentDominican Tourist Gamble (Travel Section, Aug. 28) that the Club Dominicus Americanus, a coastal resort in the Dominican Republic, was a project of the Dominican Government, not yet completed. In fact, the Club Dominicus Americanus is owned by M. Wayne Fuller of New York and was opened last February. Mr. Fuller points out that 60 individual units are now in operation and that construction will shortly begin on two additions, one of 180 more individual units, the other sevenstory, 260,room hotel.

title: South Korean Newspapers Print Translation of Park Indictment, Accompanied by Harsh Criticism of
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 10 In a surprise move, the South Korean Government released today a translation of the full text of the 36count indictment of Tongsun Park in connection with an alleged influencebuying operation in Washington.

description: IN this youthoriented world, more and more the young are teaching their elders: how to dress, how to eat, how to shake off sham and pretense. And, in business, the new generation of entrepreneur has the knack of working at what it enjoysand making it pay.

title: The Life Out Here Is Worth the Price
description: HOW much do we sacrifice to live in a house under the spreading chestnut tree and far from the next house in the suburbs of New York CityWestchester County? Our sacrifice is great when one considers the higher cost of living manifested in higher taxes, higher grocery bills, higher clothing bills, higher entertainment prices and higher costs of keeping up with the Joneses.

title: A Moving Boheme at City Opera
description: The first Boheme of the New York City Opera's fall season at the New York State Theater Friday night offered no surprises. These were familiar singers in familiar roles, working with minimal rehearsal in a warhorse opera in an ancient production.

description: WHEN Henry David Thoreau, jailed for nonpayment of taxes in protest against slavery and the MexicanAmerican War, was visited by his friend Ralph Waldo Emerson, the latter asked, David, what are you doing in there? Thoreau answered, Ralph, what are you doing out there?

Located near Wilton in a quaint hamlet known as Cannon Crossing, the twostory red construction is one of five 19thcentury buildings clustered near a picturepostcard railroad station and a gentle river rippled occasionally by animated birdlife.

Some will also be looking into allegations that senior officials the Nixon and Ford Administrations either ignored or covered up that misconduct.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The recent death of the incomparable Groucho Marx, frail and ailing at the age of 87 and the center of the sort of custody battle that is most often fought over children, evokes all sorts of associations and memories, none of them sentimental. I think of Groucho lolling in a canoe that is being paddled by Thelma Todd in Horsefeathers (1932), and en thusiastically greeting each new arrival in that stuffed stateroom in A Night at the Opera (1935) with a special leer for the manicurist. I see him instructing the contestants on You Bet Your Life about the magic wordsausages, it says at the bottom (or is it top?) of my TV screenand surviving, unscathed, the witlessness of a single act in Double Dynamite (1951), whose title referred to Groucho's costar, Jahe Russell. 1 recall also one of Groucho's funnier inprovised performances 10 years ago at lunch in the King Cole Bar of the St. Regis. An especially firm, unsmiling maitre d stood by as Groucho studied the menu.

title: AT RANDOW
description: HE was born to prosperity; at Columbia he fell in with friends destined to becometalented and important he left his job on Wall Street six years before the Crash and joined one of the most lively publishersin New York; then he was able to buy out the best part of that business (The Modem Library) and founded his own firm; he was blessed with two partners who were both capable and congenial; he was married twice, each time to a lovely woman (Sylvia Sidney, briefly, and Phyllis Fraser, enduringly); he had equal talents for finding.

title: British Auto Workers Strike Ends
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 10 (Reuters)A 10week strike by car parts workers that crippled a large section of the British auto industry ended today. A meeting of 1,200 toolroom workers at the plant of Lucas Ltd. voted by a narrow margin to accept a pay offer and return to work on Monday.

description: This summer, New York got a good whiff of itself. The unusually sultry air kept odors hovering about the city like flies at a picnic: low, lingering, and is large numbers.

The shed never got built, he said, because O.S.H.A. regulations made it cost too much.

Sept. 10The Thanksgiving night feast Rutgers enjoyed 10 months ago came back to haunt the Scarlet Knights today as Colgate turned the tables on them for that turnovers and scored a decisive and satisfying 230 victory before a near capacity crowd of 12,000 at Andy Kerr field.

Vance met today with James Shen, the Ambassador of the Chinese Nationalist Government in Taiwan, to review United StatesChinese relations afte' Mr. Vance's visit to Peking. It was the first time in almost three years that an envoy from Taiwan was received by a Secretary of State.

title: Treasures

Visitors come from all over, the world to see it; and it is for this collection, as much as for Giorgione, Rembrandt, Rubens and Poussin, that the Hermitage is now famous. Irreplaceable is a big word in this context.

description: IN THE RUNNING: Arnold Palmer was all smiles after the second round of the $200,000 B.C. open golf tournament at Endicott, N.Y. His total 134 left him in second place, two strokes behind Gil Morgan.

description: HASTINGSONHUDSON BEFORE they paved over much of Westchester, some of the cheerier sounds of that bygone era were the greetings of wagonmen, those enterprising souls who brought their green groceries, eggs or even macaroons directly to the kitchen door.

title: 26,000 Matador Cars Recalled
description: DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP)The American Motors Corporation recalled 26,000 of its 1976 Matador cars today to replace flexible fan.blades. The same kind of blades kilted a mechanic and injured 11 others in accidents involving Ford models, and 4e Ford Motor Company had to !recall 12 million cars. American Motors said tad no reports of injuries from Its own fans.

title: Airline Flight Attendants Strike
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept.10 (AP) Five hundred and fifty flight attendants of Trains International Airlines went on strike against the Oaklandbased charter service today, ending 20 months of contract talks between negotiators for the airlin and Teamsters Local 2707, according to Marvin L. Griswold, head of the local. Issues include wages, working hours and grievance procedures.

title: What's Doing in CAIRO
description: BRIDGING THE CENTURIESModern Cairo, the largest city in Africa and the Arab world, has a population estimated at 8 million. The modern city is centered in an area developed for the westerners who followed Napoleon's occupation in 1798. It is a European city, complete with French etoiles and decorative balconies, though coated with a layer of desert sand. But Cairo is also the city of the pharaohs, who built the pyramids 5,000 years ago, the city of the ancient Romans, the city of the Coptic Christians and the Islamic city of Qahira. Many tourists never explore the old parts of Cairo, with their narrow, winding, streets and hordes of people, still curious at the sight of westerner. But those who do get a glimpse of a culture and life style far different from that of the West. Prices in the Egyptian capital are still relatively low by American standards, but they've been under severe pressures from creeping inflation in recent years.

title: Wendy Horgan Wed To H. F. Gerber Jr.

On Friday night it was Heidi Lehwalder's turn, and her program was perhaps the most unusual of all simply because her instrument, the harp, is heard relatively infrequently in a solo context.

title: Private Schools Gaining Strength

Of the 15 schools for which figures were available, seven reported increases over last year, and five said their enrollments had remained the same. Only three said they had lost students.

title: Ugandan Girl Gets New Lease on Life
description: ROBERT DONNO will never forget the first time he laid eyes on Robinah Nakabuye. It was two days before Thanksgiving, he recalled, and she was sitting in an ambulance parked at the John F. Kennedy International Airport. The 12yearold Ugandan girl had flown here under the sponsorship of Mr. Donno's club, the Manhasset Rotarians, to unapron heart curgerv.

title: Quake Strikes Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10 (UPI) A new earthquake measuring 5.4 on the Richter scale shook the eastern Indonesian islands yesterday, the Jakarta Geophysical Service reported today. Several tremors have been recorded since an Aug. 19 quake left 105 dead. There have been no reports of new casualties or damage Any quake registering over 5.0 on the Richter scale can cause damage.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Most people finri it.lard enough trying to shoot good movies of family. friends or special occasions, so it is not hard to understand why when the film finally comes back from the processor they put off the job of cutting out poorly exposed, jumpy, or outoffocus shots, as well as rearranging scenes in a logical order and adding titles where required.

title: A Place To Share
description: ONE OF New York's finest re. cently tried to arrest a nut climbing the side of a big pile of rocks in Fort Tryon Park a couple of weeks ago. I am a teacher, explained the climber. I am teaching these people mountain climbing. The Apple Skills Exchange had struck again.

title: New Bronze Door for Vatican
description: ROME, Sept. 10 (UPI)  St. Peter's Basilica will get a new bronze door depicting the slave trade in America And a massacre of Roman hostages by the Nazis as symbols of evil, the Vatican Radio said today. It said the 12ton door by an Italian sculptor, Luciano Minguzzi, would be installed on Pope Paul VPs 80th birthday, Sept. 26.

title: Demonic Children
description: FOR almost two centuries, children in novels have figured as erdblems of hope and goads to the conscience of readers. In the past three years, in the pages of more than a dozen popular paperbacks, young people have become emissaries of death and destruction. Books about children sired bymachines and possessed by devils, about prodigious young killers and their victims, fill the display racks of supermarkets, drugstores and newsstandsand the imaginations of millions who read them.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE AGE of automation has gone confusingly for my friend Iry over in East Northport. He drives a car, and he can push onoff buttons, but more recent innovations have played havoc with his time and temperament.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Your article The Sun Also Rises on RareBooks (Aug. 28) is accurate in general but is incorrect about typed manuscripts. It implies that typed manuscripts offered by rarebook dealers are being palmed off as original work sheets typed by an author as part of his orher creative processand to beware of such deceit. If offered by reputable dealer, a sheet is never purported to be anything but a typed manuscript given to the writer to be signed.

description: IT beats going to a psychiatrist. That is how Joan Rubinstein, a Merrick housewife, explained her reasons for participating in Hofstra University's Gray Wig Alumni Repertory Theater Company.

description: Above: A semiperm gives hair body and shape and can be fingercombed into place. Left: A permanent set on rollers rather than rods gives curls but no frizziness.

title: Alienated Singer Goes Home Again
description: KATONAH SLEPT on people's floors and wandered around the streets of the Lower East Side, but I always could take the train back to Westchester on the weekends and sort of get my blue jeans pressed, recalled the 30yearold singersongwriter, Loudon Wainwright 3d, about his struggling years.

title: West German Aides See Malaise Because of Terrorism
description: BONN, Sept. 10  West German officials, pointing to a malaise in the country, called for a fight against terrorism at a funeral service today for three policemen who were killed in a kidnapping attack in Cologne on Monday.

title: A HarborHopping Cruise. Around Chesapeake Bay
description: To its shores came the first American Colonists; in its waters mix the Susquehanna, the Potomac and the James; from its ports sail freighters and racing yachts, and the commercial fishing fleets that supply much of the Atlantic Coast with seafood, Long be fore I read William Warner's Pulitzer Prizewinning Beautiful Swimmers,' about watermen, blue crabs and the Chesapeake Bay, I was fascinated with this region where land and water intertwine in infinite varieties of mood and pattern. Though it was possible to see parts of it by car, to cover nearly 4,000 miles of shoreline penetrated by rivers and notched with harbors, a boat seemed the only logical means of transportation. But we were landlocked in the Adirondacks, and neither I nor my husband, Craig, had any more seafaring experience than a voyage around the lake in our red canoe.

title: Larry Rivers Paints a Picture of the Past
description: LARRY RIVERS, the hiptalking 54yearold prePop Art painter, has been dividing his time between the Hamptons and Greenwich Village since 1953. In 1977, he is willing, even eager, to talk about weathering the scandal of the early clays of Abstract Expressionism, the rrsonalities of his friend Willem de ooning and his acquaintance Jackson Pollock, and his own independent, but respectful, stance toward the Abstract movement with a tolerance and a perspective that he has not always been known for.

title: GARDENING
description: NCE Labor Day comes and goes, there is a lull in the gardener's spirits. In a sense, the planting season is over. At such a time, there is nothing like flower show to brighten the mood.

title: Jobs and Jobless: Cruel Enigma
description: WASHINGTON REPRESENTATIVE Stewart B. McKinney calls it Connecticut's cruel enigma. He's referring to the way that employment and unemployment in the state have both been going up at the same time.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Sig Baseball Attendance
description: As much as I love and respect Red Smith, I must dispute his oftenrepeated claim that baseball attendance isn't what it used to be, relatively speaking. To justify this view now, in the face of an astonishing boost in attendanche insists that growth should be measured by population rise visavis pergame attendance.

description: There is a battle being waged in this country for the contrail of GT racing, the racing of modified production cars on road courses.

description: Although the goingson in restaurant kitchens are about as different from those in home kitchens as a threering circus is from a single trained seal, there are certain dishes and techniques that home cooks might well borrow, particularly when cooking for crowds. The recipe given here is a case in point.

title: Koch Is Endorsed by Chairman of M.T.A.

With voting only eight days away, Mr. Koch delivered his sharpest attack to date against Mr. Cuomo, accusing him of being beholden to special interestsespecially to the Governorand suggesting that Mr. Cuomo would never make the sort of tough uncompromising Mayor that New York City needed.

title: NEW ROLE IS SOUGHT FOR CITY HOSPITALS

title: Panamanians Acclaim Torrijos On His Return With Canal Pacts
