title: Today Is India Day in Valhalla
description: THEIR food is hot and spicy, their clothes colorful, clean and crisp, their dances gracious and enchanting, their music melodious yet discordant and their manners impeccable. They are Westchester's newest ethnic group, the county's latest immigrants600 IndoAmericans, who live, work and play in the area.

title: Brazil Rallies Popular Support on Independence Day
description: RIO DE JANEIRO. Sept. 10  Brazil, the biggest nation in Latin America, observed the 155th anniversary of independence from. Portugal this week amid efforts by the military government to give the celebration a tone of civic pride in the face of increasing civilian criticism of the regime.

title: ILLITERACY STILL GROWING SO UNESCO CANCELS PRIZES
description: PARIS, Sept. 10UNESCO will not award its two annual prizes to outstanding contributors to the fight against illiteracy this year because the number of illiterates is still increasing.

title: Peonies Planted Now Will Be Ready To Bloom in Spring
description: Perhaps the most frequently asked question on growing peonies is why don't my plants bloom? There may be a number of reasons: Plants too young and immature. Large clumps planted without proper division. Buds killed by late frost. Excessively hot weather and high humidity during early spring. Poor location. But the most common cause of most peony failures is improper plantMg.

title: GARDENING
description: DAHLIAS originated in the hills of Mexico and Guatemala and were cultivated there before the arrival of the Spanish in 1519. Taken back to Europe by the early explorers, they eventually spread throughout the world and are now grown in every country with a suitable climate. The name was given in honor of the Swedish botanist Andreas Dahl, a student of Linnaeus, the father of the universally accepted method of assigning scientific names.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Old pro, new bird. The way things are going in book publishing, it's only a matter of time until the business is dominated by seven giant companies with a little room on the side for a few wildcatters. That's the prediction Simon and Schuster's Richard E. Snyder made several months ago to a Publishers Weekly interviewer.

title: An Ohio Jury Awards Rape Victim $22,000 From Attacker as Damages
description: CLEVELAND, Sept, 10. (AP) A 47yearold South Euclid woman who was raped 2 years ago has been awarded $22,000 in damages from her attacker.

title: DINING OUT
description: ONE of the best restaurants in France's wine capital, Bordeaux, is a place called Clavel. It's in a rundown section of town near the railroad station. Clavel started out as a workman's bar and, in fact, half of it still is. The other half, separated only by a door, is one of the most elegant dining rooms in the city.

title: Amtrak Is Resisting An End to Red Caps
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Amtrak management is balking at a proposal that would eliminate the jobs of all 80 red caps on the Northeast Corridor rail lines between Washington and Boston.

title: A Rights Gadfly Is Joining the System in Suffolk
description: I WAS raised in the politics of confrontation, said James W. Couch, the civil rights activist who was recently named to the Suffolk County Human Rights Commission. But now, the civil rights movement has moved from demonstrations to the legal arena.

title: A Grim Anniversary in Chile
description: Today is the fourth anniversary of the military coup that overthrew the elected Government of Salvador Allende in Chile. The rightwing junta, led by General Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, has now held power more than a year longer than did President Allende. Whatever harm the leftwing Allende regime caused Chile by its catastrophic, ideologically motivated mismanagement of the economy, the brutal repression of the present Government has been even more harmful.

title: U.S. MISSILE DISPUTE HINDERS ARMS TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Progress toward a new treaty limiting strategic arms, already blocked by shall) differences between the United States and the Soviet Union, has been further complicated by a disagreement within the Carter Administration, officials said today.

title: Recipe for Dinner Theater
description: EAST WINDSOR at first glance may not seem a very exciting spot. It is an area of nursery and tobacco farms and an incipient mushroom industry and is home for about 8,900 people, Surprisingly enough it also furnishes top stars and top shows to 1,325 people nightly at its two dinner thalatara.

title: A Model of Conservation
description: BANTAM LAKE ON A RECENT muggy morning in Litchfield County, Gordon Loery, chief conservationist of the 4,000acre White Memorial foundation, took his telescope to the north end of Bantam Lake. He peered through the haze and confirmed the persistent, but unlikely, report that a ming at that end of the busy lake this summer.

title: Behind the Best Seller: James Herriot
description: Behind the Best Seller: James Herriot James Rerriot makes farm calls. He also makes house calls. He also writes books about the animals and people he meets on his rounds as a veterinary surgeon in the Yorkshire countryside. He had just come in from a rough day's workseveral calves had to be treated for pneumonia, two surgeries were performed on dogs and cats with assorted diseases, and a major operation that left me sweating had to be done on a cow with a lame footwhen we caught up by transAtlantic telephone, he within sight of heather in the north country, I within mugging distance of Eighth Avenue, to chat about his latest book, All Things Wise and Wonderful.

title: Florida Aggies Triumph In Benefit Game by 286
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 10 (AP)  Lastquarter touchdowns minute apart on an 88yard kickoff return and a 4yard quarterback keeper powered Florida A. and M. to a 286 triumph over Howard University at Giants Stadium today. A crowd of 35,094 attended the game, which was held to provide funds for urban youth scholarships.

title: Restoration of Dams Weighed by U.S. Unit
description: DURHAM, N.H., Sept. 10 (AP) A Federal Energy Research and Development Administration representative says that his agency will be investigating the feasibility of restoring old dams in New England.

title: U.S. Lifters to Compete
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10 (UPI)The Amateur Athletic Union said today the United States will send four men to the World Weightlifting championships in West Germany, Sept. 2125.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. .',Where Are We?, a Rosh Hashimah Address.

title: The Chief Awards
description: TOY (Harry Stecker, lodge)1, Mrs, Walter M. Jetfords Jr.'s and Michael Wolf's Pakinsgese, Ch. Punkin the Stringman; 2, Marie E. O'Nel's and Florence Sgrignouli's Toy Manchester terrier, Ch. Charmaron's Cheddar of Toy; 3, Ann Seranne's and Barbara Walforman's Yorkshire terrier, Ch. Mayfair Barban Yohoo; 4, Edward B. Jenner's Pomeranian, Ch. Lennis's Tar Lacy Foxfire.

title: The New York Times/John Sete
description: ON THE STUMP IN NEW JERSEY: President Carter waving to crowds with Governor Byrne during rally in Trenton for the Governor's reelection campaign. Arthur JHolland, the city's mayor, raises hand in victory salute below the Governor. President's trip was designed to put new vigor into state's Democratic campaign. Page 15.

title: Women at 4 Service Academies Viewed as Equal to Men Cadets
description: Women were holding their own as the second year of coeducation began at the nation's military academies last week. And at the Naval Academy at Annapolis, the Military Academy at West Point and the Coast Guard Academy at New London, Conn., fewer freshman women have dropped out during summer training this year than last.

title: Larry Rivers Reminisces About His Esthetic Past From Jazz Saxophonist in Bronx to Influential Painthr
description: Larry Rivers, the hiptalking 54yearold prePop Art painter, has been dividing his time between the Hamptons and Greenwich Village since 1953. In 1977, he is willing, even eager, to talk about weathering the scandal of the early days of Abstract Expressionism, the personalities of his friend Willem de Kooning and his acquaintance Jackson Pollock, and his own independent, but respectful, stance toward the Abstract movement with a tolerante and a perspective that he has not always been known for.

title: DANIEL M. BERNHEIM, 52; AN INVESTMENT EXECUTIVE
description: Daniel Marc Bernheim, an investment executive active in New Jersey civic and Republican Party affairs, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home in Far Hills. N.J. He was 52 years old.

title: U.S.C. Defeats Missouri As Hertel's Passes Click
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 10 (AP)Rob Hertel tossed touchdown passes to Randy Simmrin and. William Gay and scored on a 10yard run as Southern California posted a 2710 victory today over Missouri.

title: Mrs. Cook Captures Coast Powerboat Race
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10Betty Cook of Newport Beach, Calif., the only woman driver on the national offshore powerboat circuit for openclass boats, won the fifth annual San Francisco race today.

title: French Socialists Reject Demands by Communists
description: PARIS. Sept. 9The Socialist'Party has decided to reject Communist demands for a revision of their joint electoral platform and leave it up to the Communists to decide whether they want to break the alliance that has brought the left to the verge of taking power in France.

title: Pamela K. Hotz Is Married To. Peter Laurence Breves
description: Pamela Kellogg Hotz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Prindiville Hotz of Greenwich, Conn., was married'yestirday to Peter Laurence Breves, son bf Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Rudolph Breves of Mendham, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jack G. Schtate in the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich.

title: Of Special Interest
description: As the Off Off Broadway fall season gets underway, the Jean Cocteau Repertory Company officially begins its season on Friday. The company, founded six years ago and now quartered in the newly refurbished Bouwerie Lane Theater, has been devoted to revivals and classics. This year it plans to focus on rarely performed works because, according to a company spokesman, so many classic revivals are being done on Broadway that we felt we must offer an alternative. Thus, the opening play is Philip Massinger's Elizabethan comedy, A New Way to Pay Old Debts, which hasn't been seen in New York sinci. the 1870's. The title suggests its plot,.about a young Englishman who, with the aid of lovely widow, outfoxes Sir Giles Overreach, a rascal who is trying to cheat him of histightful fortune. (See Theater)

title: Wood, Field and Stream: PrimitiveWeapon Hunting
description: Hunting whitetailed deer with bow and arrow or socalled primitive weapons (muzzleloading rifles or smoothbores) continues to gain popularity in the United States.

title: Australia's Mysterious Camel Lady
description: PERTH, Australia Sept. 9 (Reuters)A camel trek through the harsh Gibson desert is nearing an end for a 28yearold model after five months of blistering travel over some of Australia's most desolate country.

title: Pakistan Press Is Free AgainAt Least to Criticize Ousted Regime
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 7To the surprise and delight of Pakistani journalists, they have found that an important feature of the country's new military Government is insistence on a relatively Lee press at least as far as freedom to attack the old Government is con. cerned.

title: Don Quixote Returns
description: MAN OF LA MANCHA"Richard Kiley, who created the role in 1965, once again dreams the old knight's impossible dreams in the musical revival that opens Thursday at the Palace.

title: Regina Cahill jersey Bride ofP.J.Keeley
description: Regina Blake Cahill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Cahill of Princeton. N.J., was married there yesterday to Patrick Joseph Keeley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Paul Keeley of Clarksburg. W. Va.

title: Oklahoma Overcomes Vanderbilt by 2523
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 10 (AP)Jay Jimerson, a freshman quarterback, came off the bench in the fourth quarter to rally Oklahoma to a 2523 victory over Vanderbilt today.

title: IRVING ROSE
description: Irving Rose, who began a long stage career as a dancer inthe early days of vaudeville and later filled supporting roles in Shubert musicals and Irving Berlin's Second and Fourth Music Box revues, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital after short illness. He was 81 years old and had lived for years on Central Park West.

title: Courageous Favored to Continue U.S. Mastery in America's Cup
description: NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 10Mount Everest has been climbed, dripdry suits discovered and men placed on the moon. But the Americas Cup remains intact, bolted securely inside its glass case at the New York Yacht Club in midtown Manhattan.

title: Best Sellers
description: To provide a broader and more accurate picture of the country's reading and bookbuying tastes, the Book Review with this issue introduces a number of changes in its best seller lists on this and page 62. The number of titles listed is increased to IS in every category. These are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States. In the case of mass market paperbacks, the calculation is supplemented by reports from 40 distributors with approximately 40,000 nonbookstore outlets.

title: Carey Reported To Be Softening Cuomo Support
description: Governor Carey is already signaling a retreat from his commitment to support Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo for Mayor all the way to the November election, even if he were only the Liberal Party candidate. The word from the Carey inner circle is that the Governor will remain inconspicuous during this week's minicampaign for the mayoral runoff primary and that he is prepared to support either Representative Edward I. Koch or Mr. Cuomo for the Democratic nomination.

title: Events Today
description: Third Avenue Merchants Association County Fair music, food entertainment, antiques; 11 A.M, to dusk; Third Avenue between 14th and 34th Streets.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press MISS AMERICA: Susan Perkins, Miss Ohio, was chosen as Miss America last night in Atlantic City.

title: Questions/Answers
description: My twoyear old lilacs developed white leaf spots after they bloomed. What is the problem? M.M. E., Yonkers, N.Y.

title: Statistics of the Game
description: FRIDAY NIGHT

title: U. S. Team Reaps Benefits of Youth
description: All of a sudden, the coach of the United States national team finds himself surrounded by an overabundance of talented young players. They represent the first crop of soccer's harvest from the development of the game at the youth level.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: BEAUMARCHAIS The Mon Who Was Figaro. By Fr0deric Grendel. Translated by Roger Greaves. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $14.95.

title: ART VIEW
description: There are great artists who divide opinion. People are for or against Wagner, for instance. They are for or against Charles Dickens. They are for or against the paintings of Ingres. They can think that Victor Hugo goes on too long and that Emily Dickinson does not go on long enough. Even Shakespeare has his detractors.

title: Copland Salutes Boulanger
description: Isn't it true that every human being ought to have the right to at least one stroke of great good fortune during a lifetime? It was my great good fortune to have met Nadia Boulanger 56 years ago when I was 20 and she was 34. (Of course, to a 20yearold, 34 represents a ripe middleage.) The year was 1921, and I had enrolled in a newly established summer school for American music students, sponsored by the French government, in the Palace of Fontainebleau. The creation of the school was said to have been a gesture of appreciation by the French for the help that the American armed forces had supplied in the winning of the World War I.

title: Saltwater Sailors Follow a Steady Course on Computer
description: KINGS POINT IT is all indoors, it is all datacontrol, television projectors and simulation, but the bridge is so like that of a real ship that the landlubber visitor feels a distinctly familiar sense of queasiness underfoot as soon as the five vast screens ahead of the wheelhouse begin to move, and the ship is under way.

title: Learning the Language of Controversy in Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT WHEN David R. Gonzalez came here from Puerto Rico five years ago, he was armed with a master's degree in physics and a smattering of English. Now, at the age of 42, he has a Ph.D. in science education from New York University, is welfare director of Bridgeport and is fluent in English, which he speaks with the marked accents of his native tongue.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE'Mass Appeal, a preBroadway opening of a new play by Bill C. Davis. Wednesday to next Sunday at 8:30 P.M. (through Sept. 25). $5.50, except Saturdays $6.50, students, children and the elderly $4.50, except Friday and Saturday. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6.6281169.

title: Carolyn Stiglic Married to Richard Bentley
description: Carolyn Stiglic, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anton Stiglic of Rosedale, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Norcross Bentley, son of Mrs. Richard Bentley of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mr. Bentley.

title: Ardent Fans of Monopoly Will Risk Even Radiation To Play and Win Fortune
description: OLDBURYONSEVERN, Britain (AP)Empirebuilders sat atop a nuclear reactor in radiationprotective coats and hats to match wits and daring in one of the world's great challengesMonopoly.

title: That's a Switch From the Crises of Other Years
description: It's nice to think it's going to be a dull year, said Robert J. Kibbee, the chancellor of the City University of New York. And he is looking forward to the doldrums with good reason. In recent years the 18unit university has opened with a series of crises over funding, tuition, faculty layoffs and possible closings of colleges that threatened the survival of the nation's third largest university network.

title: Abolish the Corporate Income Tax
description: Nothing infuriates taxpayers more than watching business executives live well at public expense. Abuse corporate expense account deductionsconferences plush resorts, golf club dues, threemartini lunchesis thus, justifiably, a prime target for tax reformers, especially as the Administration now readies its tax reform program. In economic terms, though, a far more important issue in business tax reform is whether we ought to tax corporations in the first place.

title: Chart of the Futurity Stakes
description: EIGHTHThe Futurity Stakes, $75,000 added, 2Y0, 7f, Start good, won driving. Off, 5:27, Winner, ch. c., by Exclusive NativeWon't Tell You, by Crafty Admiral, Trainer, S. Berme. Value to winner, $63,570; second, $23,309; third, $12,714; fourth, $6,357. Times 23 3/5; 46 3/5; 1:09 4/5; 1:21 3/5.

title: An Activist With Battle Scars Joins Human Rights Commission on L.I.
description: I was raised in the politics of confrontation, said James W. Couch, the civil rights activist who was recently named to the Suffolk County Human Rights Commission. But now, the civil rights movement has moved from demonstrations to the legal arena.

title: DR. JACOB ORNSTEIN
description: Dr. Jacob Ornstein, a former principal', of. William Cowper Junior. High School in the Maspeth section of Queens who was also a sculptor and a painter, died Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Cynthia Sue Morley Wed to Stephen Lacey in Darien
description: Cynthia Sue Morley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Morley Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stephen Edmund Lacey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Lacey of Newark, Del. The Rev. Samuel W. Fogal performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: ACCUSED MOLESTER OF CHILDREN IS FREED
description: A 34yearold Suffolk County man charged in two incidents of child molestation in Queens was freed on $6,500 bail after his lawyer argued at his arraignment in Queens Criminal Court that he should be released in his own recogmizance because of his standing in the community.

title: SADAKO AND THE THOUSAND PAPER CRANES
description: Hiroshimaborn Sadako Sasaki was only 12 when she died in 1955 from the atom bomb disease  leukemia. From translations of her letters, Eleanor Coerr has fashioned a wellintentioned but wooden fictionalization of Sadako's last year. According to Japanese legend, if a sick person folds one thousand paper cranes, the gods will grant her wish and make her healthy again, and so Sadako diligently begins assembling her origami flock. She does not get beyond the 644th but her determination and hope, as an epilogue explains, have made her a heroine in Japan, where every Peace Day (the anniversary of the bombing) she is honored by the placement of thousands of Paper cranes beneath her statue. More than likely, Sadako's own words would bring her closer to us, but as portrayed in Coerr's bland narrative she remains as twodimensional as her paper birds. And shimmery, softfocus drawings by Ronald Himler only make

title: Red. Sox Conquer Tigers As Aase Hurls 5Hitter
description: Yesterday was perhaps one of the biggest moments in the young life of William Donald Aase, two days past his 23d birthday and a major league pitcher for only 46 days. The 6foot2inch, 192pound rookie righthander was the center of attention as he sat on a stool in the Red Sox dressing room in Fenway park, after beating the Detroit Tigers 71, on a fivehitter.

title: Greetings
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Falk of Nsw York City and Atlantic Beach, and their family, Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Falk, Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Gran, and Mr. And Mri. Leonard N. Stern wish their reinfives and friends a healthy and Peaceful New Year.

title: BOLIVIA TAKES STEP TOWARD SEA ACCESS
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 10  President Hugo Banzer Suarez of Boliva brought his landlocked country a step closer to the seas this week by persuading the presidents of Chile and Peru to consider opening an access route for Bolivia to the Pacific.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayAmerican Gold Cup, J. F. Kennedy Stadium, Philadelphia. All jumpers. 1:30 P.M.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: AFTER four years of an improbably happy marriage, Paulette's husband Howard leaves her for another woman. Don't go, she says. I can't help it, he says. Why? she says. How should I know? he says. What does she do, anyway? Paulette asks, as if it were a question of doing.

title: Eastern College Football: Pitt Still on Top as Rutgers Fades
description: Tony Dorsett made the 1976 football season one of the most memorable in Eastern college history. Dorsett and his teammates at the University of Pittsburgh enjoyed a perfect season, and Rutgers went undefeated, emerging for at least one year as an Eastern football power.

title: Stephanie Severance Bride of Robert Y. McCarter
description: Stephanie Appleby Severance, daughter of Malcolm Douglas Severance of Rumson, N.J., and the late Marie Appleby Severance, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Young McCarter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Eyer Parker McCarter, also of Rumson. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the ceremony in St. George'sbytheRiver Ediscoal Church in Rumson.

title: How to Act When It's the Audience That Does the AdLibbing
description: The night I saw Miss Margarida's Way, Estelle Parsons, the star of Roberto Athayde's play, about domineering school teacher, bounded on stage to find carnation sitting on the teacher's desk.

title: Fordham Eases Way for Older Students
description: AT 63, having sent three sons to medical school, a daughter to law school and another daughter to graduate school, Henry Gable, a high school dropout, decided to do himself a favor: He returned to In a somewhat unorthodox approach, Mr. Gable applied and was accepted to special program at Fordham University that awarded him a high school diploma upon the, completion of his first 24 credits.

title: Montclair Student Conquers Handicap
description: MONTCLAIR JOSE FUENTES, who was crippled by polio when he was years old, has been in America for 10 years. This year, he will have the responsibility of representing more than 15,000 college students and administering a $500,000 corporation as the student government president at MnntrIair State Colleve.

title: Michigan Downs Illinois As Huckleby Stars, 379
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 10 (UPI)Harlan Huckleby scored on 15 and 3yard touchdown runs today and led Michigan to a 379 victory over Illinois in their Big Ten opener.

title: Outspoken Medich Released by Finley
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)The Oakland A's asked irrevocable waivers on Doc Medich today because the A's owner Charles 0. Finley, reportedly was unhappy over statements Medich made about the Oakland team.

title: Article 13  No Title
A Question of Timing
description: MILITARY history is a great deal more than the Valor and horror of battles. Behind the battles, large and small, lie military politics the forces that hammer out, often in violent argument, the strategies and weapons to be used. Military politics aro the inside history of wars. For example, there was the struggle waged within the Allied command in 1944 over the strategy of the final offensive against Germany. The broadftont approach, favored veiled over the single throat advocated by General Patton and Field Marshal Montgomery, with consequences that have affected Europe for a third a century.

title: The People's Choices
description: Of all the possible combinations, was one of the more unlikely. Six months ago, Edward I. Koch was highly regarded Congressman, but one little known outside his East Side district. Four months ago, Mario M. Cuomo was not even a candidate and was little known almost everywhere.

title: 200 Bales of Marijuana Found it Floating Off South Florida's Coast
description: RIVIERA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 10 (AP)About 200 bales of marijuana were found floating in the ocean yesterday off the coasts of three southern Florida counties.

title: Judge Says U.S. May Order Leave for Flight Attendants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 (AP)A Federal judge has ruled that Pan American World Airways may, for reasons of safety, force its flight attendants to go on leave if they are pregnant.

title: China Hints Change In Interpreting Mao
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 10In an important editorial marking the first anniversary of Mao Tsetung's death, China's new leaders indicated today that they might be laying the groundwork for reinterpreting his policies.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: GRAND KABUKI THEATERThe Japanese company with a cast of more than 60 in performances which combine music, dance, martial arts and drama. Translation of text and commentary via transistor headphones. It has always been an actor's theater, and Ennosuke and his colleagues are firstrate. (Kisselgoff) Beacon, Bway at 74th St. (8741717) Reopens Tues. Closes next Sun. MAN OF LA MANCHARichard Kiley in a revival of the Dale Wasserman / Mitch Leigh / Joe Darion musical. Directed by Albert Marre. Palace, 1564 Bway (PL 72626) Opens Thur. (previews Tues.Wed.)

title: Morgan 201 Lifts Lead To 4 Shots
description: ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 10 (UPI)Playing steadily while other contenders faltered, Gil Morgan increased his lead to four strokes today after three rounds of the $200,000 B.C. open golf tournament.

title: Janet Gibson Bride Of Richard M. Fricke
description: Janet Philbrook Gibson, a program assistant in the General Services Administration in Washington, and Richard Martin Fricke, a lawyer with the Newark firm of Schwartz and Andolino, were married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington. the rector, the Rev. John C. Harper, performed the ceremony.

title: A Cabinet Full of Prints in Wilton
description: WILTON AT FIRST blush visitors might think that it is another component of a movie set. Located near Wilton in a quaint hamlet known as Cannon Crossing, the twostory red construction is one of five 19thcentury buildings clustered near a picturepostcard railroad station and gentle river rippled occasionally by animated birdlife.

title: INTERVIEW
description: NASSAU COUNTY has a new postcoordinator of services for the physically handicapped. And to fill it, County Executive Ralph G. Caso has chosen Don Dreyer, a 27yearold Hempstead resident who is himself disabled and wheelchairbound because of an ailment called osteogenesis imperfecta, which results in brittle bones.

title: A Freshman With Seniority
description: IT WAS hard getting into Harvard as a freshman at the age of 63. And it was harder raising, and letting go of, the $5,000 for tuition, fees and textbooks. But hardest of all was getting through the freshman yearlearning how to listen and take notes at the same time and learning how to study, do homework, sit for examsall in alien environment of 20vearolds.

title: A Test for the State's Newest Freedom
description: OUTSIDE the temperature was at the 90degree mark, so when the lawyer spoke about a chilling effect he was not talking about the weather. Rather, he was discussing Connecticut's Freedom of Information Act and the effect that a pending lawsuit might have on people who have a complaint about a public agency.

title: Groping for a New World Wheat Pact
description: The domestic farm and trade policies of many countries taking part in discussons about the international wheat agreement are themselves a major cause of volatility in grain prices and the availability of supplies. Unless these policies can be altered through negotiation, an agreement on a commodity stabilization program has little chance to succeed.

title: SELECTION: MEETING JAMES JOYCE
description: OUR great Ulysses adventure, which culminated in 1934, had really begun in 1932, when James Joyce's Ulysses was contraband in the United States, absolutely forbidden. The only way you could buy it was underthecounter in an edition published by Miss Sylvia Beach in Paris under the colophon of Shakespeare and Company, the name of her very famous little bookstore on the Left Bank, where many American tourists found their way. Everybody would buy copies of Ulysses bound in paper, a lightblueColumlumbiabluecover. You couldn't come bane from Europe without a copy of Ulysstmewhich Sylvia Beach sold for ten dollars. I think Shakespeare and Company really lived on Ulysses. The Little Review had done some of it in successive issues, but it had even less money than Joyce. A man had pirated some of it and gone to jail, and not only for Ulysses: he was also publishing pornography of a less literary nature.

title: Cooking a la Classroom
description: THIS season, Westchester's cooking schools will leave no cuisine untasted, no technique untried. There is something for everyone, from the utter novice, the fledgling with a food processor, to those who wish to perfect advanced French cuisine, understand Japanese presentation or turn out a flaky, oldfashioned strudel.

title: Programs Bypass Neediest
description: CONGRESS is inching toward coherent Federal policy on adult education amid evidence that existing programs are not reaching those who seem to need them Ma.

title: Nassau's Own Adlai Stevenson
description: WHILE THE VOTERS of Nassau County are in the process of deciding who will be the next County Execut.i'Ve, the last County Executive, Eugene H. Nickerson, is about to become a Federal District Court judge in what most politicians concede is a fitting climax to a checkered political career and an alltoofrequent mismatching of. the man and the job.

title: Realty News
description: Twelve buildings in west Greenwich Village have been sold by a group of investors headed by Arthur Jacobs to Time Equities, of which Francis Greenburger is a principal.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: The more we think about itand we've discussed it with several other sailors in the meantimethe less we can understand the situation described in New Boating Safeguards Sought (Aug. 21). Admittedly, if Paul Hackett and his son spent nine hours floating around on the Sound before being fished out by the Coast Guard, the system isn't as reliable as one would wish.

title: Susan Karen Hines Wed to Stephen Black
description: The marriage of Susan Karen Hines to Stephen Lounsbury Black took place yesterday at the Indian Hill EpiscopalPresbyterian Church in Cincinnati. The Rev. James P. Metzger, assisted by the Rev. Edward O. Miller, performed the ceremony.

title: W. German Soccer
description: Werder Bremen I, F.C. Saarbruecken 1. Eintracht Frankfurt 3, M.S.V. Duisburo.1. Fortuna Dusseldorf 3, H.S.V. Hamburg 1. St. Paull 3 Borussia Dortmund 6.

title: NORWEGIAN COALITION UNEASY ON ELECTION
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept 10 (AP)  While buoyed by the findings of recent public opinion polls, the minority Government of the Norwegian Labor Party appears headed for an uncertain fate in Parliamentary elections to be held Monday.

title: How Olympic's Loss Was Onassis Gain
description: [Just after World War It still in the throes of its own civil war, Greece was not much interested in the soaring personal destiny of Aristotle Onassis; by the 1950's the situation had changed dramatically.]

title: Editors Choice
description: AGENCY OF FEAR, by Edward Jay Epstein. (Putnam's, $9.95) A calm meticulous inquiry into a White House narcotics agency set up to. score political points in the warimon on crime.

title: JAPANESE FEAR HARDSHIP IN NEW FISHING LIMITS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (Reuters)Representatives of Japanese fishing interests said here yesterday that their country's fishing industry could be imperiled if the United States imposed proposed new restrictions on foreign fleets inside its 200mile fishing limit Tomouoshi Kamenaga, the leader of delegation that came to Washington for talks with Government officials, said at a news conference that if fresh restrictions were imposed on foreign fishermen, perhaps we would not find the fisigng industry viable. He said Japan had already paid about $550 million in !diet to its fishing industry, on which the country relies heavily for food.

title: The Island's Cooking Schools
description: THE MAJORITY of Long Island's cooking classes, like its restaurants, are devoted to the food of Italy, China and France. There are also a variety of bread and pastry courses, wine symposiums and classes in using food processors. Diet cookery runs the gamut from basic lowcalorie shopping and cooking to elegant cuisine minceur. Every level, from beginner to highly specialized, is covered and one can arrange for an intensive series of private lessons, participate in small groups or merely attend demonstration sessions.

title: CutUps Serve Valued Purpose In the Library
description: Librarians suffer traumas when they first join the staff of the New York Public Library's Picture Collection at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: AMAGANSETTWorks by Rae Ferren. Thursday through Saturdays and Mondays, 10 A.M. to 5P.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Through Sept. 19. Gallery East, Main St. Reception today 2 to 4 P.M.

title: Malpractice Suit Against L.I. School Dismissed by Court
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 9A $5 million educational malpractice suit brought by a young Lindenhurst man who said his school district had allowed him to graduate from high school despite his being functionally illiterate has been dismissed.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Yankees play the expansion Toronto Blue Jays in 1 P.M. doubleheader at Yankee Stadium today and take tomorrow off. At 8 P.M. Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights the Yankees play a crucial threegame series against the Boston Red Sox, and the pregame sale indicates attendance will be 50,000plus each night.

title: MILK FARMERS ACT OVER COMPETITION
description: ALBANY, Sept. 10Eighteen thousand dairy farmers in New York and northern New Jersey are voting on a proposal to take over from handlers the cost of hauling their milk to market, in hopes of stemming an invasion of milk into the metropolitan area from Pennsylvania.

title: Nancy S. Roosevelt Is Married To Shomas Ireland of Citibank
description: Nancy Suzanne Roosevelt, granddaughter of President and Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, was married yesterday in Poughquag, N.Y., to Thomas Ellis Ireland, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. L. Ireland 3d of New York.

title: A Night Court for ConsumerMerchant Disputes Likely in Nassau
description: A proposal for a Nassau County Small Claims Court that would offer nighttime arbitration to settle disputes between consumers and merchants seems likely to be adopted, but it must first be approved in State Supreme Court.

title: DOROTHEA LANGHORNE
description: Dorothea Langhorne, librarian for Community School District 6 before her retirement in 1972, died Thursday at her home, 555 Edgecombe Avenue. She was 70 years old.

title: Hurricanes: State Faring Better in 77
description: The hurricane season began officially late last month, but there is no particular reason to expect one of these spectacular storms to move across the state this year.

title: Primary Lessons in Ethnic Politics
description: NEW HAVEN IN THE HEAT of the last few days of the campaign before the primary elections on Thursday, strife and a certain amount of confusion reign among New Haven's Democrats trying to pick their way through the normally placid, rarely contested quest for the office of city and town clerk.

title: Inquiry on North Carolina Sniper Finds No Evidence of Nazi Ties
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 10 (AP) Despite the fact that he wore a swastika armband, a 17yearold gunman who opened fire on a group of blacks at a Labor Day church picnic here had no Nazi affiliations, the police say.

title: LETTER FROM STONY BROOK
description: STONY BROOK WHEN Chris Claypool was living in his parents home in Manhattan, he doubted the propriety of decorating the walls of his room with pictures from his favorite men's magazine. So he scrapped the idea.

title: Three Novels
description: THIS is George V. Higgins's sixth book since 1972, when The Friends of Eddie Coyle appeared. Seven books in five yearsclearly an oeuvre in the making, and in Dreamland Higgins works to extend the range, leaving the tightly plotted, swiftmoving netherworld of Eddie Coyle for the denser, more literary air of Boston Brahmins, high finance and international skullduggery.

title: Strike Halts Louisville Buses
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10 (AP) The 20,000 people who normally ride the buses here on Saturdays sought other transportation after a wildcat strike by drivers shut down all routes of the Transit Authority of River City. The strike began in defiance of a court order.

title: Political Accounting
description: SHOULD the reporter inject himself/herself in the story? Yes, judging by some fresh evidence. Two of the best journalists in WashingtonJohn Osborne of The New Republic and Elizabeth Drew of The New Yorkerhave their 1976 campaign books out. Osborne's White House Watch: The Ford Years works; Drew's American Journal: The Events of 1976 does not. The big difference is Osborne himself. His courtly, crotchety passion sets his book apart and makes it essential for understanding the short, happy Presidency of Gerald Ford and the election of 1976. Both books are collections of previously published journalism, very intelligent impressions of a unique political seasonthe contest between the unelected President, Gerald Ford, and the implausible challenger, Jimmy Carter. The events and the characters are similar and familiar. Both use the first person singular. But only Osborne seems to have a viewpoint, or at least strong opinions, and continues to struggle to understand what he saw and heard in the wake of the 37th President.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: A guide to cooking schools. Page 15.
description: FIFTYFIVE years ago, Emily Post's first guide to etiquette dictated that it was inappropriate to serve ethnic foods at a dinper party. What would she say today?

title: BLOOD SUMMER
description: I haven't read Don Asher's two earlier novels, The Piano Sport and The Electric Cotillion, but he has done something rather remarkable in Blood Summer: Ile has written a humorous novel about incest.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: EVERYONE knows that suburban mothers spend most of their time chauffeuring their children around, right? Wrongat least in my case. I live in the suburbs, but live in what I call inner city Princeton and I don't drive my children anywhere.

title: 4 States and Edkation Group Join Maryland's Tuition Fight
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP)Maryland has sought and won the support of four other states and an educational group in its efforts to continue its practice of higher tuitions for outofstate and foreign students at the University of Maryland than it charges Marylanders.

title: Malcolm McNeill
description: Usually the most persistent of handshaking campaigners, Edward I. Koch took a day off only a couple of days before New York City's Democratic mayoral primary. What was he doing? Raising money for the runoff, Mr. Koch said.

title: Cays, Suns in Fame Game
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10 (AP)  The Cleveland Cavaliers and the Phoenix Suns will meet in the sixth annual National Basketball Association Hall of Fame benefit game on Nov. at the Civic Center. All proceeds will go to the Hall of Fame.

title: GARDENING
description: ONCE Labor Day comes and goes, there is a lull in the gardener's spirits. In a sense, the planting season is over. At such a time, there is nothing like flower show to brighten the mood.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: NEW JERSEY stands to receive at least $23 million next yearand probably much morefrom the new Youth Employment Act signed last month by President Carter. On a population basis alone, the state can hope for about $35 million.

title: His Music Celebrates The Gospel Truth
description: Children grow up to gospel music in drowsy, hot little oneroom churches in a thousand small towns across the country. Adults shout it out in the reverberating community chapels of every urban ghetto and in recent months, audiences at the Lyceum Theater have been clapping and stomping their way through the gospel experience with all the abandon of Pentecostal acolytes, thanks to Your Arms Too Short to Box With God.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: SINCE repairing or replacing windowscreen mesh is a fairly simple job that requires only ordinary hand tools, there is no reason why anyone should tolerate tears or holes for any length of time. Small holes or tears can usually be patched, but if there are many, it pays to install new screening over the existing frame.

title: Youth and Sports: Beware Of Pressures to Be a Star And the Obsession to Win
description: When I was a little kid growing up in the Bronx, I lived next door to playground. Kids used to gather at the park and play chooseup baseball games. We not only picked sides, but we also set the rules. The equipment was our personal property.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Carter's Standing Unhurt by Lance
description: President Carter has maintained his popularity among the public, despite the problems of his budget director, Bert Lance. according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: States Sending Professionals Back to the Classroom
description: NEW YORK STATE requires podiatrists to show proof of continuing education every year before they can reregister to practice in the state. In New Jersey and Connecticut, similar statutes are in effect for optometrists and nursinghome operators, and New Jersey has one governing pharmacists.

title: Letters: Bouquet For a Grandmother
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura B. Ross Attended by 7 At Her Bridal
description: Laura Butler Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Ross of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter McKay Marschalk, son of Mr: and Mrs. H. Robert Marschalk, also of New Canaan. The Rev. Alfred H. Whistler performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Travel Brochures: Separating Fact From Fantasy
description: Desperate to escape last winter's merciless cold, Jacquelin* Just, a City University graduate student, began to collect travel brochures. One promised all she desired: Splendid with color photographs, it showed the deep green palm trees, azure waters and white sands of St. Lucia and the sunlit rooms of a luxurious beach club, all at a price she could afford. But once in St. Lucia, Miss Jzist discovered what other travelers elsewhere have often learned to their chagrinbrochures often can lie.

title: Notes: Gateway Team Seeks a Fresh Image
description: With unaccustomed gallantry, the United States Travel Service has risen to the defense of its multilingual women receptionists at gateway airports from Maine to Honolulu. In addition to rescuing their jobs from Congressional budget cuts, the agency is seeking to help them shake off the label of golden girls, which it regards as sexist.

title: Recipe for Dinner Theater
description: EAST WINDSOR at first glance may not seem a very exciting spot. It is an area of nursery and tobacco farms and an incipient mushroom industry and is home for about 8,900 people. Surprisingly enough it also furnishes top stars and top shows to 1,325 people nightly at its two dinner theaters.

title: Retrial of Boyle in Murder Case Starts Wednesday Amid Secrecy
description: MEDIA. Pa., Sept. 10'W.A. Boyle's second trial on charges that he ordered the murder of a union rival begins here Wednesday amid unusual official secrecy about his health and about pretrial maneuvers. The 1974 conviction of the former president of the United Mine Workers union was set aside earlier this year.

title: LETTER FROM WESLEYAN
description: MIDDLETOWN W. E have gone to Middletown many times, but this time was different. Our son entered Wesleyan as a freshman, and so we drove to Wesleyan, not Middletown.

title: Minding the Kids: Frustrating for Companies
description: Many companies that set up daycare centers in the late 1960's and early 1970's largely at the behest of the women's movement have abandoned them after finding that they get little use.

title: At the Philharmonic This Season: A Galaxy of Guests
description: On the Nov. 25 and 26 concerts of the New York Philharmonic s subscription season, Erich Leinsdorf will conduct the BizetShchedrin Carmen Ballet, that awful example of Socialist Realism. There is something symbolic about the choice. Pierre Boulez would never have put this kind of work on a program he would have equated it with everything cheap and meretricious. But Leinsdorf is a musician of an older school.

title: Cosmos Rally to Beat Japanese, 42
description: TOKYO, Sept, 10 (UFI)Pele and his Cosmos rallied to defeat the Furukawa Electric Company squad, 42, today in the opening match of a twogame goodwill tour of Japan. The Cosmos, the North American Soccer League champions, trailed Furukawa by 21 at halftime.

title: Barbara Ellinghaus Fiancee of Loren Gurne
description: Barbara Ellinghaus and Loren Bruce Gurne, graduates of James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va., will he married on Nov. 6 at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: America's love affair with the automobile continues undiminished, even though the romance is becoming more and more costly to maintain. For months the bulwarks of the American economy have been sales of housing and sales of autos. New figures now show that in August, normally a slow month for car dealers, automobile sales set records.

title: Matching Schools With Students
description: AFTER 20 years, a Cleveland teacher.had become bored teaching second graders. She wanted badly to teach in a junior or senior high school and, perhaps, to become adepaitment head or an assistant principal, but she did not have the requisite college degree. She inquired at Cleveland State University, which said she would have to take two and a half more years of courses for a degree.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: Therefore to be accepted by the reader, who is. intently committed to the novel he has acquired as being entertaining, as a writer who heals and diverts hundreds of thousands or dozens of readers who wish to be turned away from a few .of the unbearable moments of their livesthis is not a bad model of work for anyone with art on his or her mind.

title: Bob Gaie
description: WASHINGTONEvery day there are new reports, innuendoes, allegations, about Bert Lance. Every day there are reports about the reports. In the manner of Washington, the man is already talked about in the past tense, before any formal charges have been brought and while, to most people, it is still not completely clear what exactly the director of the Office of Management and Budget has done. Or not done.

title: Rhodesia's Whites Launch a Harmony Drive
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 10 (Reuters)To the jaunty jingle of pop tune, white Rhodesian businessmen have launched an advertising campaign to improve relations between blacks and whites.

title: U.S. Researchers Are Beginning Use of British Testing for Birth Defects
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 10British health officials will soon begin what believed to be the first national program to detect birth defects in unborn children by testing women's blood early in their pregnancies.

title: Islanders Schedule
description: Oct. 15Boston; 18, Los Angeles; II Rangers; 29, Buffalo.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The continuing dispute over the ordination of women and other changes in the Episcopal Church has led to an unusual confrontation for a bishop, as well as resort by contending parties to the civil courts. Last Sunday, Bishop John M. Krumm was turned away three times on the front steps of St. Paul's Church in Columbus, Ohio, where he intended to conduct services in place of the. Rev. G. Wayne Craig, rector of the church. Bishop Krumm had suspended Father Craig because of a finding by diocesan officials that Father Craig had abandoned communion with the national church.

title: A Howard Hughes Debt Flies Home to Roost
description: The eccentricities of the late Howard Hughes are still plaguing his estate. It may be $72 million poorer now because the reclusive multimillionaire failed to appear years ago in a court suit.

title: Point of View
description: Nationwide, arson is growing faster than any other major crime. In New York City, arson is destroying neighborhoods at the rate of 20 arson fires per day.

title: The Lighthouse Gets a Home
description: WHITE PLAINS THE Westchester Lighthouse, an institution that has served hundreds of the blind and others with serious eye problems in this county since 1962, is one the least institutionalized socialservice agencies. We are communityoriented, Chester T. Williams, the Lighthouse director, said at the recent opening of its new headquarters here. We try to use existing facilities in local communities rather than create new ones.

title: Postmaster Has No Objection To Bill Curbing Mail Openings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10(AP)The Postal Service has told Congress that would have no objection to a law contravening a recent Supreme Court decision that the Customs Service can legally open letters mailed from abroad. In a letter to Representative Richardson Preyer, chairman of a House subcommittee that is investigating mail openings by the Customs Service, Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar emphasized his department's willingness to cooperate with the inquiry.

title: Ekaterina, Not Nymphodora
description: The first performance of secular play in Russia took place at the court of Czar Alexis in 1672. In France it was the Cane of Racine and Moliere, and in England Shakespeare had been dead for more than half a century. The earliest professional playwrights and theaters in Russia date from the middle of the 18th century. But this time lag was overcome within a matter of decades. By the early 19th century, Russian plays, actors and theaters were comparable with those anywhere in the Western world.

description: (Be Sure To Consult Statutes)

title: EMANUEL COHEN, OFFICER OF PARAMOUNT PICTURES
description: Emanuel Cohen, former vice president in charge of productions for Paramount Pictures, died Friday at Lenox Hill Mspital. He was 85 years old and liver at 799 Park Avenue.

title: Joan Dix Blair Is Bride Of William James Wyer
description: The marriage of Joan Dix Blair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Slingluff Blair of New Castle, Pa., to William James Wyer took place yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner.) The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Coffin Wyer of Wayzata, Minn. The Rev. Allan B. Warren 3d performed the ceremony.

title: I.R.S. Report Shows Rift in Comptroller's Office Over Help for Lance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A report by the Internal Revenue Service shows that there was a great deal of opposition within the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency to some of the decisions by senior officials there that benefited Bert Lance, the budget director.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: One of the curious consequences of the recent recognition of photography as art has been the growing tendency of famous magazine photographers not only to exhibit their work in galleries and museums but also to reedit and represent wellknown work in such a way that it no longer quite resembles the work we remember from magazines and books. The strange and beautiful exhibition of photographs by Irving Penn at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street. through Oct. 10. is a case in noint.

description: REGULAR SEASON. GAMES

title: The Question of Finances Isn't Academic
description: HARTFORD FROM around the state there appears to be a growing resolution that Connecticut should not, as some other states have done, attempt to limit the rich towns in what they can spend for their public schools so that the poor towns can more easily catch up with them.

title: lnvueilings
description: KAMPION, Tillie (nee Grossman) unveil. MI of memorial None will be lield:oir Sunday, Seel. 11 at 19:30 A.M. rain or shine, at Betts David cemetery, Eimonte Long Wand, N.Y.

description: THOMAS A. EDISON COLLEGE did not teach George Meisler thing, but it awarded him a degree anyway. The college thought he deserved it.
