title: Katherine L. Mertz Bride
description: Katherine Lloyd Mertz and Todd Richard Schonenberg were married yesterday in the Roslyn (LI.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Stark Jones The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Edward Lloyd Mertz of Port Washington, L. I., and the late Mr. Mertz. Mr. Schonenberg is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Schonenberg of Setauket, L.I. The bridegroom is attending Naval Officers Candidate School in Newport, R. I., His father is in field service management with the Grumman Aerospace Corporation in Bethpage, L.I.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTORS CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeHedda Gabler. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Oct. 15). $3.90$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: U.S. PLANS IMPROVEMENT IN MEATGRADING SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)  The Department of Agriculture, noting instances of bribery and corruption between meat graders and meat packers, announced plans today to strengthen the meatgrading service. We are determined to take whatever actions are necessary to fully maintain confidence and integrity in this service, Carol T. Foreman, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for food and consumer services, said.

title: ProfitMaking Schools Gain In Popularity and Status
description: PROFIT IS NO longer a dirty word in education. The nation's proprietary schools, the privately owned postsecondary institutions that teach marketable career skills, are rapidly gaining a new degree of acceptance and respectability. For years, proponents traditional colleges and universities have scorned the profitmaking nature of proprietary schools, their penchant for advertising on subway cars and matchbooksJoin the glamorous world of computer programming or Discover your destiny as an executive secretaryand their concern ???????????????? that, with sirarlamir nranaratinn.

title: FISHING
description: BLUEFISHING remains inconsistent along much of both the North and South Shores, but offshore the action is super, with Southern fish such as wahoo and sailfish reported within range. The Hudson Canyon is alive with gamefish and is likely to stay that way for another few weeks until the first fall storm chases them away.

title: Two Versions of Americana: In Vermont and New York
description: Concentrated and flavored or natural and rawAmericana comes both ways on the banks of Lake Champlain. At Shelburne, Vt., south of Burlington, on the east lake shore, the Shelburne Museum has gathered 35 original and reproduced early American structures on 100 acres of carefully clipped lawns and roselined lanes. An 18minute ferry ride across the lake, the rustic hamlet of Essex, N. Y., presents the plainer face of a oncebustling lake port that fell into a slumber and has never quite awakened.

title: Senate Chief Bars Action on Canal Pacts This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, today dashed any hopes the Carter Administration may have had for completing ratification of the new Panama Canal treaties this year.

title: The Galloping Profits at Wells Fargo Bank
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Visitors to the headquarters of the Wells Fargo Bank on Montgomery Street are greeted in the lobby by a rugged, 2,500pound stagecoach that once carried passengers and mail in long, lurching rides across California's High Sierra Mountains.

title: Trashing History
description: PETER TAUBER'S novel is so lacking in vitality and intelligence it makes one yearn for the pure pulp energy of Irving Wallace. Some think differently: The Last Best Hope arrives with a first printing of 50,000 copies and as a BookoftheMonth Club main selection, Tauber's publishers are calling it the first epic novel of the sixties, and by that they must mean something more than long.

title: Barbara Landreth Wed to S.B. Farley
description: Barbara Horan Landreth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Swain Landreth, was married yesterday to Stephen Blunt Farley of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mrs. Paul G. Teas of Wolfeboro, N.H.. and John Wesley Farley of Miami.

title: Women Hail Attack on Government Over Abortion
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 10Frances Farenthold of Texas, ending a blistering 15minute attack today on Congress, the Supreme Court and President Carter for not supporting public financing of certain kinds of abortions, declared: The right to an abortion has become a class issue, a race issue, a privacy issue and even a consumer issue, but it is, above all, our issue. And more than 1,200 delegates to the third biennial convention of the National Women's Political Caucus rose and applauded her for three minutes.

title: Black Family. Chronicle
description: TONI MORRISON'S first two booksThe Bluest Eye  with the purity of its terrors and Sula with its dense poetry and the depth of its probing into a small circle of liveswere strong novels. Yet, firm as they both were in achievement and promise, they didn't fully forecast her new book, Song of Solomon. Here the depths of the younger work are still evident, but now they thrust outward, into wider fields, for longer intervals, encompassing many more lives.

title: Pan Am 747 Receives Bomb Threat; Makes a Safe Landing in Ireland
description: SHANNON, Ireland, Sept. 10 (AP)A Pan American Boeing 747 jet with 314 people aboard made an emergency landing at Shannon Airport early today because of a telephoned bomb threat. An apparently nonexplosive object resembling a bomb was later found in one of the toilets.

title: At Hofstra, the Gray Wig Alumni Repertory Theater Provides an Outlet for the Frustrated Actoi.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.It beats going to a psychiatrist. That is how Joan Rubinstein, a Merrick housewife, explained her reasons for participating in Hofstra University's Gray Wig Alumni. Repertory Theater Company.

title: Getting the Picture in Westport
description: WESTPORT IF ONE picture is worth a thousand words, what are half a million pictures worth? So far, no one has attempted to place a cash value on the Westport Library's picture file, with its 600,000 graphics and photographs. but the collection is invaluable to its users.

title: The Birth of a Tour Book
description: A heavyweight in the world of travel brochures is the American Express Europe Book of escorted tours and travel packages. The 1978 edition will go to press late this month, and is expected to run to 188 pages and weigh one solid pound. Three giant presses at Moebius Printing Company, in Milwaukee, Wis., will be running 24 hours a day to print the inside pages, replete with color photographs, drawings, chart; and whole catalogue of fancy type and headlines. An additional week or more will be required just to bind the product.picture was not a favorite with the American Express staff, who preferred a castle in Spain or the scenic Rhine Valley, but they bowed to the judgement of the consumer test group.) Inside, since price is foremost in a potential traveler's mind, the cost of each package will be displayed at the top of the page in headline type; a list of What's Included will appear in an eyecatching band of white space nearby. There will also be fair warning that some trips might not be suitable for allfor example, for those unable to walk long distances and other details that might deter potential customers will be included. American Express is taking the chance of exposing the downside of its tours, not, says Miss Couch, because we like it, but because the travel business is to get a progressively cleaner image, we have to take into account a more aware consumer. The new brochure will be low on superlatives; as a matter of policy, American Express writers are not allowed to use such words as never, always and guaran.

title: HELP FOR ELDERLY POOR ON FUEL BILLS STYMIED
description: ALBANY, Sept. 10 (UPI)As a result of a very tight schedule imposed by Congress and the rivalry within the state government bureaucracy, thousands of the elderly poor are apparently going to miss out, on help in paying those large fuel bills they ran Uto last winter.

title: Benjy, a Gordon Setter, Best at Somerset Hills
description: NORTH BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 10A Gordon setter with the whimsical name of Ch. BenWen's Benjy McDee has taken his first two bests and three sporting groups in a little more than a month, and tonight he topped an entry of 2,065 dogs for the bestinshow trophy at the Somerset Hills Kennel Club's 43d show in North Branch Park.

title: Miss America of 48 Looks Back
description: WESTON SHE CUT A FLOWER from the garden, looked up and smiled a winning smile, ??? ?? it an ??? beat to mane sure the photograpner seized the moment. It has been 29 years since Bea Waring was Miss America, but she still hasn't lost the art of projecting herself, nor has she lost her enthusiasm for a contest that some see as something less than a vanguard effort in the struggle for sexual equality.

title: Ch. Chumulari Chin Te Jih: A Shih Tzu Designed to Excel in Show Ring
description: Ch. Chumlad Chin Te Jih is now the bestknown Shih Tzu in the East and, in a way, the stylish toy walked right off the drawing board into the show ring. Victor Joris, the awardwinning fashion designer and former Hollywood film costumer, News made the decision to show of his esteemed pet only after he had sketched the dog Dogs like a design, with an anatomy book in one hand and, he added, three Shih Tzu books in the other.

title: Politicians Play NewParty Game
description: WHITE PLAINS WHEN Westchester voters go to the polls in November, they will have trouble recognizing some of the parties they will find on their ballots. Even the politicians will find some curious additions to the usual lineup of Republican, Democratic, Conservative and Liberal.

title: Births
description: Jimmy and Isabel (nee Citrin) are thrilled to announce the birth of their first child, Allison Beth, on Thursday, Sept. 1, 1977. Excited grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Milton Hirschfeld of Paterson, N.J., Mr. and Mrs. Jules Field of Riverdale, N.Y. and Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Pestronk of Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Great grandmother is Mrs. Ida Gilbert of New York City.

title: State Shifts Policy on Ill Youths
description: TRENTON THE placement of emotionally disturbed or socially malajusted youngsters in residential treatment centers as far away as Florida and Texas no longer will be permitted under a plan adopted by the state's Division for Youth and Family Services.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)The Federal Communications Commission concluded a wide ranging, fourday crack. down against illegal use of citizens band radios today, closing down 279 operations in a steppedup response to complaints of frequency interference.

title: De.borahLynne Peter Wed to Thomas Hustek
description: DeborahLynne Peter, daughter of Mr.;and Mrs. Joseph G. Peter of Lloyd Harbor, LI., was married yesterday to Thomas Michael Hustek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hustek Jr. of Milford, Conti.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: The gaudy jacket of this book, with its nearly fourinchhigh colorful letters spelling out GAY, belies the tact and intelligence of the text, which offers young people a valuable, unsensationalized account of the nature, history, life styles, problems, and yesin explicit detailthe sexual acts of homosexuals.

title: Richard Frederick DeMatteis Weds Lynn M. Mormando
description: Lynn Marie Monnando, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas F. Morrriando, was married yesterday in Westbury, L.I., to Richard Frederick DeMatteis, son of Mr. and Mrs: Frederick DeMatteis. Both families are of Old Westbury, L.I. The. Rev. William R. Logan performed the ceremony, in St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr. Thomas F. Code.

title: A LIFE IN THE TALMUD
description: The two and a half million words of the Talmud were the universe for David Weiss during his childhood in Sighet, a town disputed between Rumania and Hungary. A Talmud prodigy who began his study at age and who memorized 200 of its densely printed 5,422 pages, he earned money replying to posers such as, If I put pin through word X on page Y, what words would it pierce on the pages beneath?

title: INTERVIEW
description: SOUTH ORANGE WHEN it comes to providing energy to the state, Joel R. Jacobson, the recently appointed Commissioner of Energy, says, I don't think the average man in the street believes that there is crisis.

title: County's Legacy to the America's Cup
description: FOR HALF a century, people from Westchester and Fairfield Counties have dominated the America's Cup scene in designing, building, skippering or crewing the sleek yachts. This year is different, for there was not a skipper or helmsman from either county in the whole group that began the summerlong sets of trial races. However, two men who are and have long been active in the design and building of the contending yachtsOlin J. Stephens 2d of Scarsdale and Henry S. Sayers of Larchmontcontinue to make their influence felt.

title: David Howell Weds SusanWard All port
description: Susan Ward Allport, daughter of Jane Raible Allport of Wilton, Conn., and Alexander W. Allport of New York, was married yesterday to David Carleton Howell. Justice of the Peace Edna M. Jones performed the ceremony in Wilton at the home of the bride's mother.

title: MUSIC MAILBAG
description: Reading Harold Schonberg's article, A Fascinating Document of Musical Futility [July 31], I was disturbed by the statement that ASCAP still has a headlock on most of the important American composers. The 1971 edition of the BMI Symphonic Catalogue [indicates] that BMI has its own roster of very prestigious American composers that at least equals the ASCAP topdrawer listing mentioned by Mr. Schonberg with the of Charles.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THIS is long overdue. For some time now, I've been wanting to thank Brendan Byrne for sending me $36 a couple of months ago. I think it was $36 plus a couple of cents, but whatever it was I think Brendan Byrne deserves to be thanked:

title: Belmont Jockeys
Talk With Toni Allorrsori
description: IN her office at Random House, where she a senior editor, Toni Morrison sat behind a desk stacked high with correspondence and typed looseleaf manuscripts. Around her the walls were lined with copies of books she bad edited.most prominently, an oversized facsimile of Muhammad Ali's The Greatest And, of course, there were copies of her own novels: The Bluest Eye (1970), Sula (1974) and her latest, Song of Solomon.

title: THE IRISH PARADOX
description: To an American, a problem is something to be solved. To an Irishman, a problem is something to explore, to get caught up in, to increase and multiply, to extend to the farthest boundaries of human imagination and exasperation.

title: Yonkers
description: (otb payoffs sublect to 5% municipal surtax)

title: Kimm Schlobohm, Photographer, Wed To John Hopps 2d
description: The marriage of Marilee Kimm Schlobohm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Schlobohm Jr. of Montclair, N.J., to John Stephen Hopps 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland E. Hopps Jr. of Barrington, R.I., took place yesterday in the Glen Ridge (N.J.) Congregational Church. The Rev. John McFadden performed the ceremony.

title: Young Trouble
description: IT'S hard to think about colleges in the slump days of 1977. They seem like pathetic, walledin places with a gift for delivering basic little truths and no jobs. But November  December, by George Bower, is a college novel that takes us back to 1962. We have the Kennedys, Jack Pear and the Peace Corps. Even Stevenson was tough now.

title: The Hispanic Vote: Rush for Realignment?
description: APOLITICA1 revolution is under way among New Jersey's 600,000 Hispanics. When you say Puerto Ricansthe state's largest Hispanic groupthe political paladin thinks: Too young to vote (our median ag? is 18.9 years), underregistered (it varies from onethird to onehalf of elgible adults), low turnout (low for primaries but moderate to heavy for general elections) and Democrat (80 percent voted for President Carter).

title: Steve Henderson's War
description: The battle for men's minds and money is waged under our very noses these days, and that's the main event in sports. There's horse war between New Jersey and New York, a tennis war between Forest Hills and Flushing Meadow, a boxing war between Madison Square Garden and every place else and a baseball war between the Yankees and Mets. Sometimes t h battles are fought before packed crowds, like the one that will fill the tennis stadium today, Sometimes the spectators and their cash are divided, as they have been this week among Belmont Park, Yonkers Raceway and the new night track in East Rutherford. Sometimes the action is lonelier as it was the other day when only 3,186 customers watched the Mets lose to the Philadelphia Phillies while most of the town's baseball fans waited for the Yankees to play the Boston Red Sox this week.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: vats placements in this countrya measure of its close ties to institutional customers. Salomon also ranked third among managers of syndicated public offerings of debt equity, behind Morgan Stanley & Company and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: Pride is dealt another blow in this agreeable object lesson.
description: An itinerant painter of frescoes (who's a bit of a con artist as well) trades his talent for free meals at a monastery. The bill of fare, however, consists solely of bilious green vegetable soup, and so the painter bribes extra food from the good brothers by promising each one in turn that his face will be immortalized on a St. George fresco. Of course, it's not hard to guess whose likeness actually appears on the finished fresco. For their part, the monks accept the painter's trick with good enough grace and an understandable itch to get even. And at the farewell dinner they make sure their guest of honor downs a heaping bowlful of soup du jour? Granted, the moral is drawn as baldly as the monks shiny pates, but the sunny crayoned pictures display a cheerful vitality and the tidy view of cloistered life has its own appeal.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I didn't read How to Turn Women On With Words in the present edition of Penthouse Forum, The International Journal of Human Relations. Just seeing it advertised on the cover made my blood boil. Articles like this spoil women. They all read this rubbish and then want to know why you never turn them on with words the way other men turn on women.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayWestchester K.C. 60th allbreed dog.show and obedience trail featuring 13 specialties. Lyndhurst Estate, Route 9, Tarrytown, N.Y.; 3,348 dogs; 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: BodyBuilders Cite Beame
description: Former heavyweight boxing champion Joe Louis, who also had tasted both victory and defeat, yesterday visited Mayor Beame at City Hall. The exboxer presented the Mayor, who was defeated in Thursday's Democratic primary election, with a plaque citing his great contributions to physical fitness. The plaque was awarded by the World BodyBuilding Guild.

title: Dutch Forces Raid Moluccan Quarter in Assen in a Search for Arms
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 10Using helicopters and armored personnel carriers, Dutch policemen and military units staged a predawn raid on the Moluccan quarter here today in another search for weapons.

title: LETTERS
description: I was delighted by Taylor Branch's tongueincheek article about Saul Kripke('New Frontiers in American Philosophy, Aug. 19), but saddened to think American philosophy is still so completely in the hands of the analysts. Lev Shestov, a Russian philosopher, wrote: There are things that it is better not to understand, not to explain. Strange as it may be, it is often better to weep, curse, and laugh than to understand. DAVID ROGERS South Orange, N.J.

title: A Vote for New York City
description: New Yorkers have voted for a fresh start in their city politics. Often maligned for sloth and selfindulgence, they delivered a message in last week's primary that deserves to be heard by an often skeptical nation. This city is eager for renewal, and its citizens are doing their share to earn the help they require.

title: Yankees 193 Losers; Jays' Howell Bats In 9
description: Warning: Yankee fans are advised not to read the following account of yesterday's game with the Toronto Blue Jays. It may be injurious to their health.

title: Legislators Move Slowly on Unitickets
description: HERBERT R. HANDS, publicrelations manager who lives in Eastchester and commutes to New York City, is sold on Uniticket, a new concept in bus and train travel. I save money, about $5 a month, he said, and it's tremendous convenience. When he boards his bus to the Scarsdale train station he doesn't have to fumble for change (30 cents) and on most mornings is not required to show his Uniticketthe driver remembers the passengers who bought them that month.

title: MAILBAG More on Cultural Apartheid
description: Donal Henahan and The Times are to be congratulated for Will Cultural Apartheid Poison the Arts in America? (Aug. 28). The prospect of an everincreasing split between blacks and whites in the contest over national policies about the arts is real and, as Henahan says, is not being discussed candidly and openly by those who lead our major cultural institutions.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Ed Kranepool has played for the New York Mets since 1962, when he was 17 years old. This article is excerpted from the new book Baseball, by Ed Kranepool with Ed Kirkman (Mason/ Charter, $3.95 paperbound). Copyright Ed Kranepool and Ed Kirkman 1977. It is reprinted with permission of the publisher.

title: Son to Market a Carters Album
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Jeff and Annette Carter, son and daughterinlaw of the President, have been noticed in the corridors of power with cameras in recent months, and now the reason is clear: They are planning to market their nictures in a Carter family album.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: SOME CHAMPIONS, by Ring Lardner. (Scribner's, $3.95.) The current rediscovery of the talent of Ring Lardner (18851933) is carried forward by these previously hardtocomeby journalistic pieces and stories, gathered and well arranged by Matthew J. Broccoli and Richard Layman. Of the collection, the journalism is best; all of it proves that Lardner is very much worth reading.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN the confusion over many conflicting economic statistics issued during the summer months, deepening sense of caution has arisen among investors and some business analysts, as well as an excessive level of concern about the apparently negative aspects of the current scene.

title: Dr. Rose Marie Ver Elst Bride of Dr. David Gens
description: Dr. Rose Marie Ver Elst and Dr. David Reeder Gens were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John Paul Gens, in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Lee Moore of the Congregational Church of Darien.

title: What Makes '60 Minutes Tick
description: Tonight 60 Minutes begins its 10th season on CBS, with another segment in its weekly magazine format that promises to cause a stir an interview with Idi Amin's former health minister, who discusses his exboss's cannibalism,among other things. Inasmuch as it has been this type of tough, groundbreaking reporting that helped boost the show onto the charmed circle of Nielsen's 10 rated programs last winter, it would seem an appropriate time to take a look eat what has kept 60 Minutes rolling while other magazine shows come and go in a vain effort to duplicate its success. Much of the credit belongs to the three people who have been with the show since its inception. Two of themexecutive producer Don Hewitt and correspondent Mike Wallacehave been duly recognized and appreciated. The third is a largely unsung hero, and yet an integral part of the 60 Minutes success story, the show's senior producer, Palmer Williams.

title: Brookdale College Teachers Vote To Strike for Higher Wages
description: LINCROFT, N.J., Sept. 9 (UPI)Faculty members at Brookdale Community College have authorized a strike starting Sent. 19.

title: Two Cadet Records Surpassed by Hall
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 10For those who entertained any lingering doubts that Leamon Hall is the greatest passer in the history of Army football, the 6foot5inch senior quarterback dispelled them today. Getting spectacular aerial performance from Hall, the Cadets posted a 3410 victory over the University of Massachusetts before an appreciative crowd of 22,101 at Michie Stadium.

title: IN AMERICA
description: On a far shingle long ago when as a boy I came here put ear to shell of the thundering sea sundering sea seagulls high over calling & calling back then at Cape Ann Gloucester Where Olson saw himself Ishmael and wrote his own epitaph:

title: Rosh haShanah Starts Tomorrow
description: Jews around the world will usher in the new year of 5738 tomorrow at sunset.

title: The Multipurpose Library
description: ARMONK has no movie theaters, no major stores, no exhibit spaces, and no community center. But right in the center of town there is a place where residents can find out about everything from CB radio to property tax assessments and chat with their neighbors as well.

title: Around the U.S., 20 Million Gallons a Year
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif011 is moving south from Alaska by ship at a rate projected to reach 800,000 barrels a day. A comparable addition is In prospect from the offshire development now gathering momentum on all coasts. Current oil importations are about 7 million barrels a day42 percent of the nation's consumption.

title: Trenton Eyes Genetic Studies
description: TRENTON AFTER several months of public uneasiness about recombinant genetic research in New Jersey, a special hearing examiner will begin taking testimony about the subject tomorrow.

title: Samuel Gutner Weds Elizabeth A. Dranow
description: Elizabeth A. Dranow, senior fashion editor of Seventeen magazine, was married yesterday in New York to Samuel Gutner, president of Fabricland, a textile manufacturer. Rabbi Irving Koslowe of the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dranow, parents of the bride.

title: Official's Home in Azores Bombed
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, Azores, Sept 11 (Reuters)A bomb today badly damaged the new official residence here of the resident Portuguese minister in the Azores Islands, Gen. Galvao de Figueiredo, the police said. Separatist groups have in the past taken responsibility for bombings here.

title: MIU U.S. JOURNALISTS SEEN LINKED TO CIA
description: Rolling Stone magazine will report in the issue now going to press that some 400 American journalists, including correspondents for The New York Times, CBS News and a dozen other organizations, secretly shared information with and Fin some cases provided operational assistance to the Central Intelligence Agency over the last 25 years.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list scheduled for week follows:

title: RUNNERSUP STRESS CONSTITUENT POWER
description: Bella S. Abzug, Percy E. Sutton and Herman Badillowho together received more votes than the two successful candidates in the Democratic mayoral primary last weekgot together yesterday to remind Edward I. Koch and Mario M. Cuomo of the power of their liberal, black and Hispanic constituencies. And last night it was learned that Representative Badillo had scheduled a news conference for 10:30 this morning at which he would endorse Mr. Koch, his fellow Congressman.

title: Schenly Plays a Rich Brahms As 4th Avery Fisher. Winner
description: As one of the 1976 Avery Fisher Award winners, Paul Schenly was given his big moment in Fisher Hall Saturday night as he performed three solo works and, with Erich Leinsdorf conducting the New York Philharmonic, Brahms's First Piano Concerto.

title: LAWYERS NEGLECTING RIGHTS OF THE AGED
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., Sept. 11Evidence that many lawyers cannot assist the elderly on questions of their rights, pension benefits, Medicare and Social Security was presented at a seminar here yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times Sept. 1 that the Queens Democratic organization had initiated a legal challenge to Maurice H. Nadjari as the Republican candidate for District Attorney in last Thursday's primary. The challenge had been made by Patrick Beary, an enrolled member of the Republican party.

title: Taylor's Pinkerton Effectively Sung
description: Yesterday afternoon's performance of Puccini's Madame Butterfly at the New York City Opera, the second of the new season, was familiarly cast with the exception of Richard Taylor, who sang Pinkerton with the company for the first time.

title: REV. MICHAEL J. COSTELLO
description: The Rev. Michael J. Costello, a member of the Society of Jesus who held many administrative posts in Roman Catholic education, died Saturday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Rock: A Funkadelic Yes and No
description: ParliamentFunkadelic and Bootsy's Rubber Band finally brought their PFunk Earth Tour 197677 to Madison Square Garden Saturday night. It wasn't an unqualified triumph. But 15,000 people still had what seemed to be a most enioyable time.

title: 1980 Olympics Work Roiling Lake Placid
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.Just south of this village, a 175foothigh, bright yellow crane bobs up from the top of wooded Intervale Hill. The crane, which is visible for miles around and bears a flashing blue light to warn off passing planes, is at work on a vast new skijump complex for the 13th Olympic Winter Games, an event that is expected to draw half a million visitors to this village of 3,000 people for 12 days in 1980.

title: Amy Margulies Married
description: Amy Rachelle Margulies and Stephen Mark Berman were married yesterday at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., by Rabbi Michael Robinson. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Margulies 9f Larchmont, N.Y., where her father is a dentist. Mr. Berman's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Berman of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. His father is a vice president of Bloomingdale's, New York.

title: Deaths
description: BERKMANBertha. Beloved wife of the late Michael, devoted mother of Helene Apaghian, cherished grandmother, dear sister. Services Monday, Jeffer Funeral Homes, Hillside Ave. at 188 St., Hollis, L.I.

title: Strike Grounds Lisbon Airline
description: LISBON, Sept. 11 (AP)A oneday pilots strike today virtually shut down the Portuguese national airline, TAP, and disrupted travel plans of 9,000 passengers on about 60 flights in Europe, America and Africa. The Union of Civil Aviation Pilots, which says its 306 members are among the lowest paid in the world, said negotiations with the airline broke down over issues of pay and work conditions resulting from an expansion of TAP's summer flight schedule.

title: Endorsement Expected Today
description: Representative Herman Badillo, who was among the five candidates defeated in last week's primary for the Democratic mayoral nomination, will endorse Representative Edward I. Koch in next Monday's runoff, according to aides to Mr. Koch.

title: G.A.O. SAYS CARGO BILL MAY RAISE FUEL COSTS BY UP TO $610 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11In a longawaited report, the General Accounting Office estimates that the cargo preference bill supported by the Carter Administration could raise the nation's fuel bill by $550 million to $610 million a yearmore than five times the estimate made by the Administration in July.

title: Chess:
description: The most unpredictable player in the recent Torneo del Vino in Montilla, Spain, was the Spanish international master Ricarao Caivo. While he ended up losing no less than five games, two of these to much lowerranked opponents, he also knocked off two of the favorites in the nineround event, the Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson and myself.

description: AT RIVERSIDE, Y.C.

title: ABRAHAM A. OESTREICH
description: Abraham A. Oestreich, chairman of the board and a founder of the Duray Company, a manufacturer of cosmetic bags and travel accessories, died Saturday after a short illness at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 76 years old and lived in Lawrence, L. I., and Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: Linda L. Corby Wed to Franklyn H. Beal
description: In the Joseph Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago yesterday afternoon, Linda Ladd Corby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard LeRoy Corby Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married to Franklyn Harry Beal, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Beal of Harvey, Ill. Rabbi David Graubart performed the ceremony.

title: B1 Planner Up for Appointment to No. 3 Energy Job
description: The executive, Dale Myers, the president of Rockwell International's North American aircraft operations division, is expected to be nominated as under secretary when the two dozen top appointments to the new department, which will consolidate the acclivities of the Federal Energy Administration, the Energy Research and Development Administration and the Federal Power Commission, are announced this week.

description: MAGUIR.EFrancis X. Memorial service for Frank Maguire, Wednesday Sept. 14,. at 6:30 PM in the chapel at St. Patrick& Cathedral.

title: World News Briefs
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 11 (Reu ters)The Dutch police studied today what they said was a plan by South Moluccan militants to seize hostages again in a campaign to obtain independence for their Southeast Asian island.

title: Beyond Lance
description: WASHINGTONTo help Jody Powell prepare the President for his press conference Wednesday, here are a few of the questions that should come up:

title: Saturday's College Football
Around the Nation
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 11 (AP)  A 19yearold banker's daughter, kidnapped four days ago from her college campus here, was driven to North Carolina today and released unhurt after a $150,000 ransom was paid.

title: Argentine Women In Weekly Protest Over Abductions
description: BUENOS AIRES. Sept. 11 (AP)Early every Thursday afterno6n, the women slowly begin arriving at the city's main square, Plaza de Mayo.

title: Bomb Explodes in a Bus Station And 10 Are Hurt in Southern Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 11 (AP)A bomb exploded today in a bus station crowded with holiday travellers in the southern desert town of Beersheba, wounding 10, persons, two of them seriously, officials reported.

title: News Summary
description: A plan for the Wbest Bank area, now held by Israel, is scheduled for presentation by Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan in Washington next week. It would give Palestinian Arabs a large measure of internal autonomy while Israeli forces would maintain strategic installations. It assumes that since no territorial IsraeliArab agreement is in sight, a practical arrangement for both sides to live together should be tried. [Page 1, Column. 6.]

title: The Stakes in Bakke
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11The construction industry in Massachusetts, as in much of the country, has a long history of discrimination. So the United States Court of Appeals here said in 1974. Because generalized attempts to break down racial barriers had not worked, the court allowed the state to write into a building contract a goal of 20 percent minority workers.

title: The Enimatic Poet of Professional Tennis
description: In his book of poems entitled 125, published several years ago in Argentina, Guillermo Vilas wrote of dreams, death and the loneliness of man:

title: Injury to Cavanaugh Dashes Aspirations of Pitt
description: Matt Cavanaugh, the one man the University of Pittsburgh could least afford to lose through injury this season, was lost through injury before he could help the Panthers much, but after he proved just how important he was to the Panthers's aspirations. Those hopes for a second national championship are now very slim and have almost deteriorated to a waitIllnextyear feeling with this season only one game old.

title: The Last Day at Forest Hills.
description: Jimmy Connors had hit balls for a few minutes, had a massage, took a shower, used a hair dryer and put on his usual tennis clothes with the blueandred stripes across the shoulders of his white shirt. Now, wearing a blue jacket with United States on the back, he appeared outside the upstairs door to the men's locker room at the West Side Tennis Club and hurried down the winding green staircase. Suddenly, the people on the veranda of the old Tudor clubhouse stopped talking and drinking.

title: Palm Reader Held As Widow's Captor Over Nine Months
description: A palm reader and her boyfriend were arrested on charges of holding 37yearold widow a virtual captive for nine months and robbing her of about $5,000 in Social Security payments on the pretext that they would cure her crippled 15yearold daughter.

title: Death Penalty Is Assailed
description: In his harshest denunciation to date of his Democratic opponent's advocacy of the death penalty, Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that Representative Edward I. Koch was a politician who had read the polls and seen a fear and was telling the people of New York, I will give you the electric chair, I will give you death.'

title: Carter's Visit Reminds Democrats Of Party Links and Aid for Needy
description: Trenton, Sept. 11If it was the hope of the leaders of the state Democratic Party that President Carter's campaign trip to New Jersey yesterday could make pocketbook issues the major thrust of this year's race for Governor, they succeeded as far as one committee man from Trenton's First Ward was concerned.

title: Carter Hears Sermon On News Scapegoats
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) President Carter attended church services today and listened to a sermon warning that the public tended to view exposs in the news media as the ritual replacement for public executions.

title: Yanks Split With Jays and Lead by 1
description: And then the lead was 1 games. Just one week ago, the Yankees led Boston by 4 games and the march toward their second straight division title seemed inevitable. But following their split of a doubleheader with the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday, the Yankees lead had shrunk to 1 games, which becomes an almost insignificant margin in light of the threegame series they play with the Red Sox beginning tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium.
