title: Advertising
description: In their newspapers or magazines and on radio and television, New Yorkers lately have been treated to or assailed by a plethora of soothing, reassuring and even surprising bank advertisinz.

title: 2 Olympic Skaters Wed
description: MEQUON, Wis., Sept. 11 (AP)The Olympic speed skaters, Leah Poulos and Peter Mueller, were married here yesterclay.

title: More Fuel for Consumers This Winter?
description: The present worldwide surplus of oil will probably continue through the coming winter, according to industry and Government sources interviewed since news of price shaving started seeping out of the Middle East Last week. The glut, they predict, should help keep a lid Economic on petroleum product prices throughout this unusual period. The reasons for the surplus are numerous on both the supply and the demand sides. Basically, the oil companies simply miscalculated. The industry has been doing a bad planning job of what it must produce, one specialist with a major oil company conceded in an Interview.

title: 22 New Cholera Cases Reported in Jordan for Total of 166 There
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Twentytwo new cholera victims have been reported in Jordan, raising the total number of confirmed cases to 166 as of last night, the Health Ministry announced today. The Ministry added, however, that no deaths had yet been reported in Jordan as a result of the current outbreaks in the Middle East.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: BLOOMFIELDJesselovingly romp bered today on your birthday & everyday. Gladys, Bernard, Cheryl It Jason.

title: How Many Pitchers, How Much Equality
description: The Justice Department has now struggled through the complexities of the Allan Bakke suit for admission to medical school and, like so many thoughtful Americans, it finally choked on the idea of a quota for blacks and other disadvantaged minorities. It wants President Carter to endorse a Government argument to the Supreme Court that race or ethnicity can be taken into account in assessing applicants, but that a quota reserving fixed number of places for minority students is unconstitutional.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M. WNCN. Pieces de Clavecin. No. 5, La Portugaise, Forqueray; Festmarsch from Tannhauser, Wagner; Symphony in F (K.75), Mozart; March and Battle from Rinaldo, Handel; Violin Concerto No.5, Vivaldi.

title: Vilas Captures Open Title From Connors, 26, 63, 76, 6u
description: It was a farewell to remember at Forest Hills, yesterday, as Guillermo Vilas beat Jimmy Connors in four thrilling sets for the men's singles title at the United States Open tennis championships.

title: JACK GARRATT
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 11Jack Garratt, member of the Irish Senate, the upper house of Parliament, was killed in an automobile accident in County Longford early today, the police said. Mr. Garratt, 63 years old, who lived in Ballina, County Mayo, had been a Senator eight years. He was a member of Ireland's governing party, the Fianna Fail.

title: Sauce Factories Closed in Vietnam
description: SONGICHLA, Thailand, Sept 5The fishing boat PQ 934 landed at this Vietnamese refugee camp in southern Thailand last week carrying 44 men, women and children, including a baby born somewhere between the Vietnamese island of Phu Quoc and here, and also bearing bad news for Vietnamese all over the world: They have stopped producing nuoc main on Phu Quoc.

title: 9th African Parade Salutes Harlem's Roots
description: The search for roots came home to Harlem yesterday as 10,000 participants in the ninth annual AfricanAmerican Day Parade marched and danced to the theme Salute our roots.

title: Belmont Racing
DAMN SAID TO OFFER ARABS OF WEST BANK INTERNAL AUTONOMY
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 11Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan is expected to present a proposal to President Carter regarding the Israelioccupied West Bank in which the Palestinian Arabs would be given:substantial internal autonomy and self:government while the Israelis would maintain strategic military installations for security purposes.

title: Tullius Takes Title
description: ST. JOVITE, Quebec, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Bob Tullius of Herndon, Va., finished third in the production sports car class to win the sports Car Club of America TransAm championship at Le Circuit Mont Tremblant today.

title: Asians Given More Time
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 11 (AP) The International Federation of Football Associations has extended by seven months the deadline to its Asian Members to revoke the expulsion of Israel and Taiwan from the Asian Football Confederation and the admission of China. The previous deadline was next August. The Asian group faces suspension if it does not comply.

title: ThirdRanking Foreign Aidofficial Resigns in Disagreement on Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Carter Administration's thirdranking foreign aid official said today he had resigned from the Agency for International Development in sharp disagreement with the policies of the agency's administrator, John F. Gilligan.

title: MARCH BY CATALANS DRAWS VAST THRONG
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 11Several hundred thousand people celebrating Catalan National Day marched through the heart of this graceful city today in the biggest demonstration held in Spain since the death of Franco two years ago.

title: The New York Times/Barlon Silverman
description: It was a farewell to remember at Forest Hills, yesterday, as Guillermo Vilas beat Jimmy Connors in four thrilling sets for the men's singles title at the United States Open tennis championships.

title: Foreign Press In Africa Finds Curbs Growing
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept 11An Associated Press correspondent spent a month in a fetid cell in the Central African Empire. A Canadian reporter was seized and imprisoned for three weeks in Uganda.

title: WILLIAM MAGRUDER, HEADED SST PROJECT
description: William M. Magruder, the former test pilot and aircraft designer who briefly headed a Federal project to develop supersonic airliners in the early 1970's, died Saturday of a heart attack on a golf course in WinstonSalem, N.C. He was 54 years old.

title: Parents in Queens Assail Release on Bail of Suspect In ChildMolesting Cases
description: District Attorney John Santucci of Queens met yesterday with a group of Glen Oaks parents who were angered by the release on bail of a Long Island man charged with two incidents of child molestation in northwestern Queens.

title: Multifuel Car Engine Gets New Tests
description: A 35yearold engine design, tested for many years in cars and Army jeeps, is receiving new attention today from both the Federal Government and its industrial developers as a promising means of both economizing on fuel and controlling air pollution.

title: San Francisco Ambush Called Chinese Gang Revenge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11A Chinese youth was shot to death and another critically wounded in an ambush early this morning as they were returning to their apartment in what the police described as retaliation for last week's slayings in a Chinese restaurant here.

title: Sports Authority Agrees to Pay East Rutherford $9.7 Million Over 1 0 Y ears for Using Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, Sept. 11The giw Jersey Sports and Exposition Au1 thority has unexpectedly agreed to pay East Rutherford $9.7 million over the naxt 10 years for the 156 acres of the Hackensack Meadowlands the authority acquired for a race track and a football stadium.

title: CODD IN QUEENS HOSPITAL; EXHAUSTION IS REPORTED
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd was admitted to St. John's Queens Hospital in Elmhurst early yesterday, suffering from what a hospital spokesman termed exhaustion. On the advice of !his doctor, Mr. Codd is to remain in the hospital for several days of observation I and testing.

title: Barbara Eleanora Mel Wed to Dr. Celso Bianco
description: Barbara Eleanora Mei and Dr. Celso Bianco were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Thomas Blessin in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. The bride is daughter of Armando G. Mei of New York and Oakland Valley, N.Y., and the late Lea Vetrulli Mei. Mr. Mei is a restaurateur.

title: Events Today
description: ANDY POLON, ragtime and blues singer, South Street Seaport Museum, Fulton Street and East River, 7:30.

title: CARTER SAID TO BACK BAR TO RACE QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11President Carter will not alter the general themes of the Justice'Department's proposed legal brief in a landmark civil rights case, although he may suggest some substantive changes in the wording, according to White House officials.

title: 650 Vendors Turn 3d Ave. Into 20Block Shopping Mall
description: Hundreds of thousands jammed the second annual Third Avenue fair yesterday, turning a 20block stretch of the avenue into a sidewalktosidewalk shopping mall.

title: Market Place
description: Ask the average stockbroker how business has been lately and you are apt to get a Brorpc cheer. But it is a different story at the socalled discount houses that offer customers substantial savings in commission on the sale or purchase of stocks, bonds and options.

title: RUNNERSUP STRESS CONSTITUENT POWER
description: Bella S. Abzug, Percy E. Sutton and Herman Badillowho together received more votes than the two successful candidates in the Democratic mayoral primary last weekgot together yesterday to remind Edward I. Koch and Mario M. Cuomo of the power of their liberal, black and Hispanic constituencies. And last night it was learned that Representative Badillo had scheduled a news conference for 10:30 this morning at which he would endorse Mr. Koch, his fellow Congressman.

title: Foreign Press In Africa Finds Curbs Growing
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept 11An Associated Press correspondent spent a month in a fetid cell in the Central African Empire. A Canadian reporter was seized and imprisoned for three weeks in Uganda.

title: Italian Ban Lifted, U.S. Medical Students Euphoric
description: PERUGIA, Italy  When 22yearold Deborah Bostic left Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to learn Italian this summer, she did not know whether the Italian Government would let her stay in the fall to study medicine.

title: Study Urges a U.S. Family Policy
description: Culminating a fiveyear study of how public programs affect the family, the Carnegie Council on Children will formally propose today a sweeping national family policy to guarantee a job for every family's breadwinner and to assure that no child need be raised in poverty.

title: Red Fair in France Draws Vast Throng
description: PARIS. Sept. 11 (AP)  Stalinist chants mingled with Nashville sounds and Brittany bagpipes today as French Communists, confident of new political power, turned out for their giant annual fair.

title: POLICY LIBERALIZING MORTGAGES URGED FOR THRIFT GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Robert H. McKinney, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has proposed what the agency terms a major policy change in its regulations affecting mortgage lending of savings and loan institutions.

title: CARTER SAID TO BACK BAR TO RACE QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11President Carter will not alter the general themes of the Justice Department's proposed legal brief in a landmark civil rights case, although he may suggest some substantive changes in the wording, according to White House officials.

title: I.M.F. Publishes Gloomy Assessment Of World Economy
description: The International Monetary Fund declared yesterday that the state of the world economy was unsatisfactory because of rising unemployment and subnormal growth, and that widespread inflation had imposed both monetary and fiscal restraints that left little room for maneuver to improve the situation.

title: Salvation Army Center Dedicated
description: The new quarters of the Salvation. Army's New York Temple Corps Community Center at 132136 West 14th Street, were dedicated yesterday afternoon in ceremonies held in the center's auditorium. The corps, which provides family counseling and other services for the Chelsea community in Manhattan, had operated for more than 20 years from the Salvation Army's headquarters at 120 West 14th Street.

title: Typhoon Strikes China
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 11 (Reuters)A typhoon uprooted hundreds of trees in Shanghai last night as powerful winds swept across the Yellow Sea area and into eastern China. Heavy rains flooded the already waterlogged fields near this east Chinese industrial and port city, but no other damage was visible.

title: Kill the Crocodile
description: Over the Labor Day weekend a crocodile in captivity the Miami Serpentarium killed a 6yearold boy who had fallen into its pit. A grisly tragedy. The next day, the owner of the crocodile killed it with nine shots from Luger pistol. It took the animal an hour to die.

title: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee
description: Mayor Beame yesterday made a round of public appearances in Manhattan and Staten Island that proved he still had the affection of many New York's citizens even though he did not get most of their votes.

title: Books of The Times
description: What a creepy book this is. And I'm not sure I mean creepy in a pejorative sense. In a way, Judith Rossner whose Looking for Mr. Goodbar is soon to be a moviehas reversed the strategy Lois Gould used in A Sea Change. Attachments begins in creepiness, goes on to become almost numbingly normal, and then ends up seeming to say that normality itself is creepy, that life is a pathological condition: We have met the freaks, and they are we.

title: Bethpage Scores in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, LT., Sept. 11  Led by Ted Shapiro and Harvey Rhein with three goals each, the Bethpage polo team defeated Brookville, 64, today at. Bethpage State Park. Ted Brinkman scored all four goals for Brookville.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Secessionist Mood Grows Among Sri Lanka Tamils
description: JAFFNA, Sri LankaThis sleepy and sandy peninsula at the northern tip of Sri Lanka has become the center of new separatist movement working for the creation of an independent country, like a Hindu kingdom that flourished here 2.000 years ago.

title: Seminar Discusses Ways to Assist Arts
description: PARAMUS, Sept. 11As performers for more than two dozen local ensembles acted, danced and played their instruments on the lawn of Bergen Community College today, cultural and government leaders met inside to discuss the future of the arts in New Jersey, and various ways to increase government support of artistic endeavours.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Was riding on his father's shoulders. Now you've seen Ed Koch, the father told the tot.

title: Industrialist's Kidnappers Send Bonn New Message
description: BONN, Sept. 11In their first move in 39 hours, the kidnappers of a West German industrial leader have restated their demands and set new deadlines. The Government replied at 6 P.M. this evening with a request for new proof that the abducted man was still alive.

title: The New York Times/William E. Sauro
description: Edward I. Koch, Mario M. Cuomo and their strategists worked vigorously over the weekend to attract endorsements from New York City's top Democratic leaders, but, with an exception or two, it appeared yesterday that various district leaders seemed to be split over whom to support in next Monday's runoff for the party's mayoral nomination.

title: Transformation at Boys Town. Institution Becomes a Suburb
description: BOYS TOWN, Neb.In the early years of the century, when institutions were thought of as humane places where homeless children might be helped, Boys TownFather Flanagan's boys homewas a benign symbol, made all the more symbolic by a little help from Spencer Tracy and Hollywood.

title: Israel Davis Cup Victor
description: RAMAT HASHARON, Israel, Sept. 11 (AP)  Yair Wertheimer crushed Mati Timonen, 62, 63, 63, enabling Israel to clinch a victory over Finland in a 1978 Davis Cup tennis preliminary round today. The final score was 41.

title: Zenith's Promotion Is Criticized As TV Set Marketing War Grows
description: It is almost as if the calendar had been turned back 15 or 20 years in the television business.

title: Aide Asserts Amin Is Quite Fit But Still in Hospital After Illness
description: NAIROBI, Sept, 11 (Reuters)President Idi Amin has been very ill but is now quite fit, his Britishborn adviser, Rober Astles said today, after a week during which the Uganda leader was reported to have been in a coma following an operation.

title: Amtrak Is Ending Redcap Service At Stations in Northeast Corridor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  Starting Tuesday, rail travellers along Amtrak's Northeast corridor between Washington and Boston will have to carry their own bags. The rail corporation is eliminating its last 80 redcaps at 10 stations on the route. However, elderly or handicapped passengers will be able to get help if they call Amtrak in advance, a spokesman said. The move is expected to save $1.4 million in salaries and benefits, he added.

title: Libya Seeks Oil Meeting Delay
description: CAIRO, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Libya today asked the Arab League to postpone the 10th Arab oil conference scheduled to be held in Tripoli next December until Jan. 1622 next year. League official sources said the Libyans had suggested the conference be called to discuss, among other matters; studies on energy resources to replace oil.

title: DR.,CHARLES GARRETT, 51; PROFESSOR AT C.W. P051:
description: Charles Garrett, a professor of American history at C. W. Post College and a past president of the City Club, died Saturday at New York Hospital following treatment for cancer. He was 51 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Visibility in Districts Is Stressed By Two Freshmen Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11One of them talks about the dire effects of a basketball stuck in a storm sewer in Bergen C6unty. The other is concerned about nearly unpronounceable toxic substances 7polybrominated biphenyls, or PBB's for'shortfound in Bayonne.

title: EXPERTS BELIEVE FED IS PREPARING A RISE FOR INTEREST RATES
description: The credit markets became largely convinced last Friday that the Federal Reserve had embarked on another effort to lift shortterm interest rates in order to slow down the recent rapid growth of the nation's money supply.

title: Hyatt Chain Lays Mistise of Funds To ExPresident
description: The Hyatt Corporation, one of the nation's largest hotel chains, disclosed over the weekend its findings that Hugh M Friend Jr., its former president, had improperly used for personal purpose about half a million dollars in company funds.

title: Pomeranian Judged Best at Westchester
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 11More than 10,000 people and 3,247 dogs reflect an unusually successful show and Westchester had it today on the grounds of the Lyndhurst estate.

title: Jersey Crime Commission to Argue That Reputed Mobster Stay in Prison
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11 (AP)The State Commission of Investigation is scheduled to argue in court tomorrow that a reputed mobster, Ralph Napoli, the last of nine alleged gangsters jailed for refusing to testify, should not be released trom orison.

title: Giants Lose, 2721, but Find No. 1 Passer in Golsteyn
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 11The question was a silly one: Would Jerry Golsteyn, John McVay was asked, be the Giants starting quarterback when the regular season opened next week?

title: Morgan Prevails in B.C. Open Golf
description: ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 11 (UPI)Dr. Gil Morgan scored the first victory of his professional golfing career today, shooting a finalround 69 to finish at 270, 14 under par, ior a fiveshot victory over Lee Elder in the $220,000 B.C. open.

title: Swimming Coach at Yale Reported to Quit in Rift
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 11 (AP)Yale's swimming coach, Ed Bettendorf, has resigned. complaining of unreasonable and malicious criticism, according to a letter read to the squad today by the team captain, Bill Lindsay.

title: Archives Unit Of U.S. Sought For Apartments
description: When construction was finished on the United States Federal Building in 1899, the structure, a powerful mass of red brick in the Romanesque Revival style, loomed large over its Greenwich Village neighbours. The building was intended for use by customs agents, and it was deliberately set close to the piers, on the full block bounded by Washington, Greenwich, Christopher and Barrow Streets. Other large buildings followed, but none so massive. Even now the building  which, for a long time after the custom service gave it up, housed Federal Archives  has the distinction of being the largest building in Greenwich Village. But it has another distinction, too: It is entirely empty.

title: Bridge:
description: Serious tournament players often spend hours talking to their partners, formulating careful agreements about everyarea of bidding. Or nearly every area. There is a strong tendency to ignore preemptive bidding altogether, although about one deal in 10 begins in such fashion.

title: In Uganda, Dead, Dead, Dead, Dead
description: At around 11 p.m. three State Research officers [State Research Bureau, a key agency for liquidating President Idi Amin's opponents] came to us where we were sitting and asked us where we were going, and we told them that we were going to Canada, after that they told us to produce our passports after looking at our passports they told us to go with them in their office.

title: Pinochet, Marking Coup Anniversary, Rejects Any Change
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 11President Augusto Pinochet began his fifth year as head of Chile's military junta today with a confident, sometimes aggressive, speech rejecting any change in his authoritarian rule.

title: Red Richards And Jazz Trio
description: Red Richards is a jazz pianist who has suffered from the anonymity that is the usual fate of intermission pianists or pianists in traditional jazz groups that keep playing the same tunes over and over. He has, for many years, been in both positions and, as a result, is not so well known as he deserves to be.

title: I.M.F. Publishes Gloomy Assessment Of World Economy
description: The International Monetary fund declared yesterday that the state of the world economy was unsatisfactory because of rising unemployment and subnormal growth, and that widespread inflation had imposed both monetary and fiscal restraints that left little room for maneuver to improve the situation.

title: Italian Prix To Andretti; Lauda Is 2d
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Mario Andretti, enjoying his best season of Formula One racing, won the Italian Grand Prix today, but saw his slim hope of claiming the world drivers title evaporate.

title: Women in Oceanic Corps Named To Officer's Post on Survey Ship
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)A lieutenant in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Corps has been appointed to the highest shiboard post ever held by a woman in a United States uniformed service, the corps announced today.

title: The New York Times/William E. Sauro
description: GETTING TOGETHER: Three of the losing candidates in the Democratic mayoral primary, Percy E. Sutton, Bella S. Abzug and Representative Herman Badillo, speaking at a news conference. They announced their intention to influence the remainder of the election campaign, and also to press for a national urban policy. Page 41.

title: Television
description: 6:30(2)Summer Semester (4)Profiles in Politics (7)Listen and Learn (11)The Little Rascals

title: Bonnett Victor in 400
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 11 (AP)Neil Bonnett scored his first Grand National stock car victory by winning the Capital City 400 at Fairgrounds Raceway today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Palestinian rights3 P.M.

title: Gail Lefer, a Social Worker, Is Married to Richard Beier
description: The marriage of Gail Lefer to Richard Beier took place yesterday at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A short while ago, a discourse appeared here extolling the glories of bluehardshell crabs.. Crab meat was comparedwith unabashed ardor and enthusiasmto the flesh of lobster, shrimp, octopus, and squid and most things ambrosial that swim, crawl or otherwise negotiate the waters of oceans. bays or streams.

title: United Press international
description: BRINGING THEIR PROTEST TO WASHINGTON: About 200 opponents of the Concorde landing in New York being led past the White House by New York State Senator Sheldon Farber, at center, wearing hat. The demonstrators, most of whom live near Kennedy airport, made trip on chartered buses.

title: Feminist Group Cites Backlash Vows E.R.A. Push as Parley Ends
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 11After hearing repeated warnings of a growing rightwing backlash against their cause, hundreds of women political activists meeting here vowed with cheers and applause today to push for ratification of the troubled equal rights amendment.

title: Burton Greene Plays Anthology Of Jazz as the Exile Returned
description: Environ, the jazz loft at 475 Broadway, began on Saturday a threenight series of performances by artists based in Europe. Yesterday's program and tonight's have been devoted to European musiciansGunter Hampel and the highly regarded pianist Irene Schweitzer, respectivelybut Saturday's artist was Burton Greene. a pianist with strong ties to New York.

title: Kathy Schmidt Shatters World Javelin Mark
description: FUERTH, West Germany, Sept. 11 (AP)Kathy Schmidt of Los Angeles set a world record in the women's javelin throw today with a toss of 227 feet 5 inches. She broke the record of 2269 held by Ruth Fuchs of East Germany.

title: News Summary
description: A plan for the West Bank area, now held by Israel, is scheduled for presentation: by Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan in Washington next week. It would give Palestinian Arabs a large measure of internal autonomy while Israeli forces would maintain strategic installations. It assumes that since no territorial IsraeliArab agreement is in sight, a practical arrangement for both sides to live together should be tried. [Page 1, Column. 6.]

title: Carter Aide Calls On Lance to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Margaret Costanza, assistant to the President for public liaison, has become the first member of the White House staff to urge publicly that Bert Lance resign as director of the Office of Management and Budget. Miss Costanza said in a television interview in Rochester that the controversy surrounding Mr. Lance's financial affairs had preoccupied both him and President Carter, adding, Bert Lance should relieve the President of this burden.

title: LAY TEACHERS SET STRIKE AT L.I. CATHOLIC SCHOOLS
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 11 (AP)Lay teachers at the four Long Island high schools run by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Center have voted to go on strike tomorrow.

title: SHRINES TO MARCOS OPENED ON BIRTHDAY
description: EATAC Philippine, Sept. 11President Ferdinand E. Marcos today wound up a threeday state tour of the places of his birth and childhood made in celebration of his 60th birthday. His wife, Imelda Romualdez Marcos, honored him on the occasion by converting into shrines and museums the houses that were important in his early years.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An explosion and threealarm fire demolished a pizza parlour in the Shopshead Bay section of Broklyn early this morning and injured two police officers who were taken to Coney Island Hospital. The injuries of the officersSteven Brew and Joseph Cuneenappeared to be minor, according to a hospital spokesman.

title: Concert by Chileans Picketed
description: Some 200 pickets demonstrated against the Pinochet Government outside Town Hall on 43d Street yesterday afternoon as several hundred people listened to a concert by Chilean singers and musicians inside.

title: City U. Is Reopening With Tuition, Problems and a Drop in Enrollment
description: The City University is reopening for the new academic year with both the 'huge university and its tens of thousands of students again facing serious problems stemming from New York City's fiscal troubles.

title: Britons Wedding Eimits Pomp But Has Lots of Circumstance
description: ECCLESTON, England, Sept. 11The bride was five minutes late and the people waiting outside the village church began glancing at their watches, not really nervously but with interest.

title: Knopf, at 85, Looks Back on a Life Crammed With Books and History
description: Alfred A. Knopf is 85 years old today. Like a mythic god on Mount Etna in The Aeneid, the distinguished publisher unloosed a thunderbolt to stir up men and cities for the occasion: The state of the Western world is so bad that think we are living through the beginning of the end of a great civilization. You can sum up the reason in a fiveletter word. Greed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The humanitarian concern for Vietnam's hungry children, eloquently expressed in an OpEd article and letter by Marion Wright Edelman and Arthur W. Galston (Aug. 14 and 25, respectively), is shared by many who are also deeply concerned about other nearstarving Vietnamese: those in Hanoi's fearsome reeducation camps and prisons.

title: Carter Aide Calls On Lance to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Margaret Costanza, assistant to the President for public liaison, has become the first member of the White House staff to urge publicly that Bert Lance resign as director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Dr. Anthony Cabot Weds Betsy Steiner
description: Betsy C. Steiner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Steiner of New York and Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday in Bedford Hills, N.Y., to Dr. Anthony Cabot, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Cabot of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Paul Steinberg. dean of Hebrew Union College, performed the ceremony at the Lakeover Golf and Country Club.

title: Eugene Shuftan, 91, Cameraman And a Pioneer in Optical Effects
description: Eugene Shuftan, a pioneering cinematographer who won the Academy Award in 1961 as cameraman for Robert Rossen's The Hustler, died last Tuesday in the DeWitt Nursing Home. He was 91 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times Sept. I that the Queens Democratic organization had initiated a legal challenge to Maurice H. Nadiari as the Republican candidate for District Attorney in last Thursday's primary. The challenge had been made by Patrick Beary, an enrolled member of the Republican party.

title: Dr. Steven Goldsmith Weds Cynthia Martin in Jersey
description: Cynthia Martin, daughter of Sonia Martin of New York and Nicholas Martin of Somerville, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Goldsmith, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Goldsmith of Somerville. Rabbi Abraham Feldbin performed the ceremony at the Goldsmiths home.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 (Cunard). Left Southampton Sept. 8; due 3 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: The Standings
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Storer Boardman Lunt; Former Board Chairman Of W.W. Norton Concern
description: Storer Boardman Lunt, past president and chairman of the board of W. W. Norton & Company, the book publishers, died Saturday at a hospital in Fall River, Mass., after a long illness. He was 80 years old and maintained homes in Little Compton, R.I., and in New York City.

title: Seoul Risking Image in U.S.
description: TOKYO, Sept. 11When South Korea's Foreign Minister returned to Seoul from a visit here last Wednesday evening, he stressed to two reporters for foreign news organizations the importance of cooperating with the United States in its investigation or Park Tong Sun, the South. Korean who has been in dicted in Washington for bribery and making illegal campaign contributions.

title: Red Sox Rout Tigers, Trail Yanks by 11/2 and Ride 6Game String to Stadium
description: The Boston Red Sox, whose play has varied from brilliant to dismal all season, seem to be ready for their confrontation with the Yankees starting tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium. After 62 victory over the Detroit Tigers in Boston yesterday, the Red Sox head into the threegame series with a sixgame winning streak that has lifted them to within 11/2 games of New York.

title: Archives Unit Of U.S. Sought for Apartments
description: When construction was finished on the United States Federal Building in 1899, the structure, a powerful mass of red brick in the Romanesque Revival style, loomed large over its Greenwich Village neighbours. The building was intended for use by customs agents, and it was deliberately set close to the piers; on the full block bounded by Washington, Greenwich, Christopher and Barrow Streets. Other large buildings followed, but none so massive.

title: Magnet Schools In Boston Termed Aid to Integration
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11As Boston schools opened peacefully this year for the first time since Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. ordered the city to desegregate in 1974, parents and educators got the opportunity to notice something else that finally seemed to be working properly: the experimental magnet school program, established by the court in 1975 as an alternative to the busing program.

title: Associated Press
description: BONN, Sept. 11Rain clouds have been hanging over the capital of West Germany for several days now, deepening the gloom that has enveloped it ever since urban guerrillas armed with submachine guns kidnapped the country's top industrial spokesman, HannsMartin Schleyer.

title: Women in Majority This Year At Columbia Journalism School
description: The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, for the first time in its 65 years, enrolled more women than men last week, the school announced.

title: PARKING LOT LEASES CRITICIZED BY GOLDIN
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that New York City was allowing parkinglot operators to reap enormous profits by leasing cityowned land at prices well below market value.

title: Goodman Says Managerial Skills Make Him Best Choice for Mayor
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Republican candidate for Mayor, asserted. yesterday that he was the best candidate because he has more experience as a manager and because only he had been candid in telling the public that four more years of sacrifices would be necesBaty to keep the city out of bankruptcy.

title: SUITS DISCLOSE FIGHT FOR ACCESS TO HUGHES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11  Seven months before Howard R. Hughes died, Chester C. Davis, his lawyer, lost a power struggle with F. W. pay, then the chief executive of Mr. Hughes's Summa Corporation.

title: Dancing Femme Scores In Del Mar Feature
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 11 (AP)Dancing Femme led all the way in scoring her fifth straight victory today, a 1length triumph in the $59,650 Ramona Handicap at Del Mar race track. The victory was also the fourth of the day for Dancing Femme's jockey, Darrel McHargue.

title: Roots Gets Emmy As a Show
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (AP) Roots, the most watched show in television history, proved the most honored series in the fourmonths late 29th annual Television Academy Awards last night, scoring nine Emmys.

title: O'Dwyer Is Counting on Blacks, Puerto Ricans and Jews in Runoff
description: I City Council President Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday that to beat State Senator Carol Bellamy in the runoff, he was counting on getting the ethnically motivated votes won by three candidates eliminated in the primary.

title: Auto Racing
description: AT MONZA. ITALY ITALIAN GRAND PRIX

title: Striking Detroit Nurses Back at Jobs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP)The situation at Detroit General Hospital returned to normal today after a 45hour strike by more than 200 registered nurses. The hospital's interim director, William Himmelsbach, said that 25 of the 30 nurses scheduled for the morning shift today reported to work under a Wayne County Circuit Court restraining order issued late last night. The nurses began their strike the previous night, and the cityowned hospital began transferring patients to other facilities. The strike also forced Detroit General's emergency roomone of the busiest in the nationto close. Contract negotiations between the city and the registered nurses also resumed today.

title: Commodities
description: That wisp of early fall air that was filtered into steamy New York and its environs in recent days did not escape the attention of watchful coffee traders. They have been on the lookout for some months now for signs of what has heretofore been a traditional seasonal Pickup.

title: Orthodox Tudaisin's Rise Affects Conservative and Reform Branches
description: The relationships among America's three major branches of JudaismOrthodox, Conservative and Reformare being profoundly transformed, largely because of the rising power of Orthodoxy.

title: United Press International
description: REMOVING BARRIER: Demonstrators at Ohio's Kent State University tearing down a fence surrounding the site of a proposed gymnasium near the place where four students were killed by National Guardsmen during disturbance in 1970. The protesters occupied the site for a while then marched to a rally at the Student Center.

title: GEORGE RIEDI.
description: George Riedl, president since 1970 of Riedl Associates, an advertising concern in Clifton, N.J., was pronounced dead in Englewood Hospital on Saturday after suffering a heart attack at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 56 years old.

title: Byrne Is Endorsed By Teachers Group
description: TRENTON Sept. 11 (AP)Governor Byrne has won the endorsement of the 109,000member New Jersey Education Association in his reelection bid because he delivered on promises made to educators in 1973, Frank Totten, president of the organization, announced today.

title: Bourke's 72 Leads Finalists in Golf
description: Paul Bourke of Ridgewood, Queens, shot a 72 at Van Cortland Park yester day to lead eight players into the final round of the New York City Public Links golf tournament. The final round will be held on Saturday at La Tourette Golf Club on Staten Island.

title: Were There Two Democratic Parties in Primary Voting?
description: Meade H. Esposito, the colourful Brooklyn Democratic leader, was explaining why Mayor Beame just barely won his home Borough of Brooklyna showing that sealed his defeat in the Democratic mayoral primary last Thursday.

title: TV: Daniel Boone Reincarnated
description: Daniel Bone, whose fictional reincarnation once turned Fess Parker into a pop star, returns to television tonight as Young Dan'l Bone, a reformed creature of the family viewing hour. At 8 on CBS, Dan'l, as everyone carefully calls him in pure western hokum style, sets off to explore the Cumberland Gap in Kentucky (pronounced canetukky). Dodging the French, their Indian allies and a dastardly British intelligence agent, he survives his first adventure with long blond hair and customtailored frontier suit barely touched.

title: Death Penalty Is Assailed
description: In his harshest denunciation to date of his Democratic opponent's advocacy of the death penalty, Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that Representative Edward I. Koch was a politician who had read the polls and seen a fear and was telling the people of New York, I will give you the electric chair, I will give you death.

title: OverCounter Supplementary Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The rang., shown reflec4s prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: U.S. Team Takes Soccer Tournament, 21
description: The United States national soccer team captured a tournament for the first time when it defeated Alianza of Peru, 21, yesterday at Downing Stadium on Rtundalls Island.

title: Protecting the Wetlands
description: The country's largest public works project is the Federal program for municipal sewage treatment plants. And one of the country's most urgent environmental goals to clean up our waters. The two issues come together one vital piece of legislation, to renew the 1972 Water Pollution Control Act, now stalled in a conference committee of the Senate and the House. We cast our vote unhesitatingly for the Senate version; it would far better protect the nation's wetlands.

title: LOUIS KURKE
description: Louis Kurke, a retired certified public accountant who for the last 15 years simultaneously served two Long Island villages as Clerk and two towns as Auditor, died Friday of a heart attack at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. He was 75 years old and lived at 45 Shelley Lane. Great Neck.

title: Williams Says Jersey U. S. Attorney Will Quit, With Del Tufo to Get Job
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey said last night that Jonathan L. Goldstein had reportedly agreed to resign as the United States Attorney for New Jersey and that President Carter would nominate Robert J. Del Tufo, the director of the state's Division of Criminal Justice, to succeed him.

title: Mets Triumph, 73, Foiling Reuschel's Bid for 20th
description: CHICAGO. Sept. 11It took a player who was one step away from the hospital to get the Mets offense rolline today.

title: SMALL TOWNS SUING FOR MONEY FOR JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Clusters of small towns and a few metropolitan communities have brought a total of 16 lawsuits against the Economic Development Administration, alleging that they have been unlawfully discriminated against in the implementation of the $4 billion public works lobs program.

title: Sundry Events Fill Time in Newport Two Days Before America's Cup Final. Begins
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 On the America's Cup scene today: The yacht Independence defeated France II; two dozen rather than 100 boat owners appeared at a meeting to explain the rules for spectators at the forthcoming races; an unofficial line was set for Courageous and Australia, and the crews of the two contending yachts received their wristwatches.

title: Berger Predicts Tough Problems Await Next Mayor of New York
description: Stephen Berger, executive director of the Emergency Financial Control Board, warned yesterday that the problems confronting New York City and a new Mayor next year would be enormous and in many ways as difficult as 1975, the height of the fiscal crisis.

title: Waldheirn Back in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept 11 (Reuters)Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations, who is on a visit to the Soviet Union, arrived back in Moscow today from a twoday visit to Mongolia. Mr. Waldheim is expected to meet Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, tomorrow before leaving.

title: Endorsement Expected Today
description: Representative Herman Badillo, who was among the five candidates defeated in last week's primary for the Democratic mayoral nomination, will endorse Representative Edward I. Koch in next Monday's runoff, according to aides to Mr. Koch.

title: Golf
description: AT ENDICOTT, N.Y.

title: DAYAN SAID TO OFFER ARABS OF WEST BANK INTERNAL AUTONOMY
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 11Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan is expected to present a proposal to President Carter regarding the Israelioccupied West Bank in which the Palestinian Arabs would be given substantial internal autonomy and selfgovernment while the Israelis would maintain strategic military installations for security purposes.

title: genry F. Fischbach, Dead at 85; Headed Leading Electrical Concern
description: Henry F. Fischbach, chairman of the board of Fischbach and Moore, one of the nation's largest electrical contractors, died Saturday at his home in Mayfair House at Park Avenue and 65th Street in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The policies that [have] produced the rise in minority group medical school enrolments in the last eight years still leave whites with 91 percent of the medical school places. But this is no consolation to [Allan] Bakke, who did not get in, while the school he sued took in six blacks, eight Chicanos and two AsianAmericans with scores and undergraduate grades lower than his.

title: DEMOCRATS PROPOSE TO SPEED PRIMARIES
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11The Democratic Partz's latest rulemaking commission moved today to shorten the season tor Presidential primary elections, but was divided over trying to end the prominence of New Hampshire as the state that holds he first primary.

title: Hebrew College to Build Center At N.Y.U. and Share Facilities
description: ; In 4, vote of confidence in New York City, the Western Hemispheres oldest and largest institution of Jewish higher education  Hebrew Union CollegeJewish !Institute of Religionis about to build la $7 million new home on the New York University campus at Washington Square.

title: Study Urges a U.S. Family Policy
description: Culminating a fiveyear study of how public programs affect the family, the Carnegie Council on Children will formally propose today a sweeping national family policy to guarantee a job for every family's breadwinner and to assure that no child need be raised in poverty.

title: The New York Times/Marilynn K. BACK TO BUSINESS: Mayor Beame studying notes at Third Avenue fair as crowd waited for him to speak. It was first day out since primary loss. Page
description: Mayor Beame yesterday made a round of public appearances in Manhattan and Staten Island that proved he still had the affection of many New York's citizens even though he did not get most of their votes.

title: Begin Decides to Bar Extradition Of Israeli Citizen to Switzerland
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 11 (AP)Prime Minister Menahem Begin has decided to block the extradition of an Israeli citizen to Switzerland, where he is accused of embezzlement, a Begin aide said today.

title: Daniel Nagrin To Be Honored.
description: Daniel Nagrin, the dancer and chorecgrapher whose career has ranged over three decades, will be honoured for his contributions to theatre and modern dance in a Daniel Nagrin Gala on Thursday at 8 P.M. at the Marvmount Manhattan Theater, 223 East 71st Street.

title: Mexico's Surround Concert Hall Passes Acoustics Test
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11 Mexico's new Nezahualcoyotl Hall, the first surround concert hall in the Western Hemisphere, has passed its biggest acoustical test so fara memorable performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony by the Cleveland Orchestra, wh:ch is on tour here.

title: The Tutankhamen Spirit Runs Riot In New Jewelry Everywhere
description: With enthusiasm for the treasures of Tutankhamen sweeping the country, one can hardly go wrong with ornaments patterned after the furnishings found in the young king's tomb and, by extension, with anything that harks back to ancient Egypt.

title: Race Is a Central Issue in Detroit Mayoral Primary
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11  Voters here are trying to decide whether to retain an assertive and often controversial black man who has been a relatively successful mayor, to vote for a more quiet and politically conservative black or to put white man back in the mayor's office.

title: Auto Makers Assailed By Nader on Air Bags
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Ralph Nader charged today that auto makers were showing callous indifference to human life on the highway by opposing air bags or automatic seat belts cars.

title: red Gives No Clear Sign as It Lets Funds Rate Rise
description: The Federal Reserve imprciay confirmed yesterday that it wanted shortterm interest rates to rise in the wake of its report of a su stantial S3 billion increase in the nation's money supply. How high it wanted them to move, however, remained unclear.

title: 80 Northeastern Redcaps Losing Their Station in Life
description: Joseph I. Pleasant Jr., who became a redcap more than 40 years ago at Pennsylvania Station, recalled yesterday that people called redcaps ambassadors.

title: Harvard Chooses Athletic Director
description: Harvard finally named a director of athletics yesterday, ending a long and often confusing search for the man to succeed Robert B. Watson, who is retiring. The new director is John P.

title: Goldstein Quits as U.S. Attorney; Says Carter Yielded to Pressure
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12Jonathan L. Goldstein resigned today as United States Attorney for New Jersey, accusing the Carter Administration of driving him from office in a political capitulation to Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: Television
Shipping/Mails
People and Business
description: Calling inflation a universally regressive tax, Walter B. Wriston, chairman and chief executive of Citibank, said inflation's effect on society was, and always would be, disastrous.

title: U.S. Asserts Need For Palestinian Role At Geneva Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The State Department said today in a new policy statement on the Middle East that the Palestinians must be involved in the peacemaking process to insure a successful settlement.

title: Chicago Police Escort Students After Clash at AntiBusing Rally
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12After four persons were injured and 11 arrested in an antibusing rally here last night, the police reacted swiftly today at the first signs of trouble as Chicago began Its second week of a new voluntary school desegregation plan.

title: HotLine Callers Find Knicks Have the Answers
description: HotLine Callers Find Knicks Have the Answers

title: Chamber Music Gala
description: Judging from the many musical events scheduled for the 92d Street Y this season, the Theresa L. Kaufmann Concert Hall is going to be an extremely busy place in the coming months. A Chamber Music Gala led off the activities on Sunday night with performances by a new resident group of musicians who will be exploring the chamber music literature in an annual series of concerts under the artistic direction of the violinist Jaime Laredo.

title: TAX REVISIONS LIKELY TO LIMIT DEDUCTING MORTGAGE INTEREST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  President Carter's forthcoming tax revision proposals are likely to include a limit of about $10,000 on deductions for mortgage interest.

title: ATTORNEY IS ACQUITTED OF TAXEVASION CHARGES
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12A Federal Court jury has acquitted a tax attorney, Burton W. Kanter, of conspiracy to avoid taxes, on a Nevada hotel sale by rigging transactions through a Bahamas bank, but convicted Mr. Kanter's law partner, Roger S. Baskes, of the same offense.

title: China Reports Tests Of Nuclear Missiles
description: PEKING, Sept. 12 (Reuters)China has officially disclosed that it has tested guided missiles with nuclear warheads.

title: KochCuomo Debate Canceled in a Mixup
description: What Was expected to be the first televised debate of the mayoral runoff failed to occur last night when Mario M. Cuomo showed up at the WPIX studios 59 minutes late because of what he said was a mixup in scheduling.

title: Continuing Split In Ethnic Vote
description: Representative Herman Badillo's sudden endorsement of Representative Edward I. Koch's mayoral candidacy yesterday while many black officials moved toward Secretary of State. Mario M. Cuomo underlined the continuing divi

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: L. I. College Shedding Its Dilettante Image
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.When Southampton College opened 15 years ago, it had no dormitories. So the students were housed in nearby motels, resulting in what the college's current president calls a public relations disaster.

title: Southwestern Bell Ordered to Pay $3 Million in Suit by 2 ExOfficials
description: SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 12A State District Court jury ordered the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company today to pay a total of $3 million to a former executive of the company and the family of another executive who committed suicide. James Ashley, the former executive, had vowea that he would become the Ralph Nader of the telephone company when he was discharged three years ago.

title: Carter Orders Minority Buying
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)President Carter announced today that he has instructed Federal agencies to double their purchases from businesses owned by members of minority groups within two years. This increase should raise the level of Federal Government purchases from minority firms to about $1 billion, Mr. Carter said in a statement.

title: Advertising
description: The McCall Publishing Company, parent of McCall's, a 101yearold women's service magazine, will be bringing out a brandnew service magazine early next year. But this time the publication is aimed at a dual audience, a very special dual audience.

title: L. I. College Shedding Its Dilettante Image
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. LWhen Southampton College opened 15 years ago, it had no dormitories. So the students were housed in nearby motels, resulting in what the college's current president calls a public relations disaster.

title: Murdoch Granted Delay
description: BRAMPTON, Ontario, Sept. 12 (AP)Don Murdoch of the New York Rangers was granted a postponement to April 6 of his trial on charges of possession of cocaine, a Provincial Court judge ruled today.

title: Admitting the Soviet Unionists
description: The Administration's decision to allow four Soviet trade unionists to visit the United States today at the invitation of a Chicago labor reform organization is commendableand long overdue. It reverses a policy under which successive Administrations bowed to the leaders of the A.F.L.C.I.O. and refused visas to representatives of trade unions in Communist countries (and of Communistdominated unions in other countries). By granting such persons entry, contends George Meany, the United States government equates the labor organizations of the Soviet bloc with the free trade unions of the West.

title: Goodman Bracing to Take on Democratic Nominee, But Farber Insists He'll Be One to Do the Taking On
description: While State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Republican candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that he looked forward with confidence to confronting the winner of next Monday's Democratic runoff, Barry Farber insisted that he, not Mr. Goodman, would emerge as the second major candidate in the November election.

title: Text of The Times's Letter to C.I.A.
description: Carl Bernstein has written an article for Rolling Stone magazine to be published in early October, which reports that Arthur Hays Sulzberger, former publisher of The New York Times, en

title: Rowdies to Play Chinese
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 12 (AP)The Tampa Bay Rowdies will play the national team from China at Tampa Stadium on Oct. 13, a club spokesman said today.

title: Korean Singer in U.S. Debut
description: Hea Soon Park, a Korean s!nger now studying in Dtisseldorf, West Germany, made her American debut Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: 10 Hurt in Capital Subway Test
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Two trains being used for test runs, oyer an unopened segment of the Washington subway system collided last night, slightly injuring the 10 workers aboard. The accident did not affect service on the operating portion of the subway system.

title: LAY TEACHERS STRIKE L.I. CATHOLIC SCHOOLS
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 12Lay teachers at four high schools operated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre struck today in a contract dispute.

title: GOLDSTEIN RESIGNS AS A U.S. PROSECUTOR
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12Jonathan L. Goldstein resigned today as United States Attorney for New Jersey, accusing the Carter Administration of driving him from office in a political capitulation to Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: S.E.C. ADOPTS NEW RULES AFFECTING DISCLOSURES
description: ASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had adopted new rules for disclosure by commercial and industrial companies of investments in marketable securities.

title: Polish Leader Arrives in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Edward Gierek, the Polish leader, arrived here today on a threeday visit for talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing on EastWest dtente and disarmament.

title: Soviet Lets Turchin, A Dissident, Accept Position at Columbia
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12Valentin F. Turchin, a prominent dissident, said today that he had received permission to emigrate in response to a teaching invitation from Columbia University.

title: CHOLERA SPREADING IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 (UPI)Lebanon reported two suspected cholera deaths today, the first fatalities outside Syria from a disease that appears to be spreading across the Arab world.

description: New York City public schools will be closed today and tomorrow in observance of Rosh haShanah, as will some suburban schools. Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended both days,

title: Joseph Leon Gets Mostel Role As The Merchant
description: The producers and director of The Merchant, halted in its Philadelphia tryout by the death of its star, Zero Mostel, last Thursday, yesterday placed the drama by Arnold Wesker in rehearsal with Joseph Leon assuming the role of Shylock. Mr. Leon was Mr. Mostel's understudy.

description: John Fowles's fifth and latest novel, with its rather plain title, Daniel Martin, sounds exceedingly plain in plot summary. The title character, once a promising young English playwright of the generation that was fatally under

description: New York City public schools will be closed today and tomorrow in observance of Rosh haShanah, as will some suburban schools. Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be sus pended both days.

title: Banker Urges Resignation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12David Rockefeller, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said today that he felt Bert Lance should resign.

title: Queens Greek School Gets a Week To Pay $150,000 on U.S. Tax Bill.
description: St. Andrew's Academy in Queens, the only privately operated Greek Orthodox School in the kited States, yesterday was given, one week to pay the Federal Government $150,000 or be placed on the auction block.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Displaced Homemakers: Some Action in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Tell the committee that there are many displaced homemakers in Wisconsin. They are alive and miserable and they need helo.

title: Interest Rates Hurt Market Again; Dow, Off by 2.69, Is Near 77 Low
description: The specter of higher interest rates dealt another blow to stock prices yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing within a whisker of its 1977 low.

title: Interest Rates on Bills Increased In the Weekly Treasury Sale
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Detroit Teamsters End Strike
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP)Meter maids Ind garbage truck drivers returned to work today, officially ending a threeday strike. The workers, members of Teamsters Local 214, voted unanimously yesterday to accept, a contract offer that had received tentative acceptance by negotiators on Friday.

title: Miss Bellamy and O'Dwyer Gaining Variety of Endorsements in Runoff
description: Paul O'Dwyer and Carol Bellamy won a variety of endorsements yesterday, in the race against each other in the Democratic runoff for City Council President.

title: Woman Breaks Record
description: EUGENE, Ore. Sept. 12 (AP)Kim Merritt of Racine, Wis., set a United States women's marathon record yesterday in the NikeOregon Track Club marathon. She covered the 26mile, 385yaid course in 2 hours 37 minutes 19 seconds. Her time broke the record of 2:38.19 set by Jackie Hansen of San Fernando Valley, Calif., two years ago in Eugene. The women's world marathon mark is 2:35.15, set by Chantal Langlace of France earlier this year.

title: TWO MEN ARRESTED FOR ROBBING ELDERLY
description: Two young men suspected of numerous attacks on elderly people and charged with shooting a 71yearold man and pistolwhipping his 70yearold wife in an attempted robbery last Friday were ordered held in $100.000 bail each yesterday by a judge in Brooklyn Criminal Court.

title: About New York
description: A still life about Robert Volpe would beg the ridiculous. It would show a palette, smeared lately with blue acryllic, crossed by some of his $3,000 worth of paint brushes and his Police Special revolver resting in a studio that has all the Left Bank exotica of Ray Ridge, Brooklyn, where he grew up and still thrives.

title: Powell Says 3 Aides Knew of Lance Criticism but Did Not Tell Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today that although three of President Carter's closest aides had read Federal Bureau of Investigation criticisms of Bert Lance's management of the Calhoun First National Bank, in Calhoun, Ga., none of the aides had passed along the criticisms to President Carter.

title: Hussein Ends Visit to France
description: PARIS, Sept. 12 (Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan today held lastminute talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing on the Middle East before flying home after a week's visit to France. The King arrived here last Monday as part of an Arab campaign to enlist Western help in halting the spreading of Jewish settlements on the West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Humphrey Leads Labor Group
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, has accepted the chairmanship of a coalition lobbying Congress for changes in the National Labor Relations Act to strengthen workers rights to or ganize. Called Americans for Justice on the Job, the group was formed by leaders of groups representing women, minorities, labor, business, consumer and older citizens to insure the 42yearold law is as effective for wage earners who seek to organiz into unions as the law presently works for those employers who seeks to deny their employees that right.

title: U. of Houston Eleven Defeats U.C.L.A., 1713
Robin Laurance

title: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr. and Jack Manning
description: CANDIDATES ENDORSED: Herman Badillo talking to Edward I. Koch before announcing he would support him in the runoff campaign. Below, Mario M. Cuomo gets the endorsement of black community leaders; State Senator Vander Beatty stands next to him. More on candidates day on page 20.

title: GATT Warns Industrial Countries That Protectionism Stunts Growth
description: GENEVA, Sept. 12A staff report of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade warned the industrialized countries today that they were stunting their own economic growth as well as endangering world trade by erecting barriers to the entry of foreign products.

title: Cities Planning Subway Projects Face Cutback in Federal Funding
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  A budget conscious Carter Administration, wary of rapidly rising costs, has ordered a goslow policy in the construction of urban rail mass transit projects at a time when many cities are beginning their first ventures in subway construction.

title: EARNINGS OF BACHE GROUP FELL 53% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Bache Group Inc., parent of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., a leading securities firm, reported yesterday declines of 53 percent in its earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter and 60 percent for the fiscal year ended July 31.

title: CARTER CALLED FIRM AGAINST RACE QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Despite severe pressure from civil rights activists, the Carter Administration plans to stand by its position that racial quotas are unconstitutional, according to a Justice Department lawyer.

title: Drucker Gets Post
description: Norm Drucker has been appointed supervisor of officials in the N.B.A. He succeeds John Nucatola, who resinned this summer.

title: Sold the Russians Secrets on U.S. Satellites That MonitOred the Soviet Union and China
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12Christopher John Boyce, a 24yearold Californian who contended that he had been blackmailed into becoming a spy for the Soviet Union by a childhood friend, was sentenced to 40 years in prison today.

title: Bateman, Byrne Differ on Marijuana Law
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 12Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman took opposing views today on the decriminalization of marijuana in New Jersey, with the Governor, a Democrat, saying he would sign such a measure

title: Grain and Soybeans Show Price Increase In Futures Trading
description: The grain and soybean futures markets closed higher yesterday despite a crop survey by Conrad Leslie, the leading private forecaster, last Friday that indicated near record harvests of basic foodstuffs.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
Retail Sales in August Rose 1.7% Spurred by NewCar Buying Gain
description: The nation's retail sales, spurred by a surge in car buying, rose 1.7 percent in August over the July level, registering the second straight month of gain following three months of decline.

title: Records on SaccoVanzetti Reveal 1927 Wiretap at Frankfurter's Home
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12John S. Kehoe, the Massachusetts Commissioner of Public Safety, made public today the 56yearold records of the state police investigation of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, including 260 pages of transcribed tele phone conversations obtained through 1927 wiretap on the home phone of Felix Frankfurter.

title: FUELEFFICIENT CARS GET SENATE BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Senate today rallied behind a proposal to outlaw the production of fuelinefficient automobiles after 1979, rejecting an effort to strike the ban from an energy conservation bill.

title: New Trial Called in Kent State Suit That Seeks Damages in
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed a lower court ruling today that had cleared Gov. James A. Rhodes, state officials and National Guardsmen of damages stemming from the May 4, 1970, shootings at Kent State University in which four students were killed.

title: Rumania Getting Two I.M.F. Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)  The International Monetary Fund announced today two loans totaling $128.3 million to Rumania to help ease the damage to the economy from the severe earthquake in March.

title: News Organizations Say They Find No Evidence Their Employees Maintained C.I.A. Relationships
description: Executives of a number of news organizations said yesterday they had been unable to find evidence that their employees had maintained confidential relationships with the Central Intelligence Agency over the last 25 years, as a forthcoming article in Rolling Stone magazine alleges.

title: The Best of Frenemies
description: Reading in faroff California about the Friends List, I visualize that it must have created a new parlor game, being played nightly in sittingrooms all over England: The Capsule Characterization of Friends.

description: PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 12Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman took opposing views today on the decriminalization of marijuana, with the Governor, a Democrat, saying he

title: Conferees on Medicaid Abortions Deadlocked After a Futile Session
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12A House and Senate conference committee held short, peppery but futile session on Medicaid abortions today, remaining as deadlocked as when the conferees were appointed last June.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WYOMING, Mich., Sept. 12 (AP)The General Motors Corporation said today it would spend $60 million to expand its Fisher Body No. 1 plant in this Grand Rapids suburb.

title: The Rebirth of Newport Brings Influx of Tourists And Growing Pains
description: NEWPORT, R.T.  The carpenters, painters, roofers, plumbers and electricians who are rebuilding almost every block of this city may put down their tools for a few moments today to mark the beginning here of the 23d defense of the America's Cup.

title: ELECTRICAL UNION OFFICERS ASSAIL CARTER ON JOBS
description: Officers of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America accused President Carter and his Administration yesterday of not taking effective action to combat unemployment.

title: Around the Nation
description: PIKEVILLE, Ky., Sept. 12 (AP)A Federal judge dismissed today a $60 million damage suit against the Blue Diamond Coal Company by the widows of 15 miners who died in an explosion 18 months ago.

title: P.S.C. Official Backs Plea to Raise CoinBox Phone Call to 20 Cents
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday won a state hearing officer's recommendation that the 26yearold 10cent coinbox telephone call be raised to 20 cents throughout the state as part of a proposed overall rate increase of $245.2 million a year.

title: Carter Tettimony Ruled Unneeded In Trial Involving Phone Call to Him
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP)A judge ruled today that President Carter's testimony was not necessary in the kidnapping and extortion trial of a man who ended a siege at a suburban city hall last March after Mr. Carter agreed to speak to him by telephone.

title: It Won't Hold Water
description: It is astonishing what politicians can find to quarrel about. The Panama Canal, for heaven's sake. With civilization wearing out all over the country, with dogs amok in the streets of New York, with body snatchers menacing the Elvis Presley mausoleum, the best Washington can find to worry about is the Panama Canal.

title: Bertolucci's 1900
description: 1900, the controversial Italianmade, Englishlanguage drama directed by Bernardo Bertolucci that was completed early last year, will have its longdelayed American premiere at the New York Film Festival on Oct. 8, with showings at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall at 2 and 7:30. There will be a 10minute intermission at each of the screenings of the 245minute feature. According to Richard Roud, director of the festival, Mr. Bertolucci is expected to come from Italy for the premiere.

title: Fans Flock To N.J. for Flat Racing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 12 There's a new game in town and, as had been expected, it has had the appeal of a smash show on Broadway.

title: Mets Defeat Expos, 43, Despite Perez's Hot Bat
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 12Lenny Randle led the New York Mets to a 43 triumph over Tony Perez and the Montreal Expos tonight and kept his teammate, Steve Henderson, on Andre Dawson's heels in the race for National League rookieoftheyear honors.

description: Arthur E. Blyn, who was upset last week in the Democratic primary for Manhattan surrogate, will seek a position on the bench of State Supreme Court.
