description: A LowTar Smoke By Benson & Hedges

title: Open Loss Has Connors Seething and Facing Fine
description: Jimmy Connors has refused to accept his fourset loss to Guillermo Vilas in the men's singles final at the United States. Open tennis championships.

title: Hero's Return for Brock
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP)  Thousands of St. Louisans welcomed Lou Brock home today at a parade through downtown St. Louis. The celebrating came two weeks to the day after Brock became baseball's basestealing champion on Aug. 29 in San Diego.

title: Market Place
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission report issued two weeks ago, which charged local politicians and banks with having misled investors in issuing dubious notes in 1974 and 1975, obscures a silver lining.

title: Havurah Offers Jews Religion in Commune Setting
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 12Two years ago they were five sets of strangers, passing each other in supermarkets or commuter trains. A few went to synagogue; the rest felt a long detachment from organized Judaism.

title: German Kidnapping: New Deadline
description: BONN, Sept. 12Terrorists who kidnapped a West German industrial leader a week ago reportedly set a new deadline today for the Government to meet their demand for the release of 11 imprisoned urban guerrillas.

title: Norwegian Voters Put Ruling Party Close to Majority
description: OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Sept. 13 (AP) Norway's ruling Labor Party scored major gains in Parliamentary elections Sunday and yesterday, apparently winning close to a majority in the 155member Parliament.

title: ADDIS ABABA MARKS OUSTER OF SELASSIE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 12Some 200,000 Ethiopians today demonstrated their resistance to Somali agression in a parade marking the third anniversary of the overthrow of the late Emperor Haile Selassie.

title: Giants Go With Youth and Cut Ramsey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 12In what he called a bold move, Coach John McVay of the Giants placed Steve Ramsey on waivers today and will open the season Sunday with three quarterbacks who have played a total of zero National Football League games.

title: P.S.C. Official Backs Plea to Raise CoinBox Phone Call to 20 Cents
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday won a state hearing officer's recommendation that the 26yearold 10cent coinbox telephone call be raised to 20 cents throughout the state as part of a proposed overall rate increase of $245.2 million a year.

title: Letter: On Wheat Acreage Reduction
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama filed yesterday for a divorce from his wife of six years, Cornelia Wallace. Attempts at reconciliation are impractical or futile and not in the best interests of the parties, said the divorce naners filed in Montgomery. There exists such a complete incompatibility of temperaments the parties can no longer live together as man and wife. The Wallace's marriage had been troubled since the disclosure a year ago that Mrs. Wallace had tapped her husband's bedroom telephone. Last week Mrs. Wallace moved out of the Govnor's Mansion, saying sne could no longer endure the vulgarity, threats and abuse.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IN THE KNOW Ninety artists, all former or current members of the faculty of Brooklyn College, are represented in the exhibition of painting, sculpture, photographs, drawings and prints going on view concurrently today through Oct. 8 at two Madison Avenue galleries. The works span the development of the school's art department from 1942 to today, with students now offered diversified courses in studio art and art history, including photography, by 45 faculty instructors. The staff has had many members who were significant artists in their own right.

title: Times Reporter Named in Article Resigns From Washington Bureau
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Laura. Foreman, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, submitted her resignation today.

title: Bearne Is at White House As Part of a Delegation Of Mayors
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Mayor Beame, a lameduck mayor, was in the White House this afternoon as part of a delegation of the United States Conference of Mayors to urge the administration to approve a 14point urban program in cluding an immediate increase in Federal financing for welfare programs.

title: U.N. Parleys: Their Value?; Conference on Deserts Raises Question Anew
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 12 With the cloSe of the twoweek desertification conference here last week, a meeting that produced a lofty plan of action intended to mobilize the world in a grand battle against the creation and spread of

title: Boy Shoots and Kills His Brother While Reenacting a TV Gunfight
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept 12 (Reuters)A 14yearold boy shot and killed his younger brother here while reenacting a scene from a film the two had seen on television, the police said.

title: Washington: Behind Closed Doors On ABC Withstood Rivals
description: Washington: Behind Closed Doors, the 121/2hour serial that dominated ABCTV's primetime schedule for six nights last week, was not the smash hit the network may have hoped, but neither was it a ratings disappointment over all, the $8 million production withstood an assault by a barrage of specials, movies and special events unleashed by the rival networks.

title: State Seeks to Subpoena Records: Of Closed Mental Health Facili0
description: PARAMUS, Sept. 12The State Department of Human Services said today it was studying an order to seek a subpoena for the financial records of a private mental health center here that officials said had run up about $300,000 in

title: Goodyear Introduces New AllSeason Tire
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has introduced an allseason automobile tire that it says eliminates the need for motorists to buy separate snow tires.

title: Trade Negotiators Urge Japan to Spur World's Economy
description: TOKYO, Sept. 12 (UPD)The United States today urged Japan to help share the burden of spurring the sluggish world economy.

title: Dollar Gains in Europe But Is Mixed in Trading Against Yen
description: The dollar inched higher against most major European currencies in foreign exchange trading yesterday but finished mixed against the Japanese yen.

title: WaldheimMoreOptimistic Over U.S.Soviet Relations After Talk With Brezhnev
description: PARIS, Sept. 12Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said tonight after a twohour meeting in Moscow with Leonid I. Brezhnev that the crisis in U.S.Soviet relations is temporary'. and that he was more optimistic about the problem than he was a few wens ago.

title: 2 Scientists Oppose State Rules for DNA Research
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12Two Princeton University scientists, Professors Robert M. May and Arnold J. Levine, told the New Jersey Public Health Council today that they thought the new scientific tool, recombinant DNA research, did not require any state regulation.

title: Somali Rebel Leader, in Interview, Defines Territorial Claims in Ethiopian Fighting
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 12The !eider of Somali insurgents fighting in Ethiopia said yesterday that the war is passing through a critical stage, with heavy battles continuing to rage around the majo cities of Diredawa and Harar.

title: Israel Marks Holiday With an Extra Alert
description: TEL AVIV, Fept. 12 (AP)Israelis tonight began the observance of Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year, with prayers and picnics while the police were en steppedup alert against terrorist attacks.

title: Feldman Gets State Post
description: ALBANY, Sept, 12 (UPI)Maurice M. Feldman, former Commissioner of New York City's Department of Water Resources, has been named to the Interstate Sanitation Commission, Governor Carey has anounced. Mr. Feldman, 62 years old, is an engineer and serves as director of environmental programs for the Leonard S. Weaman Company.

title: SWISS TEAM SAYS ISRAEL USED TORTURE ON ARABS
description: GENEVA, Sept. 12The Swiss League for Human Rights accused Israel today of having commonly and systematically employed torture on Arab inhabitants of the occupied West Bank of the Jordan.

title: Out on a Limb
description: If opposition to the new Panama Canal treaties is really going to become an organized effort of the American right, then conservatives are taking themselves far out on a limb all too likely to be sawed off behind them. Hanging on to the Canal may be a splendid whoopitup political issue now and in next year's elections, but what if conservatives actually defeat the treaties?

title: A Fusion Solution
description: AUSTIN, Tex.Since their meeting last November, the Northeastern governors have been pressing forward the concept of a Northeast Regional Energy and Development Corporation. It may be useful to put that concept into a national perspective.

title: CORE Pledges $50,000 So Students. Can Move Into New Bronx School
description: For 175 young students who have settled into a new school in the South Bronx, it doesn't matter that the smell of paint lingers in their classrooms or that the upstairs renovations are incomplete. At least we have a school, 9yearold Lorna Fernandez said the other day.

title: Opera: Beverly Sills and Molese Lack the Innocence for Manon
description: Tito Capobianco's production of Massenet's Manon remains one of the most lovely offerings of the New York City Opera in recent years. It was revived Sunday night at the New York State Theater with the same two principals and conductor of nine years ago, and one has to report that time has taken its toll.

title: RECORD CROPS SEEN IN CORN, SOYBEANS; WHEAT IMPROVES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Above average August rainfall over the Great Plains and Corn Belt states should raise the 1977 corn and soybean crops to records and aid farmers in producing their third bumber wheat corp in a row, the Crop Reporting Board predicted today.

title: Growing Concern in Washington Over Trouble in Metals Sector
description: Thomas E. Mullaney

title: A Givenchy Retrospective, and Even He's Amazed
description: Hubert de Givenchy can scarcely believe that he has been a wellknown fashion name for 25 years. And when he thinks of the thousands, and more thousands, of designs he has sketched and created in that period, his blue eyes look somewhat amazed.

title: In Cairo, Houses Fall and Services Fail, but People Stay
description: CAIRO, Sept. 12A house collapsed suddenly in the heart of Old Cairo the other day, killing 43 inhabitants.

title: Don't Breed a Technological Turkey
description: Those reports of the death of the Clinch River Breeder Reactor last July were unfortunately premature. Although President Carter appeared to have killed the illconceived project as part of a compromise with Congress on controversial public works projects, all he actually did was to get the demonstration breeder deleted from a particular appropriations bill. Now, the battle is about to break out again as the House Representatives takes up an energy authorization bill. A vote against funds for Clinch River could help slow nuclear weapons. It would also buy time to permit development of a more rational energy policy.

title: Westinghouse Trial for Default on Uranium Delayed
description: RICHMOND. Sept. 12 (UPI)The start of Westinghouse's trial for allegedly defaulting on uranium supply contracts with 10 electric utilities was postponed today for a day by a deluge of pretrial motions.

title: Last Weeks
CARTER WOULD LIMIT RELIEF FOR INTEREST PAID ON MORTGAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12President Carter's forthcoming tax revision proposals are likely to include a limit of about $10,000 on deductions for mortgage interest.

title: TV: Pryor's Art Is Strong Stuff Soap
description: Encrusted with the grime of rampant and eventually tedious prepublicity, Soap arrives on ABCTV tonight at 9:30 with seemingly half the country grimly determined to pounce on its every sexual nuance as solid proof that the nation is coining apart at its morality seams.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
U.S. Asserts Need For Palestinian Role At Geneva Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The State Department said today in a new policy statement on the Middle East that the Palestinians must be involved in the peacemaking process to insure a successful settlement.

title: Mayor's Friends Assert He Might Stay Neutral
description: Representative Edward I. Koch tried yesterday to line up the support of Mayor Beame in the Democratic mayoral runoff And some Beame friends said the Mayor would either endorse Mr. Koch or stay neutral.

title: Ground Coffee Wholesale Prices Are Cut by 20c by General Foods
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 12 (UPI)The General Foods Corporaton, the natoin's largest coffee roaster, today followed other major coffee companies in reducing its wholesale prices on ground coffee.

title: Taiwan Gets Increasingly Nervous Over Possible U.S. Ties to China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 9Every pack of cigarettes here now bears an admoni tion, not about the dangers of smoking, but a much more immediate problem to this island's 16 million people. Maintain selfrespect and selfreliance, it says. Stay calm in the face of adversity.

title: FORMER COMPTROLLER CONCEDES HE MISLED COMMITTEE ON LANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Robert Bloom, the former Acting Comptroller of the Currency who wrote a letter to the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee commending Bert Lance before he was confirmed as budget director, aclulowl

title: Abraham L. Kaminstein, Registered Copyrights in Library of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Abraham L. Kaminstein, who served as register of copyrights in the Library of Congress from 1960 until his retirement in 1971, died Saturday after a short illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Episcopal Priest Ousted in Ohio After Defiance on Women's Issue
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 12 (AP)The priest who has been trying to lead St. Paul's Episcopal Church out of the national; church over the issue of women priests was dismissed tonight by the church's leaders.

title: Tax Reform: The Sacred Tree
description: Since the name of our system is capitalism, it is not surprising that capital has a certain sanctity, and that dipping into it is a Victorian sin. In taxation, too, capital has its privileges. We tax the fruit of the tree, but not the tree, according to a traditional interpretation of the law that distinguishes between income and capital. Consistently, the United States has taxed the tree capital less than its fruit.

title: A's Reach Kansas City by Plane, Bus and Car
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 12 (AP)The A's had a hard time today getting back to the town that was theirs until 1968.

title: Nigerian Leader to Visit the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Lieut. Geri. Olusegun Obasanjo, Nigeria's head of State, will make a visit to Washington staking Oct. 11, the White House announced today. The first Nigerian leader to make such a visit, General Obasanjo will also visit New York after meeting with President Carter.

title: FUELEFFICIENT CARS GET SENATE BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Senate today rallied behind a proposal to outlaw the production of fuelinefficient automobiles aster 1979. rejecting an effort to strike the ban from an energy conservation bill.

title: Bees for Pay Or Pleasure
description: No one seems to know exactly how many beekeepers there are in the United States today, but a few educated guesses place the number at 200.000 to 300,000. At any rate, one supply house executive said, the number of beekeepers has been growing in the last four or five years as a result of the interest in natural foods.

title: PORT AUTHORITY AIDE HIRED 10 RELATIVES
description: They Worked as Crew Members on Harbor Sightseeing Cruises for Agency's Influential Guests

title: The Rebirth of Newport Brings Influx ofTourists And Growing Pains
description: NEWPORT, R.T.  The carpenters, painters, roofers, plumbers and electricians who are rebuilding almost every block of this city may put down their tools for a few moments today to mark the beginning here of the 23d defense of the America's Cup.

title: FORMER COMPTROLLER CONCEDES HE MISLED COMMITTEE ON LANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Robert Bloom, the former Acting Comptroller of the Currency who wrote a letter to the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee commending Bert Lance before he was confirmed as budget director, acknowledged today under intensive questioning that the committee had been misled hy, his letter.

title: Cities Planning Subway Projects Face Cutback in Federal Funding
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  A budget conscious Carter Administration, wary of rapidly rising costs, has ordered a goslow policy in the construction of urban rail mass transit projects at a time when many cities are beginning their first ventures in subway construction.

title: Winston Would Rather Switch Off Its Sign
description: The face beaming down from a billboard advertising cigarettes, has blown its lest smoke ring over the Times Square area.

title: U.S. Indicts 11 in 3 States in Fraud Involving Medicare and Medicaid
description: Eleven men were indicted yesterday In several separate Medicare and Medicaid fraud cases involving hundreds of thousands of dollars in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: HERBERT L. SEAMANS

title: WORLD OIL OUTPUT SEEN MEETING DEMAND IN 85
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)World oil production will be sufficient to satisfy demand in 1985, and any price increases are likely to be moderate, the United States International Trade Commission said in a new energy study.

title: Jets Waive Five Players
description: Special to The New York Times

title: HAROLD A. SUTPHEN SR., 80, RETIRED BANKING OFFICIAL
description: Harold A. Sutphen Sr., who retired in 1962 as executive vice president of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and the Schroder Trust Company, died Saturday in Carolton Convalescent Hospital, Fairfield, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived at 50 Southport Wood Drive, Southport, and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Nonconformist Painter Arrested
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12 (AP)Oskar Rabin, a prominent nonconformist painter, was taken from his home by the police this morning and later placed under arrest, his son Aleksandr said.

title: Two Killed in Crash
description: MILLVILLE, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Two men were killed and three persons were injured yesterday in a headon crash on Route 47. Evan Woodward, 20 years old, of Wenonmah, N.J., and Clifford Cohiel, 20, of Mantua, N.J., died in the collision between Mr. Woodward's car and an auto operated by John White, 18, of Haddonfield, N.J. Mr. White escaped with minor. injuries. Douglas Schwenker, 20, of Wenonah, and Linda Pine, 19, of Gloucester, N.J., passengers in Mr. Woodward's car, were admitted to Millville Hospital with facial injuries suffered in the 4 A.M. crash.

title: ExSutton Supporters Act on Their Own
description: A group of black political and community leaders, together with 200 of their supporters, lined the steps of City Hall yesterday morning as their spokesman, State Senator Vander Beatty, endorsed Mario M. Cuomo as a man with the ability to bring the diverse forces of this city together

title: Invited to Be Visiting Scholar
description: A spokesman for Columbia University said yesterday that Valentin F. Turchin had an invitation to become a visiting scholar.

title: Federal Agencies Told to Double Buying From Minority Business
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 12 (AP)President Carter announced today that he had instructed Federal agencies to double their purchases from minority businesses within two years.

title: NEGATIVE RESPONSE CITED TO POSTAL CITIZEN RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 12 (AP)President Carter's proposal to set a lowcost citizen rate for mailing letters is meeting overwhelming opposition from citizens who have written to the Government about the idea.

title: Belgian Bank to Open Branch Here
description: KredietballIC, one or seigiunrs largest banks, announced yesterday that it would pen a branch office in New York next month. The Brusselsbased bank has a representative office here now.

title: Bridge:
description: In big team championships, such as the annual Reisinger event in New York, the Spingold, the Vanderbilt, and, at world level, the Bermuda Bowl, stamina is a significant factor. But this does not apply in the popular Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship in which matches are spread out with intervals of three or four weeks.

title: Shuttle Orbiter's 2d Free Flight Planned in Mojave Desert Today
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)The shuttle orbiter Enterprise with two astronauts at the controls is to make its second test free flight over the Mojave Desert tomorrow morning, starting from the back of a Boeing 747.

title: Film Festival Will Honor Dr. Mead
description: In Les Metres Fous (The Master Madmen), Jean Rouch's controversial masterpiece of cinEtna verite, a group of Africans who have moved to the capital of Ghana from the beck country are possessed by spirits. They dress in the style of the English, who still ruled Ghana when the film was made, and pantomime a roundtable conference, a trooping of the colors and other civilized acts, all with exaggerated gestures and pomposity. Then, their eyes bulging and mouths foaming, deep in trance, they sacrifice a dog and drink it.* blood. The next day, the film fine theta peacefully back at work, loading trucks, waiting on wistomert in a store.

title: SelfRegulation of Accountants Backed by Price, Waterhouse
description: A plan for selfregulation of the accounting profession, instead of regulation by Federal law, drew support yesterday from Price, Waterhouse and Company, one of the nation's largest accounting firms.

title: Draft Age In Hockey Challenged
description: A 19yearold hockey player began court action yesterday that may eventually open the professional hockey draft to teenagers, undermining the Canadian junior development system.

title: CALIFANO OPENS A DRIVE FOR CLEAR REGULATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of HOalth, Education and Welfare, today ordered a top to bottom overhaul of the complex and often confusing way the department writes its rules.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Warns of Reversal
description: Civil rights advances in the last two decades will be reversed if the Supreme Court upholds a white student's contention that racial quotas amount to reverse discrimination, the head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Commerce Chief Says Carey Will Ask Substantial
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12Governor Carey will recommend a substantial reduction next year in New York State's personal income tax, the Commissioner of Commerce, John S. Dyson, said today.

title: In Search of Country Living, Couple Found the Land of Honey
description: SAYRE, Pa.Jeanne and Curtis Morgan are beekeepers in the drowsy quiet of rural Pennsylvania. Three years ago they were computer programmers in Washington.

title: Round 1 Pits Guidry Vs. Boston Bruisers
description: Ladies and gentlemen, introducing the contenders. In one corner, standing 5 feet, 11 inches, and weighing 155 pounds, Ron Guidry. And in the other corner, with 144 home runs and 464 runs batted in, the fearsome fivesome of the Boston Red Sox.

title: Provenzano, ExAssemblyman; Involved in Race Track Case
description: ROCHESTER, Sept 12 (AP)Pat E. Provenzano, a former State Assemblyman who was ordered last year by the State Racing and Wagering Board to sell his shares in the association that operates the Batavia Downs race track, died Friday at his home here. He was 76 years old.

title: PRA. CASE PUT OFF BY CONTROL BOARD
description: Heading off a threatened impasse, the Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday once again postponed consideration of the disputed contract between New York City and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Associationa move that held up payment of wage increases to 18,000 Police officers.

title: Listings of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Robert Lowell Is Dead at 60 After Sudden Illness
description: Robert Lowell, the Pulitzer Prizewinning poet who was regarded by many critics as the best English language poet of his generation, died last night at Roosevelt Hospital after a sudden illness, according to an announcement by his publisher, Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Mr. Lowell was 60 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: AMERSFOORT, the Netherlands, Sept. 12 UPI)The police searched three trains today following rumors of a new rail hijacking plot by South Moluccan extremists.

title: Winitsky Tennis Victor
description: Topseeded Van Winitsky of North Miami Beach beat Eliot Teltscher of Palos Verdes, Calif., 64, 64, Sunday to win the $10,000 PepsiCola junior international tennis championship at Forest Hills, Queens. In the girls final, Claudia Casabianca of Argentina defeated Lea Antonoplis of Glendora, Calif., 63, 26, 62.

title: Fed Lets Funds Rate Rise
description: The Federal Reserve implicitly confirmed, by letting the Federal funds rate rise, that it wanted shortterm interest rates to increase, but how high it wanted them to move remained unclear. Page 42.

title: STEEL OUTPUT IN WEEK OFF 3.7% TO 2.3 MILLION TONS
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 10 fell by 3.7 percent to 2.3 million tons,. the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This meant that the industry was only using 75.3 percent of its total available capability. A week earlier the domestic steel industry poured 2.4 million tons and was utilizing 78.2 percent of capability.

title: Wood, Field &
description: Boyce Rensberger's The Cult of the Wild (AnchorDoubleday, 268 pages, $7.95) is a splendid book that should be read by all who are concerned with man's relationship to himself and to all other life on this planet.

title: C.A. B. Tentatively Approves Plan For New Airline Routes to Europe
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board tentatively approved yesterday a network of new airline flights to Europe that for the most part duplicated a plan that was shelved last year by President Ford, pending the outcome of BritishAmerican airtreaty negotiations.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1977

title: Senator Hart Says NATO Needs a Sweeping Review
description: Senator Gary Hart has called for a sweeping review of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's strategy, weapons and deployments to assure an effective defense against Soviet attack.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The BridgewaterRaritan School Board and more than 600 teachers agreed on a twoyear contract calling for wage increases, ending the first major school strike in New Jersey this year, officials said.

title: Bridgeport Union Accepts Cuts To Keep Company From Closing
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. Sept. 12 (AP)Union workers at the Bridgeport Brass Company voted overwhelmingly yesterday to permit an 87centanhour pay cut, a reduction in fringe benefits and other concessions so the company, which has threatened to close because of reduced profits, can stay here, a union leader safid.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1977

title: Brooklyn Bank Promises Loans to Rundown Areas
description: Anchor Savings Bank, one of 10 Brooklynbased banks accused by the State Banking Department of withholding mortgage funds from deteriorating neighborhoods, announced yesterday that it would allocate $25 million for Brooklyn housing loans over the next five years.

title: Plane Crash in Burma Kills 19
description: RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 12 (UPI)All 19 persons aboard a Burma Airways twinengine passenger plane were killed when it crashed in the jungles of astrn Burma on Thursday, officials said today. They said army rescue teams reached the crash site yesterday and found the bodies.

title: Greater Public Voice on State Boards Is Voted
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12In response to several years of lobbying by consumer groups, the State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a measure that provides for a greater voice by the public on 21 state boards that supervise

title: Gustave Reese, Honorary Head Of the Musicologicai Society, 77
description: Gustave Reese, a professor emeritus at New York University and honorary president of the American Musicological Society, died last Wednesday in Berkeley, Calif., where he was attending the congress of the International Musicological Society. He was 77 years old and lived at 414 East 52d Street.

title: Cup Series Starts Today Off Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 12At 20 minutes after 12 tomorrow afternoon, give or take a few minutes, those who care will know if the 23d defense of the America's Cup, yacht racing's esteemed prize, is going to be routine again or if some real boat races are in prospect.

title: House Passes a Bill to Require Senate Confirmation of Fed Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)The House passed legislation today requiring Senate confirmation of the chairman and vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Baord.

title: Blacks Boycott Schools Segregated by Sex
description: LIBERTY, Miss., Sept. 12The black boycott of Amite County's public schools, which have been segregated by sex since they were racially integrated in 1969, entered its third week today with no sign of an early resolution.

title: Tax Rebuff to Mobil Oil Is Disclosed
description: American oil interests were rebuffed in an attempt last year to obtain Treasury Department help in fashioning a favorable overseas contract to salvage an adverse tax ruling, according to an internal Treasury document.

title: Cities Planning Subway Projects Face Cutback in Federal Funding
description: Continued From Page 1 parking, oneway streets and bus lanes are required.

title: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr. and Jack Manning
description: CANDIDATES ENDORSED; Herman Badillo talking to Edward I. Koch before announcing he would support him in the runoff campaign. Below, Mario M. Cuomo gets the endorsement of black community leaders; State Senator Vander Beatty stands next to him. More on candidates day on page 20.

title: Howard R. Newman, Press Agent For Movies, Shows and the Ballet
description: Howard R. Newman, a founding member of the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital following kidney surgery. He was 64, years old.

title: Flyer Show
description: The Grand Ole Opry, Nashville's venerable countrymusic show, was born on radio and could not have flourished in any other form. True, the broadcasts are great spectacles, attended by 4,000 people at a time, but these are simply an adornment and celebration of the heart of the matter.

title: Robert Lowell, Pulitzer Prize Poet, Is Dead at
description: Robert Lowell, the Pulitzer Prizewinfling poet who was regarded by many critics as the best Englishlanguage poet of his generation, died last night, apparently after a heart attack, according to his publisher, Farrar Straus & Giroux.

title: China, in Review of Economy, Seeks More Output
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 12China's State Planning Commission issued a major review of economic policy today, calling for increased centralization, higher profits and production in industry and more imports of Western technology and evidently ruling out any immediate wage raises.

YAKUTAT, Alaska, Sept 12 (Reuters)A fourengine DC7 carrying a cargo of fish from southeastern Alaska crashed five miles from the airport here last night. There were apparently no survivors among the crew of four, aviation authorities said today.

title: The U.N. Today
DR. JOHN S. DAVIS JR., 76; JOINED ST. LUKE'S IN 1931
description: Dr. John Staige Davis Jr., a physician at St. Luke's Hospital since 1931, died there on Sunday after a brief illness. He was 76 years old. He had an office at 135 East 64th Street and lived at 120 East 81st Street.

title: Taiwan Gets Increasingly Nervous Over Possible U.S. Ties to China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 9Every pack of cigarettes here now bears an admonition, not about the dangers of smoking, but a much more immediate problem to this island's 16 million people. Maintain

title: Msgr. James A. Feeney Dies at 48; Head of New York Catholic Schools
description: Msgr. James A. Feeney, superintendent of schools of the Archdiocese of New York, died of a heart attack Sunday in his apartment at St. Jerome Roman Catholic Church, 138th Street and Alexander Avenue, the Bronx. He was 48 years old.

title: General Strike Called in Colombia By Country's 4 Largest Unions
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 13 (UPI)Labor unions representing three million workers have called a 24hour general strike to begin at midnight tonight.

title: Schultze Says Recovery Is Showing Few, if Any, Signs of Slowing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13President Carter's chief economic adviser, Charles L. Schultze, said today that the nation's economic recovery showed few, if any, signs of slowing with age, despite signals from recently released indicators of some slackening of activity in the third quarter.

title: CALIFORNIA ORDERS TELEPHONE REFUNDS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13The California Public Utilities Commission today ordered  massive refunds and telephone rate reductions in a case that may be the forerunner of a national challenge to a Federal Law that the commission believes gives an unfair advantage to telephone utilities.

title: Drive Is Started to Protect Loon From Predators
description: Loons, whose piercing, mournful cries and rippling laughs symbolize the northern wilderness, have been so decimated by raccoons that a major effort has been started for the preservation of the birds.

title: Bridge:
description: Karl Schneider Remembered For Primitive Bidding Plan

title: The Limo Fuels A Drive for Success
description: I read with great amusement of President Carter's edict, which took away from the White House staff the privilege of having a car and driver and reduced them to the state of ordinary taxitaking, buswaiting mortals.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: CRASH KILLS EARL C. PIPPIN, ALABAMA DEMOCRATIC AIDE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 13Earl C. Pippin, long active in labor organization in Democratic Party affairs in Alabama, was killed in the crash of a small plane near Jackson, Miss. last night. He was 55 years old.

title: NORTHEAST ENERGY UNIT IS BACKED, CAREY SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Governor Carey reported a favorable response from top Federal officials here today after he and Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut conferred with them on a proposed Northeast regional energy corporation.

title: Papers Show Hoover Had Contact With Nazis Before Pearl Harbor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)J. Edgar Hoover maintained contact with top Nazi police officials until the week before Pearl Harbor, according to documents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, made available today.

title: DR. HARRY M. WEAVER, 68, AIDE OF SCLEROSIS GROUP
description: Dr. Harry M. Weaver, consultant for research of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, died of cancer Monday at his home in San Clemente, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: Tentative Agreement Ends Strike By Clerical Workers at Hofstra
description: The strike by 325 clerical workers against Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I.. ended last night with tentative

title: SPORTS
Azle Taylor Morton Takes Oath As the 36th Treasurer of U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 13 (AP)Azie Taylor Morton has been sworn in as the 36th Treasurer of the United States.

description: Music

title: Poor Nations at U.N. Are Critical Of Rich on Paris Economic Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 13Thirdworld countries criticized the industrial nations here today at the start of a fourday General Assembly session as they introduced a draft resolution protesting that an economic conference in Paris last summer fell far short of meeting their goals.

title: Long Reviving Rockefeller Plan For Energy Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Seeking a way to spend energy tax revenues on energy development, Senator Russell B. Long, chairman of the Finance Committee, today revived former Vice President Rockefeller's proposal for a $100 billion Government corporation to finance highrisk ventures.

title: Courageous Wins America's Cup Opener By a 108Second Margin From Australia
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13It takes four races to secure the America's Cup every three years for the New York Yacht Club, and Courageous achieved the first one today when she defeated the challenger, the yacht Australia, by 1 minute 48 seconds.

title: State's Auditors Will Investigate Closed Mental Health Unit's Debts
description: PARAMUS, Sept. 13A team of statecommissioned auditors is to be sent Monday to a debtridden and closed mental health center here in an attempt to determine how the center accumulated $300,000 to $350,000 in unpaid bills.

title: DeafBlind Persons Air Problems Without Benefit of Sight or Sound
description: Hurdling several communications barri ers at the same time, about 30 deaf and blind people from nearly as many countries are meeting in New York City this week for the first major international conference on the problems of coping Without sight and sound.

title: RABIN, PAINTER IN MOSCOW, IS WARNED ON PARASITISM
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Oskar Rabin, a leading nonconformist artist, was released tonight after having been held by the police for about 36 hours, his son Aleksandr said.

title: An Audience's Conductor
description: Stokowski Was Chided for Altering Scores, But He Got Incredible Colors From Orchestra

title: Beaths
description: ABELSAnne, 17 at White Plains Center for Nursing Care. Devoted Mother of Jesse Abets and Marcella Schnilter. BeWee grandmother of Robin Abets and Jonathon Abets. Widow of Rabbi Moses J. S. Abets, former minister of Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst and Temple Immanuel of Brooklyn.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES TO SEND CARTER PLAN ON GAS TO THE FLOOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)A deadlocked Senate committee voted today to send President Carter's plan to control natural gas prices to the Senate floor without any recommendation.

title: Ill Bronx. Woman, 71, Returns to Find Home Ravaged
description: A 71yearold woman convalescing from surgery in her son's home returned to her Bronx apartment to find that it had been .:burglarized trashed, her son says bitterlynot once but three or possibly four times.

title: Toyota Exports Above 1976
description: TOKYO, Spt. 13 (UPI)The Toyota Motor Company said t exported 95,541 of 171,716 motor vehicles turned out in August. It said the exports were down 26 percent from July but were 7.6 percent above August 1976. The .company said shipments to the United States totaled 34,344 units, down 35.4 percent from July but up 31.4 percent from year ago.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1977

title: A Review of New York's Cooking Schools
description: THIS year's roster of cooking schools is larger and more varied than ever. It includes not only expected courses in French, Italian, Continental, American and Chinese cookery, but ranges farther afield to cover the cuisines of Japan, India, the Middle East, Mexico, and, for the ultimate in exotica (so far), the food of Tibet. Some classes are devoted uptotheminute techniques such as working with food processor, while others reach back in time and deal with Roman, Medieval, Elizabethan, Early American and 18thcentury English specialities.

title: A Bumper Crop in McIntosh Country
description: CLAVERACK, N.Y.

title: Pakistan, Still Looking for Stability, Gets Ready for Election Campaign
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 7This poor and troubled land is about to begin yet another election campaign in the search for political stability.

title: 9 Corporate Political Action
description: Although 450 corporate political action committees contributed $5.8 million to 1976 political campaigns, nine of the committees accounted for nearly 20 percent of the total, according to a study prepared by the Federal Election Commission.

title: Chinese AllStar Team To Visit Cosmos Oct. 8
description: The Cosmos, who play in Tokyo today before leaving for Peking tomortoW, announced yesterday that they would play an allstar team from China on Oct. 8 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. The game, on a Saturday at 1:45 P.M., will be the first for the Cosmos after Pele's farewell game iweek earlier.

title: LANCE MEETS CARTER, THEN AGAIN ASSERTS THAT HE WON'T QUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Bert Lance said today that he definitely would not resign as director of the Office of Management and Budget, contradicting expectations among some members of the Carter Administration that he would step down from his post after testifying before a Senate committee later this week.

title: Chase Takes Lead, Lifts Prime to 7%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday raised its prime lending rate to 7 percent from 7 percent. It was the first time since the summer of 1976 that the rate had reached that level.

description: ENTRIES

description: RESULTS

title: Courageous Captures Cup Opener by 108 Seconds
description: Continued From Page B9

title: NeverSayDie Pirates Slice Phillies
description: With their division race among the three considered all but over, the secondplace Pittsburgh Pirates nevertheless kept their hopes alive in the National League East last night with 20 victory over the firstplace Phillies in Philadelphia.

title: Congress Urged to Reject a Plan To Curb Regulation of Saccharin
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Carter Administration urged Congress today to reject legislation that would curb the Food and Drug Administration's powers to regulate saccharin.

title: Polaris A3 Missile Succeeds
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Flt., Sept. 13 (UPI)United States and British teams launched an improved Polaris A3 missile on a flawless test flight from a land pad last night. The test was the first of a series designed to check unspecified modifications made by the British on the 1963 vintage Americanmade rocket.

title: SUFFOLK TO APPEAL RULING ALLOWING OCEAN DRILLING
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., Sept. 13Suffolk Ctilinty will seek an appeal to the United States Supreme to stop scheduled drilling for oil in the Atlantic off the Jersey and Delaware coasts, County Executive John V. N. Klein announced today.

title: Millionaire's Trial Recessed
description: AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 13 (UPI)A state district judge today ordered the capital murder trial of a Forth Worth millionaire, T. Cullen Davis, recessed indefinitely to enable a juror to have emergency dental surgery. Judge George E. Dowlen said that the delay could last for a day to a week.

title: Young Black Leader Dies in Detention in South Africa, Raising Fears of New Unrest
description: EAST LONDON, South Africa, Sept. 13 Steven Biko, probably the most influential young black leader in South Africa, died while in police detention last night, allegedly after a hunger strike, and there were fears that his death could increase racial tension.

title: Roommates: Making a Match
description: WANTED: Someone to split the rent. Easygoing. Relatively neat. Willing to water the plants. Life style negotiable. They are in their 20's and 40's newcomers to the city and people who have lived here many years. Some are recently divorced, returning to school, or had a roommate who just got married. Others simply want to he able to live at a prestigious address.

title: Dance: Taps Close Fete
description: LEGEND HAS IT that little street kids who couldn't afford tap shoes used to throw a handful of sand on the sidewalk and do a shuffling routine that developed into a dance form all its own. Howard (Sandman) Sims, a specialist in the art who swore that he never took a lesson in his life, may just be one of them. Whatever the case, he dazzled the audience at the Delacorte Theater Monday evening with hoofing and sanddancing that headed the last program of this year's New York Dance Festival.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: FIVEyearold boy (to playmate): I got color TV. Sevenyearold boy: What color is your color TV? Fiveyearold: Black and white. Sevenyearold: What happened to the other colors? Fiveyearold: My father says two colors is enough.

title: A RECOVERY BEGINS IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: Prime Rate Increase by Chase Cuts Into Moderate Gains

title: Former Zaire Aide, Guilty of Treason, Is Sentenced to Die
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept 13 (Reuters)A former foreign minister of Zaire, Nguza KarliBond, was sentenced today to death by a firing squad for high treason.

title: Difficulty Reported in Relocating; Retarded Patients at Closing Unit
description: New York State's Mental Hygiene Department yesterday reported great difficulty in finding small community places for retarded patients in its efforts to close one Manhattan residence, and said discussions were under way to phase out another.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN FAIL ON A TRADE ACCORD
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13The United States and Japan concluded two days of intensive trade talks here today with no concrete solutions to the mounting number of trade frictions that separate these two major Pacific allies.

title: U.S. Pledges ExIm Bank Would Keep Taiwan Aid Despite Peking Relations
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 13The United States ExportImport Bank would continue to provide credits to Taiwan even the United States establishes full diplomatic relations with China, according to John Moore Jr. chairman of the ExIm Bank, who is on a fourday visit here.

title: What A Summer Captures Maskette for 4th Straight
description: Doing things the hard way could well have been the theme of the latest victory scored by Mrs. Bertram R. Firestone's What A Summer in yesterday's $53,800 Maskette Handicap at Belmont Park.

description: To the Editor:

title: Court Orders Clifton to Pay Police In Cash for Holidays They Worked
description: CLIFTON, Sept. 13City officials were ordered today to live up to contractual agreements with the police union that call for timeandahalf cash payment for eight holidays worked by the patrolmen during 1976 and 1977.

title: 15 Hurt in Chicago Bus Crash
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI)At least 15 persons suffered minor injuries today when two Chicago Transit Authority buses collided on Lake Shore Drive near

title: Chinese Are Seeking a More Active Role in Europe
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13Diptomats here believe that China hs embarked on a policy of active involvement in European affairs, and that the regal reception accorded last month to President Tito in Peking was a preliminary step.

title: College Faculties Seeking More Power Over Governance, but Administrations Resist
description: Early in the current contract talks between the faculty and administration of C.W. Post College, the faculty union proposed that the performance of senior academic administrators be periodically reviewed by faculty or facultystudent committeesand that those getting negative reviews be recalled.

title: JOHN J. PURCELL
description: TROY, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP)John Purcell, former Mayor of Troy and Democratic chairman of Rensselaer County, died Thursday at the age of 70 in St. marv's Hospital here.

title: South Korea May Invite Jaworski in Bribery Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept, 13 (AP)The South Korean Government may invite Leon Jaworski to visit Seoul in connection with his investigation into alleged influence buying by Tongsun Park, Foreign Minister Park Tong Jin said today.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT HAS NOT been a banner year in the vineyards of Prance. Rain, cold, frost and generally poor weather have had a devastating effect on much of the 1977 crop. This means ever higher prices for the 1975 and 1976 vintages.

title: JOHN W. NEWLIN, LAWYER; DAIRY FARMERS COUNSEL
description: TYRONE, Pa., Sept. 13John W. Newlin, a lawyer who was a legal representative for eastern dairy farmers for more than 30 years, died of leukemia at his home here last night. He was 68 vonrc nid.

title: A Boutique of Athletic Chic
description: If you like seeing mannequins wearing gym clothes frolicking through the display windows of the city's major department stores, you'll be interested in S'port, an entire boutique of clothes in the athletic chic style.

title: REDCAPS GET A REPRIEVE BUT UNION PROTESTS PLAN
description: Amtrak yesterday announced what amounted to a modification of its plan to eliminate redcap service, but ran into immediate opposition from the union representing the luggage handlers.

title: Labor Dispute Stalls Construction At Seabrook Nuclear Power Plant
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 13 (AP)Work on the $100 million cooling tunnels of the $2.3 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant remains stalled because of labor problems.

description: SOLAR ENERGY is such serious business that almost all of the books on it appear to be published for adults. They contain complicated projects far beyond the ability of most children.

description: TOKYO

title: New Version of Reggae
description: JAMAICA'S reggae music is an amalgam of musical styles. At present, the politically con soious reggae of the island's Rastafarians is so commercially dominant that most reggae artists find expedient to pay at least lip service to the Rasta creed. But the Jamaican record industry also turns out discs of easylistening reggae and other relatively mild varieties.

title: Leinsdorf Will Give Stokowski Tribute
description: Erich Leinsdorf will add one of Stokowski's Bach transcriptions to tomorrow night's concert by the New York Philharmonic, to honbr the conductor's memory.

title: Representative to Gain Support of Rangel and Paterson
description: Most of the black political establishment in Manhattan including Representative Charles B. Rangel; Basil A. Paterson, a former Democratic national vice chairMan, and State Senator Carl H. McCall, have decided to endorse Representative Edward I. Koch in the mayoral runoff next Monday.

title: CRANGLE BACKS EVE FOR BUFFALO MAYOR
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 13  Assemblyman Arthur 0. Eve, who won an upset victory in the Democratic mayoral primary here last week, today accepted the surprise endorsement of his chief target during the campaign, Joseph F. Crangle, the Erie County Democratic chairman, who had organized the opposition to Mr. Eve.

title: The New York Times/Tyrone Dukes
description: DERAILMENT IN QUEENS: A Conrail freight train derailed yesterday, dumping a load of lumber onto Central Avenue, between Myrtle and Cypress Avenues in Glendale. No one was hurt but a parked car Was demolished by the lumber.

title: U.S. Approves Contract For a Company to HandIe Medicaid in New York
description: Federal approval of New York State's $8.2 million contract with the Bradfdiii. National Corporation to start out as statg., fiscal agent for New York City's $2 billio6 Medicaid program was announced yester. day.

title: The Unlisted Numbers List Is Growing
description: On tiny transparent squares of plastic kept secure in one cluttered midtown office are the names of doctors, lawyers and industry chiefs. The names include the famous, the infamous and the faceless thousands who would like their low profiles to stay that wayNew Yorkers who for a variety of reasons want their availability to remain as slight as the letters printed on those plastic cards, which can be read only under a magnifvine machine.

title: Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)House and Senate conferees today approved $453.25 billion Federal budget for the next fiscal year, making no provision for any increase in Social Security payroll taxes.

title: Labor Urgedto Heed A.F.L.C.I.O. in Voting
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13New Jersey's top labor leader, Charles Marciante, who is trying to withhold the support of labor from Governor Byrne, today urged 30 independent labor officials supporting the Governor to follow the lead of the State A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: Jersey Woman Testifies Of Her Ordeal in a Motel In KidnappingRape Trial
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 13A 24yearold woman who was raped last Feb. 6 after three men allegedly abducted her and her 14yearold sister from a shopping center parking lot in Paramus testified about her ordeal today as the trial of the alleged rapist began.

title: Egypt and P. L. O. Praise U. S. Support Of Palestinian Role
description: CAIRO, Sept. 13Egyptian authorities view the United States call for Palestinian representation in any Middle East peace talks in Geneva as anew opening to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: ERIK VON FRENCKELL
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 13 (AP)Erik von Frenckell, a longtime member of the International Olympic Committee, died today. Mr. von Frenckell, who was 89 years old, internationally was Finland's most renowned sports leader.

title: Municipal Labor Chief Says He's ImpressedTeachers Deciding
description: The largest union of city workers expected to abandon its neutral position and endorse Mario M. Cuomo for Mayor today or tomorrow, Victor Gotbaum, the union's leader, indicated yesterday.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: DEFENSE CHIEF SEEKS CUTBACK IN AIRCRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Defense Seclietary Harold Brown, in a major move That would affect. Navy and Marine Corps ,krategy, has tentatively decided to cut back development of a new vertical takeoff jet fighter for use aboard ships and on land.

title: Only Traces of PBB in Catfish
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)Contrary to preliminary reports, catfish taken from the Ohio River contained only trace amounts of PBB, the Environmental Protection Agency said today. The fireretardant chemical can cause severe kidney and liver damage in man. Unvalidated data provided to E.P.A. in early August had indicated potentially dangerous PBB levels in catfish.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/William E. Sam

title: TV: Bionics, Amin And Emmy Awards
description: WITH NO weekly series scheduled for unveiling tonight, a few paragraphs are hereby being filched to comment on items of television interest that tended to get lost in the newseason shuffle last week. The Six Million Dollar Man got himself trapped underwater with a remotecontrolled shark and finished seventh in the magical top .10 of the Neilsen ratings. Bionic Woman met Max The Bionic Dog and finished 18th on the charts. Both stories will be concluded this week, with an eye to fantasy escalations and continued hefty ratings.

title: Books of TheTinith
description: AMERICAN CULTURE has an interesting way of dealing with black heroism; unless it is overwhelming or athletic, it is largely ignored. There is no getting around the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. or Jackie Robinson, but the accomplishments of many otherand not necessarily lesserfigures in black history have faded from consciousness, sometimes only because white American writers have lacked the intellectual and emotional tools required to evaluate those lives accurately.

title: G.M. Offers First U.S. Diesel Auto And Introduces Slimmed Cutlass
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13  The General Motors Corporation today unveiled the first dieselpowered American passenger car as it began taking the wraps off the auto industry's biggest family so far of slimmeddown automobiles designed to meet stricter fueleconomy standards. _

title: Council Post Rivals Avoid Mayoral Choice
description: The two contenders for the Democratic nomination for City Council PresidentPaul O'Dwyer, the incumbent, and State Senator Carol Bellamy, yesterday ruled out alliances with either of the Democratic mayoral candidates.

title: Advertising
description: In January, ChrisCraft Industries, the wellknown makers of pleasure boats, will launch a new ad campaign that will largely run in business publications (They know where the money is), newsweeklies and some men's magazines.

title: SOL M. PAPPERMAN
description: Dr. Sol M. Papperman, an internist who supported a policy of physicians continuing to make house calls, died Sunday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J., after a prolonged illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 622 Paramus Road Paramus, N.J., where he also had an office.

title: When Keeping Kosher Isn't Kosher Enough
description: They won't eat their mothers chicken soup, chopped liver or roast flanken. They won't even have a taste of homemade gefilte fish garnished with a slice of carrot in quivering jellied fish broth. They'll have no pink lox on their bagel, and some won't even have the bagelunless it's made from organically grown wholegrain flour.

title: Bell, Deputy Split on Carter Pledge T o Name U.S. Attorneys on Ability
description: A major conflict has emerged at the highest levels in the Justice Department over whether the Administration will keep President Carter's campaign promise to choose United States attorneys on the basis of merit rather than politics.

description: Outgoing

title: Incumbent Mayor and 2d Black Lead Detroit Voting
description: DETROIT, Wednesday, Sept.14Ernest C. Browne Jr., a conservative black city councilman, and incumbent Mayor Coleman A. Young held the lead early today in this city's nonpartisan primary election for mayor.

title: Leopold Stokowski Is Dead of .a Heart Attack at
description: Leopold Stokowski, possibly the bestknown symphonic conductor of all time, died in England yesterday at the age of 95, in his house at Nether Wallop, a village in Hampshire, England. He had been suffering from a mild virus infection that had not been thought serious, and his death was attributed to a coronary attack.

title: Cuomo Finds Race a Scramble for Money and Support
description: Over . several cups of coffee in the dinette of his Queens home yesterday, Nlario M. Cuomo described his effort in the mayoral primary runoff thus far as a frenetic attempt to collect money; a scurrying for endorsements, not so mucr because they might help, but simply to deny them to the other candidate; a flood of demands on my time.

title: Japanese Town Gets Atom Plant And a New Life
description: TOKAI MURA, Japan, Sept. 12Chuzo Akuzawa doesn't know much about nuclear energy. But he does know one thing: the hardwon agreement to open Japan's first nuclear fuel reprocessing plant here, which was formally signed by the United States and Japan in Washington today, is good for Japan, this little town and him, not necessarily in that order.

title: A Barren Ethiopian Desert Is Key to War With Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 12The vast, arid Ogaden region that Ethiopia and Somalia are fighting over can barely support human life. But to the proud, nomadic, desertloving Somalis, it is promised land.

title: NEW CORRUPTION LAW IS SIGNED BY BYRNE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13Governor Byrne today signed a new state law that provides for up to seven years in prison and 5100,000 fines for officials who are convicted of corruption. The law takes effect immediately.

title: Bell, Deputy Split on Carter Pledge To Name U.S Attorneys on Ability
description: A major conflict has emerged at the highest levels in the Justice Department over whether the Administration will keep President Carter's campaign promise to choose United States attorneys on the basis of merit rather than politics.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: SUNSET TRAIL First Avenue has rewarding surprises tinged with drama, a stunning East River backdrop, a United Nations headquarters that too many New Yorkers take for granted, and more. A leisurely walk in late afternoon from the U.N. north to the Queensborough Bridge can be a revelation, or a tingling refresher course in Big Apple ripeness, and fun.

title: Bonn Hints Reply to Kidnappers On Demand for the Release of 11
description: BONN, Sept. 13The West German Government in a cryptic announcement on television late tonight said it had forwarded the answers of the prisoners to a Geneva lawyer for relaying to the kidnappers of HannsMartin Schleyer, leading industrialist.

title: Around the Nation
description: KENT, Ohio, Sept. 13 (AP)The United States Supreme Court refused for a third time today to stop construction of a gymnasium annex near the site where four students were killed in a 1970 antiwar demonstration at Kent State University.

title: Yanks 42 Victors on Guidry's 5Hitter
description: 55,269 See Rivers Beat Red Sox on 2Run Homer

title: Books: The Criminals of Russia Not Like U.S. Counterparts
description: IF MOSCOW UNDERWENT a blackout such as the one New York City suffered last July, would the Soviet capital suffer anything comparable to the mass looting that hit here? Valery Chalidze, the famous former Soviet dissident who has taken refuge in this country, dogs not consider that problem explicitly in this interesting book, but the implied answer he suggests is negative. He writes that as far as serious crimes against ordinary law are concerned, crime in the Soviet Union is not as had as it is in some other countries. This can be attributed to such features of Soviet society as total control over the population and the compulsory nature of labor, and to specific anticrime measures such as the ban on carrying arms. Moreover stores in Soviet neighborhoods dont carry such riches in consumer goods as those that were looted in New York, while no one can doubt that Soviet police would shoot to stop looters.

title: Careers
description: There was a time when industrial engineers, often called timestudy experts, moved through factories and offices with a furtive air attributable, in part, to the anger of union leaders who balked at speedup methods.

title: A Bill to Ban Welfare Abortions Is Vetoed by Governor of Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI)  Gov. James R. Thompson vetoed a bill today that. would have banned welfare abortions in Illinois. The Republican Governor said that the bill was more than unfairit is cruel.

title: Both Voyagers Cruising Smoothly
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 13 (UPI)Problems with Voyage 1 and Voyage 2 now have been ironed out and the two spacecraft are cruising smoothly on their 500 million mile voyage to Jupiter, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said today.

title: Market Place
description: Resurgence for the Glamour Stocks?

title: Fears of Oversell Haunting Planners of Youth Program
description: WASHINGTONA specter is haunting the conference rooms where the planners of the Carter Administration's youth program are rushing preparations to spend $1.5 billion in the next 12 months on projects aimed at starting to lift a quartermillion The unemployed young Americans out of hopelessness Labor into a quickened tide of job Scene and school opportunity. That specter is the memory of Presidnt Lyndon B. Johnson's War on Poverty in the mid1960's and the legacy of disappointment left by its failure to achieve any substantial part of the Homeric design for rescuing  the nation's poor, especially those in the explosive black slums of the great metropolitan centers, from deprivation and despair.

title: Dog Kills Baby Boy in Oregon
description: MILWAUKIE, Ore., Sept. 13 (AP)A 7month old boy playing in a crib at a baby sitter's house was attacked by a large dog and later died in surgery at a Portland hospital, hospital officials said today. The dog, described by the state police as half elkhound and half German shepherd, was killed by animal control officers. The victim was the only child of Mr. and Mrs. Terry Boyd of Milwaukie, a Portland suburb.

title: Bergland Proposes National Wilderness In North Minnesota
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Carter Administration, to the applause of environmentalists, proposed today a plan to preserve Minnesota's Boundary Waters Canoe Area as a quiet, unexploited wilderness.

title: CONSERVATIVES PLAN DRIVE TO LIMIT AMOUNT OF TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)The American Conservative Union announced today a national campaign for state constitutional amendments to limit the amount of taxes that states may collect from their citizens.

title: Damascus Colt Brings $200,000
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 13 (AP)The $200,000 paid for a bay colt by Damascus out of Chou Croute at this afternoon's session of the Keeneland September Yearling Sale equaled the record high price for a yearling at the annual sale, a spokesman said.

title: Portugal Seizes Spaniard in Theft Of Gold and Jewels in a Cathedral
description: OPORTO, Portugal, Sept. 13 (Reuters)The Portuguese police tonight arrested a Spaniard wanted in the theft of medieval gold and jewels from Oviedo Cathedral in northern Spain a month ago.

description: Agencies that specialize in matching roommates include:

description: International
