title: The West Bank by Any Other Name
description: What's in a name? Just about all the Arab countries have called for the creation of a Palestinian state on the territory west of the Jordan River occupied by Israel since 1967. The new Israeli government of Prime Minister Menahem Begin asserts that this territoryJudea and Samaria, to use the biblical names Mr. Begin employsis Israel's by ancient right and will so remain. Yet when Moshe Dayan, his Foreign Minister, arrives in Washington next week he will reportedly bring with him a proposal for giving substantial internal autonomy to the Palestinian Arabs now on the West Bank while leaving in place Israeli military garrisons for security.

title: Chess:
description: Taimanov Wrote the Book, But Might Add New Chapter

title: SENATE REEXAMINING CONFIRMATION POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13A Senate committee's reexamination of the financial affairs of Bert Lance has prompted the Senate to take another look at the way it confirms Presidential nominations, a process that some senators complain has been one of too little advice and too much consent.

title: Liddy Scores Lack of Secrecy in U.S. In Magazine Article
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13G. Gordon Liddy, the Watergate burglar who was freed on parole recently, has written 4,000word article for Chic magazine bemoaning the terrible damage done to the U.S. intelligence community by national compulsion for public disclosure.

title: Veterans Day Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)President Carter today proclaimed Oct. 24 as Veterans Day and asked Americans to remember sick and disabled veterans who are in hospitals.

title: A House in the Country
description: In a letter published last week, a reader complained that although he had moved in 1971 to Red Hook, N. Y., (not Red Hook, Brooklyn) in an effort to escape the evils of city life, the evils are following him and, in the name of mindless progress, are threatening to destroy his dream house and, with it, all other dream houses. If our correspondent were simply a lonely Vergil penning an Eclogue tinged with romantic regret, he might be left to sing unanswered.

title: Doing Time
description: The case was typicalarmed robbery with three prior felony convictionsand so was the outcome. Two judges and a probation officer met to fix the sentence, their discussion limited to a succession of numbers: 20 years; no, 12 years; would 16 be right? The decision came down at 14, just at about the average for Such a crime and record.

title: Dollar Off a Bit In Europe Trade
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP)The dollar eased slightly against most West European currencies in foreign exchange trading today.

title: Asks Additional Economic Spurs to Help Employ Blacks andYouths
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall said today that the Carter Administration's economic program was not meeting some of its goals and called for additional fiscal stimulus designed specifically to create jobs for blacks and young people.

title: Homage at the Shrine of the Idle Idyll
description: CALL me Ishmael. I owe my publisher a novel and it is long overdue. Pity me. The other day, I rang up my publisher, whom I shall call Ahab, and offered him his money back. Uh, uh, he said. You're not getting off that easy. He inquired after my health, I lied and said I was fine, just fine. He said. Good, good, and rang off. Pity me. He is not a bad man but he knew enough to get off. Else, I would have said to him, out of John, Whoso hath this world's good, and seeth his brother have need, and shutteth up his bowels of compassion from him, how dwelleth the love of God in him? In all fairness, he has enough trouble getting his authors to parse without having scraps of Scripture come wailing uo the wires at him.

title: Loon, Victim of Raccoon, Gets a Helping Hand
description: Loons whose piercing, mournful cries and rippling laughs symbolize the northern wilderness, have been so decimated raccoons that a major effort has been started for the preservation of the birds.

title: Mrs. Lance Says Her Overdrafts Were Unlike an Average Person's
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)Budget Director Bert Lance's wife says that the overdrafts she made on her checking account were different from the overdrafts most people make.

title: World News Briefs
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 13 (AP)Prime Minister Odvar Nordli said today that he would seek a vote of confidence in Parliament to continue his minority government after national elections yesterday left his Labor Party and the opposition centerright evenly balanced.

title: A Legislative Panel in Connecticut Votes Against Investigating Judge
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 13 (AP)A committee of legislative leaders voted 14 to Monday against investigating Superior Court Judge Simon Cohen's handling of the Bernard Avcollie murder trial and other controversial cases.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Merger talks between the Raytheon Company and Falcon Seaboard Inc.involving a stock swap valued at nearly $235 millionhave been terminated, the two companies said yesterday. Falcon stock, which had moved up sharPly when the talks were first disclosed last June, fell 3 points yesterday to 231% in heavy trading.

title: In Memoriam
description: KAOINIrving Constantly remernberets by all who dreg you &My. Sister and brothers.

title: Dow Rises by 0.18 in Slow Trading, Averting Drop to a 20Month Low
description: The Dow Jones industrial average registered a token recovery in late trading yesterday and thereby narrowly averted sliovine to a 20month low.

title: Eleanor Vinton, Poet Laureate Of New Hampshire Since 1972
description: CONCORD, N.H., Spt. 13 (AP)Eleanor Vinton, the last person to hold life tenure as New Hampshire's poet laureate, died yesterday. She was 78 years old.

title: Article 3  No Title
BROADENING SOUGHT IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)House tax writers voted tentatively today to include in the Social Security system all Federal, state and local government civilian employees.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: TO COOK with haste and precision implies cooking efficiently. An to cook efficiently implies familiarization with the basic techniques of cookery. One of the most useful formulas is the one used for breading foods, which we speak of in French kitchens as a l'anglaise (English style) or foods panes or panties (breaded).

title: Shift in U.S. Stand Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)The United States Government said today that the agreement to let Japan open its Tokai Mura nuclearreprocessing plant did not reflect any change in the policy of discouraging a spread of nuclear weaponmaking capacity.

title: Ship Spills Oil Near New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 (AP)A Liberianregistered tanker spilled 8,000 gallons of oil in the Mississippi River early today and emergency steps were taken to protect the city's drinking water intake lines. The Coast Guard said that the 840foot ship might have struck a buoy although that could not be confirmed. The tanker anchored at Reserve about 25 miles north of New Orleans.

title: Poet as Mirror of Our Age
description: Both as a poet and as a public figure, Robert Lowell, who died on Monday, was a reflection of our age. His work was not history, but historyhis and oursbecame the cause and substance of his work. In word and deed, he embodied our unease, our uncertainties, our despair: I An ask for bread, my father Appreciation gives me mold. He embodied our need to speak. out, to connect, even with strangers. Patrician in name and lineage, he made his private life public: he told all in therapeutic gestures aimed as much at his readers as at himself. On one of the great issues that divided America, its involvement in the war in Indochina, he stood unyieldingly with those who protested the bloodletting in Vietnam. But Lowell went further. He abhorred all war, and went to jail rather than join the armed forces.

title: G.A.O. QUESTIONS NEED OF NEW SOLAR INSTITUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)The General Accounting Office has issued report questioning the decision to build a multimilliondollar Solar Energy Researoh Institute, House aides said today. A tentative site for the institute has been selected at Golden, Colo.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday erroneously listed Robert Culp as one of the stars of the ABC television serial Washington: Behind Closed Doors. Thp actor referred to was Robert Vaughn.

title: 197 Transit Workers Ousted in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 13 (AP)Louisville transit officials dismissed 197 employees today for defying backtowork orders that would have restored bus service to more than 50,000 daily riders.

title: Rudd, Who Led Campus Revolt, Will Surrender
description: Mark Rudd, the leader of the 1968 student rebellion at Columbia University and a fugitive since 1970, will turn himself in to the Manhattan District Attorney's office today, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: New Stand For Pianist
description: THE BALLROOM, which had great success last year with its Broadway at the Ballroom series, in which composers for the tsroadway musical theater became performers and sang their own songs, is now putting another group in the spotlightpiano accompanists. This series, Monday nights only, instead of the weeklong engagements that the composers had, began auspiciously last Monday evening with Steve Ross, who brought with him six of the singers for whom he has played piano.

title: Pound Rises inForward Markets
description: LONDON, Sept. 13The British pound, like Eliza Doolittle, is becoming so respectable it's almost embarrassing:

title: Foreigners Are Filling Jobs Italians Will Not Take
description: REGGIO NELLEMILLA, Italy  A foundry owner looked in vain for workers for months, so when Magd Kedr Megahed, an Egyptian, showed up asking for a job, the ownar hired him immediately. Mr. Megahed had no papers, no place to live and no training in foundry work, but the factory here in northern Italy had been owrating at only 30 percent capacity, so the owner took a chance.

title: Courageous Wins America's Cup Opener By a 108Second Margin From Australia
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13It takes four races to secure the America's Cup every three years for the New York Yacht Club, and Courageous achieved the first one today when she defeated the challenger, the yacht Australia, by 1 minute 48 seconds.

title: Life With Good Food In a Roman Villa
description: BARBARANO ROMANO, Italy

title: Notes on People
description: We won't give it another try, said Maxie Anderson, one of two Albuquerque businessmen who were rescued off the coast of Iceland after their attempt to cross the Atlantic in a balloon failed. Mr. Anderson and Ben L. Abruzzo were forced down 800 miles short of their goal after encountering ice and whirlpool winds. In renouncing further plans to make the crossing, Mr. Abruzzo said in Reykjavik: If a young baloonist came to me and asked me if he should make a try to cross the Atlantic, I would answer, You are crazy if you try. But I know he will make the try all the same. Maybe we are all crazy, but someone must do this. Sooner or later the Atlantic will be conquered by a lone balloon.

title: TRAIAN LEUCUTIA
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP)Dr. Traian Leucutia, a noted radiologist and editor of medical textbooks, died Sunday at a nursing home. He was 85 years old.

title: For Fast Relief, Take Two
description: HELP WANTED: Relief pitcher for pennant contender. Must have strong, resilient arm and temperament to withstand pressure. Steady work until midOctober. Good benefits.

title: Japan Jails 15 for 1968 Riots
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP)The Tokyo District Court today convicted 15 radical student leaders of rioting in 1968 and sentenced them to prison terms ranging fronk two to four years. The 15 were among, 600 students arrested Oct. 21, 1968, fox a violent demonstration against the Unit: ed StatesJapan Security Treaty.

title: The NotSoWild Ones
description: Instead of Marlon Brando in a leather jacket and shades, hunched over the handlebars of a motorcycle, try picturing Senator Howard Baker of Tennessee, Malcolm Forbes, the president and editor in chief of Forbes Magazine, or an executive in a threeniece suit.

title: Paying Off the Maritime Lobby
description: Maritime union lobbyists helped elect Jimmy Carter by raising at least $150,000 for his campaign. Now President Carter is asking American consumers to return the favor by paying between $240 million and $610 million each year in higher fuel bills.

title: Expos Down Mets, 85, With 5 Runs in Eighth
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 13As statistics go, the 1,200th run batted in of Tony Perez's career was lost tonight in fiverun eighth inning that pushed the Montreal Expos to an 85 victory over the New York Mets.

title: New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. To Be Focus of Federal Drug Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration are cooperating to investigate drug trafficking by organized crime in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, the Justice Department said today.

title: Topics
description: Manhattan Salad

title: Your Old Neighborhood Movie House Is It Doomed?
description: A NNIE HALL was just beginning in the cavernous Music Hall in Tarrytown, N.Y., and Woody Allen came on to bare the scars of his psyche to an audience of 60 sympathetic viewers and 740 empty seats.

title: Fire Company in Basking Ridge Ordered to Open Rolls to Women
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13A Somerset County volunteer fire company has been ordered to open its ranks to women and amend those policies and regulations that discriminate against them.

title: Aussies
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13The moments after the finish of today's America's Cup yachting opener, Ted Turner acknowledged the cheers by giving a little shrug and holding out his right hand, palm up, as if to say, What did you exuect?

title: Private Lives
description: W E were standing around at a party. Every fall I do a lot of standing around at parties, having forgotten over the summer how much I don't care for standing around at parties with my teeth hanging out. Every fall I imagine once again that something wonderful will happen at a party. This is like imagining that the telephone book will prove to be a wonderful novel. Parties and telephone books have their reasons, but wonder lurks elsewhere, sitting down, in small groups, without any shoes on. Still, in the fall, I will go to a party so long as it isn't on a boat. In my experience, parties on boats are bad news because when I want to go home I am in the middle of the Hudson River with a rock band and an assistant professor of mortuary science.

title: Floods Strike the Kansas City Area, Leaving 19 Dead
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 13Nineteen persons were known dead and at least a score were still unaccounted for late today after torrential rains last night and early this morning touched off devastating flash floods here and in the surrounding suburbs.

title: A Barren Ethiopian Desert Is Key to War With Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 12The vast, arid Ogaden region that Ethiopia and Somalia are fighting over can barely support human life. But to the proud, nomadic, desertloving Somalis, it is promised land.

title: THOMAS F. STALEY DIES AT AGE OF 74
description: Thomas F. Staley, 74 years old, founder of Reynolds & Company, predecessor of Reynolds Securities Inc., died of a heart attack yesterday in United Hospital, Port Chester N.Y. He lived at 2435 North Ocean Boulevard, Delray Beach, Fla., and at 30 Club Road, Rye,

title: WILFRED PATERSON
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, July 13, (AP)Wilfred Paterson, quarterback with the Hamilton Tigers 1932 Grey Cup champion team of the Canadian Football League, died today. He was 69 years old.

title: They'll Be Called New Jersey Nets
description: NORTH BERGEN. Sept. 13 (AP) The Nets basketball team, abandoning its New York affiliation on Long Island, will change its name to the New Jersey Nets, team officials announced yesterday.

title: Women's Lobbying Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The National Commission on Observance of International Women's Year is not exceeding its Congressional mandate in lobbying for the proposed equal rights amendment, Comptroller General Elmer B. Staats has ruled. Mr. Staats turned down a request by Senator Jesse Helms, Republlican of North Carolina, who opposes the amendment's ratification, for an audit of the commission.

description: QuestionI've come to New York to review the Urban Crisis. How's it going?

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Before Jimmy Cartel won the Democratic. Presidential nomination, Bert Lance talked to en official of the Comptroller of the Currency's office about dealing with restrictions against one of his banks should he be appointed to a high Government position and become the subject of a background check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to testimony of a national bank examiner that was disclosed today.

title: FUTURES OF SOYBEANS AND WHEAT ADVANCE
description: A late wave of buying lifted wheat and soybean futures prices and erased most of the earlier loSses in corn yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Space Shuttle, in Second Solo Test, Gets High Marks From Its 2 Pilots
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 13The space plane Enterprise neatly executed its second freeflight test today, taking another step in the development of the $6.9 billion space shuttle that is designed to ferry people and cargo to and from space again and again.

description: Anyone hoping to land a job as a court reporter after taking a course at Adelphi Business Schools will probably have long wait, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: LANCE MEETS CARTER, THEN AGAIN ASSERTS THAT HE WON'T QUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 13Bert Lance said today that he definitely would not resign as director of the Office of Management and Budget, contradicting expectations among some members of the Carter Administration that he would step down from his post after testifying before a Senate committee later this week.

title: The Time To Retire
description: WASHINGTONChances are strong that before the year is out 0:ingress will lower another barrier to human rights. The House of Representatives will vote any day now on a bill to raise the minimum age for mandatory retirement from 65 to 70 and require the Labor Department to recommend whether mandatory retirement should be ended altogether.

title: Charles Ferris Named to Head F.C.C.
description: President Carter late Monday named Charles D. Ferris, a 44yearold lawyer who has spent 13 years as a Congressional aide, as chairman of the Federal Communications CommissiOn. The appointment is subject to Senate confirmation, but that is expected to go smoothly because of the influential backing for Mr. Ferris on Capitol Hill.

title: ]Municipal Labor Chief Says He's ImpressedTeachers Deciding
description: The largest union of city workers is expected to abandon its neutral position and endorse Mario M. Cuomo for Mayor today or tomorrow, Victor Gotbaum, the union's leader, indicated yesterday.

description: Most of the black political establishment in Manhattan, including Representative Charles B. Rangel; Basil A. Paterson, a former Democratic national vice chairman, and State Senator Carl H. McCall, has decided to endorse Representative Edward I. Koch in the mayoral runoff next Monday.

A Taste of the Tombs Buries All Illusions
description: When the door or a dingy orange cell in Block 7LD of the Tombs clanged shut in Amos Carson's face yesterday, any lingering doubts he might have had about life behind bars were dispelled.

title: Woman Killed, Shah's Sister Unhurt in Riviera Attack
description: PARIS, Sept. 13A car carrying the Shah of Iran's twin sister, Princess Ashraf Pahlevi, was attacked by gunmen on the French Riviera early today, but she escaped unharmed. Her lady in waiting was killed, and one of two Iranian friends also in the car was wounded.

title: Jewish Vegetarian Restaurants
description: Although Jewish vegetarians patronize many of the same vegetarian, health food and macrobiotic restaurants and stores as other vegetarians, they do have their own special haunts. Two such places are The Caldron, a Jewish macrobiotic restaurant and store on East Sixth Street, and the recently opened Jerusalem Gardens, a Jewish vegetarian restaurant on West 79th Street, both of which operate under rabbinical supervision and observe the Jewish Sabbath.

title: Plan to Add Police Officers in HighCrime Period Put Off Because P.B.A. Pact Is Still Being Disputed
description: The New York City Police Department. acting at the request of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, yesterday postponed indefinitely the new duty schedules that would have put additional police officers on the streets during the highcrime hours of midnight to 2 A.M.

title: CHARGES ARE INCREASED AT NEW YORK SKI CENTERS
description: The New York State Deuartment of Environmental Conservation posted new rates this week for the coming season at its three ski centers in the Adirondacks and Catskills. Most charges will become higher, but some bargain rates will be available, especially for midweek skiers.

title: More Than Stardom Is in Common As Pele Meets Oh in Park in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP)I imagined you must be much bigger when I heard of your career goal record, said the Japanese home run king, Sadallaru Oh, today when he first met Brazil's most famous soccer player, Pele, in Tokyo.

title: Personal Health
description: AS schools and colleges get into full swing across the country, a variety of pesky critters can be counted on to literally latch upon unsuspecting congregants and cause untold embarrassment as well as itchy misery. These crittershead and pubic lice and scabies (itch mite)have forced many a school to close in recent years to squelch epidemics.

title: Floridian Scheduled for Execution Loses One Plea and Files Second
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 13 (UPI)John Spinkellink, a convicted murderer, who is scheduled in he the second person to be exrcute1 since capital punishment was reinstated in the United States lost one appeal for a stay of execution today and immediately filed another.

title: 1,100 Wild Horses Adopted
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 13 (AP)More than 1,100 wild horses threatened by the drought have found new homes through a Federal adoption service, Larry Lee, wild horse coordinator in Oregon and Washington, said today, but he added that hundreds more horses are awaiting adoption.

title: PANAMA ASKS INQUIRY INTO ITS HUMAN RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Panama invited the United Nations today to send observers to its Oct. 23 plebiscite on the Pananta Canal treaties and welcomed first  hand investigation of human rights in that country by an agency of the Organization of American States.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: LOW FARE ON FLIGHTS ABROAD BEGINS TODAY
description: Today is inauguration day on major airlines for the $256 New YorkLondon roundtrip fare, but it is expected that few of the cutrate seats will be available on flights to London.

title: TV: Here's the KiddieMarket Entry
description: A NEW SEASON cannot pass without at least one series on the order of CHiPs, which comes to NBC tonight at 8. Designed for intentional exploitation of the kiddie market, these projects feature enough youngish characters in a variety of mildand. if possible, cute adventure situations. The protagonists can be anything from forest rangers to helicopter rescue teams. In the case CHiPs, they are motorcycle policemen, members of the California Highway Patrol, as the title is trying to tell us.

title: British Boxer Faces Tests
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP)  The British Boxing Board of Control said today that Richard Dunn, the former British heavyweight champion, must have a full medical checkup before he is allowed to go through with his Nov. 21 fight with Billy Aird in London for the vacant title. The stewards made their decision following Dunn's fifthround knockout loss to Kallie Koetze in Johannesburg last Saturday. It was the third straight time Dunn had been stopped.

title: Sarah Dash Scores as Solo Singer
description: ARAH DASH, who opened twoweek run at Reno Sweeney Tuesday night, had more cause than her former colleagues to yearn for a solo career, once her former group, Labelle, broke up late last year after 16 years. Patti Labelle was the lead singer of the old group, after all, so she had had a chance to shine. And Nona Hendrvx was Labelle's sone writer. But Miss Dash was just Sarah Dash. Now she's Sarah Dash, solo artist, the first of the threesome to perform as an individual in New York. (Miss Labelle is the first off the block with a record, while Miss Hendryx is currently warming up her solo act in Europe.)

title: Craft Seized at Sea With Marijuana
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP)The Coast Guard escorted a 73foot Honduran vessel into Boston today after seizing the craft at sea with a large amount of marijuana aboard. The Juliana I was taken into custody by the cutter Active at 10 P.M. Monday, about 120 miles northeast of here.

title: Maertens Victor in Cycling
description: SITGES, Spain, Sept, 14 (AP)Freddy Maertens of Belgium won the 57th Tour of Catalonia cycling race today. Maertens took the first section of the race, a 16.2mile individual time trial between La Garriga and Granollers, in 33 minutes 58 seconds, The second sector of 63.4 miles was won by Giuseppe Perletto of Italy in 2:46.46, Maertens, two seconds bellind, finished second and took the overall title.

title: Disks: Americana Revivified
description: Although Willard Robison, who died In 1968 at the age of 73, wrote a few songs that gained sufficient popularity to make their titles slightly familiarprimarily Old Folks and A Cottage for Salehis distinction as a songwriter went so unnoticed that even as astute an observer of popular songs as Alec Wilder mentioned him only briefly in his authoritative book, American Popular Song: The Great Innovators, 19001950.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: They are entitled to sympathy when they say that they are trying to preserve a place for their tribe, too. But when they argue that they will provide dignity for blacks within their system, they are mocked by the death of Steve Biko.

title: Huge Dinosaur Track Is Uncovered
description: GRANBY, Mass., Sept. 14 (AP)A dinosaur track described as perhaps the largest ever found intact, measuring nearly 5 feet by 3 feet, has been uncovered in a quarry dotted with imprints left by the ancient reptiles. Rouville F. Gingras, owner of a commercial dinosaur museum, said he found the track last week while digging in a layer of rippled shale. He estimated the imprint was left in the quarry 180 million to 200 million years ago by a dinosaur that measured 70 feet from head to tail.

title: My Fellow Americans:
description: I have asked for this television time tonight to share with you my feelings, and my decisions, about what some believe to be a challenge to the moral authority of my Presidencythe charges against Bert Lance.

title: Senators Bar Plan for Teenagers To Get BelowtheMinimum Wage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)The Senate Human Resources Committee rejected today a proposal to permit employers to pay less than the minimum wage to teenagers.

title: ALBANY ISSUES GUIDE ON BUYING INSURANCE
description: The cost of identical life insurance policies can vary by as much as 300 percent, according to a Shopping Guide for Life Insurance just published by the New York State Insurance Department.

description: HARTFORD, Sept. 14 (AP)The State Commerce Department has approved grants totaling $5.2 million to six Connecticut companies to expand their plants. Commerce Commissioner Edward Stockton said the grants would help the companies retain 234 existing jobs and create 116 new jobs. The grants went to ELTRA Corporation of New York for a plant expansion in Hamden; United Aluminum Corporation of North Haven; Paul H. Gesswem & Company of New York for a Bridgeport plant; Sonic Corporation of Stamford for a Stratford operation; Scharr Industries Inc. of Bloomfield, and New Security Concept Inc. of Shel

title: Cuomo and Koch Open a TV Blitz In Final Days of Runoff Campaign
description: Mario M. Cuomo and Representative Edward I. Koch, entering the second half of their campaign for next Monday's Democratic mayoral primary runoff, unveiled major new television advertising campaigns yesterday. In the commercials, Mr. Cuomo makes sharp personal attacks on Mr. Koch, while Mr. Koch, almost ignoring his opponent, stresses the endorsements he has received.

title: Busing Protests Curbed in Chicago
description: CHICAGO. Sept. 14 (UPI)The police started a gettough policy today against demonstrators at schools involved in the city's voluntary school busing program.

title: Study Says Alleged Looters Faced Harsher Than Normal Treatmeni
description: The State Division of Criminal Justice Services released new statistics yesterday showing that prosecutors and judges treated looting suspects seized during the July 1314 New York City power blackout more harshly than suspects arrested under normal circumstances.

title: PlugIn House: American Dream Homes in Saudi Desert
description: WHAT'S this? Peaked roofs, shutters and patios in the desert? Is it a mirage? No. It's the American way of life, exported to Saudi Arabia to house somoof the thousands of Americans working there for companies such as Bechtel, Aramco, Petromin, Mobil Oil and Northron.

title: Giants Waive Bobby Brooks, Sign Pietrzak
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 14In the confusion, the Giants broke up the three dots and a dash today by Placing Bobby Brooks, their starting left cornerback the last two seasons, on waivers.

title: Oskar Morgenstern Service
description: A memorial service will be held at 2:30 P.M. Saturday at 10 McCosh Hall on the Princeton University campus for Oskar Morgenstern, a pioneer in the development of mathematical economies and game theory, who died last July 26 at his home in Princeton. He was 75 years old. A request has been made that flowers be omitted and that contributions be made to either the Oskar Morgenstern Professorship at New York University, or to the Oskar Morgenstern Research Fund at Hebrew University. Jerusalem.

title: Report Says E.P.A. Failed to Establish Radiation Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Federal agency responsible for protecting the public against the hazards of radiation does not know the scope of the problem, does not have the resources to find out and for the last six years has failed to issue a single standard that is currently being enforced, the General Accounting Office has charged.

title: 2 Studies See French Economic Chaos if Left Governs
description: PARIS, Sept. 14Two recently published studies predict that if the opposition Socialists and Communists win next year's parliamentary elections, dire consequences will follow for France's economy, but these assessments have not noticeably damaged the standing of the parties in oublicovinion Dolls.

title: Mike Mansfield, the Ambassador, Doesn't Miss Senate One Bit

title: HELMUT J. KRAEMER
description: Helmut J. Kraemer, a lawyer specializing in estate law, died Sunday in New York Hospital after a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived at 75 East End Avenue.

title: North Korea in U.N. Air Group
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 14 (Reuters)North Wan has been accepted as the 141st member of the International Civil Aviation Organization, a representative of the agency said today. North Korea's civil aviation director, Kim Yo Ung, is attending the current General Assembly here orthe organization, which is affiliated with the .United Nations. North Korea does not belong to the United Nations.

title: West Germany Is Planning Modest Boost for Economy
description: BONN, Sept. 14After a difficult internal debate, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's coalition Government of Socialists and Liberals agreed tonight on a modest package of measures to spur the West German economy, including tax cuts for individuals and business that will pump an extra $5 billion into the economy.

title: Books: Tale Of a Noble Blackmailer
description: FRANCINE PROSE'S gothic Imagination and exotic style, characteristics of her earlier books, serve her well in this retelling in fictional form of the story of Mary Laveau. Part black, Mary Laveau was wellknown 19thcentury New Orlea* figure, who had second sight, performed various feats of magic, talked to spirits and healed those wounded in body and mind. She was also a power in local politics. She got things done in ways not always allowed by law.

title: Washington Business
description: WASHINGTONThe Carter Administration has come to the realization, belatedly in the view of civil rights leaders, that it has a very serious problem on its hands in the form of soaring unemployment among blacks. But the Administration clearly does not have a unified approach to attempting to solve the problem.

title: Foote, Cone Takeover Set for Albert Frank
description: Foote, Cone & Belding, with $455 million in billings, and Albert FrankGuenther Law, financial advertising specialists with $30 million in billings, made the expected announcement yesterday. They have agreed that the larger shop will acquire the smaller, which will become on of the F C & B. Communications group of agencies. Whether the deal will be for stock, cash or a bit of each was not disclosed.

title: LEFT WING IN FRANCE FAILS TO END DISCORD
description: PARIS, Sept. 14Leaders of the French Left met through the day today to try to end sharp disagreements over the program of farreaching changes that they would carry out if they come to power after parliamentary elections next spring.

description: One hundred hours to prepare for another elecbion, David Garth was saying, his eyes red and bleary from lack of sleep. It's a knockout.

description: Early Varieties (first two weeks in September):

title: Notes on People
description: One of the public delegates chosen by President Carter for the United Nations General Assembly meetings beginning Sep, 20 is Coretta Scott King, wiaow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The State Department declined to confirm Mrs. King's appointment or to give the names of her fellow delegates, but Mrs. King said she planned to begin her dutiei at the United Nations next week. This assignment is of particular interest to me because of the many years I have worked with Ambassador Andrew Young, said Mrs. King. And,, of course, it gives me an opportunity to renew acquaintances of mine in many other nations, particularly in Africa.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Atdter International Ltd., 595 Madison Avenue.

title: Mining Delegates Assail Extreme Environmentalists
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14In public, the leadership had qualified praise for the Carter Administration, but most of the talk away from the podium at the convention of the American Mining Congress reflected delegates fears that the Government is dominated by  nogrowth fanatics.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Pro Transactions

title: Royals 5, A's 2 (1st) Royals 6, A's 0 (2d)
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 14 (UPI)John Mayberry stroked three singles and knocked in two runs tonight to extend the Kansas City Royals clubrecord winning streak to 14 games with a 60, secondgame victory over the Oakland A's for a sweep of their doubleheader. Al Cowens belted a tworun homer and Tom Poquette got a tworun single to propel the Royals to a 52 victory in the first game.

title: I Can Assure You This Will Be a Beautiful Love Story
description: I HAD HAD MY FILL of the esoteric, the intellectual, the egghead and what not said Ely Landau, and it had taken Its toll on me, emotionally and financially. Allen Klein was a neighbor of mine, and he had often said to me, When you're through being artaycraftsy and you want to go commercial, come see me.

title: U. S. FOR ISRAELI TALKS WITH PANARAB GROUP; Feels Obstacles to Geneva May Fall if Begin Drops Old Objections
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Carter Administration now believes that the best way to overcome the obstacles to a Middle East peace conference would be for Israel to drop its objections and agree to negotiate at Geneva with a unified panArab delegation that could include Palestinians who accept Israel's right to exist.

title: 27 WIRETAPS STRESS FRANKFURTER'S ROLE
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14Transcripts of conversations recorded in 1927 through wiretap placed by the state police on the home telephone of Felix Frankfurter, who later became a Supreme Court Justice, disclose the depth of his involvement in the activities of the SaccoVanzetti defense committee.

title: Woman Awarded $421,240
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 14 (UPI)Mabel Benton, 57 years old, of Lincoln City, was awarded $421,240 in damages yesterday from Lederle Laboratories, New York drug manufacturer. She contended in her Circuit Court suit that treatment with the concern's drug sold as myambutol had damaged her sight.

title: Grete Stueckgold, Soprano, 82; Sang at Metropolitan, 192739
description: Grete Stueckgold, a former Metropoli. tan Opera soprano, died on Tuesday al the Geer Memorial Nursing Home in Fall Village, Conn. She was 82 years old.

title: Carter Is Criticized on Lag in Urban Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A leading public transit official, in a speech given in Chicago today, accused the Carter Administration of failing to live up to campaign promises to improve urban mass transit.

title: Intense Primary Voting Due Today In 50 Connecticut Cities and Towns
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 14Voters in 50 cities and towns in Connecticut will choose tomorrow from a huge field of candidates seeking to run for mayor, tax collector, constable and other municipal officesin contests in which embattled incumbents or others who have won the endorsement of their party organizations Are being challenged by contenders in those same parties.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
Beleaguered Bureaucrat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Who is Robert Bloom? Until a few days ago most people, even in the Government, would have hesitated to say. He was medium highlevel bureaucrat, one of the army of nearanonymous men and women who are the cement Man in the foundation of any Administration.

title: Policy on Pregnancy
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 14 (AP)A Federal agency has ordered the Air Force to hold up a contract with Pan American World Airways because it objects to Pan Am's policy , of prohibiting pregnant flight attendants from flying.

title: Rusk and Kissinger Unite in Defense of Canal Treaties
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 14Two former Secretaries of State appeared together on Capitol Hill today to demonstrate bipartisan support for the new Panama Canal treaties and to warn that Senate rejection of the pacts would leave the United States isolated in a hostile Western Hemisphere.

title: Official Urges Tags
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)Requiring chemical tags in explosives would speed investigators solution of bombings such as the lethal 1975 explosion at New York's LaGuardia Airport, Congress was told today.

title: Bonn Silent on Industrialist's Fate
description: BONN, Sept. 14The thief Government spokesman said today he would not make any statement at all on whether the kidnapped president of the West German employers and industry federations, warmsmartin Schlever. was still alive.

title: Nursing Homes Get Ombudsman
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 14 (AP)William Ratchford, Connecticut's Commissioner on Aging, has appointed a nursinghome ombudsman and five regional ombudsmen to investigate complaints by nursinghome patients around the state. The statewide ombudsman and the regional: officials were created on the basis of recommendations from Gov. Ella T. Grasso's Blue Ribbon Commission on Nursing Homes. The bill also requires doctors, nurses and others who work in nursing homes to report cases of abuse, neglect, exploitation or abandonment of patients.

title: JOHNWARTIN, TEST PILOT FOR EARLY JET AIRCRAFT
description: WILLOW, Calif., Sept. 14 (UPI)John F. Martin, one of the nation's top test pilots in the 1940's and 1950's, died today at his home after an illness of several months. He was 70 years old.

title: Campbell SOUD Earnings Rise to Record
description: Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Campbell Scup Company for the quarter and fiscal year ended July 31, despite higher operating costs and a loss in foreign currency translations.

title: Koch and Cuomo, in Debate, Cite What They Consider Weaknesses
description: In the first major debate between Representative Edward I. Koch and Mario M. Cuomo, New York's Secretary of State, the candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination picked at what they considered weaknesses in the other's armor.

title: American Motors Talks Progress as Deadline Nears
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 14Some progress Vfna made today in contract talks between the American Motors Corporation, the nation's fourth largest automobile manufacturer, and the United Automobile WOrkers.

title: Tight Supplies Send Cocoa Futures Prices Soaring
description: Prices of cocoa bean futures continued to soar yesterday, reflecting extreme nervousness over the immediate supply situation.

title: CONSENSUS IS SOUGHT ON XRAY SCREENING
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 14The National Institutes of Health today began an experiment in speeding up the decisionmaking process in important areas of medical policy, with the controversial and emotionally charged subject of Xray screening for breast cancer as the first Issue.

title: CARTER AIDES DRAFT SECRECY RULES SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)President Carter is proposing rules that cut four years off the normal time the Government may keep most top secrets but suggests that agencies can make employ. ees sign promises to stay silent during the secrecy period.

title: Removal of New York Motor Vehicle Chief Is Urged
description: The State Commission of Investigation called on Governor Carey yesterday to remove the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, James P. Melton, because he has been unable or unwilling to halt thefts by employees and other losses on which estimates start at $3.5 million.

title: Pipeline Authorization Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The Carter Administration urged Congress today to approve legislation that would speed construction of as many as two pipelines to transport Alaskan oil from the West Coast to the inland states.

title: Market Place
description: The Gerber Products Company, the world's largest producer of baby foods, and which has been ardently wooed since midApril by Anderson, Clayton & Company, a Houstonbased food company, soon may get a suitor more to its liking.

title: Monumental Idea! Plaster Your junk
description: WE'RE going to turn our house into a Merzbau. It's the only thing to do. We have already ordered the nlaster.

title: Home Repair Q&A
description: Q My house hasp beamed cathedral Ne ceilings, with the beams painted a deep brown color. One of these beams is right over our diningroom table and it leaks sap every summer. Is there any way to treat this beam so as to prevent this?Dr. D.D., Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: A HOSTESS IN PEKING REMEMBERS GEORGIA
description: PEKING, Sept. 10Soong Chingling, the widow of Sun Yatsen, China's first President, looks forward to the day when she may meet her fellow Georgians, President and Mrs. Carter, in Peking.

title: Family Money
description: THE couple we'll call Helen and Jim have been living together for several years now, and the biggest question they face is whether to get married or not. Helen is 67; Jim is 70.

title: ARNOLD BRECHT DIES; LONG AT NEW SCHOOL
description: Dr. Arnold Brecht, a government official in preHitler Germany who later taught for two decades at the New School for Social Research in New York, died Sunday at Eutin, West Germany, where he was vacationing. He was 93 years old.

title: Music: Philharmonic In a Wagner Evening
description: The combination of Wagner, Erich Leinsdorf and the New York Philharf monic, and a group of singers headed by Jon Vickers contributed to a full house last night in Fisher Hall. It was billed as the Gala Opening Night Concert of the Philharmonic's 197778 season, and it anticipated tonight's regular subscription concert. It also was a benefit concert for the Philharmonic, and it netted almost $45,000.

title: Black Mayor and Black Challenger to Compete in Detroit's Runoff Election in November
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14With overwhelming support from black voters, Coleman A. Young, this city's first black Mayor, handily won Ills bid yesterday in the nonpartisan primary here for a chance at a second term in office.

title: Council in Trenton, Tenn., Keeps Unusual Speed Limit of 31 M.P.M.
description: TRENTON, Tenn. (AP)The City Council decreed that the speed limit here remain 31 miles an hour despite pressure from the Tennessee Transportation Department.

title: United Press International
description: SPANISH RULER VISITS HONDURAS: King Juan Carlos waves to the people of Tegucigalpa as he walks through the streets of the Honduran capital. He and Queen Sofia are on their first tour of Latin America.

title: PBS Plea For U.S. Aid Cites Poverty
description: DURING hearings on public broadcasting by the House Communications Subcommittee last week, Chloe Aaron, vice president of programming for the Public Broadcasting Service, made a startling disclosure. On the average, in any year, she said, three out of four programs carried nationally by PBS are repeats.

title: 50,000 Pakistanis Seek Alms
description: KARACHI, Sept. 14 (Reuters)About 50,000 beggars, most of them women with children in their arms, came in trainloads to Karachi to seek alms during the Moslem holy month of Ramadan, the Englishlanguage newspaper Dawn said today.

title: United Press International
description: TRIAL IS POSTPONED: W. A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers, is helped into courthouse in Media, Pa., by his attorney Charles Puerto. Start of the second murder trial for the 76yearold union leader for allegedly ordering 1969 killing of his rival, Joseph A. Yabionski, was delayed for one day: a plea for longer delay was rejected.

title: Union Dispute Over Jobs Halts Work on Ossining Center for the Elderly
description: OSSINING, Sept. 14Work on a federally financed project here, partly intended to ease unemployment in the construction trades, has been halted for more than two months because of a dispute between rival electricians unions over jobs. The dispute has idled more than 100 A.F.L.C.I.O. affiliated construction workers who refuse to cross picket lines at the site and has prevented delivery of materials, needed for a $1 million center for the elderly.

title: Bridge:
description: Cold often engenders heat at the bridgetable especially in postmortems. If a declarer goes down in a slam and is then told by hie partner, an opponent, or, worst of all, a kibitzer, that his contract was cold, he is liable to become overheatedespecially because cold in this contest often means makable by the best line of nlay aftor houre of careful analysis.

title: Backgammon:
description: Two of backgammon's bestknown personalities, Prince Alexis Obolensky and Claude Beer, competed in the finals of the 1977 Annual Club El Morocco Tournament. Obolensky was the original driving force behind the current backeanunon explosion. Beer has long been one of the world's topranked players. Opponents have sometimes underestimated Beer, because of his disdain for mathematical computations. But Beer, a strong positional player with a fine grasp of strategy, has an impressive series of tournament triumphs to his name. Most notably, he won the 1974 World Championship. That same year, in a match pitting the top six American players against the top six of the United Kingdom, Beer made a clean sweep, 6 to 0.

title: Day Off at Newport: Toil and Praise
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14The Australians worked on their sails and the American skipper, Ted Turner, basked in the glow of a Presidential accolade today as they awaited Round 2 of the America's CUD series.

title: Powell Apologizes for Attempting To Spread Rumor Harmful to Percy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Jody Powell acknowledged today that he had tried to encourage the publication of damaging information about a senator who had raised critical questions concerning Budget Director Bert Lance. The White House press secretary said his action had been inappropriate, regrettable and dumb.

title: Ticket Sales Off at BAM: Repair Work Blamed
description: Ask a passerby near the intersection of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues these days where the Brooklyn Academy of Music is and likely as not he will point toward a huge pile of rubble and say, Down there, where all the digging is.

title: STUDENT CLASHES CLOSE SCHOOL IN CONNECTICUT
description: DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 14 (AP)City school official.; closed Danbury. High School an hour early this afternocui itfter mounting tension boiled into a series of small fights during the late morning and early afternoon.

title: 2 AIDES SAY OFFICIAL ENDED LANCE INQUIRY OVER THEIR PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A Senate committee heard testimony today in which John L. Stokes, the former United States Attorney in Atlanta, was pictured as having closed out an investigation of a bank headed by Bert Lance over the objections of his subordinates and at time when he was hoping to save his job.

title: ROLE CHANGES FOUND FOR COMPANY BOARDS
description: Corporate directors are no longer entirely who they used to be, nor are they wholly engaged in routine boardroom pursuits, according to a new study released yesterday by The Conference Board.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 23yearold Bronx man was charged ith the murder of Olin Wardlaw, the 61yearold night watchman who was :found hanged in a Bronx pet shop on Aug. 19. The suspect, Calvin Synpe, of 7525 East 143d Street, was arrested at a friend's house in West Islip,

title: CRUDE OIL IMPORTS DROP TO 5 MILLION BARRELS A DAY
description: Imports of crude oil for the week ending Sept. 9 were down sharply to 5 million barrels a day, compared with 6.7 million barrels a day in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Gas Cloud Near Trenton
description: MORRISVILLE, Pa., Sept. 14 (UPI)A reactor tank containing a potentially dangerous chlorine gas compound discharged a large white cloud of the gas at the Stauffer Chemical Company plant here last night, the police reported. Policeman and civil defense personnel here and across the Delaware River in Trenton manned cars with loud speakersAvarning residents in the area to remain in their

title: Hers
description: MY mother is not an ambitious person. She never gave a fig whether any of us came home with A's or married rich, which as things turned out was fortunate. Nor is she unduly concerned over life's little downhill runs, those situations (like the time my second cousin eloped with a walnut picker) where most people would draw back and be justifiably purselipped. Mother is sane, but not to a fault. And while she is nerfectiv aware of those areas in our lives that she hopes we will someday clean up, greatness in her view has its own gestation period and could theoretically descend in the last 10 minutes of lifewhich is one of the beauties of her outlook.

title: Design Notebook
description: ONE THINKS OF GHOSTS as empty creatures, hollow beings lacking any sort of physical substance as well as lacking life. Architectural ghosts, however, are something different: They still have ,their physical substance, or at east most of it; yet out of that substance !life has been sucked, leaving a physical shell to tell a story.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Wyszynski III With Jaundice
description: WARSAW, Sept. 14 (AP)Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Poland's Roman Catholk primate, is recovering from jaundice and is expected to leave the hospital in three weeks, his secretary said today. The cardinal was hospitalized Friday, and was feared that be had hepatitis, of which jaundice is a symptom. But his secretary, the Rev. Joseph Glent, said the suspicion proved unfounded.

title: Tank Farm Industry Informs State Federal Antipollution Rules Suffice
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14An association of New Jersey tank farm operators has accused the State Department of Environmental Protection of proposing rules and regulations that will cost the operators unnecessary expenses of $150 million to sag) million.

title: Charge in Niagara Falls
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Sept. 14  Mark Rudd is also facing a felony charge of in: connection with his arrest here on May 19, 1969.

title: SENATE UNIT DENIES POWER RATE REFORM SOUGHT BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14In a major blow to President Carter's energy program, the Senate Energy Committee tentatively agreed today to put aside a major section of the legislation dealing with utility rate overhaul.

title: Weewak Blue Amber, Terrier From Australia, Has Become a Hit on Two Continents
description: Australian Ch. Weewak Blue Amber is a winner an two continents. The impact of the top ranking champion among all terrier breeds in Tasmania for the last year and a half is clearly. evident after only two weekends and six shows on the highly, News competitive American circuits. The Australian terrier Of capped his successes and Dogs fourth birthday, Sept. 10, by taking a group's third under E. W. Tipton Jr. of Kingsport, Tenn., at Somerset Hills. This dog is reportedly the first of his breed over recent years in the metropolitan area to go from the classes to a terrier group placement. also

title: Domestic Car Sales In the First 10 Days Of Month Rise 11%
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14Domestic auto sales ran 11 percent ahead of last year's rate during the first 10day selling period of September prompting industry analysts and company spokesmen to consider it the strongest such sales period in more than two decades.

title: Ethiopians Display Captured Somali War Equipment As Evidence of an Outside Role in Fighting in Ogaden
description: DIREDAWA, Ethiopia, Sept. 14Ethiopian military leaders today displayed Somali tanks, trucks and heavy artillery pieces captured a month ago after two days of intense fighting for this city, the third largest in EthioDia.

title: U.S. Favored but British Have Hopes in Ryder Cup Golf
description: ST. ANNES, England, Sept. 14The British did not get to where they are by wishful thinking, and they are realistic enough to understand their team of 12 golf professionals from Britain and Ireland has only the thinnest chance to beat the United States in the 22d Ryder Cup matches, which begin tomorrow on a lovely seaside venue, the Royal Lytham and St. Annes Golf Club.

title: Stokowski Memorial Planned for Sunday
description: A memorial service for Leopold Stokowski, who died at his home in England on Tuesday at the age of 95, will be held at 11 A.M. on Sunday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and 51st Street. The service will include the singing of Benedicite and Pianissimo Amen, two works written by Mr. Stokowski.

title: Ballistic Missile Launched
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 14 (UPI)A Wyoming missile combat crew today successfully launched an Air Force Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missile. The launch by the crews from the 90th Strategic Missile Wing at Francis E. Warren Air Force Base was one of a series of tests to evaluate the Minuteman weapons system.

title: 2 Get Connecticut Posts
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 14 (AP)Gov. Ella T. Grasso appointed two new officials yesterday to the major state agencies that will begin the first phase of government reorganization on Oct. 1. J. William Burns, 48 years old, of West Hartford, was named undersecretary of the Office of Policy and Management, which will be the major planning department in the new government. Mr. Burns, who will earn $28,500, now works for the Transportation Department. Edmund J. Mickiewicz, 51, of East Hartford, was named deputy commissioner of the Department of Administrative Services, which will combine various administrative agencies. Also a Transportation Department official at present, Mr. Mickiewicz will earn $27,809.

title: Judge Invalidates Method of Inquiry In Welfare Cases
description: A Federal judge has ruled as invalid a ,procedure whereby New York City would stop welfare payments for dependent children whose parents refused to appear for interviews about possible welfare fraud.

title: TOP EXECUTIVES
description: Although the economy last year was none too vigorous, chief executive officers of the nation's 100 top corporations did quite well in total cash compensation salary plus bonus.

title: Film Fete to Screen 12 Oldies
description: Saved! A Retrospective of Films from American Archives is the title of the series of 12 revivals to be shown by the New York Film Festival on afternoons from Oct. 3 through Oct. at Alice Tully Hall. The films, each of which will be shown only once, are

title: Where There's Smoke Sensors
description: NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 14 (AP) A fire had little chance of success at the Edwards Company here. The company makes smoke detectors. Dozens of stockpiled detectors began blaring early yesterday when a soldering machine used to assemble them accidentally ignited small vat of oil inside the machine.. Workers at the factory got the day off.

title: Killanin Arrives in Peking
description: PEKING, Sept. 14 (UPI)Lord Killanin, the 63yearold president of the International Olympic Committee, arrived in Peking today for a week's visit to China. He was greeted by presidium of the AllChinese Athletic Association, and Sung Chung, the association's general secretary. Killanin will hold talks on a return of China to Olympics competition.

title: Too Late The Phalarope
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14Row can a people as gifted, as courageous, as profound in their emotions as the whites of South Africa have made themselves stand in the world for deafness, for inhumanity? The question torments sympathetic visitors to that wonderful, terrible country. It clouds the hope that reason can avoid racial catastrophe.

title: Moscow Book Fair Is Judged a Success as It Closes
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14Moscow's book fair ended today with expressions of satisfaction from both the Soviet organizers and foreign exhibitors.

title: Report Says E.P .A. Failed to Establish Radiation Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Federal agency responsible for protecting the public against the hazards of radiation does not know the scope of the problem, does not have the resources to find out and for the last six years has failed to issue a single standard that is currently being enforced, the General Accounting Office has chareed.

title: Letters
description: Suburban Isolation

title: Radio
description: Music

title: A Private Wine Cellar
description: With the new wine consciousness spreading from the food columns to the restaurants to the home, making your own may well be on your list in a few years. Plan ahead by planting some suitable beverage grapes. There's nothing to say you can't eat them out of hand while you're making up your mind about putting in nrivate cellar.

title: ANDERSON FOR TAX CUTS, FAVORING LOWER INCOMES
description: ALBANY, Sept. 14 (AP)The State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, today joined the growing calls for state tax cuts, but broke with a fellow Republican on how much of the cuts should eo to the wealthiest New Yorkers.

title: The New York Times/Edward Hausner
description: Clara Barton, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Luther Burbank, Louis D. Brandeis and Andrew Carnegie may not make it into the Hall of Fame for Great Americans, after all.

title: Homemade Raisins
description: American raisins are always seedless, which for the East Coast home grower usually means the white Interlaken variety. A relatively hardy (to 10 below zero) grape, the Interlaken bears at the end of August, filling the air with a heavy sweet aroma.

title: Disaster Is Declared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)President Carter declared a major disaster for the state of Missouri today because of this week's flooding.

title: VETERAN SEES REBUFF ON HIS JOB PROPOSAL
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 14 (AP)A disgruntled veteran .says his sweeping proposal to Gov. Ella T. Grasso to put collegeeducated veterans back to work has ended up as window dressing that will not change a thing.

title: U. of Texas Says It Conducted Covert Research for the C.I.A.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 14The Central Intelligence Agency awarded the engincering mechanics department of the University of Texas at Austin a covert research contract in 1961 and 1962, university officials announced today.

title: S. &
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it had lowered its rating on Kennecott Copper Corporation 77/ 8 percent debentures to BBB from A. That means the rating service now regards Kennecott as having an adequate capacity to pay principal and interest instead of a strong capacity to pay.

title: Market Place
description: If Anderson, Clayton & Company clears antitrust hurdles and goes ahead with its tender offer for the Gerber Products Company, Gerber will ask Unilever to make a bid, according to knowledgeable Wall Street sources. Page D2.

title: BELL PLANS NEW PLEA FOR KOREAN'S RETURN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that he had drafted a second letter for President Carter to send to President Park Chung Hee of South Korea requesting the return to the United States of Tongsun Park, the indicted central figure in the Korean influencebuying scandal.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC AND MILEAGE The New Russian Chamber Orchestra, an ensemble of young emigrees from the Soviet Union, are tonight's perfbrmers at 8 in a free concert of Handel, Bartok and Grieg, presented by Ars Viva at Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center. (Rain date: Monday.)

title: Norton Scores Knockout
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 14 (AP)Ken Norton and Jimmy Young tuned up for their heavyweight bout with convincing victories tonight.

title: One More Death in South Africa
description: Steven Biko was perhaps the most impressive and influential leader among younger black South Africans, the major figure in his country's growing black consciousness movement. His death Monday night while in the custody of the police deprives South Africa of yet another moderate and responsible voice for evolutionary change. It also casts the gravest suspicion upon the South African police, who say he succumbed as a result of a weeklong hunger strike. He was the 21st black South African to die in custody in the last 18 months.

title: Stocks Gain in Light Trading
description: Stock prices bounced nigner in late trading yesterday to finish at their best levels of another lightvolume session.

title: A Way to Share
description: One other form of joint ownership is tenancy by common. Each ownerand there can be two or morehas his own share In a property and controls it outright. The share can be sold or transferred. There is no right of survivorship. The share goes to the owner's heirs, who may not necessarily be the other owners.

title: Louisville Bus Strike Ends
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 14 (UPI)Buses began rolling once again early today ending a fourday wildcat strike that had paralyzed service for nearly 60,000 commuters. The 420 members of Local 1447, Amalgamated Transit Workers, received instructions from their international president in a telegram yesterday to stop their illegal strike against the Transit Authority of River City, and the men complied by slowly returning to the main bus depot.

title: STATE SUES TO KEEP INSURANCE OF 20,000
description: The New Jersey State Insurance Department went to court yesterday to pre vent the cancellation of 20,000 autome bile insurance policies by the financially troubled Empire Mutual Insurance Com pany and its subsidiary, Allcity. The cari cellation had been ordered by the New York State Insurance Department, which is running the companies in an effort to save them from bankruptcy. !ru,

title: 2 AIDES SAY OFFICIAL ENDED LANCE INQUIRY OVER THEIR PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A Senate committee heard testimony today in which John L. Stokes, the former United States Attorney in Atlanta, was pictured as having closed out an investigation of a bank headed by Bert Lance over the objections of his subordinates and at time when he was hoping to save his job.

title: Pope Advances a Cardinal
description: ROME, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Cardinal Pericle Felici, one of the most influential in the Vatican, was named today by Po e Paul Vito a second senior post.

title: Jesse Jackson's Formula for Success
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has for some time been challenging groups of black ghetto youths to overcome the handicaps of their environment through tough determination, hard work and clean living. Although skeptics scoff at the appeal as a publicrelations gimmick, his consciousnessraising program, stressing opportunity and discouraging selfpity, has been introduced, with apparent success, in a number of city school systems. The positive response of high school students owes much to Mr. Jackson's compelling personality. Veteran educators have been fascinated by the persuasive power the combined talents of an oldfashioned preacher and tough civil rights leader.

title: Rape Victim's Father Testifies
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 14The father of two sisters abducted last February from a shopping mall in Paramus recounted on the witness stand today how his younger daughter called home after the kidnapping and how one of the alleged kidnappers took the phone and demanded a $5.000 ransom.

title: Jazz: Jill Mc Manus Is at Ease On Piano
description: THE PREVAILING influences among most jazz pianists have, for years, been such seminal sources as Art Tatum and Bud Powell, with occasional touches of Fats Waller, Erroll Garner, Earl Hines or Bill Evans showing up here and there. Jill McManus has probably absorbed some of these influences but her most direct sources are Roland Hanna_ with whom she has studied, and the late Wynton Kelly, both of them pianists with a fresh, personal approach to whatever material they might be playing.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 13, 1977 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Lobbying on Abortion Issue Intensifies as Conferees Remain Deadlocked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14One hundred red roses, symbolizing the beauty of life. 450 individually wrapped coat hangers, symbolizing the danger of illegal abortions, and 800 telegrams have been received thus far this week by Representative Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

title: Albany Will Study State Aircraft Use By Carey Children
description: The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance will look into whether Governor Carey is legally required to pay personal income tax on the value of flights his children made on state aircraft, James H. Tully Jr., the Tax Commissioner, said yesterday.

title: Bid by Brooklyn Jewish Hospital For Wing Likely to Be Rejected
description: At the urging of the New York State Health Commissioner who wants to eliniinate 5,000 unneeded hospital beds in New York City, the State Hospital Review and Planning Council is expected to reject an appeal today by the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn to convert a new $11million nursing home into a temporary acutecare hospital wing. The hospital offered a lastminute compromise to use the wing only while it renovated its old hospital facilities and eliminate nearly 200 beds, but the state says it will reject that plan.

title: Espinosa Bats In Run and Hurls 3Hitter as Mets Top Phils by 10

title: Watching, Watching, Watching
description: KIGOMA, Tanzania  Two years ago, four students were kidnappci from the little Gombe Stream research station on the shores of Lake Tanganyika here in Tanzania. They were taken over the lake, in the middle of the night, to rugged Zaire, opposite. The nightmare of the two months that we waited for their release now seems nart of another world. Then, when they were safely back with their families, there was, for me, another period of anguish: Could the research into the behavior of chimpanzees, which I began in 1960, continue with the rebel group 20 miles away? I feared that Gombe might have to be closed down.

title: Film: Weak Answers To Hostage Dilemma
description: BY THE BLOOD OF OTHERS" (Par le Sang des Autres) is a 1973 French film that examines the moral questions that must be faced by anyone dealing with hostage-takingthe most agonizing of terrorist tactics because innocents are the victimsagainst which there seems to be no defense whatsoever.The film, which opened yesterday at the RKO 86th Street Twin 2 and other theaters, was directed by Marc Simenon (son of Georges) and produced by him and Mylene Demongeot, who plays a small but vivid role in the picture.The movie, set in rural France, begins with a furious, almost unbearably cruel sequence in which a young mental patient rapes and beats a woman and then takes her and her daughter hostage, demanding as their ransom the company of the most beautiful girl in the nearby village. The mayor is alerted, then the prefect, the chief of police, the doctor and the priest. How to deal with the situation? Storm the house? Find a suitably pliant prostitute? Nothing?When "By the Blood of Others" starts asking questions, the film slowly expires into a series of preconceived attitudes that ultimately have the pietyand something of the dramatic impactof a public-service clean-air commercial. Is there anyone here who'll stand up for hypocrisy? No? Then for whom is this movie intended?Given what becomes the numbing predictability of Jean Max's screenplay, Mr. Simenon obtains some decent performances, though they are all pretty much defined by how they are required to behave, not by character but by the point of the movie, which, simply put, is that anyone will compromise when his own interests are at stake.The exception to the rule in "By the Blood of Others" is the Mayor's daughter, a spunky, beautifully tanned young woman played by Mariangela Melatolong before she met Lina Wertmllerwhose bravery and love are quite spectacular and not in the least convincing.The supporting cast includes Yves Beneyton as the mental patient, a young man who looks as if he could be still another son of John Carradine; Bernard Blier as the Mayor; Charles Vanel as the old priest who drinks to forget how terrible his flock is, and Claude Pieplu as the despicably vain prefect. Miss Demongeot's role as the hooker who is brought to the scene is not especially surprising, but it is lively, and when she is removed from the scene the movie goes extremely glum.

title: Dock Union Chief Combines Hope For Pact With Warning of Strike
description: The head of the International Longshoremen's Association expressed optimism yesterday about prospects for achieving a new contract agreement in negotiations to resume today, but disclosed some of the tactics he might use if there was a strike.

title: Books of The Times
description: SCOTT TUROW'S One L Is only a sensitive, dramatically paced account of the author's first year at Harvard Law School (first law, hence One L), which, after all, is not the most universal of experiences. Why then did I read the book as if it were the most absorbing of thrillers, losing track of the time I spent with it, and resenting the hours I had to be away from it? One has to wonder: Maybe I never got over leaving the pressurecooker of school; maybe I miss the mark of excellence impressed by the grades that Mr. Turow feels so ambivalent about; maybe I secretly wish I had studied the law. Or, more plausibly, maybe it's that Mr. Turow, having been a published shortstory writer and a Fellow and Lecturer in creative writing at Stanford before he undertook his detour into the law, can be seen as a sort of hem to writers, especially those who have ever quailed before the exquisite ambiguities of the law, not to mention its cumbersome language. Maybe Mr. Throw will outshoot legalese.

title: Artists in School For 10 Downtown
description: IT MAY VERY WELL BE the case that the most beautiful exhibition galleries in New York City are those at P.S.1., the reclaimed public school at 46.01 21st Street in Long Island City that has been operated since June 1976 as a workspace for artists. There is something about that brilliant marine light, those enormous windows, those still very white walls and that still pristine wooden floor that sets expectation racing. Linda Blumberg of the Institute for Art and Urban Resources, which runs P.S.L. has seen to it that while the rest of the building is still in the state of poetic dilapidation that somehow eggs artists on to do their best the exhibition galleries look as if they had just come back from the cleaners.

This objective met with approval from the members of the caucus. The President also said he would seek the help of the black caucus in formulating a national urban policy. This too met with the approval of the caucus. Nonetheless, there is reason to wonder whether the national urban policy that would be most likely to produce longterm full employment is the same urban policy that would most satisfy the caucus and its constituents.

title: Books: Remember Rationing and Rosie the Riveter?

title: Art: The Painter As Professor
description: O ONE HAS YET gauged the role of our college and university art departments in the development of American art in the last 30 or 40 years, but it has surely been one of considerable importance. For decades now, these art departments have attracted an immense number of artistsincluding some of the most original and accomplishedto their faculties, and they have been responsible for the instruction of an even greater number of art students, some of whom have themselves become artists of distinction. Yet remarkably little attention is generally given to this historical phenomenon. Perhaps the image of the artist as college professor is insufficiently romantic for us.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Screen: Bunuel at Peak in 'Archibaldo'
description: LUIS BUNUEL'S "The Criminal Life of Archibaldo de la Cruz," also sometimes called "Rehearsal for a Crime" ("Ensayo de un Crimen"), was made in Mexico in 1955 and has been seen here at screenings at the late, lamented Cinema 16 and at the Museum of Modern Art. But only yesterday did it have its commercial premiere at the Renoir Cinema, where it is that theater's evening program. Though it's 22 years late in arriving, "The Criminal Life of Archibaldo de la Cruz" is the only new movie in town about which I can say that it mustn't be missed.Buuel made some-not-so-good films after "Archibaldo" and before the classic "Viridiana" (1961), but "Archibaldo" is the film that really begins his extraordinarily productive late period in which he has given us such masterpieces as "Tristana" and "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeosie," with the possibility of another coming up, "That Obscure Object of Desire," his newest work, which will be seen at the forthcoming New York Film Festival.One might be tempted to call "Archibaldo vintage Buuel except that that would imply the film recalls a talent since lost, worn thin, run out. "Archibaldo" is Buuel in the peak form with which he has continued to dazzle us in recent years. It doesn't have the superb European actors who have given "Tristana," "Discreet Charm" and "Phantom of Liberty" their box-office chic, but it has the wit, the simplicity of style, the directness and, above all, the total command that make his later films seem virtually perfect realizations of the director's particular visions."Archibaldo," written by Buuel and Eduardo Ugarte Pages, is the breezy, irreverent tale of a would-be arch-fiend, Archibaldo de la Cruz, well-born, rich, handsome, sensitive, who is just the tiniest bit hung up as the result of a childhood trauma.When he was 5 and the impossibly spoiled only child of wealthy bourgeois parents, he was caught one day by his governess as he was dressed in his mother's corsets. The governess scolds him, mildly, but Archibaldo is not the sort of child to take correction lightly. A few minutes later, using a music box he's been told has magical powers, he wishes the governess dead. No sooner wished than accomplished. The young woman is immediately killed by a stray bullet from a revolution raging outside.The sight of the boring, but very pretty, governess lying dead on the carpet, her skirts in a tangle around her upper thighs, makes a lasting impression on the boy, who thereafter goes through life confusing love, death and sexuality. Through a series of outrageous coincidences, the objects of Archibaldo's sexual desires and sadistic impulses are dispatched by circumstances over which he has no control but for which he feels increasingly guilty.As played by Ernesto Alonso, an actor who has the charm and the wit that Fernando Rey has displayed in similar roles in more recent Buuel films, Archibaldo is a very polite, considerate and wise nut, aware of almost everything except that he is the inevitable (in Buuel's view) product of religious and sexual repression.Archibaldo is innocent of the crimes he tries to confess to the chief of police but though this film is high comedy, his innocence is not much different from that of the delinquents of Buuel's "Los Olvidados"the slum kids who commit unspeakable atrocities but feel no guilt whatsoever. Archibaldo and the slum children inhabit very different kinds of films though the social orders are equally bankrupt in both.In "Archibaldo," Buuel's mood is light-hearted, benign and extremely funny. Archibaldo's salvation eventually is brought about by an act that might be described as a surrogate murder of the beautiful young woman he loves, and whose waxen effigy he happily burns up in his pottery oven.Miroslava Stern, who was billed simply as Miroslava in American films ("The Brave Bulls"), is cool and self-possessed as the beautiful model and tour-guide who finally is responsible for bringing Archibaldo out of his fantasy world. Unbilled is the excellent child actor who plays the young Archibaldo. Eva Calvo is the brat's mother, the sort of woman who, when she's told she can't go to the theater because of the revolution, stamps her pretty little foot and whines, "It would have to be today."
