description: THIS is the novel by Philip Roth in which David Kepesh, an  intelligent professor of imaginative literature, does not turn into an enormous female breast. That will happen later in Kepesh's life, even though it happened earlier in Mr. Roth's fiction. We know, of course. More significantly, Mr. Roth knows, and if he seems undecided on how to end his new bookthere are at least three possible endings inthe last 40 pages, all, rejectedit may be because he must face the fact of that unblinking breast. It is predestination without grace.

title: Accent Is on Antic In Atlantic Avenue
description: Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn is giving itself a party this Sunday, and everyone Is invited. There will be earthy handcrafts and glittering junk at any of the nearly 400 booths at this third annual Atlantic Antic. Strollers down the 12block section of the avenue from Furman Street to Flatbush Avenue may sample everything from saba glaba to orange Popsicles. And strains of oud music and the clanking of a children's flotsainjetsam orchestra will fill the air.

title: Business Records
Airman Said to Threaten Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)Airman Michael A. Rosel, a 21yearold member of the ceremonial honor guard that greets President Carter at Andrews Air Force Base, is said to have made threats against the President and has been released from duty and is under observation at the Maryland base's hospital, the Air Force announced today. A spokesman for the base said that

title: Victims of Hay Fever Have Gloomy Outlook
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N..I., Sept. 15 (AP)Relief is still weeks away for hayfever sufferers, according to Walter Janotti of Middlesex General Hospital. Mr. Janotti, who monitors air quality for North and Central Jersey, said yesterday's pollen count, of 122 was a high for 1977.

title: Work on Rink for 1980 Olympics, Halted in Dispute, to Be Resumed
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP)Conrtruction on the 400meter speedskating rink for the 1980 Winter Olympics here, which was halted in a dispute with the state, is now expected to go ahead as scheduled.

title: The Star Wars of Baseball
description: Joseph Durso

description: Grace Glueck

title: Corporation Affairs
description: GambleSkogmo Inc: said yesterday . that the Secursties and Exchange Commission had concluded an investigation Into the company and cleared it in connection with allegations made by a for

title: Notes on People
description: Nora Kaye is returning to the Amer:can Ballet Theater, but not as a leading star this time. Miss Kaye. who was with the A. B. T. for nearly 20 years, will become associate director of the company, sharing those duties with Anthony Tudor. Miss Kaye. who joined the company in 1940, reached stardom in 1942 when she created the role of Hagar in Mr. Tudor's Pillar of Fire. In recent years she has served as an associate of her husband, Herbert Ross, director of the movies Funny Lady and the forthcoming The Turning Point, which features the American Ballet Theater.

title: TWO MAYORAL RIVALS AT ODDS ON MEANS OF CHOOSING JUDGES
description: Cuomo, in Debate, Differs With Koch on Public Inquiry on Appointees Tone of Exchange Orderly

title: Beame Gives Support to O'Dwyer But Goldin Backs Carol Bellamy
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday endorsed the New York City Council President, Paul O'Dwyer, for a second term and Comptroller Harrison Goldin endorsed Mr.

title: A Designing Man in the Theater
description: No doubt about it, Santo Loquasto is one of the most designing young men in the theater. Last season, his stage settings for David Mamet's American Buffalo and the controversial Andrei Serban, production of Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard'.earned him two Tony Award nominations. This season, he is hard at work on Golda, doing both setting and costumes for William Gibson's play about Golda Mein he has designed John Guare's new play, Landscape of the Body, which starts performances at the Public Theater on Sept. 27, and he has at least a portfoliofull of other projects in the works, including a fulllength ballet by Mikhail Barvshnikov.

title: Added Amtrak Funds to Be Sought. By Weicker to Bar Service Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Senatof Lowell Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, said today that he would urge Congress to approve $72 million in supplemental appropriations so that Amtrak, the national rail passenger service, could avoid major cuts in service scheduled to take effect Oct. 30.

title: U . N . Council Calls For Early Renewal Of Talks on Cyprus
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept.15The Security Council today adopted a resolution calling for the resumption as soon as possible of the stalemated GreeklTurkish talks on Cyprus. Prospects were considered bleak.

title: Brazil and Colombia Receive Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Reuters) The World Bank announced today loans totaling $42 million to Brazil and Colombia to develop rural areas and combat, malnutrition respectively. Brazil will get/ $17 million for rural development in its. northeastern state of Ceara. Colombia\ will receive $25 million to help improve the health and nutrition of some 1.8 million people.

title: Selection of Women's Conference Delegates Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15'A lot of ladies in this country are disturbed, drawled Clint Fuller, an aide to Senator Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina. It seems that if you didn't favor the equal rights amendment, abortion, lesbianism, or some other militant feminist position, you were out.

title: Jewish Humorist Gets Soviet Exit Approval
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Feliks KandelKamov, a Jewish humorous writer and one of the originators of the Soviet. Union's most popular cartoon film! series, was told today he would be allowed to emigrate after four years of being denied an exit visa.

title: Lawyers Take 18 Migrant Farm Workers Out of Camps Said to Be Close to Slavery
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 15Eighteen farm workers from Florida were escorted out of immigrant labor camps in western New York this week by a team of Florida lawyers who said that the migrant workers were virtual slaves to their crew leaders, who forcedthem into debt and charged 100 percent interest on food loans.

title: Pakistanis Fast Extra Day
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 15 (AP)Millions of Pakistanis fasted an extra day today after religious committees throughout the country could not sight the new moon to end the Moslem holy month of Ramadan. Religious authorities postponed until tomorrow this Moslem country's most joyful holiday.

title: Congress Votes to Accept 1978 Budget That Includes A Deficit of $61.3 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Congress today voted final approval of a $458.3 billion budget for the fiscal year 1978. The budget includes a $61.3 billion deficit.

title: Company Reports
House Votes MinimumWage Rise And Rejects a Lower Youth Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The House of Representatives approved today an increase in the minimum wage in each of the next three years and, in a tense, dramatic rollcall, defeated by one vote a proposed subminimum wage for youths.

title: Suez Canal, in Comeback, Courts Tankers
description: SUEZ, Egypt, Sept. 12The Suez Canal has made a comeback after being closed for eight years during ArabIsraeli fighting.

title: Ohinese Declare Time Is Not Ripe or Opening A.P. Bureau in Peking
description: HONG KONG,Sept. 15 (AP)Chinese officials told a visiting delegation from The Associated Press that the time was not ripe for the news cooperative to open bureau in Peking, Keith Fuller, the 4.P.s president and general manager, renorted today.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, September 16. 1977

title: July Inventory Rise Slowed to 0.6% Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The Commerce Department reported today a somewhat slower rate of growth in manufacturing and trade inventories in July, reflecting the 1 percent increase that month in retail sales.

title: Theater: Kiley Back in La Mancha
description: IT IS NO JUDGMENT upon the new Broadway season that it begins with a revival, in this case Man of La Mancha. There is nothing wrong with revivals; any healthy theater needs them, they have kept Broadway eating in thin times, and new audiences come along,. It is only these new audiences, in fact, who are qualified to decide whether the revived work is a classic or an enthusiasm that has died with its times.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Down 0.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Association of American Railroads reported to I day that freight traffic oil United States I railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14 billion tonmiles, off 0.9 percent from the yearearlier level. Both years include the Labor Day holiday. Carloadings in the same period totaled 407,045 cars, down 3.2'percent from last year. The American Trucking Association Inc.. I reported intercity truck tonnage rose 4.8 percent from a year ago.

title: GAINS ARE WIPED OUT FOR COCOA FUTURES
description: Price of the Expiring September Delivery Drops 8.25c a Pound

title: ELECTRICAN UNION BACKS RETIREMENT BY CHOICE
description: Deldgates to the convention of the United Electrical Workers took a position yesterday that opposed forced retirement because of age but supported measures that would encourage workers to choose early retirement.

title: STOCKS UP SLIGHTLY ON RATES PROSPECTS
description: Dow Rises 2.08 to 860.79 Amid Hopes of Fed Holding Interest

title: Diversity at Stony Brook Medical School
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 15Peter Pickering flunked out of college at the age of 17, did a hitch in the Marines, joined the New York City Police Department and was walking a beat in East Harlem when he finally decided to get moving. Yesterday, at almost 30 and after four and a half years of night school, he started classes as a medical student at the State Univers'. tv's School of Medicine here.

title: Film: Allegro
description: O NE of the most delightful things about Walt Disney's Fantasia is its innocence, and one of the least delightful things about Bre() Bozzetto's Allegro Non Troppo, an ungainly takeoff On Fantasia, is its absolute lack of same. The film opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie Theater.

title: U.S. Leading Britain in Ryder Cup Golf
description: ST. ANNES, England, Sept. 15The most engaging aspect of match play in golf, its unpredictability, dominated the opening day of the 22d Ryder Cup Matches today as four pairs of partners three American and one BritishIrish rallied to win or tie their matches.

title: Namath Won't Call Plays In His Opener With Rams
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15Although Joe Namath has been given the starting assignment as quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams in their opener at Atlanta Sunday, he won't have the privilege of calling plays.

title: Tighter Curb Urged On X Ray Detection Of Breast Cancers
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 15A group of experts recommended today that the controversial nationwide screening for breast cancer he continued, but with a, tightening of Federal guidelines for thel cases of women under the age of 40.

title: Restaurants
description: Mimi Sheraton

title: G.M. to Cut Prices on 78 Chevettes
description: MILFORD, Mich., Sept. 15 (AP)The General Motors Corporation is reducing the sticker price of its 1978 subcompact Chevettes by as much as $400 on the West Coast to make it more competitive with small imports.

title: WORLD BANKING CONGRESS TO BE HELD HERE OCT.14
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that the city would play host to the First Annual World Banking Congress for four days beginning Oct. 1:

title: U.S. Conducts Nuclear Test
description: YUKKA FLAT, Nev., Sept. 15 (UP1)A nuclear device with a punch of less than 20,000 tons of TNT was tested 1,250 feet below the ground today by scientists. The explosion was the sixth announced nuclear test by the United States this year.

title: South Africa Seizes 1,200 Marking Death Of a Black Leader
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 15The South African police arrested more than 1,200 black university students today as they gathered to commemorate the death in detention of Steven Biko, the country's foremost young black leader.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Thursday, Sept. IS, 1977

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Prosecutor Sworn

title: Dayan on Way to U.S. With Mideast Settlement Plan
description: JERUSALEM, Sept 15Foreign Minister Moshe DaYan left Israel today carrying proposals for a Middle East settlement that he is due to discuss in Washington. He expressed doubt that the Arabs would accept the Israeli plan but said he hoped it would serve at least as a basis for beginning negotiations.

title: ARGENTINA SETTING DENATIONALIZATION OF STATE CONCERNS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 (AP)Citing multimilliondollar losses, the Argentine Government announced today, it was divesting itself of its interest in 370 stateowned companies and 400 companies in which it holds a minority interest.

title: Men, We Aren't Going To Make It
description: NEWPORT, ILL, Sept. 15  The Cinderella hour for today's yacht race was 5:40 P.M. There would be neither victory nor defeat if Courageous failed to get to the finish line by then, and at 5:20 Ted Turner, the Courageous skipper, said to his 10 shipmates, Men, we aren't going to make it.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: VikingsCowboys Game Tops N.F.L. Openers Sunday
description: The big game in the National Football League on Sunday, the opening day of the season, .will be in Bloomington, Minn., where the Vikings take on the Dallas Cowboys. That game will be televised to every Dart of the nation by

description: John Rockwell

title: Byrne Fails to Win Endorsement Of State A .F .L.C.I.O. Convention
description: CHERRY HILL, Sept. 15The state A.F.L.C.I.O. rejected today an endorsement of Governor Byrne for a second term.

title: Reserve Report
Logue Wins New Haven Primary
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 15Mayor Frank Logue of New Haven successfully fended off a strong challenge by former Police Chief Biagio DiLieto today in one of the most hotly contested primary fights in 50 cities and towns in Connecticut.

title: South A frica Seizes 1,200 Marking Death Of a Black Leader:
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 15The South African police arrested more than 1,2001 black university students today as they gathered to commemorate the death in detention of Steven Biko, the country's foremost young black leader.

title: Rev. William J. Rogers, Chief Of Chaplains at V.A. Hospital
description: The Rev. William J. Rogers, chief of chaplains at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Administration Hospital in Montrose, N. Y., died yesterday at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N. Y. He was 48 years old and lived in Tarrytown. N. Y.

title: Lance Rebuttal: Detailed Answers To Some Questions but Not Others
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Bert Lance today began his formal rebuttal of the allegations, charges and criticisms of recent months with a 49page statement to a Senate committee in which he promised to answer to the best of his ability every charge that has been made and every question that is asked.

title: No other low tar equals Tareyton lights' taste because no other low tar has Tareyton's
Mercantile Exchange Asks Court To Bar Potato Suit by U.S. Body
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange asked a Federal court in New York yesterday to enjoin the CommotEty Futures Trading Commission from proceeding with a prosecution of the exchange connected with the 1976 potato futures scandal. The Government agency had charged the exchange with falling to enforce some of its rules and thereby making possible the largescale defaults on potato futures contracts.

title: Regents Form New York City Unit
description: The New York State Board of Regents and the State Education Commissioner, Gordon M. Amlach, who said recently that they wanted to become more involved with urban school problems formed a Regents Advisory Council yesterday to deal with New York City school issues.

title: Money Supply Falls $800 Million; Bond Prices Show Slight Changes
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply de:Greased $800 million in the latest week, lessening some of the recent pressure that has pushed shortterm interest rates higher.

title: 4 Accused of Manhattan Bankruptcy Fraud
description: A businessman, his wife and their two daughters were indicted yesterday on charges that they carried out a fraudulent scheme to remove $300,000 from two familyowned fabric companies that were going bankrupt in Manhattan.

title: The Other Manor Comes to America
description: Massenet's Manon is firmly established in the operatic repertory, and is indeed being given this fall by the New York City Opera, with one performance taking place Sunday afternoon. Puccini's Manon Lescaut is possibly less popular, but is seldom long out of the repertory of major companies. The Abbe Prevost novel that inspired these two works has even provided the basis of a 20thcentury opera, Henze's Boulevard Solitude.

title: About Real Estate
description: Step by step the laws are changing at the state and local level to legalize and facilitate the use of the city's older nonresidential buildings as apartments.

title: A Ban on Saccharin Delayed 18 Months By a Vote in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)The Senate voted today to block for 18 months a Government ban on saccharin and rejected a proposal that cancer warnings be required in advertisements of products containing the artificial sweetener.

title: New Low Fare for London Flights To Assure ReservedSeat Travel
description: The Civil Aeronantics Board put in effect yesterday an additional New YorkLondon budget air fare under which, starting at once, travelers will be able to reserve seats at $280 for a round trip.

title: Duryea Campaigns in White Plains  For Others and, Perhaps, Himself
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept, 15Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly minority leader, campaigned here today for three Republican candidates for Westchester County offlees and probably for himself.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: What Prisons Can and Cannot Do
description: The lamentable fact that the rehabilitation of criminals has not been one of the brighter accomplishments of prisons, in the United States or anywhere else, has received striking confirmation in Sweden. A recent report disclines that in a country that boasts one of the world's most progressive and humane prison systems, the rate of, recidivism is now about 70 percentthat is, seven of ten convicts return to crime after their release. Our philosophy of rehabilitation has been shipwrecked, says Sweden's chief prosecutor. Criminality will not be cured through prison rehabilitation.

title: Times Wins Softcall Title
description: The New York Times softball team clinched first place in, the Press League yesterday with: ari 1110 victory over The Daily. News at Central Park. The triumph was the 13th in 14 games for The Tithes.

title: Dance: Balanchine at the Unknown Royal Ballet
description: LONDON

title: JOHN NEVIN SAYRE, 93;  PEACEMOVEMENT LEADER
description: The rev. John Nevin Sayre, a leading spokesman for the international peace movement for the last 60 years, died Tuesday in his home in South Nyack, N.Y. He was 93 years old. As a rector in the Episcopal Church, he served at the Christ Church in Suffern, N.Y., during World* War L However, his family said, he found his richest ministry in a career devoted to the cause of world peace. He became one of the leaders in the Fellowship of Reconciliation soon after its founding in 1915 as an ecumenical and interfaith movement espousing nonviolence.

title: Striking College Teachers Given Final Effort
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Sept. 15The administration of C. W. Post Center of Long Island University today offered its striking faculty members a fiveyear contract.

title: Chronology of Events Leading Up to the Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.15Following is a chronology of major developments in the Lance affair:

title: Bess Myerson, the Drive Behind Koch's Drive
description: Early last year, when she began talking up Ed Koch for Mayor of New York City, Bess Myerson was saying this week, many people she approached agreed he would fill the office with distinction.

title: Portrait of an American Singer
description: Joy in Singing is a series of master classes, open to the public, which Winifred Cecil has been conducting in New York for 25 years. The American soprano, concerned about what she considers a decline in the art of performing song recitals (as opposed to concert appearances by operatic personalities), set out to help young Americans learn to communicate better to audiences the subtleties of the song literature.

title: Market Place
description: Wall Street observers have long deplored a stock market that puti premium values on the shares of a select group of companies while pricing the shares of hundreds of others radically lower, But in recent ,months, more than one of the elite companies have fallen out of favor. None shows its tarnish so much as Eastman Kodak.

title: Mark Rudd, a Flawed Example of the Radical Movement
description: The hullabaloo over the surfacing of Mark Rudd, as I read it, seems intended to suggest that at last the radical movements of the 1960's and 1970's are at an end.

title: Royals
description: KANSAS. CITY, Sept. 15 (UPI)Pete LaCock singled to score Willie Wilson from second base in the 11th inning tonight and give the Kansas City Royals a 76 victory over the Oakland A's in the first game of a doubleheadee.at Royals Stadiuni. The triumph extended the Royals winning streak to 15 games, the longest in the major leagues since 1960.

title: Dr. Milos Basek, Ear Specialist, 60; An Expert on Meniere's Disease
description: Dr. Milos Basek, a nationally known specialist in diseases of the ear, died Wednesday in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a short .illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 115 Paulin Boulevard, Leonia, N.J.

title: TWO MAYORAL RIVALS AT ODDS ON MEANS OF CHOOSING JUDGES;
description: Cuomo, in Debate, Differs With Koch on Public Inquiry on Appointees Tone of Exchange Orderly

title: 72 IN CONGRESS APPEALING TO OLYMPICS FOR ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Seventytwo members of Congress today urged the United States Olympic Committee to use its influence to thwart what they called an attempt to bar Israel from the 1980 Olympics in Moscow.

title: New York's Marathon Puts In New Wrinkles
description: The blue carpet will be rolled out On the Queensboro Bridge for the New York Marathon on Oct. 23.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15Mario R. Ro riguez of Camden resigned today from the State Parole Board with sharp criticism of Governor Byrne.

title: New Bogota Riots Raise Death Toll For 2 Days to 16
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 15 (UPI)Rioting in the slums of Bogota killed at least six more persons today, bringing the death toll in two days of violence and looting to 16. Thousands of troops in battle gear patrolled the city in jeeps and armored cars.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Bonn Says It Will Keep Up Contact With Business Leader's Abductors
description: BONN, Sept 15Chancellor Helmut Schmidt told the Wert German parliament today that his Government would with steadfastness and patience continue with its indirect contacts with the terrorists who kidnapped the presdent of the employers and industry federations 10 days ago.

title: Burmese President in China
description: PEKING, Sept. 16 (Reuters)President Ne Win of Burma arrived here today for an unofficial visit on his way to North Korea.

title: Notes on People
description: The Door of Good and Evil, a 12ton bronze door for St. Peter's Basilica, has been completed in time for presentation to Pope Paul VI as an Both birthday gift. The door, which cost $154,000, will be the fifth entrance to St. Peter's, the largest church in Christendom, and will be formally presented to the Pontiff on his birthday. Sept. 26. The door, the work of one of Italy's foremost artist, Luciano Minguzzi, depicts episodes of evil and good from the slaying of Abel by Cain to the Seccnd Vatican Council of 196265. Understandably delighted to join the ranks of Berninj. Michelangelo and other artists wh8 have worked on St. Peter's, Mr. Minguzzi, who is 67 years old, said I know an artist has a better chance to last when his works become a part of a famed architectural work rather than ending up in a museum.

title: Checking Overdrafts Are Same as Credit
description: The subject of overdrafts has been a major element in the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee's Investigation of the financial practices of Bert Lance, director of the office of Management and Budget. Overdrafts are not the same as overdrawn bank accounts. Many banks now offer accounts that permit depositors to write overdrafts. Such accounts, known by such trade names as Overdraft Checking, Checking Plus and Privilege Checking, give depositors a personal line of credit. The maximum credit is usually $5,000, although some banks offer maximums up to $15,000. .

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SYPFATANICER: The, Stuyvesant almost obscured the San Francisco waterfront yeiterday on her way to the Hunters Point shipyard for repairs. The 166,000ton ship, believed to by the largest vessel ever to enter the harbor,

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONOne way of making cars lighter, to cut down on gasoline consumption, is to make automotive parts of plastic coated with metal. Nathan Feldstein, president of Surface Technology Inc. of Princeton, N.J., was granted a patent this week for a method of producing electroless (chemical) plating compositions.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Along With increases in other telephone rates, phone service users in New York; State face the prospect by midOctober that the cost of a coinbox local call will rise from 10 to 20 cents. The company is also seeking other increases in pay telephone rates.

title: What Happened to Flavor? Clues Emerge as Vegetable Breeder Discusses Role
description: Anyone who wonders what has happened to the flavor of most of the vegetables we are offered these days wouldfind a clue to the mystery in the statements of Dr. John F. Kelly, chairman of the vegetable crops department at the University of Florida.

title: Soprano Led Bel Canto Revival
description: More than any singer of the period following World War H, Maria Callas dominated opera, even changing the course of the repertory.

title: Violence Edict Won't Affect Jet Strategy
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 16Once, it would not have applied to them. But the New York Jets read and digested today the strongest stand Commissioner Pete Rozelle has taken on violence in pro football.

title: Briber Is Turned Down in Bid for Reduced Sentence
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 16The attorney for an admitted briber of an undercover police lieutenant was rebuffed again today in his court fight to remove what he called the disparity between the prison term imposed last summer on his client and the suspended sentences given to two alleged underworld figures indicted with him on similar charges.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Fiday, September 16, 1977

title: Amway's Direct Sales Foster Zeal, Success and Criticism
description: The Amway Corporation is a profoundly American institution. It started out wrapping itself in the virtues of patriotism, free enterprise and positive thinking, and still lives by them.

title: Carters Arrive at Camp David
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Sept. 16 (AP)President Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, arrived here today for a: weekend stay at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of western Maryland. Because of fog and a light drizzle, the Marine Corps that felw the Carters from Washington was diverted from the mountaintop retreat to a Little League baseball field in nearby Thurmont, Md., and they were driven in a limousine from there to Camp David.

title: U. S. Industrial Output Off For First Time in 7 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)  The Government reported today that output of the nation's industry fell in August for the first time in seven months, providing more evidence that the economy is in a late summer low.

title: Gellinoll to Retire, Ending the Inquiry into His Patronage
description: Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff announced his retirement from the New York State Supreme Court yesterday in the midst of a state inquiry into his patronage appointments.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: U.N. Staff Busily Preparing for Assembly Session
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16When the 32d session of the General Assembly starts next Tuesdy, almost everyone here will be caught up in a tornado of activity. But not Melvin Silverman.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1977

title: Dow Drops 3.98 to Close at 856.81 After Early Gains
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average once again came within striking distance of its 20month low.

title: CUOMO CONTINUES USE OF COMMERCIAL
description: Howard J. Samuels, finance cnairman of the CuomoforMayor campaign, said early this morning that a decision had been taken within the campaign organization to continue using a controversial television commercial showing Edward Koch's face metamorphosing into John V.

title: Preparing Women to Be Entrepreneurs
description: WASHINGTONEarly this summer, a daylong conference was held at the New School for Social Research in New York for women interested in starting their own businesses. Five hundred attended, but 750 more had to be turned away for lack of space.

title: JUDGE REFUSES TO BLOCK SWEARINGIN OF TROOPERS
description: ALBANY, Sept. 16 (UPI)Judge James Foley of Federal District Court has refused to issue an order blocking the swearingin on Monday of 150 new state troopers.

title: Soybean and Grain Futures Mixed
description: Moving within a narrow range for the most part, grain and soybeans futures prices closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Most trading was held within a small range because of uncertain weather conditions in the growing areas.

title: Eagleton Denounces Percy As Tempers Rise in Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Senator Thomas F. Eagleton angrily denounced Senator Charles H. Percy today, accusing him of McCarthyism and of indulging in guilt by accumulation in the Senate's inquiry into the tangled affairs of Bert Lance.

title: 5 Oil Units Get Maximum Fines In Price Fixing
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 (AP)Five independent oil company were fined the maximum $50,000 each by a Federal judge today for scheming to fix the prices of $4. billion worth of gasoline.

title: Smog Invades California Resort
description: I IDYLLWILD, Calif., Sept. 16 (UPI)Smog has invaded this milehigh blue sky mountain resort 90 miles east of Los Angeles. Results of a 40day study by the Air Quality Management District disclosed yesterday that firststage smog alerts could have been called twice in the community in the San Jacinto Mountains rising above Palm Springs.

title: Solomon Conquers Rosewall In Five Sets, Earns $60,000
description: It took all of Harold Solomon's youthful agility and baseline patience to overcome Ken Rosewall's tennis wis. dom last night.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Prime Minister Vorster on South African Policy
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 16Following are excerpts from an interview today with Prime Minister John Vorster:

title: Senate Votes Pregnancy Benefits In Disability Plans for Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)The Senate voted today to require employers to include pregnancy benefits in any worker disability plans they offer.

title: Fashion Institute of Technology Is Given $250,000 Grant by State
description: The Fashion Institute of Technology announced yesterday that a grant of $250,000 had been approved by the New York State Legislature with which the New York Citybased college will develop a twoyear program to provide technical assistance to the city's apparel industry.

title: L.I. DENTIST IS ACCUSED OF FONDLING A PATIENT
description: A 54yearold male dentist in Valley Stream, L.I., was arrested this morning on a charge of fondling a 20yearold woman patient while he was treating her with a local anesthetic.

title: FRANK L. LAZARUS. 76. REALESTATE EXPERT
description: Frank L. Lazarus, former New York City Commissioner of Real Estate, died yesterday at New York Hospital of complications arising from surgery. He was 76 years old and lived at 303 East 57th Street.

title: Daniel Nagrin Birthday Fete Features the Master Dancing
description: The customary behavior for dancers who are being honored is to remain quietly on the sidelines, leaving the performing to others. Daniel Nagrin, being saluted on his 60th birthday, departed from this custom. He did two solo works and learned a part in a dance that had been created by one of his former pupils. He considered giving up dancing for the first time 15 years ago, but he obviously had shelved that thought as he performed at Marymount Manhattan Theater Thursday evening.

title: South African Denies Ever Saying Black Leader Died of Starvation
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept 16The furor over the death while in police detention of Steven Biko, South Africa's foremost young black leader, was compounded today when Justice Minister James T. Kruger said that he had never stated that Mr. Biko had starved himself to death, as reported in newspapers around the world.

title: Barbara Wheat Wed To C. T. Fisher 4th
description: Barbara Lisa Wheat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Albert Wheat of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Thomas Fisher 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fisher 3d of Grosse Pointe. Mich. Msgr. James G. Wilders of St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, where the bride had attended classes.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY. SEPTEMBER 16. 1977

title: WEICKER URGES PAYMENT OF PENN CENTRAL DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, introduced legislation today to require the Federal Government to guarantee payments owed to states and cities, including New York City, by the bankrupt Penn Central railroad.

title: A Delightful Musical Melange
description: Alvin Crow and the Pleasant Valley Boys, who are ending their first New York appearance at, the Lone Star Cafe tonight, are an altogether delightful musical mlange. That hardly means they lack personality, however, especially Mr. Crow himself. It's just that Texas embraces such a multiplicity of music (particularly if you leak over into adjacent states such as Louisiana) that anyone who offers It in its full breadth and variety has a guaranteed diversity of material.

title: KOCH, CUOMO TRADE ANGRY ACCUSATIONS
description: The campaignweary candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination shifted yesterday from confronting the issues to attacking each other, in perhaps the most bitter terms since last week's primary vote.

title: Most Major U.S. Banks Adopt 73/4% Prime Rate
description: A 7 percent prime rate became the industry norm yesterday as most of the nation's other major banks followed the increase on commercial loan charges initiated by the Chase Manhattan Bank on Tuesday.

title: Maud Esther Dilliard, 89, Wrote on History of Dutch In New York's Early Days
description: Magni Esther Dilliard, an author and expert on the early Dutch history of New York,:died Wednesday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short Innen', She was 89 years old and lived at 1Z$ Willow Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: MITCHELL, HALDEMAN SEEK SHORTER TERMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)Attorneys for John Mitchell and H. R. Haldeman today asked Federal Judge John J. Sirica to cut short their imprisonment for covering up the Watergate scandal.

title: Rain May Put Forego in Barn, Not Woodward
description: Rain yesterday and the prediction of the same for this morning may keep some of the scheduled 14 starters in the $150,000 Woodward Handicap in their barns at Belmont Park. Indeed, even Forego, favored in the morning line, may be asked to sit out this 1mile race.

title: Bhutto Is Reported Arrested Again
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Saturday, Sept. 17 (AP)Deposed Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto has been arrested again under a martial law provision, the Pakistani radio reported today.

title: TRUDEAU REVAMPS CABINET IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 16Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau revamped his Cabinet today in a move to deal with a badly faltering economy and to keep Quebec from nulling out of Canada.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: lysts. In the current jittery market atmosphere, any downward revision in company's earnings outlook seems invariably to cause the stock to drop.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Maria Callas, 53, Is Dead of Heart Attack in Paris
description: Maria Callas, the soprano whose intensely dramatic portrayals made her the most exciting opera singer of her time, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home in Paris. She was 53 years old.

title: The Leading Games on Today's College Football Schedule
description: COMMENT

title: DR. FORD BROWN, 82; TAUGHT AT ST. JOHN'S
description: Dr. Ford Keeler Brown, author, professor and tutor emeritus at St. John's College, Annapolis, Md., died of cancer early yesterday morning in his home in Annapolis. He was 82 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Article 6  No Title
description: The Now York Times/Frank C. Dougherty

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Carter Soon to Get Suggestions for Arts Head
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The quest for a replacement for Nancy Hanks, whose eight years of running the National Endowment for the Arts are coming to an end, is narrowing down to a short list of names that will soon be sent to President Carter by a special search committee.

title: Wagner Students Major in Waiting
description: Turning to a form of campus protest that has always been popular, if not effective, 2,000 parents of students at Wagner College are expected to rally this Wednesday at the college, where a faculty strike halted classes 17 days ago. Al and Anita Rosenthal, whose son, Larry, is a juniol at the college on Staten Island, were mailing out letters to more than 2,000 parents yesterday to inform them of the rally.

title: Outbreak of Heavy Fighting Is Reported in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16Heavy fighting reportedly broke out in southern Lebanon today in what was believed to be the beginning of a thrust into Palestinianheld areas by Israelibacked Lebanese Christian militiamen.

title: Catastrophic Explosion Detected In SerpentBearer
description: An explosion of catastrophic dimensions has been detected in the constellation Ophiuchus, the SerpentBearer.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
School Results
description: SOCCER

title: Taiwan Using Unofficial Diplomatic Ties to Avoid Becoming an Outcast
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanAs the number of nations that recognize Taiwan has plummeted in recent years, the Chinese Nationalists have quietly forged an unusual substitute foreign policy using unofficial diplomatic groups and relying on such nations as Israel, Saudi Arabia and South Africa.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: BASEKMilos, MD. The New York Motoheal Society notes with deep regret the death of one of its esteemed members and expresses its deepest sympathy to his wife and family.

title: Buggs, Happy as a Redskin, Ready to Make Giants Sad
description: Danny Buggs remembers what it was like last year to be a Giant and hate the Washington Redskins.

title: New Brunswick Sees a Fiscal Rebound From Nets
description: PISCATAWAY, Sept. 16Excitement is mounting in this area as the New Jersey Nets of the National Basketball Association prepaie for their season opener here Oct. 21 at the new Rutgers University Athletic Center gymnasium on the Kilmer campus.

title: George Polk, a CBS correspondent, was killed in 1948 in Greece while covering the civil war. Here, an exinvestigator tells of his suspicions of a rightwing coverup.
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.The disappearance and Murder of George Polk in Greece has fascinated the news media for almost 30 years. Mr. Polk was an aggressive correspondent who was held in high esteem by those who had worked with him in the Middle East and in Greece. His courage and his abilities as a CBS correspondent did not endear him to Greece's extreme right wing, often the target of his reports.

title: State Study on Blackout Criticizes Con Ed ControlRoom Conditions
description: The New York State Public Service Commission said yesterday that it was not surprising that the Consolidated Edison Company's system operatorsurrounded by buzzers and flashing lights but lacking any single display of thq.)tate of the overall systemfailed to recognize what was happening just beforethe blackout of July 13.

title: Robbing New York City to Pay Alcoa
description: The State Power Authority serves New York State residents by generating electricity and selling it wholesale to municipalities, coops, .ptiVate utilities and a few large industrial firms. It does not, however, serve all equally. The New York City Housing Authority, for example, is: charged 1.23 cents per kilowatt hour, while lucky upstate customers, like Alcoa and Reynolds, pay just onefifth as much.

title: Bert Lance's Day in Court
description: The trouble with Bert Lance's day in court is that, so far, it has been more like his day at the circus. That may be good enough, depending on what President Carter now intends to do.

title: Soprano Led Bel Canto Revival
description: More than any singer of the period following World War II, Maria Callas dominated opera, even changing the course of the repertory. It was because of her that the revival of 19thcentury bel canto operas started: and in a way. such famous singers as Joan Sutherland, Beverly Sills, Teresa Berganza and Marilyn Horne are her children.

title: Capital Split Over Lance Affair, With Some Critical of President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Tom Hoy slipped out of a meeting at the National Press Club to catch a few minutes of the Bert Lance hearings on television. This brings into question Carter's judgment, said Mr. Hoy, who works for a trade association, first in choosing Lance, and then in staying with him now. Carter said, Why not the best?, but he set standards that might not have been realistic.

title: Progress Reported in Bakery Strike
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 (UPI)Negotiators have reported a little progress in talks to end Britain's sevenday bakery strike. Meanwhile; independent bakers predicted that there would be almost no bread available this weekend.

title: Rep. Evans Bowing Out
description: WASHINGTON. Sept 16. (Reuters)Representative Frank Evans of Colorado said today he would not run for reelection next year. The Democrat, who has represented the state's Third District since 1965, said he wanted to spend more time with his family. He is the 11th member of the House of Representatives to announce plans to retire after Congress adjourns next year. Five senators have also said they will not run.

title: Leftists in El Salvador Kill Rector of University Near Entrance to Campus
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 16 (AP)Leftist guerrillas armed with submachine guns ambushed and killed the rector of the University of El Salvador and two other men today the oolice said.

title: Valentino Home Shop Draws Crowd
description: Valentino likes the candy to match the china, and it did Thursday afternoon at the opening of Valentino Piu, the Italian designer's home furnishings and tabletop boutique on Bonwit Teller's seventh floor. Before the opening, Valentino sent Bonwit buyers to find colorful, liquidfilled candies to make beautiful composes, as he called them.

title: Mets Finish TwoMonth Loss to Cubs
description: The skies drizzled, the Cubs sizzled and the Mets fizzled last night at Shea Stadium. Getting together before a handful of fans and a skyful of rain. the teams managed to finish the pump suspended by the blackout last July 13. with the Cubs winning, 52.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Hanoi Says It Will Return Bodies Of 22 Americans Killed in War
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Vietnam will return the newly found remains of 22 Americans killed in the Vietnam war to the United States, the official Vietnam News Agency reported today.

title: Ups and Downs With the Arts
description: There is a certain relaxed satisfaction in the public attitude toward the arts today: They're doing fine, thank you; creativity and attendance have never been greater; more people go to museums than to baseball games. The arts are indeed flourishing, regionally, nationally and internationallybut they still rest on a shaky economic base. The worldfamous Edinburgh Festival, for example, had to cancel performances in a drastically underfunded program this year, while the Edinburgh City Council handed over land needed for an opera house to hotel developers. It was no contest between art and commercialism.

title: SEOUL SAID TO BALK AT PARK QUESTIONING
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 16The Government of South Korea has taken a new, hardline attitude in the case of rongsun Park, the businessman who accused of buying influence in Washington, according to a senior South Korean official.

title: VORSTER WARNS U.S. AGAINST MEDDLING
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 16Prime Minister John Vorster warned the United States today that he would resist its blatant meddling in the internal atfairs of his nation.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: SCHMIDT DELAYS A VISIT TO DEAL WITH ABDUCTION
description: BONN, Sept. 16Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today postponed an official visit to Poland, scheduled to start Monday, saying that the kidnapping of a leading industrialist made his presence in Bonn imperative.

title: COALITION TAKES AIM AT CARTER PROPOSAL TO TAX DOMESTIC OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16A coalition of liberal Senators, consumer advocates and labor unions has taken aim at the proposed new tax on domestically produced oil, the centerpiece of the President's program.

title: Alcan Aluminium Cuts
description: Alean Aluminium has cut its expected capital expenditures for 1977 to $250 million from $360 million. The company said that the reduced estimate represented slower spending ratter than catbacks and that both figures excluded Alcan's proposed $140 million purchase from Revere Copper and Brass Inc. of Revere's reduction plant and sheet mill in Scottsboro, Ala.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Friday. September 16, 1977

title: Eagleton Denounces Percy As Tempers Rise in Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Senator Thomas F. Eagleton angrily denounced Senator Charles H. Percy today, accusing him of McCarthyism and of indulging in guilt by accumulation in the Senate's inquiry into the tangled affairs of Bert Lance.

title: Consumer Notes
description: More than 22,000 motorists in New Jersey who have automobile insurance with the Empire Mutual Insurance Company or its subsidiary, the Allcity Insurance Company, two New York state firms, can ignorefor the time beingnotices from the company that the policies will be canceled as of midnight Oct. 7, a spokesman for the New Jersey State Insurance Department said yesterday.

title: Matilda Cuomo: A Candidate's Wife Who Puts Her Family First
description: To reach the woman who may be the next First Lady of the City of New York, it is sometimes necessary to vault a brace of bicycles fallen in the driveway, scale steep concrete steps to an unassuming Cape Cod house and wade through unremitting offers of iced tea, sandwiches and other sorts of homemade sustenance because, like charity, Matilda Cuomo begins at home.

title: Excerpts From Testimony of Lance Before Senate Governmental Affairs Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following are excerpts from the televised testimony of Budget Director Bert Lance before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Wagner May Go On G.O.P. Ballot As Stein's Rival
description: The Republican Party is preparing to offer its nomination for Manhattan Borough President to Robert F. Wagner Jr.scion of one of the historic families in the Democratic Party in New York State and Mr. Wagner said yesterday that he would accept it as a fusion effort to head off Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein.

title: Janet Lawson Has the Dream Jazz Voice
description: Janet Lawson, a striking, darkhaired improvisational jazz singer who is at Beefsteak Charlie's, Fifth Avenue at 12th Street, through tonight, has the kind of voice that most jazz singers probably wish they had. It is a full, welldevelopad, remarkably pliant voice with a lower range whose dark sonorities compare favorably with the deep power of Sarah Vaughan, and .a high register in which she does not have to strain to project very fast, often complex,, lines.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times during the last week.

title: Senate Votes a Military Union Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)The Senate today passed a bill to prohibit labor unions in the United States military services. The measure was sent to the House by a 72tos rollcall vote.

title: Blair's Homer Gives Gullett 54 Triumph
description: DETROIT, Sept. 16Through the first 23 of the Yankees 27 outs tonight. it appeared likely that a $19,000 Detroit pitcher would defeat a $1,996,000 Yankee pitcher, but the $19,000 pitcher never secured the 24th out and the $1,996,000 pitcher became a 54 winner.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1977

title: Dave Anderson
description: Dave Kingnian had been in a Yankee uniform for about three hours Thursday night, and it was almost as if he did not want to take it off. His new New York teammates were changing into their street clothes for the trip to Detroit for the weekend series with the Tigers that began last night. But at his new locker Dave Kingman, once a Met and then a San Diego Padre and then a California Angel and now a Yankee in the span of only three months, suddenly was in a pennant race, and he sat in his new pinstripes with 4S on the back. If his bat helps the Yankees win the American League East, he will be worth whatever Yankees had to promise the Angels other little goodiea, as Gabe Paul, the Yankee president, described whatever ransom exists beyond the $20,000 waiver price, $7,000 salary for IS days and Randy Stein, a minor league pitcher. Carlos May apparently was one of those .goodies, the Yankees having announced last night that he had been dispatched to the. Angels in a waiver deal. And for now Dave Kingman'is a Yankee with a crash course in education baseball education.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: College Enrollments Face Sharp Decline

title: 10 FREED OF CHARGES IN VILLAGE
description: Indictments against 10 young  Men charged with killing another during a gang attack last September in Washington Square were dismissed yesterday by a judge who criticized the excessive zeal, inexperience and prejudicial behavior of the prosecutor who handled the case.

title: RIBICOFF CONFRONTS LANCE WITH REPORT OF A LOAN VIOLATION
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 16Bert Lance was confronted today with evidence that. contrary to his previous assertions, a Federal bank examiner said as early as 1971 that his personal checking account overdrafts violated banking laws limiting loans to bank officers.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)President Carter said today he would like to visit France but wants to guard against doing anything that might be interpreted as an effort to influence the elections scheduled for next spring there.

title: Community College Gets New Head
description: Dr. Joshua L. Smith, a City College dean, has been chosen to become acting president of Borough of Manhattan Community College, City University officials said yesterday.

title: Suddenly, Aussie Yacht Looks Bettei
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16Was it a moral victory? A clue to future success by the challenger? Or was today's loss by Australia to Courageous on the America's Cup course just another failure?

title: Council Presidency Rivals Give Views on Mayoralty
description: Two candidates who are competing to spend the next four years a heartbeat away from New York City's mayoralty, were asked yesterday what they would do if they were to succeed to the top municipal office.

title: Letter: On Steel Production
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Bernard S. Wolf, 65, Radiologist and Professor At Mount Sinai School
description: Dr. Bernard S. Wolf, Distinguished Service Professor tnd chairman of the radiology department of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died yesterday after a brief illness at Mount Sinai Hospital, where he was also director of the radiology department and chief, radiologist. He was 5 years old and lived at 1215 Fifth Avenue.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TURNING COOL Jazz abounds near Columbia University. Greenwich Village and midtown no longer have a territorial monopoly on groovy sounds. A Saturday night jazzhopping tour along upper Broadway, from 108th to 113th Streets can be an eye and earopener.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Ionesco, the Joyous Pessimist
description: TOWSON, Md., Sept. 15If life is absurd for Eugene Ionesco, it is also alluring. His capacity for delightin the details of human existence struggles with his conviction of its futility; it lends depth and verve to his despair.. Ionesco's pessimism, in fact, is exuberant, and sometimes not far removed from joy.

title: A Text for Today: Book Bargains Draw a Multitude
description: To everything there is a season. This is the season for students to return in ritualistic droves, lured by a force as basic as the elements: the saving of money.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Gulf Oil CorporationWhich last month refused a request by the Federal Trade Commission to delay its 3456 million purchase of Kewanee Industries disclosed yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the F.T. C. to keep Gulf and Kewanee operations apart for four months.

title: SOYBEAN TRADERS FINED IN NONCOMPETITIVE DEALS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UPI)James E. Baggot, former floor trader on the Chicago Board of Trade, was fined $30,000 today and granted a suspended sentence on charges he violated the Commodity Exchange Act by making prearranged, noncompetitive futures trades in soybeans.

title: RIBICOFF CONFRONTS LANCE WITH REPORT OF A LOAN VIOLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Bert Lance was confronted today with evidence that, contrary to his previous assertions, a Federal bank examiner said as early as 1971 that his personal checking account overdrafts violated banking laws limiting loans to bank officers.

title: JAPAN'S TRADE SURPLUS DECLINED LAST MONTH
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Japan announced today a preliminary $465 million trade surplus for August, down more than $1 billion from the July figure. The big drop in the surplus was attributed to seasonal factors, including summer vacations, rather than to any Government action.

title: REPORT ALLEGES U.S. BUGGED CANAL TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Reports saying there had been electronic eavesdropping and blackmail during the recent Panama Canal treaty negotiations were broadcast on news programs today, and they brought immediate denials from both United States and Panamanian officials.

title: Beethoven Group Sets 10 Concerts
description: The Beethoven Society, scarcely two years old, will offer an ambitious series of 10 concerts at Hunter College this season. The opening chambermusic program will be given on Sept. 25 and will include two unusual works, the Flute Sonata in B flat, which may or may not be by Beethoven, and the Notturno in D (Op. 42) for viola and piano, adapted from a string trio. The Spring Sonata for violin and piano and the Serenade in D (Op. 2.5) for flute, violin and viola, complete the listing.

title: Boy, 11, Charged With Arson
description: An 11yearold boy was arrested yesterday and charged with setting fire to a vacant fourstory dwelling on Chester Street in the East New York section of Brooklyn, according to fire officials. The boy, whose name was not given because of his age, was accused, along with two teenagers who were previously arrested, of setting the fire on Sept. 14.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error in some editions of The Times yesterday,. the Notes on People column identified Representative William S. Cohen of Maine as a backer of Richard M. Nixon in the impeachment proceedings of the House Judiciary Committee. Mr. Cohen, a Republican, sided with the Democratic majority in support of impeachment.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Sept. 16, 1977

title: Palmer Turns Back Red Sox, 61
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 16Earl Weaver, the Oriole manager, looked around his crowded office after tonight's victory over the Red Sox and heaved one of his famous stage sighs.

title: VORSTER WARNS U.S. AGAINST MEDDLING
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 16Prime Minister John Vorster warned the United States today that he would resist its blatant meddling in the internal affairs of his nation.

title: About New York
description: Paul O'Dwyer keeps in mind the Black and Tan troubles of his Irish youth, and the gunrunning days of his Israeli sympathies, but he must also remember the palm cards for the black voting districts next Monday if he is to have a future at City Hall.

title: Breast Cancer Screening Is Urged
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 16Women over the age of 50 who are worried about the risk of breast cancer should seek screening by a combination of physical examination and Xray study, a panel of experts said today.

title: U.S. Officials Oppose Merger Plan For 3 Bank Regulatory Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Carter Administration and three highly placed Government banking officials today strongly opposed legislation designed to toughen Federal supervision of banking practices by consolidating the three regulatory agencies into a single, more powerful banking commission.

title: BRITISH LENDING RATE CUT; INFLATION SLOWS TO 16.5%
description: LONDON, Sept. 16The Bank of England cut its minimum lending rate today to 6 percent from 6 percent, its lowest level in more than five years.

title: Soviet Is Preparing to Construct 2,100Mile Siberian Oil Pipeline
description: The Soviet Union, evidently confident of the longrange oilproducing potential of west Siberia, has begun preparations for the construction of a new 2,100mile pipeline to carry crude oil from the remote fields to refineries in the industrial areas of European Russia and for export.

title: Sheep In Wolves Clothing
description: Edward Koch is a big highdomed man with a big oval face wreathed in perpetual smile wrinkles. For the purposes of this campaign he is supposed to be tough, and for this purpose he has talked a lot about capital punishment. He is for it.

title: U.S. Leads Ryder Cup Golf, 72
description: ST. ANNES, England, Sept, 16Anybody can win an Open or the Masters now and then, but how many guys can beat Jack Nicklaus and Ray Floyd in an 18hole match? An unlikely pair of British golf professionals, Nick Faldo and Peter Oosterhuis, managed to today, 2 and 1

title: Lance, Challenged, Modifies Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Under questioning that increased in intensity as the day wore on, Bert Lance today modified in at least minor ways portions of the formal statement presented to Senators yesterday, found himself drawn into an apparent conflict with the sworn statements of others and was confronted with at least two seeming contradictions in his nrevious testimony.

title: The U.N. Today
Courageous Is Victor By 1:03 for 20 Edge
description: NEWPORT, RI., Sept. 16The yacht Australia did a lot better at the AmeriWs Cup races today, but the cup defender, Courageous, still won and went ahead by 20 in the fourofseven Series. The margin was 1 minute 3 seconds.

title: Black Favoritism Charged TO Head of Police in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 16  Public Safety Commissioner A. Reginald Eaves, chief administrator of this city's Police and Fire Departments and one of the South's most powerful public officials, is under investigation by the city for allegedly ordering that answers to police promotion examinations be given to fayored black officers to insure their advancement.

title: All Around Town, a Week of. Lavish Couture Openings
description: That's the only punk dress I ever saw that looks good, Gilles Raysse remarked at the opening of the Kenzo shop at Bloomingdale's the other night.

title: Hnurilings
description: WEISSGertrude and Hyman. A monomen, to the memory of Gertrude Amp Hyman Weiss will be unveiled Sunday, Sepl. 18110 at 12;00 noon. Cedar ParjeCAT metery, Paramus, N.J. DI. 27Pl. 407.,

title: Personal Investing
description: Extremely heavy demand for taxexempt bonds has driven interest rates to the lowest level in more than three years and helped to create a vacuum that has proved profitable to investors and municipalities alike. Page 33.

title: Transit Authority Honors Student
description: A 19.yearold Dartmouth College junior who says he does not know whether I want to be a cop or a doctor was given the New York City Transit Authority's first Civilian of the Year award yesterday for being a bit of both.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court today refused to block construction of a gymnasium complex on the Kent State University's campus in Ohio near where four antiwar protesters were killed by National Guardsmen in 1970.

title: MARC BOLAN, ROCK STAR IN BRITAIN, DIES IN CRASH
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 (AP)Marc Bolan, a British rock singer who recently recovered from alcoholism and drug addiction, was killed in a car crash early today, the police reported. He was 29 years old.

title: M ixing Sounds Is an Art Form For Sandy Bull
description: Only Sandy Bull, who was at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday evening, would play an oud through an electronic phase shifter or perform on the Indian sarod a soul ballad composed by the Isley Brothers. Only Mr. Bull would perform country and western music and Brazilian bossa nova on the oud, and then turn around and sing The Tennessee Waltz with traditional guitar accompaniment.

title: Cosmos Subpoenaed in Overselling Seats for Pele's Last Game Oct.
description: The Cosmos soccer team, summoned to explain why it had sold more than the available number of seats to Pele's final game at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands Oct. 1, laid the fault yesterday to human error.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: UNREST IN BOGOTA ENDS, 2DAY CURFEW IS LIFTED
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 16 (Reuters) The Colombian Government today ended a twoday curfew in Bogota, saying order had been restored following labor riots in which at least 13 people were killed.

title: Portugal's Trade Deficit Rises
description: LISBON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Portugal's trade deficit for the first seven months of this year was more than double that for the corresponding period of 1976, the National Institute of Statistics announced today. The JanuaryJuly deficit was the equivalent of about $1.4 billion compared with about $590 million in the corresponding period last year, according to the institute.

title: The Standings.
description: Saturday. September 17, 977

title: Mrs. Long Asks for List of Loans Made by Banks to Banking Officials
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16The State Banking Commissioner, Virginia Long, said today that, obviously motivated by the controversy over the banking practices of Bert Lance, the Federal Budget Director, she had asked statechartered banks for a list of the loans and the terms given to bank officials or directors.

title: Lance, Challenged,  Modifies Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Under questioning that increased in intensity as the day wore on, Bert Lance today modified in at least minor ways portions of the formal statement presented to Senators yesterday, found himself drawn into an apparent conflict with the sworn statements of others and was confronted with at least two seeming contradictions in his previous testimony.

title: Taiwan Using Unofficial Diplomatic Ties to Avoid Becoming an Outcast
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanAs the number of nations that recognize Taiwan has plummeted in recent years, the Chinese Nationalists have quietly forged an unusual substitute foreign policy using unofficial diplomatic groups and relying on such nations as Israel, Saudi Arabia and South Africa.

title: In Memoriam
description: SAMMilton

title: Elegant Counsel to Lance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Clark McAdams Clifford, friend and confidant of Presidents, is the epitome of the Washington establishment that Jimmy Carter ran against in last year's Presidential election. Thus, it is one of the political ironies of the year that was Clark Clifford to whom Bert Lance turned in his time of trouble.

title: Edward Heath Pays Tribute To Stokowski at London Rites
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 (AP)  Conductor Leopold Stokowski was buried today at St. Marylebone Cemetery in North London after a funeral oration by the former Prime Minister Edward Heath.

title: BERT C. HANLON
description: Bert C. Hanlon, founder and president of Hanlon Auto Transport Inc., car deliverers, of Corona, Queens, died Thursday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 81 years old and lived at 8414 118th Street in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Frank Lucas, one of New York City's major Oug dealers, has admitted running a multimilliondollar drug ring while in prisbn on other charges.

title: An Ordinary Guy
description: The Democratic candidate for Mayor who fooled the prophets by winning most votes in last week's primary and has an excellent chance to win next week's isas he modestly admitsan ordinary guy. And so, he says, were his political heroes: La Guardia and Truman. They too were ordinary guysbut with exceptional talents.

title: Books of The Times
description: Sam Shepard's Rolling Thunder Logbook is a particularly interesting addition to a particularly uninteresting literary genre, the rocktourasmythicquest narrative. It is interesting primarily because the Rolling Thunder tour in. 1976 wasinterestingit was organized by Bob Dylan and featured an assortment of poets and folkies.

title: Gellinolf to Retire, Ending the Inquiry Into His Patronage
description: Justice Abraham J. Gellinoti announced his retirement from tile New York State Supreme Court :,:sterday in the midst of a state inquiry imo his patronage appointments.

title: Other Games Today
description: Home teams listed first

title: Friedgood's House Sold at L.I. Auction
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 16 (UPI)The 18room Kensington, L.I., home of Dr. Charles Friedgood, a surgeon who murdered his wife in 1975, was sold at public auction today for $82,100.

title: Metric Football Gets Its First Yardstick Today

The 6toot7inch King averaged 25.3 points and 13.2 rebounds in three seasons at the University of Tennessee and passed up his senior year to join the National Basketball Association.

title: Majestic Service Marks Farewell To Robert Lowell
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16At a service freighted with the ceremonial traditions of centuries, poets, playwrights, prose writers and publishers gathered in church here today to say farewell to Robert Lowell, the poet who died in New York last Monday at the age of 60.

title: Matilda Cuomo: A Candidate's Wife Who Puts Her Family First
description: To reach the woman who may be the next First Lady of the City of New York, it is sometimes necessary to vault a brace of bicycles fallen in the driveway, scale steep concrete steps to an unassuming Cape Cod house and wade through unremitting offers of iced tea, sandwiches and other sorts of homemade sustenance because, like charity, Matilda Cuomo begins at home.

title: $100 MILLION RISE SHOWN BY AUGUST MARGIN DEBT
description: The indebtedness of margin customers of New York Stock Exchange member firms continued to increase in August, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday, although the rise was the smallest monthly increase side November 1976. Margin debt, or the money owed to member firms by customers on stock purchased on margin, was up $100 million to $9.56 billion.

Troy, said the accounts from the Big Apple, was but one of half a dozen City Council incumbents invited to close the door softly on their way out of office. In the nation's capital, where running for office from office is the leading industry, the reports on the New York City primaries seemed last week to be the freshest evidence that the worst thing politics these days was to be a politician.

title: 18 Die in Philippines Blast
description: ZAMBOANGA CITY, the Philippines, Sept. 17 (Reuters)Eighteen rubber tappers were killed and 39 seriously injured today when their truck ran over a land mine on the south Philippines island of Basilian, the police said.

title: LETTERS
description: The press freedom/individual privacy debate is not a good guys/bad guys shootout but involves a fragile balancing of two public goods. Floyd Abrams (The Press, Privacy and the Constitution, Aug. 21) warns that in the name of privacy we risk having officials  not editors  tell us what is newsworthy and how journalists should gather news. If anything, the balance has tipped the other way. In recent years. public interest and newsworthy exceptions have all but consumed the publicdisclosure tort aspect of the right of privacy. And while many publishers, editors and reporters use discretion when considering the publication of truthful but offensive and irrelevant informal ion, commercial imperatives have encouraged others to use unfair and gratuitous items with impunity.

title: 2 Suspects Arrested in Slayings Of 4 Children in Missouri Family
description: CLIMAX SPRINGS, Mo., Sept. 17 (UPI) Two suspects, including a 14yearold juvenile who lived near the victims home, have been arrested in the shooting deaths of four children Thursday night, the authorities said today.

title: What Went Up Has Now Come Down
description: Perhaps because there are much easier ways of crossing the Atlantic, the voyage by balloon has only been tried 14 times. No one has made it, and five persons have been killed trying. The latest effort ended Tuesday when Ben Abruzzo (at left above) and Maxie Anderson of Albuquerque, N.M., were picked up by helicopter near Iceland on Tuesday, four days after leaving Massachusetts. Another effort impends: Dewey Reinhard and Steve Stephenson of Colorado Springs, Colo., are now poised for takeoff on the Maine coast.

title: SALT: The Case for Compromise
description: The fiveyear interim agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union limiting offensive strategic weapons expires on Oct. 3. Negotiations for a new agreement are stalled. The immediate obstacle is a dispute over American cruise missiles and Soviet heavy ballistic missiles. Yet lurking offstage is a more fundamental question: Have the rival strategic forces developed along such divergent paths that real limitation agreements have become both intellectually and politically impossible?

The work is being given a new production by the New York City Opera, opening Thursday, and the tall young man will sing the title role.

title: A Man's Addiction And Its Hold on Him
description: I ant a junkie: My habit was born out of youthful boredom. So many of my friends were doing it. We did it for kicks. I was so immature. Never did I think I would become addicted: I was too physically and psychologically strong. At first I tried it occasionally. Then it became more frequent. I used all the familiar excuses. I cut classes in college; left labs early in medical school and signed out to other doctors as an intern and resident. My juvenile excitement turned into an adult obsession.

title: Peter AllenFrom The Cabaret to The Limelight
description: Afew weeks ago Peter Allen played a concert in Central Park before some 8,000 wildly enthusiastic people. That's hardly earthshattering in the world of popular music, but it was a milestone in Allen's career. One year ago exactly was performing in Philadelphia for 20 people, the singer recalled the next day. Dee Anthony, my manager, was so proud last night. He said, I told you, in one year, we'll be playing for thousands, not hundreds. When he said he was taking me on, people said,  What is he doinghe's finally gone crazy. So the fact that 8,000 people turned up last night was a vindication for him, too.

title: THE
description: Five years ago, when Nodding Carter was dying, the city of Greenville got its first McDonald's hamburger stand. Until then the company had considered the Mississippi Delta too poor and unpromising a place to invest. But only last year the owner of the McDonald's franchise for the area, a handsome young Oregon native who is active in local Republican Party affairs, bought Feliciana the home Carter had built for his wife and sons in a cypress grove south of town. As ancestral homes go in the Mississippi Delta. Feliciana was hardly venerable; built in 1947. it had served just one family for something less than a generation. Yet the mark that the Carters and The Delta DemocratTimes  the newspaper that they have owned and edited there since 1936  have left on Greenville and on Mississippi generally is as indelible as it is incalculable; many people see the sale of the house as the sad symbol of the end of an era.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . canoeing on the Machias River, first phone Norris Harrington, the District Forest Ranger, for information about water conditions (2072558917). Depending on the rainfall, the river can be dangerously high in the spring and fall, or irritatingly low in the summer. (The bugs, a nuisance in spring and summer, thin out by fall.) If water conditions are right, take Route 9 to Mr. Harrington's office in Wesley (about 70 miles east of Bangor). He issues fire permits, which all campers must have, and has maps of the Machias showing rapids and campsites. title: Beauty and the Man
description: Beauty products for men started with fragrances: Colognes and aftershave lotions that, at first, had to smell masculine, fresh, bracing. But, in the last few years, men have realized that looking good is just as important as smelling good and that taking care of their hair and skin does not necessarily mean they are less than macho. First, it was the acceptance of tanning gels as a way of frankly looking good. Then came the great hair explosion, with its attendant sprays, blow dryers and the need for regular styling. Now, men are starting to accept what women have recognized for years. That moisturizers and skin care products are important for a healthy skin not just a good looking one. Michael Gibbons, vice president and general manager of Aramis Inc., a division of Estee Lauder, knows that men are buying moisturizers. In March we introduced a Moisture Care System for men in department stores, he says. Less than four weeks later those stores were sold out. Gibbons also makes the point that these products are labelled as moisturizers. Euphemisms, he says, really aren't needed any more. We feel men are sophisticated enough to know that their skin needs care. The leather look is out.

title: TEN DAYS THAT SHOOK ME UP IN RUSSIA
description: One reason that my first  and probably last visit to Russia was special is that there are a lot of Russians in my family background. Though I was not taught to speak Russian, I did, as a child, learn to sing several Russian folk songs. When there was company, my younger brotner and I used to be trot ted out to perform. He had curly red hair and blue eyes and dimples, and he sang the melody in a piping, 4yearold soprano. Everybody wanted to eat him up. I sang the harmony, a little offkey, and I was fat and I squinted and had buckteeth. I used to smack my brother on the head whenever I thought I could get away with it. title: IN BRIEF

The committee instead said it wanted to use the money for development of new energy resources . . . President Carter signed an order that puts the new epartment of Energy into operation, effective Oct. 1, and submitted to Congress the nominations of 10 topranking officials for the department, whose total budget will be $10.4 billion and will include 20,000 employees . . . A nay energy study by the United States International Trade Commission reported that world oil production will be sufficient to satisfy demand in 1985 and any price increases are likely to be moderate. The report estimated that demand for crude oil would total 69 million barrels a day by 1980 and 86 milliffn by 1915.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Episcopalians think of themselves as Catholic or Protestant or both; their clergy are priests or ministers and are called Father or Mister; they believe in seven sacraments, or two. Accommodating such diversity of opinion has been one of the Episcopal Church's claims to glory. But last week in St. Louis a meeting of dissident Episcopalians decided the church could no longer contain themor they itdeclared the rest of the church in schism, and founded a new provisional body called the Anglican Church in North America.

And on beaches that only recently were packed with escapees from a sweltering city, only a few clumps of oldtimers and an occasional housewife, freed at last from her home by the crhool bell now soak in the slanting rays of an autumn sun. Another summer season on Suffolk Counrv's beaches and resort areas is gone, but not yet forgotten.

title: Food
description: Midway down the Aegean coast of Turkey, facing its intimate enemies on the Greek island of Cos and flanked by the Pazar mountains, is the city of Bodrum, where Herodotus, the father of history, was born some 2,500 years ago. It is a deepwater port in what was andent Caria, coveted and conquered by the Phrygians, Lydians, Persians, Macedonians, Romans, Byzantines, the Knights of St. John and the Seljuk and Ottoman Turks. Today it is a village of 6,000 souls, still sheltered with breakwaters built by the ancient Greeks, where each fall we go to revisit the crusader fort that guards the harbor, to wander among the ruins of the Mausoleum of Halicarnassus (one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World), to sit alone in the 10,000seat Roman amphitheater, or just to eat ripe figs on our host's rooftop garden while sipping
