title: Of Special Interest
description: The New York Jazz Museum has delved into its film archives and come up with more than enough footage for a series devoted to various aspects of jazz. The series starts on Wednesday with a twnhour program of 15 shorts on Jazz Dance. In 1932, pianist Eubie Blake was filmed playing Pie Pie Blackbird with an orcnestra costumed in bakers hats and sitting inside a fake pie. Elmer Snowden and his band, featuring trumpeter Roy Eldridge and trombonist fickle Wells made a short that same year in Grand Central Station playing Smash Your Baggage, while a tapdance team dressed as porters took up the beat. That gives you the idea. The remainder of the series, which will run on three consecutive Wednesdays, takes a look at jazz vocalists, Cab Calloway and big bands, and blues and the gospel combined with a peek into the recording studio. (See Film)

title: They Are so Inexact That the New Policies Are Impossible to Devise
description: WASHINGTONThe national crime rate takes as many twists and turns as the DowJones Industrial Average. It may be up, down or sideways, depending on the perceptions and prejudices of both the compilers and the beholders, and almost any interpretation can be justified because the collection of crime statistics throughout the country is acknowledged to be a mess by almost everyone in law enforcement and the administration of justice. Former Attorney General Edward H. Levi stated last year that national crime data was of questionable validity, and his successor, Griffin B. Bell, now is attempting to do something about it.

In this dream. all the people who own mopeds in this count ry (somewhere in the neighborhood of a quarter of a million now; by the end of the year, maybe half a million and no end in sight ) somehow lined up at Madison Square and for reasons that were beyond me (remember, this was a dream) started to drive up Madison Avenue. title: Spain After the Thaw
description: THE health and verve of Spanish culture after 40 years of Fascism has surprised many observers of the new Spain. Now that Spain can see her own face, a cloud is lifted from the cultural scene. Instead of abstractsabout Fidel Castro or Karl MarxSpaniards can now enjoy reading about their real lives of these past 40 years and seeing films that reflect the daily events of their society. Spain is, in fact, bustling in all spheres. Catalonian architects, like the wildly original Ricardo Bofi11, creator of Walden Seven in Barcelona, are not only busy redreaming and rebuilding Spain but are also doing much of the key work in France, such as the rebuilding of Les Halles in Paris. Spanish movies are firstrate and, for the first time in centuries, Spanish is Internationally recognized as leading language of novelists and poets.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: It is always faintly alarming to see the photographs Weegee on exhibition at a museum or gallery. They were not made for exhibition but to be reproduced in tabloid newspapers, and a vintage Weegee print is usually hastily printed glossy, crumpled and dogeared from hard usage in newspaper offices and pressrooms. The current retrospective exhibition of 103 Weegee photographs the International Center of Photography. 1130 Fifth Avenue 94th Street, through Nov. 6, is largely composed of vintage prints, and it is strange to see so many refugees from the picture files matted and framed like precious Rembrandt etchings.

title: SWEPT AWAY
description: It was hurricane season in 1969, and the eastern Gulf of Mexico was a maelstrom of whitecapped seas. Hurricane Camille was coming up from the south, her voice first a moan, then a howl, and, finally, when her wind gusts hit 200 miles an hour, a highpitched scream. By any measurement, the force of this storm was the greatest on record in the Western Hemisphere. The warnings to evacuate were frantic, and nearly 75,000 people fled inland to higher ground.

title: An Old Country Village Is Proposed by LeFarite
description: WATCH out, Williamsburg! Be on your guard, Busch Gardens! Jersey City may be conjuring up some competition. Representative Joseph A. LeFante, Democrat of Hudson County, is about ready to announce a plan to get Federal help for a major, historical recreation area on the New Jersey shore of the Hudson River:

title: CHESS
description: The prevailing view among grandmasters is that the treatment of the opening in match play should stress steadiness. Whatever opening innovations they attempt are usually of a technical nature, delicate finesses to bolster what had been thought to be a flagging defense or to augment slightly a minute initiative.

title: 8 States Get Food Cost Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UFOAgriculture Department grants totaling $494,929 have been awarded to eight states to promote more direct farmtoconsumer marketing, the department announced today. Officials said the grants, the first made under a 1976 law passed to encourage efforts to shave food costs by eliminating middlemen, will be the only ones awarded for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. The states are Illinois, New York, Georgia, South Carolina, Florida, Arizona, Michigan and New

title: REPUBLICANS PRESS LANCE ABOUT ETHICS RATHER THAN LAWS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Republican members of the Senate committee investigating the financial affairs of Bert Lance threw the budget director more on the defensive today by emphasizing ethical questions rather than possible illegal activity.

title: Five Contractors Submit Bids For IND RailWelding Contract
description: Five contractors have submitted bids ranging from $1.17 million to $1.38 million for railwelding work to reduce noise on a twomile leg of the IND A line, according to New York City Transit Authority officials.

title: Women in Uniform Face Combat Role
description: BUCHLOE, West GermanyJet fighterbombers screamed through the hazy late summer skies, while helicopters skimmed above onion shaped church domes and turreted castles.

title: Unconscionable Delays Charged In Obtaining Welfare in New York
description: Getting emergency help from the New York City Department of Social Services takes an average of 25.3 days instead of the fiveday maximum set by city and state regulations, according to a report released yesterday by the Community Service Society, a civic group.

title: Anne Gilliam Is Married to Todd D. Jacobson
description: Anne Gilliam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Frank Gilliam of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Todd Durwood Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton D. Jacobson of Charlottsville, Va. The Rev. Timothy Cogan, the Episcopal Chaplain, performed the ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Twigs
description: Do you know where your children are? flashes the TV, that publicservice arbiter. I sit in the dark, with the other adults. Thinking: Are we so sure we know what the children are?

title: Cuomo Tries to Stem Split on Ethnic Lines
description: At a series of stops in predominantly Jewish sections of Brooklyn, Mario M. Cuomo pleaded yesterday that the Democratic mayoral runoff between himself and Representative Edward I. Koch not deteriorate into a confrontation of Roman Catholic versus Jew.

title: Koch Joined by Beame in Brooklyn Tour
description: On the final day before the runoff election, Representative Edward I. Koch spent most of his time touring Abe Beame Country, campaigning hard in the Borough Park and Coney Island sections of Brooklyn, which his strategists say could provide his victory margin.

title: Police in Colorado Still Out
description: PUEBLO, Colo., Sept. 18 (AP)Auxiliary policemen were called out to handle patrol and beat duties today as a weekend sick out by regular patrolmen in this southern Colorado industrial city continued. Only 4 of the 16 officers assigned to the Sunday day shift showed up for work, a supervisor said. All but 30 of the city's 190 patrolmen called in sick yesterday following a stalemate in contract negotiations between the police union and the city.

title: Bicentennial Project Concludes as a Book
description: MENDHAM, Sept. 18For about a year, the floor of Marge Dahl's living room in this small rural community eight miles southwest of Morristown was strewn with piles of sketches, maps and documents.

description: FIRST GAME

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: For the week ended Sept. 17, 1977 UTILITY BONDS Moody's Current

title: Conservation Post Is Filled
description: Terry Agriss, deputy director of New York City's Washington office, yesterday was named regional director of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, to carry out its programs in the five boroughs. The appointment was announced by Commissioner Peter A. A. Berle of the Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: 73 NIXON MOVE TO QUIT REPORTED BY EXAIDE
description: More than a year before he actually resigned as President on Aug. 8, 1974, Richard M. Nixon seriously considered doing so because of the troubles caused him and his close friends by Watergate, according to Raymond Price Jr., Mr. Nixon's chief speech writer.

title: C.I.A. Papers Cite Israelis in Attack On U.S. Navy Ship
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)Palestinian sympathizers today released three Central Intelligence Agency documents that they said showed that the Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, deliberately ordered an attack on a United States Navy ship during the 1967 Middle East war.

title: Listings of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Service Cut by Walkout At Puerto Rico Airline
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 18 (AP)Pilots and flight attendants of Puerto Rico International Airlines walked off the job today, sharply curtailing the airline's service, the airline said.

title: N.F.L. Standings
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES Giants 20, Washington 17. Houston 20, Jets 0. Atlanta 17, Los Angeles 6. Baltimore 29, Seattle 14. Chicago 30, Detroit 20. Cleveland 13, Cincinnati 3. Dallas 15, Minnesota 10 (overtime). Denver 7, St. Louis 0. Green Del 71, New Orleans 20. Miami 13, Buffalo 0. New England 71, Kansas City 17. Oakland 24, San Diego 0. Philadelphia 13, Tampa Bay 3.

title: Rains Apparently Doused Lava From Kilauea Volcano in Hawaii
description: HILO, Hawaii, Sept. 18 (UPI)Bad weather prevented scientists from checking eruption activity at Kilauea Volcano today, but officials said that heavy rains had apparently doused the lava flow that had thretened ranches.

title: No Progress Seen in Dock Talks
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 18 (AP)Negotiators reported no progress today on the key issue of job security that has stalled agreement between waterfront employrs and dockworkrs in six Atlantic Coast ports. George Dickman, president of the New York Shippers Association and the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations, told union delegates in the session that management was till working on it proposal.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Incumbent Visits Jewish Sections of Brooklyn
description: Get out the block, the shul, the sisterhood was the campaign cry yesterday as Paul O'Dwyer, the incumbent in the Democratic runoff primary for City Council President, toured the heavily Jewish section of Borough Park and Williamsburg in the last day of campaigning before the runoff.

title: Scoring and Statistics of Yesterday's N.F.L. Games
description: AT DENVER

title: Capture of Key Ethiopian Town Seems to Give Initiative to Somalis
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 18The capture of Jijiga, a strategic town at the base of the Ethiopian highlands, appears to have swung the initiative in the twomonth war in eastern Ethiopia to the Somalis.

title: WESTCHESTER TO GET NOTED NEUROSURGEON
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18Dr. Irving S. Cooper, a noted neurosurgeon who developed cryosurgery, the electronic brain Pacemaker and a host of other surgical procedures, will move his research and practice into Westchester County's new $61 million Medical Center.

title: Mets, Cubs Split
description: No matter how you slice it, the New York Mets and Chicago Cubs split the intercity honors evenly this year, dividing another doubleheader at Shea Stadium yesterday for the second day in a row and closing their season's rivalry with nine victories apiece.

title: FIDELITY MORTGAGE PACT REACHED WITH CREDITORS
description: Fidelity Mortgage Investors, a Jack sonville, Fla., real estate investment trust that filed bankruptcy under Chapter XI on Jan. 30, 1975 in New York announced over the weekend that it had reached an agreement with creditors.

title: Red Sox Set Back Orioles, 104, As Both End Ungainful Weekend
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 18The Baltimore Orioles and Boston Red Sox spent an exhausting weekend here pounding one another around the baseball field, and when it was over this evening it seemed as if all their struggle had only gone to help the Yankees.

title: TV: A Wonder Woman for '77
description: There comes a time wheneyes slipping out of focus, ears going brittlethe only consolation left is to keep repeating, this too will pass. In last week's The Betty White Show, broadcasting official was asked to comment on his network bosses reactions to a pilot for a new series He said they thought it was stupid, tasteless, insulting and suited to the mentality of an 8yearold  adding triumphantly, they love it. He could easily have been talking about The New Adventures of Wonder Woman, on CBS Fridays at 8, or The San Pedro Beach Bums, moving on to the ABC scheduled tonight at 8.

title: Virginia's Latest Blue Blood Outshines Her Candidate
description: MIDDLEBURG, Va., Sept. 18Virginia Republicans like to point out that no blue bloods are running for governor this year.

title: Rhodesia Defers Plan for Black Role
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 18 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today he had put aside his plan to reach  powersharing agreement with black moderates pending clarification of the latest United StatesBritish initiative to arranee a transfer to majority rule.

title: Saturday's College Football Scores

title: Miss Skura Plays Two of Her Own Works
description: Stephanie Skura performed two original compositions, Black Tongue and Running, on the Boesendorfer piano at 64 North Moore Street yesterday afternoon. The day was bright outside, but it was dark in the loft where Miss Skura was playing. A kitten was perched, alert and immobile, on a stepladder near the piano.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: American Is Stabbed On a Peking Street
description: PEKING, Sept. 18 (Reuters)An American friend of the film actor William Holden, who Is visiting Peking, was stabbed by a Chinese man tonight while strolling on a street near Tien An Mien Square, Mr. Holden reported.

title: Music:
description: Joao Gilberto, the Brazilian singer and guitarist who helped introduce bossa nova to North America with his hit recording of Desafinado during the early 60's, was at the Bottom Line on Friday and Saturday. It was his first New York appearance in almost to years. He did not bring a band, play electric guitar or exhort his audience to get down. He sang the songs which brought him fame in his dry, whispersoft voice, accompanying himself with lilting samba rhythms on a classical guitar. He did not say anything between numbers and he sang only in Portuguese. He did glance at the set list taped to the back of his instrument from time to time.

title: Australia Advances to Davis Cup Final by Defeating Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 (UPI)Australia moved into the final of the 1977 Davis Cup tennis competition against Italy by taking an unbeatable 31 lead over Argentina today. After winning the doubles for 21 lead, Australia clinched when Phil Dent beat Ricardo Cano in the singles, 64, 64, 63.

title: Radio
description: 7.8 A.M., WNCN. Concerto in B flat for Strings and Continuo. Vivaldi; Overture to Costantino, Rut; Reverie, Debussy; March In 13 (K. 215), Mozart; Entrance of the Guests from Tannhauser, Wagner; Trumpet Concerto, Haydn.

title: The Standings
description: Monday, September 19, 1977

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TONES AND TEAMS A new jazz crew, including a familiar face from television, bows in tonight at Storyville, the music lair at 41 East 55th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues. Brian Madden is known as a sportscaster on WNEWTV. He also happens to be an ardent saxophonist, leading his own quintet. Tonight the group will be performing from 10 P.M. to 2:30 A.M.

title: West Germany's Orderly Society Proves Vulnerable to Terrorists
description: BONN, Sept. 18Within hours after urban guerrillas kidnapped HarmsMartin Schleyer, West Germany's leading industrialist, in Cologne on Sept. 5, police officers in Bavaria set up roadblocks to catch any terrorists who might try to flee abroad.

title: Kozinski Piano Recital Honors His Teacher
description: Nadia Boulanger, the remarkable French teacher who virtually pushed American music into the 20th century with her guidance in the 20's of such composers as Aaron Copland and Virgil Thomson, was 90 years old last Friday. One small celebration in New York of that event was a piano recital In Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon by Stefan Kozinski.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: AFRICA AND MIDEAST FACING U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18The world's diplomats are gathering for Tuesday's opening of the 32d General Assembly, which seems certain to be dominated by fractious ArabIsraeli disputes and the unsettled situation in southern Africa.

title: Both Sides in Busing Fight Charge Chicago Mayor Lacks Leadership
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18As Chicago's limited voluntary school desegregation plan moves into its third week, tensions remain high on the racially troubled Southwest Side. Picketing and protests continue unabated in the Bogan Park section, a white enclave with a history of resistance to any attempts at integration.

title: Article 2  No Title
The U.N. Today
Marian Gruber Is Bride Of Walter Montgomery
description: Marian Amy Gruber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Gruber, was married yesterday at the Harmonie Club to Walter George Montgomery, son of Mrs. Charles Spiegel of Pompano Beach, Fla., and E.H. Montgomery of Avoca, N.Y. Family Court Judge Louis Otten performed the ceremony.

title: Schroeder Cards a 276, Wins Colombia Open
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 18 (Reuters)John Schroeder of the United States today won the $18,000 Colombian open golf championship by eight strokes from a compatriot, Tommy Aaron.

title: Justice Looks at Lance
description: WASHINGTONBert Lance's day in court may be behind him, but some Justice Department attorneys believe he may face many more days in a real courtroom.

title: Proxmire Thrives in His Chosen Role as Senate Maverick
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18President Carter ran into heavy opposition in Congress when he proposed eliminating water projects dear to the hearts of powerful legislators. But two years ago, Senator William Proxmire actually killed the construction of a $50 million dam in his home state, Wisconsin. on the around that it wasted taxpayers' money.

title: French Politics: Disunity Reigns
description: PARIS, Sept. 18French politics, like the Perils of Pauline, has become an unending serial of highly suspenseful incidents, with possibly drastic consequences but no conclusive answers. The big issue this week is whether the SocialistCommunist alliance, still leading in opinion polls, will break down or limp along until crucial legislative elections due next month. Either way, the existing situation diminishes the likelihood that they will eventually form a left coalition Government because suspicion and hostility between the allies have become so intense.

description: 6:00(4)Man to Woman (5)News

title: Credit Market Hopeful
description: The fixedincome securities market faces several significant hurdles this week in an atmosphere of relative optimism about the near future and pessimism about the longterm course of interest rates. Page 61.

title: Carter Aides Focus on Jobs In Shaping Policy for Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18After a faltering start, the Carter Administration is beginning to shape an urban policy based mainly on promoting the economic development of the nation's ailing big cities rather than on starting ambitious new social programs.

title: I.R.S. Charges Las Vegas Gambler Owes $9.5 Million in Back Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service nes accused Allen R. Glick, a controversial Las Vegas gambling operator and the largest borrower from the Teamster Pension Fund, of owing more than $9.5 million in back taxes and fraud penalties, recent United States Tax Court filings in Washington show.

title: United States Savings League Names Davis to Head Group
description: The United States League of Savings Associations has announced the nomination of Stuart Davis, chairman and president of Great Western Savings, Beverly Hills, Calif., to head the trade group for a oneyear term.

title: A HealthLaw Fair Dispenses Free Services
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18  Free medical tests, dental examinations and legal assistance were offered to the people of Newark yesterday at the second annual coalition Health and Law Fair staged at the Dental School of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

title: Young Asserts P.L.O. Must Be Given Role
description: BAY SHORE, L.I. Sept. 18 (AP)Andrew Young, the United States representative to the United Nations, said today that peace in the Middle East would not be achieved until the Palestine Liberation Organization was permitted to participate in formal peace negotiations.

title: Voters Appear Weary of Campaign Rhetoric
description: Shortly after 1 P. M. yesterday, Amy Adelman, who was standing at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street distributing Ed Koch For Mayor leaflets, was approached by a passerby.

title: DAYAN ARRIVES IN U.S. AND WILL OPEN TALKS WITH CARTER TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel arrived in the United States today to open a new round of Middle East diplomacy that American officials said should be decisive in determining whether there will be a Geneva peace conference this year.

title: Earle Warren Quintet Embellishes Vintage Sounds at Michael's Pub
description: Instead of the headline performers that are usually featured at Michael's Pub, the East 55th Street restaurant is offering jam sessions, a term that suggests that a variety of musicians are dropping by to sit in and toot with unpredictable results. This, however, is not actually the case. This week's lam session is being played by a set quintet led by Earle Warren, the alto saxopho nist, that is producing some of the best jazz that has been heard on the Michael's Pub bandstand.

title: Kick to Beat Redskins, 2017, Set Up by Carson's Fumble Recovery
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 18Joe Danelo, who walked in water during the offseason, kicked a 30yard field goal with 3 seconds remaining to complete what the Giants called a miracle todaya 2017 victory over the hated Washington Redskins in their National Football League opener at Giants Stadium.

title: Article 1  No Title
Percy Reports Aides to Panel Dispute Lance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois, the senior Republican on the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, said today that members of the committee's staff would present testimony in sharp conflict with that of Bert Lance.

title: OFFICER HELPS RESIDENTS ESCAPE FROM FIRE ON L.l.
description: WOODBURY, L.I., Sept. 18 (UPI)A Nassau County policeman was credited with arousing five persons living in apartments over a group of Woodbury stores that caught fire this morning, the police said.

title: 20thCentury Limited Takes Horse Show Title
description: DIX HILLS, L.I., Sept. 13Twentieth Century Limited, last year's national highpoint champion in the amateurowner fox chaser, division, captured the junior working title today at the conclusion session of the twoday Glen Head fall horse show.

title: In Memoriam
description: NIEBERGPete Beatrice, Time has not erased the precious memory of you. There will never be another you. Mom. Ike and Ed.

title: David D. Levenson, a Partner In Clothing Firm and Painter
description: David Dudley Levenson, senior partner in the clothing firm of W. Weber & Company and an amateur painter of landscapes, portraits and stilllifes, died yesterday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Westport, Conn., and in New York City.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: The E. R. A.
description: STANFORD, Calif.For anyone familiar with the history of women's suffrage, the slow progress of the Equal Rights Amendment to ratification must seem like a historical rerun. For as Carrie Chapman Catt, the 20thcentury suffrage leader, wrote, it took over half a century of agitation, with some 480 legislative campaigns and 277 party campaigns to remove the word male from the Constitution.

title: HEART VICTIM, 56, FOUND TO HAVE DIED FROM BULLET
description: A man police thought lost control of his car Saturday night because of a heart attack had actually been shot in the heart, according to a medical examiner's report.

title: FEDERAL VIOLATIONS OF WATER ACT CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Undisclosed and unprosecuted by the Environmental Protection Agency, hundreds of facilities of the Federal Government across the country are violating the antipollution requirements of the Clean Water Act.

title: George Ball Criticizes Carter Administration's Views on South Africa
description: George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State in the Johnson and Kennedy Administrations, has criticized what he called the inability of Carter Administration members to face the realities of the South African scene.

title: POLICE ARE OVERRUN NEAR SOVIET MISSION
description: About 2,000 young UkrainianAmerican demonstrators overwhelmed police lines and fought their way to within half A block of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday afternoon until their charge was stopped by a massed line of policemen.

title: Cornucopia Wins in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 18Allen Jerkens's goal in suddendeath overtime gave the Cornucopia polo team an 8.7 victory over West Hills today at Bethpage State Park in the semifinals of the Meadowbrook fivegoal tournament. The winning goal was Jerkens's fifth of the game and came after John Whittemore had scored the tying goal for Cornucopia with 10 seconds left in regulation. Peter Rizzo led the West Hills attack with four goals

title: Babcock & Wilcox: A Battle That Shook Wall St. Notions
description: The J. Ray McDermott Company's stunning victory in the threecornered fight for the Babcock & Wilcox Company has shaken the conventional wisdom on Wall Street.

title: Parachutist Tugged From Plane to Death
description: HARWINTON. Conn., Sept. 18 (AP) A parachutist fell to his death yesterday after his auxiliary chute opened accidentally while he was still aboard a plane and pulled him from the craft.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Supreme Court is to convene today to hear the first of more than 120 cases.

title: U.S.Bound Vietnam Refugees Tell Tales of Dramatic Escapes
description: MANILA, Sept. 15About 100 Vietnamese refugees will arrive at San Francisco airport Monday, the first group of refugees under President Carter's program admitting 15,000 additional Indochinese, including 7,000 who fled Vietnam by braving the South China Sea in small fishing boats.

title: Saralinda Bernstein Is Bride of Mark E. Lichtblau
description: Saralinda Bernstein and Mark E. Lichtblau were married yesterday at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J., by Rabbi Reuven Siegel. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph I. Bernstein of Tenafly, N.J. Mr. Bernstein is an English supervisor at Charles Evans Hughes High School in New York.

title: U.S. Steel Confers With Union Aides On Iron Ore Strike
description: Top officials of the United Steelworkers union and the United States Steel Corporation have met privately in recent days and discussed the sevenweek iron ore strike.

title: Aaron Congratulates Oh For Passing Homer Total
description: TOKYO, Sept. 18 (Reuters)Hank Aaron of the United States and Japan's Sadaharu Oh, baseball's two most successful sluggers, today had a warm reunion amid celebrations for Oh's carper homerun total.

title: STUDY SAYS DEREGULATION COULD RAISE GAS PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)A Congressional staff study released today said that complete deregulation of natural gas prices could add $25 billion to consumer bills by 1980.

title: 73 Record Tells of Plan by Sun Myung Moon Aides for Drive Against Nixon Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  On the evening of Dec. 29, 1973, leaders of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church in the United States gathered here to plan a drive intended to prevent an impeachment of the President they called the Archangel Nixon, according to the minutes of that meeting.

title: ISRAELIS SPECULATE ON DAYAN'S TRAVELS
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 18Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan's abrupt return to Israel last night in the midst of an overseas mission and his latenight meeting with Prime Minister Menahem Begin has fueled Israel's rumor mills.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Edward Cook, the president of C. W. Post College at Greenvale. L. I., said that tenured and senior faculty Members would not be dismissed despite their strike. He added, however, that efforts would be made to replace those who taught special and weekend courses.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: COMMUNITY SERVICE UNIT SELECTS NEW DIRECTOR
description: Ending an eightmonth search for a new leader, the Community Service Society announced yesterday that Bertram M. Beck, who has been executive director of the Henry Street Settlement since 1967, would become its general director Nov. 1.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge has never been considered suitable for inclusion in the Olympic Games, which are confined to activities requiring more physical effort than tossing cards on to a table. But Israel rates intellectual activities more highly, and recently included bridge in the Maccabiah games, which might be called a Jewish Olympics.

title: ewish Group Urges U.N. Action To Overturn Zionism Resolution
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)The Union of American Hebrew Congregations today called on President Carter and Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, to initiate action in the world body to overturn a twoyearold resolution equating Zionism with racism.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO END INTENSE CAMPAIGN; VOTERS DECIDE TODAY
description: Debating to the last, Edward I. Koch and Mario Cuomo wound up their intense 10day campaigns for the Democratic mayoral runoff primary in New York only hours before the first voters went to the polls this morning.

title: Carter Aides Focus on Jobs In Shaping Policy for Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18After a faltering start, the Carter Administration is beginning to shape an urban policy based mainly on promoting the economic development of the nation's ailing big cities rather than on starting ambitious new social programs.

title: Debbie Zlotowitz Wed
description: The marriage of Debbie Zlotowitz, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Bernard M. Zlotowitz of Fair Lawn, N.J., to Rickey Greenberg, son of Mrs. Marilyn Friedman of New York and Samuel Greenberg of Miami Beach, took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed in the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue by Rabbi Zlotowitz, who director of New JerseyWest Hudson Valley Council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

title: NEW YORK LAWYER NAMED TO REGIONAL H.E.W. POST
description: Cesar A. Perales, a 36yearold lawyer, has been chosen for the new Federal post of principal regional official in charge of the New York region of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: U.S.Bound Vietnam Refugees Tell Tales of Dramatic Escapes
description: MANILA, Sept. 15About 100 Vietnamese refugees will arrive at San Francisco airport Monday, the first group of refugees under President Carter's program admitting 15,000 additional Indochinese, including 7,000 who fled Vietnam by braving the South China Sea in small fishing boats.

title: News Summary
description: Israel's Foreign Minister arrived in Washington for a round of talks that could be decisive in determining whether there will be a Geneva conference on the Middle East by the end of this year. American officials stressed, however, that the likelihood of a breakthrough resulting from Moshe Dayan's talks with President Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance was slim at best. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Time to Vote Again
description: If you are a New York City Democrat, vote. What is called the runoff of a primary could well be conclusive, not only nominating the party's candidates for Mayor and City Council President but virtually electing them. That is not a happy circumstance. Oneparty bailiwicks are rightly going out of style, and a worthy Republican challenger for City Hall waits in the wings. But this remains an overwhelmingly Democratic city and neither Edward Koch nor Mario Cuomo is so distasteful to his party that today's winner will be abandoned in November. So what was a splendid turnout in the firstround primary election eleven days ago45 percent of the eligible Democratswould make a relatively modest mandate for the next Mayor. The city's government would benefit enormously if he is chosen by at least a majority of all votersand the country would note a frther demonstration of New York's new civic resolve. The polls are open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. Vote, and urge others to vote as well.

title: CAMBODIA AND VIETNAM IN CLASHES ON BORDER
description: BANGKOK, Thailand. Sept. 18 (Reuters) Cambodia indicated today that its troops had been in action on the border with Vietnam, and warned all enemies, near or far, big or small that it would not tolerate aggression.

title: League Leaders
description: (Based on 400 at bats.)

title: Courageous Retains America's Cup With Sweep of Australia
description: NEWPORT, R T., Sept. 18There was more action in the dockside celebration than there had been on the race course today when Courageous defeated the yacht Australia for a fourrace sweep and a 23d successful defense of the America's Cup.

title: Challenger for Council Presidency in Parade
description: State Senator Carol Bellamy wound up her campaign for the Democratic nomination for New York City Council President in the streets of Brooklyn yesterday as her campaign organization put the final touches on an Election Day operation that will use 3,000 volunteers to distribute more than two million palmcards at the polls.

title: Pandit's 2d Concert Offers Indian Ragas Moored to Midday
description: Indian ragas are associated with particular times, of day. Because most concerts take place in the evening, that means either that some ragas are heard detached from their temporal moorings (a severe dislocation if you're serious about your musical mysticism) or that evening ragas are heard disproportionately often.

title: BRITISH BREAD SHORT AGE EASES IN 8DAYOLD STRIKE
description: LONDON, Sept. 18 (UPI)  Brtain's bread shortage eased as many independent bakers went back to work today, and government arbitrators promised a new peace formula to settle the eightdayold Bakers' Union strike when mediation resumes.

title: Jones & Laughlin in Layoffs
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (AP)The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation reportedly has laid off about 30 members of its research and engineering staffs in a costcutting move. The layoffs took place last week at J. & L.'s Research and Engineering Department in Baldwin, one of five J. & L. facilities in the area.

title: Dodgers Lose, but Clinch Tie for Division Crown
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP)Atlanta tallied four runs in the seventh inning and held off Los Angeles, 98, preventing the Dodgers from wrapping up the National League West title today.

title: Man Killed and a Woman Wounded In San Francisco Chinatown Holdup
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP)A man was killed and his woman companion wounded early today when they came upon three masked gunmen who had just robbed the participants in a Chinatown mahjongg game, the police said.

title: NEW YORK CENSURED ON TAX INTAKE AGAIN
description: A report by the State Comptroller's office asserts that there are persisting shortcomings in the collection of back taxes in New York City because the Finance Department's compliance and collection division has failed to implement most of the recommendations made in a 1974 audit report.

title: Prolific and Pulsating Legacy Of Stokowski Remains on Disk
description: When Leopold Stokowski died last Tuesday, he was preparing to set off for a London recording studio to conduct Rachmaninoff's Second Symphony. Only a few weeks earlier the 95yearold maestro had completed what was to be his last disk, the Brahms Second Symphony, a performance that rang down the curtain on an extraordinary 60year recording career.

title: Kirsten Jensen Wed To Kenneth Fisher
description: Kirsten Moeller Jensen, daughter of Nina Moeller Jensen of Vejle, Denmark, was married yesterday at the Netherlands Club in New York to Kenneth K. Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Fisher of Brooklyn. State Supreme Court Justice Milton Mollen performed the ceremony.

title: Chess:
description: The 17th annual I.B.M. International Tournament in Amsterdam was won this year by Grandmaster Anthony Miles of England, who posted a 104, score in the 16player roundrobin.

title: Adopting Unadoptable Children: A Case History
description: Clarence Logan, who had been separated from his brothers for eight of his nine years, is living with them now, but he finds it hard to believe that they are togetherand he is afraid of losing his brothers again.

title: Ethiopian Leader Predicts a Long War in Ogaden
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 18Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, the head of Ethiopia's ruling military Government, said today that there could be no peace in the Ogaden region until all Somali forces had left the region. He predicted a long war to throw out the invaders.

title: De Gustibus: More on Lady Curzon's Turtle Soup
description: When mention was made here of the name Lady Curzon when used in connection with a curryflavored turtle soup, it was remarked that the most interesting thing about the lady in question was that she was Mary Leiter, the daughter of a Chicago millionaire who was married to Lord George Cur?? a viceroy of India. It was also noted that Lady Curzon soup appears on almost every important menu in Germany according to friends.

title: Sextuplets Born to Dutch Woman; All Six Reported in Good Condition
description: LEYDEN, The Netherlands, Sept. 18 (UPI)A 28yearold woman who had taken fertility drugs gave birth today to sextuplets and doctors reported all six babies were in very good condition, University Hospital spokesman said.

title: HomosexualOriented Resort Motel Is Set to Open Despite Protests
description: HILLBURN, N.Y., Sept. 18For nearly 22 years, the MotelontheMountain has been a landmark in this village 30 miles north of New York City, a basis for giving directions to visitors who can see it from major highways.

title: POLICE STUDY VIEWS LOW CONVICTION RATE
description: A federally funded study of police operations in the District of Columbia shows that fewer than 10 percent of the police officers there made more than half of the arrests that resulted in convictions.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, Sept. 18 (AP)Homeowners here and in other five cities are joining forces to keep the supersonic Concorde jetliner from landing and taking off where they live, a lawyer for one of the local groups said today.

title: NEW QUESTIONRAISED IN DEATH OF AFRICAN
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 18A newspaper editor who viewed the body of Steven Biko in a mortuary last night said today that he had observed injuries that could have occurred during a beating. He cautioned, however, that he could not be certain that the injuries had not been caused during the autopsy on the black leader's body five days ago.

title: A Brash Captain Courageous
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 18If I only had a little humility, Ted Turner once confessed in his highspeed Georgia drawl, I would be perfect.

title: DOROTHY C. FRAWLEY
description: McLEAN, Va., Sept. 18 (AP)Dorothy C. Frawley, the wife of Thomas J. Frawley, who is vice president of the Cox Broadcasting Corporation, died of cancer early today at her home. She was 49 years old.

title: Houston Policeman Testifies Against Colleagues in Chicano's Slaying
description: HUNTSVILLE Tex., Sept. 18A Houston police officer has been a major witness at the murder trial of two former fellow officers, charging them of breaking the laws they swore to uphold.

title: Proxmire Thrives in His Chosen Role as Senate Maverick
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18President Carter ran into heavy opposition in Congress when he proposed eliminating water projects dear to the hearts of powerful legislators. But two years ago, Senator William Proxmire actually killed the construction of a $50 million dam in his home state, Wisconsin, on the ground that it wasted taxpayers' money.

title: Rams' Loss Not Namath's Fault
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 18  In the quiet of the Los Angeles Rams' locker room today, Joe Namath was unwrapping the elastic bandage from his right knee when he was asked to assess his performance.

title: A Correction
description: In Michael J. Parker's letter on gun control, published Sept. 5, an editing error reversed the meaning of the sentence: There was a time when criminals preferred not to use gunsthe penalties were far less [not more] severe.

title: Public Funds for Public Watchdogs
description: In 1973 the United States Treasury issued tentative rules that banned accounting practices by which multinational corporations could hide profits in foreign subsidiaries, beyond the reach of American tax collectors. Numerous corporations testified against the proposes rules and one watchdog group,Tax Analysts and Advocates, testified in favor. Three years later, the Treasury revised the proposal and again solicited public comment. This time, more than 100 companies joined in opposition but Tax Analysts did not have the money to pay for necessary technical assistance to rebut their arguments. Shortly thereafter the Treasury adopted rules that favored the multinationals and sacrificed about $1 billion annually in tax revenues.

title: Rainfall Increases in West Africa
description: BAMAKO, Mali, Sept. 18 (Agence FrancePresse)Rains this month have brought a noticeable rise in the levels of two of West Arica's major rivers, the Senegal and the Niger, Mali's Water and Energy Resources Authority announced today.

title: Parsons Beats Pearson, Takes Delaware 500 Race
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 18 (UPI)Benny Parsons kept his Chevrolet close to the early pace, then seized the lead midway through the $126,375 Delaware 500 Grand National stock car race today and held off a late challenge by David Pearson to win by threefourths of a lap.

title: Aldrin Is Race Grand Marshal
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 18 (UPI) Edwin E. Aldrin, the former astronaut, was the grand marshal today of the 1977 Criterium of Beverly Hills, also called the Beverly Hills Bicycle Races. Mr. Aldrin, the second man to set foot on the moon, was described by sponsors of the races as a lifetime sports and physicalfitness supporter.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1977

title: REFORM DEMOCRATS BACK 6 STATE JUDGES
description: Six judges yesterday won the support of a reform Democratic caucus for nominations for the State Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx. The judges received the backing at a caucus of delegates, to tomorrow's Democratic judicial convention from Manhattan's New Democratic Coalition and the Bronx's Committee for Democratic Voters.

title: Landslide in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 18 (UPI)A landslide buried 18 people alive and destroyed part of a village north of here, the official news agency reported today.

title: Oilers Are Helped by Key Penalties
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18The nervousness showed on their faces before the game, almost like a collection of youngsters on the first day of school.

title: Books of The Times
description: ESSAYS OF E. B. WHITE. 277 pages. Harper & Row. $12.50.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions

title: Charlotte Anthony
RankinCarner Duo Captures L.P.G.A. Team Title
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 18 (UPI) Judy Rankin and JoAnne Carner won the Ladies Professional Golf Association's national team championship today when Mrs. Carney rolled in an eightfoot birdie putt on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff to turn back Betty Burfeindt and Pam Higgins.

title: Slippery
description: BOSTON, Sept. 18Watching Bert Lance perform with those Senators hour after hour, one saw why Jimmy Carter wanted him in Washington. He was smart, cool, resilientand recognizably human.

title: Playing Chicken Among the Bulls and Bears
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission wants to foster a freely competitive national marketplace. It has decreed, therefore, that as of Jan. 1, 1978, members of the New York Stock Exchange do not have to take stock sale and purchase orders to the exchange floor. They can trade stocks in their own offices, on street corners, or anywhere else. The commission hoped, by this action, to induce the various stock exchanges and securities associations to create a national electronic system which would display instantly every offer to buy and sell. The stock exchanges say their progress in setting up such a system is slow because there has been no leadership from the S.E.C. to design the system it wants.

title: The Pennant Race
description: New York (12): Home (7)Cleveland (4) Sept. 26, 27, 28, 29; Detroit (3) Oct. 1, Away (5)Boston (2) Sept. 19, 20; Toronto (3) Sept. 23, 24, 25.

title: Bill Would Curb Casino Investors
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18 (AP)Legislation to bar state officials from investing in Atlantic City casinos is sceduled to be introduced when the State Senate returns here tomorrow.

title: Bonn Receives Material Indicating Kidnapped Businessman Is Alive
description: BONN, Sept. 18West German authorities have received new evidence purporting to prove that HarmsMartin Schleyer, the industrial leader who was kidnapped 13 days ago, was still alive on the weekend, according to wellinformed sources.

title: Governor to Ask the Legislature to Help Jersey City Medical Center Meet Debts
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18Governor Byrne will ask the Legislature to pay most of the $9.5 million a year spent by the Jersey City Medical Centerthe state's largest general hospitalon treatment of the poor who have neither medical insurance nor Medicaid benefits, according to aides of the Governor.

title: Justice Department Drops Investigation Of U. S. Labor Party
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Justice Department has quietly dropped a sevenyear investigation of the United States Labor Party, a small leftwing splinter group that developed from the student protest movement of the 1960's.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Adams of Pistons Out
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP)The Detroit Pistons have lost Don Adams for at least eight weeks because of an injury, the National Basketball League club said today. The forward tore his right Achilles' tendon Friday in a pickup game.

title: Diversity of Atlantic Ave. Fair Draws Throngs to Brooklyn
description: It was diversity that brought Moselle Bohannon of Boston to Atlantic Antic III in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

title: 'Joy Reign' Makes History Live
description: "Let Joy Reign Supreme" "(Que La Fte Commence"), the second film by Bertrand Tavernier, the young French critic and film scholar who turned director with the excellent "The Clockmaker," reminds us of the special pleasures of what Hollywood used to call the "historical picture," when the historical picture was done well and wasn't just a lot of waxy-looking actors walking around in oddly cut trousers or writing with feathers instead of pens.The title is purposely ironic. "Let Joy Reign Supreme" is a witty provocative, visually dazzling re-creation of French political and social life during the crucial last years of Philippe d'Orlans, regent for the young Louis XV, who was 5 years old at the death of his great-grandfather, Louis XIV.When the old Sun King died in 1715, France had been at the peak of its power and glory. Before the end of the century, though, it would be swept by the greatest, bloodiest revolution the world had yet seen. It is the idea of Mr. Tavernier and Jean Aurenche, the veteran French filmwriter who collaborated with the director on the screenplay, that some of the factors that made the revolution inevitable were more or less locked into place by events that took place during Philippe's regency.For the benefit of those of us who may not be quite as up on French history as they are, the writers have provided us with a brief introduction that sets the scene and the time (1720-23) for the film that follows. Some references in the movie remain obscure, but mostly it is a tumultuously vivid evocation of people, place and period, with particular emphasis on three men.The first is Philippe, the regent, superbly played by Philippe Noiret, an intelligent, civilized, sophisticated man who says, when he remembers that his daughter is an abbess, "I don't get along with my son-in-law." Philippe is not an unenlightened ruler but he is limited by his fondness for epic debauchery and by his noble birth. He really cannot think of the lower orders except as abstract beings.The second is Philippe's principal foreign minster, the Abb Dubois, a cynical, ambitious, sardonic man, the son of a peasant, a churchman who has absolutely no knack for saying Mass and who schemes to be made an archbishop because the power of archbishops comes from God and need not depend on the passing fancies of any temporal rulers. It's a marvelous role that Jean Rochefort plays with great style, especially in the Abb's scenes with Philippe, the lifetime friend he faithfully attends but who can say, when the chips are down, "I hope you die a painful death."The third key figure is a Breton nationalist, the short-tempered, rugged but doomed-to-fail Marquis de Pontcallec (Jean Pierre Marielle), who has grand dreams of seceding from France to establish the Republic of Brittany. Pontcallec writes insulting letters to Philippe, negotiates for aid from the Spanish King but, when the time for rebellion arrives, find himself alone on the field."Que La Fte Commence" ("Let the Party Begin"), the film's original French title, could be the cry that begins one of Philippe's exhausting, all-night orgies, as well as one that heralds the beginning of the end of the French monarchy.As much as he delights in the interplay of power and personalities, Mr. Tavernier delights in re-creating the look and sound (soundtrack music is by Philippe himself) of the period. "Let Joy Reign Supreme" is one of the handsomest, most densely detailed color films I've seen since "Barry Lyndon."The movie, which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is so rich in referencesto everything from the boom in New World real estate and reforms in French banking procedures to the toilet habits of the aristocracythat it might send you to the library for more information. The panorama that Mr. Tavernier sets before us is alive. It's also seen through the bifocal lens of a moviemaker who, though fascinated by the closeup incident, never loses the long view. A fine film.

title: Fire Marshal and Two Aides Suspended In Kentucky Club Fire That Killed 164
description: FT. THOMAS, Ky., Sept. 18 (APThe Beverly Hills Supper Club was an electrician's nightmare and this was overlooked by the club's owners as well as local and state officials, according to a state report on the fire last May 28 that killed 164 persons.

title: Blackman's Return Is a Bleak One: Cornell Loses Game and 4 Starters
description: Bob Blackman's return to the Ivy League after six years away from the Ancient Eight came close to being a total disaster at Franklin Field in Philadelphia on Saturday night. His Cornell team lost to Penn, 177, as one might have expected. And, added to this disappointment, Cornell lost four starters for a considerable part of the season.

title: Yankees Post A 65 Triumph And Lead by 3
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18You can't get gay out on the fieldyou have to wait until you get in the clubhouse to be gay.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The Forest Hills tennis Open is closed, but an issue remains that cannot be settled by an overhead smash. It has to do with the status of Rene Richards, who entered both women's singles and doubles and reached the finals in the latter event. What was Dr. Richards, who only three years ago was ranked 13th nationally among men over 35, doing in a women's tournament?

title: Italy's Defense Chief Is Replaced After Reds Protest Nazi's Escape
description: ROME, Sept. 18Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti today demoted his Defense Minister and close personal and political friend, Vito Lattanzio, in a gesture intended to placate the leadership of the Communist Party, with which the governing Christian Democrats reached a basic agreement two months ago.

title: ACCOUNTANTS ADOPT SELFREGULATION IN REVAMPING PLAN
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 18The accounting industry, smarting from harsh criticism by Congress, has adopted a selfregulation program that includes a controversial reorganization plan for membership in its professional body, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.

title: A Game Spirit Prevails For Westchester Crafts
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y.Ready, set, go! Francis Merritt called out.

title: HAROLD GARFINKEL
description: Harold Garfinkel, vice president of sales and purchasing administration of the Swepco Tube Corporation of Clifton, N.J., died Sept. 11 at St. Vincent's Hospital of a heart attack. He was 59 years old and lived at 33 Greenwich Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Census Bureau Reports 216 Million Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 18 (AP)The population of the United States reached 216 million last January, the Government reported today in a population report.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Like a squad of recruits that cannot understand (or won't listen to) the orders of a drill instructor, the major industrial nations of the West are marching in different directions, banging into one another.

title: Bel Canto Vividly Revives Auber's Frothy Manon
description: Puccini's Manon Lescaut and Massenet's Manon are probably the only two operas in the standard repertory based on the same source that coexist on equal terms. Other versions do exist and the Bel Canto Opera, which specializes in reviving outoftheway fare in its headquarters at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church on 31st street, came up with a third operatic view of Abbe Provost's pleasureloving heroine, this one by Daniel Francois Esprit Auber and apparently never before given in this country. And a charming discovery it is.

title: HYMAN BERNSTEIN
description: Hyman Bernstein, one of the founders and for nearly 50 years president of the Roxanne Companies, manufacturers of sportswear, died Saturday of a heart attack at Long Beach Hospital in Long Beach, L.I. He was 79 years old and lived at 120 East 34th Street in Manhattan.

title: Advertising
description: We are not a directresponse agency and we broke a lot of rules, said Richard J. Lord, president of Lord, Geller, Federico.

title: Amtrak Chief to Seek Funds to Forestall Service Cuts And Ease Problem of Slashes in Improvement Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Amtrak's president, Paul H. Reistrup, is seeking from Congress an extra $45.6 million for 1978 to forestall sharp cutbacks in train service now scheduled to take effect Oct. 30. But an even more serious problem looms for the national rail passenger system: an acute shortage of funds for its reequipment and improvement program.

title: Amtrak Will Vote on $2 Million Allocation For Fire Safeguards in L.I.R.R. Tunnels
description: An allocation of almost $2 million for the installation of firefighting equipment in the tunnels of the Long Island Rail Road will be voted on today by Amtrak's board of directors after a nearly 12yearold controversy over the equipment.

title: World Bank Loans Drop After I.D.A. Uses Up Its Funds
description: Lending by the World Bank and its softloan affiliate, the International Development Association, declined slightly in real terms timing the fiscal year ending on June 30, 1977, largely because of a sharp drop in the level of commitments by the I.D.A.

title: Opera:
description: The New York City Opera's production of Turandotand most partitularly the fanciful, exotic scenery and costumes of Beni Montresorremains one of the glories of New York's presentday operatic life. The stage picture is continually appealing, with just the right blend of fantastic voluptuousness, Impressionist mystery and muted, dazzling color. And the production offers triumphant proof that you don't have to waste hundreds of thousands of dollars to achieve as opulent an effect as you could imagine.

title: OUTLOOK IS BRIGHTER FOR CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit market last week recovered its composure, and bond prices advanced moderately, as the feeling grew that the Federal Reserve would not lift shortterm interest rates any further just now. This week the fixedincome market faces half a dozen significant hurdles in an atmosphere that is more optimistic than it has been.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO END INTENSE CAMPAIGN; VOTERS DECIDE TODAY
description: Debating to the last, Edward I. Koch and Mario Cuomo wound up their intense 10day campaigns for the Democratic mayoral runoff primary in New York only hours before the first voters went to the polls this morning.

title: GEORGE W. PALMER
description: George W. Palmer, a partner in the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived in New York City.

title: African Leader to Visit China
description: PEKING, Sept. 18 (Agence FrancePrese)The President of Equatorial Guinea, Masie Nguema, is due to arrive in Peking Tuesday at the invitation of the Chinese Government, Hsihhua, the official news agency, reported today. It will be Mr. Nguema's first visit to China.

title: G.O.P. Moderates Call On Party To Prevent RightWing Takeover
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 12Leading Republican moderates called on their colleagues today to fight against a rightwing takeover of the party and to work harder to win the votes of the poor and the blacks.

title: Courageous, Giants and Yankees Win; Jets Beaten
description: Courageous defeated the yacht Australia for the fourth straight time yesterday off Newport, R.I., to successfully conclude the 23d defense of the America's Cup. Courageous, skippered by Ted Turner, won by 2 minutes 25 seconds in completing a fourrace sweep. The 126yearold New York Yacht Club trophy is considered the world's most prestigious yachting prize.

title: Gerety Calls for Catholic Unity
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Sept. 18Archbishop Peter L. Gerety, in an official statement of direction for the 1.4 million Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of Newark, yesterday called for unity.

title: Long Islanders Take to Woods to Saw Winter Fuel
description: CALVERTON. L.I., Sept. 18At this time of year the predominant sound in the woods is the music the crickets make to signal the change of seasons, but this weekend the crickets here were drowned out by the roar of chain saws.

title: EGYPTIAN WILL PRESS CARTER ON P.L.O. ROLE
description: CAIRO, Sept. 18Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt said today that he would urge President Carter to invite the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in future Middle East peace talks.

title: KSW&G Is Selected By Olympus Camera
description: The Olympus Camera Corporation, a Japanese company that has had a West Coast distributor, will be setting up its own marketing headquarters here and has selected KSW&G as its ad agency. According to the agency, which takes over Jan. 1, the total promotion budget will be $5 million, $3.5 million of it in media advertising.

title: Phone 2679800 to Learn Where You Vote Today
description: Voters who are uncertain about the address of their polling places for the Democratic runoff can call 2679800 for information from the Board of Elections.

title: Mexico: Machismo Thrives in a Matriarchy
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 18When I see a pretty girl walking toward me, I sort of block her path and say, How lovely you are, you please me,  Roberto Gomez explained shyly. Sometimes she smiles and stops to chat. Other times, she swings at me with her handbag.

title: Commodities
description: No commodity exhibits so delicate a balance between supply and demand as cocoa, and this year is no exception, muchto the profit or regrets of many futures traders.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: San Diego Voters Take a New Look at Nude Beach
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 18The voters of San Diego will decide Tuesday whether the country's first citysanctioned nude beach keeps its sanction.

title: East Seniors Sweep West
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18The East swept the West. 120, in an intersectional supersenior team tennis match today at the Greenwich Field Club. Len Hartman of New York and Sam Shore of Port Washington, L.I., were among the winners.

title: Sierra Club Aide Scores Tradeoff Of Oil Terminal for Air Cleanup
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 18 (UPI)A representative of the conservationist Sierra Club has criticized a new plan to allow construction of a terminal in Long Beach, Calif., to receive Alaskan oil in exchange for $100 million worth of air pollution cleanup.

title: Yalta Still Draws Hosts of Vacationers for Languid Velvet Season
description: YALTA, U.S.S.R.The foliage was already turning gold but the rocky beaches here were crammed with sunbathers. The lines outside the restaurants seemed impenetrable. Strollers were in perpetual motion along the seaside promenade.

title: Cost of the Olympic Games Is Worrying Los Angeles As Officials Put Site Bid Before Selection Committee
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18With only a week to go before the United States Olympic Committee selects the United States entry in bidding for the 1984 summer Olympic Games, public apprehension appears to be growing here over the economic wisdom of being host to the games.

title: PALESTINIANS CLAIM SUCCESS IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18As the fighting in southern Lebanon entered its third day today, the Palestinians said they had blunted the offensive by Israelibacked Christian forces, inflicting heavy casualties.

title: FRANCE RENEWS BID FOR PLAN TO ASSIST PROBLEM INDUSTRIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18France is making a new effort to get the industrialized nations to adopt a system of what it calls organized free trade for industries such as steel, shipbuilding, textiles and aircraft that are subject to what are known in economic terms as structural problems.

title: FEDERAL VIOLATIONS OF WATER ACT CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Undisclosed and unprosecuted by the Environmental Protection Agency, hundreds of facilities of the Federal Government across the country are violating the antipollution requirements of the Clean Water Act.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)Radioactive debris from a Chinese nuclear explosion yesterday could arrive over the Pacific coast of Alaska tomorrow night, the Energy Research and Development Administration said today.

title: Percy Reports Aides to Panel Dispute Lance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois, the senior Republican on the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, said today that members of the committee's staff would present testimony in sharp conflict with that of Bert Lance.

title: Deaths
description: ALCALAYJelena. The officers and members of the Central Sephardic Jewish Community of America and its Women's Division mourn with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and wile of our Chief Rabbi, Dr. Isaac Alcalay We offer our sincere condolences to the family.

title: Browns Survive Early Crisis and Beat Bengals, 133
description: The situation was potentially disastrous for the Cleveland Browns. On the third play of their game against the Bengals at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati, the Browns were on their 3yard line and Brian Sipe backed into the end zone to pass.

title: A Party for Warhol's Folk and Funk
description: A throng of ceatively dressed New Yorkers turned cut last night to view Andy Warhol's latest artistic achievement. A collection of Pop Art? No. An underground movie? No. Well, what then?

title: 5 City Operas to Be Done Live on WNCN
description: The New York City Opera will broadcast live five evening performances this season over WNCN, the classicalmusic radio station here owned and operated by the GAF Broadcasting Company. As of now, 12 other stations, from Boston to San Diego, will carry the broadcasts, live or on tape.

title: A New Katya By Coast Opera Brings Bravos
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19When things go wrong for the San Francisco Opera, which is rare, local audiences are still appreciative. So powerful is the appetite for opera here that the 12week season is almost always sold out before it starts.

title: Dream of Trumpet Glory Fulfilled, Gerard Schwarz Picks Up a Baton
description: As a youngster studying trumpet with the New York Philharmonic's William Vacchiano, Gerard Schwarz dreamed of following in his teacher's footsteps. Then the dream came true: Four years ago, at the age of 26, Mr. Schwarz joined the Philharmonic as a coprincipal.

title: Report Supports Unionization For Catholic Schools' Lay Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)Lay teachers in Roman Catholic parochial schools can unionize, but they must bear in mind the unique characteristics of the schools as communities of faith, a report by a subcommittee of the United States Catholic Conference said today.

title: Oil Rig Collapses in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 19 (Reuters) An American oil rig has collapsed off the oil town of Balikpapan in Indonesian Borneo, killing one man and injuring several others, oil sources said today. Salvage officials in Singapore said the rig capsized Thursday in shallow waters and that salvage vessels were standing by.

title: Carter, Meeting Dayan, Asks Courageous Leadership on Both Sides
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19President Carter, opening a new and perhaps decisive round of Middle East diplomacy, told Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel today that it was important for Israel and the Arab states to show courageous leadership and to make compromises if there was to be a lasting settlement in the region.

title: Books of The Times
description: It seems that when Richard and all the little Nixons sat down in the White House in January 1969 to figure out how to stop crime in time for the 1972 reelection campaign, they had to be reminded by Attorney General John N. Mitchell to hold their rhetorical horses. The Federal Government, Mr. Mitchell pointed out, simply hadn't the powers or the jurisdiction to do much about the kinds of crimehomicide, assault, mugging, robbery and burglarythat worried most Americans.

title: Carter Is Told Senate Will Reject Curbs and Vote Gas Deregulation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  President Carter was told today that the Senate would reject, by at least a fourvote margin, his natural gas pricing proposal and vote to deregulate gas prices.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal Transportation Department official in Washington promised to speed up a $2 million appropriation to install firefighting equipment in four Long Island Rail Road tunnels under the East River in New York. The official, Woodruff Price, an assistant to Secretary Brock Adams, told the board of directors of the Amtrak rail passenger system that he believed the money was available without special action by Congress.

title: On Loggerheadedness
description: ASPEN, Colo.One of the great wonders of environmental work is how seldom anyone has wanted to sit down to settle a dispute. In other fields, usually mechanisms to adjust conflicts between disputants develop once the parties recognize that such conflicts are a permanent fact of life. However, this has not happened much yet with respect to environmental conflicts, particularly over construction projects. Why?

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1977

title: Excerpts From U.S. Brief in Bakke Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Following are excerpts from the Government's amicus curiae brief in the Bakke case that was filed with the Supreme Court today:

title: Cocteau Repertory Overacts In Massinger Overreached!!
description: To say that a theatrical production is well intentioned is to speak well of the dead. The Jean Cocteau Repertory's version of the Jacobean play A New Way to Pay Old Debts has all the features of an unsuccessful resuscitation: good motives, lots of activity and no life.

title: House Vote of 201 to 180 Rejects Higher Ceiling on National Debt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)The House today rejected, by a vote of 201 to 180, a move to raise the ceiling on the national debt by $75 billion to a new level of $775 billion.

title: House Passes Black Lung Measure Easing Requirements for Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)The House passed legislation today to shift black lung payments from the Federal Treasury to the coal industry and to ease requirements for coal miners to qualify fo rbenefits.

title: Hughes Tool Company is Struck In Steelworkers Wage Dispute
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (AP)Pickets went up last night at the Hughes Tool Company plant here as a union local representing 2,500 workers rejected a contract proposal that it contended did not include a big enough wage increase. Company officials Said the strike would affect about 3,500 employees.

title: Korean Boy Dies in Mass Poisoning
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 19 (AP)A 9yearold boy died today after being stricken with food poisoning Friday along with 8,000 other children after eating apparently spoiled bread. The Seoul prosecutor's office has arrested three officials of the food company whose bakeries supplied the bread to a primary school lunch program.

title: Advertising
description: Standard Oil of California, marketers of Chevron brand gasoline, after a summerlong search for a new ad agency, has chosen the J. Walter Thompson Company to handle its $10 million account.

title: Waldheim Expresses Doubts on Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19Secretary General Kurt Waldheim expressed doubts today about the socalled Dayan plan for giving Arab inhabitants in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River greater autonomy.

title: Article 3  No Title
MRS. MONTGOMERYMOORE DIES AT 77 IN CONNECTICUT
description: Helene MontgomeryMoore, a civic leader of Higganum, Conn., died Sunday in Middlesex Memorial Hospital, Middletown, Conn. She was 77 years old and lived on Landing Road, Higganum, and at Treloyne, Paget, Bermuda.

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday, September 20, 1977

title: British Bakers, 9 Days on Strike, Agree to Resume Work Tomorrow
description: LONDON, Sept, 19 (UPI)The strike by British bakers ended tonight with an agreement by that union to return to work by Wednesday.

title: Dog Bettors Bilked In Computer Scheme
description: MIAMI, Sept. 19The discovery of a computertampering scheme to defraud bettors at the West Flagler Kennel Club here was disclosed today by State Attorney Richard E. Gerstein.

title: SENATE AIDES TESTIFY LANCE MISLED THEM BEFORE CONFIRMATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Congressional staff members testified today that Bert Lance misled them before his confirmation about financial problems at the Georgia bank he once headed.

title: R. H. MACY TO CLOSE BIG BRANCH STORE IN JAMAICA, QUEENS
description: R. H. Macy & Company, New York's largest retailer, plans to close its large branch store in the Jamaica section of Queens when the current lease expires on Nov. 1, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: The Pennant Race
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: Yale University Aide is Named President of Colgate University
description: Dr. George D. Langdon Jr., deputy provost and lecturer in history at Yale University, has been named president of Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., it was announced yesterday by Frankin B. Lincoln Jr., the chairman of Colgate's board of trustees.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Substitute for B1 Sought in Addition to Cruise Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Two months after President Carter's decision to block production of the B1 strategic bomber, Pentagon officials and members of Congress are pressing for development of a mixed force of another manned penetrating bomber and the cruise missile.

title: Cholera In Bangladesh Has Killed 100 People; Islanders Also Are Hit
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters)Bangladesh announced today that more than 100 people had died from cholera, while doctors in the Gilbert Islands in the Pacific said 17 persons had died from the disease there.

title: Market Place
description: For a select group of Wall Streeters, the game with the highest stakes in town is risk arbitrage. Yesterday, a big decline in Gerber Products stock caused steelnerved arbitragers to drop a bundle.

title: Films of Bygone Stars To Aid American Place
description: Film footage of great stage actors of the past  among them George Arliss, Tallulah Bankhead, John Barrymore, Nol Coward, Leslie Howard, Walter Huston, Charles Laughton, Pauline Lord, Helen Morgan and Laurette Taylorwill be a highlight of a gala evening to raise funds for the American Place Theater's 197778 season. The footage, assembled in a production conceived by Wynn Handman and edited by Kathryn Barnier, is called That's Acting! and will be shown at the American Place Theater on Tuesday, Oct. 18, at 7:30 P.M.

title: Imperiale, Withdrawing, Backs Bateman
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19State Senator Anthony Imperiale, independent of Newark, withdrew today from the governorship race and said he would support the Republican candidate, State Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville.

title: Concert: Choral
description: Back from a European tour, the Sarah Lawrence Chorus appeared in Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night for a concert directed by the group's conductor, Harold Aks. The program was a generous one and covered material from the English and Italian Renaissance through the Baroque, Romantic and contemporary eras.

title: People in Sports
description: Saying that hypnotherapy treatments had enabled him to get my mind together, Jerry Quarry yesterday announced that he would return to professional boxing after more than two years of retirement. Quarry, 32 years old and weighing 210 pounds, will launch his comeback on Nov. 5 against Lorenzo Zanon of Italy as part of the Ken NortonJimmy Young fight card do Las Vegas.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Decline
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Bonn Defends AntiTerrorism Plan
description: BONN, Sept. 19President Walter Scheel said today that proposals for solving West Germany's terrorism problem were compatible with the rule of law a free democracy. He rejected what he termed irresponsible criticism from abroad alleging that fascist trends were developing in West Germany.

title: Now to November, and Beyond
description: Congratulations to Edward Koch and the Democratic Party of New York City. The party is fortunate that its voters chose as their candidate for Mayor an able and industrious legislator who has demonstrated a willingness to speak frankly about the difficult problems facing the city. Mr. Koch has earned our admiration in an uphill climb for recognition against six rivals and a final triumph over Mario Cuomo, who showed exceptional appeal. It was a worthy test for the job he seeks and Mr. Koch has passed it.

title: Cattleman's Valley Offers No Shelter From Losses
description: VICTOR, Colo.  Up here in the Rockies, in a valley 9,200 feet in the sky, Chuck Bradley seemed almost immune to problems of a sealevel world.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: SONY'S PROFIT FELL 28.1% FOR QUARTER
description: The Sony Corporation reported yesterday a drop of 28.1 percent in net income for the third fiscal quarter ended July 31, to $20.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from $40.7 million, or 19 cents a share on fewer shares outstanding, in the similar three months of last year.

title: South Africa On Trial Again
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 18  A week after the event, it is clear that the death of Steven Biko has shaken South Africa more than any single event since the police opened fire at Sharpeville in 1960, killing 72 black demonstrators.

title: Company Reports
description: For periods ended Aug. 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Defense Fund Drive for ExF.B.I. Agent Would Aid Helms, Simon Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19William E. Simon, the former Secretary of the Treasury, said today that a group that has been raising funds for a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent recently indicted in New York would also raise funds for Richard Helms if the former Director of Central Intelligence was indicted.

title: World News Briefs
description: MIAMI, Sept. 19 (AP)Thousands of persons, most of them of Cuban extraction, staged a March for Freedom through downtown Miami today to protest the limited resumption of United States relations with Cuba.

title: Stevenson Warns South Koreans To Cooperate on Tongsun Park
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Senator Adlai E, Stevenson 3d, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Ethics, today coupled a widening of the Senate's Korea inquiry with a warning that noncooperation by South Korea with the investigations here would be considered provocative and an act of ingratitutde.

title: Woman Who Sued Over Diet Wins Damages for Feeble Daughter
description: VALPARAISO, Ind., Sept. 19 (UPIA woman whose doctor put her on a rice and fruit diet during her last two months of pregnancy in 1954 has won $50,000 In damages on behalf of her mentally retarded daughter.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Abuses in Testing Of Drugs by C.I.A. To Be Panel Focus
description: WASHINGTON.
