Sept. 19A Senate subcommittee reportedly has concluded that of the scores of scientific projects undertaken by the Central Intelligence Agency in its 25year quest for control of the human mind, none represented a greater potential abuse of governmental authority or medical ethics than the agency's testing of LSD25 and other psychochemicals on unsuspecting subjects.

title: STATE AIDES REBUKED OVER KENTUCKY FIRE
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 19A Congressional subcommittee holding hearings today on the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire in which 164 persons died, heard Kentucky Gov. Julian M. Carroll condemn the club's owners and several state officials for collectively setting the stage for such a disaster by ignoring state fire codes since at least 1971.

title: Gain Cited in Heart Surgery Without Transfusions
description: Heart operations generally require blood transfusions but it has now been demonstrated that they can be done successfully without them, according to a report published yesterday of 542 operations Jehovah's Witnesses at a hospital in Houston.

title: Disease Suspected in Fish Kill
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP)A fish kill that affected only striped bass in Long Island Sound over the weekend may have been due to a disease organism, a state environmental official said today. Robert A. Jones of the state's Department of Environmental Protection said the fact that no other species was affected indicated that a disease organism might have been the cause. He said laboratory tests would have to be conducted to be certain. Dead striped bass were seen floating on the Sound in Connecticut from Bridgeport to Greenwich and along the Westchester County, N. Y. Shore, Mr. Jones said.

title: DR. BENJAMIN NELSON, 66, PROFESSOR OF SOCIOLOGY
description: Dr. Benjamin Nelson, professor of sociology and history at the New School for Social Research, died Saturday of a heart attack aboard a train in West Germny. He was 66 years old and a resident of Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Police Labor Role Cited
description: Charging that policemen have been reduced to collective begging instead of collective bargaining, an official of the Policemen's Benevolent Association said he expected the police to be more militant in their future contract demands.

title: CORRECTION
description: The address for the memorial service for Charles Stanley, who died Sept. 3 on Vancouver Island, British Columbia, was incorrectly given in The Times Sunday. The service will be held tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Circle Repertory Company, 99 Seventh Avenue South.

title: The Fed's Money Policy: Is It Overly Restrictive?
description: Tensions are beginning to build in business and financial circles as the nation's economy apparently is entering a period of slower growth after two and a half years of rather rapid expansion. At the same time has come evidence that Washington's money managers have been gently applying the brakes in an effort to moderate the continuing growth of the money supply. In the process, shortterm interest rates have been rising moderately and steadily.

title: DIRECTOR OF AVIATION REINSTATED BY PORT
description: Caesar B. Pattarini, who was suspended Sept. 2 as director of aviation of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was reinstated yesterday in his $61,386ayear job after repaying the agency about $2,000 in improper expenditures and expenseaccount billings he admitted submitting.

title: Robert B. Frazier, Oregon Editor; Served as Pulitzer Prize Judge
description: EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 19 (UPI)Robert B. Frazier, editorial page editor of The Eugene RegisterGuard and a 1977 Pulitzer Prize judge, died yesterday of an apparent selfinflicted gunshot wound, the police reported.

title: KISSINGER APPRAISES U.S. FOREIGN POLICY
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State came to New York yesterday to deliver a major appraisal of U.S. foreign policy at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: FREDERICK MELIUS JR., 72, HEADED TRANSWAY CORP.
description: Frederick N. Melius Jr., president of the Transway International Corporation from 1966 to his retirement in 1972 and a leader in the development of intermodal transportation of freight, died Saturday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., eight hours after the death there of his wife, the former Coralie Harper. His age was 72 and hers was 71.

title: L. I. SEWAGE DUMPING IN ATLANTIC IS UPHELD
description: Long Island's sewage may be dumped into the Atlantic Ocean until techniques are developed to return it to the soil, a judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

title: Regular Democrats Seek to Upset Candidates of N.D.C. for Judges
description: Factions within the Democratic Party were striving yesterday to dislodge the package of six nominations for Supreme Court judgeships in Manhattan and the Bronx devised by the antiorganization New Democratic Coalition on Sunday.

title: Gromyko and Carter to Hold Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, who arrived in New York Saturday, will go to Washington Wednesday for talks with President Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, Soviet sources said today.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1977

title: BOWNES AND HIGGINBOTHAM PICKED FOR APPEALS COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)President Carter announced today that he had nominated Federal Judge Hugh H. Bownes to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit in Boston, covering Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico.

title: Mrs. Onassis Said to Get 20 Million In a Pact With Christina Onassis
description: ATHENS, Sept. 19Jacqueline Onassis has negotiated what her friends here call an astounding settlement with her late husband's daughter under which the shipowner's widow will receive $20 million in return for abandoning all further claims to his estate.

title: Democrats Nominee for Mayor: A Winner 9 Times in 14 Years
description: If Edward I. Koch ever needed any official seal on his runoff victory, it may have come when Jimmy Carter called.

title: REPUBLICANS FIND CARTER KEPT 121 OF 674 PROMISES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)The Republicans, happy to oblige President Carter by keeping tabs on his 1976 campaign promises, said today that 121 of 674 had been kept and that 77 had been broken in the first seven months of the new Administration.

title: End to Racial Fights Sought As Danbury Classes Reopen
description: DANBURY, Conn. Sept. 19School administrators, community workers and residents of this northern Fairfield County city sought today to explain and deal with the causes of racial fighting that broke out at Danbury High School last week, causing classes to be halted temporarily and 32 students to be suspended.

title: '78 E.P.A. Mileage Report Shows Diesel Cars as Top Fuel Savers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Dieselpowered automobiles led three of five categories in fuel economy ratings for 1978 models, released today by the Environmental Protection Agency. Among them were Oldsmobile's new diesel passenger cars, the first made in the United States, which topped the fullsized classification with 21 miles per gallon in the city and 30 on the highway.

title: J'Informe, a New Daily, Is Published in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 19A new daily began publication here today, bringing the number of generalcirculation Frenchlanguage dailies in Paris to 11. The newspaper is called J'Informe I Informa title as unusual in French as it would be in English.

title: Red Sox Defeat Yankees, 63,  And Trail by 3 Orioles Bow
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19Dave Kingman, the Yankees' new homerunagame kid, hit one of his patented towering home runs in his first time at bat at Fenway Park tonight and set himself and the Yankees wondering what might have been.

title: I.L.A. Trial Is Told of Payoffs for Unloading in Strikes
description: An official of the United Brands Company testified yesterday that he delivered cash payments of almost $50,000 to a top officer of the International Longshoremen's Association to insure that the company's banana boats would be unloaded during strikes in 1968 and 1971.

title: Conflicting Claims Over Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19Palestinian guerrillas and Israelisupported Christian forces fought pitched battles in southern Lebanon today for the control of strategic positions on the Litani River and made conflicting claims on the progress of the fighting.

title: Major League Scores
description: BALTIMORE (A.)

title: Weather Foils Balloonist
description: BAR HARBOR, Me, Sept. 19 (AP)A high pressure system veered north today, thwarting plans by two Colorado balloonists, who had hoped to lift off in their heliumfilled baloon for a transAtlantic flight tomorrow. Dewey Reinhard and his copilot, Steve Stephenson, both of Colorado Springs, spent the day making communications checks and packing their gear.

title: Abuses in Testing Of Drugs by C.I.A. To Be Panel Focus
description: The following article is based on reporting by John M. Crewdson and Jo Thomas. It was written by Mr. Crewdson.

title: On Madison Avenue, the Boutiques Usher In a Fashionable Fall
description: Fifteen of the chic boutiques that dot Madison Avenue from 64th Street through 77th Street got together yesterday morning to show highspots from their fall fashion collections in the main auction room of Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Logue Certified in New Haven As Victor in Democratic Primary
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 19 (AP)Mayor Frank Logue has been certified as the winner over former Police chief Biagio DiLieto in last Thursday's Democratic primary by 339 votes. The first officially reported plurality had been 187.

title: Drop in Dow of 5.29 to 851.52 Close Puts It at Lowest Level in 20 Months
description: The stock market lurched downward yesterday in a broad setback that sent it to its lowest level in 20 months.

title: In Memoriam
description: PASACHOFFDr. Harry D. In memory of our dearly beloved. Mildred, Alice, Jane. WINTERDr. Samuel S. Fondly remembered. Rest peacefully. Rose, Gloria, Eli, Douglas

title: Chinese Military Leader Calls for Discipline in Army
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 19A Chinese military leader has disclosed that factional conflict in recent years has given rise to a discipline problem in the army, with some officers and men disobeying orders for supposed political reasons or bargaining over how far to carry them out.

title: TV: CBS Presents Lou Grant
description: How does an innocent bystander describe Lou Grant, a weekly series beginning tonight at 10 o'clock? The CBS press department calls it a new dramatic series with comedic overtones. The CBS press department may be one of the last institutions to toss around a word like comedic. Some viewers, however, might think it is a comedy series with dramatic undertones. Evidently, CBS avoided that description because, blessedly. Lou Grant does not have a laugh track.

title: Manny Wolf's Badly Vandalized A Union Dispute Is Suspected
description: Manny Wolf's, the East Side restaurant that is undergoing renovations, was extensively damaged yesterday by a group of men in what the police suspect was a union dispute.

title: A Crisis in Search of a Theme
description: The Bert Lance confusion has now reached the status that Richard Nixon would have classified as a crisis. That much was apparent when the networks moved it onto television and Clark Clifford took the chair just behind Lance on the right of the screen.

title: Fire on Metroliner Delays Trains
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (UPI)  A fire aboard the 8 A.M. Metroliner from Washington to New York halted traffic in both directions for more than an hour today. A spokesman for Amtrak said that the fire broke out about a mile and half southwest of Philadelphia's 30th Street Station in the third car of a fourcar train. Several hundred passengers from the heavily used line were transferred to a nearby train. There were no injuries.

title: SENATE AIDES TESTIFY LANCE MISLED THEM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Congressional staff members testified today that Bert Lance misled them before his confirmation about financial problems at the Georgia bank he once headed.

title: Negotiations at Dowling College End With Both Sides Far Apart
description: OAKDALE, LI, Sept. 19The first facetoface talks in almost three weeks between negotiators for Dowling College and its striking faculty members broke down last night, with both sides remaining far apart. The college announcement said that no new talks had been scheduled.

title: Port Authority Scolded by Judge For Postponing Decision on SST
description: The chief judge of the Federal appeals court in Manhattan rebuked the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday for delaying for the last 18 months a decisoin on noise standards the Concorde supersonic airliner would have to meet to operate at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Refugees Tell of the Hardships and Fear They Say Drove Them Away From Vietnam
description: MANILA, Sept. 15Now that southern Vietnam has become virtually impenetrable by foreigners and only the Hanoi Government's picture of life in the reunited country is presented to the world, the thousands of Vietnamese who have fled in small boats are the principal source of critical firsthand information about their country.

title: SPECIAL UNIT CREATED FOR REVIEW OF LANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Justice Department has created a special threemember panel to review all questions in the department concerning Bert Lance and to make recommendations for future action, Deputy Attorney General Peter F. Flaherty said today.

title: Vermont Lottery Chief Named
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 19 (AP)The appointment of J. Henry Malkus as Vermont lottery director was approved today by Gov. Richard Snelling. Mr. Malkus is assistant superintendent of the Illinois lottery. Legislation earlier this year approving a state sweepstakes provided that the Vermont lottery commission name a director with the approval of Governor Snelling.

title: ISRAELIS GO ON ALERT ON LEBANESE BORDER
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 19Israeli military forces in the north have been placed on alert because of the intensified fighting in southern Lebanon between Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Christians.

title: U.S. Expresses Its Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (Reuters)The United States said today it was concerned at the recent increase in fighting in southern Lebanon and was continuing its efforts to stabilize the situation.

title: The Giants' Family Affair
description: The first thing that Jerry Golsteyn did as a starting quarterback in the National Football League was hand the ball off to Doug Kotar, and watch as Kotar headed out around right end. The second thing Golsteyn did was notice that Kotar, having found no daylight on the right side, was heading back to the left side. So the third thing Golsteyn did was pick out a Washington Redskin, and throw himself at that Redskin's feet.

title: Article 1  No Title
Football Rankings
description: COACHES' POLL

title: Bridge:
description: Outside North America the prowess of countries in international competition tends to oscillate in accordance with the supply of topclass young experts. Sweden has recently been in the ascendancy for this reason, while France and Britain, by contrast, seem to be suffering from hardening of the arteries.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1977

title: Jets' Harper: FreeAgent Rookie Is Only Spark in Team's Offense
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19If it weren't for a 5foot8inch, virtually unknown player from Kutztown State, the Jets' offense couldn't get off the blackboard.

title: Appellate Panel Modifies Alabama Prison Reforms
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circult has made substantial modifications in federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr.'s comprehensive order of prison reform in Alabama, saying that he had exceeded his judicial authority in several areas.

title: Dance: A Predictable Alejandro
description: The Reynaldo Alejandro Dance Theater combines the materials of Philippine folk traditions with modern dance in an effort to find the best of both possible dance worlds. Judging by Rituals, which the company presented Sunday evening at the Vorpal Gallery, it is a synthesis that is still very much in the making.

title: C. A. BLISS, 73; HELD CHAIR IN BUSINESS AT HARVARD
description: Dr. Charles A. Bliss, a professor emeritus of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, where he was the first to hold the Royal Little chair, died Saturday at his home in Angwin, Calif. He had retired in 1970. He was 73 years old.

title: Vegetarian Diet and Breast Milk
description: The levels of pesticides in the breast milk of 50 women following vegetarian diets were onethird to onehalf those found in a 1976 national sample taken of women eating a conventional diet, according to tests just completed for the Federal Government and a private environmental group.

title: Article 2  No Title
TIME INC. PICKS GRUNWALD TO BE A CORPORATE EDITOR
description: Time Inc. has announced that Henry, A. Grunwald, managing editor of Time magazine since 1968, has been named to the position of corporate editor and that Ray Cave will succeed him.

title: Manny E. Duell, 66; Led Realty Concern Active in the Village
description: Manny E. Duell, president of Morgan Holding Company, a real estate concern that owned many properties in Greenwich Village and other sections of Manhattan, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack at his suburban home in Weston, Conn., at the age of 66.

title: Boy Awarded $540,000 in School Bus Accident
description: FIACKENSACK, Sept. 19A 13yearold schoolboy who was struck by a police car three years ago as he got off a school bus in Englewood was awarded $540,000 today in an outofcourt settlement.

title: Untying the China Knot
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance returned from Peking without making visible progress toward resolving the China dilemma: how to normalize relations with China without abandoning Taiwan or generating a domestic outcry. Yet normalize we must. Shaped by strategic and other political forces, the issue for Washington no longer is whether to do so, but how.

title: Manchester Soccer Team To Appeal Suspension
description: MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 19 (UPI)Manchester United will appeal the Union of European Football Association's suspension of the soccer team from the European Cup Winners' Cup, a club spokesman, Les Olive, said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: CORRECTION
description: The address for the memorial service for Charles Stanley, who died Sept. 3 on Vancouver Island, British Columbia, was incorrectly given in The Times Sunday. The service will be held tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the ?? Repertory Company, 99 Seventh ?? nue South.

title: Red Sox, Backs to the Wall, Still Alive
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19With eight games left to play in the tantalizing shadow of the Great Green Wall of Fenway Park, the Boston Red Sox refused to concede anything tonight as Manager Don Zimmer warned the New York Yankees: We're not dead vet.

title: Kuwait Nationalizes A U.S. Oil Company
description: After more than a year of fruitless negotiations, Kuwait yesterday nationalized operations of the American Independent Oil Company, The Associated Press reported.

title: Topics
description: WAGES UP  Unfortunately, the House voted last week to raise the minimum wage from $2.30 to $3.05 over the next three years. The increase would improve the lot of some unskilled workers at the cost of eliminating the possibility of employment for others, who will be priced out of the labor market. The only good news lies in what the bill does not include. Organized labor wanted, but failed to get, a formula linking the minimum to an index of manufacturing wages; it would have automatically raised the minimum wage in the future without additional Congressional action. The House also rejected an attempt to exempt teenagers from the increase; this would have meant more work for youngsters but less for older breadwinners. We hope the Senate follows the House in approving no more than the narrowest possible revisions in the current law. More, in this case, would clearly be less.

title: Carter Undecided on Lance, Who Appears at Peace With Himself
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19President Carter has still not decided on the future of Bert Lance, an Administration spokesman said today after the two old friends had discussed their problems in a private earlymorning meeting at the White House.

title: Seoul Hints It May Ask U.S. to Return Former Aide
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 19South Korean officials hinted today, through a variety of news leaks, that they might indict and then demand the repatriation from the United States of Kim Hyung Wook, the exiled former intelligence chief whose testimony before the United States Congress linked a South Korean Government agency to alleged multimilliondollar attempts to influence American policy favorably toward South Korea.

title: Barron's Wins in Reliance Libel Suit
description: A Federal judge has ruled in favor of Barron's, a weekly financial newspaper, in a decision that is likely to make it harder for corporations to sue for libel.

title: Toronto Shows Plans for $34 Million Music Hall
description: TORONTO, Sept. 19The projected new home of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra and Mendelssohn Choir, the focus of classical music in this commercial capital of Canada, will be a glittering, $34 million glassenclosed creation, limned by shiny office towers and a spacious park in what is now just another section of the inner city bordering the financial and business district.

title: CUOMO TO STAY IN RACE
description: Representative Edward I. Koch, who was virtually discounted as a serious candidate three months ago, defeated Mario M. Cuomo in the Democratic mayoral runoff primary yesterday by a 55to45 margin to become a strong favorite to be New York City's next Mayor.

title: 15 WouldBe Mayors Vie in Seattle Primary Today
description: SEATTLE, Sept 19Fifteen mayoral candidites are skirmishing for two spots on the November ballot in tomorrow's nonpartisan primary here, and the seven leading contenders are working furiously to win votes from a largely undecided and disinterested electorate.

title: Jeter Gets Big Chance With Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19Gary Jeter has broken into the Giants' starting lineup, the most sobering thought for a team still celebrating its comeback 2017 openinggame victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: Tanker Refloated Off Delaware
description: LEWES, Del., Sept. 19 (AP)An oil tanker with about 42 million gallons of crude oil was refloated today after she ran aground four miles east of Cape Henlopen at the mouth of Delaware Bay, the Coast Guard said. Lieut. Tom Morse said the Singaporeregistered tanker, Western Ethics, ran aground about 5:20 A.M. in calm seas.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Revue: Shalom '77 From Israel
description: The Israeli revue Shalom '77, which opened a twonight stand at Radio City Music Hall last night, tends toward the secretive. It offered no printed program, and the announcement of its songs, sung understandably enough in Hebrew, was sparse in its information. Luckily I had a few names supplied to me by the theater's press office, but background material was at a premium.

title: Questioning of Senate Panel Staff Puts Unusual Spotlight on Its Role
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The unusual appearance of four staff members to testify under oath today before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee provides a glimpse into the pivotal but usually anonymous role that the staff plays in the way Congress works.

title: Barbour Meeting Opponents of FuelAdjustment Fee
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19George H. Barbour, president of the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners, said today he would meet with representatives of a group of South Jersey residents who have been withholding portions of their payments on gas and electric bills to protest against increasing fuel  adjustment charges in their bills.

title: Jewelry Theft Suspect Captured And Some Gems Are Recovered
description: An employee of a midtown jewelry manufacturer was robbed of two boxes containing uncut diamonds worth $168,000 in a West Fourth Street station of the IND in Greenwich Village by two youths, but two nearby transit policemen captured a suspect and recovered one of the boxes with $56.000 of the gems.

title: Brazil Cancels 4 U.S. Military Pacts
description: BRASILIA, Sept. 19 (AP)Brazil canceled four military agreements with the United States today in a move that the American ambassador said ends all formal structure of military cooperation between the two countries.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill 2 Gaza Arabs After Stabbing of Another Soldier
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 19Two Arabs were shot and killed by Israeli soldiers today in the shopping area of the occupied Gaza Strip, according to an official Israeli announcement.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Monday, Sept. 19, 1977

title: Key Witness in C.I.A. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The scene was an ornate Senate hearing room. The time: a steamy morning last August. The senators mission: to nail down the elusive details of two decades of secret experiments in which the Central Intelligence Agency gave drugs to human subjects without their knowledge.

title: U.S. Backs Minority Admissions But Avoids Issue of Racial Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Carter administration strongly endorsed today the argument that disadvantaged members of minority groups may constitutionally be given special consideration in university admissions, but it avoided the question of whether specific racial quotas may be used to achieve that end.

title: U.S. Role in Bakke Case: Hard Questions Deferred
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Perhaps the Supreme Court will take the Government's advice in the Bakke case and avoid for the time being the question whether racial quotas in college admissions and other fields are constitutional. But the question will not go away. It is absolutely central to the debate in the country today over civil rights, and, eventually, the Carter Administration and the Court will have to face it squarely.

title: FLOOD RELIEF FUND GROWS FOR KANSAS CITY VICTIMS
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 19 (AP)Help from government sources, private corporations and individuals continued to pour in today as estimates of damage from one of this area's worst disasters edged toward $140 million.

title: Missouri Man Denies 4 Killings
description: CAMDENTON, Mo., Sept. 19 (AP)Roy E. Richardson Jr. pleaded not guilty today to four counts of capital murder in the shooting of four children near this Lake of the Ozarks community last week. Memorial services were held yesterday for the four children, Steven Swift, 14 years old; Gregory Swift, 12; Tanya Swift, 3, and Stacy Swift, 18 months.

title: Carol Bellamy Proud of Her Independence
description: It had been a long afternoon of handshaking. Young campaign workers piled into the rented car waiting at a Queens intersection. Crammed into one corner in the back seat, a woman hardly older than they, dressed in a cotton blouse and skirt and scuffed espadrilles, sat drumming her fingers against a huge metal campaign button that read: Hi! I'm Carol Bellamy.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: For most people, having their tax returns audited is so intimidating that they don't even think of protesting further, should the I.R.S. auditor's conclusions be unfavorable.

title: Police Baffled by Death and Identity Of Train Passenger Killed in Indiana
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP)More than 100 passengers and the crew members of an Amtrak train were detained for questioning as the authori. ties investigated the death of a passenger, who jumped or fell yesterday from the speeding Lake Shore Limited.

title: Rites Held for Addison Verrill, Variety Reporter Killed in Robbery
description: A funeral service for Addison Verrill, movieindustry reporter for Variety, was held on Saturday in Hamden, Conn. Mr. Verrill was found stabbed to death last Wednesday in his apartment at 2 Horatio Street. He was 36 years old. A Variety spokesman said that the writer's apartment had been ransacked and that the police suspected robbery as the motive for the killing.

title: Portuguese Pilots Return to Work
description: LISBON, Sept. 19 (AP)Pilots of Portugal's national airline returned to work early today after a threeday strike brow2ht a premise from the Government that two senior pilots dismissed fro refusing management posts would be reinstated. In addition, the management board will be replaced and new pay agreements negotiated with its successor. Spanish air traffic controllers ended a yearold slowown yesterday, and French controllers to end a slowdown today.

title: CUOMO TO STAY IN RACE
description: Representatinve Edward I. Koch, who was virtually discounted as a serious mayoral candidate three months ago, defeated Mario M. Cuomo in the Democratic mayoral runoff primary yesterday and became a strong favorite to be New York City's next Mayor.

title: MISS BELLAMY WINS CITY COUNCIL CONTEST
description: in the Sir Francis Suite of the Drake Hotel and said of his rival:

title: Steelers Rout 49ers by 270; Harris Excels
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP)Franco Harris rushed for 100 yards and a pair of touchdowns, and a totally dominant Pittsburgh defense yielded just 101 net yards to lead the Steelers to a 270 victory over the San Francisco 49ers tonight.

title: RIGHTS LEADERS SCORE ADMINISTRATION PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 19 (UPI)Civil rights leaders representing the Civil Rights Commission's state advisory committees said today that an Administration plan to eliminate the committees would dismantle the civil rights movement across the country.

title: U.S. Indian Leader to Seek Support Of Reds Attacking Carter on Rights
description: GENEVA, Sept. 19 (Reuters)Russell Means, an American Indian leader, said today that Indians plan to ram the human rights issue down President Carter's throat by telling East European leaders of the horrendous genocide being carried out against his people.

title: A WellProcessed Antiproliferation Bill
description: The House of Representatives is expected to vote tomorrow on a comprehensive bill designed to prevent other nations from using American nuclear technology or fuels for making nuclear weapons. Incredibly, although the United States has long been the world's major supplier of such technologies, it has never spelled out the conditions of export or the circumstances that would cause it to break off nuclear cooperation with other nations. Instead, there has been a hodgepodge of inconsistent bilateral and multilateral agreements.

title: James T. Housewright Dead at 55; Led Retail Clerks International
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)James T. Housewright, president of the 700,000member Retail Clerks International Union and an A.F.L.C.I.O. vice president, died today of cancer. He was 55 years old.

title: FIynt's Resignation Demanded
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19Richard A De Santis, a local private attorney, called for John J. Flynt's resignation from the House ethics committee today because of remarks made in early August regarding the thenpending lawsuits against Tongsun Park.

title: Yankees' Box Score
description: EChambliss. DPBoston 2. LOBYankees 3, Boston 5. 2BWhite, Munson. 3BFisk. HRMunson (17), Fisk (24), Kingman (5), Yastrzemski (25).

title: MICHAEL F. MARKEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Michael F. Markel, a lawyer who was an international food and drug law expert, died Sept. 11 after an apparent heart attack while vacationing in Germany, He was 80 years old.

title: N.F.L. Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME Pittsburgh 24, San Francisco O.

title: YOUNGSTOWN STEEL TO PARE OPERATIONS
description: Citing import competition and environmental restraints, the Youngstown Sheer and Tube Company announced yesterday a major cutback in Its steel operations at Youngstown, Ohio, at a cost of 5,000 jobs.

title: Easy Triumph by Miss Bellamy Follows Surprise Race of Sept. 8
description: Carol Bellamy, a littleknown state senator when she began a lonely, illfinanced campaign for New York City Council President, won the Democratic nomination yesterday.

title: English Soccer League Accepts Player Demands
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (UPI)The English Soccer League voted today to accept the players demands for freedom of contract and for the right to wear advertising on shirts.

title: Koch Celebrates Victory Briefly. And Then Be gins Running Again
description: Like most disciplined, dedicated men, Edward I. Koch worries that he is really neither. I took up jogging, he said the other day, so I bought myself a pair of good track shoes$29.95. I knew if I paid that kind of money I'd have to use them. With $8 shoes, forget it.

title: Strike by Yonkers Teachers Is Irking Some Parents
description: YONKERS. Sept. 19I think the kids are losing out, Jane O'Brien said today, reflecting a growing Impatience by many parents with the city's teacher strike, which is entering its third week.

title: COURT BACKS COUPLE WITH A FOSTER CHILD
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19 (AP)The State Supreme Court upheld today a lowercourt judge's ruling that a 3yearold girl should not be returned to her natural parents because it would cause the child too much damage to be taken from her foster parents.

title: Mushroom Pickers From Italy Have the French Up in Arms
description: ROME, Sept. 19A mushroom war has broken out between France and Italy. The French have accused the Italians of having crossed into their territory to gather mushrooms in French woods and then sell them at astronomical prices in France and other countries.

title: The U.N. Today
Notes on People
description: When Senator Hubert H. Humphrey made his first public appearance yesterday since leaving a hospital Sept. 2, it became an emotional occasion. Addressing the convention of the Minnesota A.F.L.C.I.O. in St. Paul, Mr. Humphrey said: I'm not about ready to have somebody cover me up. I'm not about ready to get lost, I'm about ready to be found again. The Senator underwent surgery Aug. 18 at the University of Minnesota hospital, it was found that he has an inoperable cancer of the pelvis. One of his aides said yesterday that the former Vice President had returned to the hospital five times for Xray treatment designed to shrink the tumor on his pelvis as a preliminary to chemotherapy.

title: Deaths
description: AYERSJoseph Gerrish, of Westhampton Beads N.Y.on September 18,1977. 1St freed father of Audrey Tupper Burgess. Grandfather of Frank A.Tupper III and Glenn Ayers Tupper. Funeral services will be held at St.Mark's Episcopal Church, Westhampton Beach, N.Y.on Wednesday at 4PM. Donations to Camp PaQuaTuck, Center Moriches. N.Y. and St.Mark's Chords Memorial Fund, Westhampton Beach, N.Y. would be appreciated by the family.

title: SELFREGULATION BY C.P.A. IS APPROVED BY MEETING
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 19A controversial selfregulation plan adopted over the weekend by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the accountants national professional body, received a strong vote of confidence yesterday from members attending the group's annual meeting

title: Iran Plane Deal Gains in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Carter Administration moved closer today to gaining Congressional approval of the proposed sale of radar planes to Iran.

title: Fire Prevention Week Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)President Carter today declared the week beginning Oct. 9 as Fire Prevention Week and urged Americans to learn about fire prevention and personal fire safety practices, the White House said.

title: Last Two Members of Casino Control Commission For Atlantic City Are Approved by State Senate
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19The final two members of the Casino Control Commission, which will regulate gambling in Atlantic City, were approved today by the State Senate, but only after one of the nominees, Alice B. Corsey, balked for a time over financial disclosure.

title: WILLIAM J. GREENE, AT 65; CLERK FOR FAMILY COURT
description: William J. Greene, who retired last year as chief clerk of Family Court in Manhattan while continuing to serve as president of the MidManhattan chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 549 West 123d Street.

title: YOUNGSTOWN STEEL TO PARE OPERATIONS
description: Citing import competition and environ mental restraints, the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced yesterday a major cutback in Its steel operations at. Youngstown, Ohio, at a cost of 5,000 jobs.

title: New Post for Home Builders Head
description: Joseph J. Morris, 48 years old and president of the Champion Home Builders Company, has been named chief executive officer of the Michiganbased company. His appointment follows the death on Sept. 8 of Henry E. George who held the title of chairman and chief executive officer. Succeeding Mr. George as chairman will be Stanley R. Day, 52, who has served as an outside member of the board since 1971.

title: MA CHAOCHUN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 19 (AP)Ma Chaochun, senior adviser to the late President Chiang Kaishek, died here today. He was 91.

title: Koch to Quit Congress If He's Elected Mayor
description: If Representative Edward I. Koch, the winner of yesterday's Democratic mayoral runoff primary, is elected mayor in November, he would resign his seat in the House of Representatives at the beginning of the new year and his seat would be filled at a special election in January or February.

title: Easy Triumph by Miss Bellamy Opens Door to Top Council Post
description: Carol Bellamy, a littleknown State Senator when she began a lonely, illfinanced campaign for New York City Council President, won the Democratic nomination yesterday.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: British Medical Journal Doubts Any Saccharin Link to Cancer
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)The Lancet, Britiain's authoritative medical journal, says in an editorial that it doubts a purported link between saccharin and bladder cancer In humans.

title: Gerber Triumphant, But Investors Lose As Suitor Gives Up
description: After five months of court wrangling by both sides, the Gerber Products Company, the nation's leading baby foods maker, succeeded yesterday in fighting off an unwanted takeover by Anderson, Clayton & Company, the big Texas food producer.

title: Reduction Is Urged In the Money Supply
description: The Federal Reserve, at a swift sbroke, ought to erase the $4 billion summer bulge in the money supply.

title: Murdoch Is Welcomed After Difficult Summer
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept 19After having spent the summer in thorny business sessions deciding to reject a merger with the rival league, the National Hockey League came out from under the paperwork today and returned to the game of hockey as training camp opened for 18 teams in Canada and the United States.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago is considering construction of as many as four coalfired generating units costing some $1.1 billion, according to Thomas G. Ayers, chairman and president. The units would be completed by 1986. They would be an addition to the utility's previous commitment to build five oilfired generating plants and eight nuclear power units in the next nine years.

title: One More Reason for NoFault
description: If additional reasons are still needed for accepting nofault automobile insurance, there is now one more: it would better serve the poor. Such is the conclusion of a new report, done by the Library of Congress at the behest of Representative Metcalfe of Illinois, cosponsor of a bill that would require every state to adopt nofault.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: The Internal Revenue Service is considering streamlining its appeals channels. It would like to consolidate its existing twostage procedure into one. The aim is to save money that could be used in other enforcement activities. Page 67.

title: Hartford Mental Confinement System Ruled Illegal
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 19 (AP)Connecticut's system of holding people in mental hospitals in unconstitutional because patients face the burden of proving they have become sane to win their freedom, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Lumber and Plywood Futures Fall;. Soybeans, Corn and Wheat Rise
description: There were more nervous traders in the lumber futures market than calm ones yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as both groups awaited the Federal report on housing starts.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Florida Power and Light Is Denied Reconsideration By State of Rate Formula
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 19The Florida Public Service Commission denied today a petition by the Florida Power and Light Company for the reconsideration of a controversial rate formula designed to encourage conservation of electricity.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)President Carter's $31.07 billion welfare plan is totally unworkable, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee told Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare today.

title: Dollar Declines Against Most Currencies
description: The dollar slipped against most major currencies except the British pound in light world foreignexchange trading yesterday. The Associated Press reported.

title: Belmont Jockeys
JUSTICE DEPT. BRIEF 1 OF 58 INBAKKE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Justice Department's advice to the Supreme Court in the Bakke case is only one of 58 suggestions provided the Justices in the case by outsiders, but it is likely to weigh a good deal more heavily with the Court than most of the rest.

title: Emergency Landing in Oklahoma
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 19 (AP)An American Airlines DC10 jet carrying 293 passengers made an emergency landing here last night after one of its engines malfunctioned. No one on the Los AngelesNew York flight was injured. All but six of the passengers were flown to New York on another jet about two hours later. Officials did not say why the six had stayed behind.

title: Kewanee Stockholders Approve Merger Agreement With Gulf
description: The merger of Kewanee Industries Inc., an oil and gas producer in Bryn Mawi, Pa., with interests in chemicals and coal, with the Gulf Oil Corporation was approved yesterday at a special meeting of Kewanee stockholders.

title: LETTER FROM BERKOWITZ SAYS HE KILLED 6 PERSONS
description: In a letter written from his hospital cell, David R. Berkowitz, the man accused of being the 44caliber killer, says he killed six young people over the last year.

title: Aussies' Lack of Effort For Cup Sailing Scored
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 19The America's Cup races are revived every three years much to the astonishment of those who see the challenger beaten decisively time after time.

title: Horsemen Charter Jet in France And Beat a U.S. Import Deadline
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 18The excitement is over now for Caro and Blushing Groom, two of Europe's leading thoroughbred sires, as they frolic in the bluegrass here. But for a while they were part of a spectacular race against time.

title: ExG.O.P. Chairman Tells Party to Change
description: GRAND JUNCTION, Iowa, Sept. 19 AP)The former G.O.P. national chairman, Mary Louise Smith. said today, the Republican Party was not in tune with the tempo of the times and must become more responsive to people's problems.

title: Turks Trying to Revive Tourism In a Captured Resort on Cyprus
description: FAMAGUSTA, CyprusThe two young Turkish waitresstrainees, oblivious to the fact that their work is an issue of debate at the United Nations in New York, moved briskly on a veranda of the nearly deserted Constantia Hotel here and emptied the ashtrays of two unexpected visitors.

title: Blue Jays 3, Orioles 1
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 (AP)Jerry Garvin dealt Baltimore's pennant hopes a severe blow tonight, allowing nine hits while pitching the Toronto Blue Jays to a 31 victory over the Orioles.

title: ALLEGED RAPIST IS SHOT BY ROOMMATE OF VICTIM
description: A 29yearold Queens woman shot an intruder in the stomach with his own gun early yesterday morning, moments after he had allegedly raped her 28yearold roommate in their home in South Ozone Park.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Teachers in Green Brook have ratified a twoyear contract, ending a sevenday strike at two of the district's schools, officials said.

title: Belgian King Visiting Canada
description: OTTAWA, Sept 19 (Reuters)King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola of Belgium arrived here today for a fiveday state visit, the first by a Belgian monarch to Canada.

title: Senate Panel Finds Report of Blackmail On Canal Unfounded
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that it had found no evidence that Panamanian officials blackmailed the United States into concessions in the Panama Canal treaty negotiations.

title: Auto Makers Assailed on Airbags
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (UPI)The head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration today accused automobile manufacturers of vicious opposition to a requirement that safety airbags be installed in all new cars by 1984. Joan Claybrook predicted at a news conference that efforts in Congress to veto Transportation Secretary Brock Adams's ruling requiring the airbags would fail.

title: House in Rome of Designer Gucci Robbed of Cash, Jewels and Furs
description: ROME, Sept. 19 (AP)Robbers broke into the home of the Italian fashion designer Aldo Gucci today, tied up his wife and two servants and got away with an undetermined amount of money, jewels and furs, the police said.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$7,500, cl., 3YO and up, 6f.

title: Joy in Manhattan Ballroom Gloom at Queens Hall
description: It was a night of happiness at the New York Hilton Hotel in Manhattan and of deadening gloom out in the old World's Fair grounds in Flushing Meadow, Queens.

title: Picasso's Widow Accepts a Plan To Give Her Quarter of His Estate
description: PARIS, Sept. 19 (UPI)Pablo Picasso's widow has accepted a plan to share the $205 million Picasso estate, ending four years of fighting among the six heirs, the estate lawyer said today.

title: 2 Men Are Rescued Seven Hours After Sloop Capsizes in L.I. Sound
description: MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP)Two men in a dinghy were rescued from Long Island Sound today about seven hours after their 27foot sloop capsized, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: Yankees' Records
description: BATTING

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Backs Minority Admissions But Avoids Issue of Racial Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Carter administration strongly endorsed today the argument that disadvantaged members of minority groups may constitutionally be given special consideration in university admissions, but it avoided the question of whether specific racial quotas may be used to achieve that end.

title: Jackson Player of the Week
description: Reggie Jackson of the Yankees, who hit .417 with five home runs and nine runs batted in last week, has been named the American League player of the week.

title: Issue and Debate
description: In the hurryup tempo of our society, the pace of everything we do has quickened, and this is especially true of sports. The most conspicuous example, attributable largely to the influence of television, is the policy of the suddendeath playoff to break a tie in football, basketball and Stanley Cup hockey, among others. One team scores a point and it's all over.

title: NEW YORK HITS SNAG IN SALE OF ITS NOTES
description: New York City was set back yesterday in its plans for a longawaited public offering of shortterm notes this year with the disclosure that the safeguards that it had wanted to accompany the note sale would require action by the Legislature in Albany.

title: 99 Boat People Fly to Safe Harbor
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 19Ninetynine Vietnamese who fled from their country in fishing vessels hoarded a jumbo jet today for the last leg of their adventurous escapes, turning into reality President Carter's program to admit 7,000 boat people to the United States.

title: ABC's Scheduling of Oswald Film Forces CBS to Hold Off Its Version
description: ABCTV has beaten CBS in the racetothedraw with a madefortelevision movie on Lee Harvey Oswald, the accused assassin of President Kennedy who himself was killed by Jack Ruby in 1963 before he could be brought to trial.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Talks of Involvement Of Outsiders in Asian Elections
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 19 (AP)Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has said that she suspects that outside forces had a hand in the election defeats of herself and Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike of Sri Lanka and in the military coup that ousted Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: Barry Bostwick Signs For Double Feature
description: Barry Bostwick, who won the 1977 Tony Award for best actor in a musical for his performance in The Robber Bridegroom, has been signed by producerdirector Stanley Donen to star in a new film, Double Feature, a Sir Lew Grade presentation for ITC Productions. Martin Starger is the executive producer of the film, which was written by Larry Gelbart and Sheldon Heller.

title: New York City Is Facing a Snag In Sale of Notes
description: New York City was set back yesterday in its plans for a longawaited public offering of shortterm notes this year with the disclosure that the safeguards that it had wanted to accompany the note sale would require action by the Legislature in Albany.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 156 RECRUITS SWORN INTO STATE POLICE
description: ALBANY, Sept. 19I want the same opportunity as everybody else, no more, Luis Velez of Delancey Street in New York City said today shortly after he and 155 other recruits were sworn in to the state police force.,

title: Ozark Chemical Hazard Eases
description: BERRYVILLE, Ark., Sept. 19 (AP)Many residents of this Ozark Mountain community, evacuated yesterday after fire in a chemical warehouse created smoke cloud filled with deadly chemicals, returned to their homes today though the fire continued to smolder.

title: Conservatives' Voting Scorecard Rates Goodman 13%, Bellamy 0
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican candidate for Mayor of New York City, received a 13 percent rating for his 1977 legislative voting record in a Conservative Party scorecard listing him lowest of the New York Legislature's Republicans.

title: Housing Starts for August Rose 32% Over Ratein '76
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)Housing starts in August were at an annual rate of 2.02 million, showing that the housing industry remains strong even though other segments of the economy have been cooling down in recent months, Government figures showed today.

title: Coal Prospects Spur RailCar Orders
description: Railroads, buoyed in part by the prospect of carrying more coal for the nation's power plants and industries, are steadily increasing orders, for new equipment.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: ANDES HANDIWORK A new exhibition of preColumbian and modern fabrics from South America goes on view today through Nov. 13 at the Center for InterAmerican Relations, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street. Included are intricate, vintage textiles from Peru and presentday items such as belts, bags, tunics, ponchos, tapestries and hammocks. Most of the items are from the Textiles Museum in Washington, with some modern examples trom nolivia, Ecuador, Chile and Argentina on loan from museums and private collections.

title: Credit Markets Gain a Bit
description: The credit markets were buoyed modestly yesterday by news that housing starts had declined in August, and fixedincome security prices rose slightly. During the afternoon, bond trading quieted as the markets searched for a sense of direction.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Nassau County Democrats Elect Harwood to 3d Term As Chairman of the Party
description: Stanley Harwood, a Westbury, L.I., lawyer and Democratic elections commissioner of Nassau County, was elected last night to a third full term as Democratic county chairman at a Nassau party convention.

title: A Charter for Spying?
description: Senators Edward Kennedy and Frank Church have made public a letter to Senator Birch Bayh in which they recommend that a new charter for the Federal Bureau of Investigation should limit it to the investigation of crimes and rule out intelligence operations for domestic security purposes.

title: EXECUTIVE ADDS DATA ON PAYING I.L.A. AIDE
description: Beverly K. Hachmann, the laborrelations director for the United Brands Company, testified yesterday that he delivered $35,000 in 1974 to Fred R. Field Jr., the general organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association, to assure labor peace.

title: Paddy Livingston, 97, Played In Debut of American League
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP)Paddy Livingston, the longest surviving player from the American League's 1901 inaugural season, died yesterday in a hospital. He was 97 years old.

title: Free Information About Glaucoma
description: Chapters in 23 states of the Society for the Prevention of Blindness conduct free glaucoma screening programs. Check your phone book under name of state Society . . ., etc.

title: Pakistani Court to Hear Plan to Release Bhutto
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 20 (Reuters)The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a petition challenging the detention of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto under martial law. It also ordered the army to transfer to Rawalpindi Mr. Bhutto and 10 other leaders of his Pakistan People's Party arrested in a national roundup Saturday night.

title: Notes on People
description: THE Panamanian head of state, Gen. Omar Torrijos, said that he had received the unexpected backing of John Wayne for the Panama Canal treaties. President Torrijos told newsmen that the actor, usually associated with conservative viewpoints, had telephoned him to express support and had agreed to visit Panama to demonstrate his backing. Mr. Wayne has an effect on the American public and we are happy to have his backing, General Torrijos said. Arturo McGowan, a Panamanian businessman who returned Sunday from a twoday visit with Mr. Wayne in California, said he will return Friday to discuss with the actor plans for his trip to Panama. Mr. Wayne, who could not be reached for comment yesterday, last week ordered copies of articles from The New York Times concerning the treaties.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Grain Consultations Set
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 20, (Reuters)Australia and Canada today agreed on close consultation on grain production and marketing, according to Otto Lang, Canadian Transport Minister and minister responsible for the Canadian Wheat Board.

title: Stopping the Clock in Pakistan
description: In politics, unlike sports, you can't stop the clock. That is what Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq tried to do in Pakistan last July when he seized power and established martial law in the wake of a bitterly disputed election. His purpose, he has stoutly asserted ever since, was to give his country a political breathing spell before a new election. It would be fought fair and square, with no incumbent able to use governmental power to manipulate the results, as Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto allegedly did last spring.

title: Carter Expected To Approve Line For Gas in West
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20Douglas Robinson, a senior official of the Federal Energy Administration, said today that President Carter would announce shortly, perhaps tomorrow, his approval of a Western leg of the Alaska natural gas pipeline that will deliver 700 million cubic feet of gas daily to California and the West.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Public Service Commission has announced in Albany that it will study how the Long Island Lighting Company manages its construction projects, mainly because the estimated cost of the utility's nuclear plant in Shoreham has gone from $300 million to $1 billion.

title: Pollution of Water by Industry Is Called Jersey's Major Problem
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20More than 12,000 New Jersey industries are discharging pollutants some of them toxic, into the water systems that provide much of the state's drinkingwater supply, the State Environmental Commissioner, Rocco D. Ricci, said today.

title: 2 Die in Floods on Ibiza
description: MADRID, Sept, 20 (UPI)Flash floods caused by 10 inches of rain killed at least two persons and caused extensive damage in Ibiza, reports from the Mediterranean island said today. The rain yesterday flooded hotels, destroyed crops and swept away facilities at several beaches.

title: Star Wars Pirated
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 20 (UPI)Federal agents raided a motel here yesterday and seized more than $4 million worth of pirated films, including Star Wars, Jaws and Rocky. The agents confiscated tapes of the films after a representative of 20th CenturyFox had viewed Star Wars over closedcircuit television in a room at the Sam Houston Inn. He alerted studio security officials and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Market Mixed in Moderate Trading; Dow Shows Rise of 0.26 to 851.78
description: The stock market, helped by some lastminute buying, closed mixed yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Agency Charges U.S. With Failure To Act on Education Fund Misuse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The National Institute of Education has accused the United States Office of Education of failing to impose sanctions on local school districts that use Federal compensatory education funds to reduce regular operating expenses rather than to hire addition. al teachers.

title: Outlook Held Bleak For Manufacturers Of Atomic Reactors
description: American manufacturers of nuclear reactors are in deep trouble. Their slumping markets show no signs of recovery, and the industry itself is now facing the disintegration of skills and production capability built up since World War II.

title: MRS. LOUIS MARCIANTE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20  Anna L. Marciante, widow of a pioneer labor leader in New Jersey, Louis Marciante, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center. She was 79.

title: Deaths
description: AUERHelen Mars. LADO Board of Directers and members regret the passing of their first President. ESSIE SHACK, President

title: Scottish Shortbread: Butter, Flour, Sugar At Their Very Best
description: The simplest product. at its best, often can be the most difficult to find. A ripe tomato, for example, warm from the vine, smelling of its countrified life, robust in taste. A crusty loaf of honest bread that says hands were in its making.

title: Dowsers Meet to Plumb the Unfathomable
description: DANVILLE, Vt., Sept. 17They moved across the village green like sleepwalkers, slowly and silently, with arms outstretched, seemingly oblivious to everything but the forked sticks or brass angle rods or wire coathangers clutched in their hands.

title: HOUSE VOTE IS SET ON SHIP PREFERENCE; SENATE DELAY SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Despite angry Republican complaints of unfair treatment, the House Rules Committee today voted to send cargo preference legislation to the floor next week.

title: Quebec Blacked Out By a Power Failure
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 20 (AP)A power failure this afternoon blacked out nearly all of Quebec Province, leaving many of its six million inhabitants stranded in homewardbound commuter trains and subways or tied up in traffic jams.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: LANCE AND TARLETON DISPUTED IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A Federal bank official has told investigators that Donald L. Tarleton, the head of the Comptroller of the Currency's office in Atlanta, said last February that Bert Lance had specifically asked him to rescind an agreement calling for strict monitoring of the Calhoun (Ga.) First National Bank.

title: SUGGESTION TO CAREY
description: Three campaign insidersEdward N. Costikyan and Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Herman Badillowill supervise the transition of power in City Hall, Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday after his victory in the Democratic runoff made him an overwhelming favorite to be the next Mayor of New York City.

title: Precious Metals Surge in Price
description: Precious metals futures turned sharply higher in price yesterday on New York's Comex and the smaller Chicago markets because of the further weakening of the dollar against most major currencies.

title: Notoriety Haunts RealLife Sam
description: YONKERS, Sept. 20Earlier this week, Samuel Carr, named by the suspected Son of Sam murderer as the subject of his obsession, ventured out of his home with an old friend to go to a Kiwanis Club luncheon. It was one of the first social functions Mr. Carr had attended since the Aug. 10 arrest of David R. Berkowitz as the .44caliber killer.

title: 2 N.D.C. CANDIDATES LOSE COURT VOTES
description: The regular Democratic organization pulled a stunning upset of the antiorganization New Democratic Coalition at the First Judicial District nominating convention last night when it captured two of six State Supreme Court judgeship places on the November ballot.

title: SUGGESTION TO CAREY
description: Three campaign insidersEdward N. Costikyan and Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Herman Badillowill supervise the transition of power in City Hall, Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday after his victory in the Democratic runoff made him an overwhelming favorite to be the next Mayor of New York City

title: Wine Falk
description: THIS IS wine course time. There o not seem to be as many this earsome of the faddists must have dropped awaybut there are some old standbys that have built a reputation over the years.

title: INEZ HERWITZ
description: Inez Herwitz, a former feature writer for The Chicago HeraldExaminer and The SunTimes, The New York American and a copy editor at Collier's magazine, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. She was 74 years old and lived at 30 East 37th Street.

title: Food Items Used In City Survey
description: The 41item market basket used by the Department of Consumer Affairs in its weekly survey of food prices is divided into six categories and is further broken down to account for the average needs of a family of two adults and two children.

title: Personal Health
description: MARIAN had been thinking that she was overdue for an eye checkup, but it was not until she almost got killed that she called the ophthalmologist for an appointment. She had been a safe, accidentfree driver for 30 of her 53 years and was baffled at how she could have failed to see that car coming from the left. As she started through the intersection, the car appeared as if out of nowhere and hit her car broadside. Marian was lucky to escape with cuts and bruises and a broken arm.

title: First Wave of Southeast Asian Boat People Arrives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20When Cuu Do was released from the reeducation and reformation camp in December 1975, he knew he had to get out of South Vietnam.

title: KOCH APPOINTS BADILLO, COSTIKYAN AND RANGEL TO HIS TRANSITION TEAM
Take Your Pick: The Apples of Autumn
description: Americans love apples. They're second only to the banana as the nation's favorite fruit, with per capita apple consumption at almost 16 pounds a year. But as we do everything else that's readily available yearround, we tend to take the apple for granted, often limiting its use to eating out of hand as a 3 o'clock snack. And more often than not, it'll be a Delicious or a McIntosh, two of the nation's favorite, if not distinctly different, varieties.

title: Queens Company Gets Federal Loan With Help of City
description: Mayor Beanie announced yesterday that the city had helped arrange a $2 million Federal loan for a Queens manufacturing company that was among several that complained of heavy vandalism earlier this year.

title: Yanks, Rained Out in Boston, See Lead Cut as Orioles Win
description: BOSTON, Sept. 20As rain pelted Boston with more ferocity than Boston batters pelted the Yankees with home runs, the Yankees pondered today the latest controversial question in a season that has been loaded with controversial questions.

title: How the Concord Conquered America
description: In October I went agraping to the river meadows, Thoreau wrote over a century ago in Walden, and loaded myself with clusters more precious for their beauty and fragrance than for food. This fall we who have gone agraping to the arbors in our own backyards face a similar problem. I am loaded to the eyeballs with beautiful and fragant Concord grapes, but how can I turn them all into food? They drop faster than we can pick, they squish under foot, they are purpling my neighbor' pool, my neighbor's children, my rugs, my sink. We've spent hours by the TV slipping grapes from their skins (the first year we innocently seeded each grape by hand) and joking about Beulah, peel me a grape. And still the grapes go on.

title: Head of Hostos Lets No Handicaps Slow Him Down
description: In a time of energy conservation and fewer limousines at the White House, it may not be surprising that Anthony Santiago, the new acting president of Hostos Community College. has decided to forgo the privilege of a car and driver. Except, that is, when one considers that Mr. Santiago is blind.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ALTHOUGH I have been in the United States for more than 30 years, one thing that is a constant source of wonder is the number of people who tell me that they had never known the flavor of tarragon during their childhood. In most home gardens in France, it is as common as parsley and chives. As a child I grew up eating omelets aux fines herbes, which always contained tarragon, and also enjoyed tarragonflavored roasts and a variety of mayonnaise dressings with tarragon. One of the bestknown (and one of the best) tarragonflavored dishes is chicken with tarragon, which comes in many versions.

title: Memorial Services
description: DILLIARDMaude Esther. Memorial Services at the First Presbyterian Church Oct. 1. 1977 at 11AM. Services conducted by Rev. Samuel Taylor.

title: Keeping Apples At Their Peak
description: When buying apples, purchase only as many as can easily be refrigerated. Apples ripen 10 times faster at 70 degrees than at 32 degrees, and will spoil and dry out rapidly.

title: Israeli Troops Said to Enter Lebanon to Aid Christians Against P.L.O.
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20Reports from Lebanon today said that Israeli mobile units crossed into the southern part of the country during the day to aid Lebanese Christians in their intensified fighting against Palestinian guerrillas. Military spokesmen here declined immediate comment on the reports.

title: DOCK WORKERS SEEK WIDER NEGOTIATIONS
description: The head of the longshoremen's union asked waterfront employers on the North and South Atlantic and Gulf coasts yesterday to meet tomorrow in Bal Harbour, Fla., for a new phase of contract negotiations aimed at preventing a strike by dockworkers on Oct. 1.

title: Guilty Plea After 23 Years
description: BLOOMFIELD, Iowa, Sept. 20 (UPI)After serving 23 years in prison for the crime, William J. Karston, 52 years old, has pleaded guilty to murdering a Davis County farmer. Mr. Karston entered the guilty plea yesterday, one day before his third trial on the charge was to begin in Davis County District Court. He was convicted of murdering Wendell Jones in 1954, but the Iowa. Supreme Court overturned the conviction. He was found guilty again in 1956, but that conviction was overturned as well.

title: FORMULA FOR GENEVA FORESEEN BY DAYAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel said today that he believed an agreed formula will be found to overcome the obstacles blocking a Middle East peace conference, and that this could occur before the end of the year.

title: Patrice Munsel to Open Town Hall Matinees
description: Patrice Munsel, the soprano, will open the second season of the Town Hall Matinee seriesan entertainment for senior citizens and everyone who enjoys daytime events. She will perform on Tuesday at 2 P.M.

title: Britons Mourn a Giraffe After Rescue Fails
description: LONDON, Sept. 20Britain was in mourning today for a giraffe that died five days after a fall at a Hampshire zoo.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1977

title: About Real Estate
description: They paid $3.2 million for the land. They couldn't come out.

title: Historical Tinder for Black Jobless Rate
description: Statistics released by the Labor Department earlier this month confirmed what black economists and social workers had been saying for years: Elements of the economyinstitutionalized racism, the flow of jobs away from central cities, the decrease in the number of lowpaying jobs and partitularly the devastating impact of recent recessionshave been driving the black unemployment rate steadily upward. The labor section of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, for example, has been warning for years that Depressionlike economic conditions persisted in the black cores of the nation's central cities. National Urban League researchers have insisted that official Government statistics have seriously understated the economic devastation that seemed a permanent affliction in the poorest of black communities.

title: Optimistic Researchers See Different Kind of Downtown
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20Despite the continuing erosion of downtown retailing and the population flight from the center city, urban researchers and downtown improvement executives said here today that they were optimistic about the future of the American downtown. But they said it would be a different kind of downtown.

title: CALLAS SERVICES HELD IN FOUR MAJOR CITIES
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP)A recording by Maria Calls of Vissi d'Arte from Tosca was played at the end of a memorial service for the soprano, who died in Paris last week. The tribute at London's Greek Orthodox Cathedral coincided with similar services in Paris and Milan.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: I KNOW WHAT I LIKE The Dada art movement has been described as: the nihilistic precursor of surrealism, a product of hysteria, scandalous, obscene, deliberately antiart and antisense. A characteristic production of the Dada movement was the Marcel Duchamp reproduction of the Mona Lisa with a mustache. Dada started in Zurich during World War I and lasted until about 1922. An exhibition in Cologne, in 1920, was held in the annex to a cafe lavatory and spectators were provided with hatchets for smashing the exhibitsand they did.

title: Museum Area a Historic District
description: A strip of the East Side near the Metropolitan Museum of Art was designated yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission as a historic district to preserve the area's character of luxury and distinction.

title: LANCE AND TARLETON DISPUTED IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A Federal bank official has told investigators that Donald L. Tarleton, the head of the Comptroller of the Currency's office in Atlanta, said last February that Bert Lance had specifically asked him to rescind an agreement calling for strict monitoring of the Calhoun (Ga.) First National Bank.

title: Theater: Soviet Estrada Packaged for Export
description: THERE is some charm and occasionally some mild excitement in the songs, dances, acrobatics and mime acts that the Soviet Estrada company brought to the Majestic Theater last night. Taken as a whole, though, it is depressingly like the displays at airport souvenir stands.

title: Article 3  No Title
Market Place
description: T. Rowe Price, who retired many years ago from the mutual fund management company that bears his name, has since pursued an independent course as always in managing money his own at this point.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: THEY are coming to a screening, a herd of people, all descending on the Baronet Theater at Third Avenue and 59th Street precisely at 7 P.M. They are coming on foot and in taxis, and here and there is a limousine. Woody Allen there somewhere; so is Jacqueline Onassis.

title: Agent Guilty Of Stealing From Pros
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 20Richard Sorkin, a former agent for many professional athletes, pleaded guilty in Nassau County Court today to seven counts of grand larceny in the second degree involving the theft of more than $360,000 from seven players he had represented.

title: About Education
description: Consolidation is a word that is being increasingly used in describing what the future holds for the nation's public schools.

title: Child's World
description: NOT LONG after a little boy or girl has learned to talk there may well be questions about why he is called Bruce or Roger or John or she is called Jane or Nancy or Sybil or whatever. And there may be attempts to spell the name even before the child goes to school.

title: Cuomo's Pledge to Stay in Race Contains a Small Escape Clause
description: Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo insisted yesterday, as he did in conceding defeat to Representative Edward I. Koch, that he would stay in the mayoral race as the Liberal Party nominee, but he left himself a narrow escape hatch.

title: When Kids Grow Up And Move Back In
description: AFTER SPENDING four years away at college, it is not always easy to come home. And for many graduates, it is even harder to stay. But confronted with a tight job market, discouraged by high rents, and willing to sacrifice a little independence for a chance to explore career possibilities without the burden of financial obligations, more and more youngsters are giving it a try.

title: On the Art of Silence in Oysterville
description: OYSTERVILLE, Wash. When it comes to talking, some Espys do and some Espys don't. Aunt Dora and Papa did. Uncle Will and Uncle Cecil (Grandpa too) didn't and still don't. I don't.

title: Best Buys
description: HIGHER prices for grain products helped push the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City to a record level for the second consecutive week, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Letters
description: Craig Claiborne's definitive article on an Argentine churrasco. mislabeled Brazilian, is properly authentic, but some slight American innovations will spell out the distance between success and failure.

title: Nastase Spaghetti Victim
description: PARIS, Sept. 20 (UPI)Georges Goven, using an unorthodox doublestrung spaghetti racquet, upset Ilie Nastase, 64, 26, 64, in the first round of a $50,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: N. F. L. Record Is Set
description: The National Football League announced yesterday that an inhouse attendance record of 808,727 was set last Sunday and Monday, breaking the pre vious mark of 803,617 set on Oct. 10 and 11 of last year. The mark, which does not include noshows, means that each team was playing to an inhouse audience averaging 57,766.

title: Pop: Silver Convention
description: SILVER CONVENTION'S American debut at Roseland Dance City on Monday night was a curious affair, The Munichbased group, which consists of three women who sing and dance plus backing musicians, has sold millions of records in the United States. The best known and perhaps the most typical of its hits is Fly Robin Fly, in which the three women sing a few spare lines amid the chugging of a disco rhythm section and an innovative use of unison strings, which play swooping, rhythmically incisive lead lines. The record has become a disco evergreen, but the audience that gathered at Roseland to get its first look at the group was not large, and during most of the set the dance floor was deserted, with listeners standing selfconsciously behind tables or sitting in chairs around the perimeter of the hall.

title: Reed Begins His Task. Of Rebuilding Knicks
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 20A nervous Willis Reed stood before almost $2 million of salaried Knick talent today and said, Hey guys, I'm a rookie again.

title: Neil Amdur
description: On the West Coast, the gossip is about the Eastern Establishment, a Democratic Governor with Presidential ambitions in 1984, and the bankrupt city trying to sell itself as No. 1. On the East Coast, the talk is Hollywood thinkbigs. a Democratic Governor with Presidential ambitions in 1984 and the sprawling freeway city oversold on itself.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Exxon Corporation has awarded design and engineering contracts, totaling $110 million, for a pilot plant that is to convert 250 tons of coal a day into more than 600 barrels of ??quid fuel. Scheduled for completion in late 1979, the plant will be the biggest coal liquefaction facility in the United States.

title: FLORIDA POWER CHARGES FUEL OIL PRICE SWINDLE
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP)The Florida Power Corporation has sued its former president, four oil companies and a consultant, charging conspiracy to defraud the utility in a multimilliondollar fuel oil swindle.

title: New Justice Dept. Post Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)The Senate approved a bill today that would create a new post of associate attorney general as the third highestranking job in the Justice Department. The bill, passed without objection and sent to the House, had been requested by Attorney General Griffin M. Bell.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$10,000, mdn., 2YO, 6f.

title: Protesters of FuelAdjustment Fee Told Change in Law Is Not Likely
description: NEWARK, Sept. 20South Jersey residents who have been withholding a portion of their payments for gas and electricity in an effort to challenge fueladjustment charges were told today that the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners would listen to their arguments but that there was little likelihood that the charge would be eliminated.

title: Yale's Streit Starts Off At Top as Player of Week
description: Yale University's strong defense was the prime factor in its 109 Ivy League victory over Brown last Saturday, and one of the major defenders was Clint Streit, an end who was making his first varsity start. Streit, a letter winner a year ago as a reserve on the Elis' coleague champions, took over an end position vacated by the graduation of Pete Bonacum, an allIvy selection, and demonstrated his own credentials for stardom.

title: Tompkins Is Elected Chairman Of Citizens Budget Commission
