description: Rexford E. Tompkins, president and chief executive officer of the Dry Dock Savings Bank, yesterday was elected chairman of the board of the Citizens Budget Commission.

title: House, in Rebuff to Carter, Votes Funds for Clinch River Reactor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20In a decisive rebuff to President Carter, the House of Representatives today followed the Senate's lead and authorized funds for the Clinch River Breeder Reactor.

title: Vance Meets Foreign Minister
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)South Korean Foreign Minister Park Tong Jin met with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today on the Tongsun Park case and said there was an agreement that it would be better to put an end to the matter as soon as possible in a friendly way.

title: C.I.A. SOUGHT TO SPRAY DRUG ON PARTYGOERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A former Central Intelligence Agency employee told a Senate subcommittee today that he and another C.I.A. employee were sent to San Francisco in 1959 to lure unsuspecting people to a party at which the two agents were to spray the air with LSD25 as part of the agency's secret drugtesting program.

title: Carter Aides Say Lance's Future Is Still Uncertain After Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Despite continued public affirmations of faith in Bert Lance's personal integrity, some senior White House aides were privately uncertain today about the budget director's future in the Carter Administration.

title: Bond Prices Slip as Reaction Is Awaited on New Issues
description: Bond prices slipped a little yesterday as the credit markets nervously waited to see how the large volume of new issues for sale yesterday and today was received by investors. Most sold slowly.

title: White House Wants Postal Chief To Be Appointed by the President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Carter Administration proposed today that the President appoint the Postmaster General, returning a measure of Federal control to the postal Service after six years of independence.

title: The Magic of Mexican Food North of the Border
description: FOR some confounding reason known only to a few ztec gods, the authentic flavors of the Mexican kitchen, like certain fine wines and some exotic plants, do not travel well. They transport poorly through some curious dilution of tastes, some diminution of savor, some evanescence of essences.

title: Philippine Troops Raid a Rebel Area As Truce Falters
description: ISABELA, Philippines, Sept. 20 (AP)Troops supported by aircraft attacked suspected rebel forces today in a breakdown of the eightmonth truce between the Government and Moslem insurgents in the southern Philippines.

title: The Voting TradeOffs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20It would be comforting to think that political battles in Washington end like great football games, close but decisive, yet that is not the way the political game is played around here.

title: Public Works Grants Awarded
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Economic Development Administration today announced 10 grants, totaling $27,392,000, for New York City projects under provisions of the Public Works Employment Act of 1977, part of the president's economic stimulus package. The projects include highway and street reconstruction and resurfacing (about $9.4 million), sewer and water main work, renovation of school buildings and city court houses, repainting of the Queensboro Bridge, storm sewers and drainage for an industrial park, storm sewers and street work on Staten Island and boardwalk renovation.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Sept. 20, 1977

title: YOM KIPPUR
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended tomorrow for the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur. The city's public schools will be closed in its observance, as will be some suburban schools. All parking regulations remain in effect today.

title: JURY IN RAPE TRIAL MOVING INTO 3D DAY
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 20A Bergen County Court jury failed for the second day today to reach a verdict in the trial of a 25yearold South Carolina man accused of kidnapping two sisters in Paramus last Feb. 7 and raping one of them.

title: Grape Recipes
description: Concord grapes are In season now and available in many fruit and vegetables markets.

title: Shut down of Steel Works Stuns Young stown
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 20Since before this century began, the destiny of millions of men like Jim Woods, and of the steelmaking area that has been their home, has lain in mills like the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company's Campbell Works, a mammoth group of grayrust buildings and thickets of smokestacks and cylindrical blast furnaces stretching along the Mahoning River between green hills with workers houses marching the sides.

title: Vietnam Is Admitted to the U.N. As 32d General Assembly Opens
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20The 32d General Assembly opened today and approved the admission of Vietnam to the United Nations with a record number of 105 countries cosponsoring its application for membership.

title: N.F.L. Grievance Hearing Set
description: The National Football League's fourman PlayersOwners Relations Committee, will hear a grievance in Washington Friday involving the New England Patriots and Leon Gray and John Hannah, offensive linemen. Gray and Hannah have left the Patriots in contract disputes. The PlayersOwners Relations Committee is composed of officials Wellington Mara of the New York Giants and Dan Rooney of the Pittsburgh Steelers and players Gene Upshaw of the Oakland Raiders and Len Hauss of the Washington Redskins.

title: NBC, CBS to Televise; Carter News Parley
description: NBCTV and CBSTV plan live television coverage of President Carter's news conference today, which is scheduled to start at 3 P.M. There will be a rebroadcast on WNET, Channel 13, at 7 o'clock tonight.

title: Notoriety Haunts RealLife Sam
description: YONKERS, Sept. 20Earlier this week, Samuel Carr, named by the suspected Son of Sam murderer as the subject of his obsession, ventured out of his home with an old friend to go to a Kiwanis Club luncheon. It was one of the first social functions Mr. Carr had attended since the Aug. 10 arrest of David R. Berkowitz as the .44caliber killer.

title: 3 Pamphlets
description: For detailed listings of where to find the freshest in everything from apples to zucchini in the New York area, three pamphlets are available annually. Each lists names and addresses of pickyourown farms in the area, along with usual harvest dates.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Mexican Loan's Terms Disclosed
description: Mexico's $1.2 billion loan from a group of international banks, which was disclosed earlier this month, will carry an Interest rate 1 percentage points above the rate at which banks in London borrow from each other, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, one of the adviser banks, disclosed yesterday. The term of the loan will be seven years, with a threeyear grace period.

title: Birth Rate Among Girls 15 to 17 Rises in Puzzling 10Year Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Citing what it called a puzzling trend, a new Government study of birth statistics has found that the rate of childbearing among American girls in their midteens has risen slightly over the last decade.

title: Senators Criticize MIGRepair Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Four members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have criticized the State Department's handling of a recent decision favoring the sending of American technicians abroad to help rehabilitate the Egyptian Air Force.

title: Opera Buff in U.N. Spotlight
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20Deputy Foreign Minister Lazar Mojsov of Yugoslavia, who was elected today as President of the 1977 General Assembly, is a career diplomat who has been both a journalist and jurist and is a passionate opera buff. A few years ago, when he was assigned here as Belgrade's chief delegate, he managed in one season to attend 80 performances of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided Into the stock's closing price. All prices are in dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dindicates new low.

title: Recipes for a Mexican Fiesta
description: Cocktail Tostadas

title: POLLUTION OF WATER IN JERSEY SCORED
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20More than 12,000 New Jersey industries are discharging pollutants, some of them toxic, into the water systems that provide much of the state's drinkingwater supply, the State Environmental Commissioner, Rocco D. Ricci, said today.

title: The Dime Phone Call's Time Is Up
description: If Ma Bell and the staff of New York State's Public Service Commission have their way, the price of a local payphone call in the state will double to 20 cents. A preliminary commission report approved the increase last week, and the commissioners will consider the 20cent call next month as part of New York Telephone's request for a rate increase.

title: Ballet: New Look at Nutcracker
description: AMERICAN Ballet Theater opened a miniature fall season of ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with Mikhail Baryshnikov's recent staging of The, Nutcracker. This in prospect is not the dreariest ballet repertory New York City has ever witnessedafter all this same company earlier in the year gave us a grand gala season consisting of nothing but Copplia and Gisellebut the next two weeks still sadly represent dance conservatism gone slightly beserk.

title: FORECLOSURE ACTION ON COOP CITY BEGUN
description: New York City began foreclosure proceedings yesterday against Coop City, the financially troubled housing project in the northeast Bronx, but assured the 60,000 people who live there that the action posed no immediate threat to them.

title: Outlook Held Bleak For Manufacturers Of Atomic Reactors
description: American manufacturers of nuclear reactors are in deep trouble. Their slumping markets show no signs of recovery, and the industry itself now facing the disintegration of skills and production capability built up since World War II.

title: Lack of Atlantic City Policemen Foreseen
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20 (AP)This seashore resort cannot guarantee the safety of casino gambling patrons next year unless the state limit on municipal spending is lifted to permit the hiring of more policemen here, the city's Public Safety Commissioner official warned today.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Tuesday. Sept. 20. 1977

title: Books of The Times
description: IHAD A DREAM just before awakening the other morning. It was one of those nagging repetitive dreams that seem to have no narrative sequence whatsoever. When I awoke from it, all I could recall was DayGlo colors, a skewed perspective that might have come out of a poster by Peter Max and the vague sensation of having flown a kite. Yet there was one distinctive association. It was with a book I read through twice the evening before, Annie Dillard's Holy the Firm, a brief but intense religious meditation by the author of the Pulitzer Prizewinning Pilgrim at Tinker Creek. Moreover, When I skimmed back through Holy the Firm, I found a specific passage that I associated with my dream.

title: ALBERT F. TEGEN, 75, FORMER HEAD OF G.P.U.
description: Albert F. Tegen, former president of the General Public Utilities Corporation, died of a heart attack yesterday at his daughter's home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 75 years old and had lived in Manhattan and Bronxville before moving to Del Ray Beach, Fla., after his retirement in 1967.

title: Shutdown of Steel Works Stuns Youngstown
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 20Since before this century began, the destiny of millions of men like Jim Woods, and of the steelmaking area that has been their home, has lain in mills like the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company's Campbell Works, a mammoth group of grayrust buildings and. thickets of smokestacks and cylindrical blast furnaces stretching along the, Mahoning River between green hills with workers' houses marching up the sides.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: Drawings by Niculas Asclu

title: Saccharin Ban Delay Voted by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 20 (Reuters)A bill to delay the proposed ban on the use of saccharin for at least 18 months was approved today by the House Commerce Committee and sent to the full House.

title: Paul O'Dwyer Elects to Leave His Old Sod, Politics, and Is Moving On to New Ground
description: On the morning after, Paul O'Dwyer's office looked much the same as always, a highceilinged room that, with its mahogany and its mirrors, the antique desks and the flags and the mementos and its random gathering of books and papers, echoes the informal dignity of its occupant.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Purcell and Dunne Meet In First Attempt to Ease Republican Split in Nassau
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 20State Senator John R. Dunne and Francis T. Purcell, Republicans who are scheduled to oppose one another, as well as the incumbent, Ralph G. Caso, in the Nassau County Executive race in November, met today in preliminary talks that could avoid a threeway split in party ranks.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In the early part of this century, and certainly as late as 1930 in Chicago, the term Clubhouse Sandwich would appear on menus. Now one sees it reduced to club everywhere, including cookbooks; Can you tell anything of the origin of the term clubhouse and possibly which region first widely made it?

title: Judge Tries to Avert Willowbrook Strike; Gets Officials to Delay Layoffs One Month
description: In an effort to avert a strike at the state's Willowbrook Developmental Center in Staten Island, Federal Judge John R. Bartels yesterday called state and union officials to a conference in his Brooklyn chambers.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, September 21, 1977

title: Ohio Nun Slain at Convent
description: DAYTON. Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP)A nun was shot to death last night when she went to the door of a convent after hearing a gunshot outside, the authorities said. The police said that a man had been taken into custody, but his name was not disclosed. Sister Donna Blaul, 34 years old, was shot once in the chest at St. Agnes Convent, according to the Montgomery County coroner's office.

title: Gov. Blanton Scored on Pardon Vow
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 20 (AP)Gov. Ray Blanton, who vetoed Tennessee's death penalty law, has drawn the ire of some politicians and newspapers by promising to pardon a man convicted of double murder who works as a photographer for the state.

title: BIRTH RATE IS HIGHER AMONG GIRLS 15 TO 17
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Citing what it called a puzzling trend, a new Government study of birth statistics has found that the rate of childbearing among American girls in their midteens has risen slightly over the last decade.

title: Letters: On Tax Reform
description: To the Editor.

title: SENATE PANEL KILLS BID TO TAX AUTOS USING EXCESS FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Carter's energy program was dealt another setback tdoay when the Senate Finance Committee killed his proposal to tax automobiles that use gasoline inefficiently.

title: BENJAMIN L. WEBSTER, 79, AN INDUSTRIAL DESIGNER
description: Benjamin Lawrence Webster, an industrial designer for the Norman bel Geddes Company and later for his own concern, Webster & Company, died last Friday at his home in Woodstock, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: TV: Killing Affair Packs Power
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, not too long ago, Petula Clark, a white woman, placed her hand casually on the arm of Harry Belafonte, a black man, during a music special, and television was bombarded with racist outrage. Tonight at 9 o'clock on CBSTV, in a movie called A Killing Affair, Elizabeth Montgomery climbs into bed with O. J. Simpson for an explicitly portrayed adulterous affair, and, presumably, most of the national audience will remain properly cool. Television has a curious way of telling us intriguing things about ourselves as a society.

title: No Feet Being Dragged in Effort To Shift U.S. Open Site for 1978
description: Despite reports of lingering community opposition, groundbreaking ceremonies for the new home of the United States Open in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park are scheduled to take place around Oct. 6.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)The Senate joined the House today in approving legislation to make it easier for coal miners to qualify for black lung benefits.

title: Barbed Wire, Not Roses, Under the Branch
description: LONDON  A great and ominous change is taking place in the affairs of this country, and in the wake of its most recent manifestations I make no apology for raising once more a subject to which I have devoted some attention in the past  that of the delicate balance between freedom and order in society.

title: Tongsun Park Case Is Now Major Topic In Papers in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 20There were no developments in the Tongsun Park scandal here today. But that did not stop the scandal from dominating the news pages, newscasts and conversations of many South Koreans.

title: Careers
description: Every employee needs a builtin fire alarm system to alert him to the possibility of being fired, according to Robert Half, president of Robert Half Personnel Agencies.

Article 6  No Title
In Memoriam
description: FECTERJack. Remembering with gratitude. Kathleen Mundin, President Children's Caner Fund of America, 15 E. 67 Str. NYC

title: Article 5  No Title
description: In Britain, there is great public concern about the increasing use of force in pursuit of political ends. The author wants the Government to destroy the growing tyranny of these minorities.

title: Chess
description: While the old established gambits such as the Kings, Danish or Evans, are rarities these days, there is no scarcity of pawn sacrifices in contemporary openings.

title: CARLINO'S SON AND WIFE MISSING IN FLIGHT ON L. I.
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20  Joseph F. Carlino Jr., the 36yearold son of the former Nassau County Republican chairman and former Assembly Speaker, and his 24yearold wife, Cathy, have been missing since early last Saturday when their singleengine airplane disappeared while in a flight over eastern Long Island, officials said today.

title: The Labor Scene
description: A. H. Raskin reports that organized labor has quietly shelved its opposition to moves in Congress to outlaw forced retirement based on age. Page D2.

title: A.M.C. Employees Ratify Contract
description: DETROIT, Sept. 20 Employees of the American Motors Corporation have ratified their new oneyear contract with the United Automobile Workers that covers more than 10,000 workers, the union said today. The contract includes ageneral pay increase of 30 to 39 cents an hour for all workers, a 15cent special increase for skilled workers and improvements in benefits and pensions,

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21,1977

title: Bonn's Terrorist Curbs Facing Test in Court
description: BONN, Sept. 20The administrators of West Germany s justice system agreed today that any contacts between captured terrorists and people outside prison must remain suspended during the present emergency over terrorist acts.

title: U.S. Seeks a CeaseFire
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Administration officials said today that the United States had made intensive diplomatic efforts in recent days to help bring about a ceasefire in southern. Lebanon. Despite the continuing volatility in the region, the fighting was reported by officials to have eased considerably from the level of recent days.

title: Filipino Nurses in Poisoning Case Seek Reversal of Guilty Verdict
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21 (UPI)Attorneys for two Filipino nurses convicted in the nonfatal poisoning of five patients at the Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Hospital have filed motions seeking reversal of the guilty verdicts or a new trial.

title: Cuban Quintet to Open Tour Against Marquette
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 (AP)The Cuban national basketball team will open a ninecity tour of the United States by playing Marquette, the defending National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, in an exhibition game at the Milwaukee Arena Nov. 12, the university announced today.

title: Adventure in an Orchard
description: Fresh air. Fresh tastes. An autumnal awakening. A bargain. They all await the adventuresome souls willing to take a day out to pick their own apples, be it a bushel or a peck.

title: U.S. Certifies 2,500 Steel Workers For Special Unemployment Help
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)  The Labor Department certified more than 2.500 steal workers as eligible to apply for special unemployment benefits today because their jobs either were lost or threatened by increased steel imports.

Labor Ends Fight on Moves to Bar Forced Age Retirement
description: Organized labor has quietly shelved its opposition to moves in Congress to outlaw forced retirement based on age.

title: Technology
description: The microelectronic roller coaster, carrying prices down and down until only a handful of highvolume manufacturers survive, may be operating in the digital watch business even more ruthlessly than it did with pocket calculators.

title: Advertising
description: Preliminary findings from a pilot study by Alan R. Nelson Research indicate that the most potent form of communications affecting consumer buying decisions is one even the wealthiest advertiser can't buyfavorable wordofmouth reports. Isn't that sad?

title: Israel's Small Settlements in Arab Lands Are Issues of Dispute at Home and With U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20There are currently 77 of them, most of them modest Jewish settlements engaged in farming and light industry and ringed by forbidding looking security fences.

description: Well, it's backtoschool time. And everyone reacts in a different way. Take Susan Schwartz, for example, a sophomore at Bayside High School:

title: Strong Thief Lifts Jets' Weights
description: A weight lifter without his barbells is like a bagel without lox, and that is why Paul Mastropasqua is forlorn these days.

title: Counties to Get Voter Message to Deliver
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20The State Election Law Enforcement Commission will deliver 500word statements by the major and minor candidates for Governor to the 21 County Clerks tomorrow, but it's doubtful that the voters will get the chance to read them.

title: SENATE PANEL KILLS BID TO TAX AUTOS USING EXCESS FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Carter's energy program was dealt another setback tdoay when the Senate Finance Committee killed his proposal to tax automobiles that use gasoline inefficiently.

title: The U.N. Today
Dodgers Clinch Title
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the San Francisco Giants, 31, last night and won the National League West title. Story on Page B12.

title: Federal Workers to Get Raise
description: WASHINGTON, Septs. 20 (AP)Presilent Carter announced today that he was granting a 7.05 percent pay increase, efective Oct. 1, to 3.4 million Federal whitecollar workers and members of the firmed services. The acrosstheboard raise followed a recommendation made by Ray Marshall, the Secretary of Labor; Bert Lance, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the Civil Servce Commission. The raises will cost about $3.4 billion.

title: Her Name HelpedSo Did Her Talent
description: GERALDINE CHAPLIN sat crosslegged on a couch in her St. Regis suite, dressed entirely in black except for one baggy beige sock. Her jetblack hair hung limply down her back, and her face was free of makeup, except for a touch of black mascara. She looked very starkalmost as stark as she looks in her current movie, Cra, in which she plays a Spanish pianistturned housewife who dies from uterine cancer.

title: 3 Onondaga Officials Arraigned for Coercing County Workers for G.O.P. Contributions
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 20Three Onondaga County officials were arraigned today on charges that they conspired over the last seven years to coerce county employees into making contributions to the Onondaga County Republican Party.

title: Dollar Sets New Low Against Swiss Franc
description: The dollar hit a record low in heavy foreign exchange trading against the Swiss franc in Zurich and dropped sharply in New York but trading in other world currencies was described as fairly light and trendless yesterday,The Associated Press reported.

title: Steiner Violin Sparkles
description: OLIVER STEINER, a violinist who teaches at the Eastman School of Music and who made his New York debut in 1975, came to Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night to play another program. With Barry Snyder, also an Eastman faculty member, at the piano, Mr. Steiner offered Beethoven's Sonata in E flat (Op. 12, No. 3), Faure's Sonata in A, Mozart's Sonata in G (K. 301), Bruch's Kol Nidrei (in a Steiner edition) and Wieniawski's Polonaise Brillante in D (Op. 4).

title: Television
description: Morning

title: People and Business
description: Timm Crull, formerly senior vice president and a director of the Carnation Company of Los Angeles, has been named president and chief operating officer of Norton Simon Inc.

title: No Nothin'
description: A black youth sits on his Harlem stoop, thinking quietly.

title: What Garth Hath Wrought...
description: Talk about strange bedfellows. Not more than an hour after Edward I. Koch thanked his supporters in a hotel ballroom, Billy Carter stood in a back cubby of David Garth's Fifth Avenue headquarters sucking on a gin and tonic, Joe Garagiola sat slumped and looking disconsolate on an orange sofa, two money men  each wearing black wingtipped shoes and pinstriped suitsflashed 300watt smiles and Gabe Pressman was on the telephone, urgent.

title: Cuomo's Pledge to Stay in Race Contains a Small Escape CIause
description: Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo insisted yesterday, as he did in conceding defeat to Representative Edward I. Koch, that he would stay in the mayoral race as the Liberal Party nominee, but he left himself a narrow escape hatch.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$5,500, cl., 3YO and up, 6f.

title: Pentagon Challenges Senator Hart's Charges of NATO Weakness
description: The military hierarchy in the pentagon, both civilian officials and senior service officers, has challenged Senator Gary Hart's criticisms of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's plans for meeting a Soviet attack in Europe The Colorado Democrat charged in a speech that the American defense establishment had failed to deal with what he considered crucial issues of strategy, organization and technological trends within the alliance.

title: Private Lives
description: HE HAD BEEN to a movie. This was not entirely a mistake, even though they didn't have any buttered popcorn. They didn't have any buttered popcorn because the occasion was a screening. Movies are often screened in New York, in small private theaters without buttered popcorn, for small groups of people who are thought to be opinion makers, before the general public gets its gross chance. All his life he had wanted to be an opinion maker. What fun, to sit in a dark room surrounded by opinions being made. You can hear the brains ticking, like alarm clocks or timers for threeminute eggs.

title: Bomb in Spain Kills One
description: BARCELONA, Spain. Sept. 20 (Reuters) A package bomb killed one man and injured 10 when it exploded in the offices of a magazine specializing in political commentary and photographs of nude women, the police said today. The dead man was identified as the building porter who had received the package and was taking it to the newsroom of El Papus, a weekly magazine, when it exploded.

title: Orioles Win With Palmer, Trail by 3
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (AP)Jim Palmer, with homerun support from Eddie Murray and Rich Dauer, posted his fifth consecutive victory and kept the fading hopes of the Baltimore Orioles alive with a 52 decision over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Tuesday, September 20, 1977

title: Too Many Goalies on Ice For Islanders, Rangers
description: The New York Islanders will open their exhibition hockey schedule with two games each against Philadelphia, Vancouver and Buffaloand that fact had Glenn (Chico) Resch, the Islanders' garrulous goalie, laughing yesterday.

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Dodgers Clinch Crown By Beating Giants, 31
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 (AP)The Los Angeles Dodgers clinched the National League West Division title tonight behind Rick Monday's tworun homer and the pitching of Tommy John and lance Rautzhan in a 31 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Congress Is Puzzled Over Role in Aiding SteelImports Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Breakfasting with steel company executives, Congressmen from steelproducing districts shouted approval today of legislation to do something about steel imports.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Wrigley Will Filed in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (UPI)The will of the late Phillip K. Wrigley, the chewing gum magnate, has been filed in California probate court because of property in California that produces $18,000 a year. The Wrigley family attorney, James M. Cowley, presented the will for probate yesterday to Commissioner Franklin E. Dana of Los Angeles Superior Court but did not specify the location of the California property. The bulk of the $60.3 million estate is already being handled by the Chicago courts, with Mr. Wrigley's son, William, acting as executor in both states.

title: Cuba Releasing 16 Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (Reuters)The first Americans to be released by Cuba since relations between Washington and Havana improved will arrive in the United States on Thursday, the State Department said today. A charter flight bringing 16 United States citizens and 39 dependents will land at Homestead Air Force base south of Miami, a spokesman said.

title: World News Briefs
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 20 (AP) Prime Minister John Vorster today announced the dissolution of Parliament and provincial councils and called for general elections Nov. 30.

title: Rules in Politics Changing
description: Many of the rules and traditions of New York City government and politics are changing, and the decisive victories of Representative Edward I, Koch and State Senator Carol Bellamy in the Democratic runoff primary not only dramatized these often fundamental shifts but could also accelerate them. Both candidates came from narrow political bases  almost political obscurity in the case of Miss Bellamy  to defeat three of the bestknown politicians in this city: Mayor Beame, Bella S. Abzug and City Council President Paul O'Dwyer. Mr. Koch led in the initial primary and in the runoff defeated Mario M. Cuomo, who had the support of Governor Carey and of the Liberal Party and who was even better financed than an incumbent Mayor.

title: Dining Out: Smokers' Section?
description: SHOULD restaurants be required to have separate areas for nonsmokers? ASH (Action on Smoking and Health), which has 30,000 contributors, and the National Interagency Council on Smoking and Health, composed of 34 organizations, want such segregated sections to be required by law. Many would extend such a law to ban smoking completely in restaurants and all public places.

title: Doyle Dane Divides Creative Leadership
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach, which stresses the word creative in its advertising product, traditionally has had only one creative director. And the man who has most recently had that title is Marvin Honig, a 41yearold executive vice president.

title: Crime Figure on Trial
description: Anthony Salerno, a reputed figure in organized crime, went on trial in Manhattan on Federal charges of incometax evasion. John S. Siffert, the prosecutor, said Mr. Salerno had reported an income of about $40,000 a year but had spent about $100,000 a year from 1971 through 1974, Roy M. Cohn, the defense lawyer, said Mr. Salerno was a gambler being attacked for his standard of living. Judge Whitman Knapp is presiding over the Federal District Court trial.

title: Amin Bans All but Three Christian Churches as Risks
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 20 (AP)President Id?? Amin today banned all but three Christian churches from operating in Uganda an the ground that they are a security risk.

title: Canada and U.S. Sign Accord to Build Gas Pipeline
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 20Canada and the United States formally signed the agreement today to construct a multibillion dollar pipeline to carry Alaskan natural gas through Canada to American users, and possibly to transport Canadian gas to consumers in southern Canada at a later stage.

title: Carey Meets With Aides on Role In Race Between Koch and Cuomo
description: Governor Carey conferred yesterday with his top aides to weigh his political options in the mayoral race amid growing indications he would endorse the Democratic nominee, Representative Edward Kochand abandon Mario M. Cuomo, who won the Liberal Party line with the Governor's help.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state lottery office reported new records in receipts, prizes and payments to the state for the year ended June 30.

title: Trifecta Halted By 17 Scratches In New Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 20 With 17 late scratches decimating fields, the Meadowlands race track tonight was forced to cancel trifecta wagering in the third and ninth thoroughbred races.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
SHARON STEEL HEAD, SON AND DAUGHTER ACCUSED BY S. E. C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Victor Posner, the controversial multimillionaire and chairman of the Sharon Steel Corporation, and his son and daughter of charging more than $1.7 million worth of personal housing, services and travel in corporate aircraft and cars to the companies he and his family have controlled.

title: Look Who's Polluting Us Now
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce is perfectly right to complain that the Federal Government has made a big thing of industrial violations while ignoring its own role as a polluter. The Environmental Protection Agency admits that 25 percent of all Federal installations requiring discharge permits are not in compliance with the Clean Water Act, dumping wastes of one sort another into adjacent streams as if no laws applied. About 600 private industrial plants are in the same scofflaw position, as are the facilities of 2,000 cities and towns. But they are subject to prosecution and penalties. Nothing has been done to apply comparable sanctions to Federal agencies.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: People in Sports
description: E. J. (Buzzie) Bavasi, his team in turmoil after a year of injuries and freeagent frustrations, retired last night as president of the San Diego Padres. The 61yearold Bavasi will remain as a consultant for the rest of the season.

title: City Winners and Losers
description: Edward Koch is the big winner, of course, and Mario Cuomo the big loser in their joust for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York City. That the contest came down to these lesserknown challengers, and also produced a landslide victory for Carol Bellamy over the familiar Paul O'Dwyer in the race for City Council President, was testimony to a dramatic and needed shakeup in the city's politics. The city itself stands to gain from this surge for a new beginning.

title: Hotel Workers Strike in Bermuda
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 20 (AP)Hotel workers have struck the 100 hostelries on this midAtlantic resort island, forcing some visitors to carry their own bags but generally not disturbing essential services. At issue is a dispute between the hotel division of the Bermuda Industrial Union and a small nondemoninational religious retreat that has refused to recognize the union.

title: Richard F. Merrifield, 72; Essayist, Novelist, Artist Also Edited 3 Magazines
description: Richard Forrester Merrifield of Keene N.H., essayist, novelist, editor, artist and musician, died there Saturday at Cheshire Hospital. His age was 72.

title: Deficit Is Reported For Addressograph
description: The AddressographMultigraph Corporation, a leading manufacturer of duplicating machines, reported yesterday sharp losses for the quarter and fiscal year ended July 31 reflecting writeoffs and other special actions designed to improve future profitability.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication must include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Because of the large volume of mail received, we regret that we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: WAGNER IS EXPECTED TO GET G.O.P. BACKING
description: The Republican Party last night cleared the way for City Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr. to become the party's candidate for Manhattan Borough President by nominating its original Borough President candidate for a judgeship.

title: 21 Toy Soldiers Auctioned for $1,392
description: LONDON. Sept. 20A Chicago businessman, Alvin Whitehead, today paid the equivalent of $1,392 for 21 toy soldiers at an auction here. In 1938, when the figures representing a Royal Marines band were made, they cost $1.50 a set.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dindicates new low.

title: John L. Lewis on a New Stage
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20The spirit of John L. Lewis, longtime president of the United Mine Workers, has come back to life again in a oneman stage show produced by organized labor that had its world premiere here last night.

title: Rules in Politics Changing
description: Many of the rules and traditions of New York City government and politics are changing, and the decisive victories of Representative Edward I. Koch and State Senator Carol Bellamy in the Democratic runoff primary not only dramatized these often fundamental shifts but could also accelerate them.

title: Nets Cut Jim Fox
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 20The Nets opened their training camp today at Manhattanville College by releasing Jim Fox, the 6foot10inch center. Fox had failed the electrocardiogram that was part of the preseason physical examinations.

title: Cosmos Lose In China, Win Friends Here
description: The Cosmos made some friends on both the eastern and western fronts yesterday.

title: Los Angeles Teachers Get Raise
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UPI)Teachers headed for classes today with a pay increase granted on the eve of the start of school for nearly 600,000 pupils in the nation's secondlargest school district. School officials reached agreement last night with the United Teachers of Los Angeles on a six percent raise and increases in benefits.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: There's a new piece of jewelry designed every minute but only a few of those minutes count in the long run. No one is saying that the Fantasy collection from California, now at Henri Bendel, is going to make any permanent impression on the style of the nation, but at the moment it's timely, amusing and decorative, which is as much as one can logically ask from costume jewelry. The pieces are made of porcelain and most of them are faces, with real hair or feathers or hats. There are, as well, porcelain legs with shoes painted on them, arms and hands. They're attached to ribbon cords to loop at will. The prices go from $17 to $55 and the main floor is where to find them.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Aug. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Merola Seeks Psychiatric Tests For Man Held as Son of Sam
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx yesterday asked that a panel of psychiatrists from Bellevue Hospital be appointed to conduct a new series of psychiatric examinations of David R. Berkowitz, the man accused of being the .44caliber killer, also known as the Son of Sam.

title: Charles B. G. Murphy Dies at 71; Donated Millions to Aid Psychiatry
description: Charles B. G. Murphy, a philanthropist who aided the mental health field, died yesterday in Livingston Memorial Hospital in Livingston, Mont., while on a fishing vacaton. He was 71 years old and lived at 610 Park Avenue.

title: Candelaria Posts 18th as Pirates Down Mets, 42, on Robinson Hit
description: It's not clear why 3,372 people left the warmth and dryness of their homes to pay their way into chilly and damp Shea Stadium last night to see the Pittsburgh Pirates' 42 victory over the New York Melts.

title: Pop: Robust James Talley
description: JAMES TALLEY, President and Mrs. Carter's favorite country singer, was in Manhattan on Monday for a onenight appearance at the Lone Star Cafe. As the late show got under way, shortly after midnight, Mr. Talley surveyed the halffull house and remarked in a drawnout drawl, It looks like this is going to be a, laidback set.

title: LAOS FACES THREAT OF FOOD SNORTAGES
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 19 (Reuters)Laos is facing severe food shortages next year if international efforts are not made to help it now.

title: ABC Dominates Ratings
description: ABCTV HAS JUMPED into a strong lead in the new television season, having for the second week in a row overwhelmed its rivals in the ratings competition. But while ABC's potency the first week derived from a 12hour serial. Washington: Behind Closed Doors, its dominance last week was achieved by regular weekly series, the socalled meat and potatoes of the industry.

title: Bridge
description: On rare occasions an imaginative defensive stroke will serve to defeat an apparently impregnable contract. Almost invariably the players continue on their way, totally oblivious of a missed opportunity. In a strong game, a perceptive post  mortemist may uncover the truth, too late to affect the result.

title: Former Track Owner to Testify
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Sept. 20 (UPI)Eugene Mori, former owner of the Gardent State Park race track has agreed to testify in court about alleged secret Swiss bank accounts set up by his father. Mr. Mori is scheduled to appear in Superior Court tomorrow for a hearing on the settlement of his father's estate, estimated at up to $40 million. The Bank of New Jersey, executor of the estate, .has been trying to get Mr. Mori to testify since he first refused to answer questions last February.

title: French Reds Ease Industry Policy
description: PARIS, Sept. 20 (Reuters)The French Communist Party offered concessions today on a controversial nationalization issue in an effort to settle an election policy dispute that is dividing the country's leftwing opposition alliance.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: In America, everybody who's anybody has got them some money.

Letters
description: Credit Counseling

title: Koch Avoids Acting Like Mayor, But Presses His Transition Plans
description: Edward I. Koch said yesterday that I'm not the governmentinexile.

title: Lakeville Miss Takes Matron, Returns $7.20
description: A muddy track at Belmont Park failed to prevent the handicappers from correctly choosing the top three finishers yesterday in the $86,725 Matron Stakes. The only mistake for the form players was that the onetwothree finish was the exact reverse of the betting.

title: Fire Strikes at Fisherman's Wharf
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 (AP)Six persons were injured today in a gas explosion and fire at a twostory building on Pier 43 at Fisherman's Wharf, officials said. Thousands of tourists watched as firemen fought the blaze at the headquarters of the Crowley Maritime Corporation. Three of the victims appeared to be seriously burned.

title: Foreign Auto Prices Rise Here
description: MADRID, Sept. 21(AP)hrysler and Renault raised prices 6 percent to 7 percent today on passenger cars in this country., leading the Spanish automobile industry in a new round of price increases Citroen and Seat, Spain's largest automaker, were expected to follow suit soon, industry sources said. Chrysler set a new price of $2,988 for its Simca 12001 model and Ford put a price tag of $2,761 on its Fiesta moeel. Renault's four models will cost $2,047.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: ENERGY FINANCE UNIT IS BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Senate Finance Committee, which has already made clear its opposition to a proposed rebate to consumers of domestic oil tax revenues, indicated today that it would favor diversion of the receipts to an energy finance corporation and to mass transit.

title: The Viking Bed: Carved To Order
description: We've had water beds, tree trunk beds, twig beds, and even minkfur beds, but not, until now, the Viking bed.

title: Israel Would Grant Naval Base to U.S., House Panel Is Told
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Foreign Minister Moshe Davan of Israel has told members of Congress that his Government would be prepared to allow the United States to establish a naval base at Haifa for use by the Sixth Fleet.

title: DEFICIT IN NEW YORK PUT AT $350 MILLION, 4 TIMES PROJECTION
description: New York City faces a budget deficit next year of at least $350 million, four times greater than the $86 million that Mayor Beame has projected, but fiscal officials who disclosed the gap yesterday said they hoped it could be offset with additional revenue generated by an expanding economy.

description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

Vegetable Soup Bubbling for 2d Antibigotry TV Series
description: With Woody the Spoon, Max the Marvelous X Machine and Max's nemesis, Long John Spoilsport, all taking bows, Gordon Ambach, the New York Educate Commissioner, yesterday announced the second series of Vegetable Soup, a children's television program produced by the State Education Department to help combat ethnic stereotypes and promote racial Understanding.

title: Kissinger Visits State Department To Confer With Secretary Vance
description: WASINGTOHN, Sept. 21 (Reuters)Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger visited the tate Department today to review the international situation with his successor. Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Wage Loss Is Put at $5 Million In the July 1314 Power Failure
description: Federal statistical samplings indicate that New York City workers lost about $5 million in wages because of the July 1314 electricity blackout.
