title: Postal Service Rules Out a Plan To Eliminate Saturday Service
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 21 (AP)The United States Postal Service has no immediate plans of going to a fiveday week for mail delivery by eliminating Saturday service, the Deputy Postmaster General, William F. Bolger, told reporters today before a national meeting of the National Postal Forum.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: NUDISTS PROTEST VOTE TO SHUT COAST BEACH
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 21Large numbers of nudists gathered on Black's Beach today in a gesture of protest over an election referendum that called for their eviction from what, for three years, has been the country's only beach where nude bathing was officially sanctioned.

title: 16 Northeast and Midwest States Find Inequities in Defense Outlays
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Northeastern governors and a bipartisan coalition of 204 Congressmen from the Northeast and the Middle West charged today that Defense Department spending policies had aggravated economic problems in their regions while stimulating booms in the South and the West.

title: The Pennant Race
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: There's More to Sophia Loren Than Being a Sex Symbol
description: SOPHIA LOREN turned 43 on Tuesday. The big smile on her face as she sat on a brocade sofa in her Pierre Hotel suite indicated that she didn't really mind, and she saidseveral timesthat she didn't really mind, because she realizes one can't be a sex symbol forever, that there will come a time in her life when she has to get by on her talent alone.

title: World News Briefs
description: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines, Sept. 21 (AP)Fighting spread through the Sulu Archipelago today in violation of a ceasefire that had kept government troops and Moslem rebels apart for nine months.

title: LEBANON SAYS ISRAEL OCCUPIES 6 KEY HILLS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21Lebanese security sources said today that Israeli forces had strengthened positions they had seized in southern Lebanon yesterday in support of Lebanese Christian militiamen and now occupied six strategic hilltops.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING FIRES IN SMALL AUTOS' TANKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)The Transportation Department announced today that it had begun a major investigation of gasoline tank fires in all subcompact cars sold in this country.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Furniture/Art

title: $4 Million Awaiided Against Merrill
description: Jung Ja Malandris, a 34yearold Korean immigrant, yesterday won a $4 million damage award against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the nation's largest brokerage firm, as a result of a $31,000 loss on securities in 1973. Merrill Lynch promptly said it would appeal the verdict.

title: Providence Area Picks Successor To Its Imprisoned Representative
description: PROVIDENCE, Sept. 21 (AP)Leonard E. Walker, a Democrat, has overwhelmingly defeated a young Republican opponent to replace the imprisoned WilliamH. Bailey as State Representative from the 19th District.

title: Foreign Banks Putting Acute Accent on Branches in U.S.
description: It was Hungarian Night on New York's international banking cocktail circuit, and Martin E. Stroethoff, the man from DG Bank in Frankfurt, was making his way around the tables of stuffed cabbage and Bull's Blood red wine. He started in on some arithmetic.

title: Selective Compassion
description: PRINCETON. N. J.We often think of people as either compassionate or not compassionate and regard the former as morally superior. But compassion is usually selective, and this poses problems. The most striking example of selective compassion was Hitler. He was a vegetarian and opposed vivisection of animals. His case was extreme, but the syndrome is typical. Millions of people have more compassion for fetuses than for starving and abused children, not to speak of their mothers.

title: U.S DOUBTS LEBANON IS FACING A FULL WAR
description: Defense Department analysts say they doubt that the present skirmishing in southern Lebanon will expend into fullscale fighting.

title: ATOM SALES CONTROLS ARE SET BY 15 NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Fifteen nuclear exporting countries reached agreement today in London on tightened guidelines on transfer of technology that are aimed at curbing the spread of atomic weapons, United States officials reported here.

title: Architectural Drawings Make Comeback to Respectability
description: IT IS TEMPTING to attribute the enormous surge of interest in architectural drawing in the last couple of years to the depressed state of the architectural profession itselfif no one hires an architect to build, he can at least make pictures.

title: Sound
description: WALTER STANTON, the manufacturer of phonograph cartridges, occasionally invites members of the press and audio industry for leisurely outings on his boat.

title: Laker Wants to Add Flights
description: LONDON, Sept. 21 (Reuters)Freddie Laker, the British airline owner, asked Britain's Civil Aviation Authority today to lift restrictions on the number of nofrills bargain kytrain flights he can operate between London and New York. Mr. Laker said that lifting the restrictions that limit him to one flight o day each way would give him a better chance to compete against the major airlines.

title: PRICES HOLD STEADY IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets held stable yesterday as the Treasury sold $3.14 billion of twoyear notes at an average rate of 6.74 percent and a subsidiary of the Bell System sold bonds that were priced to yield 8.03 percent, a touch lower than the rate on a similar issue sold one week earlier.

title: IRMA DUNCAN DEAD; DISCIPLE OF ISADORA
description: Irma Duncan, a foster daughter of Isadora Duncan, who became the American dancer's bestknown disciple in the United States, died Tuesday in Cottage Hospital Santa Barbara, Calif. She was80 years old.

title: Yankee Tickets on Sale
description: Perhaps fans of the New York Yankees are cautious, but the club reported yesterday there had been no telephone calls nor any mail orders for playoff tickets. The Yankees announced Tuesday that tickets for the American League playoffs would be available by mail order immediately and overthecounter at the Stadium on Saturday.

title: Architect Pleads Guilty To Tax Evasion Charges Involving Brothel Owner
description: A wellknown New York City architect who laundered his corporation's funds through a brothel operator in New York and a stock manipulator in Washington, D.C.., pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to evading more than $13,000 in income taxes for 1971.

title: Stage: The Imagery Of Gertrude Stein
description: THE SPECIAL QUALITY of Gertrude Stein's writing is that it is funny, sad and dignified in a wrold somewhere between a prison and a catastrophe. She is subversive, but it is the subversion of someone who pretends the bars are not there because she knows she can't get through them. She was too bulky, perhaps. The answer to desolation is an ingenious disorder She is the last child, playing alone among ruins.

title: YOM KIPPUR
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended today for the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur. The city's public schools will be closed in its observance, as will some suburban schools. Banks and both stock exchanges will remain open as will most department stores and most government offices, including post offices. Mail deliveries will not be affected.

title: Morristown's Legacy Is a Victorian Showplace
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J. STYLE, not substance, sustained the village of Morristown in the late 19th century when it was trying to be a southern Newport. Even though it wasand isa landlocked little town, more millionaires were said to spend their summers within four miles of its village green than within four miles of any other spot in the world.

title: Brennan Rejects Bid to Withhold Legislative Data From Grand Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court rejected today an attempt by. State Senator Henry J. Cianfrani of Pennsylvania to withhold legislative documents from a Federal grand jury.

title: TONGSUN PARK TOLD TO REMAIN IN KOREA
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 21The American attorney for Tongsun Park said today that he had advised his client to stay put here for the moment pending the results of negotiations between the United States and South Korean Governments.

title: PACT WOULD TIGHTEN RULES ON ATOM SALES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Fifteen nuclear exporting countries reached agreement today in London on tightened guidelines on transfer of technology that are aimed at curbing the spread of atomic weapons, United States officials reported here.

title: SAILING TOMORROW
description: TransAtlantic

title: President of Equatorial Guinea Says Spain Sought to Murder Him
description: PEKING, Sept. 21 (Reuters)The President of Equatorial Guinea, a former Spanish colony in Africa, has used a dinner speech here to accuse the Spanish Government of attempting to kill him and overthrow his Government.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of cost positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Coronary Bypass Patients Found Not Outliving Those Using Drugs
description: Coronary bypass operations help relieve the chest pains of angina, but patients who had such surgery did not live longer than a similar group who were treated with drugs instead of surgery, according to preliminary results of a cooperative study that is continuing at 13 Veterans Administration hospitals.

title: 2 Officers of Defunct Bank Indicted
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept.21(AP)A Federal grand jury today indicted the former chief executive officer and a former vice president of the American City Bank and Trust Company of Milwaukee, which went out of business In 1975.

title: TV: Atlantis, Comic In Sea of Foolishness
description: IF NBC CAN KEEP Victor Buono around to play the archvillain on a regular basis, The Man From Atlantis could turn out to be right up there on the success ladder with The Six Million Dollar Man. The man in the new title is Mark Harris (Patrick Duffy), who, several television movies ago, was found washed ashore on a beach. As a watergoing mammal with gills instead of lungs, he is presumed to be the last citizen of Lost Atlantis. So much for the concept of rational plots.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL. 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900. WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800. CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Idea of EverExpanding Universe Dealt a Blow by Two New Studies
description: After several years in which various observations seemed to indicate that the universe is infinite and destined to expand forever, two studies have revived the possibility that it is finite and predestined to collapse.

title: Daring Czech Is Found Dead
description: VISALIA, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP)A body found buried in a shallow grave near here has been identified as that of Vaclav Wally Uhlik, who escaped from Czechoslovakia in a homemade tank almost a quartercentury ago.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Help Wanted 2600

title: Making Space Work
description: THE furnishings are spare, but sybaritic too. I like to do things minimally and elegantly, Marlys Hann explains. I like to get down to the essentialsthe important things are the light, the shape of the space and having a few nice things working with the spaces.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Wednesday, September 21, 1977

title: Kurt Adler, 70, Conductor Of 20 Different Operas At Met During 22 Years
description: Kurt Adler, opera conductor and chorusmaster of the, Metropolitan Opera from 1945 through 1973, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Butler, N.J.

title: Backgammon:
description: Backgammon combines the elements of luck and skill. Because the dividing line between the two is elusive, players' perceptions of these elements are often distorted.

title: Notes on People
description: A Circuit Court Judge in Miami order Telly Savalas, star of the Kojak detective series on television, to appear in court next Monday in the murder trial of a 15yearold boy whose lawyer is using TV violence for his defense. In ordering Mr. Savalas to appear, Judge Paul Baker questioned whether the actor could contribute anything to the trial. What does he know about this case? he asked. I don't think his personal opinion is pertinent. Ellis Rubin, lawyer for Ronald Zamora. the defendant, said Mr. Savalas does have something to contribute and is familiar with the effects of TV violence. Mr. Rubin is contending that the Zamora youth's constant exposure to television shows like Kojak contributed to his killing an 82yearold woman.

title: The End of the Affair
description: The only good thing about the Lance affair was the way, finally, it ended. It could have been maudlin bitteryou won't have Bert Lance to kick around anymore. But instead, both Mr. Lance and the President handled it cleanly, directly and without recrimination. To us, it seemed that Jimmy Carter had regained his political balance.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Arts and Leisure Guide in Section 2 of The Times last Sunday incorrectly listed Sept. 22 as the date for a lecture on Isadora Duncan at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. The event was held the preceding week.

title: South Carolina Man Guilty of Rape and Kidnapping
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 21A 25yearold South Carolina native was convicted today of kidnapping two sisters during a shopping excursion in Paramus last February and raping one of them while another alleged abductor was demanding a $5,000 ransom.

title: Model Rooms Open:
description: IT MUST be fall. The handsome young men at this week's department store modelroom openings are wearing all black instead of all white. And while the breadandbutter items that the stores' model rooms are offeringsuch as upholstery and case roodsare mostly made in the United States, the accessories and pieces de resistance are imported (or look as if they were).

title: U.S CHARGES NASSAU WITH DISCRIMINATION
description: The Justice Department charged Nassau County yesterday with discriminating against blacks, Hispanic people and women in hiring and promoting members of the County Police Department.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Sales Help Wanted 2677

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: The New York Times

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Sales Help Wanted 267

title: Pop: From Woodstock To the Other End
description: FIVE YEARS AGO, a group of well  known and not  so  wellknown folk musicians in Woodstock, N.Y., made an album called Music From Mud Acres. It was a surprisingly substantial success, but the musicians who made it went their own ways and it was not until last winter that they reassembled to record a followup.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Hsehold Help Wtd. Female 3102

title: Article 2  No Title
Jersey City Mayor Backs Byrne; State Plans $12 Million Aid to City
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21Although he still considers the state income tax inequitable, Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith today endorsed the reelection of Governor Byrne, the main proponent of the levy. The Mayor said he would support the Governor on the streets of Jerse City and with our alumni throughout the state.

title: A Banner Day at U.N. Begins, Precisely, at 10:10
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21At this institution, where events habitually never get started on time, something in the nature of a minor record may have been established this morning when, precisely at the scheduled time of 10 minutes past 10, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim emerged from the General Assembly Building and strode toward the row of flags that stand like sentinels in front of the complex.

title: $100,000 Reward for Gunmen
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 (AP)Mayor George Moscone announced yesterday that the city was offering a $100,000 reward for information leading to the arerst and conviction of three gunmen who killed five people and wounded 11 others at a Chinatown restaurant on Sept. 4.

title: First Baseman Also Stars With Glove at Fenway Park
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21Hold everything, folks. The Boston Red Sox shaved the New York Yankees again tonight, 32; swept their twogames series in angular old Fenway Park, and threw the Yankees back into a tight threeway race with only a week and a half to go.

title: A.T.&T . Net Tops Billion Dollars For the Fifth Consecutive Quarter
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest business enterprise, has exceeded the billiondollar quarterly profit mark for the fifth consecutive time, according to a report issued yesterday.

title: Banks' Rate War Can Pay Off
description: WITH SOMETHING like $25 billion in deposits up for grabs, bankers have started a rate war that longterm savers can capitalize on in the form of higher interest returns on their savings accounts.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Furniture/ Art

title: CORRECTION
description: The Arts and Leisure Guide in Section 2 of The Times last Sunday incorrecdy listed Sept. 22 as the date for a lecture on Isadora Duncan at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. The event was held the precoding week.

title: PRESIDENT IS SOMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21After weeks of controversy about his past business and banking practices, Budget Director Bert Lance resigned from office today and President Carter said he accepted his friend's decision with regret and sorrow.

title: FOUR CITIES CONSIDERED FOR DEMOCRATIC PARLEY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 (UPI)Citing political factors, a site selection committee has chosen Honolulu, Seattle, Denver and Memphis as final candidates for location of the 1978 midterm Democratic Party convention.

title: Carter Signs Defense Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (Reuters)President Carter signed today legislation that provides $109.75 billion for defense spending in the fiscal year beginning on Oct. 1. In addition to weapons' purchases and development, the bill provides funds for the intelligence community staff and other defenserelated activities.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended Aug 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter. 1977 1976

title: College Results
Gondoliers Protest in Venice
description: VENICE, Sept. 21 (AP)Dozens of gondoliers used their gondolas today to block Venice's main thoroughfare, the Grand Canal. They accused authorities of having failed to take action against unlicensed boatmen

title: Powerful BehindtheScene Figure in China Emerging as a Pivotal Man in Hierarchy
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 21When China's leaders assembled in Peking recently for a memorial service to commemorate the first anniversary of Mao Tsetung's death, a nationwide television broadcast showed a short, baldish man in gray tunic directing them to their places. It was Wane Tunghsing, former head of Mao's elite bodyguard, who has emerged in recent months as a pivotal figure in China.

title: The Fears of Flying Free
description: Nobody wins when the Federal Government regulates domestic airlines. Passengers pay more  as much $2 billion more each year, according to the General Accounting Officethan they would if airlines set their own fares and routes. Most airlines barely turn a profit: High fares are offset by millions of unsold seats because travelers are priced out of the market. And the economy suffers: Fewer travelers means fewer jobs for airline employees to serve them.

title: SingleSeason Homer Mark Set
description: Sixto Lezcano of the Milwaukee Brewers hit the 3,430 homer of the year in the major leagues last night, breaking the singleseason home run record. Lezcano's homer surpassed the record of 3,429 set in 1970.

title: RHODESIA IS ASSAILED ON VILLAGE PROGRAM
description: LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP)A Roman Catholic commission accused Rhodesia's white Government today of putting 580,000 blacks into conditions of great hardship by moving them into socalled protected villages to get them away from the black nationalist guerrillas who are fighting the Government.

title: A 2d $10 Million Suit Calls Police In Yonkers Negligent in Sam Case
description: YONKERS, Sept. 21 (AP)Notice of a second $10 million negligence suit against the Yonkers police has been filed by Robert Violante, wounded and left partially blind when he and Stacy Moskowitz were shot July 31. the last victims of the 44caliber killer. Miss Moskowitz died.

title: Warhol the Collector: A Taste for the Commonplace
description: TO ANDY WARHOL, virtually everythingfrom junk to the Empire State Buildingis collectible. And as a collector, he has birddog instincts that place him five years ahead of the pack. He was out 20 years ago buying many of the 75 pieces of folk art that go on view tomorrow in Folk and FunkAndy Warhol's Folk Art World at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

title: News Summary
description: Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel has told members of the House International Relations Committee in Washington that his country would be ready to let the United States establish a naval base for the Sixth Fleet in Haifa. He reportedly said he did not. want American troops involved in a peacekeeping role as part of a peace settlement with the Arabs. Administration officials said the idea of a naval hase had been under study for some time but was not under active consideration, although it might be considered as part of an overall settlement. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: MAURICE A. RABEN
description: NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 21 (UPI)Dr. Maurice S. Raben, who first reported that human growth hormones could be used to correct some types of dwarfism, died at his home Monday. He was 62 years old.

title: Reaction on Capitol Hill Ranges From Lynching Charge to Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21While some Southern supporters of Bert Lance complained tonight that a lynch mob had triumphed, his resignation was greeted on Capitol Hill with mostly a sense of relief.

title: YOM KIPPUR
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended today for the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur. The city's public schools will be closed in its observance, as will some suburban schools. Banks and both stock exchanges will remain open as will most department stores and most government offices, including post offices. Mail deliveries will not be affected.

title: School Board and U.S. in Accord On Improving Bilingual Programs
description: The New York City Board of Education announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Federal Government to establish better monitoring end testing procedures for bilingual programs in an effort to improve instruction for school children not competent in English.

title: People and Business
description: The Travelers Insurance Corporation has tapped an executive of Bache Halsey Stuart Inc. to fill the new position of chairman and chief executive officer of the Travelers Investment Management Company, a wholly awned institutional advisory subsidiary.

title: S.E.C. Settles an Accounting Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission issued yesterday an opinion and order concerning a settlement with Laventhol & Horwath, a Philadelphiabased accounting firm, and three of its former partners.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEW HAVEN EVERY September for the benefit of its library the town of Redding holds what it contends is the biggest book fair in the Northeast. Fortythousand books are on sale, so I have no reason to doubt the assertion. They ate unwanted volumes donated by residents of the area who seem to have a strong urge either to help the library or to clean out the attic, and I drove over there last Sunday thinking that I might find a few jewels amid the junkearly books by favorite authors, perhaps, or books that I have long been vaguely looking for. With 40,000 volumes, how could I miss? I missed. I came back emptyhanded, unless you count the dust that I collected on empty hands.

title: A REPORT TO PARLIAMENT SEEMS TO DOOM CONCORDE
description: LONDON, Sept. 21A committee of Parliament counting the cost to Britain of the supersonic Concorde airliner reported today that there appears to be no practical possibility of production beyond the 16 aircraft being authorized.

title: Vietnam Official Criticizes U.S. But T ells U.N. Hanoi Wants Ties
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21Deputy Prime Minister Nguyen Duy Trinh of Vietnam, speaking a day after his country was admitted to the United Nations, told the General Assembly today that the Vietnamese Government wanted normal relations with the United States.

title: The Standings
description: Thursday, September 22, 1977

title: Short Interest on Big Board Rises 1.1 Million Shares for the Month
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 1.1 million shares in the month ended Sept. 15 to 31.2 million shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 22.7 million shares. the American Stock Exchange fell 223,958 shares in the same monthly period to 4.4 million shares.

title: OFFICIALS IN CONNECTICUT ASK AID IN RELIEF FRAUD
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 24 (AP)investigators of welfare fraud said this week they were hampered by a shortage of staff and money and by the unwillingness of doctors to testify about fraudulent medical claims.

title: Greetings
description: FALKMr. & Mrs. Isador Falk and family of 75 WoodLane. Woodmere, Long Island, wish all their relatives and friends a happy and healthy New Year!

title: With Knight and Barkum Ailing, Jets' Rookie Look Is Deepening
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 21The prospect of an allrookie Jets' receiving corps, to go with a virtually allrookie running attack, directed by a secondyear quarterback, loomed today as illness and injury sidelined David Knight and Jerome Barkum.

title: Books: Dynasty Traces Fortunes Of an Influential Eurasian Family
description: ROBERT ELEGANT'S uneven, sprawling novel recapitulates the violent history of the Orient since 1900 as it chronicles the affairs of a Hong Kong family of merchant princes. The wealth of that familythe Sekloongsoriginated in the opium and slave trade, but by the 1970's they are people of enormous resources and influence. They are also an ubiquitous tribe. At one point a brother is an aide to Chou Enlai; another is an aide to Chiang Kaishek; a third is on the way up to becoming a cardinal, and a sister is married to an American undersecretary of state. Often enough an act of state turns out to be a family affair.

title: Glenn Munn, Retired Economist With Paine, Webber, Dies at 87
description: Glenn G. Munn, a retired economist with the brokerage firm of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., died Monday night in Central Suffolk Hospital, Riverhead, L.I., after a short illness. He was 87 years od and lived at 580 New Suffolk Avenue, Mattituck. L.I.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on the Resiznation of Bert Lance
description: Opening Statement I would like to read first a letter that I have just received from Bert Lance.

title: Ford to Replace Gas Caps
description: LIVONIA, Mich., Sept. 21 (AP)The Ford Motor Company will replace gasoline tank caps on about 322,000 of its 1977 Ford Granadas because the caps could leak if the cars were hit from the rear, a company spokesman said today. Owners of the Granadas are being notified and will be mailed a new filler cap beginning next month.

title: Dvorak, Cut Last Week, Rejoins Giants' Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 21 Rick Dvorak, who was peacefully planting wheat yesterday in Kansas, returned to the violent world of pro football today and noticed that the undefeated Giants seemed a little more fired up than they were a week ago when he left.

title: Ellis Floors Ali Twice
description: DEER LAKE, Pa., Sept. 21 (AP)Muhammad Ali was knocked down twice today by Jimmy Ellis, the retired former World Boxing Association champion, during a training camp sparring session, a spokesman for Ali's camp reported.

title: GARDENING
description: THINKING about a Christmas cactus in the middle of September may seem like an odd sort of musing, yet it's the right thing to do. Good thoughts now with proper care of the plantwill result in full bloom for Christmas.

title: Con Ed Planning to Install Buttons For Instant Reductions in Power
description: Pairs of buttons to allow Consolidated Edison Company system operators to reduce wattage or disconnect customers virtually instantaneously are to be installed in the company's energy control center by the end of October, company officials disclosed yesterday at a state inquiry into the blackout of July 13.

title: Article 1  No Title
Corporation Affairs
description: The Federal Reserve Board, settling a threeyearold order that the Alfred I. du Pont estate divest itself of a controlling interest in a bank holding company, approved yesterday the estate's sale of its nearly 25 percent stake in the $1.6 billion Florida National Banks of Florida.

title: U. S. Tobacco Drops Sano LowTar Brand
description: Irony of ironies, now that lowtarandnicotine cigarettes are the hottest thing in the tobacco industry, the U.S. Tobacco Company is dropping its Sano brand, a pioneer product in the category.

title: National League Names Umpires for Playoffs
description: A sixman umpiring team that includes two arbiters working their first playoff series was picked yesterday by Charles Feeney, the National League president, for the circuit's championship series that opens in Los Angeles Oct 4.

title: Juxtapositions
description: PHOTOGRAPH, be Gertrude Stein. Directed by James Lapine; costumes and settings by Maureen Connor; lighting by Paul Gallo; music by Dwight Andrews; narration by Walt Jones; production supervisor, Jennifer Hershey. Presented by the Open Span In SoHo, Lynn Michaels, artistic director. At 64 Wooster Street.

title: And Regulators Trapped in Paradox
description: If you doubt the pernicious effect of airline regulation, consider this paradox: The six major airlines that fly between the United States and Britain traditionally oppose bargain fares, but now wish to lower them substantially on advancepurchase excursions. The Civil Aeronautics Board, whose members are dedicated to reducing the cost of international air travel, won't let them.

title: Time of the Falling Leaf
description: This is the week of the autumn equinox. Next week it will be fall by the index of stars and planets, and the astronomical seal will be affixed to a set of facts obvious to any eye. Summer is ended. Growth has fulfilled its mission, come to fruit and maturity. Now, in garb of celebration, the hills approach their long nights of rest and preparation for another spring. Now the color comes. The reds and tans and golds of fall finery start to spread over the wooded hills and warm the whole countryside. A lowland begins to blaze with the flame of swamp maples. A stony slope covered with birches turns yellow, and a nearby clump of poplars tarnishes to russet. A row of sugar maples becomes an area of arboreal sunlight. And the viburnums, the briars, the cherries and the Virginia Creeper will soon be ablaze with every shade of red from crimson to scarlet.

title: Kheel Sees Transit Negotiations Making or Breaking Next Mayor
description: Theodore W. Kheel, in an address to the Transport Workers Union convention yesterday, said that the next city administration would be made or broken in the first three months, depending on what happened in the labor negotiations involving bus and subway workers.

title: Home Beat
description: WHEN Elizabeth Taylor was the guest of honor earlier this year at Bloomingdale's White Flint shopping center in Kensington, Md., Richard Knapple, Bloomingdale's modelroom designer, mentioned that the theme of his New York rooms this fall would be Egyptian.

title: Policemen Fire on Soweto Youths
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 21 (AP)Riot policemen said they fired on groups of stonethrowing youths today in Soweto, the area set aside for blacks outside Johannesburg where the death of a black leader, Steven Biko, has caused unrest. A radio report said one youth was believed to have been killed, but there was no immediate confirmation.

title: U.S. Sets China Tennis Tour
description: The United States Tennis Association and the National Committee on United States  China Relations announced yesterday they had accepted an invitation from the AllChina Sports Federation and will co  sponsor the visit of an American tennis team to China from Oct. 12 to 26.

title: Australia Plans Borrowing
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 21 (AP)The Government is prepared to borrow heavily overseas to stave off another devaluation of the Australian dollar, Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser said today. The Government has been told that $600 million could be raised in Europe

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING Yonkers Raceway, Central and Yonkers Avenues, 8 P.M. Monticello (N.Y.) Raceway, 8 P.M. Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, 1 P.M.

title: 250th Year Is Marked By Maryland Gazette
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 21 (AP)The Maryland Gazette, which says it is America's oldest surviving newspaper, is celebrating its 250th birthday.

title: Home Repair Q &A
description: Q. My cherry wood cocktail table has been marred along one side by heel marks left due to my son's bare feet resting along that side. I read somewhere that soap and water would take care of this, but all I accomplished was dulling the finish on that part of the table. The results were no better after I applied two different wellknown brands of furniture polish and wax. Do you know what I can do?Mrs. M. S., Syosset, L. I.

title: Country Visitor Without a Visa
description: FAIRFIELD, CONN. ARRIVING at night, my friend from the city pauses before entering the house: Wow, he says, look at that moon! It's right out of Magritte!

title: The U.N. Today
Deaths
description: ACHARDColette in West Cornwall Conn, September 19, 1977. Mother of Demian and Dona Achard. Sister of Millicent Matland of West Cornwall Conn. Funeral Mass at St. Bridget's Church, Cornwall Bridge Conn, Saturday, September 24 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Cancer Research institute, 133 E SB St, NY NY 10022 would be appreciated.

title: Dollar Hits 2d Law in Switzerland
description: The dollar plunged to a record low against the Swiss franc in Zurich for the second consecutive day yesterday and slid further in New York foreign exchange trading as well, according to The Associated Press.

title: Israel Would Grant Naval Base to U.S., House Panel Is Told
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel has told members of Congress that his Government would be prepared to allow the United States to establish a naval base at Haifa for use by the Sixth Fleet.

title: Ban Is Lifted on Pesticide in Effort To Spare Hudson Valley Orchards
description: ALBANY, Sept. 21Peter A. A. Berle. the State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, today approved the use of Endrin, described as a highly toxic pesticide, to combat the pine vole, a rodent threatening the $18 million apple industry in the lower Hudson Valley.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Dave Anderson
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21Jim Rice hopped up the steps the Boston Red Sox dugout as Don Zimmer glanced at him.

title: Romach Skye Terriers Prove Significant Breed for Century
description: A century has passed since the name Romach became known in the world of Skye terriers. Just 100 years ago, a bitch called Romach was the first Skye to be registered with the American Kennel Club. This month Ch. Bell wether's Romach another silver bitch, was singled out for best of breed over a record entry of 110 Skyes by Mrs. Elsbeth Clerc of Burloch, Switzerland, at the 50th national specialty of the Skye Terrier Club of America on the Lyndhurst estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Mrs, Clerc is a prominent European judge of terriers, so the Romach of the present day has to be sensational. It's quite a feat to win from the males in this breed. In the history of 50 specialties, Romach is only the ninth female to attain this goal.

title: Kings Point Is Passing the Grade Without a Completion
description: Kings Point's football team has won both its games this season without the help of a passing attack. Coach Pete Carmichael and his players didn't exactly plan it that way. It just happened. The Mariners have beaten Coast Guard and New York Tech without completing a pass. Their total offense is 500 yards rushing. They picked up 222 yards against Coast Guard and 278 against Tech while failing to make a completion in eight pass attempts in the first game and in four last Saturday.

title: News Summary
description: Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel has told members of the House International Relations Committee in Washington that his country would be ready to let the United States establish a naval base for the Sixth Fleet in Haifa. He reportedly said he did not want American troops involved in a peacekeeping role as part of a peace settlement with the Arabs. Administration officials said the idea of a naval has had been under study for some time but was not under active consideration, although it might be considered as part of an overall settlement. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: CIVIL SERVICE CHIEF WARNS OF DOUBLEDIPPING CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)The Government would lose a pool of skilled, experienced personnel if retired military persons were barred from Federal service to prevent pension edoubldipping, the chairman of the Civil Service Commission warned today.

title: WITTEVEEN LEAVING AS HEAD OF I.M.F. IN SURPRISE MOVE
description: H. Johannes Witteveen, the softspoken, aesthetic Dutchman who over the last four years has led the International Monetary Fund in an aggressive effort to stimulate and redirect the world economy, announced yesterday that he would not seek reelection as the managing director of the fund.

title: U.S. SECURITIES DRAW MORE OPEC DOLLARS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Oilproducing nations have sharply increased their investments in shortterm, highly liquid United States Treasury notes and bonds, according to information disclosed at a Senate foreign relations  subcommittee hearing today.

title: Michigan Opera Theater Will Revive Regina
description: Marc Blitzsteln's Regina, the operatic version of Lillian Hellman's The Little Foxes, will be given one of its infrequent revivals by the Michigan Opera Theater in Detroit, starting Sept. 30. The five performances will be conducted by John Yaffe, with staging by Francis Rizzo and designs by Franco Colavecchia and Carol Luiken.

title: Koosman Loses No. 20 As Pirates Rout Mets
description: Jerry Koosman, who had a right to be bitter about losing 20 games just one year after he won 20 games, sat calmly in front of his locker after last night's 40 loss by the Mets to the Pittsburgh Pirates andcounted his blessings.

title: PRESIDENT IS SOMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21After weeks of controversy about his past business and banking practices, Budget Director Bert Lance resigned from office today and President Carter said he accepted his friend's decision with regret and sorrow.

title: Beame Welcomed in Washington, But Gets No Help on Welfare Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Mayor Beame got a friendly reception but no commitment today in a visit with the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., during which he sought support for an immediate increase in Federal spending on welfare to ease the load on localities.

title: Aides Report Carey Will Support Koch and Scrap Pledge to Cuomo
description: Governor Carey is preparing to abandon Mario M. Cuomo's mayoral candidacy and to endorse Representative Edward I. Koch, the victor in the Democratic mayoral primary runoff, sources close to the Governor said yesterday.

title: CRUDE OIL IMPORTS RISE TO 7 MILLION BARRELS A DAY
description: Imports of crude oil rose to 7 million barrels a day for the week ending Sept. 16 from 5.1 million barrels a day in the previous week, while stocks of distillate oil, used mainly for home heating purposes, rose significantly to 235.7 million barrels from 229.6 million barrels a week earlier.

title: At 82, Collegian Is Fulfilling Life's Ambition
description: Irving Kantor sat in the front row between a young woman in cutoff jeans and a young bearded man in overalls, pen poised for the first class of the semester, which turned out to be on recreation and leisure.

title: COUPLE CHARGE BRUTALITY BY OFFICER OVER A TICKET
description: The Civilian Complaint Review Board has received a charge of brutality from a Chinese couple against a police officer, resulting from a parking incident last Saturday on Canal Street, near Mott.

title: Personal Beauty
description: WHY DO people travel all over the country for a week of spartan activity eating skimpy, if tasty, meals at the Golden Door spa in Escondido, Calif? And pay $1,250 for the privilege?

title: Grain, Soybean and Pork Bellies Futures Rise Daily Limits
description: Just after the spot September grain and soybean futures expired at noon yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, waves of buy orders inundated the bean, oil and meal pits.

title: Ambassador to Chile Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (Reuters)The Senate today confirmed George Landau as United States Ambassador to Chile.

title: Jazz: Structured Jamming
description: ONE of the more or less instant traditions that Eddie Condon created when he had his jazz club on West 3d Street 30 years ago was Tuesday night jam sessions at which the house band was supplemented by three or four additional horn men.

title: STOCK PRICES PLUNGE OVER A BROAD FRONT AS DOW DROPS 10.82
description: Stock prices tumbled along a broad front yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 10.82 points to 840.96, its lowest closing level since late 1975.

title: Pop: Townes Van Zandt Ranges From Charm to Choppiness
description: POPULAR MUSIC is a field in which a few superstars bask in brilliant adulation, countless others struggle upward toward the light, and a few talented misfits lurk in the shadows. Unlike those who lie unrecognized simply because they lack talent, these few are prized by their fellow musicians and tiny cult audiences, but lack the will power or the ability to compromise, or the sheer dumb luck to succeed.

title: Medicaid Cuts Loom for 22 States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)The Federal Government will withhold $241 million in Medicaid funds from 22 states on Oct. 1 unless Congress intervenes, according to the the Department of Health. Education and Welfare.

title: State Not Opposed to Offshore Oil Drilling, Aide Says
description: NEWARK, Sept. 21The State Energy Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobson, told representatives of the petroleum industry today that the state was not opposed to drilling for oil offshore and that New Jersey would reach quick decisions on applications for drilling permits and for landbased facilities.

title: Books of The Times
description: GEORGE SMILEY SAYS: A lot of people haven't these days. The will. Specially in England. A lot of people see doubt as a legitimate philosophical posture. They think of themselves in the middle, whereas, of course, really they're nowhere. Of George Smiley, failed priest, lonesome man. it is said: One day... one of two things will happen to George. He'll cease to care or the paradox will kill him. If he ceases to care, he'll be half the operator he is. If he doesn't, that little chest will blow up from the struggle of trying to find the explanation for what we do. And George Smiley writes to his wife, whom he has finally left: These people terrify me, but I am one of them. If they stab me in the back, then at least that is the judgment of my peers.

title: BURGER MOVES TO AID COURTCONGRESS TIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Chief Justice Warren E. purger is taking steps to improve relations between Congress and the Federal judiciaryrelations that have been proper but distant.

title: DR. PAUL FRISCH, TEACHER AND PSYCHOLOGIST, AT 51
description: Dr. Paul Z. Frisch, a psychologist, died last Sunday at his home, 44 Arleigh Road, Great Neck, L.I. He was 51 years old.

description: THERE are few parts of the New York streetscape as dreary, if well intended, as the closed sidewalk cafes that have multiplied lire rabbits in midtown and Greenwich Village over the last few years. They are canvasroofed shacks, jerrybuilt intrusions into the sidewalk that have neither the relaxed air of tables set directly on the sidewalk nor the dignity of welldesigned interior d??ning rooms.

description: LONDON, Sept. 21James Pitt, a well  educated young family man, worries these days about the kind of people moving into Islington, the increasingly attractive north London borough in which he lives.

description: DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 21In an attempt to beat the economic and critical Russian roulette of producing musical theater in New York, Duke University and Richard Adler, the veteran Broadway producer, announced today the formation of a Broadwaystyle production corporation called the American Musical Theater Center. It will be based at Duke.

description: SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 21Charles Royer and Paul Schell, two political novices who beat 13 other candidates for Mayor in yesterday's nonpartisan primary with similar campaigns promoting their status as nonpoliticians, began new efforts today to win the runoff in the November general election.

description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 21The State Board of Education has rejected Bridgeport's proposed school desegregation plan and has threatened to cut off about $9 million a year in state aid if an acceptable plan is not submitted by Oct, 17, it was announced today.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)President Carter told a group of senators today that he was worried about steel mill shutdowns and layoffs, but saw no immediate need to grant the industry's demands, for more restraints on foreign imports.

title: Rules to Enforce Antiboycott Law Are Said to Favor U.S. Businesses
description: The Commerce Department yesterday outlined proposed regulations intended to enforce the Government's new antiboycott law. Several officials close to the proposals said the rules would continue to give American business considerable leeway in carrying on trade with Arab countries.

title: A Fine Manon Chevalier
description: THE TENOR WHO TAKES ON the role of the Chevalier Des Grieux in Massenet's Manon should be a handsome devil with a lyric voice to match, and Henry Price's portrayal on Tuesday night at the New York City Opera met those basic requirements. In the fourth Manon of the season, Mr. Price essayed the part for the first time with this company and gave a tasteful, credible performance opposite Beverly Sills, who is a fixture in the title role.

title: Protecting Wetlands
description: WASHINGTONCongress will soon decide how many billions should be spent to clean up the nation's waters. Ironically, the same cleanwater legislation may lead to widespread destruction of our nation's wetlands, a natural resource of immense environmental value.

title: About New York
description: There are people who take the A train in the dark, going down from Harlem and points south to the city's ocean coast so they can watch birds stirring about Jamaica Bay in the blue edge of dawn. These city bird watchers walk from the subway's Broad Channel station to the marshes, and they are as quiet and undemanding as the birds they stare at, and as adaptable.

description: Governor Carey, rebuffed by Manhattan and Bronx Democrats on one of his two choices for State Supreme Court, refused yesterday to say whether he would go through with his announced intention to appoint either or both for interim terms that would end Dec. 31.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 53yearold Staten Island woman was killed and her 23yearold son was injured when a fire swept through their private house early yesterday. The police said that the woman, Debba Cermak of 41 Monroe Avenue, in the Arlington section, had died of severe burns and that her son, Steven, had sustained minor injuries. The son was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island.

description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 21John Ferguson jumped to his feet. Come on Benny, he shouted. Do something. Hit someone.

description: Gladys Hall, a Hollywood fan magazine interviewer and writer for more than a generation, died Sunday at her home in Huntington, L.I. She was 86 years old.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Art Deco Lives On The 20th century is getting almost as eclectic as the 19th in its tendency to recycle past styles. Art Deco, that style of startling geometrics, extravagant florals and sentimental kitsch, has waxed and waned several times since it came into its own after World War I. Now, after a spurt of popularity earlier in this decade, it's back. Altman's has just opened what it calls a trend shop that is filled with home accessories in the Art Deco style, from tumblers frosted with a single opulent flower to a photosilkscreened gardenia print covering throw pillows and a huge pouf. Many of the items, in glass, ceramics, metal and fabric, come from Milan and Paris. Some, like the few pieces of furniture, are domestic, and even Japan makes a contribution with roundcornered, rectilinear dinnerware. Not only motif and line, but color gives these things the spiritif not the letterof Art Deco. Colors in the shop are cool, clear grays, buff and all the variations of pink, from salmon through apricot to peach and up again through rose. Prices are from $3 for placemats to $550 for then pouf; most, however, are in the $25 to $35 price range. The shop is on Altman's fifth floor.

title: DEFICIT IN NEW YORK PUT AT $350 MILLION, 4 TIMES PROJECTION

title: Families of Son of Sam Victims Stage Demonstration at Hospital
description: Thirtyfive friends and members of the families of two of the victims of the 44caliber killer, known as Son of Sam, yesterday stood outside the Kings County Psychiatric Hospital where David R. Berkowitz, the suspect in the killings, is being held, and called for revenge.

title: Alan D. Allen, Realty President Who Specialized in Construction
description: Alan D. Allen, president and founder of the Tandy & Allen Realty Corporation of Manhattan, died Tuesday in Pascack Hospital, Westwood, N.J., after an illness of six months. He was 60 years old and lived at 27 Pascack Road, Woodcliff, N.J.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Two linked problems will dominate the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank that begin in Washington this weekend. One is whether the world economy, hit by the worst slump of the postwar period in 197475, can regain its forward momentum or will slip into a possibly more severe secondary slump. The other is whether the substantial buildup of international debt, in large measure a consequence of the quadrupling of oil prices by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, can be financed, especially with the help of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, as well as that of the commercial banks of the West and the oilrich potentates of the Middle East.

title: Letter: On Panama Canal Treaties
description: Your Sept. 8 editorial The Canal in Panama contained so many erroneous points that it is impossible to offer a factual, indepth rebuttal in a brief space. However, I want to take issue with your ridiculous comment that opponents of the Panama Canal treaties have raised not one telling point of substance. If you were genuinely interested in what opponents are saying about these treaties you would realize that this statement simply untrue.

It was the home of the world's biggest neon sign, people chuckled, and of brassieres, Oreo cookies, steam engines, baseball and Frank Sinatra. It was the kind of place that Lillian Russell, John L. Sullivan and John Jacob Astor could visit; but nobody wanted to live there.

description: OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 21Faculty members at Dowling College agreed today to end their strike under a settlement that reportedly lets them retain their authority over academic affairs, but concedes that the power to hire and discharge faculty members lies entirely with the college's board of trustees.

title: Key Figure Testifies in Private on C.I.A. Drug Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Dr. Sidney Gottlieb, a key but shadowy figure in the Central Intelligence Agency's secret drug testing program, told his story to a Senate subcommittee today, but he managed to elude the lights and microphones and the crush of reporters waiting for him in the Senate hearing room.

title: Yonkers Drivers
Hers
description: SAGAPONACK, L.I. ONE OF THE THINGS I achieved in my 39th year was the incomprehensible luxury of regaining not only my own bedroom but my own bed as well. It was startling how much the regaining of lost nocturnal turf meant to me.

title: F.C.C. Inquiry to Study Rates On 2 Forms of A.T.&T. Service
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had started an inquiry into the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's widearea telecommunications services, known as WATS, as compared with message telecommunications services. or MTS.

title: Bessonov Scores Triple In World Weight Lifting
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Sept. 22 (UPI)Gennady Bessonov of the Soviet Union won all three gold medals in the lightheavyweight division of the world weightlifting championships today.

title: CHURCH UNIT OPPOSES TONGSUN PARK STANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The National Council of Churches of Korea, which has often criticized the South Korean Government, has urged Tongsun Park to return to the United States from Seoul to face an indictment for alleged bribery of American Congressmen.

title: Akselrod, Soviet Dissident, Seized After Questioning by K.G.B. Agents
description: MOSCOW. Sept. 22 (AP)Ernest Akselrod, a Soviet psychiatrist, has been arrested after earlier questioning by state security agents about his relationship with Anatoly Shcharansky, a jailed dissident, and a meeting with an American correspondent, dissident sources reported today.

title: A U .N . Report Says? Arms Race Goes On At Alarming Tempo
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22The arms race among the major industrialized nations is continuing at an alarming tempo and such developments as the talks on limiting strategic arms, the Helsinki Conference and detente have failed to make a discernible impact on the situation, according to a study made public here today.

title: League Leaders
description: By The Associated Press

title: Smith Describes U.S.British Plan As Appeasement
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 21Prime Minister Ian D. Smith condemned today the BritishAmerican proposals for bringing about black majority rule in Rhodesia as an attempt to appease the Russianoriented terrorists who are operating from Zambia and Mozambique.

title: Jogger Raped, but One Fights Back
description: A jogger fought off a wouldbe rapist in Central Park early yesterday morning, but minutes later a second jogger was attacked and raped.

title: U.S. Yachtsmen Hold Lead
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan, Sept. 22 (AP)David Ullmam nd Tom Linskey of the United States held their lead today for the third straight day with a fourrace total of 41.4 points in the seventh world 470 Class yachting championship. Their yacht finished ninth far 15 points. Two races remain.

title: World News Briefs
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 22 (AP)A Hungarian airliner with an engine on fire crashed and burned as it tried to make an emergency landing in a sunflower field near Bucharest last night, killing 29 of the 53 passengers and crew, it was reported today.

title: ORDERS UP IN AUGUST FOR DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)New factory orders for durable goods rose by 3.3 percent in August, the biggest increase since March, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Police in Albany Allegedly Are Getting Payoffs to Ignore Growth in Prostitution
description: State investigators using stakeouts and hidden cameras have been looking into allegations that prostitution has been able to flourish in Albany, in part because some policemen regularly are paidin some cases as much as $700 a weekto look the other way.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)Starting next year, members of the House of Representatives will have more money to spend either on office space in their districts or other office expenses, at an estimated added total cost of $3.4 million.

title: I Wish They'd Do Right
description: My son and his wife are not married. They have lived together for seven years without benefit of license. Though occasionally marriage has been a subject of conjecture, it did not seem important until the day they announced, jubilantly, that they were going to have a child. It was happy news. I was ready and eager to become a grandmother. Now, I thought, they will take the final step and make their relationship legal.

title: Fire Damages 5 Homes
description: A threealarm fire early yesterday heavily damaged five private homes on Harman Street in Brooklyn's Ridgwood section and forced the relocation of 16 families. The blaze began at 146 Harman Street, a vacant, threestory frame building.

title: PARENTS /CHILDREN
description: Some teenagers grow so fast that their image of themselves cant keep up with the facts. A boy of 15 might grow 4 or 5 inches in one year and reach a height of 6 feet in that single burstbut he'll persist in thinking of himself as 5 feet 7 inches tall.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: THE SINGLE MOST impressive event of the weekend, justifiably placed in NBC's Big Event slot on Sunday at 9 P.M., is a madefortelevision movie called Kill Me If You Can. Described as factbased, this is the story of Caryl Chessman, who spent 12 years in San Quentin before being executed in May 1960. Like all factbased television, whether it be labeled true story or docudrama, this dramatization is not without a point of view or, if you will, a strong bias. The production's sympathy is entirely with Chessman, not only for the cruel and unusual punishment he suffered in 12 years of legal wrangling on the doorstep of death, but also for the strongly implied belief that he was innocent in the first place.

title: Mr. Vorster Rallies the Faithful
description: Evidently protest is so popular in South Africa these days that Prime Minister Vorster wants his white supporters to do some protesting too. The target will be outsidersthe Carter Administration in particularwho have lately been increasingly outspoken in their criticism of his government's racial policies. The vehicle for protest will be a snap election among South Africa's whitesthe only group that has the voteon Nov. 30, a year and a half before they would have been required. Mr. Vorster wants the electorate to say whether they agree with my standpoint and that of my ministers that no other country has the right to interfere in our affairs or prescribe to us.

title: Bridge:
description: Organizers of team events must choose between two basic formats, each of which has disadvantages. The single knockout, even if carefully seeded, may give one team an easier schedule than its rivals, and means that most of the competitors get little action.

Mrs. Hill performed as a trick rider and roping artist in her father's wild west show after he retired from film work; She had lived in Corpus Christi since 1954.

Mr. Boyle, 75 years old, was taken to Crozer Chester Medical Center Monday afternoon after he complained of chest pains during jury selection at the nearby Delaware County courthouse in Media.

The transaction would increase Chemical Bank's holdings in Multibank to 100 percent from 30 percent.

Its smoky, racketing progress up the avenue is now almost forgotten, though in its early days the elevated train attracted much excited interest. Gone are the steel girders that supported its tracks, and in its place a broad, fashionable thoroughfare has blossomed.

description: HOW MANY TIMES have you seen The Savage Is Loose? Not even once? The time has come, then, for you to zip over to the RKO 59th Street Theater, where you can inspect this unflinching drama that boldly answers the question, What is the prescribed etiquette for a man, a woman and their erotically rambunctious son when they find themselves stranded, presumably forever, on an otherwise uninhabited island?

description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP)Bert Blyleven, the righthanded curvebalt specialist. hurled a nohitter tonight in the Texas Rangers 60 victory over the California Angels.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22A Congressional study has concluded that construction of subways and other rail transit systems is one of the least efficient solutions to the use of energy in mass transit and offers little aid to the nation's efforts to save fuel.

title: New Music: Pauline Oliveros
description: PAULINE OLIVEROS, who gave solo recitals Wednesday and last night at the Samaya Foundation, 46 Warren Street, is a fascinating figure in American music who is heard very rarely in New York. Partly that's because she is based in La Jolla, Calif., as director of the Center for Music Experiment at the University of California, San Diego, and partly because she works in an austere idiom that can only be performed by herself.

description: AT MASON, OHIO

title: PAKISTANI MILITARY RULER OUSTS THE CHIEF JUSTICE
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 22 (AP)The military ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq, ousted the Chief Justice today, two days after the Supreme Court granted a hearing to former Prime Minister Zuifikar Ali Bhutto on his appeal for freedom from army detention.

title: Give OTB Bettor Fair Deal, Goldin to Urge Next Mayor
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday he would urge New York City's next Mayor to give offtrack bettors a fairer deal than they are getting now.

title: Film Festival: Varda's 'One Sings'
description: THE 15TH NEW YORK Film Festival gets very fashionably under way tonight at Avery Fisher Hall with a woman's picturea movie by, for and about women. These are women who haven't exactly done away with men but they have successfully established an emotional strength thatunintentionally, I thinkmakes the men around them look superfluous for everything except for the reproduction of the species and singing in the kind of harmony that requires a soprano, an alto, a tenor and a bass.The film is "One Sings, the Other Doesn't," written and directed by Agns Varda, who, over the years, has made so many interesting, original, surprising films ("Le Bonheur," "Lion's Love," "Daguerreotypes," among others) that critics no longer feel compelled to make a big sexist deal out of the presence of a woman in a field dominated by men.In a peculiar way, now, "One Sings, the Other Doesn't" wipes all that away. It's as if Miss Varda had become fed up with the old integration bit and had switched to a new separate-but-equal line and, instead of demonstrating a woman's right to be taken seriously as a film artist or even as a person, had begun her own propaganda campaign."One Sings, the Other Doesn't" has some good sequences in it, is beautifully acted by two actresses who are new to me, is handsomely composed but, at key moments, it's as phonyas relentlessly schematic and upbeatas Soviet neo-realist art. It's of less interest as a movie than as a statement of position.The film, which opens its commercial engagement tomorrow at the Plaza Theater, is about two women and their friendship over approximately 15 years when each in her own fashion achieves some kind of liberation from the chains that bind one exclusively to kitchen, kids and kaffeeklatsch.Suzanne (Thres Liotard), the more conventional of the two, and also the more interesting, is a pretty brunette who lives with an unsuccessful photographer named Jerme (Robert Dadis) who gives her babies and love, but whose wife refuses to divorce him. Jerome appreciates women but he cannot cope. His studio is filled with pictures of women of all ages, shapes and dispositions. "I'm after women in their naked truth," he says at one point, but though he loves and admires them, he's incapable of doing much more than making them pregnant. Jerme commits suicide.Pauline (Valrie Mairesse), nicknamed Apple, several years younger than Suzanne, sees Suzanne's impossible position and resolves not to be similarly caught. She becomes a successful street-singer and women's rights worker and suddenly, to her surprise, falls in love with a young Iranian student. Darius (Ali Raffi), her lover, appears to share her "radical" views, that is, until they go home to Iran where he's as much of a chauvinist as the next fellow.Suzanne, abandoned by Jerome through his suicide, takes her children to the farm of her disapproving parents in the south of France. During the day she tends the stock. At night she teaches herself to type and, in the kind of transition that is typical of this film, she suddenly becomes a successful family-planning counselor whose own children are models of adjustment.Pauline/Apple, who has given up her singing career to follow her husband home to the picture-postcard scenery of Iran, has a child and feels she must get on with her own life. She and Darius reach an agreement: he can keep the first baby if he makes her pregnant again so that she can have one of her own, which is how they work out their problems.Throughout all these adventures, Suzanne and Apple keep up a correspondence whose principal theme is how each misses the other, feels a deep womanly kinship to the other, and longs for a reunion so that they can talk about women and women's problems.Somehow, I never particularly believe in this friendship, nor do I believe in the sunny resolution to the various problems.It all has the air of whistling in the dark, or maybe of positive thinking. When Apple and her all-woman combo sing in public squares, the repeated refrain is "I'm a womanI'm me!" The self-absorption is intense. It's also abstract. If we were more aware of the toll taken of the two women in their struggles, the film would carry more emotional impact. As it is, it has a sort of high-toned perfunctoriness to it.The two leading actresses are appealing in ways the material is not, and Miss Varda obtains some attractive performances from the children in her cast.I admit that my tepid reaction to "One Sings, the Other Doesn't" is biased. I'm no more or less interested in "women's" pictures than in "men's" pictures. I am interested in good movies, which transcend sex.

title: Farmers Total Income at Depression Level
description: PRATT, Kan.It was too wet to plow, but that was not the reason for the expression of dismay on Kenneth Lawton's face as he turned away from a field where recent rains were still soaking into the black earth. Something heavier lay on his mind.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided Into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dindicates new low.

title: Love, Hate And the Violinist
description: One day she is cold and aloof, and half the treasures of the Orient laid at her feet will not move her. The next she is responsive and giving, for no apparent reason. But the one thing she will never forgive is inattention, even at those times when her hair is in curlers and she has all the allure of a worn carpetslipper.

Wife of the late Ben, adored mother of the late Mildred Fox, loving grandmother of the late Jerome and Joel Fox, dear aunt of Mildred, Charlotte, Beulah, Ruth and Edith, Great grandmother. Services at Riverside Mount Vernon, 21 West Broad St, 1:45PM, Friday. Burial al Mount Hebron.

title: Property Owner Rebates Ready; Tax Extension Is Called Possible
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22Governor Byrne today announced that checks totaling more than $136 million from the proceeds of the state income tax were ready to be mailed out to property owners in the form of homestead rebates, and he said that he did not rule out the possibility of attempting to amend the incometax law to delete a provision that the income tax expire on June 30, 1978.

description: ELIZABETH, Sept. 22Judge Harold Ackerman of Superior Court here will hear preliminary arguments next Thursday on a suit brought by the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey to determine whether St. Stephen's Church in Plainfield may continue as an Episcopal church, rather than a schismatic church.

title: SpanishBritish Thaw May Ease Isolation of Gibraltar
description: GIBRALTAR, Sept. 16At the end of the working day, the people come, laden with binoculars and small children, to the very end of Winston Churchill Avenue to shout through the fence to relatives 70 yards awayin Spain.

title: Saturday
description: The spirit of Montmartre comes to Central Park South this weekend. The sidewalk on the park's south side, from Fifth to Seventh Avenues, plus nearby Grand Army Plaza, will be turned into an outdoor gallery. There will be paintings, drawings and prints all signed piecesand 100 or so participating artists will be on hand to talk about their work. About 75 craft workers will also be there, showing ceramics, jewelry, leatherwork and other itemsall for sale, of course. Prices range from $1 into the high hundreds. Part of the proceeds will go to Daytop Village, the drugfree rehabilitation program that serves nearly 77 addicts and drug abusers in nine treatment facilities around the state.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)Cuba's national basketball team will play eight games in the United States Nov. 12 to 25, Senator George McGovern said today.

title: Ashland to Aid Commonwealth Oil By Exercising $50 Million Option
description: The Ashland Oil Company disclosed yesterday that it did plan to come to the rescue of the financially troubled Commonwealth Oil Refining Company of Puerto Rico, a decision that is expected to strengthen the Puerto Rican economy.

title: Management
description: From the corporate standpoint, one of the major ironies of the 1970's involves employment tests  or the dearth of them. Until a few years ago, corporations utilized a variety of psychological and aptitude tests to evaluate and screen new employees. Now, few want to talk about testing and others say cryptically that we don't use tests.

title: Soviet ExPrisoners, Estranged, Appeal to Carter and Brezhnev

To his knowledge of English, French and Spanish, he also added Hindi and Arabic. Now Mr. Repnikov works as a stoker in a heating plant in Strunino, a town about 90 miles east of Moscow.

title: Beene Is Just in Time for Rome's Fall
description: ROME, Sept. 22Geoffrey Beene conquered Rome last night with a presentation of his fall fashion collection at the American Ambassador's residence to an audience that included Victoria Leone, wife of the President of the Italian Republic, and Maria Fanfani, wife of the president of the Italian Senate. More than 200 invited guests, including members of the Governments of both Italy and the United States and members of the Rome social set, sat on the regulation little gold chairs with red velvet cushions in a setting that juxtaposed modern American paintings with old Italian tile floors and crystal chandeliers.

title: Assignment of Teachers by Race: Anxiety in New York City Schools
