description: An obituary in The Times Sunday of Marion K. Sanders, contributing editor of Harper's magazine and biographer of he late Dorothy Thompson, failed to report that at the time of her death she was managing editor of Atlas World Press Review. a position she had held since 1974.

title: Some Democrats Are Expressing Their Concerns That the Byrne Campaign Has Become Slipshod
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Offers from at least three of New Jersey's 11 Democratic Representatives to help Governor Byrne's reelection campaign have been largely ignored, and some of the Democrats feel that the Governor' campaign organization has become slipshod.

title: Art: The Japan Of James Michener
description: SOME 25 YEARS ago James A. Michener was writing Hawaii and living in the island of that name. One of the great amenities of Hawaii in the cultural field is the Honolulu Academy of Arts, which is particularly strong in Japanese art. Such is the geographical situation of Hawaii that those who live there call the East the West and West the East. It is therefore the ideal place in which to form an infatuation with Japanese prints and yet keep one's feet on American soil. Mr. Michener did just that, and by the end of the 1950's he had acquired soma 5,400 Japanese prints and placed them in the Honolulu Academy on permanent loan.

title: Hnueilings
description: KRAMERWilliam C. Sunday. September 25. 9:30am. Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Section lY, Path 1. No postponements.

title: EGYPTIAN SAYS ARABS ARE WILLING TO LIVE IN PEACE WITH ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt said today that Arabs were ready for the first time to accept Israel as a Middle Eastern country to live in peace in this area.

title: Farrell Eleven Raises $20,000 To Fly to Ohio to Play Top Team
description: Dennis Barrett of Monsignor Farrell was looking over his football schedule last spring and realized he needed another game. The coach got one. Boy, did he get one.

title: Radio
description: 78 Aid., WNCN. Variations on God Save the Queen. Paganini; Fetes from Nocturnes. Debussy; Yankee Doodle, with Variations, Hewitt; Six Marches, CPE Bach; Flute and Harp Sonata, DonJuni; Cockaigne Overture, Eiger.

title: Bergland Offers Only Sympathy To Farmers Threatening a Strike
description: PUEBLO, Colo., Sept. 22Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland listened to angry complaints about farm policy today from a crowd of more than 2,000 persons, including hundreds of farmers who are threatening to stop growing crops unless the Federal Government guarantees at least a breakeven price for their produce.

title: Swiss Franc Gains As Dollar Hits Low Third Straight Day
description: The dollar sank to an alltime low against the Swiss franc for the third day in otherwise quiet foreign exchange trading abroad yesterday but recovered somewhat in late New York trading, buoyed by a rising trend in United States shortterm interest rates, The Associated Press reported.

title: China Oil Supply Put At 400 Billion Barrels
description: China, whose reported oil resources have risen and fallen like a roller coaster over the last several years as Westerners have tried to estimate the impact that Chinese oil might have on world supplies, is once again the center of speculation.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1977

title: Television
description: Friday

title: Martin Post, PublicRelations Head Of Jersey College of Medicine, 58
description: Martin Z. Post., director of public relations for the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, died yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital, where he had undergone surgery. He was 58 years old and lived at 25246 Leeds Road in Little Neck, Queens.

title: A LittleUsed Power
description: The melancholy Lance affair has come to a predictable end. If a useful conclusion can be drawn from it, perhaps it is that the Senate ought to put far more time, energy and thought into its Constitutional function of confirmingor rejectingPresidential nominees.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Acting Budget Director
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22It was not yet dawn when James Talmadge McIntyre Jr. walked down the nearly deserted corridors of the Executive Office Building this morning to pick up where his former chief Bert Lance had left off. It was to be a long day, his first as acting director of the Office of Management and Budget. But, aside from giving a pep talk to the agency's senior staff, it was a day much like those he has known ever since he was sworn in as Mr. Lance's deputy 151 days ago, for he has been directing much of the agency's technical work all along.

title: U.S Is Expanding Plan For Training Teachers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)The Government is expanding its Teacher Corps program, which trains teachers how to instruct lowincome students, so as to include other school staff members in poverty areas.

title: PRICES MOVE DOWN IN SOYBEAN FUTURES
description: Dry weather had a dampening effect on soybean futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. To traders, good weather currently indicates more harvesting, which in turn means more beans moving from farms to grain elevators. A large number of grain elevator owners selling futures leads to lower prices.

title: Lance Tells a Cheering Calhoun He's Proud to Be Back Home
description: CALHOUN, Ga., Sept. 22Bert Lance returned to his hometown today, to hero's welcome and an uncertain future.

title: Notes on People
description: Evel Knievel, the mottorycle daredevil, was charged yesterday. in Los Angeles with assaulting a television executive with a baseball bat. He was released on $1,000 bail and is to appear in Municipal Court for arraignment next Wednesday. Mr. Knievel allegedly beat Sheldon Saltman, the executive, outside the commissary at 20th CenturyFox studios, causing Mr. Saltman to suffer a compound fracture of the left arm and a fracture of the right wrist. Lieut. George Tawes of the Los Angeles police said that Mr. Knievel was angry with Mr. Saltman about parts of a book he wrote about Mr. Knievel's unsuccessful attempt to jump the Snake River Canyon in Idaho.

title: BristolMyers Deodorant
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 22 (AP)The BristolMyers Company has introduced an antiperspirant deodorant pump spray designed to capture a significant share of South Africa's $32 million a year deodorant market. It is the first nonaerosol deodorant spray to be marketed in South Africa.

title: PATERSON TO CHECK ON FEDERAL CENSUS
description: PATERSON, Sept. 22A sample census survey of more than 1,100 residents is scheduled to begin here next week. Thedoortodoor survey is part of an effort by city officials to convince the United States Census Bureau that there are 13,000 more people living in the citythe thirdlargest in the statethan the Federal census reflects.

title: An American, 2 Russians Among Cliburn Finalists
description: Seven finalists have been chosen in the Fifth Van Cliburn International Quadrennial Piano Competition, now going on in Fort Worth. They are Alexander Mndoyants and Alexander Toradze of the Soviet Union, MichelJeanJacques Dalberto of France, Christian Blackshaw and Ian Hobson of Britain, Steven DeGroote of South Africa and Jeffrey Swann of the United States. Both Mr. Hobson and Mr. DeGroote have lived and studied in this country in recent years.

title: Antiques: A Fall Shopper's Country Guide to 20 Dealers
description: These days, going antiquing in the country is quite a different weekend experience from the freewheeling activity it was a decade or so ago. Few shoppers nowadays try to drop in unannounced on the top dealers expecting to snare a bargain. Nevertheless, the rewards today can be greater than ever, especially if a fall trip through the antiquesrich countryside from New York City north to Kingston, or east through Connecticut to Stonington, is well planned and the dealers to be seen are forewarned.

title: 3 Delta Rocket Launchings Reset Pending Study of Sept. 13 Explosion
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 22 (UPI)Three Delta rocket launchings have been rescheduled to give a board of inquiry more time to look into a Sept. 13 explosion, the Kennedy Space Center announced today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Cabaret: A Bit of English Fustian
description: Michael Sedgwick is not the kind of singer one normally expects to find in a supper club. He has a welldeveloped, trained voicea strong, high tenorand a delivery that would be completely at home in operettas of the vintage of The Student Prince or Naughty Marietta. In actuality, Mr. Sedgwick's background encompasses more contemporary musicalsthe London productions of Oklahoma! and Brigadoon but his basic style is of an older school.

title: Assembly to Take Up CleanWater Act Curb, Backed by Both Parties
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22Two bills that would prevent the State Department of Environmental Protection from enforcing the New Jersey Clean Water Act were put on the State Assembly calendar today for a vote Monday.

title: Farmers Total Income at Depression Level
description: PRATT, Kan.It was too wet to plow, but that was not the reason for the expression of dismay on Kenneth Lawton's face as he turned away from a field where recent rains were still soaking into the black earth. Something heavier lay on his mind.

title: Sarkis Tells of Contacts
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Sept. 22President Elias Sarkis said today that the new fighting in southern Lebanon had disrupted plans by his Government to send Lebanese soldiers to police the area.

title: Tigers Box Score
description: Cubs 5, Phillies 3

title: AIDE SAYS PRESIDENT ERRED ON LANCE DATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22What President Carter knew about Bert Lance's financial and legal problems and when he knew it is becoming a more confusing matter each time Mr. Carter mentions it

title: White House Strategy on Lance: A Case of Leaving It Up to Bert
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Twenty days ago, one of Bert Lance's closest friends at the White House told Mr. Lance he did not believe the beleaguered budget director could survive in office and that an attempt to make an allout defense at impending Senate hearings would not help. Mr. Lance should try to save his good name, the friend said, but not his job.

title: EGYPTIAN SAYS ARABS ARE WILLING TO LIVE IN PEACE WITH ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt said today that Arabs were ready for the first time to accept Israel as a Middle Eastern country to live in peace in this area.

title: Lance Tells a Cheering Calhoun He's Proud to Be Back Home
description: CALHOUN, Ga., Sept. 22Bert Lance returned to his hometown today, to a hero's welcome and an uncertain future.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Flanagan Subdues Blue Jays, 71
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 22 (AP)Lee May cracked a threerun homer and Mike Flanagan pitched a sixhitter as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 71, tonight and moved within 11,4 games of firstplace New York in the American League East.

title: What's a 4Foot Boa Doing Under a Hood?
description: PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Sept. 22 (UPI) The next time Francis Ludwig's auto sounds bad, she'll know enough to look for a boa constrictor wrapped around her air filter.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 1.6%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.5 billion tonmiles,up 1.6 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 481,709 cars, a rise of 0.8 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage rose 3.2 percent from a year ago.

title: In New Haven, Art's Just Around the Corner
description: There's a real element of serendipity in a new, free art show in New Haven: turn a corner, and then a crank, and you get a celebration of a city.

title: At the Tone, the Correct Phone Number For Time Will Be 9361616, Exactly
description: The telephone numbers that New Yorkers have used for nearly 50 years to find out the correct timeMEridian 71212 or the more familiar NERVOUSwent the way of the live operator and the nickel call yesterday.

title: China Plans 1978 Parley to Revive Scientific Work
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 22China will hold a national conference next spring to promote science, and scientists are to be given more time, money and freedom to pursue their work, it was announced today in Peking.

title: Cosmos Arrive in Calcutta
description: CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 22 (AP)The Cosmos, champions of the North American Soccer League, arrived from China tonight to play an exhibition match Saturday against Mohun Bagan. The match has dominated Calcutta's attention for a week and touched off intense bickering over the 60,000 tickets available to millions of soccer fans.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Dance: Ukrainians
description: AFTER ALL these years of SovietAmerican cultural exchange the unwary might well imagine that we had seen all of the various folkdance ensembles that seem to flourish in the Soviet Union like buds in the spring or supermarkets in the suburbs. Or, at least, if not all of them, at least all of the best of them. The unwary wouldas usual, for that is the nature of unwarinessbe wrong.

title: Egypt Quotes Carter To Back Plea at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22Egypt drew on President Carter's own words today to justify its request for a General Assembly debate on what it termed illegal measures by Israel to establish Jewish settlements on the West Bank of the Jordan.

title: Books of The Times
description: I SUPPOSE that when all is said and done Richard Kluger's third novel, Members of the Tribe his first book since his monumental Simple Justice: The History of Brown v. Board of Education appeared last yearcan be described as a pleasant read. It's got a pretty fair murder trial in it, and a murder that doesn't come to trial, and some erotic byplay, and a duel, and a lynching, and plenty more to keep a reader diverted along the way. Its narratorhero. Seth Adler. is an interesting enough fellow  a young Jew from New York City who goes South in 1878 to seek his fortune in Savannah, Ga., and ends up by dint of hard work and intelligence becoming the defense attorney in the trial that is the novel's centerpiece, as well as a millionaire shareholder in a softdrink enterprise he helps to launch.

title: The Pop Life
description: THIS ERA of crossmedia careers hasn't always produced stars equally talented in everything they do. Especially television stars. They get enormous national and international exposure, particularly if they appear in a regular series. And then they turn to films or the stage or records, and the results aren't always felicitous.

title: TAMMANY LEADERSHIP DRAWS HIGH INTEREST
description: Tammany Hallfamed in New York City political lore, feeble in the reality of its recent, fragmented yearsis about to get a new leader amid the belief that the job might regain some of its oncelegendary power with Edward I. Koch likely to become the Mayor.

title: American Nun, Held in Rhodesia On Security Charges, Is Deported
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept 22Sister Janice McLaughlin, an American Roman Catholic nun who had been imprisoned for three weeks in Rhodesia on charges brought under the country's security laws, was deported today.

title: RaidersSteelers No Wasteland for TV Fans
description: Be there, in front of your television set on Sunday afternoon at 4 P.M. when they kick off in Pitsburgh. The Oakland Raiders, the champions, and the Pittsburgh Steelers, spiteful enemies, meet in the game of the weekend and of the new season. Channel 4 will bring it your way. Earlier, at 2 P.M., you can begin watching the Giants cope with the Cowboys in Dallas (Channel 2). Both local teams are twotouchdown underdogs. The Jets game against the Colts in the Giants Stadium is blacked out, while the Monday night presentation will be between playoff contenders, the Patriots and Browns in Cleveland (Channel 7, 9 P.M.).

title: Mail Delivery to Area Is Stayed Because Fleas Bit the Couriers
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 24 (UPI)Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night stays the mail service, but fleas did.

title: Conway Twitty Returns
description: Success came to Conway Twitty in 1958. I had disbanded my rockandroll group and was back home in Helena, Ark., Mr. Twitty recalled earlier this week, when he arrived in New York to prepare for a weekend engagement at the Westbury Music Fair on Long Island which begins tonight. I had recorded a song called, It's Only Make Believe, Mr. Twitty said, and I was sure it was a hit, but the record had been out three months and hadnt done anything. Actually, they were pushing the flip side,Ill Try. Anyway, I had a call from a disk jockey in Columbus, Ohio. He told me I had a smash in that town.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Colson's Prison Evangelizing. Proves Irksome to Chaplains
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.Charles W. Colson, former aide to President Nixon and a convicted Watergate figure, stood before 200 attentive inmates at the Federal Correctional Institution here the other day and preached his born again message.

title: Calfee, Kite Shoot 66's For OneShot Golf Lead
description: MASON, Ohio, Sept 22 (AP)Bill Calfee shot his best professional round and tied Tom Kite with a fourunderpar 66 today for the firstround lead in the. $150,000 Ohio Kings Island open.

title: RISE IN WORKING MOTHERS RECORDED IN LABOR STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)About half the mothers in the nation with children under 18 years old are now in the labor force, reflecting a tenfold increase since 1940, the Labor Department said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. MEDIATOR TO ENTER DOCK WORKER NEGOTIATION
description: Wayne L. Horvitz, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, is scheduled to enter the dock workers negotiations in Bal Harbour, Fla., today in an effort to help the workers and management reach an agreement before the current contract expires at midnight next Friday.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: 2 Accused of Burning A Car for Insurance
description: CARLE PLACE, L. I., Sept. 22 (AP) Two Coast Guard members face arraignment today on charges of reckless en?angerment for allegedly setting fire to one of the men's autos in the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center here. The police said. They were alleged to have set fire to the car, a 1976 Gremlin valued at $2,600, in an effort to collect the insurance.

title: About Real Estate
description: HOWELL, N.J.Route 9 in Monmouth County is the vehicular spine through what has been one of the most active homebuilding regions in the metropolitan area over the last 10 years. Monmouth itself is among New Jersey's ????? growing counties.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Aug. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. IN) indicates stock! A listed on the New York Stock Ex) change, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows just now among America's young; it takes a salesman to proclaim that the nation is enjoying a flowering of radicalism. And sure enough, the surfacing of Mark Rudd after eight years as a Weatherperson is being used to celebrate the vitality of the radical spirit today.

title: Court Orders Mississippi County To End School Segregation by Sex
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22 (UPI) A Federal appeals court ordered an end today to sexually segregated schools in Amite County, Miss.

title: Management
description: Until a few years ago, companies used a variety of psychological and aptitude tests to evaluate and screen new employees. Now the situation is different, and few want to talk about testing. The cause of the change is a confusion of rules and laws about discrimination. Page D5.

title: Criminal Code to Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 22 (AP)  Four days are being set aside early next month for the Senate Judiciary Committee to consider legislation to overhaul Federal criminal laws. The proposed new criminal code, the product of more than 10 years of effort, was unanimously approved by the Subcommittee on Criminal Laws and Procedure.

title: Market Place
description: It may be of small comfort to investors, for whom the stock market slump this year has spelled bitter disappointment, but their brokers are hurting, too. There are some 15 publicly owned securities firmsmany of whose stocks trade on the New York Stock Exchange and these issues generally are selling near their lowest levels since early 1976.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall said today that illegal aliens entering the United States could defeat the Carter Administration's fight against unemployment.

title: Water Pollution Case Settled
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 22 (AP)The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has agreed to pay $4.5 million for water pollution control equipment at its Sparrows Point plant and $500,000 in civil penalties, Maryland Attorney General Francis B. Burch said today. The settlement is the largest in a water pollution case in Maryland's history, Mr. Burch said.

title: Reserve Report
SYLVIA CHEN SHANGRAW
description: Dr. Sylvia Chen Shangraw, curator of Chinese art at the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco for the last 10 years, died of ancer Sunday. She was 40 years old.

title: Ivan I. Artobolevsky, Soviet Expert On Theoretical Side of Machines
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP)Ivan I, Artobolevsky, a Soviet scientist, has died at the age of 71, Tass reported today.

title: Yonkers Drivers
SCHOOL IN CALIFORNIA FACES SUIT MONDAY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22A new legal attack on the controversial special admissions program of the medical school of the University of California, Davis, comes before a court in Woodland, Calif., on Monday.

title: Restaurants
description: ONE OF THE latest additions to the fastgrowing number of Indian restaurants in the city, the threemonthold Mumtaz on Third Avenue near 84th Street, turns out to be one of the best and most reasonably priced. Unlike several of the more ambitious midtown Indian restaurants that have opened recently, this one has no slickly designed interior. Rather, it uses a somewhat naive draping of fabrics to create a tentlike effect that would be less murky if it had better lighting.

title: FRENCH LEFTISTS PARLEY ENDS ON A DIVIDED NOTE
description: PARIS, Friday, Sept. 23 (AP)A meeting of France's leftist alliance broke up early today with Socialists and Communists still bitterly divided over the issue of nationalization. The parties are seeking to update their joint platform in time for national legislative elections next March.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary in The Times Sunday of Marion K. Sanders, contributing editor of Harper's magazine and biographer of the late Dorothy Thompson, failed the report that at the time of her death Ole was managing editor of Atlas World Press Review. a position she had held since 1974.

title: RESULTS
C.A.B. Gives Passengers 45 Days To File Claims for Lost Baggage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)Airline passengers now have 45 days to file claims for lost or damaged baggage under a rule adopted today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: SENATE KEEPS ALIVE PLAN TO DEREGULATE PRICES FOR NEW GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The Senate handed President Carter another sharp defeat on energy tonight, by voting to keep alive a proposal to end price controls on new natural gas.

title: Orioles Box Score
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 22 (AP)A rookie lefthander, Dan Schatzeder, limited St. Louis to six hits and drove in the winning run with a twoout single in the seventh inning as the Montreal Expos edged the Cardinals, 20, tonight.

title: Publishing: Isak Dinesen in Chicago
description: AMERICA'S university presses do not publish just for college students and professors. Quite often these days, they are putting out books that almost any regular trade house would be proud to include on its list.

title: School Results
description: SOCCER

title: Books: The Towering Caper
description: THE DISASTER NOVEL has almost become a category of popular fiction, like mysteries, romances or Gothics. A term that can encompass Jaws and The Towering Inferno probably is open to charges of imprecision; still, terms arise when there is a need for them and there have veen a lot of books focusing on some sort of central cataclysm, whether manmade or natural, that wipes out a sizable numberof people.

title: Broadway
description: CHEATERS, a new comedy by a new author, will be here on or about Jan. 19. It has a cast of sixtwo couples, one with a son, one with a daughterand its first act takes place ni three separate bedrooms. You may guess that this has at least something to do with marital infidelities, but not to worry because the producers insist that it is funny, too. The producers are Ken Marsolais and Leonard Soloway, with Philip Getter as an associate producer, and the director is Robert Drivas, who, among other things, directed The Ritz. The author, Michael Jacobs, is a young actor.

title: Suit by Reserve Oil Charges Violations
description: Adding yet another thread to the expanding web of civil suits involving the price of uranium, the Reserve Oil and Minerals Corporation yesterday sued the General Atomic Company and its joint owners, the Gulf Oil Corporation and Scallop Nuclear Inc., part of the Royal/ Dutch Shell Group.

title: NEW YORK NOTE SALE PRESSED BY PROXMIRE
description: Senator William Proxmire urged Governor Carey yesterday to summon a special session of the State Legislature to enact whatever legislation is necessary to enable New York City to reenter the public credit market before the end of this year.

title: Upstairs at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22The representatives of the nations are gathered here for their annual review of world political, economic and milltary problems and to put it mildly, they don't like what they see.

title: Art: Suspiciously Easy to Like
description: THE IMPULSE of criticism is to categorize the objects of its concernto divide, so to speak, in order to comprehend. Hence the customary division between the abstract and the representational, between realism and fantasy, and so on. The danger, of course. lies in making such categories more important than the works they comprise, but common sense seems to call for such divisions. Categories answer to something essential in the way we perceive what we experience, and thus aid in understanding, especially what is unfamiliar. Whether they sharpen our esthetic pleasure in what we experience in art is something elsebut sooner or later, I think, they do.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1977

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Amman Isn't Philadelphia
description: The ancient name of Amman, an overgrown village of stately Roman ruins and ersatz Arab palaces is, ironically, Philadelphia, city of brotherly love. It is also the scene of one of the bloodiest of recent fratricide struggles among the Arabs when, in 1970, King Hussein wiped out the militant Palestinians who were threatening the stability of his makeshift regime.

title: Sir Eric Miller, British Realtor Who Was Target of Fund Inquiries
description: LONDON, Sept. 22Sir Eric Miller, a prominent British realty operator and friend of Sir Harold Wilson, died early today from an apparently selfinflicted gunshot wound. He was 50 years old.

title: CAR AND TRUCK PRODUCERS PLANNING HEAVY OVERTIME
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22 (UPI)Car and truck producers this week are planning the heaviest overtime schedule since the startup of 1978model production during the summer as they prepare to introduce the new models.

title: Solar Heating Grants Awarded
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22The State Energy Office awarded grants of $400 each today to 867 persons in the New York City metropolitan area for the installation of hotwater systems using solar energy. A total of 1,738 persons applied for the, federally financed grants, said James L. Larocca, acting chief of the State Energy Office, and the winners were picked in a drawing.

title: The U.N. Today
SENATE KEEPS ALIVE PLAN TO DEREGULATE PRICES FOR NEW GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The Senate handed President Carter another sharp defeat on energy tonight, by voting to keep alive a proposal to end price controls on new natural gas.

title: A TugofLaw Over Canvases
description: THE COURT BATTLE that began last May over the canvases of Arnold Friedman (18721946), a painter praised by critics but ignored by an marketeers, has been wonat least for the momentby heirs to his estate. Surrogate Louis D. Laurino of Queens County has decided that 305 Friedman works in the possession of Charles Egan, an art dealer. must be returned to the Friedman heirs.

title: The Standings
description: Friday. September 23, 1977

title: Assignment of Teachers by Race: Anxiety in New York City Schools
description: As 3,500 laidoff New York City schoolteachers were rehired in recent weeks, they dipped into boxes and pulled out their school assignments. Black and Hispanic teachers chose from one box, white teachers from another.

title: Basic Money Supply Rose by $2 Billion; Credit Prices Drop
description: The nation's basic money expanded sharply in midSeptember, and the increase apparently led the Federal Reserve yesterday to push shortterm interest rates up another notch.

title: Fair Set in Mamaroneck
description: More than 60 craftsmen will exhibit jewelry, pottery, needlepoint, quilts and sculpture at the Emelin Theater Street Fair, to be held Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Library Lane in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Magicians, musicians and mime artists will entertain children and there will be an outdoor cafe offering snacks as well as a jazz concert. In case of rain the fair will be held Oct. 2. Information at the Emelin Theater: (914) 6983054.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT

title: World Cup Soccer
description: QUALIFYING ROUND

title: Tigers 54 Victors on 4Run 7th
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22 (UPI)Steve Kemp, who has more runs batted in than any other rookie in the league, stroked a tworun double in the middle of a fourrun seventh inning tonight as the Detroit Tigers posted a 54 victory over Boston and put a severe crimp in the Red Sox's American League Eastern Division title hones.

title: BORYS MARTOS, EXLEADER  OF INDEPENDENT UKRAINE
description: IRVINGTON, N. J., Sept. 22 (UPI) Funeral services are scheduled Saturday for Borys Martos, who headed an independent Ukrainian government in Kiev in 191920 before the Bolshevik takeover. He died Monday at the age of 98.

title: Italy's Payments Surplus Rose To Record $1.03 Billion in August
description: ROME, Sept. 22 (Reuters)Italy had a record $1.03 billion balanceofpayments surplus in August, enabling it to repay some of its heavy foreign debt, the Bank of Italy announced today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: For the second day, an aerial search of a 130squaremile area of Long Island failed to turn up any trace of a singleengine plane carrying the son and daughterinlaw of former Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino.

title: Little Fallout Expected From Cloud Passing Over the East Coast Tonight
description: Radioactive debris from the Chinese nuclear test conducted in the atmosphere last Saturday is expected to begin passing over the New York metropolitan area and other parts of the Northeastern coast at midnight tonight. Its passage is expected to continue for about 24 hours, according to the Brookhaven National Laboratory here.

title: People in Sports
description: Tom McMillen, a 6foot11inch forward who is beginning his first full season with the Knicks, suffered a pulled muscle in his right calf and will miss practice for six or seven days. He will not be available for duty when the Knicks begin their National Basketball Association preseason schedule against the New Jersey Nets in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.

title: NEW YORK NOTE SALE PRESSED BY PROXMIRE
description: Senator William Proxmire urged Governor Carey yesterday to summon a special session of the State Legislature to enact whatever legislation is necessary to enable New York City to reenter the public credit market before the end of this year.

title: Armco Steel, Citing Import Inroads, Will Lay Off 600 at 2 Plants in Ohio
description: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Sept. 22 (UPI)The Armco Steel Corporation citing inroads made by steel imports, antipollution projects and inflation, announced today that it would eliminate 600 jobs at two Ohio plants. It was the second cutback this week by a major steel producer.

description: Film

title: 29 Americans Arrive From Cuba With 26 Relatives Under Accord
description: HOMESTEAD AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Sept. 22Twentynine Americans and 26 of their Cuban relatives arrived from Havana today in what President Carter called the first in What we hope will be a series of similar humanitarian actions on the part of the Government of Cuba.

title: Women Who Waited: Starting a Family After the Age of 30
description: When Joan Sibley, a fashion designer and manufacturer, went to her obstetrician to confirm her pregnancy several years ago, he smiled at her and said, Thirtythree. You're the perfect age for a woman in New York to have a baby.

title: High Cuban Official To Visit Washington For Talks on Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Cuba's Minister of Foreign Trade, Marcelo Fernandez Font, is scheduled to visit Washington next month to speak to American businessmen and politicians interested in reopening trade with Cuba, State Department officials reported today.

title: Wave Threatens Puerto Rico
description: MIAMI, Sept. 22 (UPI)A sprawling tropical wave skirting the northern Caribbean moved toward the Dominican Republic and Haiti today while continuing to threaten Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands with stormy weather.

title: Sunday
description: Cecily Barth Firestein, the rubbing expert who ruefully notes that she is now known as the graveyard lady, will return to Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx on Sunday at 1 P.M. to lead another stonerubbings tour. The afternoon will begin with a 45minute lecturedemonstration in Woolworth Chapel. Then Mrs. Firestein will lead the group to the cemetery's older section for some firsthand experience. Mrs. Firestein, author of the recently published Rubbing Craft, says that she plans to emphasize the crafts aspect of rubbingshow to make Tshirts, hooked rugs, embroidery and other things besides framing them. Cost of the program, sponsored by the Bronx Historical Society, is $4 ($1 for children under 12). Rubbing kits will be sold for $1.25. Everyone will be given a map showing the locations of Woodlawn's celebrity graves, and after the program you can wander around and make rubbings of famous tombstones. Information: 8818900. Rain date: Oct. 16.

title: A Mix Up Leaves 30 Irish Amateur Soccer Players Stranded in State
description: EAST ORANGE, Sept. 22It was Thursday and 30 touring Irish amateur soccer players were supposed to be at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. But a misunderstanding over finances had disrupted their prearranged itinerary and the Irishmen were in an East Orange restaurant eating ziti and roast beef, complaining of a local insurance man.

title: Criminal Law and the Other 5 Percent
description: Some liberals, President Carter observed drily last spring, are hard to please: If they get 95 percent of what they want, they can only remember the other 5 percent. That problem seems to be afflicting the patient effort to revise and reform the Federal criminal laws.

title: Japan's August Auto Production Rose 8.2% to a Record 598;314
description: TOKYO, Sept. 22 (UPI)Japan's automobile production last month reached a record for any August at 598,314 units, up 8.2 percent from a year ago, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: GATT CITES GROWTH OF INFORMAL CURBS THAT DISRUPT TRADE
description: PARIS, Sept. 22International trade is increasingly being subjected to informal and disruptive restrictions that many governments want to make permanent, according to a new report prepared by the secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: PARK SERVICE BUYING MORE PRIVATE LAND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  The United States Park Service is stepping up its purchases of property in the older national parks to prevent private developments.

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Down To 201 From 201.4 a Week Ago
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 201 in the latest week from 201.4 last week.

title: Pamela Jean White Wed To Harold Riebesell Jr.
description: Pamela Jean White, a legal assistant with the Denver law firm of James Lapin, was married yesterday to Harold Frederick Riebesell Jr., a partner in the Denver law firm of Mason, Reuler and Peek. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church in Hilton Head, S.C., by the Rev. Dr. James Black.

title: Accounting Board Moves to Drop A Financial Disclosure Regulation
description: The private sector's authority on accounting rules moved yesterday to scrap a requirement that companies disclose data on such things as major customers in their quarterly financial reports.

title: Rate of New York's Pupil Losses Is Lowest of Nation's Big Cities
description: Although enrollment in New York City public schools has declined in recent years and is expected to drop even more through the remainder of the 1970's, the city's losses are proportionately smaller than those in the nation's other big cities, the City Planning Commission reported in a study released yesterday.

title: New Dawn Is Joining North American List
description: The North American Publishing Company, has added a third consumer magazine to its titles (Cue and Audio) by acquiring New Dawn from the Montcalm Publishing Company.

title: Marcel Carpentier of France, 82; Led NATO Units in Central Europe
description: PARIS, Sept. 22 (Reuters)Gen. Marcel Carpentier, who commanded Atlantic forces in central Europe until 1956, died last week at his Loire Valley home, his family announced today. He was 82 years old.

title: Zooming In on Film at Lincoln Center
description: THE ROSTER FOR THE 15th New York Film Festival, which begins a 17day run this evening at Lincoln Center with Agns Varda's One Sings, the Other Doesnt, is dominated by big and familiar European names. France will be represented by a diverse and impressive group of entries. In addition to Miss Varda's film, a tale of two feminist friends, there is Francois Truffaut's The Man Who Loved Women, starring Charles Denner and a long list of leading ladies. Robert Bresson's The Devil Probably, his 12th feature, will be shown. and so will Luis Bunuel's That Obscure Object of Desire, in which Fernando Rey fails in love with a woman played by two different actresses. Other French entries include The Truck, starring Grard Depardieu and the director Marguerite Duras (starring a fiveaxle truck, too), and L'Enfant de Paris, a 1913 film rediscovered by the late Henri Langlois that is billed as providing an extraordinary picture of the Riviera at the beginning of the century.

title: Fire in an Oxygen Pump Delays Test of Space Shuttle's Engines
description: A fire in an oxygen pump, the second in six months, has interrupted ground testing of the space shuttle's rocket engines. But project officials expressed confidence that the trouble should not disrupt timetables leading toward the new craft's first orbital flight in the spring of 1979.

The teenager was hit by flying glass and was reported in good condition at Bridgeport Hospital. The po?? said they suspected arson.

title: Molly McMahon Is Bride Of Frank Julien Maguire

Paul Duane of the Vineyard Haven (Mass.) Yacht Club after seven races. Each has 19 points in this championship, for the Clifford D. Mallory Cup.

They saw the High Chief Ranger of the ledependent Order of Foresters throw out the first ball and they heard an amateur singer from London, Ontario, start The StarSpangled Banner this way: Oh, say can you hear by the dawn's early light.

title: MISS KRUPSAK'S AIDES DEFEND USING PLANES

title: Paralyzed Economists, Stagnant Economy
description: A decade ago, had unemployment been frozen at a high rate and the economy appeared headed for a slowdown, a Democratic President surely would have called for major economic stimulusa tax cut, a spending increase or both. But not now. Despite the unsatisfactory performance of the economy, policy is paralyzed because economists here and elsewhere in the industrialized world have lost their faith in rapid economic growth. They fear that faster growth would generate more inflation and, ultimately, sink us into another recession. We are left with uncommon inflation, high unemployment and fearful economists.

description: Brooklyn College scored three quick firstquarter touchdowns and added a field goal in the final quarter to defeat Manhattan, 2410, at the winner's field last night. Eddie Conroy scored on 27 and 2yard runs. John D'Iorio added the third touchdown. George Fidel kicked a 24yard field goal.

title: Trees That Like the City
description: We thought that we would never see a Crimson Cloud hawthorne, Allegheny serviceberry or Carolina silverbell as a New York City tree; but these exoticsounding varieties are among those recommended by the Department of City Planning and the New York Botanical Garden for planting on city streets. What do they have in common with the Ohio buckeye and littleleaf linden besides seductive names? The same thing that all New Yorkers have in common: stamina and the will to survive. According to the city guide, the 99 trees suggested for New York have proved themselves able to grow under duress in the abusive city environment. They have made it against the odds. Our response is instant empathy.

description: 1. For years, the way to get the correct time by telephone was to dial MEridian 71212 or alternatively, the numbers corresponding to NERVOUS. Those numbers will still get you the time until Oct. 15, but even now a recording gives the caller a new num. ber to dial for the time. What is the new number?

title: Consumer Notes
description: With home heating oil prices already up by one and a half cents in some sections of the state and further increases of up to a nickel a gallon projected, the State Energy Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobson, said yesterday that he would aggressively monitor the oil price structure.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 23Two bills that conservationists have said would endanger New Jersey's proposed cleanup of the state's water, were withdrawn today from the calendar of the State Assembly.

title: Opera: A Sweet and New Figaro
description: The love affair between Julius Rudel an dthe Mozart operas is by now an old story. City Opera's new production of Le Nozze di Figaroor, one should say, The Marriage of Figaro, as it was sung in the Ruth and Thomas Martin translation. Why a new Figaro when the old one was still serviceable? Love knows no bounds; and, anyway, Mr. Rudel, who conducted, keeps thinking about the Mozart operas, and continues to have new insightss.

title: Mehta Excites the Philharmonic
description: Zubin Mehta does not become music director of the New York Philharmonic until next season, but a preview of sorts is currently being afforded by the Bombayborn conductor in his oneweek guest engagement with the orchestra. While it would be foolish to try to construct an artistic profile based on one programs evidence, it was nonetheless apparent from Thursday night's subscription concert that in Mr. Mehta the Philharmonic has a conductor determined to bring a rather traditional kind of musical excitement back to Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Carey Choice for a Health Czar Is Resisted by Beame and Koch
description: Governor Carey's latest attempt to fill a position that state officials have likened to a health czar for New York City generated strong resistance yesterday from Mayor Reeme and Representative Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO CURB FORCED RETIREMENT BEFORE THE AGE OF 70
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to increase from 65 to 70 the age at which employers may require their workers to retire.

title: Gelsey Kirkland Is a Joy in The Nutcracker
description: In no version known to man is Clara in The Nutcracker one of the great ballet roles of legendnot even when, as in Mikhail Baryshnikovs recent staging of ballet for American Ballet Theater, she gets to dance in place of the Sugar Plum Fairy in the last act. Yet Mr. Baryshnikov's production does at least give his heroine something to dream about as well as something to dance, and just how good a part Clara can be was neatly demonstrated by Gelsey Kirkland at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night.

title: Air Force Plans to Assign Women To Titan MissileLaunching Crews
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The Air Force is planning to assign women to underground missile silos, giving them the same role that men have in launching nuclear weapons.

title: Two Documentaries Depict Erosion of Ideals by Time
description: History recollected by the people who made it and the inevitable erosion of ideals by time are the themes shared by a pair of American documentaries, "Men of Bronze" and Children of Labor," which will be shown at the 15th New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 6 and Monday at 9:30 P.M.Of the two, "Men of Bronze," which is about the exploits of the largely black 369th U.S. Infantry Regiment in World War I, is the most moving and finished, if only because the film makers have somehow scaled their subject to the dimensions of film. "Children of Labor" examines the social and political history of Finnish immigrants to this country beginning at the turn-of-the-century, with emphasis on the radical Finnish-American tradition. The film is effective as far as it goes but the subject appears to be too big and complex to fit neatly into a 53-minute movie.William Miles, who directed "Men of Bronze," and Paul Killiam who produced the film with Mr. Miles, have constructed their film out of old newsreel footage and stills and, most importantly, from interviews with three excellent subjects.The first is the patrician Hamilton Fish Sr., who was a captain with the 369th and who seems to represent the best of an American aristocratic tradition long gone. Another is Melville T. Miller, is still wonderfully garrulous, witty Brooklyn man who enlisted in the 369th when it was still a part of the New York National Guardit didn't receive its Federal designation until it was attached to the French Army in 1918.Mr. Miller, now in his mid-seventies, appears to remember everything clearly but with the particular detachment of time that can make even the most hair-raising memories funny.The most interesting interview, even though he says less than the other two, is the comparatively taciturn Frederick H. Williams, a grizzled old black man whose memories are not entirely sweet, and whose silences and pauses suggest that, in his case, time may not have healed all wounds."Men of Bronze" is a fine tribute to the history of the 369th, whose spectacular battle records proved that black soldiers were fit for considerably more than stevedore duty. This is a lesson that apparently wasn't even understood by World War Two, when the United States Navy would pressure black enlistees to take mess dutythough, of course, there was no doubt in anyone's mind by the time Vietnam came along."Children of Labor" is no less sincere but the subject is too vast to be covered by a short film except in a sort of textbook style that touches names, dates and places so rapidly that at the end you suspect you might be subjected to a spot quiz.

title: Vilas Advances in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 23 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas, the United States Open champion from Argentina, defeated Hans Gildemeister of Chile, 61, 62, today in a $50,000 Grand Prix tournament.

title: Meanwhile, Back in the Senate
description: In newspaper terms the Bert Lance affair was a big story. A big story is often just that, A big story. Rita Weds My. The Lance story was better than that. At least we learned something about President Carter's character. But like so many big stories, while big, it was also not terribly important to many people outside Washington political society.

title: Peruvian Girl Wins Alien Resident Status
description: A 13year old Peruvian girl who had been the subject of a dispute between the Long Island family with which she has been living and the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has been given permanentresident alien status by the service. The new status permits her to leave the United States without fear of being denied permission to return.

title: Adolescent Pregnancy
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassThe United States faces a problem that has reached the dimensions of a national disaster, comparable to a flood, epidemic or famineand one that results, similarly, from a colossal flaw of nature. That flaw is the precipitous, unprecedented drop in the age of puberty; the problem is the spread of teenage pregnancy.

title: East Germany Is Expelling Critics
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 23East Germany is moving to rid itself of hundreds of critics of the leadership by forcing them to emigrate before a discussion of human rights issues begins at the European se curity conference in Belgrade next month.

N.Y., Sept. 23Steven Biko was eulogized here today as a visionary who brought special hope to South African blacks and his recent death while in police detention was characterized by diplomats from dozens of African and Asian countries as an atrocity committed by Prime Minister John Vorster's white minority government.

title: People and Business
description: William G. Mitchell, who is 46 years of age, has resigned as chairman and chief corporate officer of the Beatrice Foods Company. Announcing this yesterday, the Chicagobased company noted that Wallace N. Rasmussen, 63, who has been president and chief executive officer, has been elected chairman. He will continue as chief executive officer. Beatrice gave no reason for Mr. Mitchell's resignation but said he would continue in a consulting capacity. There have been reports this week of policy and personality differences between the two men.

title: Mike Hill Leads by a Stroke on 133

title: Reaction to the Concorde Plan: Dismay and Applause

title: Miss Casals Will Coach U.S. Wightman Cup Team

title: A French Silent of 1913 Holds Up
description: "L'Enfant de Paris" is an exceptionally well-photographed 1913 silent film that has been included in the New York Film Festival partly because it was a personal favorite of the late Henri Langlois, founder of the Cinemathque Francaise. Directed by Leonce Perret, who made or appeared in an estimated 600 films (21 of them in America) before he died in 1935, the movie tells the story of an almost inhumanly sweet little girl who is kidnapped by scoundrels.The story is unexceptional, and so is Perret's general approach. But his technical sophistication is quite impressive, particularly during a long sequence in which the kidnapper has the good taste to cart his captive off to Nice. "L'Enfant de Paris" is well worth seeing on the strength of its location footage alone.As the film begins, the little girl is rich and happy, safe in the bosom of her loving family. Half an hour later her father, a soldier, has disappeared in battle, and her mother has died of grief. The sweet little girl is sent to an orphanage???, where the other girls laugh at her and the teachers take her favorite doll away.When she escapes from the orphanage and faints as a result of her exertions, a crook comes along to steal her gold locket, which of course contains pictures of her poor, lost parents. As an afterthought, he steals her???, too.The little girl, who is carried through the film like a human suitcase, winds up in the predictable den of iniquity, living with a drunken shoemaker and his hunchbacked assistant. The assistant falls in love with the little girl, rather unwholesomely, and eventually returns her to her father, who is, of course, not dead after all. In movies as treacly as this one, fathers who disappear in battle seldom are.The little girl, Suzanne LeBret, has a strangely middle-aged face and an acting range that allows for little more than her extending her arms joyfully or staring tragically at the floor. The crook, played by Louis Leubas, is more interesting, because he oozes crookedness from every pore, as do his very amusing henchmen. "L'Enfant de Paris" has no dialogue subtitles, only a few printed telegrams and newspaper articles, and would seemingly lend itself to overacting of the most painful kind. Fortunately, many of the performances are as unexpectedly forth???-right as the stunning pre-World War I landscapes.

title: Screen: 'Femmes Fatales' Opens:Movie Falters After Getting Off to Fairly Good Start
description: For a while, "Femmes Fatales," the French film that opened yesterday at the Columbia II and Quad 3 theaters, gives indication of accomplishing the considerable feat of being a successful comedy about misogyny.But about halfway along it stops deriving its strength from the portrayals of Jean-Pierre Marielle as a jaded gynecologist and Jean Rochefort as an irrisistible pimp who is his companion in flight from women. Instead, it shifts abruptly in mood and focus from their new lives in a tiny village where they loaf, cook, eat, drink, befriend the local clergy and counsel a young boy against the consequences of sex.In a jarring transition from reality into fantasy, "Femmes Fatales" transforms its two principals into leaders of a horde of like-minded refugees. Pursued by a uniformed army of lubricious women, the pair are taken prisoner and turned into scientifically monitored studs before they are turned outbroken, terrified and prematurely agedto a bleak life-on-the-run that brings them to an ironic and unexpected final destination.The effect of the transition is very much as though Bertrand Blier, who also directed "Going Places," had lost his footing on the most slippery high wire he could find. Certainly these are not the times when the making of a movie that makes women and their sexuality the objects of scorn and revulsion can be deemed anything less than an exercise in risk and an invitation to condign condemnation.But thanks to the credibility of Mr. Marielle as the gynecologist, Paul, and to Mr. Rochefort as the pimp, Albert, director Blier manages to teeter about halfway toward success on his own terms before turning cosmic and plunging into artistic failure."Femmes Fatales," sexually graphic, foul-mouthed, intermittently funny, initially deft and ultimately clumsy, is neither witty enough nor strong enough to override the current of social history. Narrow and likely to offend many, it stands like a bigot at a conference on brotherhood, capable of generating laughter, yes, but chiefly remarkable for insensitivity to time and place.

title: Steak and Cheops
description: My own introduction to Egyptian food was cataclysmic. I had bought a great mound of melukhiya leaves, grown fresh in some pseudoNilotic neck of New Jersey and sold in the Syrian souk on Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, to transplanted Cairenes and xenophilic folk like me who wanted to prepare the national soup of Egypt. My recipe came from an Egyptian Jew and called for a blender to pure the leaves with stock, I turned on the motor and a pebble, goodsized, crashed at high speed through the glass of the blender jar, leaving a neat hole and permitting a mess of leaves and liquid to pour out on the linoleum below.

title: Brazilian Story of a Saint Puzzles
description: "Tent of Miracles" is to be commended on a couple of scores: It condemns racism and it was made in Brazil; a country whose films don't receive much representation in this country. It's also the story of a very saintly man; and certainly such stories are rare these days. That said, "Tent of Miracles" is also too messy and jumbled to have many other selling points.The subject of the film is Pedro Archanjo, a black Bahian sociologist who is also supposed to have been a brilliant philosopher, his principal theory being that miscegenation is necessary and healthy for Brazilian society. Unfortunately, his story is told and discussed by a bunch of hip young film makers, supposedly at work on a biographical movie, who aren't properly equipped to explain his genius. Their story, which takes up almost as much time as the movie-within-a-movie about Archanjo, is uninteresting and at times almost unintelligible.Archanjo turns out to have been a man who enthusiastically practiced what he preached. In the film's best sequences, he appears as a young man, involved with women of all shades and persuasions and merrily outraging the supposedly white upper classes. One of Archanjo's theories is that everyone in Bahia is of mixed blood anyway, and one of his supposedly most daring acts is to publish a booklet naming black ancestors of all the fanciest white families.Nelson Pereira dos Santos is a well-established Brazilian director, but the film is surprisingly clumsy, almost amateurish at times: for instance, it is at first difficult to tell whether the footage of Archanjo's story is meant to be a series of flashbacks or excerpts from the film being made. A white American scientist, who yells things such as "May I have my money?" at the top of his lungs, is supposed to be a Nobel Laureate but looks more like a freshman quarterback. Sonia Dias is a great beauty, but her ubiquitousness in the film goes entirely unexplained.

description: PARIS, Sept. 23The lethargic Paris stock exchange came to life today and relief swept through France's dispirited business community: the Communists and Socialists were quarreling.

title: POLICE FIRE IN SOWETO AFTER THEY ARE STONED
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Policemen opened fire with shotguns and pistols in the black township of Soweto tonight when they were stoned by crowds of blacks waiting for buses to go to the funeral of Steve Biko, the black activist who died in detention last week.

title: JOSEPH W. CHAMBERLIN
description: Joseph W. Chamberlin, former president or Million. Market Newspapers Inc., a national newspaper advertising sales organization, died Thursday in Rancho Santo Fe, Calif., where he had lived since his retirement last year. He was 64 years old.

title: Food
description: Perhaps you know Maida Heatter. If not as a cookbook author, which you should, at least as the lady who painstakingly created a book of recipes, testing each one down to the last jot of salt, the last spot of sugar, only to discover on the day the hook was accepted by a publisher that the temperature of her oven was, and had been for several months, critically off by 25 degrees. Thus she began again, a jot of salt here, a spot of sugar there, and so on. From scratch.

title: Pele's Farewell: What Soccer Has Meant
description: I believe that the beautiful game of soccer has arrived in the United States not to take the place of the other great American sports. I believe it is here to simply complete the repertory of sports fans in this great country? For, I believe, American sports fans are the greatest fans in the world and they deserve another pastime.

title: 4 Families: Life Dictates Style
description: AGREENWICH WOMAN keeps a long dress for social emergencies in her Manhattan pied a terre....A Long Island teenager claims that she can walk perfectly well on her towering platform shoes and, when no one is looking, releases her feet to the security of the ground. ...In Westchester, one of the country's largest markets for the pinstripe suit, a cartoonist proudly admits to owning only one jacketalthough it is a Cardin . . ..A newcomer to rural Sussex County, N.J., mourns the lack of fashionable stores.

Cushman Jr., son of Lieutenant General Cushman, U.S.A., and Mrs. Cushman. General Cushman is commander of the First Corps Group in South Korea.

title: LET'S PUT DETENTE BACK ON THE RAILS
description: President Carter's approach to the Russians is on the wrong track. This is a severe judgment, but coexistence is a fateful issue. The direction the new President takes in his dealings with the Kremlin will predetermine the state of SovietAmerican relations and hence the lot of mankind  for a decade ahead. The attitudes that control the way great powers act and react toward each other cannot be shifted back and forth from year to year. Therefore, it is of paramount importance that we consider now where we are going and where we'll end up.

title: Game at Montclair Reset
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 24The Montclair StateSouthern Connecticut football game scheduled for tonight at 8 o'clock has been rescheduled for 7 P.M. tomorrow.

title: A Harpsichordist Comes Home to Yale
description: WHEN Ralph Kirkpatrick goes onstage at Sprague Hall next Friday, it will be more than just another concert. For one thing, the evening will be an affectionate homecoming to Yale University, where the renowned harpsichordist was on the music faculty for more than 25 years. For another, it will be Mr. Kirkpatrick's first New Haven recital in nearly a decade. And perhaps most important, the event will mark yet another milestone in the artist's winning battle against personal adversity.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: The touring pros are fond of saying how easy the sand shot is, but we weekend golfers know better. We find getting out of bunkers about as simple as getting out of debt.

title: Tightening Welfare Procedures At 7 Centers Reduces New Cases
description: A new staff training program his helped tighten welfare application procedures in seven New York City centers so that 45 percent of the applications are rejected during first tests, as opposed to 28 percent last fall.

title: The Disabled Get a Legacy
description: WHEN St. Jude's Habilitation Institute took title earlier this year to property in Pleasantville, the organization acquired considerably more than an imposing mansion and six acres of land. The institute, which cares for children with multiple handicaps, now owns an impressive piece of Westchester history, a part of the legacy of the Hays family, one of the county's distinguished old families.

title: Ustinov's Many Lives
description: THE color photograph of Peter Ustinov on the dust jacket of Dear Me sells his autobiography as if it were yet another celebrity puff job. Certainly there is enough in Ustinovs long and varied career to ballyhoo. As playwright, novelist, shortstory writer, actor, film director, raconteur, Ustinov has turned his urbane intelligence to all facets of public entertainment and made a good show of it. Dear Me is addressed to Ustinov's alter ego and puns on the conventional shallow celebrity romp through trials and triumphs. But Dear Me is the exception: an unusually graceful memoir whose wit bears witness to Ustinov's generosity and seriousness.

title: Erving Injures Knee In 76er Scrimmage
description: COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP)  Julius Erving injured his left knee today during a scrimmage at the Philadelphia 76ers training camp at Ursinus College.

description: When we set about hunting for a home in the country, we knew almost nothing about historic houses of New England, but after years of living in Manhattan where cardboard apartment buildings seem to rise and fall with the sun, we knew we wanted something solid. And preferably historic, to boot.

title: HOME CLINIC

This not only calls for additional insulation and weatherstripping where needed, but also requires heating system that is operating at maximum efficiency.

description: THE Washington political novel was once the more or less exclusive province of journalists Allen Drury, Fletcher Knebel, Tom Wicker, Les Whitten and Ward Just come to mindbut recent years the newsmen/novelists have faced stiff competition from an unlikely source: Presidential assistants who, upon emerging from the White House, have produced works of fiction rather than traditional nonfiction memoirs.

title: The Outlook From the Industry
description: All over America, there is a renewed emphasis on the home. As people spend more time there and entertain more there, they insist that their homes reflect their own individual tastes. And there are home furnishings available to suit everyone's requirements. Since the 60's Americans have acquired the freedom to mix. Today, 18thcentury Chippendale is put with Bau haus glass and chrome and a dash of updated 17thcentury China. Lord & Taylor's Frank Watson, vice president and general merchandise manager, says, People are more confident today, and even better, they're willing to spend their money. Armed with this new confidence, Americans are looking to informal elegance or sophisticated rusticity. The feeling is natural and sensual, soft and romantically lit. Here, then, from some of the leaders of the home furnishings industry, is the news in furniture, lighting, floor coverings and accessories.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr, and Mrs. James Raymond French of the engagement of their daughter, Patti Lynn French, to Lars Anders Tegenborg, son of Mr. and Mrs, Carl John Tegenborg of Westport, Conn. The wedding is planned for Dec. 2.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)The House yesterday voted final Congressional approval for a fiveyear, $892 million extension of Federal programs to assist library construction and services. The bill would authorize money for public library construction and services, interlibrary cooperation and library services, for the elderly.

description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 24 Surprising interest in New York surfaced today in the countdown before the United States Olympic Committee will make its decision on the American city to bid for the 1984 Summer Olympics.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Architectural drawing has come out of the drafting room closet. It is going public with a bang this fall, in at least five shows in three cities, either on view now or scheduled later. An important double exhibition opened in New York this week called Drawing Toward a More Modern Architecture that is being held simultaneously at the Cooper Hewitt Museum (2 East 91st Street) and downtown at The Drawing Center (137 Greene Street). It will continue until Nov. 6 at both places. This will be followed by a show at the Leo Castelli Gallery in October.

title: Native Orchids: How to Cultivate Them
description: A NUMBER of choice New Jersey wildflowers that are best planted in early autumn, when they are dormant, are available now from wildflower nurseries. Trilliums, for instance. And orchids.

title: The Nation
description: The United States Supreme Court often decides important constitutional cases on the narrowest possible grounds, lest general principles come back to haunt the Court in the future. Last week the Justice Department, for political as well as legal reasons, urged the Court to decide narrowly in the case of Allan Bakke, who claims that he was denied admission to the University of California Medical School at Davis because he is white.

title: To Seal Cold Drafts Out and Keep Heat In
description: One of the easiest and least expensive ways to conserve fuel and energy in many homes and apartments is to add weatherstripping to doors and win dows that do not already have it, or replace old weatherstripping that is no longer doing its job of sealing out cold drafts.

title: Trials of the People's Courts
description: IN THE IDEAL world the Small Claims Court provides ordinary people with the means of settling a dispute in an informal atmosphere without lawyers and legal mumbojumbo. There are no juries. The judge works within the law, of course, but it is still the judges common sense that is supposed to lead him to a decision. It is called the peoples court and it is meant to provide an easy, simple remedy to their problems. Connecticut, like other states, is striving for such a goal, and recent reforms here may move the state a little closer.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP)A 69yard touchdown pass from Mike Fallon, the quarterback, to a wide receiver Dennis Dent in the second period today keyed the University of Massachusetts to a 170 victory over Haryard.

title: Topics
description: MAMMOGRAPHY MISTAKE Evidence continues to mount that the nation's massive breast cancer screening project, started by the America Cancer Society and funded largely by the National Cancer Institute, was iilconceived and even dangerous. According to a new study of the project's operation over four years, 58 women had their breasts wholly or partly removed because of erroneous diagnoses of cancer. The Xrays did indeed pick up tumors that were not detected by physical examination alone. But someincluding those in the 58 womenwere later determined to be benign.

title: Florida Downs Miss. State, 2422
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 24 (UPI)Terry LeCount raced 16 yards for a touchdown with 57 seconds left today to enable 10thranked Florida to salvake a 2422 victory over 16thranked Mississippi State in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: LORNA LOCKWOOD, EXHEAD OF HIGH COURT IN ARIZONA
description: Lorna Lockwood, a former Chief Jus tice of the Arizona Supreme Court, the nation's first woman Chief Justice of a state Supreme Court, died of pneumonia yesterday in Phoenix. She was 74 years old.

title: White and Black and Everything Else
description: With his first book of stories, Hue and Cry, James Alan McPherson established his standpoint as that of a writer and a black, but not that of a black writer. He refused to let his fiction fall into any colorcode or ethnic code, remarking, Certain of the people happen to be black and certain happen to be white; but I have tried to keep the color part of most of them far in the background, where these things should rightly be kept. Occasionally, he found this credo impossible to maintain, especially when a story demanded strong identification with strong black charactersas in the fine piece, A Solo Song: For Doc, which retraced the lifetime service of two railroad dining car waiters, a study in pride and injury.

title: The Little School Carries On
description: MARGARET TERRY gazed at three rows of empty desks in the classroom where she has taught fourth, fifthand sixthgraders simultaneously for the last eight years. In addition to teaching, Mrs. Terry is also the principal of the threeroom New Suffolk School, where 29 students are enrolled in kindergarten through sixth grade.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Michael Pertschuk, an ardent consumer protectionist who spent his earlier Government career trying to influence business and industry, bounded into the chairmanship of the Federal Trade Commission last spring with the expectation that the slowmoving agency would serve as the country's largest public interest law firm.

Hunter completed touchdown bombs of 21, 43 and 80 yards to Byron McMillan, a wide receiver, and hooked up with Rich Alston from 7 yards out. Alston scored Barringer's other touchdown on a 40yard burst. Hunter hit on six of nine passes for 169 yards.

description: LONDON, Sept. 24Andrew D. Silk, a 24yearold American student, said here today that his departure from South Africa yesterday was the result of his own decision and that he had not been deported.

title: Personal Journalist
description: JAMES BOSWELL is back. (He was never away.) We rejoin him during dangerous, adventurous years. But all Boswell's years were dangerous and adventurous. During autumn 1779, my left great toe troubled me a good deal. Physicians attend it. More than once Boswell dreams of it. In January he becomes resolved to have the doctor cut it effectually. But Boswell's pain is always metaphysical, too, and thinking of the cutting he also thinks, I had a strange desire to taste of pain, as one will long for what is bitter. That was Monday. Luckily, on Tuesday the tune changes: I had no appetite for pain today.

title: Store to Test Sunday Sales Ban
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 24 (AP)Rhode Island's ban on Sunday sales at most businesses will be tested tomorrow by the First National chain of retail grocery stores at the company's Pitman Street store, a company spokesman said. The spokesman added that the chain surrendered the store's Sunday sales permit to the Bureau of Licenses this week after questions were raised by small retailers about its validity. To open on Sundays under a state law that took effect last year. a store must be small enough to employ 10 workers or less for eight hours a day.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: THE Best American Short Stories 1977, edited for so many years by the late Martha Foley, should constitute a reasonably representative state of the union message for our writers, so suppose we see what they are doing.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: In her previous novels, Picnic on Paradise and The Female Man, Joanna Russ used science fiction as a vehicle for the most intelligent, hardminded commentary on feminism that you are likely to find anywhere. Her premise seemed to be this: If the war between the sexes is really a war, women are never going to win (or even hold their own) unless they are willing tomobilize their minds and bodies. People who declare war when they are unready to fight deserve the disaster that awaits them. Russs women are ready to fight.

title: U.S. Is Asked to Pay $35,208 in Car Fines
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UP)The Phiadephia traffic court has told the Federal Government to pay $35,208 in traffic fines. In a letter to LeRoy Evans, the General Service Administration motor pool manager, the court's chief adviser. Dr. R. S. Bacheler, said the Government had until Oct. 1 to pay up, or I am requesting the Police Department to cooperate fully with our traffic court officers in the locating, towing and impounding of scofflaw vehicles.

title: Some Midtown Private Clubs
description: There is a hierarchy among the city's private clubs. At the top are such socially exclusive places as the Knickerbocker, the Metropolitan and the Union. Somewhat below them are the prestigious skyscraper clubs the Board Room, the Sky Club, the Pinnacle Club, for example whose main emphasis is the business luncheon. And on down the scale are the university and professional clubs. Despite their differences,most have had problems with rising costs and declining use by a more transient membership.

title: A Critic's Guide to Chicago's Loop, The Birthplace of the Skyscraper
description: Chicago is far and away the nation's first city of architecture. History books tell how modem American architecture came of age here through the work of Louis Sullivan, Frank Lloyd Wright, John Wellborn Root and others, but no book can equal the thrill of standing at the corner of Dearborn and Adams Streets in the heart of Chicago's Loop. There, Mies van der Rohe's great Federal Center, the ultimate refinement of the austere glass tower, occupies the foreground. Just beyond is Burnham & Root's Monadnock Building, an 1891 relic that is one of the greatest masonry office buildings of all time, and across Adams Street is the Marquette Building by Holabird & Roche, a fine example of early steel frame architecture. Still without taking a step, the visitor can look along Dearborn Street to Skidmore, Owings & Merrill's essay in glass and steel, the Inland Steel Building, or down Adams Street for a view of Burnham & Root's powerful yet warm Rookery Building of 1886, and Skidmore, Owings & Merrill's Sears Tower, tallest building in the world.

title: The Lance Hearings Pointed Up Their Growing Importance
description: WASHINGTONPeople asked me how I felt being elected to Congress, and I told them I never thought I'd gite up that much power voluntarily, said Representative Norman D. Dicks, Democrat of Washington, who quit after eight years service as an aide to Senator Warren G. Magnuson to become a freshman in the 95th Congress. Mr. Dicks was only half joking. The power and influence of Congressional aides, especially in the Senate, has surprised and perplexed many who deal with Capitol Hill. Last week's spectacle of a Senate committee publicly questioning its aides to bolster its case against Bert Lance is only the latest example of extreme dependence upon staff members.
