title: Vikings Rally To Hand Bucs No. 16 in Row
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 24 (AP)Fran Tarkenton hit Chuck Foreman with a 31yard touchdown pass in the third quarter to give Minnesota a comefrombehind victory, 93, over the struggling Tampa Bay Buccaneers tonight.

title: St. Etienne: Embodiment of Split
description: ST. ETIENNE, France, Sept. 24By an odd set of historical and political circumstances, the breakup of the alliance of the left in France is being played out in real life here in this bleak industrial city 240 miles south of Paris.

title: Meditation U.S. Style
description: BETWEEN my first and second readings of Harvey Cox's Turning East I received a phone call from Swami Vishnu Devananda, at whose ashram I was once a guest. Swami Devananda said he was holding a press conference to denounce the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, proprietor of Transcendental Meditation. TM, said Devananda. had peaked, its revenues were plummeting, and now the Maharishi had strayed so far from the proper principles of Hinduism that TM was now offering, for high fees, a course in levitation. Swami Devananda offered $10,000 to the first TM graduate who could really levitate.

title: GENERALS IN SURVEY ASSAIL VIETNAM WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The majority of generals who served in the Vietnam War from 1965 to 1972 say, in retrospect, that the United States should have avoided involvement, according to a survey.

title: Leslie J. Wemyss Married Upstate To Louis Higgins
description: Leslie Jo Wemyss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Wemyss of Needham, Mass., was married yesterday to Louis Hall Higgins, son of Mrs. James H. Higgins Jr. of Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Higgins. The Rev. William D. Hayes performed the ceremony in St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid, N.Y., where the couple's families have summer homes.

title: Soviet Plays and Directors Are Headed This Way
description: To Robert Kalfin of the Chelsea Theater Center, the Soviet stage provided the best theater I've ever seen in my life .... You see it taken to its fullest extension in a way that we never in this country have the opportunity to develop in our producing situation and our system of theater .... It was like seeing a goal that we're always aiming for. One could hardly say that Alvin Epstein, the new head of the Guthrie Theater of Minneapolis, was less enthusiastic. In Moscow and Leningrad, he saw some of the most magnificent acting .... In largecast plays it was hard to tell the leading actors of the company. Ther were no tiny parts; the stage was alive with characters.

title: Koch Becomes Mayor Apparent
description: Like a nervous actor who requires the constant reassurance of favorable reviews, Representative Edward I. Koch of Manhattan has stood outside subway stations for years, shaking hands and asking passersby, How am I doing? He does this ritualistically; it doesn't matter whether or not he is even running for office.

title: POAGE OF TEXAS, IN HOUSE SINCE 36,WILL STEP DOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)Representative W. R. Poage, Democrat of Texas, the secondranking House member in seniority, says he does not intend to seek another term after more than four decades in Congress.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: 4 Backs Star As Holy Cross Prevails, 460
description: Holy Cross assaulted Spellman with all of its running backs in a 460 Catholic Schools League victory yesterday at its home field in Flushing, Queens.

title: Remembering the Dashiell Hammett Of Julia
description: Suddenlytumbling from the attic of my memorybits, pieces and people from an island in the Aleutians during World War II; icy williwaws that numbed my life for a couple of years in the early 1940's, a mimeographed Army newspaper called The Adakian and a corporal we all knew as Sam.

title: The Shocked Nation Is Reminded of the Early Hitler Days
description: BONNThe dominant response in West Germany to the current outbreak of terrorism appears not to be fear, anger or even the inevitable lawandorder backlash. It is utter bafflement.

title: TaxFree Bonds for the Little Guy?
description: The taxexempt bond market, once the trading arena for only the most conservative investors, has suddenly emerged as an attractive alternative for a broad segment of the investment community.

title: Community Concerts Inc.: Bastion of Local Control
description: Afew weeks back, I mentioned Arthur Judson, the concert manager whose vision led to the founding of the Music for Westchester Symphony Orchestra. Just 50 years ago, Mr. Judson and 13 of his farsighted colleagues came up with another concept that revolutionized the concertgoing habits of music lovers all over the country.

title: BRIDGE
description: THE EXPERT bridgeplayers of Connecticut often find themselves locked in battle with their neighbors to the north and west. Players from Boston, in particular, often compete in Connecticut tournaments and carry off some of the titles.

title: Couch Brothers Want to Make It Big in Tennis
description: CARLSBAD, Calif.Except for a few details, it is a scene repeated wherever tennis is played.

title: Michigan Tops Navy, 147, On Huckleby's 2 Scores
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 24(AP)Harlan Huckleby ran for two secondquarter touchdowns today, then Michigan fought off Navy to hang on for a 147 nonconference college football victory.

title: Giving A Model Haircut
description: THE SETTING: a huge room with long, mirrored walls, photographic enlargements of bigeyed, curlyhaired women, baskets of pink and yellow chrysanthemums, dramatic track lighting. The action: snipping scissors, humming hair dryers, pulsating music.

title: U.S.TravelSurgesinPostBicentennialYear
description: Americans took to the road, sea and sky during the summer that officially ended last week in a surge of travel that topped last year's Bicentennial touring.

title: They Are Central to the PeaceMaking Process in the Middle East
description: CAIROThe hen, rabbit, horse, fish, cat, birdeverybody has a home but the Palestinian. The home of the Palestinian is in Palestine but it is occupied. However, the Palestinian will regain his home through struggle and sacrifice. This is the theme of a popular Palestinian children's book called Home. Its message is reminiscent of the Jewish people's great romantic longing through the centuries for a national home.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Air New England, a small airline serving the hamlets of the Northeast, reported a year ago this month that it had become virtually fogbound in Government regulations.

title: Catamaran Sail Title To West German Pair
description: LONG BEACH, California, Sept. 24 (Reuters)Jorg Spengler and Rolf Dollenkopf of West Germany won the Tornado Catamaran world sailing championship today by finishing second in light, shifting winds that prompted a number of boats to abort the race.

title: Farrell Needs Rally To Lift Streak to 20
description: After being held to a minus one yard rushing and trailing by 126 in the final quarter, Monsignor Farrel was rallied by John Skronski to an 1812 victory yesterday against its Staten Island rival, New Dorp, in the last eight minutes. passes to give the Lions a triumph that Skronski completed two touchdown passes to give the Lions a triumph that stretched their unbroken streak to 20 games.

title: Judge Named to Coast Retrial
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP)Judge Gordon Ringer of Superior Court, who presided over the Watergate West trial, has been assigned as the judge in the, third murder trial of Leslie Van Houten, a former follower of Charles M. Manson. Miss Van Houten, whose second trial ended with a hung jury last July, is charged with murder and conspiracy in the 1969slaying of Leno and Rosemary LaBianca. Judge Ringer was assigned more than four years ago to preside over the trial of four White House aides accused of breaking into the office of Dr. Lewis Fielding, the former psychiatrist of Daniel Ellsberg, who disclosed the Pentagon papers.

title: Space Shuttle's Successful Test To Allow Removal of Tail Cone
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP)After passing three test flights, the space shuttle is being prepared for another experimental flight minus the streamlined tail cone that was used for testing purposes.

title: The Ins and Outs of Discount Shopping:
description: DISCOUNT shopping is not a game for the fainthearted. Those who are put off by crowds, a certain amount of rudeness, the inability to exchange or return purchases, communal dressing rooms, and a general absence of concerned sales personnel, may not be suited to the sport. While only a sampling could be included here, and the discount boutique business is proliferating, only one of the shops covered made a serious attempt at offering personal service all customers.

title: Looking Easy And Stylish This Fall
description: IF it fits too snugly, don't buy it. If it feels too heavy when you hold it on the hanger, put it back on the rack. Fashion is launched this fall on an absolute sea of comfort.

title: Sally Scott Is Married To Frederic Dittmann
description: Sarah Anne Scott, who has completed the corporate bankmanagement training program of the Chemical Bank in New York, was married yesterday to Frederic Dittmann, who is with the trust department of the United States Trust Company in New York. The Rev. Harry L. Mayfield, assisted by the Rev. Harry E. Krauss 3d, performed the ceremony in All Saints Episcopal Church in Wynnewood. Pa.

title: Hundreds Protesting at Kent State Rip Wire Fence and Pelt the Police
description: KENT, Ohio, Sept. 24Several hundred protesters at Kent State University ripped and trampled down a wire construction fence surrounding the site of the new gymnasium today, then broke windows of construction equipment and pelted watching policemen with rocks in a 20minute demonstration in the construction area.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Shakes A Bit of History
description: OLD BROOKVILLE

title: Fashions and Foibles In Decorating
description: It's September, and Americans and their possessions are on the move again. From coast to coast, movers struggle to fit arc lamps  last year's status lights  into elevators. Ten years ago, no one ever heard of an arc lamp  and, three years from now, they'll probably be as old hat as Bentwood rockers, Spanish bedspreads, hairpin legs, chromeand glass coffee tables and butterfly chairs.

title: The World
description: The foreign ministers of Israel and Egypt met last week with President Carter, and afterward they spokeas visiting officials often doin conciliatory terms. United States officials expressed cautious optimism, which also is a neartradition. On merely procedural questions, the resolution of which could lead back to the negotiating table at Geneva, a hopeful change of attitude was reported, but there certainly has been no visible progress on such fundamental issues as how the Palestinians are to be treated.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: SOME years ago, through a phlegm curtain on one of those days when the air quality in my sinus cavity was unacceptable, I was watching television and had a dream. What I was watching was The Newlywed Game, an afternoon quiz show. To quality as contestants on The Newlywed Game, you had to be a recently married couple in the vicinity of Los Angeles. Several such couples were collected and cleverly broken up into squads of male and female. The males were brought on camera and asked to guess how their wives would respond to a question like, Last night, your hugging and kissing were (1) heavyweight, (2) middleweight. (3) lightweight? They were followed, of course, by the females, who, on being asked the same question, invariably proved their husbands to be dunderheads. There was a lot of squealing.

title: Liveable Luxury
description: There's a strong new spirit in interior design today. It's a demand for comfort and practicality combined with a quest for quality. The result: Easy care, simplified, very liveable luxury.

title: Catherine Gerhart Wed to G.C.Landon
description: Catherine Hamilton Gerhart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Clifton Gerhart of Binghamton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gregory Charles Landon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. W. Landon of Vestal, N.Y. The Rev. Robert S. Hammer performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Binghamton.

title: Janet Maciarz Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Maciarz of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Theresa Maciarz to John Peter Garvey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Garvey. Both families live in Franklin Square, L.I.

title: ART
description: LINCROFT

title: East Hampton Women in the Spotlight
description: WOMEN are obviously becoming a major force in politics not just as voters, but as candidates. Indeed, a political scientist would be hard pressed to find a better example of the role of women in politics than in the far reaches of Suffolk County, in the Town of East Hampton.

title: Health Care Takes New Turn in Suffolk
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY'S first comprehensive healthmaintenance plan became a financial reality last week when it won a mortgage for the health center it will open next year.

title: Byrd Expects Reservations to Be Added to Canal Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, predicted today that the Senate would attach reservations or understandings to the Panama Canal treaties if it approves them.

title: Two Dissident Voices
description: These are very different novels by contemporary Russian writers now living in exile on this continent. Both books could not be published in the Soviet Union. Though poles apart in their subject matter and their styles, their moral landscape is the same: the desperation, helplessness, meanness, lunacy of Soviet life.

title: What's Doing in the POCONOS
description: FALL FOLIAGEOne of the best places in the East to see the countryside burst into color is the Pocono Mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania. These lowlying hills, amid 2,400 square miles of lakestudded woodland, are now coming aflame with the scarlet of oak and maple leaves, the gold of aspen and tulip trees and the reds and greens of sumac and hemlock. The Poconos, about 80 miles west of New York City on Interstate 80 and 85 miles north of Philadelphia via the Pennsylvania Turnpike's Northeast Extension, encompass Monroe, Carbon, Pike and Wayne counties. To drive anywhere in these mountains for the next few weeks is to be engulfed in orange, bronze and vermillion. Some particularly scenic byways: State Route 447 alongside Brodhead Creek from Canadensis to Route 191 near Analomink; the unnumbered road skirting the north side of the Lackawaxen River from Rowland to Kimbles; Route 402 through the state forests of Pike County; the 10mile Sullivan Trail, a blacktop road that begins at Route 715 in Tannersville, climbs toward Big Pocono State Park, then veers in the direction of Pocono Pines. Branching off to the top of the state park 2,131 feet above sea level, the motorist gets a view of the Catskill Mountains of New York 84 miles away

title: They Make Yogurt A Movable Feast
description: IT is a hot and sticky day, approaching noon, as an old truck turns a final corner into the Cross Westchester Executive Park in Elmsford. The driver, a woman in a white top and yellow shorts, watches as her partner takes up a position on the curb side and clangs an old cowbell.

title: 18,000 Sue Con Ed Over Blackout, But Chances of Winning Are Slight
description: Since July's blackout, 18,000 customers of Consolidated Edison Company have filed claims against the utility, asking for millions of dollars in damages, mostly for food spoilage.

title: Carter's Grand Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24President Carter's 11day tour of eight nations in South America, Africa, Asia and Europe probably was not planned as an escape from the rising tide of trouble that now reaches about to his knees. But the trip may help a little.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 24An Israeli Army lieutenant was killed during the night in a clash with Palestinian guerrillas at the northeastern flank of the frontier with Lebanon, according to an official Defense Forces announcement here tonight.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Upon These the Foundation Rests.

title: FOOD;
description: ON commercial farms and in home gardens, this has been a bountiful year for local tomatoes. The ripe, scarlet globes fairly burst with juice and rich, sweetly tangy flavor. The flesh is moist and satiny, a mixture never achieved by the dismally pale, dry and mealy alternatives available most of the year.

title: Coach at RutgersNewark Busy Attending to Details
description: Last season Rutgers University at Newark had some good fortune and some bad with its volleyball teams. The men finished No. 1 in regularseason play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Division, and made it all the way to the national final. RutgersNewark's women's team did well in the regular season, too. It compiled a 93 wonlost record that was good enough to qualify it for an invitation to postseason regional competition. (Under the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women format, regionals are the first step toward the national tournament.) But the RutgersNewark women didn't play in the regional because of a mixup in paperwork. Nobody answered the invitation in time.

title: The Vanishing Custom Tailor
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Oklahoma Beats Ohio State, 2928
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24Uwe von Schamann, an unflappable native of West Berlin who now lives in Fort Worth, settled a big football game that a bunch of fast, husky native Americans could not resolve when he kicked a 41yard field goal in the last three seconds to give Oklahoma a thrilling 2928 triumph over Ohio State today.

title: Somali Front Leader Bars CeaseFire With Ethiopia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia. Sept 24The Western Somali Liberation Front, which is seeking to wrest control of eastern Ethiopia from the Addis Ababa Government, said today that it was not prepared td engage in ceasefire negotiations with Ethiopia until every inch of the land it claims had been liberated.

title: Two Rhodesian Chiefs Are Refused Visas by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Slate Department said today that it had refused visas to two black Rhodesian tribal chiefs and members of Parliament who had sought to present to Americans their case for negotiating a political settlement with the white minority Government of Prime Minister Ian D Smith.

title: H. B. Comstock, Gretchen Handy Wed in Fairfield
description: Gretchen Woodbury Handy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Douglas Handy of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Harwood Brooks Comstock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Morris Comstock of Essex, Conn. The ceremony was performed in the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church by the Rev. Stanley Lyon Houston.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: ALTHOUGH he never got farther west than what is now known as West Germany until late in life, Karl May (18401912) turned out a string of Germanstyle lime novels set in the American West that have been read by generations of German youth.

title: College Football Scores
Rain Halts MetsCards; Doubleheader Set Today
description: CHICAGO,Sept. 24 (UPI)Al Oliver got three hits, including his 18th homer and a single that ignited a fourrun sixth inning, in pacing the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 73 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: Ali in Midtown Drill
description: Muhammad Ali and Earnie Shavers will work out tomorrow at 12:30 P.M. at the Promenade Cafe at Rockefellr Plaza, between 49th and 50th Street. All will defend his world heavyweight title against Shaver Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. Tomorrow's workouts are open to the public.

title: Golf
description: SARAH COVENTRY OPEN

title: 3 FROM VIETNAM ERA START PRISON TERMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)At the start of the 1970's, in an age of student protest, three young men participated in a demonstration in a small college town near Washington. This week, uprooted from typical middleclass lives, they went to jail for their part in that protest seven years ago.

title: Tartuffe: Ruthless, Bullying, Evil And Human
description: There are some inhabitants of art, like Hamlet and Don Quixote, who have a freestanding existence in the mind as image and idea. For most who saw it, any mention of The Hunchback of Notre Dame (RKO, 1939) will produce an immediate mental picture of Quasimodo; and this picture will be vivid and sharply focused, even if the plot and the other actors have all but faded from memory. Something of the same sort happens, I believe, when Moliere's Tartuffe is thought of: what's promptly visualized is a grotesque, sinister and ruthless figure, somberly dressed and uttering false pieties. So separable is this figure from his play, so far has popular imagination made of him a discrete type and symbol, that the baser principals in our recent Watergate drama have repeatedly been likened to him.

title: Soviet Explores Lake in Siberia, World's Deepest
description: Soviet scientists aboard deepwater re search craft have begun a twoyear effort to study firsthand the bottom of Lake Baikal in southern Siberia, the deepest body of fresh water in the world.

title: A Discussion of the Mayor's Problemsby Three Who Know
description: The next Mayor of New York City will face many of the same difficulties as the current Mayor, plus new ones that are likely to arise. To identify some of these issues and explore possible solutions. The Week in Review last week invited three men intimately familiar with city government for a discussion. From left to right, they were Stephen Berger, who resigned this month as executive director of the Emergency Financial Control Board, John E. Zuccottl, former First Deputy Mayor, and Victor Gotbaum, head of the largest municipal workers union, District Council 37. Excerpts of the conversation follow.

title: U.S.C. Crushes Texas Christian, 51 to  0
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI)A thirdstring tailback; Dwight Ford, sprinted 70 and 9 yards for touchdowns, and Frank Jordan kicked three field goals, leading Southern California to a 510 rout over Texas Christian University today.

title: Touring Europe's Toilets From the Sublime to the Unspeakable
description: The men's room Claridge's in London was all marble and gilt, with a uniformed attendant who ran water into the basin, tested its temperature with a delicate pinkie and stood by at attention, fresh Turkish towel over his ann. The men's room in the picturesque little restaurant in a back street of Naples was a doorless, windowless, reeking hole. Moral: The traveler who goes first class can expect firstclass toilet facilities in Europe, but others take their chances.

title: An English Hero
description: JOHN FOWLES'S reputation as a highly readable and resourceful storyteller has carried with it the hint that as a novelist he was slightly suspectthat books as tricky and teasing as The Collector (1963), The Magus (1966) and the rightfully admired The French Lieutenant's Woman (1969) somehow lacked the deeper sincerities and purposes of more serious fiction. Such an account will no longer do, if it ever did. This new, long, ambitious novel must be judged his best piece of work to date and is a masterly fictional creation, dense with fact. In its overall tone and sympathetically critical engagement with its hero, Daniel Martin follows along naturally from the title story in Fowles's collection The Ebony Tower of three years back, where a confident, successful academic critic and painter, encountering an Augustus Johnlike painter and his women, is confronted with enigmas of art and sex that bring him up against himself, as if for the first time. And, as in that story, the themes and ideas of this new novel only emerge through the voice of a narrator of immense tact and charm.

title: A Doubtful Device, Even Before Lance
description: Bankers have been uneasy lately. All that publicity about Bert Lance's ways of handling money has drawn attention to the banking industry.

title: The Region
description: The pressure for racial integration in the North, usually applied in cities with large numbers of blacks and other minorities, is now being increasingly applied in small towns and the suburbs. This was particularly evident in the New York region last week.

title: Yachting
description: MALLORY CUP REGATTA

title: Lead Cut to 2 Games Doubleheader Set Today
description: TORONTO, Sept. 24Rain became the feature attraction in the Yankees part of the pennant race today, and the rain won.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE one thing that businessmen and the financial markets detest intensely is broadbased uncertaintyand they were dealt a heavy dosage of that unpalatable medication last week. It did not result in any outright rout in the ?tock market, but it did cause continued weakness and it widened the gloom that has pervaded the financial markets most of the yeara mood so dark ?t is seldom lightened even by upbeat economic data, such as the favorable reports on consumer prices and orders for durable goods issued a few days ago.

title: Today's Joggers Keep Pace With Style
description: SHINY SATIN shorts, edged with crisp piping. Colorcoordinated tanktops or Tshirts with catchy logos emblazoned on their fronts. Soft velour warmup suits. And shoes every shade in the rainbow. Here they come, today's joggers, as aware of fashion as they are of health.

title: Janet Gregg Is Bride Of Daniel DeBiasio
description: Janet Gregg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Kirker Gregg of HoHoKus, N. J., was married there yesterday at the home of her parents to Daniel Joseph De Biasio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Atteo De Biasio of Feeding Hills, Mass. The Rev. Hayward L. Levy Jr., rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in HoHoKus, performed the ceremony.

title: India's President Returns Home Following Operation in New York
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 24 (AP)President Neelam Sanjiva Reddy of India returned tonight from New York, where he spent three weeks in a hospital and underwent an operation for lung cancer that was pronounced successful.

title: Nets vs. the Knicks
description: THE recently settled dispute between the New York Knicks and the New York Nets over the Nets' move to New Jersey struck a raw nerve among owners in professional sportsand with good reason.

title: MORRIS STRAUSS
description: Morris Strauss, general agent of the Madison Life Insurance Company and one of its founders, died Friday in his New York office of a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived in Westbury, L.I.

title: After 4Years,West Germany Has Come of Age at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24Quietly but definitely in the four years since its admission to the United Nations, West Germany has become a skillful and increasingly influential diplomatic force here.

title: Cowboys Are Favored Over the Clownish Giants
description: The Giants may have taken the NY off their helmets and moved their team and offices to New Jersey, but to the rest of the country they still represent New York, and that is one of the reasons they should expect trouble today from the Irving Cowboys.

title: Carter Seeks Aid for Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) President Carter has asked Congress for an additional $71.7 million to provide domestic assistance to Southeast Asian refugees living in the United States. approved, the extra money would be dispensed by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Elizabeth Scheffler Bride of Robert Hardwick
description: Elizabeth Mary Scheffler, daughter of Mrs. Thor Bjorn Andersen of Maplewood, N.J., and Elmira, N.Y., and George Scheffler of Hyattsville, Md., was married in Maplewood yesterday to Robert Duncan Hardwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hardwick of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Gustavus Warfield performed the ceremony in the Prospect Presbyterian Church.

description: Say you had a large backyard for your home and you decided to turn it into a pasture and keep goats (assuming the zoning ordinance would allow it). Would you be able to claim a lower assessment on your property because it is now being used as a farm?

title: Kim Walker Becomes Bride In New Haven
description: The marriage of Catharine Kim Walker to Per Torbjoern Bergstroem took place yesterday afternoon in the United ChurchontheGreen in New Haven. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur Kolsti. senior minister, and the Rev. Dr. David Weinland, minister emeritus, of the church.

title: Harry C. Hagerty, Retired Executive
description: Harry C. Hagerty, a former vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday at his home. He was 85 years old and lived at 791 Park Avenue.

title: Special Tricks To Prolong the Herb Harvest
description: The harvest of herbs in my garden continues unchecked till about midOctober.Then the frost comes, the beginning of the end. First goes basil, the tenderest herb. ?rost blackens it the same as tomato plants.

description: Leonard Jones scored a pair of touchdowns yesterday, one offensively and one on defense. as Seton Hall shut out host Nutley, 180.

title: Zambrano, Catcher Turned Runner, Carries Bergenfield to a 270 Romp
description: Jose Zambrano, normally a top receiver, moved to running back yesterday and paced Bergenfield to a 270 victory over Fair Lawn at Bergenfield. Zambrano rushed for 130 yards and one touchdown, a 2yard burst. The quarterback, Tom McNulty, also scored from the 2, and Greg Butler and Joe Green tallied on sprints of 13 and 18 yards.

description: Cardozo had the Public Schools Athletic League volleyball championship taken away by Newtown last year and now it wants the title back.

The three new disks under discussion here provide a fine instance of this restlessly combinatorial tendency.

title: IN AMERICA
description: Star Wars maintains its great boxoffice Force, and literary planets are proliferating at a mighty rate as books of scifi and fantasy. once a connotsseur's category, now move into the mainstream of publishing. With the magic mushrooming of titles. It is often hard to keep track of who's where and what's when. Therefore, this guide for earthlings, so that we need no more feel like strangers in a strange land.

title: Ban on Horse Imports Eased
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)Horses that have not reached breeding age are exempt from a partial ban on horses imported from Europe and Australia, the Agriculture Department announced this week. The prohibition was imposed recently to prevent the spread of equine netritis, a genital disease, to the United States.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: RAISE THE TITANIC! by Clive Cussler. (Bantam, $2.25.) It's 1988 and the United States and the Soviet Union are in a contest to retrieve an Invaluable elemental substance that sank with the Titanic back in 1912. An exciting suspenser flawed by a clichcrammed literary style. A veteran of the hardcover best seller list.

title: Tambay Reaches Fork In His Road to Stardom
description: Patrick Tambay, the young Frenchman who can clinch the Sports Car Club of America Citicorp CanAm driving championship today in Sonoma, Calif., may not get a chance to defend that crown next season. Instead, he may be a regular on the Formula One circuit, even though he says, I would like to have a career in America. I like the country and the American way of life.

title: Guide to Nearby Game Preserves
description: Shooting at Spring Farm is strictly by reservation, which should be made as far ahead as possible (5167250038 or 1132). The preserve is open from September through April 1. No hunting license is required. The prices charged at game preserves within easy reach of New York are fairly similar, a fairly typical example being Spring Farm's rates for pheasant hunting$140 for a party of up to four persons for half a day, with fair shots at 10 birds guaranteed, dogs and guide included. Ammunition is available, at extra cost, but you must bring your own guns. Make sure when reserving just what the rate is and how many guaranteed shots you get. Also, bear in mind that there are different kinds of hunts: pass shooting, with the party shooting from the base of a hill at 50yard intervals, duck, partridge, pheasant and quail shooting. Prices and customs differ for each.

title: Posner's Perks
description: A MercedesBenz limousine and driver, firstclass travel to places like the Bahamas, Mexico and Las Vegas, a penthouse suite in the Plaza Hotel in New York, and hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of food, liquor and servants. Those are real perks, and they are just a few of the fringe benefits enjoyed by the multimillionaire businessman Victor Posner, his son and his daughter since 1970, and not disclosed, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission in a. complaint filed in United States District Court in Washington last week.

title: Neonatal Center Having Birth Pains
description: VALHALLA

title: Columbia Sets Back Lafayette by 2110
description: Columbia's chances for its first winning football season since 1971 got a needed lift yesterday at soggy Baker Field where a drenched crowd of 1.500 peered throught the rain to watch the Lions down Lafayette. 2110.

title: Penn State Downs Maryland, 279
description: UNIVERSITY PARK. Pa., Sept. 24One of these Saturday aftrnoons, Penn State's football team is going to delight Coach Joe Paterno by winning a close, tough game by point or two. Until then, Paterno will have to settle for clearcut victories.

title: A Plea to Let the Old Die Peaceably
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y.I remember when my grandmother died many years ago. She wasn't very oldin her mid70's. But she had been failing. And then began these terrible nose bleeds. It wasn't long before she was gone.

title: How C P.A.'s Sell Themselves
description: Last spring teams of top executives from 10 nationwide firms, wellbriefed on the most minute details of the crucial assignment they were about to undertake, all boarded planes for the same California destination. They were laden with flip charts, audiovisual props and other persuasive paraphernalia.

title: Lawrence Turns Back Farming dale
description: The realignment of the football conferences is apparently not the only thing that will be new in Nassau County football this season. Yesterday Lawrence, which won only twice last year, registered a major upset over Farmingdale, 226 in the Nassau County Conference1opener for both teams.

title: Albert Thornbrough Weds Diana Stanton
description: Diana Jeanne Stanton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Oliver Stanton of Laurel Hollow, L. I., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Albert Grant Thornbrough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Adam Thornbrough of Boca Raton, Fla. and Toronto. Village Judge James Eisenman of Laurel Hollow performed the ceremony.

title: Carter Stumps Virginia for Howell, an Old Ally Running for Governor
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 24President Carter ended a campaign trip across Virginia here tonight, urging the election of Henry E. Howell Jr., the Democratic candidate for Governor and a personal as well as a political favorite of Mr. Car ter

title: Cincirmati's Daily Papers to Apply For Approval to Merge Production
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 24 (AP)Cinclnnati's,two daily newspapers will apply for Federal approval under the Newpaper Preservation Act to merge production and sales in a single facility. Separate.,editorial and reporting staffs will be maintained.

title: BRIDGE
description: The danger lurking in the deal shown today, from the writer's angle, is that readers will inspect the diagram and the bidding, draw a plausible but inaccurate conclusion, and turn disgustedly to another section of the paper or hurriedly pen a letter of indignant complaint to the editor on the subject of typography. Before taking either of these precipitate actions the reader should ask himself what could possibly cause East to pass originally with 14 highcard points and a strong sixcard major suit, and what could possibly cause South to open three notrump with a nondescript 13 points.

title: Policy Is Slowly Forming on the Old Issue of the Old Cities
description: WASHINGTONThese two remarks, uttered in separate interviews, reflect a fundamental debate that is emerging as a new Democratic Administration commits itself to doing something to help the nation's great urban centers. Few issues will present the Carter Administration, headed by a man whose roots are planted deep in the rural South, with more difficulties than the question of what to do about the ailing old cities, with their acres of rotting tenements, racial tensions, potholepitted streets, deteriorating water and sewer systems, deserted factories and staggering debts.

title: Apparently, Collapsed
description: PARISIn the last five years, France's venerable Socialist Party has recovered from a nearfatal squeeze between the Gaullists and the Communists to become, according to the polls, the'most popular party in the country. The impulse for the turnaround was the Socialists alliance with the Communists, both as electoral partners and as signatories of a joint platform they were pledged to carry out in a coalition government of the left. Now, with the combined left within sight of coming to power for the first time since General de Gaulle formed the Fifth Republic in 1958, the alliance appears to have collapsed.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now Robert Mulcahy 3d, New Jersey Commissioner of Correction.

title: CHESS
description: The object in declining a gambit or in first accepting one and then quickly returning the material is to maintain a positional balance. This avoids the difficulties in volved when one side has an advantage in material and the other has dangerous compensation in a lead in development, control of the center, or attacking chances, or all three.

title: MalariaLike Disease Diagnosed in 2 on Long Island
description: A malarialike infection that first appeared in this country on Nantucket Island, off the Massachusetts coast, has now been detected on the tip of Long Island. Experts suspect that the infection, called babesiosis, is not as rare as they once believed.

title: The Sam Spade Caper
description: The subtitle of Richard Brautigan's novel, A Private Eye Novel 1942, should have served as a tipoff. Brautigan, or his publisher, or his editoror maybe all three in concertwanted to spell it out for the reader to make sure we got it. The upfront shill announces that the writer is using a genre to display his talent. I have news for them.

title: Major League Averages
FamiliesLife Dictates Style
description: ANEWCOMER to rural Sussex County mourns the lack of fashionable stores....In Westchester, one of the country's largest markets for the pinstripe suit, a cartoonist proudly admits to owning only one jacket, although it is a Cardin. . .. A Greenwich, Conn., woman keeps a long dress for social emergencies in her Manhattan pied a terre....A Long Island, teenager claims that she can walk perfectly well on her towering platform shoes and, when no one is looking, releases her feet to the security of the ground.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Followup. Although fall officially arrived last Thursday, many residents of Publishers Row are still engrossed in projects begun in seasons past. Herewith a few new chapters of continuing stories.

title: 19,500 See Tigers Drop 12th in Row at Home
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept 24Princeton's football team, driving for the winning touchdown late in the final quarter, gave up the ball on a fumble by Gary Larson, a junior fullback, ending its hopes of victory today.

title: Smoke, Fire and Bert Lance
description: Bert Lance has gone back to Georgia, but the bitter questions linger on: Was he, people continue to ask, hounded out of office? Was he the victim of reporters too eager to show they could look under Carter rocks as zealously as those labeled Watergate? Was Mr. Lance the victim of no more than, as Senator Eagleton put it guilt by accumulation? Was it all smoke and no fire?

title: The Standings
description: Sunday, September 25, 1977

title: INTERVIEW
description: DANCE on the Island? There's not enough at all, said Norman Walker, the tall, lithe, 43yearold dancer whose 22d year as a teacher is also his sixth year as chairman of the dance department at Adelphi University.

title: Remembering Percy Grainger
description: FEW White Plains residents realize that right in the center of their city, there's a landmarka fascinating museum of sorts, though it isn't open to the public. Right off busy Route 22, a block past the Roger Smith Hotel, passersby scarcely give a glance It's just a brown frame house, in truth a trifle shabby.

title: Playboy Magazine Banned in Morris Jail
description: MORRISTOWN

title: LETTERS
description: When you see a good game of soccer, you might almost wonder if the whole thing were choreographed (The Selling of Soccermania by Lowell Miller, Aug. 28). The disciplined restraint, along with the tremendous effort and highly sophisticated teamwork required, makes soccer the world's most beautiful game. When the world has only one home team and it is pitted against visitors from another universe, the game will be soccer.

title: The New Politics of Development
description: The rules of the development game in the city are changing.

title: Helen Frech Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hans Alexander Frech have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Frothingham Frech, to John Edward Kippax, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn Kippax of Swarthmore, Pa. A December wedding is planned.

title: Israel Plans to Expel 25 Black Hebrews
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 24 (AP)Israeli authorities said today they were holding and planned to expel 25 black Americans who the Israelis say are members of a black Hebrew sect who intended to settle illegally in the Jewish state.

title: Notes: Hydrofoils To Run From Miami
description: The only regularly scheduled hydrofoil service from the continental United States will be established when three hydrofoilsthe largest in the worldbegin daily runs between Miami and Nassau and Freeport in the Bahamas on Nov. 18.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: This book brings together a sampler from 25 years of newspaper and magazine columns by one of America's bestknown contemporary humorists. From his days covering and spoofing the European jet set to his days as a Washington columnist, Buchwald has managed to touch a responsive nerve in an American readership that sometimes regards humor as a suspect, if not black, art.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: 4 Fashionable Families
description: IN Westchester, one of the country's largest markets for the pinstripe suit, a cartoonist proudly admits to owning only one jacketalthough it is a Cardin. . ..A newcomer to rural Sussex County, N.J., mourns the lack of fashion able stores... .A Long Island teenager claims that she can walk perfectly well on her towering platform shoes and, when no one is looking, releases her feet to the security of the ground. ...A Greenwich woman keeps a long dress for social emergencies in her Manhattan pied a terre.

title: U. S. May Overrule New York City Ban On Nuclear Traffic
description: The Federal Department of Transportation is considering overruling a New York City regulation that prohibits the shipping of radioactive materials through the city.

title: Easy Does It For the Fall
description: Fall clothes are softer, looser and more comfortable than they've been in years. Easytomovein big skirts and shawls that cover the shoulders indoors or out are two important components. They are shown here in printed challis, the season's most important fabric.Other new fashions on Page 12.

title: It Was Time To Go
description: Last Thursday, Bert Lance went home.

title: Commission to Study
description: TRENTON

title: LAG IN GROWTH LIKELY, ECONOMIC GROUP TOLD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24A sense of anxiety about prospects for reducing unemployment and warding off protectionism was registered today at a meeting here of finance ministers and central bank governors of leading industrial and thirdworld countries.

title: In Memoriam
description: DONDavid. In loving memory of our he loved father. passed away September 28, 1962. Stanley and Bernice

title: California Law Giving Royalties to Artists Is Stymied by Complications
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 24The first state law granting royalties to artists from profits on resales of their work has become hopelessly stymied, nine months after taking effect, by legal complications and an organized boycott by California art dealers and collectors.

title: Offshore Oil Drilling May Begin This Winter
description: SEVEN major oil companies have submitted for Federal approval final plans for drilling for oil in a promising geological formation 80 miles out in the Atlantic Ocean, specifically south of the Island and east of New Jersey. Federal experts say, though, that it will take at least several more weeks to review the plans: that the oil companies probably will nut be able to begin their search for oil and natural gas until December, and perhaps even later, and that oil production won't begin sooner than 1980.

title: RaiderSteeler Matchup: It's More Than Just a Game
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24The sensitive Lynn Swann was driving through Europe alone last June and revising his thinking. The graceful yet sturdy wide receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers had been on the receiving end of blows from the Oakland Raiders in games in 1975 and 76 which resulted in concussions and considerable controversy. The violence in pro football had appalled the 25yearold Swann and he had said he would never play again. While touring the Continent, Swann's mind changed. I decided I've never quit anything, he said here the other day. I wasn't going to quit now.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Yastrzemski, Lynn, Cox HomerTigers Are Beaten, 62
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24Home runs by Ted Cox, Carl Yastrzemski and Fred Lynn powered the Boston Red Sox to a 62 victory over the Detroit Tigers today and kept Boston's pennant hopes alive in the American League East.

title: Miss Ritchie Bride Of Dr. A.M.Walker
description: Patricia Anne Ritchie. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Ritchie of Bay Head, N.J., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Dr. Alexander Muir Walker of Boston. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Basil C. Walker of San Francisco. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lloyd H. Uyeki of St. John's Episcopal Church in Pleasantville. N.Y., of which the bridegroom's grandfather, the late Rev. Emmons Parkman Burrill, was formerly the rector.

title: GARDENING
description: LIKE THE PROPHET who is without honor in his own country, one of our showiest native flowers is seldom given space in either our gardens or our nurseries. Perhaps we consider it too commonplace for our gardens in that one or more of its species may be found growing wild in almost any uncultivated open or partly wooded plot of land from coast to coast.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Whether they like it or not, and many don't, most astronomers are resigned to the apparent destiny of the universe: endless expansion to infinite size and zero density. Two recent studies, however, have revived the possibility that the cosmos is finite after all, and may someday begin to collapse again toward its beginning.

title: LETTER FROM YALE
description: NEW HAVEN

title: 3 Unusual Boutiques
description: THOSE women who decide to avoid a trip to the city and buy their fall and winter wardrobes in Westchester usually head for one of the major department stores with a branch in the county. There's Macy's, B. Altman, Bloomingdale's and others in White Plains, Gimbels in the Cross County Shopping Center, and the new Alexander's in Yonkers. But those who yearn for a small shop that offers unusual designs and personal attention must do some detective work to locate the stores in the county.

title: Briarcliff: A Touch of 1962 Class
description: FIFTEEN years ago I began my first year of teaching English, at the nowdefunct Briarcliff College... Still working on my master's degree at Columbia University, had written to several colleges in Westchester asking if they had any special needs that I might study for in my final months at Columbia.

title: A Good D y in t e Field
description: Has anybody noticed that doctors constitute the new aristocracy? Like the gentry of 18thcentury England, they hunt, collect paintings and sail yachts. They're the only people left who aren't ashamed to be rich and show it, almost as if membership in the A.M.A. automatically removes the inhibitions about money the rest of us feeland opens up the world of Mercedes Benz 450 SEL's, African safaris, $27,000 Purdy shotguns and solidgold Rolex wrist chronometers. As a way to wealth, bad hearts are worth more than coronets.

title: TwoWomenFound Stabbed to Death In 47th St. Home
description: Two women were found stabbed to death last night in a wellkept midtown apartment house near Eight Avenue, accordina to the police.

title: College Results
description: CROSSCOUNTRY

title: The Cost of Not Building Housing
description: MUCH PUBLICITY has been given to the refusal of the Federal Government to provide communitydevelopment funds to some Nassau County communities because they did not accept lowincome housing.

title: Rise in Nassau School Taxes Seen
description: MINEOLA, L.I.school taxes in Nassau County can be expected to rise in the future, despite a continuing declining enrollment, because of the present method of financing public education on a districtwide basis through the local property tax, the County Planning Commission said in a report last week.

title: Strike Ends at Jersey Refinery
description: CARTERET, NJ., Sept. 24 (AP)A 12week strike by 1,200 steelworkers at the U.S. Metals Refining Company here ended today when union and management officials agreed on a threeyear pact, according to Anthony Cascone, the Sec;ittary of. Steelworkers Local 837. The contract will increase the base pay from $5.88 an hour to $6.73, Mr. Cas one said, adding that the pact was still subject to ratification by workers on Monday.

title: Inflation Slackens but the Outlook Is Still Cautious
description: The inexorable rise in consumer prices slowed a bit in August, to an increase of only threetenths of one percent, the smallest monthly increase since November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported last week Much of the relative stability was caused by declining farm prices on retail food costs, which rose only twotenths of a percent.

title: Carter's Energy Program on the Chopping Block
description: The last few days have been a hard lesson for President Carter on the check and balances in the political system. Not the least of his disappointments was the continuing dismemberment of the energy program in Congress.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Helping to Fill the Fashion Gap
description: ALTHOUGH the suburban scene abounds with a variety of shops and stores, the woman in search of a sophisticated contemporary wardrobe, or even a skirt or two, often discovers it difficult to told what she wants. In many areas, she may find herself caught among three choices.

title: The Taylor Law And the Teacher
description: ON AUG. 21, the Long Island Weekly published an article on teacher unionschool board negotiations entitled The Strike Is Not the Problem. Among the error% and prounion rhetoric, the author, Willard L. Hogeboom, dropped a few truths, notably the statement that it is in the bargaining, not the striking, that the basic problem lies. Then he quoted Theodore W. Kheel, the mediator, on the virtues of permitting public employees in this case. teachersito strike.

title: China, in Burst of Diplomacy, Hosts Foreign Leaders
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 24In a burst of diplomatic activity, China this week has entertained three visiting heads of state from Asia and Africa and has sent several highlevel delegations abroad, including a large military mission to France.

title: Lovers Adoption Plea Is Rejected by Judge
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 24 (AP)A Superior Court judge has ruled that a 30yearold man may not adopt his 20yearold girlfriend in Rhode Island.

title: Best Glove in Town
description: Baltimore, by 1890, was fast degenerating, H. L. Mencken once observed, and so was civilization.

title: The Episcopalian Row Is Atypical
description: While a row over women's ordination brought dissident Episcopalians to St. Louis two weeks ago, claiming to be the true church and talking schism, for many Protestant churches the question of women clergy has become largely academic. Women are in the pulpit now, and an increasing number of them will enter the churches from the seminaries in the immediate future.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 1:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 1 P.M.)

title: Ford to Speak for Providence Mayor
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 24 (AP)  Former President Gerald R. Ford will speak here later this year at a $100aperson fundraising event for Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the Republican Mayor said yesterday. Mayor Cianci said that Mr. Ford would also meet with city leaders in the fourhour visit.

title: HARTFORD GETS WEAPON TO CURB FRAUD IN RELIEF
description: HARTFORD, Sept, 24 (AP)For the first time in three years, the state has the right to cut back payments to welfare recipients who have been overpaid because of fraud or administrative errors.

title: Over40 Skydivers Get a Lift Out of Forming a Successful Floating Star
description: Mike Efstration is a 52yearold engineer from Coram who favors bushy muttonchop sideburns and diving out of airplanes. His friends Jerry Thompson, a 44yearold restaurateur from Hewlett, and Larry Corderia, a 41yearold crane operator from Wantagh, are beardless. But the Long Islanders all have the same habit when airborne.

title: IN BRIEF
description: HOUSING STARTS declined slightly in August to a 2.02 millionunit annual rate from 2.08 million in July, the Commerce Department reported. The rate, however, was 32 percent above the 1.53 million rate in August 1976. Permits for new housing rose 8 percent in August to a 1.77 million annual rate from 1.64 million in July ... New orders for durable goods rose 3.3 percent in August to a seasonally adjusted $57.91 billion from $56.03 billion in July, the Commerce Department also reported. The increase came after two months of decline and was the largest increase since March's 7 percent rise ... The United States balance of payments with other nations, as measured on the current accounts basis, was in deficit $4.6 billion in the second quarter of the year, compared with a deficit of $4.2 billion in the first quarter ...,The Commerce Department also revised the growth reported for the nation's gross national product for the second quarter to a 6.2 percent annual rate, from its 6.1 percent growth rate estimate in August. The department first estimated second quarter growth at 6.5 percent in July.

title: EntebbeRaid Film
description: MATAWAN

title: Theories on College Dress
description: THEY still hire people to trim the ivy on the sedate campuses of the Ivy league colleges, and they still sing about being well dressed. They still dream of marrying someone with money, and they are still fascinated by what once were secret, almost sacred traditions.

title: FILM VIEW
description: As of this writing, one week before the opening of the 15th annual New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, I've only seen one of the 21 programs (and have very mixed feelings about that one). Yet, if one can be allowed to review a festival on the basis of expectations, this one, which actually opened Friday night, is a smashthe most exciting festivalonpaper in years. Not in a long time have there been so many entries by directors whose past work would lead one to expect new films of an unusual order.

title: Dance: Double
description: The marathon dance being made the subject of a dance is the sort of double jeopardy that never entered the minds of the inventors of those pernicious contests. They were interested in the money, but the American Dance Asylum examined the elements of marathon dancing after two of its members, Lois Welk and Arnie Zane had entered and participated in a 23hour dance. It was cut short of the full 24hour length because it conflicted with a hockey game, they explained Friday evening at American Theater Laboratory.

title: Preview of '78 Boats at Norwalk Show
description: With pennants flying and a fleet of more than 400 cruising, sailing and fishing boats, the second annual International InWater Boat Show will be launched Thursday at Cove Marina in Norwalk, Conn. The fourday show, the largest inwater show in the Northeast, also will feature 147 shorebased accessory exhibits, running the gamut from electronic gear and engines to scrimshaw and sails.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Dorothy Uhnak
description: Dorothy Uhnak, a former policewoman, knows the neighborhood of her novels. She's on home ground in The Investigation, when she writes:

title: THE WOMAN AS ARTIST
description: If women artists today could collectively choose a historical role model, a female star from the past to shine in the male firmament of Michelangelo, Leonardo and Rembrandt, the likeliest candidate would be Artemisia Gentileschi, a 17thcentury Italian painter known as the first woman in the history of Western art to contribute significantly to the work of her time.

title: COSMETIC LIB FOR MEN
description: During the past decade, thousands of American men have discovered what their wives knew all along: that nobody needs to struggle through life with mismatched features, waiting abjectly for the ravages of time to apply a final crusher. Advanced techniques in a branch of plastic surgery called cosmetic, or esthetic, surgery provide a way out? Cyrano nose? Greenstreet dewlaps? Jackson Pollock wrinkle pattern? No problem.

title: The Woman Behind the Women
description: EAST BRUNSWICK THERE are days of laughter when everything goes well and women in various phases of undress goodnaturedly swap stories and anecdotes even as they slip into one garment after another in their search for bargains.

title: Measles Outbreak in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept 24 (AP)An outbreak of measles has killed 60 children on the Indonesian island of Lombok since April, the official Antara News Agency reported today. The disease also killed 28 children in central Java last month, according to previous reports.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Para 2  No Title

title: Morey Defeats Oehmig In Seniors Golf Final
description: PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP)Dale Morey of High Point, N.C., won the 23d annual United States Seniors golf championship today by beating the defending champion, Lew Oehmig of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., 4 and 3.

title: Randy Newman The Moral Is Implicit
description: Randy Newman's favorite song on the dazzling new Little Criminals, his first album in almost three years, is called In Germany Before The War, and it gives a brief account of the same Dusseldorf child murderer who figured in Fritz Lang's film M. The song is stark, very frightening, and deliberately bereft of detail: all we know about the killer is that he sits on the bank of the Rhine at precisely the same time each day, telling himself, I'm looking at the river but I'm thinking of the sea/ I'm thinking of the sea. All we know about him, in short, is that he is in some way removed from the mainstream, just as surely as he is distracted from the Rhine. And it is his sheer strangeness, rather than his depravity, that makes him a fitting subject for Newman's attention.

title: LOW INFANTDEATH RATE IN NEW YORK IS ENVIED
description: Chicago sent municipal health officials last week to study New York City's significantly low infant mortality rate, Dr. Pascal J. Imperato, New York's Health Commissioner, has reported with some pride.

title: KENNETH W. JOHNSON
description: AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP)Kenneth W. Johnson treasurer of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst and overseer of its postWorld War H expansion, died yesterday at his home. He was 59 years old.

title: Flyers Down Islanders In Preseason Opener
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Sept. 24An experimental rule instructing players to proceed directly to their respective benches when a fight breaks out made no impression tonight on the New York Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers. The Flyers' 31 victory over their Patrick Division rivals before 13,331 fans in the preseason opener for both teams was marked by a typical display of quick fists, quicker tempers and sound defensive hockey.

title: Popular on Campus: Cultivated Casual
description: THE prevailing attitude toward clothes on college campuses everywhere today is casual. Whether the school is Manhattanville, Sarah Lawrence or Vassar, freedom of choice is dominant. A couple of pairs of blue jeans will see anyone through the school year, yet there is no discrimination against those who want to be more adventurous.

title: How Are We Going to Get People in Public Office?
description: WASHINGTONIt was back in July, when Bert Lance had been called before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee for the third time, that Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, warned his colleagues that he thought they were going too far. How are we going to get people into public office if we are going to make their life a nightmare when they get into public office? he demanded. I'm very concerned about what's happening to government. I think we're eating ourselves alive.

title: Capt. William W. Kuhne, Retired Freighter Skipper And Sailor Since Age 14
description: Capt. William W. Kuhne, retired commodore of the American Export Lines, for which he had skippered ships for half of his 50 seafaring years, died on Sept. 15 in Brunswick, Me. He was 89 years old.

title: Questions/Answers
description: GRAPE HYACINTHS

title: Individualists Among the Group
description: GARDEN CITY

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Income Tax Takes
description: NOW that the summer vacation season is over, the real campaign for Governor has begun, and the state income tax remains the point of reference in the race.

title: Thea Musgrave's Elusive Ariadne
description: Thea Musgrave beams benevolently at her visitorthrough hornrimmed glasses and remarks with cheer: I don't know if you noticed, but I pinched the bit for four cellos in the seduction scene from the beginning of Act III of Tosca. It is a characteristic comment not in its confession of pinching, in which Miss Musgrave indulges sparingly, but in its candor and its indication that this brisk, 49yearold Scottish composer knows her way around 19thcentury opera scores in a thoroughly comfortable manner. Just now, however, it is 20thcentury opera that is on her mind specifically her own.

title: For the Fall, Take It Easy
description: Fall clothes are softer, looser and more comfortable than they've been in years. Some are shown here in printed challis, the season's most important fabric. Other new fashions on Pages 6 and 7.

title: Vera: Designer of Simple Purity
description: THIRTY miles from the bustle of the Seventh Avenue marketplace, high in the hills overlooking the Hudson, Vera lives and works, shuttling daily in 10minute trips between her home, Finney Farms in CrotononHudson, and her factory, Printex, in Ossining.

title: Civil Rights: A Critical Look
description: CIVIL RIGHTS in Connecticut are not deadjust buried alive beneath layers of weak leadership, improper state priorities, and vicious institutional racism, sexism and handicapism. Governor Grasso heads the list of public officials, with the responsibility and power to eliminate discrimination, who feel strict civilrights enforcement is a political liability.

title: Lida Livingston, 64, Health Writer And PublicRelations Specialist
description: Lida Livingston.a writer on health and a publicrelations specialist. died Sept 17 of a heart attack while travelling to New York City from Verment by car. she was 64 years old and lived at 20 West 86th Street in Manhattan

title: FISHING
description: THE fish are on the move. All those fish you looked for this summer are being caught now. For example, waves of striped bass are moving along the coast en route to their winter grounds up the Hudson River or in Chesapeake Bay, and bluefish have moved inshore and helping the bass to devour mullet, which are abundant in the surf.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Fashion's Stepchild: The Little Woman
description: FASHION has let me down. It has ignored my aging 9foot, 11inch, 92pound frame. Its practitioners have cut off my breathing with turtleneck sweaters that cover my nose, exposed my navel with Vneck dresses and immobilized my head with mandarin collars. Their longsleeved dresses have left me handless and their offtheshoulder creations have rendered me topless.

title: Irving Cooper, Man Of Science and Arts

title: The Colonial Boundaries, the Only Boundaries There Are, Now Are Threatened
description: NAIROBI, KenyaConflicting nationalisms, irredentist issues, religions and great power designs have all come into constellation in the horn of Africa to produce the fiercest war being waged in the world. The clash, between proSomali forces and the Ethiopian Army in Ethiopia's bleak Ogaden region, threatens AfroArab solidarity and puts the Soviet Union into the embarrassing position of supplying both armies in the name of Socialist solidarity. For African noncombatants, however, the greatest potential threat is that the fighting in the Ogaden may topple the continent's artificial colonial boundaries.

title: Fashion
description: Four nights from now, two of these four designers or design teams will win the Coty American Fashion Critics Award for women's clothing. This award is to the fashion world what the Oscar is to Hollywood  recognition of the year's best talent, creativity and innovation. Four hundred and fifty fashion editors across the country have voted. And, like the Oscar awards, nobody knows who the winners are until the envelope is opened on Thursday night. Officially, only two designers, or one designer and one team, can win. But, in fact, all deserve awards for talent and excellence. Without individuality such as they show, fashion would be a dogmatic bore. Here are this year's nominated designers, each with a sampling of his, or her, own fashions from their upcoming resort collections.

title: Communities Versus The TV Networks
description: Emma Bowen is a New York City grandmother whose outrage over how the networks treat minorities and their needs has made her a fulltime advocate of citizen rights in broadcasting. Her Black Citizens for Fair Media coalition has 197 organizations as memberschurches, unions, civic bodies, tenant associations, social, professional and arts groups. An advisory board of two representatives from each borough meets four times a year with executives of the networkowned stationsWABC, WCBS, WNBCand of Channel 13 to discuss black problems. Mrs. Bowen and her lawyers have negotiated agreements with WABC and WNBC for improved hiring and training procedures for blacks; WABCTV has produced a threepart program series about mental health problems of minorities, and Channel 13 did a comparable series on minorities in national politics. Only WCBS has spurned the coalition's recommendations (They are so arrogant, sighs Mrs. Bowen), but the management still talks with them regularly.

title: MOYNIHAN STAND ON SCHOOLS LAUDED

title: Ali's XFactor

The next minute Muhammad Ali is saying. I train for good fighters. Earnie Shavers is a good fighter. Ken Norton don't want no part of Earnie shavers, that's bow good a fighter Earnie Shav ers is. The message is clearMuhammad Ali is either trying to con Earnie Shavers or trying to con himself. But on Thursday night in Madison Square Garden the world heavyweight champion will not be able to con his 35yearold body.

title: S. Africa Has Definite Limits On Its Black Consciousness
description: KINGWII LIAMSTOWN, South AfricaBy Prime Minister John Vorster's estimate, not one in a hundred blacks knew who Steven Bantu Biko was until his mysterious death in a Pretoria prison cell two weeks ago. Yet even Mr. Vorster must have been given pause by the protest provoked by the death. Today, 20,000 blacks are expected to attend Mr. Biko's funeral, attesting by their numbers to the martyr's place that is now assured Mr. Biko in the history of the black man's struggle for freedom in South Africa.

title: A Passion for Running, Especially in February Snow
description: Running is a perverse sport. This probably explains my passion for it. To kick off the covers and unfurl from the fetus position on a bleak winter morning, to dress in a ridiculous, yet sentimentally important, costume that bears the name of the school from which we came or wish we had come; to push protesting muscles down endless stairs and finally to stumble out into the blueblack haze of the yawning day, all to greet the rising sun at the top of the hill that never ends, is Perverse.

title: LEARNING WITH THE HEART
description: For several years now, the tendency of most schools has been to speed kids up whenever possible. We seem to believe there's something inherently valuable in precocity  in being able to read, say, before you can tie your shoes  and so, without necessarily pushing kids to exceed their capacities, we've revised our notions of how they ought to spend their early school years. Almost invariably, kindergartens today cover material that used to be taught only in first grade, and more and more nursery schools have begun offering reading readiness to threeand fouryearolds.

title: FISHING
description: THE fall run of striped bass has begun off Montauk. And the fishing should be outstanding for the next few weeks as the bass sweep southward toward their winter grounds in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries.

title: Peking Drugs, Moscow Gold
description: JOHN LE CARRE (or John the Square) is the nom de plume of David John Moore Cornwell. whose preliterary career encompassed a spell of teaching at Eton and a period of work with the British Foreign Office. This latter biographical fact is important. Le Carre's contribution to the fiction of espionage has its roots in the truth of how a spy system works. If in Ian Fleming's James Bond novels we meet fantasy and embrace it with a willing suspension of disbelief, in books like The Honourable Schoolboy we approach a truth, or at least a plausibility that must be accepted even if we would prefer to reject it. The people who run Intelligence totally lack glamour, their service is short of money, they are up against the crassness of politicians. Their men in the field are frightened, make blunders, grow sick of a trade in which the opposed sides too often seem to interpenetrate and wear the same face; they have no notable dexterity with women, they vomit, and, when they get hurt, the hurt lasts.

title: Inside Harvard Law School
description: ONE L is a compelling and important book. it is compelling in its vivid portrayal of the hightension competitiveness of Harvard Law School and of the group madness it seems to induce in the student body. It is important because it offers an inside look at what law students do and don't learn and who they are and are not eauinned to represent when they graduate.
