description: SAILING TODAY

title: First Daley Marathon Shows a Dash of Politics
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 25It was the Mayor Daley Marathon. It was Chicago's first, and some said that, with more than 5,000 participants, it was the biggest. Some Chicagoans also said it was the best, but that was not official.

description: TAKING CARE OF BUSINESS

title: Dorsett Paces Cowboys in 98 Weather
German Paper Says Kidnappers Also Sought to Take Dutch Prince
description: BONN, Sept. 25 (UPI)The terrorists. who abducted a German industrialist, three weeks ago also planned to kidnap Prince Claus, husband of Crown Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands, the newspaper Bild am Sonntag said today.

title: Meal on Plane CanBeFunIf You Bring Your Own
description: So the airlines, after all these years, are about to institute no frills flights in earnest, thanks to the enterprising Laker group in England. The wonder is why the airlines, both foreign and domestic, imposed all those terrible (where food is concerned) frills on passengers all those years in the first place.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The panel of experts that recently reported on the causes of a 14year decline in Scholastic Aptitude Test (S.A.T.) scores may seem to be contradicting themselves when they call the downward curve serious business while urging coolheadedness and warning against overreaction. In fact, there is no contradiction between the conclusion and the recommendation. They add up to sensible advice to a public that frequently seems paranoid over test scores.

title: High Metal Pollution Is Found Off Sandy Hook
description: A study by marine scientists has found that two bodies of water in the metropolitan New York areathe apex of the New York Bight and Long Island Soundare contaminated by extraordinarily high levels of heavy metals.

description: 6:50News

title: Mike Hill Gets First Victory On Pro Golf Tour in 5 Years
description: MASON, Ohio, Sept, 25 (UPI)Mike Hill, who hadn't won a tournament in five years and was ready to quit the pro golf tour if his game didn't improve, won the $150,000 Ohio Kings Island open today by one stroke over Torn Kite.

description: Holding one stopper in a suit the opponents are sure to lead, a partnership should seldom consider a notrump contract if the stopper is the ace. In such cases, a suit contract, even in a minor suit, will nearly always be more productive.

title: British Ship's Visit Rec ails 1777 in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25Hundreds of inquisitive, noncombative American landlubbers occupied Her Majesty's Ship Penelope today on the eve of the 200th anniversary of the British occupation of Philadelphia in the Revolutionary War.

title: Ogaden Villagers Begin to Savor Freedom From Ethiopia
description: EL KERE, Ethiopia, Sept 23After living for 85 years under Ethiopian rule, the Somali people of this tiny mountain village are just beginning to believe that the despised Ethiopians will not be coming back.

description: AMSLOWMerris, loving husband brother and to us a dear uncle who made our childhood joyous. We will always membered.Goodbye Uncle Moisbe. reMember Goodbye Uncle Mo????

title: Los Angeles Began Its Drive to Get Games 8 Years Ago
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25Los Angeles, which was selected over New York City today as the United States choice in bidding for the 1984 Summer Olympic Games, began preparing for its victory more than eight years ago. And it won its race with New York through a combination of persistence, good organization and help from ,Depressionera economics.

title: Argentina Seizes Soviet Catches
description: PUERTO MADRYN, Argentina, Sept 25 (Reuters)Argentina today confiscated the catches of four Soviet trawlers arrested Wednesday while fishing inside Argentine territorial waters. The trawlers are also liable to fines of $5,000 to $100,000

title: Marya K. Thomas Married
description: Marya Kristen Thomas, an actress, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard James Coburn, a plastic surgeon. The Rev. Henry H. Sturtevant, vicar of St. Clement's Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony at the couple's home. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Amando Zabalas of Quezon City, the Philippines, where her father is a lawyer. Dr. Coburn is a son of Mrs. Robert Ernest Coburn of Concord, N.H., and the late Mr. Coburn.

title: Yarborough Is Winner In 500 Race in Virginia
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 (AP)No number of caution periods, fresh tires and lucky breaks could help the competition today as Cale Yarborough ran away with victory in the Old Dominion 500 Grand National stock car race.

title: Libya to Compensate Two U.S. Companies
description: Libya has agreed to pay Texaco Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California for their subsidiaries, nationalized in 1973 and 1974, the two petroleum producers announced yesterday.

title: ANGLICANORTHODOX TALKS HIT A SNAG ON ORDINATION
description: MOSCOW. Sept. 25 (Reuters)The Archbishop of Canterbury's personal mission for closer links between the Anglican and Russian Orthodox churches received a jolt today as differences over the ordination of women were brought into the open.

title: Swiss Voters Uphold Abortion Ban
description: GENEVA, Sept. 25Switzerland retained its ban on elective abortions today by rejecting in a nationwide referendum a proposal to permit a woman freely to obtain an abortion up to the 12th week of pregnancy.

title: Joint Economic Committee Says Fed Blocks Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Joint Economic Committee of Congress issued a pessimistic report today on the economic outlook, attacking the Federal Reserve System for having systematically obstructed recovery's since the 1974 recession.

description: Horses listed In order of Post positions Letter designates 0TB listing

title: Cliburn Competition Won by a South African
description: FORT WORTH,Sept. 25A 24yearold South African, Steven DeGroote, today won the fifth Van Cliburn International Quadrennial piano competition.

title: ExRep. Passman Asks U.S. Court To Void Ruling on Aide's Ouster
description: NEW ORLEANS,Sept. 26 (AP)A former United States Representative asked a Federal appeals court today to upset a decision against him in a lawsuit by a woman employee he dismissed and replaced with a man.

title: StateRun Air Force FliesUnder a Cloud
description: ALBANY, Sept. 26A twinengined turboprop aircraft in the blue and gold colors of New York State took off at 7 oclock the other morning from Albany County Airport, carrying State Transportation Comissioner William C. Hennessy to a meeting in Dunkirk.

title: Notes on People
description: Lester Maddox, former Governor of Georgia, was listed in guarded condition yesterday at a hospital in Marietta, north of Atlanta, after suffering a heart attack. The 61yearold Mr. Maddox was working in the yard of his home Sunday when he began having chest pains, and he was taken to the hospital because he couldn't stand it anymores according to his wife, Virginia. In recent months Mr. Maddox had been traveling with a biack comedian in a songanddance act. He first received attention in Atlanta and elsewhere as a vociferous foe of integration at the time of the civil rights turmoil of the 1960's. At one point Mr. Maddox gave away ax handels to supporters who helped him keep his Pickrick cafeteria segregated.

title: New York's Jobless Rate Improves Over 1976 Figure
description: New York City is making gains in reducing unemployment as compared with the. country at large, although it remains too high by any historic measure, the regional Federal commissioner of labor statistics said yesterday.

title: General Mills Earnings Rise 22.1%; Quarterly Dividend Is Increased
description: General Mills Inc., reported yesterday a 22.1 percent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 11 percent in the first fiscal quarter ended Aug. 28 .

title: End Who Scored After Running the Wrong Way Has Right Answer for Critics
description: Leroy Jones of the Greenwood, Miss., Joneses stands 6 feet 8 inches tall and weighs 274 pounds, which makes him the largest of all specimens in the National Football League. Leroy toils at defensive end for the San Diego Chargers_ and last Sunday ne scored a toucnaown alter running the wrong way. Shades of Jim Marshall! Here is how it went. John

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 27, 1977 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Assembly Votes Provision to Ease State's No Fault Law on Divorce
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26A significant change in New Jersey's divorce law was approved today by the State Assembly, including the elimination of a provision that a husband and wife must live in separate dwellings for 18 months before filing for a no fault dissolution of marriage.

title: Frederick E. Bolk Dies at 65; Banker Headed Mortgage Group
description: Frederick E .Bolk, who retired in January as senior vice president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, died Friday in Colorado Springs. He was 65 years old and a resident of Syosset, L.I.

title: U.S. Team Takes Soviet Series
description: LENINGRAD, Sept. 26 (UPI)The United States squad defeated the Soviet Union, 87, in the threecity Weisman Cup tennis tournament, despite losing four out of five sets tonight to a Soviet team.

title: WESTMORELAND SAYS WAR IN VIETNAM WAS MISTAKE
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 26Gen. William C. Westmoreland said today that he agreed with the majority of generals who fought in Vietnam that the United States should not have gone to war there. But he qualified his opinion, saying it was based on the fact that we weren't allowed to win it.

title: Israel Denies Settlement Approval
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 26Prime Minister Menahem Begin has told leaders of a militant ultranationalist group that his Government would not sanction their plans to establish 11 new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River this week.

title: Impasse on Sugar Export Quotas
description: GENEVA, Sept. 26The three largest sugarproducing nationsCuba, Brazil and Australiahave been unable to resolve their differences over export quotas at talks here on a new international sugar agreement.

title: Market Place
description: On Sept. 21, 1976, the post1974 bull market recorded its closing peak at 1,014.79, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average. Exactly one year later, the bluechip Dow had sunk to 840.96 . For the owners of steel, chemical, paper and many other bigcapitalization stocks, the 12 months were marked by sinking prices and sinking optimism.

title: Senate Hearings on Canal Open With  Vance Defending View of Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee bore down hard today on what they said were important differences of interpretation between American and Panamanian officials on key passages of the new Panama Canal treaties as the committtee began hearings on the pacts.

title: Companies List Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Aug. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: BAYER SEEKS TO BUY MILES LABORATORIES IN UNOFFICIAL OFFER
description: Bayer AG, the big West German chemical company, disclosed yesterday that had offered to pay at least $40 a share or nearly $216 million in cashfor Miles Laboratories of Elkhart, Ind., maker of AlkaSeltzer.

title: Stocks, in Late Rebound, Erase Some Losses for a Mixed Closing
description: Despite some unfavorable economic news, the stock market yesterday managed to finish mixed after a mild recovery in the last hour of trading erased some of the earlier losses.

title: Power Failure Test of Mettle For Residents
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 26Blow dryers stopped in the middle of haircuts, cars in repair shops were suddenly stranded on immobilized lifts, shop windows went dark, and on North Broadway in White Plains the only spot of color yesterday at 4 o'clock was the brilliant orange slicker of the policeman directing traffic under signal lamps gone dark.

title: Film Festival Today
description: THE CARTOON. NOW AND THEN, HERE AND THERE. 17 shorts, running from 40 seconds to 11 minutes each, by American and foreign animators. 3:15 at Alice Tully Hall. $2, $1.50 by subscription.

title: Dollar Sinks to Low Against Swiss Franc for 5th Straight Day
description: The dollar continued its slide against the; strong Swiss franc yesterday, reaching; a new low in Zurich for the fifth consecutive day,The Associated Press reported.:

title: Overlooked Aliens.
description: So much exposure has been given in the news media in recent months to illegal aliens that legal aliensspecifically, those seeking permanentresident status through the normal legal processhave been virtually forgotten.

title: Columbia Backs Coffee Price Cut To Fight Declining Consumption
description: LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP)Colombia, the world's second largest coffee grower, urged fellow producing nations today to lower prices to levels the man in the street can afford in order to stop the flight of coffee drinkers to cheaper beverages.

title: David Soul Sings Off Camera
description: Camerawielding teenage girls charging the stage, the flicker of hundreds of exploding flashcubes and a continual squealing that would subside to a barely perceptible murmur only to swell into a trebly roar were among the highlights of David Soul's Sunday afternoon concert at Radio City Music Hall. Mr. Soul, who stars in television's Starsky and Hutch series and is a pop singer, was giving his first American concert since the television series catapulted him to fame; there was second show Sunday evening. If the early performance was an accurate indication of his musical talents, then perhaps he should stick to television, although his many fans might not agree.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Sept. 26 (Reuters)President Valry Giscard d'Estaing made several minor cabinet changes today following the resignation of three ministers who were elected yesterday to the Senate.

title: A Contractor in Brooklyn Is Arrested for Altering Check on Looting Losses
description: A Brooklyn electrical contractor whose oneman shop in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn was looted during the July 13 blackout was arrested yesterday on charges of raising a $500 New York City emergencyaid check by $71.000.

title: Television
Sundays, 5Day Week Considered at Aqueduct
description: Winter racing at Aqueduct may be cut next January to a fiveday week, the New York Racing Association disclosed yesterday.

title: ExSergeant is Subpoenaed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  A Senate Judiciary subcommittee issued a subpoena today directing a former Army sergeant to produce any records on allegations that United States intelligence services had bugged communications of the Panamanian delegates to the canal treaty negotiations. The subpoena named Hor Rodriguez Brustmeyer, 28 years old, formerly of Brooklyn and believed to be now in Panama.

title: Art Displayed in Government Buildings
description: An unusual art show has brought a swirl of bright colors, abstract paintings and modern sculpture to the traditional dignity of the United States Court House at Foley Square and five other Government buildings in lower Manhattan.

title: SouthWest Africa Talks Reported Near Collapse Over Troops Issue
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 26 (Reuters)Four days of talks between South Africa and the five Western members of the Security Council on the future of South West Africa ended today with no immediate indication of agreement.

title: CONFEREES BACK RISE IN AID TO OLDER CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Senate and House conferees agreed tonight on threeyear $12.4 billion housing and communitydevelopment program that would provide vastly increased aid to older urban areas with severe problems of blight, including an extra $75 million year for New York City.

title: Where Do a Film's Credits Belong?
description: I didn't really mean to come back from a month on the beach with a redhot controversy all ready for you, but I do. Occasionally, as I sunned and partly clouded myself, my idle hands would grow weary of propping up the 18th and 19thcentury novels  together with biographies of the good folk who wrote themin which I was taking refuge, and I'd reach for something flimsier. (The 18th and 19th centuries are very good for clearing one's head of the 20thcentury theater, except that they don't, so remind me to tell you about an actress named Mrs. Oldfield sometime. But not now.)

title: Brzezinski in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 26 (Reuters)President Carter's adviser on national security affairs, Zbigniew Brzezinski, arrived here tonight for talks with Prime Minister James Callaghan. Earlier in the day Mr. Brzezinski met with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France in Paris.

title: Brown Signs 2 Solar Energy Bills
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (UPI)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California signed into state law today a bill giving a major tax break to those who install solar equipment in their homes and businesses. He also signed a bill that empowers the state Energy Commission to certify laboratories throughout the state that produce solar equipment to insure that the products are of high quality.

title: Clare Torrey, Investment Banker; ExHead of BelgianAmerican Unit
description: Clare Morse Torrey, a retired investment banker and former president of the BelgianAmerican Educational Foundation, died Sunday, at the Amsterdam House in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived at the Union Club Park Avenue and 69th Street.

title: Community Boards Are Ensnared In Red Tape, Assembly Panel Told

It was sold at a net interest cost of 5.75 percent, or onehalf percentage point less than the agency's previous bond sale. Mr. Byrne said the building of 3,316 housing units would create about 2,540 construction jobs.

title: Con Edison Averts Wide Blackout By Cutting Power in Westchester
description: With nearly 40 percent of its power supplies lost, apparently to lightning strikes, the Consolidated Edison Company averted a systemwide power failure yesterday by quickly cutting voltage, imposing limited blackouts in Westchester County and firing up reserve generators.

title: Senator Williams Would Retain OffBoard Rules for the Present
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., one of the architects of the law that mandated a national securities market system, has urged that prohibitions against offboard trading be continued until the basic framework of a nationwide system is in place.

title: TWO PBS PROGRAMS CREATING PROBLEMS
description: Publictelevision stations are faced with two delicate programming decisions, both of which have already provoked controversy.

title: Man, 67, Jailed in Obscenity Case
description: William Moore, 67 years old, of 237 West 10th Street, was sentenced yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Bentley Kassal in Manhattan to spend nine months in jail for promoting obscenity. Mr. Moore reportedly sold obscene films to undercover police officers who ran a pornographic book store at 711 Eighth Avenue. Mr. Moore had previously pleaded guilty.

title: Taxes &
description: The Internal Revenue Service has backed off from implementing a controversial ruling that would have treated some business transportation expenses as personal commuting expenses, and raised taxes for countless salesmen, accountants and construction workers.

title: 3 Top Government Regulators See Future for Lance in Banking
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Leaders of the nation's three top bank regulatory agencies said today that if they were managing a bank, they would have no qualms about hiring former Budget Director Bert Lance despite his previous banking difficulties.

title: Vilas Wins, Extends String
description: The victory was Vilas's 52d straight on a clay surface. The streak started last May in Paris and has carried him to the French and United States Open championships.

title: Giants, in Wake of Loss, Get a Day Off to Cool Off
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, NI., Sept. 26On doctor's orders, the Giants did not work out today and Coach John McVay reported obvio'sly nobody's in the steam room or sauna.

title: Tallbut TrueTales Run in Her Family
description: Therese Willig is probably best known as the mother of George Willig, the 28yearold human fly who last May scaled the South Tower of the World Trade Center. She also knows a thing or two about tall buildings herself.

title: Taxes &
description: The Internal Revenue Service has backed off from implementing a ruling that would have treated some business transportation expenses as personal commuting expenses. It will instead pursue the idea in regulations it plans to issue for public comment. Page 67.

title: Let the Workers Know the Risk
description: Another chemical horror story has come to light. An ambercolored liquid known as DBCP, used in pesticides, has been blamed for causing sterility in workers and may cause cancer as well. Federal regulators and the manufacturers have now moved belatedly to restrict worker and public exposure to the substanceyears after was approved for marketing on the basis of laboratory tests that would be considered inadequate by today's standards. So the immediate danger to thousands of industrial workers, tens of thousands of agricultural workers, and uncounted numbers of consumers may eventually be brought under control. But the case is a chilling reminder that our environment remains saturated with chemicals whose dangers may not yet be recognized, and the workers remain ignorant of the daily hazards.

title: People in Sports
description: The Mets, who will finish their National League schedule this week in Pittsburgh and St. Louis, yesterday acquired George (Doc) Medich on waivers from the Seattle Mariners of the American League. The 6foot5inch righthanded pitcher is expected to join the team today in Pittsburgh and may start one of the club's final eight games.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, tne number times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided into the stock's closing price. All prices are in dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dindicates new low.

title: Film Festival: 'Pafnucio Santo':Mexican Movie, Admirable in Some Respects, Is Curiosity
description: It's not every day that the opportunity arrives to see Patricia Hearst (a.k.a. Kane), Hernando Cortez, Juliet, Adam, Jesus Christ and a team of football players cavorting under one roof to the music of Anton Dvorak, Edvard Grieg, Antonio Vivaldi, Richard Wagner and Giaccomo Puccini, among others.And perhaps that's reason enough to run off to the 15th New York Film Festival tonight at 6:15 P.M. or next Sunday at 3 P.M. to see the Mexican movie "Pafnucio Santo," which may be the most eclectic extravaganza to play Lincoln Center since "The Night of the Scarecrow" by the Brazilian director Srgio Ricardo made the festival lineup in 1974.But audiences in search of films of less reach and greater grasp are best advised that "Pafnucio Santo" iswhile admirable in some respectschiefly a curiosity.The work of Rafael Corkidi, perhaps best known as the cameraman on the Alejandro Godorowsky films "El Topo" and "Holy Mountain," this movie mixes religion, politics, Mexican history and opera.At its simplest, it deals with the search for a woman to bear a new Messiah, undertaken by a small, football-helmeted boy, Pafnucio, at the behest of a sinister-looking, black-caped heavenly emissary who has borne witnesswe seeto the flight from Paradise, cross burnings by the Ku Klux Klan, the march of Jewish children into Nazi death camps and the crucifixion of Jesus.The search undertaken by Pafnucio carries him back and forth in Mexican history from Cortez to modern revolutionaries, with Patricia Hearst thrown in as Patricia Kane, obviously a descendant of the cinema Citizen of the same name. Everybody sings, and in the case of classic compositions, the original lyrics are retained, although the subtitles on the screen have the characters saying such things as "Don't you see the Empire is crumbling?" or "Your God killed our godsour temples, our art all lie in ruins.""Pafnucio Santo" is at its best visually. Mr. Corkidi has a keen eye for the visually striking: figures set against desolate landscapes, football players in full uniform drilling in the ruins of a cathedral, banner-waving peasant armies. But his ambitious movie is a bit like a homemade backyard shrine, admirable for what it says about the builder's capacity for compassion, regrettable in its confusion of prettiness for high art.

title: House Leaders Seek to End Standoff With Senate Over Abortion Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26House leaders will seek tomorrow to break a threemonth deadlock between the House and Senate over Medicaid funding for abortions, a situation that has stalled $60.1 billion in appropriations for the Departments of Labor and of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Paying the Nuclear Piper
description: WASHINGTONIn its three decades of existence, the American nuclear power programpushed with too much zeal and too little concern for the consequencesmay have created a Frankenstein's Monster that threatens to slip out of control. Much testimony recently taken by a House subcommittee supports that view.

title: The FamilyAlive but Not So Well
description: The Carnegie Council on Children, after deliberating for five years, has accurately and unoriginally identified poverty, unemployment and discrimination as the worst enemies of America's children. The suggested remedies in its report, All Our Childrenfull employment, a guaranteed annual income, and tax reformare equally unoriginal and not as readily attainable as the report suggests. Not until it reaches the family's role in dealing with the problems of America's children does the council introduce some new and potentially controversial issues. It rejects the fashionable cliche that the American family is dead or dying, leaving its children at the door of the state.

title: House Approves Bill On Child Pornography
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)A bill to thwart the multimilliondollar child pornography business passed the House today despite a warning that problems of constitutionality might enable lawyers to get violators off without penalties. The bill, approved 375 to 12, was sent to the Senate.

description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1977

title: Browns Beat Patriots in Overtime, 3027
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (AP)Don'Cockroft's 35yard field goal with minutes 45 seconds gone in suddendeath overtime gave the Cleveland Browns a 3027 victory over the New England Patriots at Municipal Stadium tonight.

title: State Run Air Force Flies Under a Cloud
description: ALBANY, Sept. 26A twinengined turboprop aircraft in the blue and gold colors of New York State took off at 7 oclock the other morning from Albany County Airport, carrying State Transportation Comissioner William C. Hennessy to a meeting in Dunkirk.

title: BROWN NAMES DEPUTY FOR INTELLIGENCE JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Defense Secretary Harold Brown has begun a major overhaul of the Pentagon's intelligence apparatus by appointing as his deputy for intelligence a retired admiral who worked in the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: President Carter's Sister in Bonn
description: BONN, Sept. 26 (Reuters)Ruth Carter Stapleton, President's Carter's evangelist sister, today had talks on religious subjects with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. She told journalists the discussions had touched only lightly on political themes.

title: Deaths
description: BECKMANNRhoda. Beloved wife of Selig. Devoted mother of Charles & Robert. Loving sister of Diana Raphael. Services Wednesday, 10AM at Gutterman's, Nassau Mamorial Chapel Long Beach Road at Greystone, Rockville Center, L.I.

title: Books of The Times
description: According to Gerald Jonas's Stuttering, as many as 75 muscles may be called into play during the production of a simple mama. And, of course, each movement must come in exactly on cue. Think about that long and hard enough, and you may find that like the fabled centipede you can no longer do what once came naturally. That's exactly what one of the more plausible theories of stuttering holds. In the opinion of Wendell Johnson of the Iowa Speech clinic: sometime between the ages of 3 and 5, when the problem of stuttering typically begins, the child learns to doubt that he can talk smoothly enough to please the people he talks to, mainly his parents and, He learns to fear what will happen if he doesn't. What this to is

title: Panel Backs Debt Ceiling Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a $73 billion increase in the national debt ceiling. The new ceiling of $773 billion would be effective through Sept. 30, 1978. The current ceiling expires this Friday, and some action must be taken by then to avoid disruption of Government functions.

description: He is hundreds of miles from Knoxville, the scene of the crimes, but he still flinches whenever a patrol car cruises by, and he still worries whenever he sees a cop. Force of habit.

The brother of the Indian sitarist Ravi Shankar, h was 76 years old.

description: PITTSBURGH', Sept. 25  1t has been observed of actresses that Juliet is a role only for either the very young or the very old. This is probably an exaggeration, but Shakespeare's immortal teenager does sometimes take on a special luster, a special glint of awareness, when played by a girl in that very .first rush of womanhood, when love and the world are hung with pristine dew.

title: PARKING

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26President Carter, noting that international economic health depends on the health of individual domestic economies, told the world's leading economic forum today that the United States would achieve its targeted 6 percent growth this year and was committed to vigorous activity in 1978.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26The Arab states were generally united today in rejecting Israel's conditions for accepting a panArab delegation at the Geneva peace conference.

title: Hawaiian Volcano Flares Up Again
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 26 (UPI)  Kilauea volcano flared up again today in the most explosive show of force since eruptions began two weeks ago. New fountains of lava were spurting nearly 100 feet in the air along a 200yard long rift between two fissures that had been pouring out lava earlier. Dan Dzurisin, a geologist with the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory, said no inhabited territory was immediately threatened by the new lava flow

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)The Agriculture Department says cigar smoking continues to decline, mainly because young people have not taken to them.

description: A Housing Authority police officer was shot to death last night while on duty outside a housing development on the Lower East Side.

description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 26The Israeli Ministry of Defense announced today that a ceasefire had gone into effect in the IsraeliLebanese border area, the scene of intense fighting in the last 10 days between Palestinian guerrillas and Israelisupported Lebanese Christians.

description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 26 (AP)Dr. Norman R. F. Maier, an internationally known psychologist and professor emeritus at the University of Michigan, died of a heart attack over the weekend, the university said today. He was 76 years old. Survivors include his wife, three sons and two grandchildren.

Poll Shows Blacks See Limits in Integration
description: Although nearly threefourths of 2,000 black Americans polled for the National Urban League said that they favored integration, only 28.9 percent said that they felt it was the best method for overcoming racial discrimination, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: CARTER ASKS SENATE TO ACT RESPONSIBLY ON HIS ENERGY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26President Carter, moving to salvage his beleagured energy program, today called on the Senate to act responsibly and reject narrow, special interest attacks on all segments of the national energy plan.

description: Five years have passed since Congress made the above words law in an Amendment to the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The revolutionary piece of legislation called Title IX strives to provide equal opportunity for both sexes in all areas of education.

title: The Canyon Tomorrow
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N. Y.My wilderness experience was shattered by the roar of an overflying airplane. So wrote a Grand Canyon hiker recently in a letter of complaint to the National Park Service. The plane, it turns out, was from a tourist airline based in Las Vegas. Besides stirring our empathy, the event illustrates a basic tension that will continue to exist for the Grand Canyon, and indeed for most of America's other spectacular wonders.

title: GOHEEN SEES U.S. TIES WITH INDIA IMPROVING
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 26The American Ambassador, Robert F. Goheen, said today that the relationship between India and the United States had sharply improved this year with the change in government in both countries.

description: A deputy director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has become the fourth agency official disclosed to have been named in connection with false expenseaccount billings.

title: Byrne and Bateman Debate Issue of State's Income Tax
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26The debate over the state income tax between the two major gubernatorial contenders heated up today as Governor Byrne and State. Senator Raypond H. Bateman of Somerville exchanged barbs in separate statements here and later in a direct confrontation before the League of Women Voters in Atlantic City.

title: Congress Seeks an Arms Pact Role
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The Senate Foreign Relations Committee indicated today that it would probably require some form of Congressional approval for the Administration's decision last week to adhere to the 1972 SovietUnited States agreement limiting offensive strategic missiles.

title: Panel Approves Apartment Tower for Art Museum
description: A controversial plan to build a luxury apartment tower over an enlarged Museum of Modern Art on West 53d Street was unanimously approved yesterday by the New York City Planning Commission.

title: H. R. Poindexter, 41, a Designer Of Sets and Lighting for Stage
description: H. R. Poindexter, setting and lighting designer, who was represented on the New York stage last season by William Luce's play, The Belle of Amherst, star, ring Julie Harris, and by The Circle in the Square's production of Tennessee Williams's The Night of the Iguana, died of a heart attack on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 41 years old.

title: HOME HEATING GAS SEEN ADEQUATE THIS WINTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)Despite a dwindling supply of natural gas, the Federal Energy Administration said today, home deliveries should be better this winter than last if the weather stays normal.

title: Harvey to Promote French Rallye Plane
description: The Rallye Aircraft Corporation, a division of France's Governmentowned Aerospatiale, is going to undertake the first serious selling effort in the United States in behalf of its sports aircraft.

title: CarnegieMellon U. Is Training Rhodesians for Government Service
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26After Lawrence returns to Rhodesia he hopes some day to become a member of the Government that will provide majority rule in the African nation.

title: 32,000 Cars Recalled by G.M.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP)The General Motors Corporation recalled today about 32,000 late 1977 and early 1978 model cars to inspect rear axles that could break. The rear axle shafts on some of the models recalled had a flaw in the metal which could result in axle breakage, G.M. said. The company said that it had no reports of accidents resulting from broken axles. Models in Chevrolet Nova. Pontiac Ventura, Pontiac Phoenix, Oldsmobile Omega and Buick Skylark lines were recalled.

title: Song: Al jarreau's Varied Style Wins Cheers of Diverse Group
description: The rapport between Al Jarreau and his audience Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall was quite extraordinarygiven the variety of the listeners. Particularly favored soul singers can inspire that sort of devotion, especially from womenone thinks of Al Green. But Mr. Jarreau's audience was not by anv means just a soul crowd.

title: Ramirez, Gotfried in Final
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (Reuters)Raul Ramirez of Mexico outplayed Manuel Orantes of Spain last night and qualified to meet his longtime doubles partner, Brian Gottfried, in the final tonight of the $100,000 Southern California open tennis championships.

title: Arthur Siegel Enjoys His Songs
description: During the many years that Arthur Siegel, the pianist and composer who wrote Love is a Simple Thing has been Kaye Ballard's musical director, he has offered brief indications of his charm as a singer as part of her act. Now he has moved into the back room of the Coriander Restaurant, 314 East 72d Street, where he can give full rein to his singing and playing.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TransAtlantic

title: Letter &
description: To the Editor:

title: Paper Futures Make Strong Start
description: Trading in commercial paper futures began yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade and the three nearest contracts promply advanced the daily permissible limit of 25 basis points from the opening call.

title: 3 Operas to Be Televised Live From Met by PBS
description: As a result of the success of last spring's live telecast of Puccini's La Boheme, three performances by the Metropolitan Opera will be televised live this season by the Public Broadcasting Service from the opera house. Funds will be provided by Texaco and the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Poisonous Chemicals Stolen
description: Three cans of a highly poisonous chemical, labled Dunsban, were stolen early yesterday from a locker at Grand Central Terminal, the police reported. The chemical was stolen between 4 A.M. and 7 A.M. from a locker belonging to the ESCO Exterminators of 60 Madison Ave. The police said they were told the chemical was so powerful it could cause death merely by touching it, but a company spokesman said Dursban is not exceptionally dangerous, although you won't want to drink it.

title: EMPIRE MUTUAL ILLS LAID TO MANAGEMENT
description: The financial troubles of the Empire Mutual Insurance Company and its subsidiary, Allcity, can be traced to mismanagement, according to an outside consultant that analyzed the company's operations.

title: Miss Kruger Triumphs
description: PALM HARBOR, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP)Marise Kruger of South Africa defeated a countrywoman, Linky Boshoff, 64, 63, in firstround action tonight in $35,000 Women's Tennis Association tournament. In other action, Mona Guerrant of Scottsdale, Ariz., defeated Lesley Charles of Worcester, England, 64, 62.

title: Desai, After Euphoric Start, Faces Frustrating Problems
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 26Six months ago, after a stunning electoral turnaround that unequivocally restored India's position as the world's most populous democracy, Morarji R. Desai came to power here in a dramatic celebration of human rights.

title: TAX CREDIT FOR TUITION FOR ALL SCHOOLS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  Senators Bob Packwood and Daniel Patrick Moynihan today introduced what they called revolutionary legislation aimed at providing tax credits to almost every American who has to pay education tuition. including those in parochial schools.

title: August's $2.7 Billion T rade Gap Was 2d Largest Ever
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)The nation's trade deficit grew to $2.7 billion in August, the second largest on record. the Government said today.

title: Negotiations That Could Put U.S. In Wheat Accord Begin in London
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Preparatory talks that could lead to this country's participation in a new international wheat agreement, a move opposed by many American farmers and grain dealers, began today in London. A team of Agriculture Department negotiators hope the talks will establish a framework binding both wheat exporting and importing countries to a mechanism that would stablilize world wheat prices and end the wild fluctuations of the last six years.

title: Bridge:
description: The world's population explosion is trivial if compared with the bridge explosion of life masters. The original 10, nominated on a basis of performance in 1936, had grown to a relatively modest 2,000 by 1959 but now there are 26.000.

title: Treaties Are Attacked in Panama, But Officials Predict Ratification
description: PANAMA, Sept. 26While opposition to the new Panama Canal treaties is intense in nationalist circles here, the military Government of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrerair expressing confidence that the accord will be overwhelmingly ratified in the plebiscite next month.

title: CARTER WELFARE PLAN CALLED TOO RESTRICTIVE
description: A new research study criticizes President Carter's proposed welfare changes as involving only $28 billion. Federal programs this fiscal year will transfer as much as $250 billion in cash or other benefits from one part of the nation's population to another.

title: State Judge Is Suspended Over Gift
description: A justice of the New York State Supreme Court was suspended from the bench without pay for six months yesterday for accepting a free weekend stay at a resort from a law firm whose members appeared regularly before him.

title: Grant Asserts That He's Not to Blame For New York's Failure on Olympics
description: Potential conflicts over Shea Stadium and a strong endorsement by athletes, who for the first time had signific,ant voting power, emerged as the key elements in the choice of Los Angeles over New York for the designated American city to bid for the 1984 Summer Olympics.

title: Meadowlands
Mediator Intensifies His Efforts to Avert a Dock Strike
description: The nation's top Federal mediator intensified his efforts yesterday to develop a formula that would avert the possibility of an East Coast dock strike on Saturday.

title: FREDERICK MERK, 90; A HARVARD HISTORIAN
description: Frederick Merk, the historian whose Wagon Wheels course on the nation's westward expansion, left an indelible impression on generations of Harvard students, died of a heart attack Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 90 years old.

title: Portland, Ore., Acclaims Downtown Mall
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept 26The Portland Mall, a 15block stretch of wide sidewalks, renovated .stores and outdoor art, is nearly finished, and thousands of area residents are already enthusiastic.

title: Margolis Trial for Tax Fraud Goes to Jury After Six Months
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 26A jury of nine men and three women today !began deliberations in the trial of a Bay Area lawyer, Harry Margolis, who has been on trial here for more than six months on charges of tax fraud in connection with the use of tax havens.

title: Ranger CallIn: Gilbert Walkout Talk of Town
description: New York Ranger fans, concerned about Rod Gilbert's future, flooded the Ranger office with telephone calls yesterday during a ninehour ticket promotion. The promotion gave the public a chance to speak with John Ferguson, the general manager; JeanGuy Talbot, the new coach, and Mike Burke, president of Madison Square Garden Center.

title: Laker Starts Flights From London; 2 U.S. Bargain Fares Approved
description: Laker Airways, the initiator of regularly scheduled cutrate transAtlantic air service, sent its first Skytrain from London to New York yesterday.

title: SALT Diplomacy, Abroad and at Home
description: The decision of the United States and the Soviet Union to behave as if their fiveyear interim agreement limit strategic arms were still in effect, even after expires on Oct. 3, makes sense: The two Governments are in midnegotiation for a new agreement to limit longrange offensive nuclear weapons; neither wants to jeopardize that accord with steps that would violate the old limits. But it also makes sense for the Carter Administration to invite Congressional scrutiny of what it doing.

title: GARTER LOWERS FARES ON FLIGHTS TO LONDON
description: President Carter put in effect yesterday two new transAtlantic bargain fares That will increase competition for the minimumfrills, no reservations New YorkLondon service that Laker Airways has just started.

title: Machine Tool Orders in August Totaled $248.5 Million, Up 13%
description: Machine tool orders in August totaled $248.5 million, a 13 percent increase from July's total and a 23 percent increase from the total for August 1976, according to the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: Recital: Rudyntsky Performs Liszt and Beethoven
description: Since his Town Hall recital debut in 1969 shortly after graduating from Juilliard, Roman Rudyntsky has not played in New York, preferring to pursue an active career abroad and in other parts of the United States. On Saturday afternoon the pianist gave his first New York concert in eight years at Carnegie Recital Hall and he proved to be a keyboard technician of uncommon skill and facility.

title: 4 Mayoral Candidates Address Brooklyn Businessmen
description: The new mayoral debating teamthe four major candidates in the general electionput on its first show yesterday, talking before Brooklyn businessmen about taxes, economic development and crime.

title: Jersey College Uses Pornography in a Sex Attitudes Workshop
description: MADISON, N.J.The Fairleigh Dickinson University campus here, a serene place of neat lawns and old trees, seems an unlikely spot for a profusion of hardcore pornography. But over the weekend, a group of about 180 students and invited guests was deluged by a combination of the kinds of pornographic films that would be at home on 42d Street and other equally explicit films produced for sex education purposes.

title: Coast Woman Starts Medical Study As Court Blocks Admission Rule
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26  Rita Clancy paid her registration fees this morning and went to her first lecture at the medical school of the University of California at Davis, having won a courtroom round against the school's minorities admission program.

title: Pennsylvania Senators Bar Ouster Of Indicted Head of Committee
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.,Sept 26 (UPI)Democrats of the Pennsylvania State Senate refused today to force Senator Henry Cianfrani, Democrat of Philadelphia, to step aside as chairman of the Appropriations Committee because of a Federal indictment charging that he misused committee funds.

title: New Rochelle Plan Suggests Ways To Shed Its Persistent Poor Image
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 26Last February the leaders of New Rochelle asked David Finn, a 20year resident and the president of Ruder and Finn, a public relations concern, to suggest ways to improve what they felt was the persistent but undeserved poor image of the city.

title: Identity of Crash Victims Sought
description: BEATTYVILLE. Ky., Sept. 26 (AP) Tests were under way to identify the charred remains of seven persons killed in the fiery crash of a gasoline truck Saturday. The crash occurred when the truck's brakes failed on a 700vfootlong grade on a road leading into the business district of this town of 1,200. The tanker crashed into a building and plowed through several stores, killing persons inside.

title: Political Turmoil in China That Paralyzed Scientists Reportedly Increased Quake Toll
description: Although Chinese scientists say that Warning signs were observed before the Tangshan earthquake of July 28, 1976, the scientific leadership in Peking was so paralyzed by efforts of the Gang of Four to seize power that no action was taken.

title: Egyptian Rejects Israeli Conditions on Geneva Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt today rejected the conditions attached by Israel to its acceptance of an American proposal for a unified Arab delegation at a Geneva peace conference.

title: Advertising
description: Yesterday Prince Matchabelli, a division of ChesebroughPcmds, began its television advertising for the first Aziza products that are not eye cosmetics.

title: Laker Starts Flights From London; 2 U.S. Bargain Fares Approved
description: Laker Airways, the initiator of regularly scheduled cutrate transAtlantic air service, sent its first Skytrain from London to New York yesterday.

title: Youth, 18, Pleads Guilty to Slaying Of Expectant Brooklyn Mother, 21
description: An 18yearold student yesterday pleaded guilty to the rape and murder last March of Rachel Brecher, the wife of a young rabbinical student from the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: NEW RULES PLANNED TO CUT SMUGGLING OF CIGARETTES

The changes could end an illegal traffic that costs the Federal Government and state governments as much as $22 million in tax revenues annually, the Bureau of Alcohol. Tobacco and Firearms said.

title: Torrez, Lyle Stop Indians And Yanks Raise Lead to 31

title: A DIAMOND CUTTER REPORTED MISSING
description: A diamond cutter who was supposed to meet a young diamond broker on the day the broker mysteriously disappeared last week is now also missing, the police said yesterday.

title: JOSEPH POLLINO
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (AP)Services will be held Wednesday for Joseph Pollino, a boxing trainer, who died here yesterday at the age of 65.

title: CONFEREES BACK RISE IN AID TO OLDER CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Senate and House conferees agreed tonight on a threeyear $12.4 billion housing and communitydevelopment program that would provide vastly increased aid to older urban areas with severe problems of blight, including an extra $75 million a year for New York City.

title: H.E.W.ACTS TO REDUCE HOSPITALBED EXCESS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Federal health planners proposed today a series of standards for most of the nation's hospitals that, they said, would eliminate most of an estimated 100,000 unneeded beds over the next seven years.

description: PARIS, Sept. 26 (AP)Lucie Faure, a French editor and author, and wife of the President of the National Assembly, Edgar Faure, died yesterday at their country home near Paris of a heart attack. She was 69 years old.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26Israel was reported to be pulling out tanks, trucks and armored personnel carriers from southern Lebanon today as a ceasefire, worked out after intensive diplomatic efforts by the United States, went into effect.

description: Dr. George F. Thomas, who introduced the study of religion as an intellectual discipline with the liberal arts curriculum at Princeton University, and who retired as M. Taylor Pyne Professor in 1968, died Sunday at the Merwick Unit of the Princeton Medical Center. He was 78 years old.

description: Look, Ma, we're all dancing. With the ballet one of the city's most popular art forms, look for dance clothes to make a great leap into everyday fashion. title: News Summary

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: WASHINGTONWhile the overriding mood at this year's meeting of the international financial institutions continues to reflect a high level of concern over lagging economic growth, observers are detecting at least a few degrees of change from the The anxieties and priorities that prevailed a year ago in Economic Manila and two years ago Scene in this city. At least, some of the background developments are a bit more pleasant. The world is somehow managing to cope with its economic problems. Debt is being serviced, and, in real terms, the total burden is not much different from what it was at the beginning of this decade. Economic growth has increased a bit, and there is a disposition to expand the resources of the financial institution to permit greater help for nations in need.

title: TIME. The most colorful coverage of the week. And the most intriguing
description: When James Bond was riding high, womanizing inexhaustibly, and matching the forces of evil, gimmick for gimmick, an anomaly appeared: a portly, rumpled, donnish gentleman named George Smiley, whom we now recognize as the premier spy of his time. Which is only right, since his creator, John LeCarre, is the premier spy novelist of his time.

title: ExKlansman Indicted in 63 Bombing That Killed 4

Robert Chambliss of Birmingham was being held without bond in Jefferton County Jail in Birmingham.

title: Stage : Sponsor Attemptsto Deal With Old Age
description: We all get old, but when? Not so soon to ourselves as to others.

Carlino, was found floating in the waters of Montauk Harbor by a Coast Guard cutter, officials announced. Mr. Carlino and his wife, Katherine, 23, had been missing since Sept. 16 when their singleengine plane disappeared after leaving Montauk Airport. Mrs. Carlino's body was found last Friday a mile south of Montauk Point by a search plane of the State Civil Air Patrol.

The park is also home to a variety of fauna, of which 400 are squirrels, locus of 100,000 trees  Kentucky coffee, cucumber, magnolia, horse chestnut. Chinese pagoda, Japanese holly, London plane, nannyberry and many others  and site of visible Manhattan schist, the 360millionyearold bedrock on which Manhattan's skyscrapers rest.

description: Following is the statement by Governor Carey on the mayoral election:

description: ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP)The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation plans to develop 15 more hydroelectric generating plants in the state, including, in the upper Hudson Valley, new developments for Fort Edward and Hadley, with expansions at existing facilities at Spier Falls, Sherman Island, Feeder Dam, South Glens Falls and Hudson Falls.

description: Gordon Lamont, a past president of the Dairy Industry Supply Association who was a vice president and director of Lamont Corliss & Company from 1925 to 1951, died Sunday at his summer home in Darien Conn.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Federal health planners proposed today a series of standards for most of the nation's hospitals that, they said, would eliminate most of an estimated 100,000 unneeded beds over the next seven years.

description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 26A combination of indifference and widespread hostility around the nation appears likely to limit the impact of the proposed Carter Administration policy that the Concorde supersonic airliner be allowed to land at the airports of 13 American cities.

title: Defense Sums Up in 3d Trial on Policeman's Slaying
description: ELIZABETH, Sept. 26The defense attorney in the third trial of a man accused of wielding a meat cleaver during the slaying of a Plainfield police officer by a mob during rioting in 1967 urged the jurors today to ignore color photographs of the dead officer's wounds and to judge the case on the hard evidence presented.

title: Pontiff Turns 80; He Shows No Sign Of Wanting to Quit
description: ROME, Sept. 26Pope Paul VI was 80 years old today. Contrary to widespread speculation in the Italian press over the last few months, he not only gave no signs of wanting to resign but was reported to be deeply involved in the preparation of a bishop's synod opening Friday that he will address.

title: Puetz Confused but Not Bitter After Benching by Michaels
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.,Sept. 26Even before the Jets discovered him at Valparaiso College, Garry Puetz knew that football players never question their coach.

title: Divorce Law Change Progresses in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26The State Assembly approved a revision today that would eliminate the provisions that a husband and wife have to live in separate dwellings for 18 months before filing for a nofault dissolution of marriage.

title: Pesticide Work Suggested for Those Seeking Sterility
description: WASHINGTON,Sept. 26A national agricultural group has suggested that older workers who do hot want children and persons who would like to get around religious bans against birth control be allowed to handle a pesticide that has been known to cause sterility.

title: Sand Is Named Chief At Parents Magazine
description: Edward A. Sand, who has been president of Parents Magazine Enterprises Inc. isnce 1964, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the company.

title: Film Festival: 'The Truck' Talks And Talks but It Says Very Little
description: In "The Truck," the director and novelist Marguerite Duras plays a woman whose lips curl into a joyless, knowing half-smile every time she makes mention of despair. Her film should appeal most strongly to those viewers who are similarly attuned to the romantic possibilities of gloom. However, even those who have little patience for Miss Duras's preciousness may find her work as haunting and determinedly self-possessed as it is quietly infuriating."The Truck," which will be screened this evening at 9:30 and tomorrow evening at 6:15 in the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall, involves two players and a blue diesel rig. The actorstiny, stiff-backed Miss Duras and beefy, hulking Grard Depardieusit fixedly at a table, reading aloud and discussing a film script she has written. The truck, seen intermittently, rolls inexorably along highways and byways. There is no other action.The script is about a woman possessed of "the noblesse of banality," to use Miss Duras's phrase. The woman is given a lift by a young truck driver. "He's exercising his profession," Miss Duras explains, "and she, she's tranported by him."In the truck, as the script has it, the woman sings and talks a great deal. Mr. Depardieu's character asks her. "But what are you talking about?" "She says, 'I'm talking,'" is Miss Duras's reply."The Truck" is full of exasperatingly banal interchanges, which are in no way improved or illuminated by Miss Duras's admission of her character's banality. It is also rather coyly self-pitying, because Miss Duras and her character seem to overlap, and the character is at times made to seem pathetic.But the scenes of the truck take on an eerie grandeur after a while, and Miss Duras's disdain for her audience's expectations becomes perversely transfixing. It's a pity that her script is not as stern and unrelenting as the film's visual style.On the same bill, and on quite a different note, is "Grandpa," a 29-minute short by Stephen Forman and Paul Desaulniers, an affectionate and admiring portrait of Mr. Forman's feisty grandfather. The talkative grandfather says more in this film's first five minutes than Mr. Depardieu says during the entirety of "The Truck."

title: Debate on New Jersey's Income Tax Heats Up as Byrne and Bateman Trade Charges
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26The debate over the state income tax between the two major New Jersey gubernatorial contenders heated up today as Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville, exchanged barbs in separate statements here and later in a direct confrontation before the League of Women Voters in Atlantic City.

title: Chess:
description: How do you know when its time for a change to the strange? Why, it's when you meet the same opponent all too often anddespite all your study of his favorite defenseyou Still feel uncomfortable.

title: CARTER TO AID KOCH IN RACE FOR MAYOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27President Carter will campaign for Representative Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York City, in New York on Tuesday, Mr. Koch announced today after a meeting with the President at the White House.

title: Mirage Is a Dance Of Illusions
description: THE MIRAGE is  classically associated with desert wastes and desperate men. It is conventionally considered nature's prank on thirsty travelers in extremis, but Joan Jonas in her Mirage suggests that illusionary effects exist around us every day. The work, given at 80 Wooster Street Monday evening, was an effective trompe l'oeil compilation of live movement, video and film.

title: Jazz: Vache's Trumpet
description: WARREN VACHE is an anomaly. Although he is only 26, he plays the trumpet in a style that was current in the 1920's and early 30's. This is not in itself terribly remarkable, but Mr. Vach is original, within his stylistic context, and he has a sound and control that would make him a notable musician no matter what the context.

title: Fashions: LowKey and HighStyle
description: Philippe Venet, one of the best tailors in Paris; the Fendi family, creators of miracles in fur in Milan, and Ohrbach's, the store on 34th street that has perfected the process of translating European couture clothes into reasonably priced copiesthese were the heroes for three of this week's fashionable activities.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, September 28, 1877

title: Despite Promotion, CBSTV Rates Last
description: ESPITE a major cashgiveaway campaign designed to increase its audiencea promotion that reportedly represented a total investment of $1 million CBSTV last week finished last in the national Nielsen ratings, a shade behind NBCTV.

title: Pele Presented an Award For Support of UNICEF
description: Delegates from the United Nations and members of the United States Committee for UNICEF honored Fele at a United Nations reception yesterday afternoon. Then, later in the evening, Fele enjoyed a dinner in his honor with his family and about 500 others at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: OW THAT the peak vacation season has ended, some of the better souvenirs of travel are turning up. One of Helen Wyle's friends is a dentist, who was vacationing in Dublin when the messate clerk handed him a note.

title: 56th Body Found in 1968 Blast
description: FARMINGTON, W.Va., Sept. 27 (AP)Nearly nine years after explosions ripped through a coal mine here, killing 78 miners, workmen sifting through the rubble yesterday discovered the body of a Brideport man. His was the 56th body found by a recovery team at the Farmington No. 9 mine owned by the Consolidation Coal Company, a Consolidation spokesman said. The state police identified the man as Hoy B. Taylor, who was 40 years old at the time of the explosions on Nov. 20, 1968.

title: A Gallimaufry Of Great Cooking
description: From Taillevent in the 14th century to Escoffier, who died in 1935, the history of cookery presents a fascinating picture that is well documented by Anne Willan, the founding director of one of Pariss newest and most highly respected cooking schools, Ecole de Cuisine La Varenne.

title: Television
Police in 2 Nations Asked to Help Find 2 in Gem Mystery
description: New York City police, acting through Interpol, askel the police in Belgium and Israel yesterday. to be on the lookout for a diamond broker who vanished last week while carrying possibly as much as $1 million worth of gems, and for a diamondcutter who reportedly disappeared Sunday, also possibly with a quantity of diamonds.

title: Concorde: The Federal Lateral
description: The Carter Administration has now rendered its verdict on the Concorde, the BritishFrench supersonic transport that seems destined to become a financial disaster as well as an environmental liability. The 16 Concordes already built or under construction will be allowed to fly into as many as 13 American airports under restricted operating conditionsunless local airport authorities ban them for violating reasonable, nondiscriminatory noise rules. That throws the burden back on local officials who in turn will have to respond, as in New York City, to community pressure and court decisions as well.

description: LONGTIME study of 95 of Harvard's best and brightest graduates has shown that, contrary to popular belief, men who become company presidents have the happiest marriages and the richest friendships.

title: This Is a Recorded Message

(The Times. we hasten to add. has no intention of usine it.)

title: Underground Nuclear Test Held
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Sept. 27 (UPI)United States scientists detonated an undeground nuclear device today that was barely felt off this reniote Nevada test site. A spokesman for the Energy Research and Development Administration said that the test was a success and that no radiation had leaked into the atmosphere.

title: Soft Sell Tried in Midtown Cleanup Drive
description: Twentyfive businesses in midtown Manhattan sent maintenance men into the streets yesterday to try a softsell campaign against littering.

title: Gromyko Meets With Carter After Addressing U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27Andrei A. Gromyko told the General Assembly today that the Soviet Union was eager for progress on armscontrol agreements with the United States. Several hours later, in a surprise move, he flew to Washington to meet with President Carter tonight.

title: CeaseFire Stirs Hope in South Lebanon, but the Foes Remain on Alert
description: KHIAM, Lebanon Sept. 27The olive groves were scorched brown. Hardly any of the stone houses were left intact and the only sign of life on the main street was a small girl and three stray cats.

title: DR. JOHN S. NILES JR.
description: Dr. John S. Niles Jr., a surgeon at Robert Packer Hospital, Sayre, Pa., died Monday in his home in Crystal Lake, Pa., after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: S. E.C. Asks Stiffer Audit Disclosure
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday proposed stiffer disclosure rules involving relations between certified public accountants and their corporate audit clients.

title: Books Of TheTimes
description: WHEN Associate Justice William O. Douglas retired from the United States Supreme Court in November 1975, he had served for more than 36 years. During this timeas turbulent as any for testing the Constitution and the countryhe wrote more than 1,200 majority, concurring and dissenting opinions. To take a sampling in The Douglas Opinions is to savor the choicest fruit from the tree of liberty. Who else but Justice Douglas, writing for the public as well as for the student of the law, would have defined the purpose of the Bill of Rights as to keep the Government off the backs of the people?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The Times yesterday on changes in the Pentagon's intelligence operations, it was erroneously stated that Adm. Stansfield Turner, Director or Central Intelligence, has been granted control over the entire national defense budget. It should have said that Admiral Turner has control over the entire national defense intelligence budget.

title: Wine Talk
description: NEW YORK has never really lacked for good French restaurants, but there seems to be a permanent shortage of French restaurants with good wine lists. A handful of places make an attempt to offer a varied selection, but hardly any ever tries to put forth a wine card prepared with imagination.

title: FREDERICK SCHMIDT, 52; A COPY EDITOR ON TIMES
description: Frederick C. Schmidt, a copy editor for The New York Times for the last 26 years, died of cancer yesterday at Monte. fiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 52 years old and lived at 6255 Broadway, Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Stage: Margarida Explores Power
description: he stage is a schoolroom pa trolled by a demented teacher who flays and cajoles her students and never reaches them. The teacher is allpowerful and totally helpless: She does anything she wants and accomplishes nothing. She is a drum pounding in an airless void.

title: On Replacing Lance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27In choosing people to preside over the major questions of money, justice and communications in his Administration, President Carter called on three friends: Bert Lance at the Office of Management and Budget; Griffin Bell as Attorney General, and Jody Powell as White House press secretary.

title: Lincolns Return To Spanish Fields
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 23It was from Barcelona that they left Spain, with the war against fascism they had come to fight still undecided.

title: BrownsPatriots Scoring
Rites for Leslie Gould
description: A memorial service will be held for Leslie Gould on Thursday, Oct. 6, at 4 P.M. in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 91st Street. Mr. Gould, financial editor of the old New York JournalAmerican, died last Friday in Naples, Fla., where he bad lived in recent years.

title: Market Place

Bethlehem, No. 2 in the industry after United States Steel, reduced its dividend by half this summer and then saw its stock plummet.

title: Carter's Latin Policy: No Big Pledges but Honest Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  President Carter has launched a Latin American policy shorn of the traditional rhetoric and prodigal promises, with strong emphasis on human rights but enough flexibility to conclude new canal treaties

title: Gov. Busbee Says Committee's Bill Would Rob the South to Aid North
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 27 (AP)Gov. George Busbee charged today that a Congressional conference committee would rob the South to aid the North under a $12,4 billion housing and community develc ment program it approved yesterday.

title: Saks to Take American Express Card
description: Saks Fifth Avenue said yesterday that its 30 stores across the country would begin accepting the American Express credit card starting Oct. 17. The card will be used in addition to Saks own credit card. In accepting the American Express card, Saks joins other retailers, including R. H. Macy & Company, Bonwit Teller, Cartier and John Wanamaker.

title: Baltimore 61 Victor
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (AP)Mike Flanagan struck out 13, including eight in the first three innings, as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Detroit Tigers, 61, tonight and kept alive their slim hopes in the American League East.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state should deny requests by three of New Jersey's four gas utilities to add new customers. This the recommendation of Energy Commissioner Joel R. Jacobson.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Tenneco Inc. and the Philadelphia Life Insurance Company jointly announced yesterday that the board of Philadelphia Life had been asked to consider a revised offer by Tenneco to acquire approximately 76 percent of Philadelphia Life's common not now owned by Tenneco.

title: Ramirez Beats Gottfried in Final on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP)Raul Ramirez of Mexico broke service in the 10th game of the third grueling set last night and went on to defeat topseeded Brian Gottfried and win the $100.000 Southern California open tennis charnnionshin 75. 36. 64.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided Into the stock's closing price. All prices are. In dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dindicates new low..

title: Plight of Yonkers Is Laid to DelBello By G .O. P. Rival
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 27Assemblyman Gordon Burrows, seeking to unseat the Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, said today that Mr. DelBello, as the Mayor of Yonkers several years ago, created the conditions for that city's fiscal plight and was now leading the county into similar difficulties.

title: Robert Lipsyte Quits at The Post, Charging Restrictions on Column
description: Robert Lipsyte, a columnist for The New York Post, said last night that he had resigned from the paper because he was denied the freedom to have opinions in counterpoint to the paper's policy.

title: Annenberg Again Changes HisMedia Center Plan
description: Walter H: Annenberg, president of Triangle publications and former Ambassador to Britain, who last March withdraw his proposed gift of $40 million for a communications center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and then asked the University of Pennsylvania to submit a plan and budget for the center, has notified university officials of yet another plan.

title: Spending Rise Is Set By U.S. Foreign Units
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)Foreign affiliates of United States companies plan to increase their capital expenditures 12 percent in 1978, the same as their prediction for this year, the Commerce Department said today. Expenditures declined 3 percent in 1976, reflecting the slow recovery abroad from the 197475 recession.

title: Yanks Win in Ninth And Need 3 to Clinch
description: Dave Kingman, who could be on the verge of signing with the Yankees, won a game for his fourth team of the season last night without even swinging his dangerous bat.

title: CRIME RATE UP 0.4% IN 76 ; RISE SMALLEST IN 4 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that serious crime last year did not increase much over that of 1975. It was the first time in four years that there has not been a substantial rise.

title: Secretary Kreps Warns Japanese Trade Imbalance Is Unacceptable
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27One day after her department reported the second largest monthly United States trade deficit in history, Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps warned businessmen here today that a continuation of such trade imbalances is simply unacceptable.

title: Employ Handicapped Week Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)President Carter today designated next week as National Employ the Handicapped Week.

title: LEVITT'S AUDIT CITES $15.4 MILLION SAVING
description: New York City could save $15.6 million a year by replacing 1,200 uniformed personnel in four departments with civilians, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt asserted yesterday.

title: The Left Rumble in France
description: The squabbling in France between the Communists and Socialists has raised hopes that the left's electoral edge will be eroded. Considering the risks for France and its allies if Communist ministers share power after the parliamentary elections next March, that hope is understandable. But it may be wishful thinking. At least, that is this writer's impression after revisiting France and Western Europe.

title: Continental Airlines Pact Backed
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP)Continental Airlines flight attendants yesterday ratified a twoyear contract, a negotiating committee spokesman said. Under the old contract, flight attendents were paid $496 a month for 65 hours of flight time, while under the new pact they will get $690 for the same 65 hours in flight.

title: Outstanding Piano, Cello
description: A GLANCE AT THE PROGRAM for Monday night's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was enough to disclose the musical intentions of the performers. Customarily the pianist in a duorecital is listed second and in smaller type, too often deservedly so. But Elizabeth Wright, the pianist who shared the stage with the cellist Joel Krosnick, not only was given the courtesy of printed precedence over her partner, but also enjoyed a solo interlude as well, nothing less than Beethoven's Sonata in Aflat (Op. 110). Rightly so, for Miss Wright sounded like an artist too strong to fade into the background as anyone's mere accompanist.

title: F.D.A. Says Rapeseed Oil Is Safe
description: WASHINGTON (AP)The Food and Drug Administration has affirmed that fully hydrogenated rapeseed oil in peanut butter and superglycerinated fully hydrogenated rapeseed oil in cake mixes are generally recognized as safe for use in the two items. The oil is pressed from the seeds of the rape plant, an Old World plant of the mustard family whose leaves are sometimes used for forage.

title: L.I. Lawyer Charged in Alleged $700,000 Swindle
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 27A Suffolk County lawyer was arraigned today on 63 counts of grand larceny and forgery in an alleged $700,000 Ponzi scheme that involved selling false corporate mortgages to friends and associates with the promise of a high rate of return. He was jailed when he could not come up with the $5,000 bail set by the judge.

Dunne, who lost the Republican primary but who has an independent line in the race for Nassau County Executive, announced today that he would support the primary winner, Francis T. Purcell, thus strongly enhancing 'r. Purcell's prospects of defeating the Democrat in November.

title: Swiss Curb Lifts Dollar and Mark
description: GENEVA. Sept. 27Switzerland moved today to ease the upward pressure on the franc, giving a strong boost to the depressed dollar and the weakened mark. However, foreignexchange dealers predicted that the fillip to the dollar and mark would only be temporary.

title: Report on Fire at Danbury Prison Finds Chaos, but No Malfeasance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27A Federal board of inquiry said today there had been confusion and unpreparedness, but no dereliction or malfeasance, in the fire at Danbury Federal Prison on July 7 that killed five inmates and injured 68.

title: Notes on People
description: WO leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States ended yesterday a private visit to Hungary that was regarded as another important step toward resumption of diplomatic relations between Hungary and the Vatican. John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia and Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin spent six days in Budapest and elsewhere as guests of the Hungarian Primate, Laszlo Cardinal Lekai. Sources in Budapest said that the visit was a further manifestation of a warming of relations between the Vatican and Hungary, which were officially cut off in 1948 when the Communists took over. Seventyfive percent of Hungary's 10.5 million people are Catholics.

title: Hogan Memorial Scheduled
description: A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M. Sunday in the Milbank Chapel of Teachers College, 525 West 120th Street in Manhattan for Dr. Peter D. Hogan, who died Aug. 9 in an auto accident while vacationing in Switzerland. He was 50 years old and lived at 1385 York Avenue in Manhattan. He was a fellow of the Amrican Academy of Psychoanalysis and a clinical professor of psychiatry at New York University. Dr. Hogan, who had been divorced twice, is survived by a daughter, Jeanette; two sons, Peter D. Jr., and Sean, and two grandchildren.

But they do not accept his contention that New York State's horrendous deficit in its balance of payments with the Federal Government is a major factor in assessing Federal impact on the state's economy.
