title: IllinoisGovernorActingLikeU.S.Candidate
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27About the time the other day when the last stragglers were limping along Chicago's lakefront toward the finish line in the first annual Mayor Richard J. Daley Marathon, Gov. James R. Thompson was sprawling in the Arizona sun absorbed in an account of a different kind of running. He was reading Jules Witcover's Marathon, a recounting of Jimmy Carter's dogged, fouryear campaign for the Presidency he won last fall.

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: HERE is an interesting if curious notion that French chefs live on the likes of foie gras and sturgeon, cocks combs and caviar. That th???urn up their nose at the thought of such downtoearth fare as American hot dogs and corn on the cob and barbecued spareribs. Nothing could be further from the truth. I, personally, have a great liking for liverwurst sandwiches, pastrami on rye and a wellmade hamburger. On occasion, however, when I serve typically Americanand unFrenchfoods in my home, there may be a temptation at times to give these dishes a French touch.

title: New Accounting Leader
description: Donald James Kirk, elected chairman yesterday of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, is described as a forceful, harddriving executive who does not shrink from taking a minority stance. His independent attitude will probably prove useful in the maths ahead as he seeks to guide the standards board, the private sector's top authority on accounting rules, throughsome controversial issues that have aroused divided opinions in the business community and in the Congress. The election was held in Stamford, Conn.

title: THE EXPERT SHOPPER
description: T this season, scallop devotees have ample cause for rejoicing. Tender, nutsweet Long Island bay scallops started coming to market on Sept. 15, and will continue to cio so until about April 15, and the New England varieties will be on hand from about Sept. 30 to the end of April.

title: TOUCHE TOLD TO GIVE S. E. C. ITS PEAT DATA
description: Touche Ross & Company, the big national accounting firm, was yesterday ordered by a Federal court here to turn over working papers to the Securities and Exchange Commission about its professional review of Peat, Marwick Mitchell & Co., the nation's biggest accounting firm.

title: West Point Found Deficient in Study
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The Army sharply criticized West Point's academic and training programs today and said that the 175yearold military academy suffered from a slackening of the pursuit of excellence.

title: SECOND MAN INDICTED IN INQUIRY ON KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27A Federal grand jury here today indicted a naturalized United States citizen, Hancho C. Kim, on two felony charges stemming from an alleged influencebuying effort by the Korean Government.

title: Trial in Three Killings Put Off
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Sept. 27 (UPI)Patrick Wayne Kearney. a homosexual charged with the slayings of three young men alleged to be victims of the trashhag killier, who mutilated victims and scattered their remains along highways. has won delay in the start of his murder trial. Mr. Kearney, 37 years old, scheduled to go on trial next week for three of the killings, won a d elay yesterday in his trial until Jan. 23 because his attorney said he needed more time to prepare his case.

title: TAX PLAN EXPECTED TO HALVE DEDUCTION ON BUSINESS MEALS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27A proposal to limit tax deductions for business meals to onehalf the tab is virtually certain to be part of President Carter's taxrevision package, Administration sources say.

title: Jays Lose, 65, 51
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP)Luis Tiant pitched seven scoreless innings as the Boston Red Sox defeated Toronto, 51, tonight, completing a sweep of'a doubleheader and keeping alive their pennant hopes in the American League East.

title: Film: 'Short Eyes' Eloquently Adapted
description: "SHORT EYES," Miguel Piero's screen adaptation of his stage play, is so tightly and effectively constructed within its small enclosed landscape that not until it's over does one realize that this prison melodrama reaches well beyond the walls of the Manhattan Men's House of Detention, where it's set."Short Eyes" has the natural eloquence and wisdom that one is supposed to find in street peoplebut seldom does. Without seeming to try, without straining, the movie is less a story of prison life than it is the story of a segment of modern American urban society that's on the bottom but refuses to recognize the fact, if only because there are shadowy figures even further down the scale of values.The film will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 9:30 and repeated there tomorrow evening at 6:15. It will begin its regular commercial engagements Friday at the Sutton and Paramount Theaters."Short Eyes" has had a long and fascinating history, having begun life as a workshop production staged by Marvin Felix Camillo and the Family, the resident company at the Theater of Riverside Church, where Mr. Piero was a playwright in residence. It was subsequently picked up by Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, and presented at the Anspacher/Public Theater, from which it was moved to the Vivian Beaumont Theater in May 1974. Along the way it won two Obies and the New York Drama Critics' Award as the best play of 1973-74.Its theatrical origins are quite apparent in this furious but controlled screen version directed by Robert M. Young, who made a number of award-winning television documentaries in the 60's. He also collaborated, with Michael Roemer, on the fine feature film, "Nothing but a Man," shown at the Film Festival in 1964.In this case, though, the theatrical origins contribute to the claustrophobic atmosphere that is essential to the point of "Short Eyes," which is about a kind of overcrowding that is the physical equivalent to emotional desperation. There's no way out. As lines of dialogue overlap in that supercharged way of a theatrical production, so do Mr. Piero's characters fight for space in the single cellblock where all the action takes place.The blacks have staked out one section, the Puerto Ricans another and the white minority still another. The one person who has no territory is the new man, a nice-looking, mild-mannered, WASPy fellow named Clark Davis (Bruce Davison), who, once the word gets out that he is a "short-eyes"prison jargon for child molesteris subjected to the systematized torture that gives shape to the story.Although there are only four members of the stage production in the film, the acting has the balance and the ferocity to be found in a group of actors who have been playing withand againstone another for years. This is ensemble playing of the first rank.Among those you'll remember are Jose Perez as the father-confessor figure among Puerto Rican prisoners, a man who tries unsuccessfuly to maintain some order in the ranks; Don Blakely as an angry black nationalist who, when the chips are down, is unable to commit a race murder; Shawn Elliott as a Puerto Rican prisoner whose viciousness has both grace and charm to it; Tito Goya as the "kid" who is the object of apparently unwanted attentions, and Joseph Carberry as the leader of the white prisoners, who initially befriends "Short Eyes" and then becomes his most relentless judge.Curtis Mayfield, the singer and composer, makes a brief, very effective appearance as an older prisoner who wears "granny" glasses and believes there should be some decency even among people fighting to hang on to the bottom rung of the ladder. If Mr. Davison stands outwhich he doesit's not only because of his position within the film as the victim of the victims, but also because he gives a performance so intimate it's almost painful to watch.There is something of this quality about the entire film. "Short Eyes" is cough and depressing but it's also remarkably effective film making, which relieves the gloom at bit.

title: Panel Is Appointed By Beame to Find A Convention Site
description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed a sevenmember committee of prominent businessmen, civic and labor leaders to report back in 30 days their recommendation for a site for the new convention center.

title: Water Contamination Inquiry On
description: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Sept. 27 (AP)Officials say they are concentrating their investigation into last week's contamination of a main water plant in this suburban Miami city on area industrial parks. We believe a break in a gas line or another source of industrial waste was the cause, said Colin Morrissey, director of Dade County's Environmental Resources Agency.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TAVERN OFF THE GREEN Fraunces Tavern was built in 1719, but it takes its name from its West Indian owner, Samuel Fraunces, who bought the building and opened it as the Queen's Head Tavern in 1762. As many know, George Washington bade farewell there to his officers in 1783. The Sons of the Revolution restored the building in 1907 and now it functions as a restaurant and a museum.

title: Rangers Display Many New Faces
description: Rod Gilbert was absent last night from the New York Rangers battle with the Philadelphia Flyers. But the fans did not have a chance to make known their opinions of the now acrimonious dispute that has Gilbert asking to be traded. The Rangers had made a quick callback of the program insert and deleted Gilbert's name from the lineup so that the announcer would not have to direct spectators, Scratch from your lineup No. 7 Rod Gilbert

title: Oh Hits 46th Home Run
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27 (UPI)  Sadaharu Oh hit his 46th home run of the season to lead the Yomiuri Giants to a 103 victory over the Hiroshima Carp in a Central League professional baseball game today. Earlier this season, Oh hit the 756th home run of his career to surpass Hank Aaron's total of 755.

title: Helping the Arms Talks

description: KUALALUMPUR, Malaysia (Reuters)Copper bangles worn by people who believe in the metal's power to cure rheumatism can attract lightning, a Health Ministry bulletin warned here.

title: Harold L. Schine, 59, Businessman And Civic Leader in Bridgeport
description: Harold L. Schine, a business and civic leader for many years in Bridgeport, Conn., died Monday night at GraceNew Haven Hospital after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 27 Darbrook Road in Westport.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The outline of a compromise that would break threemonth deadlock between the House and Senate on abortions funded by Medicaid emerged today after the House voted, 252 to 164, to affirm support of a ban on such abortions except when the mother's life was endangered.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The Carter Administration does not have an authentic, reflexive, let'sdoitforaDemocraticPresident, leadercumcheerleader in the Senate. It does not have a Tip O'Neill.

title: Q&A
description: Q At some point, you mentioned a source for real charcoal in Manhattan. To my dismay, I have misplaced the clipping which listed your source. My wife is threatening to feed me yakitori cooked over charcoal briquettes. Please, where can I get real charcoal?

title: \STRIKERS AT C. W. POST AGREE TO A NEW CONTRACT
description: MINEOLA, L, J, Sept. 27Agreement on a new threeyear contract was announced jointly this evening by the C.N. Post Center of Long Island University at Greenvale and its striking teachers.

title: Dayan Says 2 Key Palestinian Issues Are Still Hampering Peace Talks
description: Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel said yesterday that two issues dealing with the Palestinians remained unresolved and were at the center of American efforts to convene a new Middle East peace conference at Geneva by the end of the year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Stocks Plunge to a 21Month Low
description: The stock market resumed its losing ways yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average set yet another 21month low.

title: After Supper, Dinner With Jane Austen
description: WASHINGTONThe recent report on the decline in Scholastic Aptitude Tests is part social, part intellectual history. What it implies is that there are differences in quality and usefulness between ideas; how we recognize and interpret those differences has good deal to do with our future.

title: Regional Dispute Over U.S. Aid Raises Fears of Split in Congress
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 27The SunbeltSnowbelt controversy has intensified in recent months to the point that it qualifies as a genuine national debate that many fear threatens to divide Congress along regional lines.

title: Eincolns Return To Spanish Fields
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 23It was from Barcelona that they left Spain. with the war against fascism they had come to fight still undecided.

title: Beame Seems Quiet and Withdrawn As He Prepares to Leave Office
description: At dinner the other night at a restaurant in Colorado Springs, the guests at Mayor Beame's table, who included Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut, were engaged in a spirited discussion of the State Legislature's role in the upcoming sale of New York City notes.

title: Administration Tightrope Act: Curbing Prices and Wages
description: A. H. Raskin

title: Beame's Plans for City to Reenter Public Securities Market  Snagged
description: Mayor Beame's plans to create a New York City security to sell publicly to investors this year, already complicated by disagreements among lawyers and financial experts over what sort of guarantees were needed to make a city note marketable, are rapidly becoming enmeshed in political considerations as well.

title: Bankers and I.M.F. Meet in a Social Whirl
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27While the string ensemble played a classical air, A. Robert Abboud, chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, shook handsperhaps 1.500 of them.

title: Ernie Lombardi, 69, a Catcher; Batted .306 in 17Year Career
description: Ernie Lombardi, the National Leagues most valuable player in 1938 and a catcher in major league baseball for 17 seasons, died Monday in a hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif., following a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Annenberg Again Changes HisMedia Center Plan,
description: Walter H: Annenberg, president of Triangle publications and former Ambassador to Britain, who last March withdraw his proposed gift of $40 million for a communications center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and then asked the University of Pennsylvania to submit a plan and budget for the center, has notified university officials of yet another plan.

title: People in Sports
description: Muhammad All submitted to Xrays of the chest, kidneys, hands and neck, and also had an electrocardiogram yesterday at the offices of the New York State Boxing Commission in lower Manhattan. The special examination was performed to eliminate doubts that All might have been hurt when he reportedly was floored twice by Jimmy Ellis in a sparring incident last week.

title: PUERTO RICAN PARADE FACES STATE ACTION
description: New York State's Board of Social Welfare started action yesterday to stop the Puerto Rican Day Parade Inc., generally regarded as the major Puerto Rican civic group in New York City, from any more fundraising because of what the board called unsatisfactory records and loans to individuals.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Battlefield of Beauty: Wounded in Action
description: My grandmother's hair was long and gray and shiny. Sometimes it had pale yellow streaks. sometimes it turned bright blue, which suited her. I loved it, and I loved her upperrighthand bureau drawer filled with tortoise shell combs, hairpins, nets, elaborate hand mirrors and heavy soft brushes.

title: TV: Surveying The 7:30 Quagmire
description: SEVERAL YEARS AGO, the Fed eral Communications Commission took away from the networks a halfhour of prime time each evening and gave it to the local stations. The noble intention was that the timebetween 7:30 and 8 in the New York areawould be used for innovative, perhaps even experimental programming that would encourage local production. But with a steady eye on the bottom line of their profit statements, the stations quickly found the acquisition of syndicated game shows and animal adventures to be infinitely more expedient.

title: Jazz: Virtuoso on Bass
description: BROWN'S GUEST HOUSE is large basement at 185 Waverly Avenue in Brooklyn. There are comfortable chairs, junkstore lam'ps, fat pillows and private nooks with red light bulbs. Though it is operating irregularly as far as live music is concernedweekends it is a private clubexpanded operations are due to begin Oct. 29. The Guest House is already winning a reputation as one of the metropolitan area's most relaxed jazz rooms.

title: Nader Going To Bat for Sports Fans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate who has hurled more than his share of brushback pitches at the heads of large corporations, announced today he was taking up the cause of another huge consumer groupthe sports fans.

title: South Africans Disperse 500 Blacks During Third Day of Disturbances
description: KINGWILLIAMSTOWN, South Africa, Sept. 27 (AP)Some 500 rioting black youths set fire to government offices and a delivery truck today on the third day of disturbances after the funeral of Stephen Biko, the black leader.

title: Where Sundays Are for Working
description: Outside the window of Joe Paterno's bluecarpeted office, a drizzling rain continues to drip onto the stone Nittany Lion that crouches in a wooded shrine on the campus of Penn State University. It's been 37 years, a returning pilgrim reminds her husband as she gives the glowering lion an affectionate pat on the head and poses for a snapshot. Presumably, the woman is referring to her apparent membership in the Class of 1940. The thought suddenly occurs that here is an alumnus who might remem ber the last time Penn State had a losing football season. It happened in 1938. But why spoil her Sundaymorning visit to the shrine? Another football Saturday has come and gone, and Paterno's people. as the coach calls his players, are still undefeated after three games.

title: Around the Nation
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 27 (UPI)The Billy Grahain Evangelistic Association said today that it had ceased to offer gift annuities in Minnesota until problems could be settled with state commerce officials.

title: Browns 2dDown Field Goal Result of Faith in Cockroft
description: The big play of many had to be the last playDon Cockroft's 35yard winning field goalin the remarkable Monday night game won by the Cleveland Browns from the New England Patriots, 3027. in the fifth minute of the overtime period.

title: French Left's Rift May Affect Reds In Italy and Spain
description: PARIS, Sept. 27Many French politicians and analysts believe that the break between the Communists and Socialists has raised questions about the independence of Communism in Western Europe and will affect domestic politics in Spain and Italy.

title: A Matter of Maneuvers
description: TRENTON, Sept. 27Governor Byrne has managed a remarkable campaign maneuver during the last few days. He has succeeded, however briefly, in making his largely unknown Republican opponent, Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville, the issue in the contest for Governor. Normally it is the incumbent who must defend his record when he stands forreelection, but Governor Byrne, in news conferences, campaign commercials and in debates, is attempting to make Senator Bateman's voting record over his 19 years in the Legislature as much a matter of current concern as the income tax and other issues identified with the Governor.

title: Ernie Lombardi,69, Dies
description: Ernie Lombardi, most valuable player in the National League in 1938 and a major league catcher for 17 seasons, died Monday at the age of 69. Page B2.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Pavan in G minor, Purcell; Overture to La finta semplice, Mozart; Jupiter from The Planets, Hoist; Pour les chasseurs from 11 Pastor Fido, Handel; Sonata for Strings No. 5, Rossini.

title: TAX PLAN EXPECTED TO HALVE DEDUCTION ON BUSINESS MEALS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27A proposal to limit tax deductions for business meals to onehalf the tab is virtually certain to be part of President Carter's taxrevision package. Administration sources say.

title: LOS ANGELES BOARD OFFERS BUSING PLAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27Faced with a Monday court deadline to enact desegregation plan, the Los Angeles Board of Education approved last night a complex program that would require busing of 55,000 pupils in the fourth through eighth grades next fall and 112,000 pupils in the same grades by the fall of 1979.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1977

title: GOODMAN ASKS DRIVE AGAINST CHILD ABUSE
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman called yesterday for a massive preventive campaign against the physical and emotional abuse of children, which he said had risen to epidemic proportions in New York City

title: NEW ENGLAND AGENCY MAPS REGIONAL PLANS
description: ROCKPORT, Me., Sept, 27The New England Regional Commission, an unorthodox and uneasy partnership between the Federal Government and the six fiercely independent New England states, agreed here today to study the commercial possibilities of selling unwanted Atlantic fish in the Far East, the ability of the region's railroads to carry increased amounts of coal and the economic effects of future exploitation of the Georges Bank natural gas fields off the coast.

title: Futures in Juice Up 3Cent Limit
description: Prices of all frozen orange juice futures through the July 1978 delivery rose the daily limit of 3 cents a pound yesterday. It was the third limit advance in as many sessions and left. the spot November delivery at a historic high of $1.29 a pound.

description: 12MONTH TREND

description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Child's World
description: AVE you ever tried to rock a baby to sleep in a crib? It's not a matter of rocking,actually. It's more a matter of pushing the bulky crib back and forth, trying to synchonize the creaking of the joints to the rhythm of a lullabye. Cradles are better.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: West Point Found Deficient by Study
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The Army sharply criticized West Point's academic and training programs today and said that the 175yearold military academy suffered from a slackening of the pursit of excellence.

title: Charter Establishes Communications Unit
description: The Charter Company, already a 56 percent owner of Downe Communications, which it hopes to own totally, has established a communications group with Fred C. Danneman, 57 years old, as president and a magazine publishing division with Carlo Vittorini, 48, as president.

title: High Tides Around New York
Carter to Be 53 Saturday
description: WASHINGINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)President Carter becomes 53 years old Saturday, and he will celebrate his birthday with his family at Camp David, Md. The President is expected to fly to the mountaintop retreat Friday afternoon and to remain until Sunday;

title: Bankers Fear U.S. Trade Deficit Will Bring Protectionist Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27A number of international bankers at the joint annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank expressed uneasiness today over the protectionist implications of the ever widening American trade deficit.

title: Baryshnikov and Bruhn, A Brilliant Evening
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER gave us two of the greatest male dancers in the history of ballet on the same program Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House when it presented Mikhail Baryshnikov in the season's first La Bayadere and Erik Bruhn in The Moor's Pavane.

title: 6MonthOld Siamese Twins Are Separated
description: MANHASSET, L.I. Sept. 28Sixanda halfmonthold Siamese twins were separated yesterday in a fivehour operation at North Shore Hospital here.

title: Angels Down Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28 (AP)Ike Hampton drove in two runs with homer and a double, leading the California Angels to a 42 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers tonight.

title: Film Festival Today
description: SOUND WAVES. 14 shorts, running from 3 to 9 minutes each, made by American and foreign animators. 3:15 at Alice Tully Hall. $2 and $1.50 by subscription.

title: Congress Nears A Final Decision On Auto Safety
description: WASHINGTON, SEPT. 28A decision on whether to require automatic crash protection in automobiles, which has been in the making for years, will become final next month, but not before a spirited argument in Congress has run its course.

title: Most Casino Operations In Atlantic City Termed Two Years From Opening
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 28Gambling casinos in Atlantic City probably will not begin operating for at least a year, and most of them will not open for two years, the new chief officer of Summa Corporation's gambling and hotel division said here today.

title: 6% Inflation, 4% Growth in 78 Forecast at Business Conference
description: Despite continued optimism by the Carter Administration, the economic outlook for next year is somber, according to economists and business leaders who addressed a 1978 Business Outlook conference at the WaldorfAstoria hotel.

title: Israel Diverts New Settlers to West Bank Army Camps
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 28The Israeli Government today blocked attempts by ultranationalists to start two unauthorized settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan but then worked out an arrangement that would allow the wouldbe settlers to move into army camps in the area.

title: Maria Rasputin Bern, Insisted She Was Child of Mad Monk
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (AP)Maria Rasputin Soloviev Bern, dancer and circus performer who contended that she was a daughter of the Mad Monk Grigori Rasputin, died Tuesday night at the age of 77, officials said today.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1977

title: Hillary of Everest Tackles the Ganges
description: HARDWAR, India, Sept. 24Sir Edmund Hillary, who was the first man to climb Mount Everest, is back in south Asia undertaking a different kind of challengea 1,500mile motorboat trip up the Ganges River.

title: 6MonthOld Siamese Twin Girls Separated in Operation on L.I.
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 28Sixanda halfmonthold Siamese twins were separated yesterday in a fivehour operation at North Shore Hospital here.

title: Dance: Rod Rodgers, New and Old
description: ROD RODGERS shows an admirable sense of continuity in designing his programs. Unlike most moderndance choreographers who display only what they have done in the last year and ignore everything else, Mr. Rodgers picks and chooses from recent and notso  recent repertory. His company presented a balanced selection of works at the Henry Street Playhouse Tuesday evening in a benefit program for the DeWitt Elementary School.

title: Slouching Toward Geneva
description: In the Middle East, the glass is either half empty or half full. We prefer to call it half fullto believe that the basis for a settlement of the conflict between Israel and the Arab nations is slowly being laid. That is how we read two recent developments.

title: Statewide Desegregation Is Proposed in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 28A statewide school desegregation plan that would mainly affect predominently white schools in several Connecticut cities where black and Hispanic students are in the majority overall in the school system was proposed today by the State Department of Education.

title: KOCH SCORES ASSIGNING OF TEACHERS BY RACE
description: Representative Edward I. Koch last night denounced the Board of Education's agreement to assign teachers to schools on the basis of race and said that if elected Mayor he would use the full resources of his office to reverse the decision.

title: CaliforniaStanford Sold Out
description: STANFORD, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI)The CaliforniaStanford Big Game scheduled for Nov. 19 at Stanford Stadium is a sellout, a Stanford spokesman said today. All 86,307 tickets have been sold. It is the earliest sellout of the 85yearold rivalry.

title: There's a New Awakening in Staten Island's LongDormant Stapleton
description: After two decades of drift and decline, Stapleton, the tired old community that hugs the northeast shore of Staten Island, is beginning to perk up.

title: Hers
description: IT WAS the kind of party where everyone knew everyone else, except no one knew me. Deciding to utilize my assertiveness training, I clenched my muscles and aimed for a tanned, mustachioed blueeyed man, whose Tshirt alligator rippled on a most beguiling ridge of muscle. We hit it off immediately, bantering, laughing, cracking entrenous jokes before we even had an entrenous.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Chicago Officials Ordered to Pay For Curb on Hare Krishna Sect
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (UPI)Two city officials have been ordered to pay $18,700 in attorney's fees because they tried to stop members of the Hare Krishna sect from passing out religious materials at O'Hare International Airport.

title: TV: Best and Worst
description: AS COVERAGE of this season's first wave of new weekly programs dribbles to completion, it is perhaps fitting that a single review deal with one of the best and one of the worst series in the fresh batch. The best, We've Got Each Other, comes out of MTM (Mary Tyler Moore) Inc. Studios, which has also unveiled The Betty White Show and Lou Grant this year. All three are of superior quality, and all three happen to be on CBS.

title: Latest Accredidation Effort Is Lost By Trenton Psychiatric Hospital
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28 (AP)Trenton Psychiatric Hospital has lost its latest effort to win accreditation by the National Joint Commission on Hospitals, officials here say.

title: PopArt Food: Taste Is No Object
description: SEX IS the alltime best seller, but this year food is a close second, said Sandi Berman, who, sells popart sex and food bricabrac In her Madison Avenue shop, Art Adventures.

title: Hughes Organization Ends Secrecy
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 28.A practice of silence among executives of Howard R. Hughes organizations was shattered today when an official of the Summa Corporation held a news conference. The event emphasized the changes that have come to his company since Mr. Hughes died 17 months ago.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY A G.I. GAVE PANAMA DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28A United States Army sergeant sold the Government of Panama transcripts of official Panamanian telephone conversations intercepted by American intelligence devices in 1975 and 1976, Defense Department officials said tonight.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1977

title: RightsCase Lawyer Tries Again
description: SEATTLEAs a student, Marco DeFunis failed to win a United States Supreme Court ruling on his discrimination suit. Now, as a lawyer, he has presented his arguments on that controversial question to the Court once again.

title: Havernization
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y.One of the things I always forget about American society when I'm away from it, so that it quickly gets forced on my consciousness when I come back, is the degree to which it's a society based upon phatic communion.

title: Diamond Block Fears Slaying Violated Industry's Honor Code
description: On the diamond block47th Street from Fifth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americasthere are burglar alarms so sophisticated that if one goes off by accident the police are sometimes denied access to the office for fear they may learn how it works.

title: Public Hospital in New York May Merge With a Voluntary Institution
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and the New York Medical CollegeFlower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals have reported a mutual determination to merge the private hospital with the Metropolitan Hospital Center, a public institution. It would be the city's first major consolidation of a voluntary hospital with a municipal institution.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: SAY THAT AFTER all these years you don't quite understand what the Doppler effect is and why it matters. If you were to look it up in the 30volume Encyclopaedia Britannica, you would find a brief definition along with references to two dozen articles in 12 other volumes. From all this you could construct for yourself a fairly complete picture of what is implied by Christian Johann Doppler's theory of wavefrequency observation, provided, of course, you had the time and energy to scramble through the various volumes, not to mention the money and space to own them. If you were to look up Doppler effect in the onevolume New Columbia Encyclopedia, you find a slightly longer definition. but that of would be all.

title: Japanese Willing To Meet Terms Of Air Hijackers
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Thursday, Sept. 29 The Japanese Government agreed early today to meet the demands of Japanese guerrillas holding 156 hostages aboard a hijacked airliner here that it free nine imprisoned comrades and pay $6 million in ransom.

title: Red Army Assails Jordan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28A communique attributed to the Japanese Red Army and distributed to reporters here today carried the demands of the hijackers as well as a virulent attack against the Japanese Government and Arab governments it said were helping it in tracking down Japanese guerrillas. Jordan was cited by name in the Englishlanguage statement.

title: Body of Diamond Broker Found As Missing Gem Cutter Turns Up
description: The body of a 25yearold diamond broker who vanished last week with up to $1 million in gems was found yesterday, his head smashed by blows with a wooden plank. The body was bound and stuffed inside a small box in the Manhattan office of a diamond cutter on West 47th Street.

title: R. D. Thomas Head Of Ladies Journal
description: Robert D. Thomas was named publisher of The Ladies Home Journal yesterday, replacing Fred C. Danneman, who was appointed president of the newly formed communications group of the Charter Company.

title: ACTIVITY FOR BUILDING GAINS 46% OVER 1976
description: The surge in building activity continued at a rapid pace in August, with contracts awarded for all kinds of construction climbing 46 percent over a year ago to $14.2 billion, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information systems Company reported.

title: GERALL A. SIVAGE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)Memorial services for Gerald A. Sivage, a director and former president of Marshall Field & Co., will be held tomorrow at the Fourth Presbyterian Church here.

title: Nursing Home Sued
description: The Department of Public Advocate charged in a civil suit that a nursing home in Monmouth County was improperly using Medicaid funds.

title: Home Beat
description: LAWRENCE PEABODY was in New York last week. Mr. Peabody, the peripatetic furniture and interior designer, doesn't come to New York too often, since he lives in Haiti in winter, New Hampshire in summer and Denmark in fall and spring. But when the General Tire and Rubber Company asked him to do sample apartment in the Galleria, the apartment house on East 57th Street, using the company's vinyl wallpaper, he said yes.

title: Japanese Willing To Meet Terms Of Air Hijackers
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Thursday,Sept. 29The Japanese Government agreed early today to meet the demands of Japanese guerrillas holding about 150 hostages aboard a hijacked airliner here that it free nine imprisoned comrades and pay $6 million in ransom.

title: Home Repair Q & A
description: Q.I have an air conditioner in the wall which I would like to take out and then close up the opening. My house has three coats of plaster on the inside walls, and shingles on the outside. What Material do I use to close the opening that will be left?S.S., Bayside. Queens.

title: Kenyon J. Scudder; Was Prison Official And Crime Expert
description: Kenyon J. Scudder, the first superintendent of the California Institution for Men in Chino, Calif., died Monday at Saddleback Hospital, Laguna Hills, Calif., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Vote Due Tonight in Fight Over Con Ed Fuel Cell
description: When Consolidated Edison said it wanted to build a fuel cell at 15th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, it expected opponentsif anyto ask how it would work.

title: LIBERALS IN BRITAIN UPHOLD LABOR PACT
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 28Britain's Liberal Party endorsed overwhelmingly today a pact with the Labor Government, making it less likely that Prime Minister James Callaghan will be forced into calling an early general election.

title: SOMALIS IN CONTROL OF ETHIOPIAN TOWN
description: JIJIGA, Ethiopia, Sept. 27  Somali forces fully control this strategically important town and a vital mountain pass nearby that cuts through the Kara Marda range into the central highlands of Ethiopia.

description: CONSTANT SHIPMENTS OF FURNITURE AND ACCESSORIES FOR EVERY ROOM OF YOUR HOUSE FOR IMMEDIATE DELIVERY

title: Alabamian Is Acquitted in Slaying Of Suspect in a Series of Deaths
description: ALEXANDER CITY; Ala., Sept. 28An Alabama truck driver was acquitted of a murder charge last night by a jury that found that he was insane at the time he shot a minister at a funeral service for the minister's foster daughter in June.

title: Metals Producers Request A U.S. Stockpile for Copper
description: Metals producers have asked the United States Government to stockpile copper to help relieve pressure on the domestic market, a trade publication reported yesterday.

title: Panel on Assassinations Allowed To Seek Immunity for Witnesses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)The House voted today, 290 to 112, to allow the committee investigating the assassinations of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to ask Federal courts to grant immunity to witnesses.

title: Topics
description: Perhaps the news shouldn't be spoken aloud, but the New York Yankees seem about to win the Eastern Division pennant of the American League. The prospect of victory arouses memories of tickertape parades, Murderers Row, and a stadium built by home runs, not taxpayers. In any case, win or lose, this is the moment to salute the Yankees for a uniform note of cheer during a summer otherwise regrettably devoid of that quality.

title: $12 Million U.S. Aid Earmarked for State
description: The United States Secretary of the Interior, Cecil D. Andrus, announced the award of more than $12 million in Federal funds for New Jersey.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Deaths
description: BARONBessie (Simon). On September 27th in Miami Beach. Devoted mother of David and Herbert Simon and Helen Schwaidelson. Beloved grandmother and treat grandmother. Funeral services Thursday, September 29th, at 2:30PM I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead.

title: Tropical Storm Bypasses Bermuda
description: MIAMI. Sept. 28 (UPI)Tropical Storm Dorothy, bypassing Bermuda, swirled its 65mileanhour winds across the open Atlantic today, heading away from land. The storm was moving toward the northeast nearly 400 miles northeast of Bermuda at between 20 and 25 miles an hour.

title: Washington & Business
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today opens a series of public hearings on its fivemonth study of public participation in corporate decisionmaking, including shareholder communication. Page D3.

title: Yonkers Racing
Gottfried and Ramirez Advance In First Round of Coast Tennis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (UPI)Topseeded Brian Gottfried disposed of Peter Pearson, 62, 61, and secondranked Raul Ramirez ousted Jeff Austin, 57, 76, 63. today in the first round of the $125,000 Transamerica tennis tournament.

title: Carter News Parley Is On at 2:30 Today
description: President Carter's news conference today, scheduled to begin at 2:30 P.M., will be televised live by the three networks and their local stations, Channel 2, 4 and 7. On radio, WCBSAM and WINS will also offer live coverage.

title: Night Filibuster Cost Estimated at $10,103
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28(UPI)The allnight filibuster that kept the Senate in session from 9 A.M. yesterday to 7:15 A.M. today cost the taxpayers $10,103 and that would pay for one helluva lot of energy, Senator Barry M. Goldwater told his colleagues tonight.

title: Jaworski Assailed With House Panel On Korea Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Representative Bruce F. Caputo, the junior member of the House ethics committee, vigorously criticized today what he called the committee's slow and unduly narrow investigation into alleged misconduct of Consressmen in the Korean scandal here.

title: A Festival of Brownstone Expertise
description: WHAT CITY brownstoners needed was something like a harvest festival, said Nat Hendricks, founder of the Brooklyn Brownstone Conference. Harvest festivals have corn husking, greased pig racing, woodsawing, macrameeverything you need to know to live in the country, he said. City brownstoners needed answers to their questions: What's 220 wiring? How high are closing costs? How do I fix plaster molding?

title: Lockheed Banks Agree to an End Of U.S. Backing
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that, as a result of its improved financial condition, it had won agreement from its lender banks to eliminate the sixyearold Federal guarantee of its major bank loans.

title: Barnes Takes the Lead In British Masters Golf
description: WORKSOP, England, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Brian Barnes of Scotland took a twostroke lead in the first round of the $70,000 British Masters golf tournament today by shooting a threeunderpar 68 in windy, cool weather.

description: PALM HARBOR, Fla.Sept. 28 (AP)Dr. Renee Richards of Newport Beach,

title: Market Place
description: The double taxation of dividends has increasingly become a bone of contention for stockholders, corporations and Wall Streeters.

title: Miles Laboratories Soars by 12 While Dow Slips 1.13 to 834.72
description: Miles Laboratories was Wall Street's star performer yesterday as the general market retreated slightly in slower trading.

title: Carey Goes to Buffalo to Combat Gloomy Reports on the Economy
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 28Fighting an onslaught of gloomy economic reports in western New York State, Governor Carey traveled to Erie County today to call attention to the expansion of a local steel foundry, to talk optimistically about tax cuts next year and to stump for the $750 million economic development bond issue on the ballot in November.

title: PORT AGENCY ACTING TO AID MASS TRANSIT BY CALLING IN BONDS
description: In an effort to free itself of restrictions on providing funds for mass transit, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has reportedly agreed to call in up to $1.1 billion of outstanding bonds, more than half its total bonded debt.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2

title: MEXICO CONSIDERING LOAN TO HELP LIMIT POPULATION GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Mexico's Finance Minister, Julio Rodolfo Moctezuma, said today that his Government was considering taking its first World Bank loan aimed exclusively at discouraging Mexico's population growth rate, now among the highest in the world.

title: Palmer Takes No.20
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 28(UPI)Rick Dempsey's twoout single in the bottom of the 11th inning scored Kiko Garcia with the winning run tonight as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Detroit Tigers, 32. Jim Palmer posted his 20th victory in a season for the seventh time in the last eight gears.

title: East Germany, in a New Booklet, Alleges Violations of Rights in U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (Reuters)East Germany, long a critic of President Carter's human rights campaign, has started another offensive through its embassy in Moscow.

title: Boston 32 Loser
description: BOSTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)The Boston Red Sox slipped to the brink of elimination in the American League East race tonight when Bob Bailor's seventhinning single scored Tim Nordbrook to give the Toronto Blue Jays a 32 victory.

title: 2 Nuclear Subs Collide
description: NEW LONDON, Conn. (AP)Two Navy nuclearattack submariesthe Archerfish and the Philadelphiacollided tern to stern at slow speeds this morning, causing minor damage to both ships, the Navy said. Both ships are stationed at the submarine base in Groton.

title: Harold Newman Memorial
description: Theater and film friends of Howard Newman, the playwright and publicity man, who died Sept. 8, will gather at Sardi's Belasco Room on Monday from 5 P.M. to 6 P.M. to honor his memory. Mr. Newman was the author of a Broadway play, Brooklyn Biarritz. Recently he had done publicity for the films Equus and Network.

title: Film: Bresson Takes Stock
description: "THE DEVIL PROBABLY" ("La Diable Probablement") is the 12th feature film by Robert Bresson, the rigorously original French film maker who was 70 years old last Sunday. This fact should be mentioned immediately because this latest Bresson is very much the work of a man taking stock, which is not to say that it's by any means sentimental or gently autumnal.Time hasn't softened the Bresson esthetic. The world he perceives still looks unlike that of any other director. Objects, people, placeseverything is seen with a clarity so fine that his images achieve something beyond realism, as if clarity so intense could distort truth, at least as we have come to accept it.The film will be shown at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 9:30 and tomorrow evening at 6:15."The Devil Probably" has the air of something out of the 1960's in that it recalls a time when dropping out was so fashionable it was virtually epidemic among the young of the bourgeoisie. But Bresson is not a film maker of fashion. Fashions rise and fall around him like tides around a continent.This film, Bresson's first to be based entirely on his own screenplay, is about a young man who, realizing that he cannot support the world as he finds it, nor hope to change it through revolution or religion, nor even to adapt to it through psychoanalysis, chooses the way of the ultimate dropoutsuicide. In telling you this, I'm not giving away a plot point because Bresson, as is his custom, refuses to allow us to watch his movies in anticipation of what's going to happen next.He reports this suicide in newspaper headlines in the opening sequence, then proceeds backwards from there as he coolly presents us with the picture of an age that, like his hero, Charles (Antoine Monnier), whose androgynous beauty is a directorial position, is systematically destroying itself, though in preposterous arrogance and innocence. Charles's choice is an intellectual statement.So, too, are all Bresson films, which may explain why they are so difficult on a first viewing and become, with repeated showings, increasingly rich and rewarding. One of the difficulties, as others have noted, is that Bresson films simply do not operate on the same senses that most other films do. There's no easy identification through primary emotions. His actors don't act. They exist to be moved around and so lighted and photographed to fit the director's line, which is simultaneously instinctive and stern, like a poet's.Two recent Bresson films that have given me more and more pleasure over the years are "Lancelot of the Lake" (1974) and "La Femme Douce" (1969), both of which I found almost impossible when I first saw them. I didn't find "The Devil Probably" at all impossible, which makes me wonder whether I'm tuning into Bresson or if "The Devil Probably" doesn't really measure up.The new film looks and sounds like a Bresson work, but it's not especially difficult. Furthermore, though no one comes close to smiling within the film, there are times when it's almost funny. At one point Charles and a friend, riding on a bus, argue about the responsibility for the world's dreadful state, involving suddenly the other passengers and finally the bus driver who, when he turns around to speak, rams into something. Only Bresson would have the nerve to keep his camera on the feet of the passengers instead of showing us what then happens in the street.The pollution of the contemporary worldintellectual as well as physicalis the apparent subject of the film but a contemplation of idealized beauty is the method, which is why the looks of the actors are so important. It's no accident that the actor who plays Charles looks startlingly like Tina Irissari, the girl Charles sometimes lives with, or that they both look like Dominique Sanda, who had never acted before she made "La Femme Douce."No other director I can think of has come as close as Bresson to molding his players into what are, in effect, variations on a continuing personality, much the way a painter might.What sets apart "The Devil Probably," though, are social concerns that are sometimes expressed with irony and wit. "Isn't there a limit to doing nothing?" asks Charles's friend Michel. "Yes," says Charles, "but after that there's extraordinary pleasure."When Charles and his friends go on a picnic, ordinarily blas Parisians exclaim when they see an old man catch what one of them describes with wonder as "a live fish!" In the world that Bresson shows us in "The Devil Probably," the catching of a live fish has become not only very rare, but also a crime.

title: COMPROMISE ON GAS IS GIVEN TO SENATE IN BID TO END DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28In an effort to break a fiveday filibuster over the deregulation of natural gas prices, the Democratic leadership of the Senate tonight offered a compromise proposal that appeared to have strong chances of passage.

title: 2 ExMinisters in Burma Arrested
description: RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Two ministers recently dropped from the Burmese Government have been arrested on the orders of President Ne Win, according to reliable sources here. They said the two men, U Tun Lin, the former Minister of Transport and Communications, and U Than Sein, who was Minister of Finance and Planning, had been seen by leaders of the ruling Burma Socialist Program Party as a threat to the President's authority.

title: Judge Orders Union to End Strike Against Trans International Airlines
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Sept. 28 (Reuters)Federal District Judge Robert F. Peckham issued a permanent injunction today against a strike by flight attendants and baggage handlers involving the cargo operations of Trans International Airlines that began Sept. 10.

title: Judge Issues Warrant for Patient Who He Had Ordered Released
description: FREEHOLD, N.J.,Sept. 28 (UPI)A New Jersey judge issued a warrant yesterday for a man he had ordered released from a state mental hospital the day before.

title: Changes at Schechter
description: Fifteen years ago Schechter & Luth, a design firm, was formed by a couple of chaps out of Lippincott & Margulies. Now that entity is splitting and multiplying as Philip J. Luth and Alvin Katz leave to set up Luth & Katz. Schechter & Luth, having lost Luth, becomes the Schechter Group.

title: Dropout Destroyed
description: THE DEVIL PROBABLY (Le Diable Probablement), directed by Robert Bresson: screenplay (French with English subtitles) by Mr. Bresson; executive producer, Stephan Tcholgadileff; director of photoggraphy, Dasoualino de Santis; editor, Germaine Lamy; music, Philippe Sarde; a Production of Sonchild/Gaumont Films. Running time: 95 minutes. At the New York Film Festival, Lincoin Center.

title: Notes on People
description: Surrounded by dozens of Americans of Italian descent as he proclaimed Oct. 10 Columbus Day, in White House Rose Garden ceremonies yesterday, President Carter had some rosy things to say about Italian accomplishments. He mentioned Italian contributions to art, science, music, medicine and politics. Then speaking of Italian influences on government, Mr. Carter noted the presence of Federal District Judge John J. Sirica and Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. Referring to their part in the Watergate affair, Mr. Carter said, In a moment of greatest challenge to our Government, they extracted from their background a wisdom and courage that preserved our way of life.

title: Tito Aide Visiting Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Edvard Kardelj, one of the closest aides of President Tito of Yugoslavia. arrived here today at the start of a sevenday visit. He is to meet with President Carter and Vice President Mondale. Mr. Kardelj, who is a possible successor to President Tito. was met at Andrews Air Force Base by Warren Christopher, Deputy Secretary or State.

title: 25 Black Americans Stage SitIn Over Their Treatment by Israel
description: Twentyfive black Americans who said they went to israel as tourists and were briefly Jailed and then expelled staged a sitin yesterday at Kennedy International Airport to protest the way they were treated.

title: An Outspoken Senate Outsider
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  James George Abourezk is nobody's idea of the typical United States senator. His clothes are often rumpled. He prefers beer busts to champagne soirees. Just about everybody calls him Jim.

title: French Socialists and Communists Issue Rival Appeals to the Voters
description: PARIS, Sept. 28Leaders of the Socialist and Communist parties, each contending that their broken political alliance could be mended, issued rival appeals to French voters today in what appeared to be the start of separate campaigns for the parliamentary elections of next spring.

title: EMPRISE CORP, LOSES PLEA FOR U.S. PARDON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The White House has rejected a request by the Emprise Corporation, the Buffalo based sports and concessions conglomerate, for a Presidential pardon from a 1972 felony conviction, spokesmen for the Justice Department and the company said today.

title: Republic Steel Expansion
description: The Republic Steel Corporation has received approval of the Environmental Protection Agency to build a group of coke ovens at a cost of $47 million. The company said that the project. which will start immediately, involved building 85 ovens with a capacity to process 1,500 tons of coke a day. The work will be done at Warren, Ohio, where the new ovens will replace older ones.

description: The term safety play is used by bridge writers to cover two groups of card combinations that are subtly different. The true safety play is something like this:

title: Cauthen Rides Both Winners Of Split Stakes
description: Using different tactics with a favorite and a long shot, Steve Cauthen rode both winners of the divided Manhattan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Foster, Rose, Bench Sparkle
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 28 (UPI)Johnny Bench hit a grandslam home run, George Foster belted his 52d homer of the season and Pete Rose picked up two singles to reach the 200hit total for a record.tying ninth time in his career tonight as the Cincinnati Reds romped to an 80 victory over San Diego behind the fivehit pitching of Paul Moskau.

title: Gas Control Filibuster: Talk of the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  With dazed senators dozing in the cloakrooms, tempers fraying on the floor, and a seemingly endless string of parliamentary delaying tactics being unwound, the Senate worked into the night again today after its first allnight session since 1964.

title: Reporters Unit Asks Judge to Rule Kissinger in Violation  on Records
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)The Reporters Committee for a Free Press asked a Federal district judge today to declare that former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger violated the Federal records act by removing transcripts of his phone conversations from official files.

title: Americans and Israel
description: Sympathetic public opinion in America has always been vital to Israel, and never more so than in her diplomatic nearisolation these days. The sympathy is natural: It is right that Amercans should care about a. country of shared ideals and so compelling a history. But the support should reflect not only human feelings but a realistic sense of Israel's longterm interests.

title: EMPRISE CORP. LOSES PLEA FOR U.S. PARDON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2SThe White House has rejected a request by the Emprise Corporation, the Buffalobased sports and concessions conglomerate, for a Presidential pardon from a 1972 felony conviction, spokesmen for the Justice Department and the company said today.

title: United Technologies Loses $15 Million Suit
description: A Superior Court jury in Los Angeles has awarded $15 million in damages to Albert Bodine, an Inventor, in a F,I;+ originally brought against the former United Aircraft Companynow United Technologies Inc.in 1962. Mr. Bodine's suit charged the Connecticut company with allegedly stealing his idea for a submarine detector. A jury awarded him $13.5 million in damages in 1968 but a judge later vacated the verdict as excessive and ordered a new trial. The new trial, after years of appeals, started last June 12.

title: Chile's Junta Seems Torn Between Rigidity and Restraint
description: SANTIAGO, ChileFour years of milltary rule have restored Chile's shattered economy to moderate health, but social and political tensions remain.

title: Phillies  Are Greeted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (UPI)The The Philadelphia Phillies, National League Eastern Division champions for the second straight year, were greeted by more than 500 fans tonight upon their arrival from Chicago at International Airport.

title: Demolition, Derby
description: GRAND THEFT AUTO, directed by Ron Howard Produced by Jon Davison; executive producer Roger Carman; written by Rance and Ron Howard director of photography, Gary Graver; stunt coordinator, Victor Rivers. A New World Pictures release. At the Harris 42d Street, Loews 83d Street and RKO 86th Street theaters. Running time; 85 minutes. This movie has been rated PG.

title: PANEL TO MAP PLANS TO CLEAN UP WATER
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28Amid increasing resistance from industry, a special committee representing government, business and environmental groups will meet tomorrow to try to agree on how to begin cleaning up'New Jersey's water.

title: New Magazine in Works at Conde Nast
description: Conde Nast Publications, which publishes five magazines for women, has announced plans for another. To be called Self, it will be the company's first major monthly magazine in 39 years.

title: Aid Plans Are Regarded as Potentially Hurtful to American Industry
description: PARIS, Sept. 28The Carter Administration is expected to warn European governments tomorrow that their plans to assist their crisistorn steel industries would severely damage America's own beleaguered steel producers.

title: Great Western Extension
description: The Great Western United Corporaton, pursuing its takeover battle for control of the Sunshine Mining Company, last night extended its tender offer, due to expire today, until Oct. 5. Great Western, which is offering $14.75 a share for 1.25 million shares, said payment would be delayedand was subject toa ruling by a Federal District Court in Boise, Idaho, on efforts by Sunshine to block the offer.

title: SOMALIS IN CONTROL OF ETHIOPIAN TOWN
description: JIJIGA, Ethiopia, Sept. 27  Somali forces fully control this strategically important town and a vital mountain pass nearby that cuts through the Kara Marda range into the central highlands of Ethiopia.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: At Governor Byrne's request, the Public Utilities Commission yesterday placed a temporary freeze on increases in the fueladjustment charges that are passed along by utilities for the rising cost of raw fuel. The board also scheduled a hearing for Oct. 23 to gather evidence before permitting a new cycle of adjusted charges.

title: On the Block: A Big Collection
description: WHAT did Elizabeth I, J. Pierpont Morgan and Greta Heckett have in common? They shared a passion for miniature portraits, and each assembled memorable collections.

title: G.W.HINMAN JR. DIES; EXHEARST OFFICER
description: George W. Hinman Jr., a retired Army colonel and a former foreign correspondent and news executive for the Hearst newspaper chain, died on Sept. 22 at the Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington. He was 85 years old.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: WILKIE HILL BRERETON
description: Rear Adm. Wilkie Hill Brereton, United States Navy, retired, of Bridgport Conn., and PortauPrince, Haiti, died Sept. 18 in Bethesda (Md.) Medical Center after a short illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Battering of Women Held Most Unreported Crime
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28Quoting a report by the Federal Bureau of investigation that battered wives represent the country's most underreported crime, Paula Webster of the Northeastern Regional Office of the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that such assaults were made at least three times more often than rape, which is estimated to occur every 12 minutes in the nation.

title: DOROTHY BRETT
description: Dorothy Brett, an artist in Taos, N.M and the last livin member of the circle around the novelist D.H. Lawrence, about whom she wrote Lawrence and Brett: A Friendship (1933), died there on Aug. 27. She was 94 years old.

title: 4 Tully Hall Concerts To Be on WNCNFM
description: Four Sunday afternoon programs of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center wIl be broadcast live on WNCNFM from Alice Tully Hall this fall. The dates are Oct. 16, 23 and 30 and Nov. 20

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: All 1,200 scheduled classes resumed Yesterday at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island Uniiversity in Greenvale, L.I. The return to normal for 14,000 students followed agreement Tuesday on a threeyear contract between the college and its union faculty members, ending a 15day strike.

title: Gold Soars as Dollar Slips Abroad
description: Gold was at its highest London closing price in more than two years yesterday, and the Swiss franc resumed its upward move against the dollar in foreign exchange trading, The Associated Press reported.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEW HAVEN IN THE whole realm of spectator events, I have never found one so slow and ponderous, so lacking in the usual graces of sport and entertainment, as cattle drawing at a Connecticut country fair. Teams of oxen compete to see which can pull the heaviest load of cement blocks for six feet without stopping. The loads keep getting heavier and may eventually weigh five tons. It is not, in short, actionpacked.

title: Koreans Bank Ties Allegedly Concealed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the Diplomat National Bank, which has figured prominently in the South Korean influencebuying scandal, of violating Federal securities laws by concealing the bank's true owners.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: EBuskey 2, Gross. DPPhiladelphia 3, Chicago 3 .LOBPhiladelphia 10, Chicago 8. 2BGross, Schmidt. SBDeJesus, FAndrews, McCarver. 5Gordon. SFFAndrews.

title: RHODESIA PROPOSES TALKS ON PEACE PLAN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 28 (AP)Rhodesia announced today that it had invited the United Nations and Britain to send representatives to Salisbury to discuss key points of the latest BritishAmerican peace proposals.

title: Honeywell Prices to Rise
description: Honeywell Inc.'s computer facility, Honeywell information Systems, announced maintenance and other prices on a variety of computer equipment. The company saki it would raise maintenance prices 6 percent to 15 percent and softwear license fees an average of 5 percent on most systems. Monthly rental prices will be increased by 2 percent to 7 percent and purchase prices by 7 percent on selected computer equipment. International Business Machines, earlier this week, also announced a series of price adjustments on equipment and maintenance fees.

title: HOUSENARROWLY APPROVES INCREASE IN DEBT CEILING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) In its second try, the House narrowly approved an increase in the national debt ceiling today just two days before the present ceiling was to expire.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1

title: Sound
description: IF YOU'D LIKE to bask in the warm glow of exaggerated esteem (your own included), try building one of your stereo components from a kit. It takes no special skills to speak of but everyone who sees your handiworkvisually indistinguishable from factorybuilt equipmentwill assume it does. And so, after a period of blushing modesty, will you.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON  Gentlemen: Your arrogance and powermadness is evidenced in this release, the writer concludes in a singlepage, handscrawled note.

title: U.S. Decrees Youngstown Steelworkers Can Get Special Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28(AP) The Labor Department today certified nearly 5,000 Youngstown, Ohio, steelworkers as eligible for special Federal assistance on the ground that import competition was an important factor in the elimination of their lobs.

title: Knicks Reward Coach Reed With a Victorious Debut
description: As Willis Reed walked into Madison Square Garden last night, one of the special policemen said, Hope you do better than the Rangers did.

title: TwoYear Study of Hudson River Finds Toxic and CancerCausing Chemicals That Threaten 150,000 Upstate
description: A twoyear study by environmental and consumer groups has concluded that the Hudson River is contaminated by a complex spectrum of toxic and cancercausing chemicals that pose a threat to 150,000 people upstate who drink the river's water.

title: People and Business
description: Robert E. Lauterbach, chairman of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation. said yesterday that he would hand over the post of chief executive officer to Dennis J. Carney, the company's president.

title: Moorer Criticizes Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)The Panama Canal could fall under the influence of the Soviet Union if the Senate approves a treaty relinquishing control to Panama, Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, retired, a former. chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the House International Relations Committee today.

title: A Switch to Beer
description: Robert A. Rechholz, a wellknown figure in advertiser circles, is switching his professional interest from cigarettes to beer. He has resigned his position as vice presidentmarketing of the Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company. to take the job of vice president, marketing planning and development of the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company.

title: NEW &USEFUL
description: Among the antique Chinese porcelains that have been put on sale in Altman's fourth floor gift shop, there are some delightful items for well under $100 (little blue and white ink pots are $12 each). And if you want to go as high as $200, the choice widens considerably. Most pieces in the collection date from the 1860's and 70's and include vases, ginger jars, urns, plates, bowls, teapots and figurines. The decorations are charming, from vignettes of roosters and flowers ai ound the outside of a small bowl to a merry parade of men carrying banners, which trails its pageant across a slender white vase. But no matter what the pattern, everything combines the painstaking detail and economy of line that are so typically Chinese.

title: Going Out Guide
description: EASTERN STARS The usual moviegoer in India subsists on a cinematic fare of what has been described a flashy and colorful popular entertainments, usually musicals and adventure stories. Now, young Indian directors are making different films, often more realistic and niore controversial.

title: LEADING CAMBODIAN    IN A VISIT TO PEAKING
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 28Pol Pot,a shadowy figure who now appears to be Cambodia's highest ranking leader, arrived in Peking today for his first known visit abroad since the end of the Indochina war two years ago.

title: House Clashes Over Neutron Bomb; Vote Set Today on Fund Deletion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 28A debate over the issue of the socalled neutron bomb ended abruptly tonight, with supporters and opponents angrily clashing over funds for the weapon.

title: Sex Segregation Banned in 2d Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, sept. 28 (UPI)Schools segregated by sex in suburban Jefferson Parish are illegal and the officials must immediately begin considering an alternative educational system, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Plywood Company Pays Safety Fine
description: ANDERSON, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI)The United States Plywood Company pleaded no contest yesterday to one count of violating California health and safety codes in a 1976 explosion and fire at a Shasta County particle board plant that killed seven persons and injured five others. The company paid a $6,250 fine. The fatal explosion occurred when an excessive accumulation of sawdust exploded and touched off a fire that destroyed the $25 million plant, the officials said.

title: Carrell,Marvaso Dropped by Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 28Two Jets who committed errors in the first two games were dropped suddenly today by Coach Walt Michaels and replaced immediately.

title: RALEIGH GIBSON DOUGHERTY
description: Raleigh Gibson Dougherty, president and chief executive officer of the New York Technical Institute and Affiliates, died Monday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J., after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J., and Honolulu.

title: BERGLAND SEES AIDE WHO SOUGHT FAVORS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland met today with Robert H. Meyer, an Assistant Secretary who owns large tracts of land in California's Imperial Valley, to discuss Mr. Meyer's efforts to obtain special treatment for his area's Federal water rights.

title: Backgammon:
description: Awarness of which numbers are good for your opponent is crucial. For example, when you leave a man exposed, you should, of course, be aware of which numbers will hit. This does not mean. however, that you sliould mechanically minimize the chances of being hit; rather, you should minimize the total of all your opponent's favorable rolls. In the diagrammed position, X has just been hit and now has a 21 to play. He must reenter from the bar with the 2, then decide how to play the 1. One obvious consideration is to avoid having O hit his other exposed man, the blot now on the 14point. X cannot safety this blot; he must leave a direct shot (a shot 6 or less points away). The slightly safer play is 14/13, moving closer to O. (When leaving a direct shot, the closer you are, the less likely you are to be hit.)

title: How Escrow Would Help
The Standings
description: Thursday, September 29, 1977

title: Mayor's Primary Victory In Election in New Haven Is Reaffirmed in Recount
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28Mayor Frank Logue's primary victory was reaffirmed today in a recount of all votes in the Sept. 15 Democratic primary election. However, the recount, ordered yesterday by Judge Harold M. Missal, narrowed Mr. Logue's margin of victory from 339 votes to 243.

title: Macha Helps Pirates Top Mets, 32
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 (UPI)Ken Macha atoned for a firstinning error by singling home Al Oliver with the tiebreaking run in the sixth inning tonight, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 32 victory over the New York Mets.

title: The Needy Get Iciness
description: On May 24, 1976, John Smith (a fictitious name) went to a Department of Social Services center in New York City to apply for public assistance. He had stopped working to enter a hospital for surgery, and was applying because his wife and four children would be without financial resources.

title: Calendar of Events for the Home
description: A tour of 12 artists studios in Greenwich Village, for the benefit of the Guild Hall museum in East Hampton, L.I., will be held Wednesday afternoon.

title: Belmont Racing
description: By The Associated Press

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, Sept. 28 (Reuters)American and Soviet delegations resumed work today on a new treaty to limit strategic arms following an unexpected meeting in Washington last night between President Carter and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: Experts Think the Legion Disease Is Wider Problem Than Expected
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 28Recent events and the results of investigations conducted over the last year indicate that the type of pneumonia called the legionnaires disease is a far broader problem than seemed a year ago after an outbreak inPhiladephia in which most of the patients had attended an American Legion convention there.

title: Carew Gets Hit No. 232
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 28 (UPI)Richie Zisk hit his 30th home run and doubled home another run today to help the Chicago White Sox to a 43 victory over Minnesota as the Twins Rod Carew became the first major leaguer in 40 years to get 232 hits in a season.

title: DISTILLATE OIL STOCKS UP 6 MILLION BARRELS IN WEEK
description: Stocks of distillate oil, used mainly for home heating purposes, rose significantly in the week ended Sept. 23, according to the latest weekly supply statistics released by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies of distillate oil were up 6.1 million barrels to 241.8 million barrels from the preceding week.

title: S.B.A. Plans to Help Minorities In Buying Radio and TV Stations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The Small Business Administration will soon propose a change in its regulations to make it easier for women and members of minorities to obtain Government loans to buy radio and television stations, the Federal agency said today.

title: Lance Departure: A Mondale Gain as Carter Confidant
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 28The departure of Bert Lance from the Carter Administration seems more likely to add to the influence and Importance of Vice President Mondale than any other Administation official.

title: General Signal Acquisition
description: The General Signal Corporation, maker of controls, said in Stamford, Conn., that its acquisition of Sola Basic Industries would be completed tomorrow. Shareholders of the electrical equipment company will receive seventenths of a General Signal share for each Sola share, or slightly more than four million shares, valued at about $100 million,

title: Personal Beauty
description: FOR women who wear glasses and are still baffled about choosing either glasses or eye makeup, or how to combine the two, Meyrowitz opticians have asked Trish McEvoy, a makeup artist, to pass on some eyeopening tricks. First, choosing the frames. Many women tend to wear frames that are too small, making their eyes look crowded. Eyeglass frames are like picture framesif the eyes are to look important, there should be room between the eyes and the frames.

title: GARDENING
description: ARE you looking for a small investment that will pay large dividends in six months? Then plant some hardy bulbs on the penthouseand there won't even be a capital gains tax.
