title: Skeletons of a Man and a Woman Found in Luxury Car in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)The skeletons of a man and a woman, both wearing winter clothing, were found today in a luxury car parked in a garage on the South Side, the police said.

title: French Premier in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (UPI)Prime Minister Raymond Barre arrived in Moscow today for a fiveday visit aimed at strengthening FrenchSoviet relations irrespective of internal political upheavals in France. He was met at the airport by Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: Body of Diamond Broker Found As Missing Gem Cutter Turns Up
description: The body of a 25yearold diamond broker who vanished last week with up to $1 million in gems was found yesterday, his head smashed by blows with a wooden plank. The body was bound and stuffed inside a small box in the Manhattan office of a diamond cutter on West 47th Street.

title: Dance: Alicia Alonso In Ambassador Role
description: IN CUBA, there are postage stamps showing Alicia Alonso in Giselle, the ballet the Cuban ballerina will dance tonight with American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. There are still no dancers on United States stamps, she is told during her current visit to New York. A pity, she murmurs, and adds, You have good enough dancers to have stamps.

title: Series Tickets on Sale
description: With the Yankees drawing closer to cliching a spot in the playoffs, the club's ticket office has announced it is accepting orders for the four World Series games scheduled in the American League city.

title: Carter Energy Plan Would Pollute Less, U.S. Study Asserts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)Air pollution will get worse over the next 20 years but not because of the increased use of coal proposed in President Carter's energy plan, according to a report issued yesterday by the Energy Research and Development Administration.

title: Plan for Rejuvenation Of Paterson Initiated
description: An $11.1 million economic and cultural revitalization of Paterson has opened in a national experiment to save the old, industrial cities.

title: Senate Told Some School Lunches In New York Are Low in Nutrition
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 28The quantity and quality of food served to 170,000 New York City schoolchildren do not meet Federal requirements, according to testimony today before the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition.

title: Shapp Firm on Ouster of Official In Use of State Aides for Profit
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 28Gov. Milton J. Shapp refused today to rescind his dismissal last week of C. DeLores Tucker as Commonwealth Secretary, a post that had made her the highestranking black woman in state government in the country.

title: Soybean and Corn Futures Rise, Spurred by Prospect of Rain in Midwest
description: Soybean and corn futures rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, spurred in part by the expectation of rain in some of the Middle West harvest areas.

title: Creamer Gets Channel 4
description: Creamer/FSR, which has had a hot streak since George Lois joined the management team, announced yesterday its appointment as agency for WNBCTV (Channel 4). Billings are expected to exceed $1 million. In recent years the station hasn't had a fullservice agency.

title: Kingman's Contract Talks
description: Gabe Paul, Yankee president, met for much of the day and evening with Lowell Morse, financial adviser for Dave Kingman. They planned to meet again today in their efforts to agree on a multiyear contract for Kingman.

title: A House Rewards Affection
description: I FIND that I have to remind myself that New York is the center of the universe after several weeks in a New England town. It is not just that one is seduced by the insidious idea that small is beautiful, or that one builds up a false ideal of smalltown virtues that may be largely in the mind, or that one confuses the reality of work with the unreality of vacationit is that the living is easy. That means that compared to life in New York, every minute of the day isn't a hassle. Compared to life in New York, every encounter isn't a joust with survival.

title: Genesco to Propose A Recapitalization
description: Genesco Inc., which had a net loss of $135.7 million in its fiscal year ended July 31, said it would propose a recapitalization plan to convert all outstanding shares of its 11 classes and series of preferred stock, as well as related dividend arrearages, into common shares.

title: Syria and Jordan Tell Carter They Agree to Plan for Unified Arab Delegation at Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Syria and Jordan informed President Carter today that they accepted the American proposal for having a unified Arab delegation, including Palestinians, meet with Israel at the opening of a Middle East peace conference.

title: School Aide Dies in Rescue Attempt
description: SALINA, Kan., Sept. 28 (AP)The bandmaster at St. John's Military School died after running into a flaming building three times looking for a cadet who had already made his way to safety, school officials said. The victim of yesterday's fire was identified as the school's sergeant major, Eugene Lewis, 47 years old, who collapsed, apparently from smoke mhalation.

title: Yankees Rout Indians, 100; Clinch Tie for Division Title
description: The fivefoothigh yellow numbers on the scoreboard clock said 10:00 last night when the Yankees learned they were only six outs away from assuring themselves of at least a tie for their second straight division title.

title: Italian Exxon Official Resists S.E.C. Decree
description: ROME, Sept. 28 (AP)The former president of the Exxon Corporation's Italian affiliate said today that he would refuse to sign a consent decree sought by United States authorities as a result of bribery allegations.

title: UTAH'S POLICE PRESS SEARCH IN A SLAYING
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 28Exceptional security measures are expected Saturday and Sunday when Mormons by the thousands stream into the Salt Lake Temple grounds for the 147th annual Conference of the Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saints.

title: COMPROMISE ON GAS IS GIVEN TO SENATE IN BID TO END DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28In an effort to break a fiveday filibuster over the deregulation of natural gas prices, the Democratic leadership of the Senate offered a compromise proposal tonight that appeared to have a strong chance of passage.

title: Where to Get Help
description: Cornell University, in cooperation with the Horticultural Society of New York, sponsors a Plant Line where city gardeners can call for garden help. The phone number is 7570915 and Tuesday through Saturday, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., two professional horticulturists answer queries on garden problems. Or, sick plants and specific problems can be taken directly to the Horticultural Society's offices at 128 West 58th Street.

title: About New York
description: Twentyfourtrack sound, driven and redriven through the night, is an awesome event, particularly when not a bit of it leaks down onto Broadway. But it is contained by the finest wood and glass enclosure as rock musicians toil away in a recording studio like farmers in a terrarium.

title: Ali's Bravado Is Back for Fight Tonight
description: Satisfied that the public had bought his original scare script, Muhammad Ali turned bold yesterday at the weighin for his heavyweight title defense against Earnie Shavers tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Peking Is Reported to Execute Man Who Stabbed a New Yorker
description: PEKING, Sept. 28 (Agence France Presse)A Chinese man who stabbed a New York businessman, Richard Talmadge, in Peking 10 days ago has been executed, a wellinformed diplomatic source said today.

title: Judge Bids Interior Department Not Do What It Doesn't Plan to Do
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27Several aides of Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus find themselves in the ambiguous position of having won a lawsuit that enjoins steps they do not intend to take

title: People in Sports
description: I know it sounds strange after saying I had hung it up, but I got a call from Red Auerbach [Boston Celtics general manager] the next day and he wanted to talk to me right away, said Dave Bing, the 11year player announcing his comeback to pro basketball yesterday after an announced retirement that lasted about 48 hours. He [Auerbach] made me an offer I couldn't refuse.

title: How to Get There
description: Brooklyn Union Gas, site of the Brooklyn Brownstone Fair, is at 195 Montague Street, between Court and Clinton Streets, and is easy to reach by subway or by car.

title: MOSHE INDELMANYINNON, LEADING HEBREW EDITOR
description: Moshe IndelmanYinnon, former editor of The Hadoar, the Hebrew weekly published in New York, died Saturday in Mt. Sinai Hospital, Miami, after a short ill ness. He was 82 years old.

title: DR. ARTHUR DALLOS, 84, HEARTSURGERY PIONEER
description: Dr. Arthur Dallos, a pioneer in chest surgery, died yesterday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 100 West 57th Street.

title: Goodman Warns of More Austerity In City Finances Over Next 4 Years
description: Warning that bankruptcy is still a stark possibility for New York City, State Senator Roy M. Goodman chided his fellow mayoral candidates yesterday for not leveling with the people.

title: Carey Acts to Extradite ExRCA Chairman
description: Governor Carey yesterday asked the state of Maryland to extradite Anthony L. Conrad, the former chairman of the RCA Corporation, to New York to face state incometax evasion charges.

title: Plan Gains Support at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28A majority of Security Council members supported a British proposal today to have a United Nations representative assist in obtaining a ceasefire in Rhodesia.

title: Expelled Student Wills $5 Million to Andover
description: ANDOVER. Mass., Sept. 28(AP)Phillips Academy spent about $450 for a scholarship and room and board for a poor student, Walter Scott Leeds, 73 years ago. The student, then 20 years old was expelled after only one year.

title: Screen: For Auto Fans
description: UBIQUITOUS and versatile, Ron Howard turned up yesterday at the Harris 42d Street, Loews 83d Street and RKO 86th Street theaters as star, director and screenwriter, with his father, Rance, of the latest automotive chase and crash movie, "Grand Theft Auto." Puns aside, Mr. Howard need take a back seat to no one when it comes to competence in the genre. His debut as a director of feature films may not mark him as an innovator, but neither does it suffer from comparison to its many predecessors, including "Eat My Dust," which Mr. Howard starred in last year."Grand Theft Auto" may have the usual idiots for characters and it may tax credibility well beyond the fracture point, but it isn't dull, and its vehicles are better looking than the ones in "Eat My Dust" and "Smokey and the Bandit."Nobody who has ever wanted to see a Rolls-Royce in a demolition derby is going to walk away from this movie disappointed.As for the chase itself, it involves Mr. Howard and Nancy Morgan as the runaway lovers, bound for marriage in Las Vegas against the wishes of her wealthy and politically ambitious father and against the intentions of the wealthy incompetent she was supposed to marry.Just about everybody, from parents to bounty hunters to preachers, to private detectives to mobsters to chicken farmers to a disk jockey and oh, yes, even the police, winds up in the chase, using everything from a camper, a commandeered bus and a Volkswagen Beetle to assorted sedans and helicopters.The PG rating is doubtless attributable to a bit of the languagenothing out of the ordinary, reallyand to the fact that the young lovers make it clear that they have a strong sexual attraction for each other.

title: JOE R. HOFFER
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 28 (AP)Joe R. Hoffer, former executive secretary of the National Conference on Social Welfare, died today at University Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Newport Plans Kennedy Museum
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28 (UPI)  City officials have approved creation of a John F. Kennedy museum in the main building of Hammersmith Farm, the estate where the late President courted his wife, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. The Auchincloss family recently sold the estate for $825,000 to a group of nine businessmen from Rhode Island and Massachusetts.

title: ExCell0 Earnings Rose 42.4% for 3d Fiscal Quarter
description: The ExCello Corporation, a leading producer of machine tools, packaging equipment and aerospace and electronic items, reported yesterday profit increases of 42.4 percent for the third fiscal quarter to Aug. 31 and 23 percent for the ninemonth period.

title: Mets Box Score
description: ERosado, Macha. DPMets 1, Pittsburgh 3. LOBMets 6, Pittsburgh 6. 2BNorman, Oliver. 5BRandle, Garner 2, Robinson, Ott, Taveras, Moreno. SFRosado.

title: Beirut Army Hopes To Move Into South To Regain Control
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28Lebanon's newly reorganized army hopes to move into the south near Israel in a few days to reassert Beirut's sovereignty over the battledevastated regionif a ceasefire declared Monday between Israelibacked Christian militia forces and Palestinian and Lebanese leftists proves effective.

title: U.N. Employees in Geneva Office Assail Proposal for Salary Cut
description: GENEVA, Sept. 28 (UPI)Employees at United Nations European headquarters today rejected an official finding that their salaries were too high and should be cut by 15 to 19 percent.

title: RATES OF INTEREST REMAINING STEADY
description: Investment bankers raised yields on corporate and taxexempt bonds yesterday, with varying results. The increases apparently were large enough to satisfy investors purchasing municipal bonds but not large enough for corporate bond buyers.

title: Membership of Amex Approves Plan for 150 New Options Seats
description: American Stock Exchange membership approved yesterday proposals to create up to 150 new options memberships and to allow the renting of Amex seats.

title: 3Year Undercover Operation Ends In Arrest of 29 Persons in Jersey
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28Six Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and state police detectives who worked and socialized with underworld figures for almost three years have provided law enforcement agencies with information that led today to the arrest of 29 persons, the recovery of more than $1 million in stolen goods and the opening of Federal and state grand jury investigations into New Jersey's trucking and shipping industries.

title: Carter Nominates Arms Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters)President Carter announced today that he would nominate Barry Blechman, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, to be assistant director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Mr. Blechman, a 34yearold native of New York, is head of Brookings defense analyses staff and a Pentagon consultant.

title: Japan Explains Position
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 29 (AP)Chief Cabinet Secretary Sunao Sonoda said today that the Bangladesh Government had taken responsibility for handling the direct negotiations with the hijackers of the Japanese airliner since the plane was in its territory.

title: Highly Ranked College Elevens Struggling With Injuries to Their No. 1 Quarterbacks
description: The casualty list of No. 1 quarterbacks on contending teams is getting so long that Jackie Sherrill, the Pittsburqh coach, observed yesterday: The team that ends up No. 1 will be the team that keeps its quarterback healthy and on Ms feet all season. And there aren't many of those teams left.

title: Police Explain Failure to Find Body
description: The police said yesterday that they did not find the body of the missing diamond broker late Monday when they visited the office where it was later discovered because they had not been looking for a body.

title: Complaint on Emotionalism
description: DAVIS, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP)David S. Saxon, president of the University of California, says that the controversial minority admissions program at the University of California at Davis Medical School involves not a quota but a goal and that a wave of emotionalism is clouding the situation.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)The Postal Service announced today that it would not require handwritten addresses for personal letters to qualify for the proposed 13cent citizen mail rate. The business rate is scheduled to go up to 16 cents next spring.

title: Refunds on Ralnout Tickets
description: Those fans who had tickets for last Sunday's MetsCardinals Family Day doubleheader at Shea Stadium can receive refunds at Shea from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. The two games, which were rained out, had to be rescheduled for St. Louis as parts of a twilightnight doubleheader tomorrow and an afternoon doubleheader Saturday.

title: U.S. Mediator Plans New Attempt To Avert Strike by Longshoremen
description: The Government's chief mediator planned to make a new effort today to gain a settlement of the longshoremen's contract dispute and avert an East and Gulf Coast strike toreatened at 12:01 A.M. Saturuay.

title: Ford Hints at Use of Foreign Steel
description: Lee A. Iacocca, the president of the Ford Motor Company, hinted yesterday that the nation's second largest auto maker might soon begin using foreign steel, an action that would be a severe blow to the already hardhit United States steel industry.

title: Raised Voices Greet NoiseLabeling Plan
description: WASHINGTON

title: CONNECTICUT WILL HELP WAR VETERANS FIND JOBS
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 28 (AP)State government and business leaders announced a new program today to find jobs in private industry for Connecticut's 14,500 veterans, half of whom served during the Vietnam War.

title: Service Spreads
description: Since July, when the first Flexible Loan Insurance Program mortgage was written, the service has spread into 13 states, but is only beginning to establish itself in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Diamond Block Fears Slaying Violated Industry's Honor Code
description: On the diamond block47th Street from Fifth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americasthere are burglar alarms so sophisticated that if one goes off by accident the police are sometimes denied access to the office for fear they may learn how it works.

title: TED ARMSTRONG
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 28 (AP)Ted Armstrong, a harness race horse owner whose Jade Prince captured this year's Cane Pace, died last night in Grady Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Abortion Curb Gains in Loulsville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 28 (UPI)The Louisville Board of Alderman has voted to enact an ordinance banning the use of any city money for virtually all abortions at the Louisville General Hospital. The ordinance, which passed 11 to 1, allows abortions only to save a mother's life. The measure now goes to Mayor Harvey Sloane, who has not said whether he will sign it.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Wednesday, September 28, 1977

title: New for Winter: Thermal Sheets
description: LONG underwear, flannel nightgowns, portable heaters and electric blankets aren't the only ways of keeping warm in bed this winter. For the consumer who hates the cold and has everything, there are now thermal sheets.

title: TwoWay Cable TV
description: This week in Columbus, Ohio, Warner Communications will launch a multimedia advertising campaign for Qube, its revolutionary, twoway cable television system that will allow subscribers to select any one of 30 programming events and to participate in some of them.

title: W.B.A. Picks Mandry
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 28 (AP) Fernando Mondry of Venezuela was unanimously elected president of the World Boxing Association today, succeeding Elias Cordova of Panama. Among the other officers elected was Chuck Davey of the United States, fourth vice president.

title: Disks: Mystical Drama
description: Communications being so fast today, composers in Western countries tend to follow a common, socalled international style. The result is an impersonal similarity in their music. Fortunately, there are always the mavericks. One of them, in Sweden, is Allan Pettersson, whose works are just beginning to arouse interest not only in his native land, but also in other countries. His Eighth Symphony will be given its American premiere in November by the Baltimore Symphony under Sergiu Comissiona.

title: Work, Welfare and Servitude
description: Anyone who thinks the American Presidency has become too powerfullet alone imperialshould pay careful attention to the Senate Finance Committee and its chairman, Russell Long. Just think of all the cards he holds in his hand now. an Administration aide exclaims, referring to the Louisiana Senator's current power over the Carter Administration's prize proposals: the energy package, the rescue of Social Security, tax reform and welfare reform. Quietly, and with odd haste, the committee has now exercised its power with respect to welfare reform. The result is potentially brutal. It should undone by the Senate.

title: The Real Stability
description: LONDONThe average Briton, with a per capita income about half the average West German's, and with a Government mindlessly calling for reflation despite an 18 percent inflation, can still claim the most stable political system in the world: His ship of state is sinking on an even keel.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended Aug. 31 inless otherwise indicated.(N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: PORT AGENCY ACTING TO AID MASS TRANSIT BY CALLING IN BONDS
description: In an effort to free itself of restrictions on providing funds for mass transit, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has reportedly agreed to call in up to $1.1 billion of outstanding bonds, more than half its total bonded debt.

title: West Point Reforms, Asked by Pentagon, Due in Year
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 28Officials of the United States Military Academy indicated today that many of the reforms recommended in a highly critical report issued yesterday by the Defense Department would be introduced over the next year.

title: House Rejects a Rise In Ford's Allowance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28(AP)The House defeated a move yesterday to increase former President Gerald R. Ford's Federal allowance for staff help from $96,000 to $150,000 a year.

title: Leonard Silk
description: WASHINGTON  While the immediate focus of attention at these annual meetings of world finance ministers and central bankers is almost always on the Internttional Monetary Fund, with its worries over world slumps, inflation, unemployment, mounting debts and floating currencies, the World Bank plugs away; outside the limelight, at the longrun problem of how to raise the underdeveloped countries out of poverty.

title: 300 BLACKS ARE DISPERSED BY SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 28 (UPI)Police used shotguns and riot sticks today to disperse a crowd of 300 blacks near Kingwilliamstown, which has been hit by violence since Stephen Biko, the black student leader, was buried there three days ago.

title: MOVE IN CHICAGO TO CURB TRADING BY HUNTS DENIED
description: A Federal District Court in Chicago denied yesterday a request by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that members of the oilrich Hunt family of Texas be prevented from trading in concert on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: World Wheat Decline Seen
description: ROME, Sept. 28 (UPI)  The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization predicted today the world wheat crop for 1977 would be 4 percent lower than last year but coarse grain crops better than expected. The F.A.O. said heavy rains in temperate areas of the northern hemisphere in late August and early September had caused its 1977 wheat forecast to be lowered four million tons to a total of 401 million metric tons. This is 4 percent lower than the record 1976 wheat crop, F.A.O. said.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: AllPurpose Retreat At Showcase
description: AllPurpose Retreat At Showcase

title: F.B.I. and State Police Operate Undercover 3 Years and Seize 29
description: WEST ORANGE, Sept. 28Six Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and state police detectives who worked and socialized with underworld figures for almost three years have provided law enforcement agencies with information that led today to the arrest of 29 persons, the recovery of more than $$1$ million in stol goods and the opening of Federal and state grand jury investigations into New Jersey's trucking and shipping industries.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Rev. Joseph Wiest, Pastor Emeritus Of St. Patrick's in Bay Ridge, 82
description: The Rev. Joseph P. Wiest, pastor emeritus of St. Patricrs Church in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, died last Saturday in the rectory after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Port Chester Hospital Post Filled
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 28United Hospital's board of trustees has named Dr. Leo T. Delaney, an attending surgeon, as the new chief of the hospital's division of surgery. He replaces Dr. David A. W. Wilson, who resigned from that post last month to protest alleged inactions by the hospital in resolving a dispute with physicians over nurse staffing.

title: U.S. Policy Tested in Conflict Over Whale's Survival and Eskimo Rights
description: The battle to insure the survival of endangered species of whales is reaching a crucial stage in which the once strong and heavily moralistic pro conservation position of the United States is being put to its first real test.

title: Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, Inc.
description: Frank E. Campbell

title: The September Song of Joshua Logan
description: JEALOUSY  pure, greeneyed jealousy  is driving Joshua Logan to the Rainbow Grill on the 65th floor of the RCA Building to make his New York debut as a singer Monday night.

title: SUSPECT IN BOMBING GIVES UP IN GEORGIA
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Sept. 28 (UPI)J. B. Stuner, who says he will be killed if he is sent back to Alabama to face trial, surrendered today on charges of exploding dynamite at a black Birmingham church in 1958.

title: 30% of Births in New York City Called Illegitimate
description: Nearly one of every three infants born in New York City last year was illegitimate, according to Health Department data showing the rate had skyrocketed from 6.7 percent in 1956 to 14.8 percent in 1966 and 30.2 percent in 1976.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Some of the people around him had on white Tshits with his picture on them and the words, Earnie Shavers Next Champ but Earnie Shavers was wearing a white shirt with Pony on it, the name of his equipment manufacturer. He had appeared at the weighin for tonight's fight at Madison Square Garden, weighed 211 1/4 in his red satin trunks, and departed quickly, before Muhammad Ali arrived. He had changed into his Tshirt and dungarees and put on a dark blue windbreaker and now, shortly before

title: Egypt Gives Terms for Israel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28Foreign Minister Fahmy of Egypt, speaking in the General Assembly, insisted today that to attain peace Israel would have to give a commitment to forgo atomic arms, to accept a limit on traditional weapons and to end its open door immigration policy.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions

title: Spaghetti Tennis Racquet Faces a Ban
description: Bowing to pressure from players and officials, the International Tennis Federation will ban the controversial spaghetti racquet from tournament competition, it was learned yesterday.

title: Schaefer Is Fined On Payment Charges
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company agreed to pay a $50,000 fine growing out of charges that it made illegal payments to numerous companies to promote its beer sales in New York State.

title: Seasonal Rail Rate Increase In Southeast Allowed to Stand
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 28 (AP)An attempt by seveta; agricultural concerns. to block a seasonal rate increase charged by Southeastern railroads hauling their grain and grain products failed today when Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court refused to intercede.

title: 2 More Homers for Oh
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28 (AP)  Sadaharu Oh hit two tworun homers, his 47th and 48th of the season, as the Yomiuri Giants whipped the Hiroshima Toyo Carp, 135, tonight. Oh, who surpassed Hank Aaron's career home run record of 755 on Sept. 3, lifted his career total to 764.

title: Settlement Talks Fail in PBB Case; Michigan Trial to Resume Oct. 4
description: CADILLAC, Mich., Sept. 28 (UPI)The state's first trial stemming from the destruction, of thousands of dairy cattle and other livestock that ate feeds contaminated by PBB a few years ago will resume Oct. 4.

title: Family Money: Mortgage Help
description: WHEN Allan Smith was in the real estate business not so long ago, one of his biggest sales problems was matching up young couples in the market for a first home with mortgage payments they could afford to carry.

title: Free Night at Parr Meadows
description: Parr Meadows, the quarterhorse track in Yaphank, L.I., will remain closed tonight while its financial problems are reviewed. The track shut down last night. However, it will reopen tomorrow night with free admission as an incentive to customers.

title: 3 Real Estate Men, 6 Companies Guilty In PriceFixing Case
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Six prominent real estate concerns and three executives were convicted today on Federal charges of price fixing in what the prosecution said was a historic case.

title: Soviet Rejects Plea for Rehabilitation of Bukharin
description: The Soviet Communist Party has re portedly rejected a request for the posthumous exoneration of Nikolai I. Buldiarin, the Bolshevik revolutionary, who was ousted from the ruling Politburo in 1929 for his opposition to Stalin's policies and was executed in 1938.

title: MENINGITIS VACCINE PROVES EFFECTIVE
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 28A vaccine to prevent one form of epidemic bacterial meningitis has proved effective in preventing the infection in all age groups, Federal scientists at the National Institute of Health reported today.

title: Accounts
description: Metropolitan Chicago Fiat Dealers to Carl Ally Inc.

title: Princeton to Build Energy Lab
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27 (AP)Princeton University has announced plans to build a $3 million energy research laboratory and to open the facility next fall. The 30,000squarefoot building is to house test equipment for experimental combustion engines and solar and plasma energy projects. Construction is expected to begin this fall. Officials said yesterday that the bulk of the funds would come from General Motors, the Allied Chemical Company and several major oil companies.

title: Former Councilman Sentenced
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (UPI)A former Philadelphia City Councilman, Isadore Bellis, 57 years old, was sentenced today, to two to seven years in prison for his conviction on charges of misconduct while in office. Richard Wickersham, a visiting judge from Dauphin County, also fined Mr. Bellis $9,000, the amount he was convicted of accept in return for awarding a $180,000 contract at Philadelphia International Airport.

title: Ohioan Convicted in Hostage Case
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP)A man who took two persons hostage at gunpoint and gave up only after President Carter agreed to talk with him was found guilty today of charges stemming from the March siege. The convicted man, Cory Moore, 26 years old, of Warrensville Heights, had been the only defense witness. The jury in Cuyahoga County Commons Pleas Court found him guilty of two kidnapping charges and one each of robbery and extortion.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: The U.N. Today
School Results
description: GIRLS FIELD HOCKEY

title: Big Board Members Disciplined Over Bets
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the fining and disciplining of three members for accepting bets on sporting events while working on the exchange floor. The disciplinary action completes an investigation begun last Anril.

title: Byrne Nominee Says the Brother Of Senator Sought Quid Pro Quo
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29  Gerald Weinstein, whose appointment to an Atlantic County judgeship was blocked this year and last when Senator Joseph L. McGahn of Atlantic City invoked senatorial courtesy,  said today that the Senator's brother had suggested something return for support of the appointment. what is in it for us? Mr. Weinstein quoted the brother, Patrick T. McGahn Jr., as asking during a breakfast at the Atlantic City Club on April 4, 1976. What do we get out of it?

title: Paying the Nuclear Piper II
description: WASHINGTONWhen an experimental nuclear facility at Elk River, Minn., was dismantled, the cost ran to $6.2 millionalthough the plant had cost only about $6 million to build. At Oyster Creek, N. J., a nuclear plant could be safely dismantled for an estimated $100 million; but that's more than 150 percent of the original $65 million cost.

title: DOW AVERAGE GAINS AS VOLUME RISES
description: The stock market, propelled by signs that the economy has picked up steam, moved higher yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Friday
description: The dance season in Brooklyn begins tonight at 8, with the opening of Brooklyn College's new season. The first program is a mixed bill: the Linda Dance Company, featuring the choreography of its artistic director, Yvonne Hicks, whose ballets reflect her Danish training in the Bournonville style; and the adagio team of Luis Villaneuva and Kuniko Narai, known for the acrobatic onearm lifts that are a specialty of Soviet ballet. Tonight's program in Whitman Hall will be repeated tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday afternoon at 3. Tickets are $4, available at the box office (or call 8591180 for reservations). From Manhattan take the Seventh Avenue IRT's No. 3 express to the end of the line. For information about the rest of the series, which will include the Dance Theatre of Harlem, the Los Angeles Ballet and the New York debut of the Royal Ballet of Flanders, call 7803291.

title: Pat Oleszkn at the Kitchen
description: Pat Oleszko will present a mixedmedia performance called the Clothe Your Eyes (Revue) at 8:30 P.M. tonight and tomorrow in the Kitchen Center for Video and Music, 484 Broome Street. She uses films, song, story and dance and draws on vaudeville and burlesque. Admission is $3.50. Information: 9253615.

title: Dollar Again at Low in Switzerland
description: The dollar fell to a new low against the Swiss franc in foreignexchange trading in Zurich yesterday and also lost value against the Japanese yen and other foreign currencies, The Associated Press reported.

title: JESSE JAMES, 72, DIRECTED TEXAS TREASURY SINCE 1941
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 29 (AP) Jesse James, the Texas official with a train robber's name who had served as State Treasurer since 1941, died at a hospital today after a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: Orioles Beat Tigers, Stay In Race, 63
description: BALTIAIORE, Sept. 29 (AP) Eddie Murray drove in four runs and Ken Singleton had a two run homer as the Orioles defeated the Detroit Tigers tonight by 63. The victory was No. 18 for Rudy May.

title: Beamel Appoints Archivist
description: Eugene Bockman director of both the Municipal Reference and Research Center and the Municipal Archives and Record Center since 1975, was appointed yesterday to Mayor Beame as Commissioner of the new Department of Records and Information. His salary will be $30, 000 a year. The department was created last July to place under one agency responsibility for records management, archive preservation, research and informational services.

title: BRIAN BREWER BLADES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Dr. Brian Brewer Blades, an internationally known thoracic surgeon, died yesterday at George Washington University hospital after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The New York Times/Tyrone Dukes

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Gains L.I. Women's Golf Final
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 29Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, who won the Metropolitan title at Metropolis earlier this year, today moved into the final round of the Long Island women's golf championship at The Creek Club.

title: China, Japan Sign Trademark Pact
description: PEKING, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  China and Japan signed today an agreement on protecting each others trademarks. The New China News Agency said the agreement stipulated that the two countries woud give each other mostfavorednation treatment when trademarks are registered.

title: American Fashion Designers Honored In a Theatrical Evening of Coty Awards

title: Film Festival: Good Buddies
description: MOST OF THE PRINCIPALS in Jonathan Demme's "Handle With Care" have citizens' band radios, and these people careen into one another's lives just as easily as they interrupt one another's broadcasts. The visual editing of the film is very much like its sound editing, so scenes become short and fragmented, like loosely overheard snatches of conversation. The radio conceit also provides the film with a unifying notion, because each character has a real name and a C.B. "handle," with separate identities for each. One of the characters even spells this out, though the point is hard to miss: "Everybody in this town is somebody they're not supposed to be.""Handle With Care," which was originally released in other cities under the title "Citizen's Band," is so clever that its seams show. Mr. Demme's tidiest parallels and most purposeful compositions are such attention-getters that the film has a hard time turning serious for its finale, in which characters who couldn't communicate directly come to understand one another at long last.The film will be shown tonight at 9:30 in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center as part of the New York Film Festival and again tomorrow at 3 P.M.Even though the film's energy and its intelligence are at war with each other all the way through, their incompatibility is eminently engrossing. The structure is thoughtful, and some of the imagery is so calculated it seems chilly; on the other hand, the film's surface is flippant and funny, full of talented performers in whimsical, open-ended roles. It's easy to see why "Handle With Care" was too scrambled to succeed during its first go-round. It's even easier to see that the film deserves a second chance.The characters include a bigamous trucker (Charles Napier) and his two wives (Marcia Rodd and Ann Wedgworth), who first meet on a bus in one of the funniest sequences here; after comparing family photos and then weeping their eyes out, the wives begin to wonder if they aren't related. Another triangle includes two competitive brothers (Paul Le Mat and Bruce McGill) and their mutual sweetheart (Candy Clark), who is fored, by an otherwise-graceful screenplay, to tell one of them "I'm a woman, not a trophy."There is also a squealy, roly-poly hooker who operates out of a mobile home, and who laments "Now with that gol-darned 55-mile limit, nobody's got time for nothin.'" There is the brothers' drunken old dad, who is forever threatening to eat the family dog. And there are a wide variety of crackpots on the airwaves, who become Mr. Le Mat's prey after he decides to do his civic duty by eliminating all improperly used C.B.'s with a baseball bat.The plot may operate on the premise that wackiness is its own reward, but Mr. Demme's direction is decidedly, almost jarringly, on the serious side. When Mr. Le Mat and Miss Clark, whose affair has been on and off the rocks, finally get back together, Mr. Demme manages to make a high school setting look like a chapel, shooting up at the couple and letting a light bulb shower them with beatific rays. The composition has a life of its own, almost more life than it needs, and it has very little bearing on the characters as we've come to know them. But it's a stunning composition just the same.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The Senate moved tantalizingly close to a compromise this afternoon in the sixdayold filibuster over natural gas pricing, only to reach a new stalemate that dragged on through the evening with no sign of resolution.

title: David Hare: A Painter Of the Human Psyche
description: THE DAVID HARE exhibition opening today at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, brings us an artist once very much in the forefront of the New York School, but only occasionally seen here in recent years. The show is not a retrospective, however. It concentrates entirely on the work of the last 10 yearson the paintings, sculpture and drawings in which Mr. Hare evokes the legendary figure of Cronus, the god of Greek mythology who, after dethroning his own father, was himself dethroned by Zeus, his son.

title: How to Get There
description: To get to Dingmans Ferry base from the George Washington Bridge, a trip through New Jersey of a little more than an hour and a half, take Interstate 80 to Route 15 north, then Route 206 north and Route 521 north to the parking lot just across Dingmans Bridge on the Pennsylvania side of the river. (The Kittatinny office is actually further inland, but the company dispatches vans with canoecarrying trailers to the bridge.) To get to the Kittatinny base two miles above Berryville take Interstate 84 to Port Jervis and then Route 97 north, which runs along the river to the base. Kittatinny's phone number is (717) 8282700 or 8282338.

title: At the Movies

But that's all rightyou don't have to marry your actors. My inclination is to see what they will bring ??? scene on their own, to see how moves me, and then to take it from there and work with them. From the beginning, Jane had strong ideas, most of them quite good, so she needed very little help from me. And I didn't need to talk to Vanessa Redgrave at all. Those two girls just do.

title: Saturday
description: The Hartford Ballet, usually spinning from tour, to tour, will stop in Purchase on Saturday for It performance at the State University of New York campus theie. Totally professional and unusually interesting. is how Clive Barnes, dance critic of The New York Times, has described the fiveyearold troupe, which will include several works choreographed by its artistic director, Michael Uthoff, formerly a dancer with the Jose Limon Company and the Joffrey Ballet. Tickets are $3 (a little less for faculty members and students)  on sale at the humanities building auditorium. From New York City, take the Hutchinson River Parkway to Lincoln Avenue (Exit 28); turn left, go to the second light and turn right, and you'll see the campus entrance. For information about future programs  music, dance, theater and a weekly film series  call (914) 2535575. A little bit of everything. That's how the North Jersey Cultural Ccucil describes the Bergen County concert series, which begins its ninth season Saturday night at 8:30 at Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack. Opening night's headliner is Virgil Fox, the popular organ virtuoso. Tickets range from $6 to $8; call (201) 4445750 for reservations and information about coming attractions, which include the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Odetta, Peter Nero and the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble. Subscriptions, as well as individual tickets, are available. The Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium is off Route 4.

Owned by Salvatore Sorrentino, a native of Silo Paolo who worked for seven years at the Brazilian Coffee House on 46th Street, and the chef, Mario Cristovan, who was born in Lisbon and, until recently operated the Sugar Loaf restaurant in Southampton, L.I., this bright, airy place, with its light, fresh and entertaining food, has all the earmarks of a winner.

title: Books: Feel for the Essential
description: WILLIAM MAXWELL was an editor at The New Yorker for more than 40 years; he has also been one of the magazine's most distinguished contributors, judging fr.m thEe 12 short stories, nine of which first appeared there. He has arranged the stories so that urban settings alternate with the smalltown milieu of the fictional Draperville, Ill. The stories were written over 35 years and are not presented chronologically, giving the effect of two regions of the author's mind, which neither conflict nor interrelate but rather, like the right and left hemispheres of the brain, perform an ongoing ruminative dialogue.

title: Georgia Death Penalty Upset
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP)The State Board of Pardons and Paroles today struck down the death penalty imposed on a convicted slayer, Charles Harris Hill, and commuted the term to 99 years in prison. The trial judge in the case, Superior Court Judge Clarence Peeler, asked the board in a letter to commute the sentence to life in prison, saying he would have imposed a life sentence but interpreted applicable law to mean that a judge must impose a death sentence when Iat is recommended by a jury.

title: Situation in Cambodia Excellent,  Its Leader Says at Peking Banquet

title: Dance: Leap Into Fantasy
description: THE FRESHNESS of Remy Charlip's choreographic return to New York is no doubt because of his sustained activity as designer, dancer, author, actor and director in the seven years since his last concert in New York. He has retained the innocence of the 60's, when everything was possible, no rules were too sacred to break, and traditional dance practice was transformed into the liberated climate that the youngest of today's choreographers enjoys. The quietly triumphal return took place Wednesday evening at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: News Summary
description: An agreement is impossible on the Middle East, President Carter said, without adequate Palestinian representation at a peace conference. At his televised news conference, the President said that a Middle East peace was of vital national interest to the United States, but he avoided taking sides between Arabs and Israelis on such questions as who should represent the Palestinians at Geneva. He said however, that the Palestine Liberation Organization represented substantial part of the three million Palestinians and again offered to meet snd work with the P.L.O. if it accepted Security Council Resolution 242, which recognized Israel's existence as a state [Page A1, Column 3.]

title: Books of TheTimes
description: TOWARD THE END or her long, calm, careful and intelligent account of last year's Presidential campaign. Elizabeth Drew is clearly fed up. She had been following these people around since January, the election loomed, and what had they said? When. Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter spoke at all to serious issues, it was to heave misleading statistics, like medicine balls, at each other. Between them, they couldn't have inspired bacilli to connive at anthrax. No wonder that a skeptical public had as much trouble as the CBS computer in picking a winner. Only a lobotomized people,  she says, would not be affected by 13 years of assassinations, urban riots, a hated war and the greatest scandal in our political

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29President Carter is faced with a difficult political and human question of whether to veto or acquiesce in legislation that would deny veterans benefits to almost all veterans of the Vietnam era who have sought to erase lessthanhonorable discharges from their records this year.

description: The Soviet Union orbited yesterday a new space station, Salyut 6, in what could be a prelude to a manned in ssion in time for the 20th anniversary of the birth of the space era, the flight of Sputnik 1 on Oct. 4. 1957.

description: The International Longshoremen's Association went ahead yesterday with plans for a dockworkers strike at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow amid a flurry of moves aimed at forestalling a walkout.

title: Article 2  No Title

It said preliminary indications were that the problem was in the torpedo tube mechanism used in the underwater firing, and not in the missile itself.

title: The Screen: Pacino Skids
description: WHAT CAN YOU SAY about a guy who, when he's in bed with a new girl for the first time, and strokes her sleeping head, and finds that a large hank of her hair comes out in his hand, simply shrugs and replaces the hair, patting it back in place as if it were self-sticking?Very little, I'm afraid. You might think that the next morning the fellow, using some discretion, would ask the young woman how she's feeling, or maybe whether or not she's been in chemotherapy or if she's recently come into contact with a lead-based paint. Is her ceiling flaking?Not Bobby Deerfield, the title character in this big, expensive, ultimately ridiculous movie that appears to have been constructed to be a "Love Story" on wheels."Bobby Deerfield" may turn out to be the year's most cynical movie made by people who know better, including Sydney Pollack, the director, and Alvin Sargent, who wrote the screenplay. It stars Al Pacino as a self-centered, remarkably uninteresting (and uninterested) international race-car driver and Marthe Keller as his doomed, soon-to-be-bald beloved, a girl whose manic behavior is supposed to indicate a love of life but suggests rather more strongly that she's in desperate need of a Valium.The film, which opened yesterday at the Baronet and Coronet Theaters, starts with a good deal of promise, that is, with a mystery: In a race in France one of Bobby's colleagues is killed when his car, a duplicate of the one Bobby is driving, cracks up for no apparent reason. Bobby, a boy from Newark who's hit the big time (French mistress, apartment in Paris, product-endorsements), sets out to find out what's wrong with the car. His hunt takes him to a fancy Swiss clinic where he interviews a man who has survived the crash. He also, unfortunately, meets Miss Keller, also a patient and someone clearly to be avoided even if you don't mind loose hair.The would-be tragedy of their love story, which is supposed to resurrect Bobby's humanity, is neutralized by just about everything the film's makers think they have going for them, incluing the scenery (the Swiss Alps, Bellagio, Florence, Paris) to which the lovers gravitate as if they were travel agents. It's so relentlessly picturesque you may come out of the theater and walk directly to 42d Street to become reoriented.There's also something off-putting about the lovers Mr. Pacino and Miss Keller play, sometimes coyly and sometimes with such intensity you can't believe they're in a movie of such essential fatuousness. They rattle around the script, saying its lines as if they were touching bases, but they succeed in creating not a single moment of genuine pathos.It says something about the sort of film "Bobby Deerfield" is that the audience is inclined to applaud at the sight of hot-air balloons. It also says something about me, I suppose, that this is the first film about automobile racing I've ever seen when I wished the movie would get back to the track. I'd put up with just about anything to avoid watching Mr. Pacino doing an imitation of Mae West and hearing Miss Keller, who is supposed to be Italian describe things as "bowing" when she means boring and blab on endlessly about death."Bobby Deerfield," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some vulgar language and partial nudity that will be seen by those members of the audience who are not taking a snooze.

title: Cerebral Palsy Unit Praised by State Aide
description: New York State's Acting Commissioner of Mental Retardation confirmed yesterday that he had entrusted his own retarded daughter to a rehabilitative residential program operated by United Cerebral Palsy.

title: Yale Gets Strindberg Done by Serban
description: Andrei Serban is a man not afraid of silences. The young director whose productions of Fragments of a Trilogy,  Agamemnon,  and The Cherry Orchard brought an invigorating element into recent New York theatre seasons, is now an associate director of the Yale Repertory Theatre and has directed August Strjndberg's The Ghost Sonata for the company. The play is opening tonight in New Haven as the first play in the repertory theater's 12th season.

title: Catalans Win Back SellRule Symbol,  AnOld Institution
description: MADRID, Sept. 29After months of negotiations, the Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez tonight restored to the northeastern region of Catalonia its ancient institution of selfgovernment known as the generalitat, which was suppressed by the victorious Franco forces at the end of the civil war in 1939.

title: Music: Ax Performs Elegant Mozart
description: ANDREW DAVIS, the young British conductor, had his turn with the New York Philharmonic last night. Is it coincidence that there was a big Berlioz work on the program? It was England that sparked the Berlioz renaissance after the war, and Colin Davis soon became one of the world's most prominent exponents of the French composer. Perhaps Mr. Davis plans to follow in his footsteps.

title: An Injustice Is Born
description: Congress is about to write another chapter in the sad sale of national abortion policy. An appropriations conference committee is moving toward a vote to restrict Federal funding for Medicaid abortions during the next fiscal year. Although the final words of the law are still being debated, the limits on future funding are already apparent. Federal aid for operations to terminate pregnancy might be allowed for victims of rape incest, and will almost certainly be allowed in cases disease that could endanger the life of the mother or the health of the fetus. Rut that's all.

description: MANILA, Sept. 29A United States mission on its way to Hanoi to recover the remains of 22 Americans who died in Vietnam arrived here today.

title: Oswald as Imagined by ABCTV
description: A muddling of fact and fiction takes a giant tumble forward this weekend as ABC presents The Trial of Lee Harvey Oswald. This is the television film that asks the question: If Oswald had lived to stand trial for the 1963 assassination of John F. Kennedy, would he have been found guilty or innocence Further, if guilty, did he act alone or as part of a conspiracy? To help the audience decide on these facts,  the production adopts the fiction that Oswald was not killed by Jack Ruby. That astonishing scene, carried live on national television, is now reduced to Oswald being momentarily startled by Photographer's flashbulb.

title: Don't Sell Jimmy Short
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29You can agree or disagree with President Carter on policy, but some personal things you can't deny. In good times and bad, he faces his critics with more regularity, more precision of fact and language, and more patience and courtesy than any other President of the television age. So it would be bad idea to sell Jimmy short.

title: Sunday
description: New Brighton, on Staten Island's North Shore, is the destination of two o'clock Sunday afternoon walking tour sponsored by the Staten Island Museumthe first of four architectural tours of the borough scheduled for October. All outings will be led by Barnett Shepherd, an architectural historian on the museum's staff. When the tours began three years ago, with only 10 participants, Mr. Shepherd was the sole guide, But now that more than 100 people are likely to show up, he gives opening and closing lectures, and a staff of trained guides helps him lead small groups to various sites. Th.; threehour tour of New Brighton,

title: BONN CHECKING A REPORT OF ANTISEMITIC INCIDENT
description: BONN, West Germany, Sept. 29 (AP)West German defense authorities are investigating reports that a group of army lieutenants staged a mock burning of Jews last February at the Armed Forces University in Munich.

title: Notes on People
description: Travis McNeil,  a retired Air Force major general who is executive director of the Confederate Air Force,  said the group had called off plans to reenact the atomic bombing of Hiroshima at its annual air show. A reenactment last year, at Harlingen, Tex., included a simulated mushroomshaped ctoua. It set off an international fallout of protest in Japan and elsewhere. The performance was to have been repeated Oct. 69 at this year's air show, but General McNeil said that a meeting with officials in Washngton had changed the plans. He said that the Confederate Air Force, made up of 2, 000 enthusiasts of flying who like to restore World War II aircraft, is dependent on the Government for some support. There are some goodies handed out in the form of supplies and equipment,  he said. They could have made it difficult for us. The people in Washington explained to us that we could upset the balance of an ongoing or future negotiations with some of our allies.

title: Lower 77 Grain Crop Expected for Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Soviet Union's 1977 grain crop will be smaller than expected, the Agriculture Department said today.

description: AMERICA and Jimmy Webb, who shared a concert at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday, fought against one of the worst sound systems that this reviewer has ever heard. Levels went up and down without rhyme or reason, there was much distortion, and the band backing America sounded hopelessly muddled.

title: U.S. Extends Deportation Deadline For Religious Sect in West Texas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Immigration and Naturalization Service today extended from Saturday to Jan. 31 the deporation of 500 Mennonites who came to Texas from Canada and Mexico and bought land in hopes of establishing a religious community A spokesman for the Federal agency, Vern Jervis, said that the decision to postpone the deadline was made because of hardships the Mennonites would suffer if they were forced to leave west Texas before they could harvest this year's crops and pay back loans they took out to finance them.

title: BANCO DE PONCE OFFICIAL FACES S.E.C. CIVIL CHARGE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission alleged yesterday that the New York operations manager of a Puerto Ricobased bank violated Federal securities laws in stock dealings using insider information.

title: Archer Hoping for a Day in the Shade
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 29 The phone rang, hardly making a noise today in the carpeted, soundproofed exclusive club known as the Giants locker room.

title: Seurat: A Master Of Elusive Perceptions
description: THERE ARE ARTISTS who make up in power, originality and conviction in the absolute certainty of what they attempt, and in the absolute beauty of what they achieve what they may lack in variety and versatility. Georges Seurat is one of them. His career was distressingly shorthe lived from 18591891, and he actually died before reaching his 32d birthdayyet his art remains for us one of the most sublime and most complete achievements of an extraordinary period, the PostImpressionist era that shaped the very way we think about pictorial genius.

title: Giants and Jets Face Another Tough Weekend
description: The New England Patriots are favored by two touchdowns over the Jets for their game at Shea Stadium on Sunday, and the Giants will also be underdogs against the Falcons in Atlanta. The latter game will be televised in the metropolitan area oy Channel 2 at 1 P.M. Channel 4 will show Cincinnati at San Diego, beginning at 4 P.M. Previews of all games follow with wonlost records in parentheses.

title: Byrne Campaign Aides Challenge G.O.P.'s Finance
description: The managers of Governor Byrne's reelection campaign believe that their Republican opponents may be trying to circumvent the publicfinancing law and have filed a formal complaint, which became the subject yesterday of a hearing before the Election Law Enforcement Commission in Jersey City. The gubernatorial candidates must raise and spend $40, 000 before they begin qualifying for the $2 in public funds for each $1 in private contributions that they receive. There is also a $1.5 million limit on how much can be spent to help elect each candidate. Private contributions are limited to $600 a person.

title: President Links National Security To Decision on Helms Indictment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29President Carter suggested today that national security considerations would play a role in any decision on whether to prosecute Richard Helms should the Justice Department seek to indict the former Director of Central Intelligence.

title: MINORITY BUSINESS EFFORT DEFENDED BY GOVERNMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Awarding 10 percent of Government public works contracts to minorityoperated businesses is not discrimination, the Justice Department has argued in urging Federal court to drop a new challenge to affirmative action programs.

title: Soybean Futures Prices Rise With Rain Reports
description: Rainy weather over some parts of the Middle West and forecasts of more rain over the weekend led to a substantial increase in soybean prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The nearby November delivery closed at $5.44 a bushel. uo 15 cents.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: CAGLIARI, ItalyFranco Zurlo, Italy, knocked out Paddy Maguire, Ireland, rounds, and retained European bantamweight crown.

title: Photography's Broadest Views
description: O N MAY 29, 1906, a photographer named George Laurence lifted a 46pound camera 800 feet in the air over San Francisco by means of a kite, then tripped ts shutter with an electrical impulse. A device in the camera swept its lens across a 90degree path, exposing theview below to a large negative. The result was a magnificent panorama of San Francisco in ruins after its famous earthquake and fire.

title: Rangers Top Flyers As Heaslip Stars, 42
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (AP) Mark Heaslip's shorthanded goal 29 seconds into the second period put New York ahead to stay as the Rangers defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 42, in a National Hockey League exhibition game tonight.

title: House Role on Canal Pact Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Carter Administration defended before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today  its decision to transfer American property in, the Panama Canal Zone to Panama by treaty, bypassing the House of Representatives.

title: RESULTS
description: FIRST$6, 000, pace, mile.

title: A Pianist Marks 50th Year of His U.S. Debut
description: There have been at least four important dates in Robert Goldsands life: March 17, 1911, when he was born in Vienna; the day in November 1921 (he doesn't remember exactly which any more) when he made his first public appearance as a pianist; March 21, 1927, when he made a highly successful American debut in New York's Town Hall, and the year 1939, when the Nazis made Vienna intolerable for him and he fled to this country.

title: Belmont Racing
$14, 442 For a Wine
description: LONDON, Sept. 29  Good wine seems to be getting more expensive all the time. Today, for instance, Addy Bassin of Washington paid the equivalent of $14, 442 for one bottle of Chateau Lafite, vintage 1806. In May 1976 a similar bottle fetched only $14, 200 in New Orleans.

title: Atorn Device for L.l. Gaining in Congress
description: House and Senate conferees yesterday approved the construction on Long Island of a 400billionelectronvolt accelerator that, according to its proponents, would restore the primacy of the United States in the research of atomic particles.

title: Blumenthal Plans Trip Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Secretary of the Treasury Michael Blumenthal announced today that he would make a sevennation trip through the Middle East and Europe from Oct. 21 through Nov. 2. He said at a news conference he would go to Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iran, Israel, Italy and West Germany for discussions on financial and economic matters.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: SLAIN GEM DEALER BURIED: Mourners surging to view the coffin of Pinchos Jarbslawicz as it was borne from funeral parlor in Brooklyn yesterday. A grand Jury began an investigation into the murder. Page D13.

title: New York's Black Leaders Now Focusing on Economics, Not Protest
description: James H. Dowdy, a former plumbing and heating contractor, spends much of his working time these days with bankers or studying demographics, budgets and innercity economics.

description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Oct.

title: Albert (Papa) French, Banjoist And Leader of a Dixieland Band
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 (AP) Albert (Papa) French, banjostrumming leader of the Tuxedo Jazz Band and a wellknown New Orleans musician, died Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Art: Shows by Untermyer and Women
description: ONE OF THE great secret sights of New York in the 1950's and 60's was the private collection of Judge Irwin Untermyer. Devoted to the decorative arts between 1200 and 1789, it was not a specialized collection. Nor had it set fast once and for all. Judge Untermyer bought what most took his fancy in a wide variety of fields, and he went on buying almost until the day of his death in 1973.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: D RESSED LIKE an Egg,  JoAnne Akalaitis's enthralling excursion into the life and art of Colette, returns tomorrow night for limited run of weekends at the Public Theater. This is the first in a season of plays from the Mabou Mines experimental theater company. It will be joined Oct. 5 by Samuel Beckett's The Lost Ones,  starring David Warrilow, and will be followed in November by Lee Breuer's The Shaggy Dog Animation. The company wil be in guest residence at Joseph Papp's theater until January.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Broadway
description: LISTEN NOW about a man with a mission. He is Norman Twain, and he is an unbuttoned type, who commutes each week between New York and Los Angeles, and all the time thinks about The Goodbye People. This is the play by Herb Gardner that lasted only seven performances when it was on Broadway in 1968, but which, Mr. Twain insists, is absolutely touching, uplifting and marvelous. Therefore, he wants bring it back. Mr. Twain says that he loves Mr. Gardner, but that Mr. Gardner should not have directed Goodbye People in 1968 because playwrights should not direct their own plays. (Yes, he knows that Edward Albee directed a revival Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? and that it was wonderful.) Mr. Twain has a director in mind, but the only thing he is saying now is that he will open The Goodbye People on Jan. 25 at the Westwood Playhouse in Los Angeles, which he leases, and then try to have it on Broadway before April 1.

title: Leading Indicators Index: How Useful or Reliable?
description: The Government's report yesterday on the most recent performance of its index of leading economic indicators should deflate the nervous tension that was building up in some circles over this year's summer slowdown in general economic activity. And it should also down grade the importance that some analysts have attached to the index as a precursor of what is ahead in business,

title: Butler Assumes Lead In British Masters
description: WORKSOP, England, Sept. 29 AP) Peter Butler of England started his round early in the day and birdied three holes in a row before strong winds swept over the Lindrick Golf Club course. He went on to shoot twounderpar 69, which gave him the lead by three strokes today after the second round of the British Masters golf tournament.

title: I.L.A. AIDE CONVICTED OF PAYOFF CHARGES
description: Fred R. Field Jr., a leader of the International Longshoremen's Association, was convicted yesterday of obtaining $124, 500 in cash payments from the United Brands Company to maintain labour peace and assure the unloading of banana shipments during dock strikes.

title: Laos and Vietnam Strengthening Their Military Ties
description: VIENTIANE, Laos: Sept. 29 (Reuters)Laos had given a new stimulus to its close relationship with Vietnam by sending military delegation to Hanoi.

title: Issue of Jamming On West's Agenda For Belgrade Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Carter Administration and the nine members of the European Economic Community intend to ask the Soviet Bloc countries to stop jamming Western radio broadcasts at the European security conference beginning next week in Belgrade.
